business.full_address:
10250 Baltimore Ave
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Boardwalk Fresh Burgers & Fries

reviews.text:
Totally need to bump this place rating... 

It took me a LONGGG time to park as we were going to Buffalo Wings and Beer across the street...well the wait was 15-20 and after walking for 3+ hours at Ikea..you just want to go and eat! so instead of parking again we found Boardwalk Burgers! 

1) Reason for the bump...the black bean burgers!!!! not on the menu as of yet but once they get the new menus they will be there!... 

Ok...2) reason...the 35y/o guy that took my order was kind of cute...hehehe...but I could had gone HUNGRY if he did not mention the black bean buuuurrrrgggeeerrr. I gave up on the salad...lettuce, tomatoes, onions and cheese (their version of garden salad...yuck)...that's not a salad! suggestion: more veggiessss!! (cucumbers, beets, tiny corn, shredded carrots...blue cheese crumbled....ok, now I'm going off topic!) 

3) sauteed mushroom topping...I thought THAT made my bun fall apart...was pretty a great addition! and my black bean burger with a side of chipotle sauce...and of course, mustard! was awesome...for a black bean burger! I hate those other cardboard veggie burgers or the overcooked Boca burgers...this was a winner! 

4)...not really a plus...but the fries were PLENTY but needed salt. Or have I gotten used to the over salted fries everywhere! 

We mentioned FG...the feared Five Guys...but you guys got veggie burgers... woooo hoooo!

It's no Five Guys and I mean that as a criticism of Boardwalk...  

It's a brand new location, where Moe's used to be.

They do the same thing really... but the burger patties were dry, not juicy, and they offer whole wheat rolls but mine crumbled apart from being dry, then I had to eat the rest with a fork.  Lots more topping and sauces...The jalopenas were jarred while the ones at Five Guys are fresh.

Fries were too crisp/cooked for my liking... 

So, one and done for me.
I agree with review #1. Burger average but fries were decent. Highlight was the orange Fanta on tap! My roll broke apart as well.

business.full_address:
1215 Amsterdam Ave
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Che' Bella Pizza

reviews.text: I really love this place even though the pizza isn't the best I've ever had.  The staff is so, so friendly and the price is good.  I have only ordered the veggie slice of pizza, and it's good enough to back week after week.
Good for pizza by the slice. I like the BBQ chicken pizza.
Staff is friendly. Wished they delivered east of Morningside Park. Great for events at the Columbia schools because they always deliver on time.

Stopped in today after a meeting at TC.  Tried the BBQ Chicken slice and garlic knots.  For just over 5.00, it was mroe than a meal worth.  The pizza slice was healthy, the toppings generous, and the BBQ sauce just a tad spicy--the way I like it.  The garlic knots were definately the highlight of the meal, though.  Five chunks of greasy, garlic filled goodness for a dollar beats a bag of chips any day.  One caveat--be ready to invest in toothpaste, gums, or mints before you have a conversation afterward!

Just ordered Margarita pizza w/ ricotta, greek salad, & meatball parmigiana. I want to say the pizza is delicious here! I have been look for a neighborhood pizza spot  that delivers since I moved from Brooklyn & I'm glad to say I found it. The pizza here is delicious, it comes fast & hot. The meatball parmigiana could use some work, but still tasty. And trust the other reviews about the garlic knots, they are delicious...
has that same generic flavor you find in california.

Che' Bella pizza is a very good slice place, with a thick sauce and excellent crust on its pizza.  It's real New York pizza, with a friendly staff; delivery usually takes 30 minutes or less in their delivery area.  I've been eating here for eight years, and I don't feel the need to go anywhere else in the neighborhood to get a slice.

GARLIC KNOTS!! At 5/$1 I can't think of any reason not to swing by for some... except maybe my heart will stop, I will reek of garlic , and my fingers shall be covered in butter.. meh. It's worth it. 

The rest of the food is alright. Nothing to go out of the way for, but it's a reliable spot.

Very underated Pizza. Delicious. Best toppings. Try the Grandma or BBQ chicken Pizza! Great experience every time. Also, the roasted chicken is pretty good. Can't go wrong here for a delicious and reasonable lunch with a lovable and friendly Mexican staff cooking right in front of you. Get to know them. They will always give you the best slice and throw extra cheese for free. 

Trust me, I have been here approx 50 times.

Pizza was pretty good. Crust was AMAZING. Super crispy, and stayed crispy and warm throughout my meal. My friend and I ordered two slices and garlic knots and have more than enough. 

-The Bella Chicken pizza (which I believe is the chicken parmigiana pizza that people previously mentioned) wasn't as good as I expected.
-The sausage and pepperoni were very tasty in all its salty, meaty, oily glory
-Cheese pizza was meh. Not served on NY-style crust, but really big
Above average pizza for way above average prices. Try their Gyro sandwich. That's a definite winner. They also take credit cards, which is rather refreshing for a NY pizza joint.
Service here is consistently quick and friendly, keeps me coming back.

I lived up the block from Che Bella for a year and came here fairly often. I think that they have best toppings in morningside. I've tried their taco pizza and several others; all very filling. But my favorite was the grandma slice! It's like a sicillian,

Would I eat here if I didn't live directly above it? Probably not. Is it worth putting down $10 every now and then for a totally solid BBQ pizza that l can get two grad-student style meals out of? 

Absolutely. 

A reliable, decent, affordable, and friendly weekday option around Columbia (of course, as other reviewers have pointed out, that's not saying much).

It's a greasy pizza joint - it's exactly what it should be!  Cool guys behind the counter, quick service, typical fare.  Love the margharita pizza's, chicken parm sandwiches, and the sausage and peppers.  Chicken parm dinner is enough for 2 plus leftovers!  Seating can be a little tight at times, but people move in and out pretty quickly.

This place is great. I have called to change things on my order any times and they always accommodate my order. Also, the pizza arrives quickly, and still hot! My personal favorite is the Buffalo Chicken Pizza. This is basically hot wings on a pizza, add ranch and beer and you're in heaven. These guys don't mess around when it comes to pizza.

Fast food for the hungry Columbia student.  Food is decent, price is affordable, and reasonably close by. I'd give it a 3.5 stars because the garlic knots make me happy :) 

Recommendations
*Garlic Knots
*Calzone with fillings
Great Bruschetta slice. Not sure about the Greek; didn't seem necessary to me but maybe it's good.

It's close to me and fairly cheap.

I thought I ordered a cheese pizza.  However, after tasting it, I think they just melted a few handfuls of salt on there.

Buffalo wings aren't too bad.  Friendly service.

That's all.

The pizza is alright here... dough kinda resembles cardboard, but that's ok. After making it past the part with the toppings, I feel like I can afford to skip the crust. Che Bella has a tendency to make pizza-topping chicken too dry, but when they get it right the Buffalo Chicken Pizza is pretty good (10x more true when drunk). Something kinda works when you add slightly spicy fried breaded chicken on top of cheese and bread. Margarita pizza is good too if you're not in the mood for too much fat.
While I'm not too adventurous with my pizza flavors (except for the buffalo chicken slice here), some of my friends enjoy the lasagna and taco pizzas. They both taste gross to me, but I'm not big on lasagna and tacos so whadda I know? When I've bought pizza pies for others, the eggplant, as well as the peppers+onions have been hits. Da Vinci panini is alright, even though it leaves me uncomfortably bloated afterward, but maybe that's a more of a personal problem than Che Bella's fault.

Anyway, the only reason I eat at Che Bella's regularly because they accept pizza pie orders on their website. For really good pizza, you gotta get out of this neighborhood.

I have had better pizza in other places in the city. The hot entrees are a great deal. The food is seasoned well and they are HUGE portions for the price. Skip it for pizza but definitely consider ordering hot entrees(especially the chicken and eggplant parm)

Reliable delivery. Friendly service. Good pizza. They take large orders. There isn't much more to say about this place. By the slice they are a bit expensive, but if you need to order a bunch of pies and don't want to eat that Famiglia crap, this is the place to use.
They don't deliver to four blocks away.

Perhaps this wasn't the best place to go for a NY style pizza virgin like me. (I know, I know. Where have I been all my life?) My friends from Jersey winced when I told them that I'd paid 4.50 for a slice of pizza and a bottle of water. For that reason, I detract one star. 

The pizza itself though, is wonderful! I had mushroom broccoli, and I mean to tell you, that broccoli was cooked to absolute tender perfection. 

The atmosphere is nice enough. It seems just a little commercialized, though.

I really like the slices here.  Koronet has larger slices, and they deliver farther, but I think the sauce and toppings are better here.  Definitely don't grab a slice to stay during the summer, it's a sauna with no AC.
Randomly discovered this place with a friend during our college days. I am quite shocked that more people haven't raved about their MARGHERITA PIZZA - which is the best I'd ever had.

Scale of 1-10 (multiple visits):
6 Food
n/a Service  (just ever had delivery)
n/a Atmosphere
6 Value
paninis are gross.  definitely processed meats.

I shudder just thinking about this place. The pizza is pretty low quality because they have to make it pretty quick for the demand. 

However, this place is cheap and fast. You can dash in and out in under 5 minutes. Can't beat that :-)

This is our go-to neighborhood pizza place.  Not cheap, but the quality is consistently good.  Better than Koronet, but more expensive too (and it seems their prices went up recently.)  We get the Bella Chicken frequently and have never been let down by it.  It isn't Grimaldi's, but if you live on the UWS it is a lot quicker to get to, and the line is almost nonexistent.  Garlic knots are dirt cheap and tasty; the calzones not so much.  No one in Brooklyn is going to make a pilgrimage to come here, but if you're in the neighborhood it is worth a visit.

I went here for lunch the first 2 weeks of grad school at Columbia. I'm a creature of habit so yes, I literally went for 2 weeks straight. Its a pizza place, but I got the small greek salad with grilled chicken. The "small" greek salad is pretty big. It comes with a ton of lettuce, olives, cucumbers, onions, grape leaves (yay!), tomatoes, and feta cheese. The salad also comes with a huge pita that they toast for you. 

And its only $3.95! With chicken its an extra $3.00. They give you two giant pieces of healthy grilled chicken breast, not greasy or gross. So $6.95 total. A great deal for an awesome salad. 

The pizza and other stuff always looked great too, but I stuck to my salad :-P

Not crazy about this place. I have tried it twice, and I always end my meals feeling unsatisfied. The Stromboli (which they spell as stramboli) are pretty small and not that great. I ordered two bc it was supposed to be dinner for me and the guy, but when we saw them we were let down. He immediately left to go get a sandwich at Olive Tree Deli. I understand they are only 5.50, but hey it's dinner time and if you specialize in pizza, but not include size variety? This actually leads into my next point that this is an Italian and Greek restaurant...not fusion, they just offer both...it seems like they couldn't make a decision. 

Finally, delivery experience was weird. I ordered online and submitted pay with credit card, but they didn't get my info online. I immediately called, despite not being prompted, and they ran it over the phone, just want you to be aware of this because I personally don't like when delivery people take my card imprint. Also, when the delivery man came evidently he chose not to call my cell even though my number was on the order, and so my boyfriend who was sick could not answer our apartment line, I guess after a while, he finally decided to pick up our apartment line and get the food, and the delivery guy started yelling at him. Not great....

The pizza was good, and I'm kinda picky with pizza, but I liked it. I went there while they were closing though (10 pm?) so they really didn't have much choice.

Don't get the baklava! It was soft and soggy. I didn't even take a bite becuase I was grossed out by how soft the filo on top was.
Average. I had a cheese slice on one occasion and chili/rice on another. Both were adequate, satisfied cravings.

One of the employees tried to overcharge me for my pizza. He then tried to shortchange the next guy in line. This may just be a rare occurrence, but you still need to be wary of the possibility of this happening again. 

Food isn't bad.

I used to frequent this little joint for a slice or two on a weekly basis when I attended Teachers College, and I maintained that it ranked among the top slices of pizza in the city.

But after visiting it a few weeks ago, I was surprised at how disappointed I was, especially given my fond memories of the pizza. It wasn't bad at all, it was just...salty. Too salty. I'm going to mark that visit up to an aberration, and this review will represent all my good visits here.

Fantastic pizza. Always piping hot, a little greasy but dab it with napkins, and quick service. If you come during lunch hours, you might feel a little rushed, and you might have to squeeze next to strangers to sit, but it's worth it. I always ordered the sausage and pepperoni. Perfect blend of crust, cheese, sauce and toppings, and it folds likes a New York Pizza should: crack the spine of the crust and fold the ends together. Not too floppy, not too stiff. Might be a little salty, or it may have been just that one visit. I guess I'll have to go back to redetermine! If you're in the Columbia University area and have a hankering for pizza, this is the place to go.

This pizza place is close to the Columbia campus, is that reason enough to increase the prices every couple months? I think not!!


~BBQ chicken pizza is great, but i'm not sure if it is worth the 4.25!
Good food, good people and a fair price. A hit with students and locals alike.

Stopped in after a late night class & got a gyro (which is my new favorite food).  It was delish.  I got the platter, which comes with fries, and I couldn't finish it all.  Looks like I have dinner for tomorrow...

Great pizza and good prices. The guy who owns the place actually works there sometimes and once gave me a free salad because he forgot to ring it up. Only downside is how early they close. Sometimes you just need a slice after drinking a little too much.

$2.75 for a plain slice?   Are you kiddin' me? Are YOU kiddin' me?   Che Bella, you must be joking... because I will laugh every time I pass your place.


Pizza was OK, so I'll give them 2 stars, but seriously, 2.75 is just ridiculous for a slice of cheese.  NYTimes just ran an article about how in midtown a few pizza places are competing on price and sell slides for 75 CENTS!!  

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/31/nyregion/in-manhattan-pizza-war-price-of-slice-keeps-dropping.html?pagewanted=all

And honestly, Two Bros Pizza (75 cent pizza place mentioned in the article) makes a comparable slice to Che Bella.

Just ate the worst food Ive had in New York at Che Bella.  I got the falafel plate per Varun's recommendation and it was aweful.  The falafel balls were too large so while the outside was crusty dark brown, the inside was raw and  doughy.  This was served with undercooked french fries and some type of sauce that I'm guessing was supposed to be tahini?  It was really just flour mixed with water, it tasted like paste and made it hard to open my mouth.  

This place would be a one star but their pizza is edible.  I got a large margherita when I was craving some fast pizza and it was both fast and large.  Way too salty.  Won't be back.

Solid pizza and Italian fare. Pretty quick to get your food, and very much like Ameena said, the people are super nice and friendly.

Stop in if you're hankering for some pizza on the Harlem side of Columbia!

I can't explain why, but I'm slightly obsessed with Che' Bella's salad pizza.  It's an actual salad on top of a garlicky crust and it's really good.  

The restaurant itself is nothing special, but there are almost always open tables upstairs where you can sit to eat.

i ordered a pizza for take out.  I always worry about just getting it by the slice becasue I am not sure how long the slice has been there and it is always better fresh out of the oven.  It claimed fresh ingredients and it tasted pretty fresh.  Quick service, and pizza was good, it satisfied the pizza craving i had.   Will prob order a pizza again sometime.  This time i just ordered pepperoni and sausage, maybe next time I will try one of their specialties.

So I have eaten the pizza and other meals at Che' Bella. The slices of pizza are pretty good, especially the chicken parmigiana slices and I like to get a side salad to go with it. The prices are a bit high for what you get though.

I haven't enjoyed the other food that I have ordered at Che' Bella and wouldn't recommend it as much as I would the pizza.

Che Bella is one of the best quick food options around Columbia, in my opinion. Now, let's be real, that's not saying much (I agree entirely with the captive demographic theory presented by a former reviewer--if you're located around Columbia, people will eat your food whether it's good or not), but it is important to note. 

I've only had the pizza, but I've always been pretty impressed by it. The sauce is especially delicious. The line system here is a little strange in terms of ordering then waiting for your food to reach the cash register, but it usually does go pretty quickly as long as you listen for what you ordered to be called.

Great pizza--in fact, it has changed my life it's so amazing! We have always ordered online and picked it up. Try the large pepperoni. They have tables inside but most folks get slices or pies to go. I have not tried any other food than the pizza.

Decent pizza, lots of variety, updated "A" rating. 

Good Baklava and great Nantucket Nectar selection (Orange, Guava, Pineapple-yum!).

It's close to school and good in a pinch.  Still looking for that perfect NY slice without having to trek for miles.

I'm not sure if I didn't receive the proper amount of change or if the pizza here is just ridiculously expensive. I had a chicken and tomato slice and the guy charged me $5.50!!!

It was definitely good but not worth that price. Service is nice in store but they are extremely slow when it comes to deliveries.

Due to peer pressure I ended up eating a few slices at this place.  And if you have any smarts about you at all, you will also only go under duress.

Because, the food is mediocre.  Plain and simple.  But it's supposed to be.  It's college-type pizza (greasy and strangely tasteless at times).  Or just really salty.

But I guess as others have already mentioned, it's (relatively) cheap and fast.

Tiny little Italian restaurant tucked in the back streets of Amsterdam. Very tasty foccacia sandwich. Their salad dressing is a little lacking, and nothing compared to the neighbors, but their pizza and dough is amazing. 

Bonus, their credit card minimum is $5, a very reasonable price for lunch.

I wound up ordering pies for a birthday party.  We got two types.

The Pizza Bianca was delicious.  The ricotta was generously scooped on top.  I'm impressed that they managed to make a pizza which was all cheese without making it greasy.  The crust was decent.  Nothing hugely special of note about it.

We also got the Mucho Meat Pizza for the birthday boy (pescatarian myself), and if meat, meat and more meat is your passion, welcome to Nirvana.  It was a stuffed pie, crust on top and on bottom.  Even the birthday boy himself, Mr. MEAAAAT, had only one slice.  Maybe a slice and a half.  Incredibly rich, very filling.  I mean hey... lotta meat in there.

I'm excited to try more of their stuff.  What I've already seen shows potential.

Two stars for decent price, eat in area, and good drink selection.  But really, their pizza is sub par.  It's close to my apartment which is why I ever go, but I wouldn't go out of my to eat there.  Koronet is worth the extra 10 block walk.

Che Bella puts the "fast" in fast food, but what makes it special is some of the less-chosen menu items. 

Sure, the pizza here is good, but not necessarily exceptional (you'd have to venture a little further for that). I like the Sicilian slices; they're nice and chewy just the way they should be. 

What's REALLY fantastic however is the falafel sandwich. They'll fry a hefty amount of falafel in front of you, layer on fresh tomatoes and lettuce, put on white sauce, and wrap it, hot and fresh, in a pita. My recommendation is to ask for extra sauce, then dig in and enjoy!

business.full_address:
660 Plainsboro Rd
Ste 2
Plainsboro, NJ 08536
business.name: Silk Cut II

reviews.text: Horrible experience. I asked for two inches off + layers and Kim, my hair stylist, ended up chopping off over six inches of hair and barely layered my hair at all. I'm very unhappy with this experience.
Decent haircuts at a decent price.

I had very long hair before and went to Silk Cut for a short classic bob.  My hair dresser didn't even ask me what I wanted to do when he sat me down in his station.  He just started brushing my hair and got a pair of scissors.  He either heard me talking to the lady at the front desk about what I wanted to do or he could just had an idea in his mind about a style.  I believe his name was Andy.  It is funny that other reviewers described that their hair dresser seemed angry.  I think I must have met the same guy.  My hair dresser seemed very unhappy and he smelled of cigarette factury.  I asked him to cut my hair  a little shorter and he snapped "NO".  I wondered if he spoke to me that way because English isn't his native language.  I too from another country but I know better when talking to customers.  I was really nervous the whole time sitting in the chair, but surprisingly the result was very nice.  

I gave him a good tip eventhough I did not enjoy his attitude.  I figured most hair dressers like waiters and waitresses, they rely on tips.  I won't tell you that it is right to put up with negative attitudes, but I really think Silk cut has good hair dressers they are just not very good at English and customer service, so hint the grunting and teeth grinning.  


I had my hair cut over three months ago, and I plan to go back next week to have it shape up.  I cross my fingers that this time I'll get better customer service.

I give 3 stars for my first experience.  Stay tune for my 2nd review next week.
I got a haircut which is decent.  Since my husband purchased a VIP card, the haircut costs me $21+tip.  I should say for that price the service is OK.  I think I will go back.

Avoid this place - for the price, you would expect reasonable service, but the "hair dressers" here are unprofessional and inconsistent.  You might as well hit up a Supercuts or Great Clips.

I have never heard a hair dresser blame a bad hair cut on the way your "hair grows" - give me a break.  If you were talented, you could make it work if you could.  Last time I checked, if a customer asks you to fix something bc they are unhappy with how things turned out, you would do your best to fix it since they are PAYING for your services.  Refusing the customer's request is simply a sign of arrogant behavior for services that are mediocre - by defending your work and saying that you know what's best only means to me that you are disillusioned about your own talent.

P.S.  I can happily say that it was not MY hair that was ruined.

business.full_address:
4034 Walnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Lee's Hoagie House

reviews.text:
it wasn't as amazing as other reviews made it sound.
they could have put more meat in my breakfast sandwich.
and the milkshakes aren't worth $5.
i would go back but i wont be dying to go back.

My 8 year old's first hoagie.  She was born in Norristown but we moved to Arizona when she was a baby.  So we came back for a visit and stopped for a hoagie and Herr's chips.  Of course we topped it off with TastyKake Butterscotch Krimpets!  And of course all of our hoagies were too big to finish :-)

This place is right close by, next  to the Bridge Theatre and the Rotunda. The first time I came here I got the "Special" It was so damn good, that its the only thing I ever get when I go here. I could try something else I guess, but I feel no need to do so.

When it grew cold outside on Tuesday I had a serious hunger that could only be quenched by a huge sandwich. So I braved the wind and a 5 block out of the way walk to Primo's only to find that they were closed. Rather than shed a tear I went with the next best option - a semi out of the way train ride and a long walk back home after hitting up Lee's. Good thing it was worth it!

I remember Lee's back when it used to be in Wynnewood and how it always hooked up a monster sized Hoagie. It was a sad day when that one closed and I was hoping for the West Philly one to at least provide sandwiches that were equal in size. So when I found out that they did and also hooked up all kinds of chicken wings, finger foods, and breakfast sandwiches - Needles to say happy days were here again. I picked up a monster sized turkey Hoagie and loaded it up with hot/sweet peppers, lettuce, tomato, and sharp provolone and t sent me to flavor country. It's good to get reacquainted with old places!

Oh how I miss this place. I used to live across the street and would run over in flip flops in the dead of winter at 8 at night when it was just as easy to order delivery. The hoagies are big and awesome (the chicken cutlet and the roast beef rock a lot) and the milkshakes remain some of the best I've ever had. A fair amount of chips by the bag and soda too. 

Greatest thing ever was the 100$-for-120$-worth-of-food-meal-plan, I always enjoyed getting something and saying 'put it on my tab.' Maybe a little too much.

Great for those Penn undergrads who are unfamiliar with the city/afraid of going further West than 40th St., but for anyone else it's just not worth the trip. 

The prices are expensive and the food is mediocre. I've been there a few times and each time I had to shell out close to ten bucks for a sandwich and drink. If you're willing to spend that much money you might as well go down the street to Koch's and get a real hoagie.

On the plus side, service is quick and friendly. The upper deck seating is also kind of cool but the decor and furniture are really, really cheesy.

You will find contentment at Lee's.  I took my coworker there the other day without much expectations.  I ordered a "half" special and birch beer which was plenty of food.  

Just as a note.., there's a surcharge if you charge under $10 on your credit card.

Depending on what you get off the menu, Lee's could prove to be a decent experience.  The milkshakes are yummy, but are not worth $5. Sometimes they can be stingy with the meat.  I prefer Koch's deli, plus their customer service is a lot better.

1st Hoagie Exp  beef cheesesteak. Delicious, recommend!
2nd Hoagie Exp: imperial with oil, loved it will be back
3rd Hoagie Ex:p: flounder hoagie with tarter sauce, fish was cooked well, but they forgot pickles. Overall, not impressed.  4.95 black/white shake was good, but not worth the price. 

Like them on facebook, $2 off discount. I'm hoagie out....3 times in a week I'll be back next month.

I'm amazed that this place has a 4 star rating....

Came here today and paid $10 for a "giant" size sandwich. Not only does the sandwich have barely any meat on it, but I could probably get a better sandwich down the street at Fresh Grocer, or subway for that matter. Roast beef and turkey is dry and tastes old, and for a place that calls themselves a deli to only have 3 types of cheeses is a little ridiculous. 

Maybe I should try it for the egg sandwiches....

There are three or four locations of these hoagie delis. Prior to my discovery of Primo, this was my favorite.

Lee's delivers, and has a bit more welcoming interior than Primo. Also, they do grill hoagies, something that much of the competition won't. I always find their italian hoagies to be the best, though I do believe they have a special outside the variety. 

Lee's goes out of their way to create that tube of sandwich that looks grotesque to some, and appealing to others. I can understand why they're so popular to Philly, because the quality is there, and they have plenty of options. If you're ordering for the office, or just looking to bring some home, a good place to know, that's all over the city.

The sandwiches aren't bad enough to refuse, but they aren't good enough to yearn for when outside of the city.  Furthermore, they seem a tad pricey for what you get.  They deliver to the Penn area, which is nice, and they have a cooler full of diverse drinks(Arizona Green Tea) to complement your meal.  

My recommendation is the chicken tender w/ cheese hoagie.

You can't go wrong ordering anything off the menu here. I order takeout at least twice a month. My wife always gets the chicken cheesesteak and says it's the best in the city (she's not easy to please, trust me). I either get the double supreme, which is a double meat cheesesteak, or the turkey. Both are phenomenal, depending on your mood. The reason being, for the cheesesteaks they don't cut the meat up in a million pieces, thus losing its juices and naturally the taste. For their cold cuts, they have a special Lee's oil that puts the taste above anything I've ever had. Their bread is fresh too but really it's the oil. They have a great staff, so no issue with incorrect orders or misplaced items like you have at some places. Sure their prices are a little bit on the high side, but you pay for quality, right? Otherwise go to the carts.

Quick and dirty fast food, except not so quick...  for some reason everything took a million years to get to us (how does a strawberry milkshake made from vanilla ice cream + strawberry flavoring/coloring take anywhere over 5 minutes??).  Bread was meh and the strawberry milkshake was nothing impressive.  My lukewarm double cheeseburger was also nothing impressive and apparently the steak sandwich was good, but I only had a bite.  Acceptable food for what it is, but I've had better for cheaper.  And Lee's would get the 2 stars of "meh"ness from me, except:

- Super friendly service dude
- Moderately clean space
- Also decently clean bathroom!
- Aaaand the whole place smelled heavily like french fry oil.  So delectable.

Lee's Hoagies has been in University City for many years. Good meats, good ingredients, good service, good portions, great selections and a good location. But the bread sucks! They don't get it, the bread is the most important ingredient!!!!!

From a guy who's folks have owned three delis/sandwich shops... Lee's makes a good hoagie. 

I had no idea what this place was until my coworker took me here, and I had the "special" which is various cold cuts. the "1/2" is more than enough for a normal person. Prices are not bad at all for what you get. 

I would definitely eat here again, especially since they deliver!

Afterward we went to see a movie at the Bridge Theater just next door, practically.

What a terrible idea, "let's order out from Lees". We will not repeat that mistake again. I should have seen it coming.  The woman taking my order was indifferent, bored????.  The food: the fries were soggy, cold and tasteless. The peppers on the side must have escaped during delivery.  The hoagie/cheese steak rolls are lacking in flavor.  They are too soft.  Not  great rolls. Delivery: it took over an hour to deliver.  Guess why? The delivery guy is on a bicycle.  Hello Lees!!!!

I got "the Jewish", a hoagie with four types of meat, cheese with veggies and olive oil. Within about 5 minutes it was ready; i was impressed.The taste was average for hoagies, not great, but not terrible. In retrospect I, having been a bar mitzvah boy and an attendee of plenty a seder don't really associate the taste of the hoagie with anything distinctly Jewish I've tasted. I'm sure my great grandpa, Ben from whom I bear namesake would eat it though. The friend I went with likes this place.

 It seemed like an okay place to go before watching a Penn basketball game. The Philadelphia Big Five took up a large space on the cloth covered wall among the photos of insipidly displayed Penn Sororities and Fraternities. In the upper deck of the restaurant with the tables, I felt like they were tackily trying too hard to attract Penn students by trying to  embellish their atmosphere with pictures of what appeared to a tennis team from the nineties cornily posing in a library with serious faces and cold fish attitudes. Privacy may have been an issue for the hundreds of names and faces posted on the falls, when what I mainly wanted was a solid hoagie. Yeah they're your business if you like bland hoagies but it seemed apropos of a my high school's graduation photo collection.

As I left, I asked the guy at the counter if he would wrap up the remainder of my sandwich, he politely did and wished us farewell.
Lee's is great, but Primo's is better. But when I can't get a primo's hoagie, i'll goto lees to satisfy my hoagie craving. Their hoagies are HUGE and fairly priced
Just try the tuna hoagie.  Don't think, just order it and plan on not eating anything else for a while.
Very very decent vegetarian hoagie. The best onion rings I've had. Crunchy and tasty, not too greasy.

No ifs, ands, or buts, Lee's Hoagie House is most definitely a Philly staple.  Now while I usually go for a plain jane tuna hoagie with american cheese, I love that Lee's has plenty of other options on the menu no matter what your craving happens to be.  They serve breakfast all day, and their breakfast sandwiches can be made on a kaiser, long roll, or wrap.  Lee's is great at any time of day!
Damn good hoagies!  Love the hot pepper oil.

I'm fond of Lee's, it was the first cheese steak place I went to in Philly.  At first I frequented the one in Abington, when I moved to University City I quickly looked for the nearest Lee's.  I'm happy to say it's only a few blocks away.  This Lee's is a little slower and once lost my order, but the food is just as delicious!!  Defitiely try it at least once.  I always order the small cheese steak with onions, the large is about as big as your torso, so just know that before ordering.  Also, there's a fountain machione upstairs, so if you eat in don't buy a bottle.

The only reason this place deserves four stars instead of five is the bread... the bread is ok, but let's face it, Sarcones basically has that market cornered.

I should probably branch out at some point because even though I've been there like five times in the past few weeks I can only tell you about one sandwich: the Italian imperial.  I'm pretty sure if you mashed the bread down so it was just the actual bread, no air (appetizing, I know, but work with me, here), the overall proportion of meat/cheese to bread would be two to one.  Even as it is the amount of meat and cheese is just absurd.  It's amazing that they can physically cram that many fillings into a single roll.  Top it off with the delicious little oil/vinegar/herb combo and there's really no REASON to branch out to the rest of the menu.  Which is why I haven't.

Lee's doesn't mess around. Huge hoagies at a reasonable price. They also have an excellent soda selection. They are pretty busy so order on the web and have it delivered by the guy with the bike helmet from 1983. He is a legend.

I'm giving it a 5 because the workers there are awesome!!! 
The milkshakes are really delicious too!!
this place is ok.  Solid breakfast sandwich I guess.   $4.25 for a bacon, egg, and cheese just doesn't cut it in this neighborhood when you got food trucks pumping them out for $3 just blocks away.

I have been going to this place since I was a kid. My family used to stop by for hoagies after a day trip tubing down the Delaware River. It was a stop that we all looked forward to. Now, many years later, stopping by Lee's is always a treat.

Their milkshakes are still as thick and delicious as ever. The hoagies are still fresh and made to order. They even have a few new things on the menu like Chicken Parm sandwiches and mozzarella sticks. 

If you are ever in the mood for a good old fashioned milkshake and a classic hoagie. Lee's is your spot.

3.5 stars. Bring the half stars yelp. If the Mayans can invent negative numbers,  you can surely calculate 1/2 stars.

Lee's Hoagie House is a nice sandwich shop just off of the main part of Penn's campus. The servers there take and process your order pretty fast. What's really nice is that if you eat in, they will bring your order upstairs when its ready. So you can grab a seat and settle down without having to pay first. 

The sandwiches are pretty decent, though frankly I usually just get the Italian imperial. A half sandwich is usually enough to assuage my hunger. It's chock full of  Italian meats, peppers, onions on a decent roll/bun. About the only thing I wouldn't mind having on it is mortadella, but that's not cheap to get so I can understand why they wouldn't have it.

Overall its a good alternative to some of the other joints that Penn students tend to frequent. You can enjoy your meal without the din of the underquakers and you aren't sandwiched between people you don't know.

The only thing I would say is that some of the Italian meats, while decent , could be better. I like Primo's meats(Thumann) better.

Good service, good value for the buck. That's a win-win in my book.

This place is a heavyweight contender for king of the Philly sandwich shops.The woman who took my order over the phone was a sweetheart--I would tip her if I could. The bike dude was swift as the wind. 

Onto the food. These hoagies are titanic. A half is pretty satisfying. A half of a half will cut it if you're a chick (or a wuss). Even a true beast will have trouble ripping into a giant. 

I've always got the Imperial. It's so perfect that I haven't bothered branching out. The sandwiches are loaded with meat and cheese and the extra toppings are quality. The pickles are real pickles, if you know what that means. Like the other reviewer said, the oil takes this thing to the next level.

The price is decent. The value is awesome. If I'm craving a sandwich, this is the place to hit.

I went there one day when I was telecommuting because of some business that kept me out of the office. It was great. I had the best cheese hoagie of my life. I'd be back more often if I didn't worry about my waistline, for sure.

LOVE the hoagies. I think I've only really ever gotten the Italian, but it is by far the best italian hoagie I have ever had. 

The bread is huge (and generally nice and soft without falling apart too much), and the balance of the meat inside is almost always perfect. Oil, mayo, peppers (on the side). Delicious!

About $12 for a full sized hoagie, and I'm talking a 2 footer stuffed to the brim with good deli meat! Haven't tried anything else here. Usually, I get it delivered, although I've gotten take out once or twice as well. The inside is a typical deli place, but the cashier was very friendly. 

A MUST TRY!
Tuna hoagies are great!!! veggies are always fresh.. sandwiches are huge.. i can never finish them  excellent customer service and delivery is fast!!

I admit it. I partake in some greasy goodness now and again.

I like this place. The right amount of meats/cheese/veggies/mayo/oil. It's fairly reasonable, quick and absorbs alcohol nicely. Most people there are nice.
don't get a wrap. was expecting more in my buffalo chicken wrap for 7.50...

If there was one thing I loved about the weather turning warm again, it was that it becomes Lee's milkshakes season for me!  My only regret is not discovering them sooner.  Their chocolate shake is made with chocolate ice cream, not just syrup thrown into

I had ordered from Lee's once before, but it was totally the wrong thing to get (some non-hoagie food). When I had the chance to order from them again, I went for their Italian hoagie and a black and white milkshake. Let me say that it was perhaps one of the most satisfying deli sandwiches I have ever had, and certainly the best milkshake I have ever had. My mouth waters just thinking about it. Just as a warning: their milkshakes are ridiculously filling, and a "half" hoagie is about 12" long. You can probably get two meals out of one.
Delivery is prompt as always.
The only reason Lee's doesn't get 5 stars is because it cost me about $14 for just those two items (but that's their delivery charge's [$2] fault).

2.5 stars.  Lee's was a Penn spot when kids got tired of the trucks or wanted heavy ass bread to help sop up some of the pre-gaming.  I didn't like it much.  Average meat, crummy bread, way more expensive than the trucks.  Just go to Bui's for a steak if it's open.

I used to order lots of hoagies for events from here.
Long, short, big tall... the best was always the Italian, and it makes my mouth water to think of the oil, salt, pepper, hot and sweet peppers, and more all packed into their grinders.

Tasty milkshakes, but those you should get in person (they're not the same delivered, oddly enough).

I've never eaten here. I've always had my food to go!

Lee's makes gigantic hoagies. Seriously, their typical "half" size hoagie is much bigger than a foot long from subway, and tastier too. My current favorite is the Italian with everything, but they're all pretty good, and full of high quality meat and cheese. Combine their big subs with their very reasonable prices, and you've got a winner. 

Lee's is also one of the fastest places I know of to get a sub. The staff is quick and friendly. They have takeout and deliver, and there's seating inside as well, which never seems to be crowded if you want to eat in. 

After Koch's, Lee's is probably my next favorite place to get a sandwich in University City.

we grabbed sandwiches one night from Lees hoagie house coz its so close to home bt we never got around to eating from there. They were real filling and tasty, with just the right amount of sauce that gave it the taste without making it soggy. You can get delivery but its nice to walk up and buy since its just around the block.
I'll take Lee's over Primos any day.  I've been known to attend meetings solely because Lee's hoagies are being served.  All I ever eat is their Italian, but its awesome, so why change?

This hoagie I bought was...mediocre.
I got the "special" which has 4 different types of meat and provolone cheese (+ the shebang -- lettuce, tomato, mayo etc). The meat is sort of like a combination of 4 different kinds of lunch meat -- oscar mayer lunch meat status. lol.

In fact, here is a good comparison: If I were to compare this place to a standard, commercialized, staple of mass production-ness place like Subway, I'd say go to Subway. Hands down. Here's why.

1) Subway offers a variety of rolls - from honey wheat to plain to jalapeno cheddar (or something fancy sounding like that) but here, they only offer one type of bread.
2) Subway offers the option of toasting it for you, here they don't. 
3) Subway offers more variety -- veggies,  condiments, etc.

In terms of the price though, this place comes on top. This place's portions are huge. For $6, you'd get a whole foot long sub. Wait, is that also the case at Subway? If so, the only aspect this place comes on top on may be ...

its ability to underwhelm its consumer. =T

business.full_address:
1221 Amsterdam Ave
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Ye Olde Cleaning Shop

reviews.text:
STAY AWAY --  LATE, DIRTY, MISSING!   This used to be a reliable cleaner until the past year.  Zero star rating. 

Ex: several suits smelled like horrible B.O. after they "cleaned it"... But my clothes weren't smelly or that dirty to begin with. I had to get it cleaned again (and they tried to charge me again) but it still has a residual funky smell.  

Ex: they lost some very nice clothes of mine worth hundreds of dollars. The staff refuse to give me the owner's name and number, they keep saying he'll call me but it's been months and I haven't gotten a hold of him. 
From what I read in the other reviews, other customers also are experiencing the same problem..I wonder if it's only because they're disorganized or if they are stealing my designer clothes to resell.

I tried this dry cleaning place because it was conveniently located down the street from my dorm.  It's kind of hit or miss.  My peacoat came back smelling like some weird chemical.  One of my friends brought several items to be dry-cleaned - they lost her cardigan shell and denied any wrongdoing.  Others have deemed it to be an average dry-cleaners.  You can take your chances but not with an expensive item...
I have only had jeans hemmed here, and the gentleman that did them was great.  I have seen a different woman working at the tailor's seat when I've walked by recently, so I can't vouch for her.

This place has a great location near Colubmia University, offers a 10% student discount, and the staff is very friendly.  If you're a student, it's great.  If not, good luck.  The hours do not accomodate for us working folk, and the delivery service is never on time.  I've waited a week for my dry cleaning to arrive.

I've lived in new york my entire life I've never paid so much for dry cleaning.  They charge you extra for stains (umm, the reason i'm even going to the dry cleaners is for the stains!).

They also said they could get the tailor's chalk off automatically and i didn't have to point it out.  Get what... they didn't.  There are way too many dry cleaners in this city to waste your money here.

Ye Olde is fine if you live in the area - they've always been on time, and they offer discounts to Columbia students. The staff is also exceptionally nice, and the cleaning/pressing quality is exactly what you'd expect from a dry cleaning service. The prices seemed a little high to me, but I'm pretty new to New York, so the prices could be normal for the area.

Please never go there. They lost a new pair of pants and starting playing stupid games to avoid paying for them. 
REPEAT NEVER GO THERE UNLESS YOU WANT TO LOOSE YOUR CLOTHES.

This place has been bought by a new owner and I'm going to take my business elsewhere. They charge more for a woman's shirt than a man's shirt; they counted a long tunic shirt as a suit coat; they counted a collarless long sleeved button down shirt as a cardigan; and then the last straw was today: they charged me for two pairs of pants and I only brought one. Too bad I lost  my neighborhood dry cleaner of 17 years! (I tried arguing with the guy and his pricing and he told me to go elsewhere!). And they discontinued the long-standing Columbia University affiliated discount.

I brought a suit jacket here that I'd gotten paint on (thanks a lot MTA) and they cleaned it up for less than ten bucks.  It took twice as long as they said it would, but with the amount of paint on the jacket I wasn't shocked or angry.  It is only the fact that they kept telling me "come back tomorrow" for about 6 straight days that keeps this from being four stars.  I thought the employees were actually quite friendly too.
Decent dry cleaning service, but I got a pair of jeans hemmed here and the hem doesn't sit flat. It's all warped and I'll have to get it re-hemmed.

These people lost my clothes. When I tried to get reimbursed I had to go into their store FIVE times. Each time the woman said "The check's on the way". When she finally realized I wasn't going to just disappear, she reached into the cash register and gave me cash. They were just trying to not have to pay for their own stupid mistake. NEVER go here.

If you like your clothes I wouldn't suggest going here. The final straw for me was when the "misplaced" a suit and dress shirt. I had ordered it rushed (next day) and the next day I showed up and they didn't have it, the lady said that I didn't order it rushed. So, I came in the next day (after having a very unsuccessful interview in a less than clean suit and shirt) and they still didn't have it. It was then when the admitted it was 'misplaced.' 2 days later they finally found it. They expected me to pay full price (including extra for rush). I told them where they could stick it.

It really is no surprise, I should have seen it coming. A few weeks before that incident they closed the store 4 hours early without any sort of indication as to why or if they would open later that day or even be open the next day. They never really did that great of a job on laundering the shirts (dry cleaning was fine). It was so easy because I went to school at SIPA, how could I NOT go there, right? Well simple, I care about my clothes. I want them to be there when I expect, and to be clean once I pick them up... Not asking too much but this place fails miserably.

Bring your clothes here at your own risk--there's a good chance you will never see them again.  A year ago this was a decent, reliable cleaner; but since then, it's plunged into the 10th level of hell.  Not only are they *regularly* 2-3 days late returning my clothes, often the staff are so disorganized that they can't find clothes their own records indicate are on the premises, so you still have to wait 1-2 days more for the ones that showed up on time.  On 2 separate occasions they lost some of my nicer items (and refused to replace them)--and even when I do get them back, almost half the time they smell of riper B.O. than when I dropped them off.  

With my best stuff missing and my "clean" stuff rank, I jokingly wondered whether this place was running some sort of racket with my stuff.  Seeing now that others have had similar experiences, I'm starting think this thesis has some merit.  But whatever the explanation, they clearly aren't doing their job and can't keep track of their volume.  It's awful.   

My advice:  avoid this place.  Go to Grace Cleaners over at 123rd & St. Nick.  They're organized and take their work much more seriously.  They're worth every second of that extra 5 minute walk.  

But whatever you do, don't go here.

I really hate this dry cleaners.  They always leave staples and safety pins in my clothing, even when I've requested they make sure not to.  I hate getting back an expensive silk blouse or cashmere sweater to find it has holes in it from their careless treatment.  The woman who works at reception can also be really curt.  Never again.

DO NOT GO HERE. Go to one of the million other dry cleaners/tailors in NYC. 

I went in with a pair of dress pants to be hemmed. Dropped them off on a Tuesday, they said come back Friday---the pants weren't done. I came back Monday--pants weren't done. 

Tuesday! The pants were done (1 week later). The stitching was loose and horrendous (one little snag and the entire hem would have come out) and they never pressed down the hem. It looked very sloppy. I asked them to re-do them. They said come back tomorrow (Wednesday). I arrived on Thursday, THEY WEREN'T DONE. 

I do not know how this place is still in business. GO ELSEWHERE.

If I were to say one nice thing: The people are pleasant

Should be called ye olde IRREPARABLY STAINS YOUR CLOTHES shop. 

I have never written a review on yelp for any store, but ye olde cleaners has inspired me to write. 

A few months ago I purchased a custom tailored shirt from downtown. It was by far the most expensive clothing purchase I have ever made (aside from a couple of suits), and as a graduate student I do not have a lot of money to throw around. I bought it specifically for upcoming interviews and was very excited to have it. My tailor told me to have it pressed before wearing it and he gave me specific instructions to tell the cleaners. I decided to go the Ye olde cleaning shop because it is close to where I live. 

So I brought the shirt and and gave them the instructions as communicated to me by the tailor. I received the pink return slip and all seemed well. I picked up the shirt a couple of days later and cheerfully brought it to my apartment to try it on. Uh oh.  There was a small but extremely noticeable dark black mark on the left front breast of the shirt. It was as if someone had taken a pen and rubbed it a few cm.. in either direction. I had that sinking feeling in my stomach because this shirt was suddenly no longer interview worthy. 

I immediately returned the cleaners and very nicely suggested to the man behind that counter, who had helped me both at drop off and pickup, that perhaps something had gone wrong in the cleaning process. I explained that it was a brand new shirt, never worn outside of my tailors shop. In fact I had taken it directly out of the tailor's box and handed it to the dry cleaners. I told him that it was a custom shirt and very important to me. 

In response, the man behind the counter hardly said a word, but rather took the shirt, examined the mark, and stated, "That's not a pen mark." Then, he ran up something in the computer, gave me a slip and somewhat harshly exclaimed, "three days." 

Now at this point I should have grabbed the shirt back and gotten out of there. Any establishment that will stain your garment, and then seem annoyed that you brought it to their attention, should be avoided. And i knew it then. but I thought that maybe they could fix the stain. Heck they are a dry cleaners right? 

So three days later I show up, and the same man tells me the shirt is "on it's way," but hasn't arrived yet. Ok. Fine. So I leave, and come back the next day. The same man searches for the shirt for a few minutes, and guess what, he can't find it. He looks bewildered. He tells me to give him my phone number and he'll call me. At this point, I'm still acting extremely polite because I really want it all to work out, as the dry cleaners is so close. Of course, hours later, I still hadn't received a call. So I call them. And this time a lady picks up and tells me she found it. Great! 

So I go down the next day to pick up the shirt, but again the guy can't find it. Pretty ridiculous. So same thing over again. I call later that evening and the woman tells me it is definitely there.The next day I go back and indeed, this time, it's there. I take it back to my apartment and check it out. Quite unhappily, the stain is still in the breast pocket, but now there's a new addition to my interview shirt: red stains all over the cuffs! 

At this point I'm quite frustrated and bring the shirt back to show them what's happened The guy hardly says a word, sort of smirks when I explain that I have to bring it to another dry cleaners to try and fix the damage they have done, and then merely offers to try and fix it again. ha! Fooled me once! 

I never received an apology, or an offer of reimbursement for another dry cleaners. The other dry cleaners I brought it to has been unable to remove the stains. Ye Olde cleaning shop stained my shirt and did so with little remorse. 

If you have any interest in your clothes, steer clear of this place.

The customer service was terrible! I would give 0 if I can. The women there were very rude to EVERY customer. The register refused to reprint the recipt for me becasue I took some closthes off and she said I gave her a lot of pain. NEVER EVER had customer service like this. DO NOT GO THERE!!! I took all my clothes back and didn't use their service at all. I heard others compalint too when I was waiting. That was terrible!

Used this place all year for dry cleaning and the tailor since it was the down the street from my dorm.  The service was very nice, they are very efficient and I've never had a problem.  In fact, I even once had to have them do a rush steaming job and they were extremely accommodating.

The woman who usually works at the register is very friendly and the tailor speaks fluent English which is very helpful.

I would give this place 0 stars if I could. I went here because it was convenient from where I lived. DO NOT GO HERE. They ruined a blazer I had dry cleaned. I am in the process of trying to get a reimbursement for the cost of the item. They are extremely unhelpful and unapologetic about what happened. If you care about your clothes avoid this place like the plague.

I had a couple of problems: 1) the person I dropped my clothes off lied to me about when they would be finished 2) when I went to pick them up, the second person was also overly optimistic about when my clothes would be ready...  That said, they were very nice and friendly, but give them AT LEAST an extra day or two to finish your clothes,

Ye Oldy - as the proprietor pronounces the name - is an adequately-priced, though very disorganized and poorly-run drycleaner business near Columbia U.  There is little to no competition in the area, which leads me to believe Ye Oldy has no incentive to do better.  Always allow at least 20-30 minutes for a pick-up.  1 out of 5 times they either do not have it as promised or have simply lost it (anything from a tie to a tablecloth), with only a mumbled explanation.  The only reason they are still in business is that there are no other drycleaners in the area.  If you want to expand your better-run dry-cleaning business, Morningside Heights could really use a competent laundry service!  Readers please note: this review is based on regular patronage over a period of 6 months -- they are simply no other options in the area, unfortunately.

Would give 0 if that was a possibility. Sent a couple shirts in for dry cleaning more than a week ago. Told to come back in 3 days. Not ready. A week later, I called and asked to have it delivered to our house. They said it would come between 8 and 9AM. Had plans today so needed to get out of the house by 10 so said that would be fine. Come 10:20...still not here. I all them and they say the earliest they can come now is 1PM. WTF? Why say you'll be here ridiculously early if you can't come till the afternoon at the earliest?

THEN, the shirts come back and SOMEHOW they've managed to crack all the buttons on the front of the shirt. They must have held the iron on them too long or something. Never had that happen before. When I brought it back to them, they replaced the buttons but used 2 different color thread! White and dark blue! 

DO NOT GO HERE. A HORRIBLE HORRIBLE PLACE!!!!

I've only been here a couple of times.  Have yet to have any kind of problem with their service itself.  Clothes go in dirty, come back clean and ready to wear.  Staff is particularly friendly and efficient!

business.full_address:
2873 Broadway
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Pinkberry

reviews.text: Wish they offered coupons because you can get gallons for what you pay for one cup of frozen yogurt - but it's soooo good.

ugh, i love pinkberry's froyo, but this place has literally no where to sit. the tiny store front is always  crammed with people and there's barely any space to move. also, the line usually goes by pretty slow. froyo deserves 5 stars tho.

After going there tonight on the tail end of a hot 90 degree NYC day, the workers behind the counter were friendly to everyone in the line (...which was out the door, of course), service moved quickly, and Arturo at the cash register STILL managed to call me "sweetheart".

Folks, please patronize this Pinkberry, if only for the kind customer service you will receive.

And they have "mini" sizes now too. HUZZAH! A mini original with blueberries might be my new obsession. Oh boy, oh boy...

GROSS!

I've heard all the buzz... "You have to try it... So good... Healthy... Amazing..." 
ALL LIES

With my curiosity peaked, I headed off on a hot evening to see what all the fuss is about. A crowd inside is a good sign. The place is so funky-cool that they only offer three flavors of Yogurt. "PinkBerry(c) or Coffee or GreenTea. That's it... No Chocolate! ... The confusion set in immediately.
And it's not the easiest process to figure out for newbies... 

So I stepped up to the register and ordered a Coffee Flavored Yogurt with one topping. I had to pick it right there! I don't know what I like until I can see the topping spread... I went with crushed Oreo, I believe they called it cookies and cream. This could be where I went wrong... but the rest is on them!
My wife went with the "PinkBerry" flavor (who knows what laboratory that came out of) with Banana and Chocolate Chips. Again we were thrown by having to know exactly what we want up front...

So we wait and watch as the yogurt technicians build all the orders. One guy pumps each cup (no cone option?) then weighs it with the precision of a Lasic Eye Surgeon. Then two young ladies add the toppings. I think they counted each chocolate chip and banana slice to ensure the correct amount was applied.

Then we tasted it. 
I didn't know what I was tasting. Was it just bland? Maybe I had it wrong... Was it was too cold... We try again... crystals of ice... no flavor... fake Oreos... My teeth froze... still no taste...
No Oreo filling (the Cream in "Cookies and Cream") the best part of an Oreo (Yes, debatable) But still... yuck!

I tossed mine after a few bites... My wife had a couple more bites in disbelief of the fact that we actually spent so much $$ on this crap

Worst $12 dollar Yogurt ever!

Expensive (as far as frozen yogurt goes) but always tasty.

And this particular location has very friendly staff!

Yay! They have a new flavor, WATERMELON, and I guess it replaced Pomegranate. Not sure if it's seasonal, and I was a bit sad because I couldn't imagine Watermelon Pinkberry tasting all that great (they HAVE had a few misses, such as this chocolate mess and coffee?). But it is DELICIOUS. It is refreshing and not all that artificial flavored. I'm not sure how long it's going on, but at the time I went, all Pinkberry with watermelon flavored yogurt was half off during two hours in the afternoon. Huzzah!

OK, so this is the kinda place the trendy set likes to visit.  Yeah, the ambiance is like THAT.   The yogurt is good and the toppings are really good too.  It's the "Starbucks" of the yogurt world.  (Remember how baffled you were to pay 5 bucks for coffee @ Starbucks?  You'll be just as baffled when you shell out 6 bucks for a small bucket of shaved ice!)  You place your order, pay a ridiculous amount of money, and stand around waiting for the "baristas" to prepare your concoction and then yell out your name.  All the while, the other patrons mill around, looking at the treats being doled out to the other lucky customers and wondering if they'll be next. Pinkberry is an experience if nothing more.  It's the rich cousin of "Tasti D'Lite."  There is nothing SPECTACULAR about it.  But will I go back?  ABSO-FRIGGIN- LUTELY!

Chocolate flavored chemicals for everyone! 
i don't actually know whats is made out of but this is Ben trying to be witty. 
Its actually not horrible yogurt, the chocolate with pieces of brownies and nuts is actually better then eating a pt of your standard ice cream. Ill have to do some research on the fat intake with the yogurt to ice cream to be certain on which is worse for you..... 
The chef in me is curious on the nutritional facts but the fat kid in me is happy it doesn't taste like cold crap in a cup. 
She seemed to enjoy the mango yogurt and i really don't care for fruity things unless its a smoothy of some sort. 

The help was a little too nice....... Like seriously the girl was at a 10 i needed her to turn down her chippiness to like a 6 or something. Wayyyyy too much. She was helpful and pleasant for like 5 seconds then a slight change in her attitude happen when she asked for a sample and i didn't want any chocolate chips on my yogurt. She must have a soft spot for them cause she asked my like 3 times. Every time i answered "no thank you, can i have bla bla bla instead" 
she replied "chocolate chips?" 

I get it, you apparently like chocolate chips, can i have my yogurt please its kinda melting there..... O_o
Over-hyped and over-priced. The coffee stuff had a weird aftertaste. I didn't even finish it.

The instant we came in the door we were greeted by this girl at the counter with her very huge smile and very impressive speech on introducing pinkberrys all wholesome delights. Sad to say she only lasted for about 5 min on being the cheerful person that she is, when we couldnt decide that very instant on what to get. She almost threw the mango sampler i asked her. lol
Anyways, we ended up taking the chocolate flavored yogurt with nuts and brownie bits - and the mango flavor with crushed crepes and fresh strawberries for a whopping $12.
Stayed there to eat, then the whole town came in so we had to leave right after checking in.

So I used to live up here and would walk by this place a lot. My boyfriend and I are Tasti-D-Lite people, but I wanted to give this place a try.  I'd read a review about it a few years back.  So one night, I convince my boyfriend that we should go here.  We will never go back.  

For starters, it's pretentious.  The whole decor pissed him off.  It didn't bother me so much except for the workers' attitudes that went along with it. 

First there is a line, with one worker ringing you up and then another line to the other worker delving out the fro-yo.  The prices are high.  A small is $5 and it is small (smaller than Tasti-D-Lite small at least).  Toppings are about $1 each.  After we got past the first line and finished paying, we went to the second line.  There they had a small sign that students get a discount.  Hmmm, that might have been more helpful if we could have seen it from the register - guess that's the scam, make you come back a second time for a discount - not going to happen.  

Ok, now we've paid, but the pretentiousness continues.  The person serving up the fro-yo pours some in a cup, and then uses a small scale to weigh it.  Give me a break!  (1) You're wasting time people are waiting for their ice cream; (2) unless you're charging us by the ounce, I think eyeballing it is good enough.  It's like, they want to make sure that you don't get more than an ounce of a small.  More likely, they only have one size cup and want to differentiate between small, mediums and larges.  Either way, don't weight my f*(&)(*& ice cream.  

I hope I've stressed how this whole 2 line process, which includes a machine in the back that prints up your order for the second person and then the whole thing getting weighed, takes time.  More time than getting frozen yogurt should take.  Tasti-D-Lite, with their one person doing everything is much more efficient.  

How does the stuff taste?  It wasn't bad, but not really special either.  My boyfriend did not like it, but I think he was swallowing the whole experience with the ice cream.  

Moral: Back to tasti-d-lite for us.
Nice spot for a Pinkberry

I love Pinkberry, but this location is significantly smaller than others and understaffed -- also, they don't have some of the toppings that they do at other locations.

None-the-less it's still great and I'll be back again and again.

How to eat at Pinkberry: 

1. Get a medium. They rig it so that the small with two toppings is as much as the medium with three, so just get the big one.

2. Get the original flavor. Pinkberry fro-yo tastes like unflavored Greek yogurt, i.e. sour. Would you eat unsweetened coffee-flavored or green tea-flavored Greek yogurt? No? Then don't order it here. I'm not sure why they have it, except that the colors are kind of pretty.

3. Get some kind of sweet item, to balance out the sourness of the yogurt. I like white chocolate chips, but the mini-mochis are also great.

4. Get two other different-colored toppings (I like blackberries and kiwi). Trust me, it looks prettier, and Pinkberry is largely about the aesthetic experience. 

5. Eat it fast, son, because if you wait too long, it'll melt into a $6 puddle of sour milk. But if you catch it at just the right stage of partial meltedness, you'll experience sweet-sour-milky-fruity bliss.

I have to pretend that Pinkberry does not exist in order to not be upset that it's not in my life anymore.  It's the other Crackberry.  Would have given 5 stars but it's so damn expensive.

Even still, I need that soury-sweet explosion in my mouth.  Carob chips.  Blackberries.  I'm going to cry.

Hate the Green Tea flavor, but love the Coffee.  Maybe that's because I grew up eating Dannon coffee yogurt and it tastes the same except colder and more solid.

I miss you, Pinkberry.  I miss seeing my name on a label stuck to the side of my cup.  I miss that little scale you weigh yourself on which makes me feel like a crazy person on a diet.  I miss your ridiculous, useless, pop-art merchandise, your shellacked pebbly floors. 

I just wish we could go back to the way things were.

This particular Morningside Heights locale has a super duper friendly staff.  The line gets long and hairy and often flows out the door, and they handle it efficiently, and with a smile to boot.  Not so easy with some of the rancid Colombia students I've seen here (no offense to non-rancid Colombia students, of course)

Alas, some of my favorite flavors have gone to the wayside.  Green Tea?  Coconut?  I just tried the Watermelon flavor, and it tasted nothing like watermelon - just a generic fruit like taste.  The Pomegranate is OK.  

One good new thing - you now get all the toppings you want for a flat rate,  rather than paying per topping.  Gluttony made easy - always a good thing.  Still a bit pricey though.  

I think my love affair with Pinkberry has slowly fizzled out over time.  While we used to be hot and heavy, particularly in the Green Tea days, it has now degraded into random quickies which, while enjoyable, are just not that memorable.  Maybe the new peanut butter flavor will re-ignite some of those old flames?

It's frozen yogurt! The chocolate is amazingly, surprisingly delicious.

The place is a little too cramped, and the tables are not clean enough. The staff is friendly, though.
I would give it two more stars if it weren't so expensive to get fro yo with toppings.  Besides that, this location is never that crowded despite it's small setting.

No surprise that greek-style yogurt tastes pretty darn good when it's frozen.  Pinkberry offers some yummy toppings too, especially the truly fresh fruit (e.g., kiwi, blackberry, pineapple, pomegranate seeds!!!).

Healthy yogurt, healthy portions, healthy toppings and ... not so healthy prices.  Toppings, which I consider essential to the Pinkberry experience, can really add up.  Plan on dropping about $6 for medium yogurt with choice of 3 toppings.

I'm addicted to this stuff - just not the prices.  As they say, you pay for what you get, which in this case is premium frozen yogurt and fresh, high-quality toppings.  Delicious way to treat yourself for (insert anything here).  Pinkberry is also a little out of the ordinary, making it a good option for out of towners looking for a quick and memorable snack.
I wish I could be a jaded hipster and talk about how overrated and overpriced this fro-yo is, but the fact is, I watch bad TV, listen to pop music and LOVE me some Pinkberry.

Tried it for the first time this weekend. Vile vile vile stuff. 

Did I mention how vile it is? Tasted like Dow Chemical waste products mixed it up in an ice cream maker. 

So all I can say is... Pinkberry - WTF? I don't get it.

Dude what da heck.  Why is this Pinkberry so awesome?
I haven't had Pinkberry since I've moved to NY (August 2010) because I am very loyal to Yogurtland (Why don't they have Yogurtland here?!!)
But customer service at this Pinkberry was really great.  
The guy who helped me was very nice and informative.  When he was ringing me up he gave me two stamps on my card for being patient, but I don't know what he's talking about because I felt like the wait was normal.  But I'm cool with it!

I really was not too happy with my first trip to Pinkberry. The store itself was small, and it did appear to be clean but the tables were sticky. I felt very cramped sitting at the table I was at and I could not fully enjoy the yogurt. Plus the workers were singing and dancing to Michael Jackson songs, really give me a break. Not to mention I did not care for the pebblestone floor, it made me feel like I was sitting outside. Also there were some odd decorations that looked like dog bones and dog bowls that they drink water out of, weird.

I initially had the large combo with mango, pineapple, and blueberry to share with my sister.   So tasty, especially with the pineapple.    We had the plain pinkberry which was just so darn tasty.  

Its a very light snack... a little expensive and I don't get the whole weighing thing.  They weigh it withought showing the customer the figures or whether the scale is even on.  But so yummy and so quickly gone.    

I'm happy to say that Yogurt Harmony in Berkeley is just as tasty... yum yum...

An exemplary Pinkberry. 

Helpful, charming staff and lively, interesting crowd. They play good music and it's always really cold in there which is great.
Absolutely refreshing for these unbearably hottt days...but just a tad too pricey for a dessert

Before I moved to NYC a few months ago, I saw the yogurt store boom begin.  Every neighborhood had a place with the word "berry" in it or some clever take on yogurt.  I tried one that wasn't all that impressive and basically left me with the impression that they all sucked.

....Until I tried pinkberry.  My first visit, I stupidly decided to get a mini size plain, which only allows you to get 2 toppings.  How stupid.  

On my second visit, I got it right.  Small chocolate and plain swirl with brownie pieces, strawberries and chocolate shavings (I don't think that is the real name though).  This place is pretty top notch and the only real strike against them is that they have such a small store front that the paying area gets crowded by idiots who can't walk out of the store once they pay.  Move the hell out once you paid, is it that hard?

Anyway, the place is stellar and im truly glad its a good 12 block walk away, or I'd be there too much.

This Pinkberry is a totes hotspot for depressed Columbians wanting a lovely forzen yogurt pick-me-up.

I don't know why there's all these haters for this Pinkberry. The manager Arturo is a fabulous, lovely person who always greets with a smile or a sly comment. The staff is also very friendly.

It might not be the biggest Pinkberrry ever, but when the line isn't out the door, it has an intimate feel where one can chill with friends eating delicious yogurt listening to cool tunes in a bright cheery place.

Who wouldn't enjoy that?

You are more likely to find me at Red Mango as I am not a fan of the tartness of their original yogurt. Found out however, they have a special topping (mochi) you have to ask for since it is not listed on the menu. Apparently like In-n-Out, you have to be in the know to get the true Pinkberry experience.
Great product, good service.  Low on variety.  Clean store.

I would never have stepped foot in one of these places if I'd not been pulled in to one of the Midtown locations by a friend who'd insisted we try it.  I'd heard about the chain, which debuted in Manhattan over the summer.  Seemed like a buzz-driven fad shop, not worth investigating.

I ordered a medium, plain (non-green tea) fro yo with 3 toppings, and was floored by how simply good it was: I'd never had frozen yogurt which actually tasted like yogurt.  Fantastic!  Maybe it was the timing - it was late at night and I was hungry for desert after some spicy/greasy Korean chow - but I can still recall my first spoon of the stuff.

I've been to this particular outlet two or three times, and I make sure to have pomegranate seeds added as a topping.  There's usually a line late nights, but it moves surprisingly quickly, even with the one cashier typical of all the locations, which seem to be architectural enantiomers of each other (cashier on left or cashier on right).

i love pinkberry- toppings are fresh and the different types of yogurt are great. I placed an order online (was feeling very indulgent) with them last night through delivery.com and everything went through just fine until i got a call about 35 mins later from delivery.com saying they couldn't get a hold of the store. no one was answering the phone or confirming the order. what the deuce pinkberry? very disappointing.

Wish I didn't love this so much, but I have to admit I love the sour frozen yogurt--- the original, plain flavor.  The green tea is vulgar, yet the new coffee  flavor is great, especially if you are a Dannon fan.   I don't care if it is powder and water; it's so refreshing and tart.  And yes, I also like the interiors, with the expensive, little gifts for sale;  can you guess what that thing is for?    The fruit toppings have been disappointing,  not fresh nor tasty; so we go au naturel.

Okay, so I HATE the coolest, hippest thing, and when my name-dropping, desperate to be "in" acquaintance gloated to me that he stood an hour and a half this summer to get him some Pinkberry, well, it was pretty much over for me then. And I was mildly amused/bewildered at the Pinkberry craze that unfolded, and further intruiged when I read conspiracy theories online about how it's not "really" a dairy product and is instead some sort of secret powder mixture, and so on and so forth.

All the same, I figured when the cold set in, and more storefronts opened and everyone realized if there were more than 1 it couldn't be that awesome anymore, I'd go.

And go I did, the other week, choosing this one perhaps because of its surly Hot Topic-reject employees, one of whom was off the clock but not willing to go home and start her homework, and opting instead to harass her co-workers and text her friends. Clearly this was a sign of decadence and high quality fro-yo!

I asked for the original, after some debate, with strawberries, mango, and mochi. I decided to go all out! I had heard how great the fresh fruit was with the tart yogurt, and then the girl in front of me got mochi and I thought that sounded like a good idea.

I asked for it to stay, which must have been a mistake, because the kids at work proceeded to kind of glare at me (i also overheard them talking about how pinkberry "wasn't all that"). 

So I dug in. And.. meh. All I could think of, was that I was eating frozen Fage, with fruit. For like 6 bucks. I was eating a big styrofoam cup of soft serve Fage Greek yogurt. I persevered though, waiting for that epiphany of how AWESOME this was, and how SEXY it was going to make me.
