Nothing changed though, and I eventually trudged through the street with half a cup of goop, tired of the sassy attitudes of the kids working there. And to be sure, I did finish it, and I didn't think it was bad, per se, but certainly not worth the hype. I think I'd like to go back and try the green tea, and maybe a different topping but I dunno. I think I could do a lot better for $6.

Finally i got to taste what the craze is all about.

the plain frozen yogurt is better than the green tea. somehow green tea flavored desserts just end up not tasting like anything.
The frozen yogurt is quite sour - it reminded me of sour milk. But the taste grew on me after a while....

I left thinking....well....not too bad, but really i won't be coming back on my own free will.

I'm a froyo addict, and yes, said addiction is messing with my bank account. Prices could be cheaper, lines stretch out the door, and staff is hit or miss (for some reason, the ones behind the register seem surly and the ones handling the yogurt are always so pleasant). BUT I will happily brave it all for my beloved salted caramel Pinkberry.

I always make it a mission to stop at PB everytime I go to NYC. This is a nice location. Decided to stop at this one because it's close to Harlem. I usually go to the one on 14th & 6th. This one actually gave me 5 toppings instead of 4.

this pinkberry earned itself an extra star
for spelling my name right for like the
first time ever. and the fact that i usually
go here either somewhat high or 
tipsy, which makes it taste even better.

I'm obsessed with Pinkberry. It's become a problem. So many tasty options for frozen yogurt! Lately I've been ordering the salted caramel yogurt with chocolate shavings, yogurt chips, and honey. FYI you can add honey to everything and it doesn't count as a topping! Yay, fatties!

My only complaint is the $0.50 extra for "premium" toppings. You go up, you pay, then you choose your toppings. If you decide the melty-chocolate-crunchy-thingies look good, then you are faced with the awkward moment in which the staff member tells you it's a premium topping and you have to pay $0.50 more. Not really a big deal, but they should get this out of the way to begin with - it's just awkward and holds up the line. 

The line does tend to get pretty long at this location, and there's not a lot of seating, so be prepared to take your yogurt to go.

When I want cold yogurt, I buy some yogurt and refrigerate it, thus saving myself five bucks over Pinkberry.

When I want dessert, I want something that tastes like dessert. That is to say, I don't come here.

Let me start off by telling you that I have filled up 4 Pinkberry loyalty cards (the ones where you get 9 punches and the 10th is free). Obviously I love Pinkberry so I'm a bit torn here.

I've decided on 2 stars for 2 reasons. First, if you look at any other Pinkberry I have reviewed they have gotten 5 stars so the quality of the product is there. However, secondly, I'm huge on service and I thought Pinkberry had great service (it must be that new employee training) until I came to this particular location. 

One thing I love about all the other locations is that a medium and a large usually last me for two times. That means I'm buying a larger portion because I want to eat some tomorrow. But this Pinkberry skimped big time on their portions. My medium was more like a small drowning in a medium cup. Secondly you would think that raspberries were going extinct: one raspberry on the entire thing? And you should have seen the girls face when I told her I would like more. The kiwi was watery and diluted the entire FroYo and the strawberries were nowhere near fresh. 

The one thing that bothered me the most, though, was the cashier system. You basically pay before you get your FroYo so by the time I got to the counter, the server just said nonchalantly "Sorry Ma'am, the coconut machine is broken." Now when I ordered at the cashier, I ordered mango and coconut, like I always do. But this time was different. He actually charged me 50 cents for the coconut and 50 cents more for the mango. Basically a dollar more than every other time AND I didn't even get my coconut. 

The place is crowded, hot, and filled with annoying couples on dates. I just wanted to be in and out (I know my order faster than anyone in there), but the hoards of people in front of me insisted on trying all the flavors. I will definitely not be back to this location and it's a shame because it's within walking distance of my apartment.
Mini chocolate with strawberries keeps your sweet tooth covered.

Tasty for something that was a powder mix not so long before I ate it.  Not very expensive, for the moment, although the add-ons will add up.  

Better than Yolato?  No.  Do I plan on going back?  No.  

If I want an oddly tasty powder-based refresher, I'll go drink some Ovaltine (except the Ovaltine at least has some nutrients).
Really good but $$$$ ,make sure you look down when u go in , the floor is beautiful , the service is great !!!

Probably my favorite pinkberry so far, and I am pretty much a pinkberry expert.

1) Unlimited Toppings
2) Friendly staff who greet you by name AND ask how you're doing
3) They deliver!
4) Every person working at this Pinkberry wears a huge smile. (I really can't get over their friendliness)
5) The fruit here tastes sooooooooo fresh.
Expensive. Over $14.00 for a small and a medium with toppings.Tasty and staff is always pleasant. Why do the charge extra for some of the toppings?

Finally! After weeks of walking by a lonely store front, Pinkberry is up and running in the Heights.

The bad news is that it's crazybusynotcool with all of the waifish sorostitutes getting their frozen yogurt fixes. I was honestly the only person in line with a Y-chromosome. And it's set up so that you're constantly running into someone. Um, and they misspelled my name? Four letters, people.

I can't hate it too much since the product is, of course, the same and I like it and it's stupidly close to me. I'd rather go to Chelsea, though.

In closing, here is a passage from the official "The Pinkberry Song". Or is it Edna St. Vincent Millay? The lyrics are so resonant and inspiring that I often confuse the two:

"Tart and sweet / fresh and airy / blue and black / straw and raspberry...Swirly and fluffy / exquisite dream / sorry ice cream / I'm on my way to Pinkberry"

In case you're wondering, the rhyme scheme is WTFWTFWTF.

In the early 80's I used to get the most delicious frozen yogurt bars in the world at the grocery store. They were just plain low-fat frozen yogurt bars on a stick. No chocolate coating, no added poisons -- and they were fantastic! Of course, they eventually discontinued them and I spent years testing out random and disappointing substitutes (Tasti-D-Lite should be banned). 

Enter Pinkberry. The original flavor is the frozen yogurt of my memory. Light, flavorful, not sugary sweet and not filled with preservatives. Just delicious. 

This is the closest Pinkberry to my house and admittedly I've only eaten Pinkberry about 10 times in my life. I actually love the tangy sweet original flavor but don't really feel inclined to schlep 10 blocks out of my way to buy expensive frozen yogurt on a regular basis. I was delighted to learn they deliver! 

I placed a delivery order on a Saturday evening and it took 60 minutes for it to arrive. When it did, it was delightfully packaged and just as yummy as I remembered it. They do have a minimum fee for ordering (I think it's $10) so I ordered the largest size (a pint?) with side orders of strawberries...it was enough pinkberry for a week! 

While delivery was slow by NYC standards, it seems a reasonable amount of time to wait for a delectable treat like this.

So if I was in LA, Pinkberry would get two stars. There are just so many more options in terms of fro-yo out there. But alas, I'm in NYC, where the fro-yo density is much smaller. 

It started with just green tea and original. But now it's exploded into peanut butter, watermelon, coconut, etc. You're not a Yorgutland. I think you might do better if you stuck to your original business plan of just plain and green tea. 

Yet New Yorkers seem to enjoy paying too much for fro-yo. There is usually a small line. But then again, New Yorkers over pay for many things, myself included. 

Yet, if you are looking for a solid fro-yo establishment, this is not a bad place to go. So three stars it is.
Great service friendly staff and they are very helpful. Very patience and even gave their opinion about there fab toppings. Would def be coming back
So, this actually is the best place ever. The staff is so friendly and the product is worth the slightly-high price tag. This is one fad that I'm glad is actually quality.

business.full_address:
Princeton Shopping Center
301 N Harrison St
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Cross Culture

reviews.text: I love this northern Indian cuisine. The potato flat bread was spectacular, even turning one of my non- believer friends to the Indian cuisine light side. The samosas are beyond belief delicious, and the sauces that go with them make them perfect. Very good.

Really liked this place. Went here for lunch on my lunch hour. Food was delicious and came out very fast. There is no lunch buffet. instead they offer an "executive lunch" which comes with rice, pakoras, daal and a main course. Very reasonable and all very good. Service was excellent. I would definitely go back.

This is the only place I trust so far for non-spicy Indian food (because I can't take spicy foods well). I've been here literally dozens of times with my coworkers for lunch, and I've really enjoyed these dishes: Palak Panir, Navratna Korma, Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Cashmere, Lamb Saagwala, and Lamb Korma. The Pakoras are pretty good, and you get unlimited white rice.

My new favorite Indian place in the area by a wide margin.  I'm still a fan some dishes elsewhere (best veggie samosas: Mehek, best naan: Masala Grill), but overall, this place blows the other guys away.  All of the chicken entrees I've tried have been outstanding, including tikka masala, korma, and cashmere.  The grilled chicken appetizer with onions and peppers (can't recall the name) was amazing.  

Can't comment on the service or atmosphere, as all but one of my experiences have been take-out, but everyone seems quite friendly, and they have done a good job with the space (which wasn't all that great to begin with).

I would probably award 4.5 stars if I could, because the naan is just a tad dry and lacks the chewy, moist center underneath the crisp crust that I like.  Also, the samosas are very good, but I think they are a bit heavy on the spices.  I also got the chicken soup once because I had a cold and needed a backup in case I couldn't stomach the normal fare that the rest of my family wanted.  I suppose it's what you get for ordering chicken soup at an Indian place, but it wasn't great.

A great place to go to. There's really good food here. If you want spicy all you need to do is ask them. The service is really good and I thought they were fast at getting the food to you. We ordered the chicken tandoori masala, chicken achari, and chicken Malay kabob. The chicken tandoori masala was great, it was really creamy and had a lot of tomato in it. Overall I think it was a great restaurant and the ambiance and setting is great along with the food. :)
Great Indian food and nice ambiance.

This is by far our favorite indian restaurant if not our top restaurant period.The food is the best the service is great very friendly people and especially lunch you get tons of food all these free extras and its so cheap.Extremely fresh we go all the time and its always great.If i lived closer i would ge alot more.Don`t miss it!

We had a really good dinner at Cross Cultures.  The restaurant serves food that is both traditional and authentic, yet the atmosphere as well as the food is a bit more refined than your typical Indian restaurant.  Our entrees were tasty and prepared with the amount of heat we requested.  The dining area is spotless and tastefully decorated, providing for nice ambiance. The service was both attentive and friendly. We'll definitely return.

Best North Indian place in Princeton hands down!

Garlic Naan, Daal Makhni, and Paneer Tikka Massala are the closest thing to being in India! Awesome service and cool menus and bibs!!
Overrated. $18 for a chicken tikka masala. Not very much food. Avoid.

Wow, how am I only the second person to review this place and I don't even live in Princeton?  Cross Culture is apparently a new addition to the Princeton Shopping Center, and I'm super excited about this discovery.  They make some of the best Indian food I've had in awhile.  I went with my family for a pre-Christmas dinner.  There were five of us, so we tried a bunch of different items.  From the appetizer menu: chicken samosas, harabhara kabab, and the panir tikka (OMG amazing!).  For entrees we had: chicken korma (one of my all-time favorites, excellently done), lamb curry, tandoori chicken, bhindi masala (awesome okra dish).  All of it was super yummy and I can't wait to go back!

The atmosphere is really nice & is beautifully furnished & decorated. They are very vegetarian friendly with a well organized menu. The food is very good & prices are fair. Highly recommend. Oh & it's a BYOB.
It's a very rare thing to have a good vindaloo in New Jersey. Thank goodness for Cross Culture which brings quality technique and flavors to North Indian fare.
Great food.

Excellent quality and ambiance. 
Indian food in Princeton varies a lot and it's difficult to find a consistent experience, even at one restaurant. I hesitate to give a huge, glowing review based on one visit, but if the second visit is anything like the first, I'll go to 5 stars.
I had the Cashmere Chicken and my bf had the Chicken Vindaloo and it was all extremely tasty.

Pleasant, attentive staff. Loved it!
Highly overrated. The food is just okay -- seemed like less than fresh ingredients.

This is an omnivorous restaurant that is extremely receptive to vegan customers.  You can call or email ahead of time or just speak to the waitstaff when you come to dine; they understand what vegan means, will point out the vegan menu items, and even offer additional suggestions/options.  

The pretty dining room is spotless and the food is terrific.  Be sure to ask for extra spicy (the scale is 1-10; next time I'm requesting a 15!).  I will be returning soon and often.

My wife and I went last night and we had a great time. The place is clean and simplistic. It's a BYOB and the service was excellent. We started with apps, including a huge bread basket and mix veggie appetizer. They were good, the veggie app was 3 fried items including samosas. It came with 2 sauces, sweet and tangy, and spicy mint. For dinner I had chicken tikka masala and asked them to make it a little spicy (4 out of 10), and it came out perfect. My wife had the navraton korma, which was a veggie coconut curry sweeter dish. Everyone around was getting the simmering Tandori dishes, such as the mixed grill, and they looked and smelled great. We will definitely go back to try those and the desserts, because we were too full to get one this time.

The restaurant was well-decorated and classy, but the air was smoky.  The service was also extremely slow... it took several attempts to flag down someone for more water, an order for dessert, or the check.  We also noticed that the surrounding tables which had been long abandoned were still not cleared or wiped down.  What were they doing all this time...?

The food was good, not unusually greasy and heavy like cheap Indian food... but lacking in punch.  We ordered 7 entrees, and all of them were very mild and not spicy at all, which was disappointing; the waiters didn't even ask how spicy we wanted the food.  For the price we paid, we expected more pizazz.  We prefer Paratha Junction for gravy-based Indian food.

We tried two of their desserts, which were excellent.

My friend adds that it is a poor substitute for Zen Palate, which used to be in this location.

Fantastic lunch.  We have been there several times on Fridays.  Wish the prices were more reasonable for dinner and take out.  We would come more often or take out.  Maybe they could have a frequent eater discount or web specials for locals.

I'd give this place 4 stars despite the food (though it's delicious).  A clean, well-decorated Indian restaurant is all too rare, at least in my experience.  One with great service is unheard of.  
While being Indian grants me familiarity with most menu items, I'm used to the staff being of zero help in helping to describe or navigate the menu.  The people here however were happily willing to give advice on everything.

I liked that they put their own touches on the menu items, while remaining true to the cuisine.  There wasn't the oily heaviness I'm used to on north Indian menus, and the spices were well balanced.  It's a little pricier than most white linen Indian restaurants, but the BYOB makes up for that.

For lunch, this is top of the line. Prices are wonderful and the quality is good and consistent. Service is very good too. Especially since at lunch you want to be in-out in less than 1 hour.  

For dinner the prices are a bit higher though.

Yum yum yum

Seriously the most refined Indian cuisine I've had since Manhattan. Multilayered flavours that devote more to artistry than merely heat and garam masala from a jar  (the Indian version of "Italian seasoning"); here, each dish has its own distinctive flavor and texture, and idiots like me want to start learning which breads are supposed to accompany which dishes, instead of the usual any bread with any dish simply because we don't know any better. Yes, it's that good.

We had the mixed grill tandoori, lamb saag, pickles, eggplant, the best okra I've ever had (even later, reheated for breakfast).

There were four of us splitting everything, so I missed what I was told was incredible fish and shrimp from the mixed grill. The chicken was tender, spiced well, and what one wants from a good tandoori. The only doozy was the lamb, which, as tender and juicy as it was, had that livery tinge from steaming.

Okra--oh my God good. Or Gods, as it might be. Again tender, separate pieces that were neither tough nor greasy. If you haven't ever had good okra, please try it here (or at a really Southern place fried or stewed with tomatoes). There was texture, the seeds were tender, no woodiness at all. 

The saag was fine, as in fine dining, finely minced spinach that doesn't get stuck in your teeth and has a layered set of spices that doesn't just burn your mouth or turn your lips yellow. Sublime.

I can almost dismiss my desire for heat because the flavours were so good.

There are some good Indian restaurants around here, and I think this is one of the best.  All four dishes we ordered were good, and although the place was crowded (no empty tables at all), the service was good too.

Delicious. If you're new to Indian food, Cross Culture is a great place to sample; if you're already an Indian food fan, it will certainly satisfy you. For a beginner, I recommend chicken malai kabab (grilled garlic and ginger marinated white meat chicken) with kachumber and raita accompaniments (order these a la carte). Also recommended lentil daal makhani, any masala dish (very creamy) and aloo gobhi (cauliflower and potatoes). BYOB -- there's a liquor store in the shopping center if you forget to plan ahead. Sparkling wine (champagne or prosecco) or crisp beer work well with both spicy and creamy foods. Service is good. Very pleasant decor.

business.full_address:
1147 Route 601
Skillman, NJ 08558
business.name: New World Pizza & Cafe

reviews.text: We like the buffalo chicken pizza here. Take out is recommended as the dine in is small.
The margarita pizza here is very, very good. I don't know much about some of the other foods, but it looks good and possibly worth trying in the future, if the margarita wasnt so good.

Even though this pizzeria is down the street from my house, I eat there under no circustances. Not only is the pizza hardly average but the employees are extremely rude. Eating there was an overall unpleasant experience.

The two stars are for the shoddy service.
Last weekend, I called New World Pizza at 5pm and ordered a pizza to be ready for 6:10pm. Plenty of time for an advance order, I thought. At 6:10pm, I walked into the restaurant and yes, they said, my pizza would be right there. They took my money and I sat there. Almost twenty minutes later, I got it. The pizza was pretty tasty, but these guys could care less about customer service. They refused to acknowledge they'd forgotten to put the order in on time. I won't go back. THere are plenty of pizzerias in the area that are more interested in keeping customers.

They're one of the few places in my area that delivers, so they get an extra star for that.  If I order from here, I stick to their gourmet pizzas like the Garden or the Mexican.  I've received some pies from here that were overcooked and burnt on the bottom.  Their subs are also "sub-par" and they're really stingy with the meat on their hot subs and cheese steaks.  Their appetizers are acceptable, but nothing great.  On a good day, this place could be great but they're just too inconsistent; however, I find myself ordering from them whenever I'm feeling too lazy and the weather is bad.

New World serves great pizza with gourmet toppings. They do have traditional pizza too, but I just go here for the excellent Mexican pizza.

You can read a more complete review on my blog.
Not fantastic. Sadly, they're among the few pizza places that deliver to my area, so sometimes I have to settle for them.
We get Pizza from these guys all the time. It's usually very nice as are the wings. They are super quick to deliver as well.
Okay restaurant.  I usually order pizza here for parties, and when my kid's babysitter comes over.  My son loves the pepperoni!

business.full_address:
968 Amsterdam Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Taqueria Y La Fonda

reviews.text:
Good beer, great food, and friendly staff = Taqueria y Fonda...

Went with a couple friends last night...I had been eying the place and they suggested it - a good sign...

The place is tiny and cramped, but that just adds to the allure of what others have termed a hole in the wall...the staff was very friendly, always a plus for any business, but appreciated and noticed at the smaller ones...

I ended up getting two tacos, which more than filled me up...carne asada and al pastor...massive mound of meat on each...my friends got the chicken mole and chile rilleno platos...also good portions...

Good selection of Mexican beers - they have all of the usual suspects, no surprises...wine & sangria too...

Prices are right too...whole check for 3 - which included a couple rounds of beers, an appetizer, and 3 dinners - came to $70...

Favorite "hole in the wall taqueria to plan a revolution" on the West Side.  Many good times as raucous, rushed students missing California/South America and wanting a $4 tasty meal with fresh vegetables on top and avocado. I won't comment on whether it's "authentic" or not, but in 13 degree weather in February, it satisfies the craving.  They also sponsored a few film school crew meals for us.  Sometimes you'll spot local Oscar winners and Nobel laureates in the corner.  Get a Margarita, taco, and blast the Spanish top 40 on the Jukebox.  If your entire table sings along, no one will care.  If you want giant portions, go to El Rey del Caridad across the street.  Anything on Amsterdam is better than Chipotle on Broadway.

When they say "Giant Burrito", you better believe you are getting a giant burrito. This isn't any Chipotle burrito, this is huge. Also, it's great for vegetarians, and it's totally two meals' worth of food.

Delish horchata!

Amazingly good Mexican in NYC. I'm a Cali girl at heart and I love a REAL burrito and this is the best I've had in the Northeast. I went to Tortilleria Nixtamal in Queens because of all the hype and was disappointed but without fanfare this place is the real deal.

This needs to be appended/merged with the more extensive listing for Taqueria Y La Fonda La Mexicana New York 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/taqueria-y-fonda-la-mexicana-new-york
Hole in the wall Mexican tacos and burritos. The closest you can get to decent Southern Californian Mexican food in Manhattan.

Super yum and super low-key.  I like that there are authentic Mexican dishes alongside the football sized burrito (maybe a basketball, it is huge).  I have had the Pipian (pumpkin seed sauce) and Mole Rojo as well as standard tacos. Bottled beers in the cooler-perfect for chill dinner/lunch or takeout.

Big portions, tiny prices for authentic Mexican food.  I've been introducing friends to this place since I tried it (with the armchair psychologist on this board!), and we all love it.   Being a serious carnivore, I have no problems with the dishes being heavy on the meat, especially when they are well-seasoned and tasty!  Yes, seating is cramped and at a premium, but you can always order it and take it home.  However, then you miss the fabulous chips & salsas, which are SOOOOO good!

Just got delivery from Taqueria for the first time.  It came very quickly, even at peak dinner time on Friday night.  And.. the food was still hot!  

I knew you would never let me down, Taqueria.

I've been here a couple times and tried a number of different entrees and daily specials. They were all good, but nothing that made me wanting to run back.  The prices were reasonable and the service mostly acceptable. On one occasion a friend didn't like the dish he ordered. I tasted it and agreed it was horrible and that he should send it back. it was quite difficult to explain to the waiter that the food was no good and he wanted something else. they did eventually understand and replace his meal. I guess they handled it okay, but it certainly wasn't like they were gushing with desire to satisfy.

The best Mexican in NYC hands down.

I love this place. It's a hole in the wall--just a few tables inside and the grill is up front. You can watch them make your food. The food is cheap but really good and you get a LOT of it!

I am vegan so I usually stick to bean, veggie, or cactus taco--they are sooo huge and really good. Their rice is the bomb-sticky and soft. I always leave this place with leftovers and totally stuffed! 

T

We all have to face the truth:  most Mexican food in New York City is crap.  I would rather eat at Chipotle than your average fake Mexican spot (which I've done one time, a little too in my cups and I needed food immediately).  This said, I would've gone to Taqueria y Fonda la Mexicana if it had been close by.

The place is small, so if it's busy you may just have to wait.  I'd say there are no frills, but that's not true.  They bring you complimentary chips and salsa that are surprisingly good.  The food is between good and very good, as well, and actually reminds me of real Mexican food.  There are a number of reasonable vegetarian options, and you'll leave full for likewise reasonable prices for NY (definitely under $10). 

Were TFM located in another city, it might not be my go-to, but on the Upper West Side it absolutely is.  Well worth stopping in.

If a friend hadn't recommended and accompanied me to Taqueria, I probably would have walked past it saying "that place look gross."  I'm glad i went and now know how excellent and authentic is really is.

The main area of the restaurant is very small, only about 6 or 7 tables, but apparently, we found out afterward, that there is another part of the restaurant next door, were there are at least 15 other tables.  

The wait staff is very friendly and greeted us quickly so I could order a negra modelo, for only $4 (sweet).  They brought by some fresh chips and 3 different salsas.  Each were tasty and very fresh.

I had a hard time deciding what to order.  Part of me wanted the beef tongue and pig ear tacos, but I'll save that for next time.  They have a lot of dishes that aren't on your average texmex or Americanized Mexican restaurant.  What intrigued me was the Alambres, which comes with veggies, your choice of meant, guacamole, and tortillas underneath.  I picked pork strips and chicken as my meats.  The meat was excellent, cooked nicely and the pork was not tough.  The chicken was nicely marinated and had a nice spice blend to give it a bit of kick.

I had the pleasure of trying the veggie and chicken tamale, which both were excellent, moist and the veggie had tomatoes in the center.  I also tasted one of the GIANT burritos.  And they are freaking giant, and easily two meals for the low price of 8.25 for veggie and 9.25 for meat.  

This place will never win any awards for ambiance or style, but they serve great food, use tasty fresh ingredients and no stuffy feeling.  This place apparently doesn't have the same greatness for delivery, but I will be getting take out again and again.

-authentic, hole in the wall feel
-reasonable prices
-gives chips and salsa
-only legit mexican place so far in the morningside heights/columbia area that I feel safe walking to
-i ate the rolled tacos(taquitos) and carne asada taco...both were up to par...i'm from southern california so I know what authentic mexican food tastes like
Love the burritos.

This is a great Mexican food place.  Their burritos are huge, wonderful, and about $8.  Tacos are $3 a piece.

I suggest calling a head for a take out order because there can be quite a wait.  Delivery can take a while as well.

I gave this place two chances, the mole and a burrito, and I'm left underwhelmed.  What am I missing?  

Aside from the general dissatisfaction with the food, I want to talk about burritos and foil.  Foil is important.  It should be rolled tightly around the burrito, so that it holds everything together.  Then you can peel it off as you eat and stay relatively unmessy.  Here, they plop the burrito down on a sheet and fold it over a couple of times, so that when you unpack, you just have to trust the tortilla (which never works - mine lasted about 10 seconds before I gave up and forked it).  Fix the foil problem, and I'll add an extra star.

They are really friendly, though, and I suppose if you like your Mexican food with no kick at all, you might appreciate the pretty fresh tasting veggies.

They cured my jones for a Sonora-grade carne asada torta. If you've lived near the border, or south of it, and miss the real deal, come here. Burritos are the size of fire hydrants. A deep menu and friendly staff.

i judge mexican restaurants - at least the ones that people seem to call "authentic" - by just a few things:

tacos al pastor
tortas
sopes

i appreciate when horchata is on the menu, but i'm not a fan so it doesn't factor.

but, anyway, that's what i use, those three foods.  and, quickly:

taco al pastor: failed.  miserably.  when the woman asked me if i wanted cheese and guacamole on my taco, i knew i should've cancelled my order.  that was a dead giveaway that too many people who think "guac" goes with everything eat there.  not surprisingly, the taco sucked.  and for $3.50 or $4 (whatever they're charging now), which is *a lot* more than the 2-2.50 that other fantastic places charge, they should've been ridiculously good.  there was a lot of food.  but it wasn't good.

torta de pollo:  it was made with marinated chopped chicken thighs.  for anyone who's ever had a torta de pollo, well, i don't need to say anything else, do i?  this one was a joke it was so bad.

sopes: didn't even get to them because i was so turned off by the taco and the torta.

there are people who say the burritos are good.  christian bale says "good for you".

oaxaca cheese is great.  forget this place.  it's for college kids that think they go to school in "the city".

Probably the best mexican food I've had in town!! This place is as good as any expensive restaurant boasting authentic mexican food. Check out their gi-normous vegetable burrito, enough for 2 people.
All time favorite place!

My tamales were very good. They are a nice staff but hopefully they can hire another person or two because they always take about 5-10 min longer than you'd expect them to. 

That being said, they take a while because it's freshly made food that really hits the spot when you want Mexican, not Tex Mex, food.

And the beer isn't a rip off. Not cheap but fairly priced. Try this place out.

Burritos not that good. They are indeed giant, but fall apart when you try to eat them (knife and fork deal). They are dry and the steak was bland and chewy. Chips are VERY thick tasted greasy. Only came with a few tiny containers of salsa in our delivery order. Better options in Harlem!

This food might be authentic, but it's not as good as mexican food should be. 

I have had the steak torta, which was good and I would have it again. But that is not saying much, because there is no way to mess up tarta, it's a basic mexican sandwich. 

I have also had  their steak tacos and their nopales (cactus) tacos... both good, but not the best. The tortillas are good, they don't fall apart in your hands.  The salsa's need a little work, they are watery and not very flavorful. One of the green salsa's is mostly chopped onion. :(  Salsa's should be thicker and chunkier and should come with a kick of flavor. 

I most recently had the chile relleno (stuffed green pepper), it came with rice and beans. I liked the beans more than I did the chile. The tomato sauce was too thick, and the batter on the chile was not flavorful. I will not have this dish again.

Had high hopes, and waited awhile in line but this place is just awful (food wise).  Customer service was decent.

I got an al pastor quesadilla and it lacked flavor as mentioned in other reviews.  The cheese had the consistency of hard mozzarella and was

the burrito here is super big and the beef is very flavorful
its a fairly small place so its a bit squished...
they're nice and I really enjoyed the burrito here

my only issue would have been the sauces that they give you for the chips.  the chips are great, since I think they fry them in lard...  but the sauces don't seem to be very sanitary.  it could be me not being used sharing the same sauce container from table to table and not being sure if someone double dipped.

we used a restaurant.com coupon so it was under $10/person after tax/tip but normally, it would probably be higher... but the portions are good enough for sharing so if you both got something to share, it'd be under

I've eaten here multiple times over the past few years and it is always satisfying. I love the salsa that they bring out with the fresh chips before your meal. You should get the Giant Burrito if you're hungry or otherwise the baby burrito which is still a good size. I'm sure the rest of the menu is good too but I've never cared to venture. The staff is friendly and they seem to care about what they are doing.

First and foremost, I am from Los Angeles.  Not outside of LA, not Long Beach, not San Diego, not Orange County-LOS ANGELES.  I know my Mexican food and I know it well.  From Mexican food trucks in Echo Park to Taco San Pedro in Hawaiian Gardens (aka Little Mexico), I am your flauta queen.  Rosa Mexicana is for the dummies, La Esquina is better/overpriced but if you want a true hole in the wall taco in New York City-this is your place.  My craving for a real carne asada was realized for all but $3.50 (still not my $1.50 taco in LA but I'll live).  It had just what I wanted: CORN tortilla, grilled carne asada, cilantro, onions and tons of SPICY salsa verde.  That's green salsa for all your gringos.  Much better quality meat than the overpriced taco truck on 96th Street.   I might be able to stay in New York indefinitely now since California is going bankrupt.  Thank you Taqueria y Fonda.  All I need if the In-N-Out truck and my life would be perfect.

I love the food here!

One thing. The last two times I went here, they forgot my friend's order and took a long time to bring us the bill. It seems like the service is getting worse ):

BEST TACOS IN THE CITY!!!!

Someone said to get the tongue, and I agree.  It's the best meat on the menu.  However, i wasn't a huge fan of the oreja - there was a little bit too much cartilage.  

Delivery can be a little slow, but it's worth it.

Total hole in the wall with delicious food, cheap prices on food and drinks, service, gigantic portions and free chips and delicious salsa! Seriously, best place in the neighborhood.  Boyfriend and I went there for dinner and have deemed it our place. In addition to the standard Mexican fare, they are innovative with their specials and include salmon anf fun vegetables as options. Love this place.

I don't mind a hole-in-the-wall so long as the food is great, but I was disappointed with Taqueria y Fonda la Mexicana.  It seems that the restaurant was overwhelmed with customers; they had to open up another part of the restaurant when my party of 4 arrived and service was spotty.  The chips were greasy and I've had better salsa.  My chicken taco never arrived.  My cheese enchiladas were fine, but not fabulous.  The real tragedy was that my friend's burrito was cold, almost frozen, in some parts.  Inexcusable.  The waitress offered to reheat her burrito, but at that point she no longer found it appetizing.

Food is great but a female mgr. pulled a fast one with the salmon tacos. She told us there were two tacos for the price offered. We ordered salmon taco. We got two salmon tacos in a plate. We were then presented with a bill for two separate salmon tacos at $7.50 each for a total of $15.
As my wife speaks fluent SPANISH I WAS SURPRISED THAT ANY CONFUSION COULD OCCUR.
As business is slow we suspect she was trying to maximize the few customers there. Be careful.but....we'll eat elsewhere.

My classmates had been telling me for a few months that Taqueria Y La Fonda was an awesome, authentic Mexican restaurant that would rival the food I so dearly miss back in Cali.  So, we decided to go and try it out at our latest girls gathering.

The four of us split a carnitas giant burrito, carne asada taco, carne asada sope and chicken tamale.  The carne asada taco was a tad dry, but decent.  The chicken tamale was moist and flavorful, but I was never a big fan of chicken tamales, so I am a poor judge on that one.  The carnitas giant burrito was a pretty big disappointment.  It was bland and only upon finishing did I realize that there wasn't any sour cream or guacamole in that huge burrito that was the size of a newborn baby!   If you make a burrito that huge, it MUST have sour cream and guac!  How can you forget those necessary condiments??!?....the horror!  If those key condiments were added, it would hike my star rating up a notch to 3 stars.


The best thing was the carne asada sope.  It's a thick corn tortilla covered with the meat of your choice, lettuce, mexican cheese and salsa.  It had the perfect amount of each to make all the flavors pop.  Also, their chips are pretty darn good.  I couldn't stop eating them.

Verdict:  Decent portions (exception: the giant burrito...which is indeed GIANT), but sorely lacking in flavor.  I'm still on the hunt for good Mexican in NYC.

I liked this place except for the bad seating near the door that kept my feet freezing.  The food was good, but not GREAT, the enchilladas were oddly tasting- and the quesadillas were delicious.  I think this is a neighborhood gem.  I would go back, and recommend it.  I am sure the food is better if you are a meat eater!

P.S. The salsas are tasty.

The texture of the mole (as thick as hollandaise, but not goopy)  on my tongue still haunts me. 

Every single flavor in the complex sauce was bright and smooth. 

Black absorbs every single color in the spectrum--- and that dark (red) mole melded Ancho and Guajillo chiles, onion, tomatoes, pecans, peanuts, sesame, garlic, oregano, and chocolate together like I've never known. 

The aftertaste had sweet hints of cumin, they cooked that bold spice until it was refined enough to carry (and not overpower) the chocolate. It must take them well over five hours.

I almost cried in gratitude at getting taken here. 

I did cry, actually. They really took my request for "extra spicy" seriously and spiked my mole with marinated long green chilies. The tangyness of the chilies were not a perfect fit for the sauce but the heat was amazing. Thus, the tears came and my friend smiled victoriously for spicing me out.

He got tacos. The pollo was a flavorful triple threat: marinated, grilled, then kissed with spices, there's probably not a better or more enormous chicken taco out there. The carne asada  was scrumptious, but not as memorable. 

Their beer selection is varied and priced perfectly at 4 dollars a bottle. The wine (supposedly from Abruzzo, Italia) goes for 15 bucks a bottle--- I'm not so sure I want to go to there. 

When I woke up in the morning after my magnanimous mole enchilada meal--- all I could think about was eating it again.

I went back, they laughed when they saw me. I was too embarassed to order the same dish and went for the goat and cactus special instead. It was great. The goat was shockingly fresh. I felt like Dionysus. But I regret not getting the mole--- I'll just have it for dinner tonight!

This unassuming mexican joint is nothing if not authentic. In a space barely the size of my dorm room they've managed to fit a kitchen, grill, cash register, several fridges with various sodas and beers, and a scattering of small tables. It's not overcrowded, though. Instead, it has a charming, friendly atmosphere that's perfect for a casual dinner out or after-midnight snack. Plus, they deliver till 12:30am.
I guess my real reason for giving it 5 stars is that the menu offers so many delicious vegetarian options. My favorite is the simple veggie taco with guacamole. You're not gonna find a better or healthier dinner for under 5$.
As for their "Giant Burrito," it really does live up to its name. I think it cost around 9$, but was so huge that last time we ordered it, two teenagers couldn't finish it. 
The only problem I have with the place is that the tacos are literally inedible without either a fork or a chip. They are so stuffed that you have to eat away half the filling before you can even hope to pick it up. A lot of the time they'll throw in some free chips, especially if you have a big order, though, so it's not a serious deterrent.

This is an incredible hole-in-the-wall Mexican place on the Upper, Upper West Side.  I are dinner a few days ago with my friends from Columbia University and thoroughly enjoyed it.

The atmosphere is totally casual -- you walk in and there's an open kitchen to the left (which smells AMAZING) with cooks moving feverishly to complete the in-house and take-out orders.  It's great to see an open kitchen loaded with fresh veggies, meat and tortillas when you go into a place like this.  That's the great thing about Taqueria y Fonda - everything is really fresh and prepared to order.

I ventured off the usual choices of tacos and enchiladas and tried their stuffed pepper.  The pepper was stuffed with a delicious mix of pork, beef, bananas and raisins, topped with a cream sauce with generous sides of black beans and rice.   It was one of the most delicious dishes I've had anywhere in months.  They have lots of creative, interesting dishes like that, and that's where Taqueria really shines.

A few days before, I tried a chicken taco and a beef taco.  Both were topped with salsa fresca, cilantro and cheese.  The chicken was marinated, spicy and tender while the beef was in really tiny pieces and a bit dry.  I'm going to try the pork and tongue tacos next time I'm there.

The owner -- George, I believe -- was there the whole time, managing the waitresses, watching the kitchen, and keeping an eye on the delivery orders going out.  He is a GREAT guy, make sure to introduce yourself!  The whole additude of the place is friendly and "neighborhoody."  

This would be a great place to go if you're a student on a budget, need a quick bite after work or before going out with friends.  I will most definitely be back!

I order from this place once a week.  

The store itself is a bit small but worth it for the food.  Tacos and horchata are mui bueno.

The food is great. But they REFUSE to NOT cover everything with cilantro. If you ask them to not put cilantro on your food, they will anyway. So if you can tolerate cilantro, then eat here. If you can't, then fuhgeddaboutit.

This place is reallly good and for any college students reading this its VERY CHEAP! 3.25 for 2 tacos! the only reason why i am giving it 4 stars is because they need to turn down the garlic just a tad...like even 30min after I ate it I still had an after taste of garlic. i had the chicken and carne tacos both were delish!

I'm from Texas, and when I moved to New York I very quickly began to miss eating cheap tacos several times a week.  Eventually, someone pointed me here, and I'm thankful for it.  

The chips are thick and great.  The salsas, too, are all very good - so much better than anything else I've had hear.  I especially especially like the avocado salsa.  

As for food, I've mostly just had tacos because, well, I think those are my true love.  Sadly, none of the tacos I've had here rise to the level of my favorites back home, but some of them are pretty good.  My favorite so far is the carnitas tacos, but I also have liked the al pastor and lingua tacos as well.  The only thing that has disappointed me has been the carne asada.  The last time I tried it was months ago, and I don't remember anymore what exactly my problem was with it, but it was enough that I haven't tried it again.  

More than just the food, the atmosphere of this place just makes me happy.  It's small and usually crowded, charmingly (to me) dirty with only a few seats, and often loud Mexican music playing.  It reminds me of my favorite restaurants back home, and for that alone I'll keep returning (also the fact that morningside is a culinary wasteland).

Though I went to Columbia for three years, I didn't discover this spot till I started working in the neighborhood.  I'd like to apologize to the Taqueria for my years of neglect!  I made up for it though because in the five years I worked in the 'hood I was a Taqueria/Giant Burrito evangelist.  Just the best burritos in the city.  Fresh and mammoth.  Best with an icy Mexican beer or fruity Mexican soda.  Really cheap, too.  Most of the burritos are about 6 greenbacks and are so gianormous they're good for sharing or for leftovers.   They put fresh made tortilla chips in the bag when you order take out or delivery and they include all the good spicy mejicano condiments.  So crazy good!

Beyond disappointing.  I have walked past the place over the years, but it's a hole so I never paid attention.  Received a menu under my door recently.  Got on Yelp to see what folks had to say.  After reading, the great reviews, I ordered quite excitedly.  And it really made sense to me that the nondescript little spot could be an underground hit b/c of authenticity and simply great food. This was gonna be really good!   

Wow,  you yelpers steered me wrong in this case.  Well, in all seriousness, taste is of course subjective so I'm really not mad at that. But in this case, I just severely disagree with the majority.

First of all, the food arrived and the bag was dripping in grease.  Everything was SOOOO GREASY.  It was disgusting. Even the soup was full of grease.  We had to throw out the tablecloth literally from just placing the containers on it.

What we ordered:

Caldo de pescado - decent flavor under all the grease.  Even the container was covered in oil.  It was disgusting. I couldn't eat it.  I hate throwing out food, so I put it in the fridge.  Tonight I took it out and skimmed off about 1/2 inch layer of solidified fat that settled at the top, then re-heated.  Now it was good.  Good flavor.  Not amazing, but good.  And certainly better than the inedible bowl of grease and fat from the night before. 

Misc tacos - Greasy.  Tacos can actually be quite healthy. Learn meat cooked over an open flame, fresh herbs and salsas in a soft corn tortilla.  But again, these were so greasy, it was terrible.  And the flavor wasn't there. Very bland. The steak tasted like it wasn't even seasoned.  Once I put on salsa verde, lime, some guac, and my Frank's Red Hot, it was edible and okay. But I hated eating all that grease and the taste certainly was not worth the high number of fat calories I was ingesting.

The guac - It was okay. It was definitely made fresh. Loved the fresh cilantro. It was decent.

The tortilla chips - inedible due to the amount of grease

The salsa verde - now this was good! Delicious. The only think I loved.

I have had incredible Mexican (in Mexico of course, but also NY, San Fran, etc) and this wasn't it. My husband barely ate at all. I tried b/c I hate wasting food but it wasn't enjoyable. 

NEVER, EVER AGAIN!

Yeah this is definitely not the best Mexican food anywhere. Definitely not in CA or NY. It doesnt compare to other places I have been that I like way better. 

I ordered the carne asada tacos and while they were tasty they were not the best I have had. At least, unlike other NY joints they dont smother then in lettuce and cheese crema. That is a plus. The home made chips were good but the salsa was watery. I like my salsa more chunky and definitely not the most flavorful I have had. My bf ordered the huevos rancheros they were ok. The rice and beans were the best thing on his plate. Didnt have a chance to try the burritos, maybe next time. Also at amost $4 a taco, the tacos are pricey. They should be around $2, $3 max each. 

For some great tacos, try spanish harlem for tacos al pastor yum!!

This is one of the most authentic Mexican hole-in-the-wall places I've found in Manhattan, and I'm grateful I live a mere 2 blocks away. I live for street food when I travel to Mexico, and this place reminds me of the delicious tortas and tacos I've had in Mexico City (although the owner, Jorge, is from Guerrero). 

I almost always go for a torta milanesa (breaded steak sandwich), tacos dorados, alambres (tacos plus bacon!), tacos (either al pastor or chorizo), or the cesina (a salted beef cut). The chorizo is the least greasy that I've found, and the meat in the torta is very good quality.  The al pastor tacos are not the most authentic, I'll admit (the meat is usually cut from a spit in Mexico) but they are plenty delicious. The Chilate, a spicy red-chile chicken soup, is a must order when I have a cold. 

Burritos seems to be popular here. Are they good? Dunno, never had one. But the students seem to like them. I tend to stay away from burritos that are in the "bigger than your head" variety. 

My only complaint is the terrible seating (the tables by the door are particularly bad) and the ventilation is not the best. The wait for a table can be a nightmare too - but that's what delivery is for.

Disappointingly I have noticed an increase in the frequency of screwed up orders...

In spite of the unreliable service, it's still my favorite place for cheap, authentic Mexican in New York City.

yelp what is going on?? this is the first time you have ever steered me wrong! 
being a native Texan i was looking for a taco to crave my tex mex appetite. i stumbled upon taqureia and while not tex-mex .. the reviews made it seem out of this world so i had to try it !

the tacos were huge! i had no idea  they would be so big 
i got twp steak tacos an done chicken 
- the steak tacos lacked any kind of flavor what soever.. took lots of habenero sauce and extra lime to give it some help 
- the chicken taco at least tried!  a little bit more flavorful than the steak, but not by much 

an ok spot if you are starving and don't have the cash, but def not my first choice 

and the extra .75 cents extra PER TACO really turned me off as well

I may be from CA and have high expectations but let me say this loud and clear:
Mexican food in NYC sucks in general.

This place has medicore food for the most part, however, their Tortas are quite good.  I love the Carne Asada one in particular (guac, beans, cheese, etc).  The Super Burrito is decent and better than many burritos in the city, but nothing to write home about.  In CA, this would be two stars.  In NYC, I'll give it three.

This is a delivery place.  The restaurant itself is small and the kitchen makes your clothes smell afterward cuz of how crowded it is.

After living on the west coast for 10 years, I was relieved to find Taqueria y Fonda in my new hood. No, it's not as good as the taquerias in Arizona or California. But it is a million times better than what passes as Mexican food in most of NYC. (Rice doesn't belong in tacos! And tortillas should not be heated to a gummy stretchy stick-in-your-teeth orb in a steamer. And pico de gallo is not salsa.)

The basics are what matters in Mexican food: beans, rice, tortillas, salsa, chips. A good Mexican restaurant ALWAYS makes its own chips, served fresh, and always makes its own salsa/hot sauce.  Taqueria y Fonda gets this right. Tortillas are heated on a griddle so there are delicious dark spots and no gumminess. Chips are fresh, salsa is hot but with depth of flavor, beans and rice are consistent and well seasoned. 

My favorites: chorizo or carnitas tacos - tasty pork!, cheese and jalepeno tamales, enchiladas verdes, carne enchiladas, chips, rice & beans.

Not so much: the popular giant burritos (I like to be able to pick up a burrito in my hands, and these are wrapped loosely and overstuffed with less expensive ingredients. Get a few tacos for a tastier bite.)

The family run place recently expanded and I hope they continue to do well. Late night delivery is a plus.

I live half a block away and pick up from here all the time. I highly recommend the tacos, the alambres, the green mole, and the nogada sauce dish. As far as meat goes, I like the chorizo and particularly the carne enchilada. The guac is good, but not great. I've had other dishes here -- sometimes they miss the mark. But if you stick with the above-mentioned dishes, this place is really great.

Alright, so I moved a bit up the street from this place a few years ago, and immediately was excited because it looked like one of those great, divey, Mexican restaurants. The first time I went there, I ordered something I hadn't tried before, because I wanted to be adventurous. I should say, at this point, that I grew up on the west coast, so I know what good Mexican should taste like, and I knew that a place like this would probably be my best bet. Well anyway, the food was not good. I still wanted to believe, though! I've been to this place probably 5-6 times over the years, every time thinking "this can't be as bad as I remembered it". It is. So this morning, I got a hankering for huevos rancheros, and since they are still the most authentic place that delivers to my house, I decided to go for it again. Big mistake. Over an hour later, I had a fairly soggy bunch of huevos. Clearly I should have gone with the egg and cheese bagel instead.

What's wrong? Well, nothing really has much flavor--it's all kind of bland. If you do feel like you need to go for one of their enormous burritos, you won't finish it and you'll feel horrible from eating all those carbs. There might be a little meat too, but you won't taste it. Even their guacamole doesn't taste good--I don't know how, but they've managed flavorless guacamole. Now I know that I probably had it coming with the breakfast I ordered today--not a big surprise that it would be a bit soggy after delivery. Still, it was pretty disappointing. I was also forced to get a carnitas taco to push it up to $10 (why are their tacos $3?) . Again, flavorless, and I didn't notice much of the green sauce I selected.

Do yourself a favor and look up La Aguila on either 103rd or 116th and Lexington. SO MUCH BETTER. Unfortunately I'm a bit out of their delivery range.

I love this place.  It's the best mexican food I've had in New York.  In general, the dishes are very fresh, the service fast and attentive.  

The enchiladas de mole are great, and same with the chile rellenos and burritos...except for the veggie burritos.  I don't like assorted vegetables in my burritos, and that's what they do here.  

Sometimes it can be a little loud because the place is small, has hard surfaces - one table of yappy Columbia students can pollute the sonic environment of the place.
This time I got the enchilada verdes and my boyfriend got the chicken tortas.....DELICIOUS. OMG and this time we got delivery and they sent over just the right number of hot sauce. Love this place.
Seriously - this is the best Authentic Mexican restaurant in the UWS and it's such a treat to watch them prepare your dish on two tiny steel grills.

I have to work on the UWS which means I also have to eat up here for lunch and when I don't bring it with me, I'm at the mercy of the surrounding area. This little spot saves the day for me all the time.

I remain unimpressed.  Flavorless meat, an over-reliance on rice, and sub-par chips.  Sure the overstuffed burritos might travel well, but do you really want them to?

I've never been to Mexico to explore all the various taco joints there, and while I may believe that it's "authentic" that doesn't make it good.  Surely Mexico has some authentically bad places that this place is ripping off.

This is an authentic hole in the wall Mexican restaurant! It is small and cozy, but it can get crowded. The staff is really friendly and the food is great. The downside was that they brought my meal first and took five minutes to bring my companion's dish out and halfway during our meal, they blasted the music really loud . We were still fans of this spot!  I consider this is the place to go whenever I get homesick for my Texas home!

go in this place even if it looks slightly sketchy from the outside.  it is the only place for good mexican near columbia.  the burrito is delicious and comes with a topping of salad.  the tacos are among the best i've ever had.
I love this place so much I once said I wanted to get married here.  The burrito is by far the best.

Alas, a solid authentic Mexican restaurant where the focus is on the food, not the drinks.   The menu is accross the board solid.

Downside:  tacos like the lengua are packed with too much vegetable garnish that distracts from core flavors. 

Yet. the ever-elusive homemade flour tortilla is not to be found.  

A plea to all the Mexican restaurants in NYC:  please visit Texas or New Mexico to see how these rarities are made.  It's not difficult - you just need to make a flour ball and then put it on this conveyor belt that instantanously smushes and cooks it.

there is no "atmostphere" here but you don't come here for that. you come for the religious experience of the aphrodisiac green tomatillo sauce and the hot salsa that makes you see apparitions of the Virgin Mary. You can also get "real" mexican stuff like cactus leaves and goat ceviche (or whatever) if you're brave! 

the little woman and I eat here regularly and always share a dish, which we cannot finish. the waiters are pleasant and the clientel are all regulars. love it love it love it.

they have recently expanded into the neighboring store so they have more dining area. hopefully the quality will stay exactly the same.

It's Great Food. It's Cheap. The Service is Wonderful. It's a hole in the wall. 
I would have walked right by this place a millions time if a friend had not insisted on taking me here 3 years ago. Everyone I know loves the burritos. I however, love the carnitas tacos. They make me happy. And with a side of tamalles I just can't help but smile when my food comes out. As an extra bonus the free chips and salsas hit the table right when you sit down.

I just don't understand, so many people say this place is "good authentic mexican food" and to me it just seems like they are insulting mexican food.  After so many people told me how great this place was I tried it out with a friend.  We both got burritos because they were recommended as "the best around".  Mine was basically a giant mound of disgusting beef wrapped in a tortilla with rice and beans as just an after thought.  What do I mean by disgusting?  there were little bits of bone mixed throughout.  bone?  how do you get bone in there?  
The end result was 2 burritos in the trash after only a few bites.  When i confronted those who said it was great most backed down and said "well I've only been there once or twice"...
... you're on your own

This is a great Mexican joint that comes off looking like a whole in the wall.  The employees are very friendly, and service is prompt and food comes out very fresh.

They use quality ingredients in a menu that balances both classic mexican-american favorites (giant burritos) but the specials and some everyday dishes seem to take you further below the border, using traditional cooking methods and very flavorful sauces.  

If I am in the UWS it is my go to with clients if we're taking a lunch break.  

The best part may be the 3 very different salsa-esque sauces that are on the table.  Try them with the chips and then slather on your burrito!

Note: they use fresh mozzarella a lot as their cheese - this is odd but still tasty.

Yes, I know NYC mexican doesn't compare to that in Texas or California, but La Fonda is darn good regardless of location.  The nopales burrito special was delicious (and Huge) as is the veggie burrito, the salsas are great, the sopes are yummy and tasty, and so on.  It's a little small, but that doesn't bother me. I'd love it even if it weren't so affordable. =)

FIRST, I'm from the great state of Texas, so I KNOW good Mexican (or shall I say, Tex-Mex) food.  This... is "real" Mexican food.  Don't come here looking for "chips and queso" or "chicken wrap with cilantro" type of dishes cause you'll be disappointed like some people that posted before me.  

This isn't the CaliMex/TexMex dishes that us boarder staters have grown accustomed to.  For example, instead of the cheddar/jack cheese that us CaliMex/TexMex fans are used to, they use "Queso oaxaca"  or "asadero" which has a Mozzarella type of texture.  Also, they use "crema" instead of sour cream.  The point is to come in looking for "real" Mexican food, not the Americanized dishes we have all grown to love.

Now onto reviewing it.  Portions are big, meat is great, beans are great, rice is eh, guac is good, veggies are good, atmosphere is... hmm... homely (note: i didn't say homey), staff is friendly, beer is good (costs too much though), food price is excellent.

Again.  DON'T come here looking for Chipotles/Taco-Bell/Del-Taco/Papacitos (for my Texans) type of Mexican food.  This is legit.  This is the real-deal.  If you have never had "real" Mexican food, then come in with an open mind and you'll be pleasantly surprised.  Just don't expect much of an atmosphere.

I'll start with the obligatory I'm from California, so all my ratings are skewed because nothing will taste like authentic Mexican food back home.

My friend took me to "the best mexican place" in the city.  While that isn't true, this place is definitely solid.  The tacos are slightly bigger than most if that's your prerogative.  The tortilla is bigger than a normal corn tortilla and slightly smaller than a flour.  I was tricked at first.  When I saw that taco I was about to go into rage mode and yell at my friend about the fallacies of flour tortillas as a taco base.  YEA I'M A TACO SNOB.  SO?!?!?  haha.

So going back, the Carne Asada meat is pretty tender.  The tortilla is solid.   Good taco.  The Al Pastor (my personal fav. taco) was a disappointment.  They had more pineapples in there than pork.  COME ON!  You don't need pineapples in it anyway, but if you do, don't over power the natural taste of the delicious Al Pastor man.  That's just wrong.

The hot sauce sucked.  That's where the dock in points comes from.  It's the problem I have with almost all NYC taco places.  Everyone has good meat.  But no one has good hot sauce.

Homemade chips and guac was a plus.  They made it unique by topping the guac with added fixin's like jalapeno's, cliantro, tomatoes, and onions.  Pretty unique and righteous.

This is more like a 3.5 stars as Hannah down there points out.  But I rounded down because I rounded down for bad hot sauce.

After exhaustively cross-referencing between suggestions for authentic mexican on the Chow Hound forums and Yelp and Citysearch, I settled on Taqueria y Fonda la Mexicana.

Sadly, the food was disappointing. While it may have been made with authentic flavors and ingredients, the quality left something to be desired. The chips were way too greasy, and cold. The three salsas were not bad (all spicy - something to be aware of) and I did enjoy the avocado salsa.

The enchilada cheese was too tough and stringy, and the tortillas were soft and a little odd on the bottom. Flavors weren't very strong or delicious.

Overall, disappointing :(

You probably won't be telling your grandchildren about this place, but in your next letter home you might say, "Dear Mom, I had my first halfway decent burrito in Manhattan and I couldn't believe it, it was actually cheap!"

I haven't had the carry-out problems others have had who posted so maybe they've gotten things under control.  Things were actually a little slower when I had table service, but I like the folks who run it.  They're friendly in sort of a no-nonsense way.  This is a qualified 4 star because 1) its value and 2) places like this are uncommon in Manhattan, though more common in Chicago, SF, or even Queens.
Excellent authentic Mexican.  Eat it in the shop, as delivery often gets confused.

Excellent delivery thru www.campusfood.com , via which they also have frequent promos. Can't speak to the authenticity, or lack thereof, of it as Mexican fare, but the food was tasty, not too spicy but not by any means bland. As a side note, they included more napkins, utensils, and condiments than you could ever imagine (for better or for worse).

Tiny place with little to offer as far as seating or any of that crap, but what they do offer is more than enough. Certainly one of the best Mexican places in NY. Specials of all different kinds, incredibly authentic, HUGE portions and very reasonably priced. It is kind of like eating at a taco cart, but this would hands down be the best taco cart ever and that is nothing to complain about. Ingredients are fresh, sauces are home made and just the right amount of spicy. You can not go wrong here, unless you are a whiny yuppy who wants better salad options. Go someplace else for that.

This isn't a hole in the wall. This is a hole in the hole. 

But what a glorious, glorious hole it is. Imagine putting your hand into an open sewer and pulling out a nugget of gold. That's what it's like at La Taqueria. A couple of pointers:

1) Make sure you wear your least prized shirt or jeans. Their idea of "ventilation" is "smoke the customers so we know what to serve if the chicken runs out". You will REEK by the end of this. But, again, it will be the smell of the Gods. Mayan Gods, of course.

2) They have this incredible little green sauce that should be poured all over the place, on whatever it is that you are eating. It's a green avocado/onion/chili salsa of sorts, and they only give you one or two. You need more. You need five or six. So, go ahead. Ask for six. And grin proudly, as you watch The Man's look of recognition form on his face. "You like!". "Si. I like".

3) The burritos are basically your weight in food. Don't eat them unless you are ready to finish them. Halting the process would be like interrupting a love-making session with Naomi Campbell. You've gotta finish what you start.

4) I love this place. I really do. It's so ugly, so small, so smelly. But so good, and authentic. And fresh. Fear not. You will survive the experience. I have eaten their food hundreds of times, and have never been sick. Take me to French Roast, and I'll be up all night with The Heart Burn From Hell.

5) Viva Zapata.

There is a burrito crisis in New York City.  There are no good burritos that are affordable, just a sprawling wasteland of soggy tortillas and filthy meat products.  In this decrepit burrito market the best I have experienced is Taqueria y Fonda la Mexicana, an establishment whose name is far too long.

I got a pretty massive burrito for nine bucks and it was large and good.  I'll end this here so I don't have to retype the name of the place.  So much for my discourse on the destitute burrito world.

I'm quite "fonda" this place. (Sorry, couldn't resist.) I agree with many of the other Yelpers' positive comments. TyF has serves reliably good burritos, tacos, tortas, and other Mexican goodies. 

My all-time favorite dish here, however, has to be the chilate (hot spicy chicken soup with herbs -- no soy Mexicano, but I can imagine that this is a staple of hearty winter home cooking); it is a delightful combination of concentrated chicken broth with a fiery kick. The waiters always give me a nod of approval when I order it; the chilate always leaves me satisfied, with fire in my belly (literally). 

A tip regarding the burritos: the ingredients in the filling are often unevenly distributed, so you may run out of lettuce, cheese, and/or quacamole by the time you reach the last 1/3 of the burrito. Be prepared for that; better yet, redistribute the filling a bit before you start eating.

As a native of California, I have not found many Mexican restaurants here that I can endorse wholeheartedly, but TyF is one of them. The food and portions are satisfying, whether you dine-in or order takeout (they deliver); but if you choose to dine-in, beware: wear clothing that you don't mind hanging up for a few days or throwing into the wash immediately. TyF is something of a hole in the wall, with patrons seated close together and within five to ten feet of the open kitchen grill, which means you savor the food aromas long after you have left the restaurant and your appetite has subsided.
   
Most of the menu is solid, but If you like spicy food and chicken soup, try the chilate.

I've been coming here for 10 years and its by far my favorite Mexican place in New York.  
I love that the place is a cozy hole in the wall.  The people there are incredibly friendly and I like feeling like I'm having a home cooked Mexican meal: no frills but delicious.  The ingredients are fresh and the food is consistently good (maybe with exception for the tacos which really are on the dry side).  
The mole rojo, pollo en chipotle, and nogada chicken enchilada are my favorites.  Or is it the fish torta?  Or the tamales?  They make it hard to decide.

I think I've just found my new favorite Mexican taqueria in Manhattan!  I used to think Downtown Bakery in the East Village was the best, but Taqueria y Fonda surprised me and I have to say it's the best Mexican taqueria food I've had in NYC so far.  Yeah it's waaay uptown, but no matter.  I'LL BE BACK.

A good sign that you are in a great Mexican restaurant is the chips.  The chips and salsa set up at Taqueria y Fonda impressed me immediately.  They don't give you any store-bought or wimpy, thin chips.  They don't give you mediocre salsa.  At Taqueria y Fonda you will get a modest bowl of thick, tasty homemade tortilla chips and three different salsas as soon as you are seated at a table.  They offer a red salsa, a green salsa and another guacamole/salsa mix and all are perfect.  They are spicy and fresh and flavorful and they offer plenty of all.

For my entree I ordered the cheese enchiladas with mole sauce.  This plate was something to be reckoned with.  Their cheese enchiladas are filled with some very fresh-tasting Oaxaca cheese and they are very, very generous with that cheese.  And they don't give you two tiny enchiladas -- you get three huge enchiladas that span the length of the plate!  The mole sauce I tried with the enchiladas was amazing.  AMAZING.  The sauce, straight up, is a work of art.  It's definitely the thickest mole sauce I've experienced, but what I liked about it was that the chocolate flavor was very bold and was balanced perfectly with the spiciness of the chilis and the complexity of all the other millions of spices they put in there.  And it tasted fresh, like they had just made it a few hours before.   Even the black refried beans and the yellow rice they served with the plate were awesome.  Usually the beans and rice that come with a plate are just kind of "eh, whatever", but the rice and beans here were soooo good.  I ate them all!  And I appreciated getting a fresh green salad with the meal too.

I can't wait to go back to Taqueria y Fonda and try their tacos, burritos, and other goodness.  I'm sure it's going to be just as good and I really am so excited to have found some Mexican food that rivals all that I used to have in California.  Plus, the people that work here are nice.  They do acknowledge and seat you right away (when you don't have to wait for a table) and they offer expedient, polite waiter service and a good selection of Mexican beers.  Now, I only wish they'd create a downtown location!

The huge chicken burritos are my favorite. And they are not huge because they are Americanized. They are huge because they are filled with fresh rotisseried chicken, beans, rice, vegis and Mexican cheese. Soooo good. An easy thing to crave. The deliveries can take a while, but that's only because they are delivering to so many. Their two lines ring off the hook. It's a total hole in the wall, and we love it.

$3.75 per taco... granted it is huge and filled with tons of meat something bout it just didn't make it taste good enough for me... even tho it smelled awesomeeee

first off takes bout 10 minutes to prepare my two tacos to go?  too slow...

second of all ordered the following:
-lengua - ok that was nice and juicy but lacked flavor... texture wise was all there but i kept adding more lime and nothing... just not good
-carne enchilada taco thinking it would have cheese... nope... just huge pieces of onions that usually i would love but again it was too much onion for me...

i should have known when seeing the makeup of the clientele there it wasn't gonna be super super authentic... or maybe i just ordered the wrong things... the beans looked good... i dunno i wish the other taco joints in the area were open at 9pm!!

Okay, for some reason I thought this place was closed.  But I walked by it today and was happy to find it open.  Cool.  

I stepped in and ordered three tacos - al pastor, chorizo, and lengua.  I was given a bowl of chips and three salsas.  The chips were alright.  Feeling kind of homemade but lacking a little something.  But yards better than Tostitos or some crap.  There were two green salsas, one a little garlicky (?) and one more straight up pureed.  The red salsa was a little creamy (?) and had a slightly off taste.  Anyway, the green salsas were pretty good.

The tacos were $3.75 each with a $.75 surcharge for guac or cheese.  I got guac on all three.  Well, actually, I got a little thing of guac on the side which cost me $2.25.  Besides that, the guac was really forgettable.  Not worth it.  Anyway, the point is that this was an expensive three-taco lunch.

The portions, however, are quite large, somewhat compensating for the relatively high prices.  The downside of large portions, however, was that the tacos tended to fall apart and the garnishes got lost in the mass of meat.  I don't know if I've just been accustomed to having my tatsebuds shocked by Chipolte or whatever, but the meat seemed underseasoned.  Even the chorizo, which really should taste pretty strongly, was a bit bland.  And bland meat in large quantities lends to bland tacos. 

I'd come back here again, but I think they'd be better off with slightly smaller portions and, accordingly, slightly lower prices.  I want to try the mole sauce sometime soon.  And they should work on the guacamole.

3.5 stars, rounded up for the benefit of the doubt.

Short story: The tacos here are legit enough to qualify, in my eyes, as Mexican, and while there are better places in the city, I could easily see this place as being an apropos late-night destination...and goodness, those burritos were mighty swole!

Long story (complete with dissection of said tacos):
- Short primer on judging Mexican food: Yes, good, authentic food is difficult to find in general in the US.  The only areas I've been particularly impressed with are the southern borders of Texas--near my hometown--and California, mainly in the San Ysidro/south SD area (Greater LA and the Bay Area have their pockets, but I've never been floored in either locale).  Everywhere else is hit-or-miss, so I never approach a place with any real amount of hope unless I'm back home, where Yelp doesn't even exist yet.

Ignore all the comments about dingy hole-in-the-wall whatnot.  Either my threshold for cleanliness is extremely low or this place seemed perfectly fine.  I ordered two tacos al pastor and one of carne asada.  I know this place gets a lot of fame for its burritos, but since a burrito is not a genuine Mexican concoction, ordering one would preclude me from rating this place fairly.

The tortillas were white corn, not homemade but correctly doubled-up, as they should be.  I prefer smaller, yellow corn tortillas to be a bit more true to my roots, but I can go with it.  The filling was good for the most part: chopped tomato (not too common in Mexican taqueria-style tacos), both chopped and grilled onion (though the latter was sliced too big and, thus, not properly caramelized), and a hint of cilantro, though I was longing for much more.  All three of the salsas were tasty, though none was particularly hot.  The carne asada was fairly tender, but otherwise could use much more spice and salt.  The pork in the al pastor had too much of the pineapple in the marinade and not enough of the various chiles and other flavors, in my opinion.

Overall, this place is about the most authentic that I've been to in Manhattan, but a bit of searching and traveling to the other boroughs should take you to more representative establishments should you desire something a step above the quick and easy.

Of the Mexican places I've been in New York, this is the best.  It doesn't hold a candle next to your average taco shack in Southern California, but by New York standards it's outstanding.

I love their spicy avocado salsa, which is filled with chunks of avocado and cilantro, with just the right amount of kick to make things interesting.  This is available in unlimited quantities (along with two other types of salsa) for dine in guests, but they are curiously stingy about giving you more than one little container of it for take out orders.

The food here is hit or miss, I've tried a lot here, and some things are very good, and some things are quite bad.  My go-to choice is the carne asada (steak) tacos.  Give them a generous dollop of the avocado salsa and you can't go wrong.  Their burritos are also pretty good, and truly massive.
