The interior is cramped, and nothing to write home about, but the service is friendly and personal.  Overall, for anyone craving an authentic taco shack experience, I would give Taqueria my solid recommendation.

Small, very casual restaurant. Mostly take-out but there are 6-8 tables, so you can sit as well (it can be a bit cramped). Great food. My favorite dish is Camarones a la Diabla (Shrimp in a chipotle sauce) - $11.95 - but there are also giant burritos - $8.75 - and tacos, tortas, etc. The staff is nice, and if you come here often, they will recognize you. We live near by, so we go about once a week. Overall, reliable and friendly.

I mean, it's alright. I don't really get why everyone is in love with Taqueria. Echoing a previous reviewer, the hot sauce sucks. And hot sauce is extremely important in my mind. Also, mozzarella cheese in the burritos?? How exactly is that authentic? Maybe I'm biased because I'm a vegetarian and their menu isn't all that vegetarian friendly. Ah well. The burritos ARE massive though, definitely two meals' worth for your money.

Love this food.  My only regret is not daytripping out to NY sooner to fill the Mexican food void Boston has left in me.  I'm kind of ambivalent about the chips served with the chips and salsa combo, but they appear to be homemade so props.  

They bring you three different salsas: red, green, and greener.  It all tasted funny at first since I'm used to the anglicized Mexican food thrust upon me by the chain and semi-chain 'staunts in Texas.  While I didn't like the green, as it is chock full of onions--which I hate, the red and greener salsas had grown on me by the end of the meal.  

I'm on the outs with cheese these days, so picking an entree was tough but I found one such in the mole verde y puerco.  I haven't had pleasant past experiences with mole so I was a bit worried, but all my fears were assuaged once I tasted it.  The black beans were so fucking good, I actually made sure I ate them all while they were still hot/warm before I touched my meat (huh huh huh huh).  The rice was comparably good, it was very goldilocks the way it was seasoned.  The only downside was the small autopsy I had to perform on my pork in order to not eat bones or cartilage.  Corn tortillas tasted homemade too, so I took the extras to go, but ended up giving them to what was possibly a crack head : (

This is no frills Mexican food.  You go in to a place that could equally be a pizza parlor.  You sit in chair at a small table.  You order, 5 min later you are served and you eat.  Lunch is even cheaper.

Seemingly every time I've gone to visit a friend at Columbia, we end up with tortas.  And with good reason.  They're huge, cheap, and stuffed full of refried bean, avocado, cheese, tomato, and oniony goodness.  Sometimes the choice of meat can be a bit tough and dry, but wikipedia tells me that cecina is Spanish for "meat that has been salted and dried by means of air, sun or smoke" so I guess that one gets a pass.  It'd be nice if they sliced the meat into smaller slices.  Half a torta makes for a pretty filling lunch or breakfast.

Since the first half of the name is taqueria after all, I finally tried the tacos.  They're big and taste fresh, although the carnitas could have used more salt.  Adding of some salsa (three kinds to choose from) definitely helps.

Tasty food for cheap?  Oh yeah.

Dude... seriously this place is tasty...  Taqueria Y Fonda is a small (maybe 12 seat) Mexican spot on 107th and amsterdam that is the epitiomy of the phrase hidden gem.  It couldn't look less assuming in it's location or apperance but the food is actually excellent.  Very authentic Mexican flavors in everything form the chips to the salsas, moles, tamales, and meats.  The mole enchiladas were really special and the carne enchilada and carnitas tacos I had were really special, two is enough by the way.  The spot is poplular with the Columbia kids and can get crowded.  The tables and ambience are pretty basic but its worth waiting for.  Very delicious.

I went in with the promise of great burritos and great atmosphere. The burritos were decent. They were authentic Mexican, but they could have used a little more flavor. I liberally applied the salsas that come out at the beginning of the meal with their thicker version of corn chips, and this helped considerably. I was also disappointed by the atmosphere, as we ended up in the annex. The main space certainly felt authentic, complete with the smell of the grill hanging in the air, but the adjacent space is somewhat forgotten, which may have accounted for the hour it took to get our food.

Definitely my favorite Mexican food in NYC. 

I mean, give me a taco and I'll be happy. I never have anything mean to really say about tacos. But these definitely take gold. The corn tortillas are thick, but not too thick and they never break on me. They never get too soggy to the point where I have juices from meat or salsa forming a river down my sleeve. There's a healthy serving of meat in there - even if it falls out of the tortilla, there's still enough. The cilantro, tomatoes and grilled onions with the lemon make the taco so fresh. I order red sauce and green sauce and enjoy the flavor blast. I've had both the shredded beef and pollo - I'm a pollo fan. 

I've also had the Sopes here - which are pretty loaded, might want to be seated with a napkin on your lap when eating this. 

Real good.
This is a great place for cheap, authentic and tasty mexican food. The people who work there are friendly and the whole experience is no frills, just good eats.

Dirt cheap and super tasty is what I love about this place. Burritos are very tasty. The sauces and dressings that come along with them complimentary on the side are also great. Worth trying for anybody having Mexican food cravings.

Without a doubt some of the most authentic Mexican food in this fine city.  The portions are absolutely huge and the prices are super low.  I've been coming here since I went to B-school at Columbia and this last weekend I came back to this restaurant to satisfy a craving for good Mexican food.  Why is there such a shortage of truly good and authentic Mexican food in Manhattan?  The restaurant was just as it was years ago - excellent food for almost nothing.  The burrito cannot be consumed by one person.  My personal favorite dish is the chicken quesadilla.  It is different from any other quesadilla I've ever had and so very good.  Without a doubt this place is worth a visit.  The only negative here is that the place is small and a bit dirty.  Service is plenty attentive though.

Super authentic, hole-in-the-wall Mexican, with the real deal soft two-bite tacos and the spicy green avocado and roasted pepper sauces. Their cheese is like mozzarella and is highly recommended on everything. Try the alambres if you want everything on the menu in one plate, the most bang for your buck. They even have a lot of regional dishes too, but the big-as-your-head burrito is Veronica's favorite and will last as leftover lunch the next day.

Pricing: Cheap
Venue: Take Out
Cuisine: Mexican
Favorite Dish(es): Chicken Burrito ($8.50), Beef Alambre ($8.95), Carne Asada Taco w/ Cheese ($3.75)

REPOST FROM: http://nynyeateat.com
Delicious, cheap, free delivery, solid vegetarian choices (the vegetable quesadilla is like no other quesadilla you will ever have, and I mean that in a good, good way).  Highly recommend!

I went to this place recently and had a great meal. I'm a big fan of Mexican food. I mean, BIG! I love it and could eat it everyday. I'll try just about any type of Mexican or "Mexican" (i.e. Taco Bell, Del Taco, Taco Cabana). I love the stuff. That being said, I found Taqueria y Fonda to be an enjoyable experience. 

Now, the ambiance..it ain't there. Don't look for fancy b/c you won't get it. Frankly, if you go, don't look around too hard. It might turn you off. You might start thinking, "hmm is my food gonna be handled safely". Yea, it's not pretty. I just ignored it and focused on everything being tasty. My good friend suggested it, so I wanted to make sure I gave it a fair shot. 

The food: I ordered the Tacos Dorados. I'd never heard of this but it's basically tacos that are rolled and deep fried. It was 3 tacos with a salad on top. I know, salad on top? Weird, but good. I got the chicken and was a little scared because someone reviewed this place and said they got a chicken dish and had bones in it. Well, I did not have bones in my chicken, so I don't know what that was all about. I did, however, have dark meat, so if you're not a fan of that, you might pass on ordering chicken. I think in traditional Mexican cuisine, they tend to use dark/darker meat from the chicken. Anyway, I really enjoyed the tacos. My only critique was that I wish there was sauce inside the taco. There was just meat, no cheese or anything. But, luckily, they give you three sauces with your chips and so I just put some of the sauce into the taco and it was great. I also tried my boyfriend's regular tacos. He got the carne asada tacos and honestly, it was some of the best steak I've tasted on a taco. It was very well seasoned and pretty tender. 

Overall, I'd go back to this place. The service was fast and friendly.

I only go for the dachshund sized burritos (carnitas, of course). And what a burrito! After a session with one of these puppies, I feel completely sated yet oddly desire a cigarette. The burrito is a mixture of rice, black beans (pinto not available), lettuce, tomato, and meat (lots of it). If you get it to go, they wrap it in foil so you can eat it with your hands, as God intended a burrito to be eaten. Other places I've been to top the burrito in a sauce then put it in a container for take out. For the love of Pete, how is any self-respecting person supposed to eat a burrito on a bench in the middle of Broadway with a knife and fork? No such problem at Taqueria Y La Fonda.

Yes, you could have a massive burrito or some such other tex-mex thing, but this place has actual authentic Mexican food, and their pork red mole was absolutely delicious, and reasonably cheap too. The service is attentive, and the portions generous. The downside is that the place feels a little food court-y, but I was very pleased with my meal.
Best Mexican I've had in NYC.  Authentic no frills place.  Get the tacos, but not too many because they're huge.  Don't be discouraged if there's a wait - it's worth it.

As a Californian, it's always my goal to find a place in New York with even mediocre Mexican food.  This place isn't bad - tasty beans (even though they use black beans, and a Mexican join should use pinto) and tasty rice.

The most important advice I can give is this: If you order delivery, make sure you say NO SALAD.  That is, unless you want a quesadilla that has a fucking salad on top of it.  Seriously, an entire salad on top of the quesadilla, all wrapped up in foil.  I can't even fathom the though process that went into that.

Also, don't order queso fundido for delivery.  You'll get congealed cheese on top of a tortilla.  I don't know how that's considered queso fundido, but apparently it is. 

Anyway, bottom line, they have some tasty stuff (great tortas), but be specific when you order, because they don't really give a shit.

I'm from the west coast so when I moved to NYC one of my first discoveries was Taqueria y Fonda.  This small gem in the UWS is a hole in the wall but the food is as Mexican authentic as it gets for NYC.  The food is great, the portions are large (for NYC)

This is the only place we've found that remotely resembles San Francisco taqueria fare, and its great!. The tacos and burritos are all excellent, especially doused in the 3 house salsas. The meat is pretty good and there are also several vegetarian options. My only complaint is that the tacos aren't as cheap as they should be (they cost ~3.50 each).

I had the chicken enchiladas with green sauce.  They add lots of different sauces on top of their plates so make sure you ask for them on the side as needed.  I found the dark meat chicken to be just ok.  The green sauce and the soft corn tortillas they were wrapped in might be a welcome treat for someone looking for traditional Mexican food.  I wasn't really impressed with this dish priced at $10.95.

My friend ordered the "doradas," basically a corn tortilla rolled up with chicken and then deep fried.  It also was covered in lettuce and sauces.  He ended up picking out the three doradas and eating them on their own after carefully removing the crema and sauce.  $6.95.

Overall our experience was disappointing as far as the food quality was concerned.  The space (as of Nov 2009) is being renovated so it was a cramped narrow storefront with an open kitchen in the back.  The front door kept slamming everytime the delivery guys came in.  

The service wasn't bad.  Not a place I'd visit again unless I was in the area anyway.   

PS the guy at the next table had a giant burrito which looked like a much better choice than ours.

First word that comes to my mind when I think of Taqueria: greasy.

Not even the food itself, but the atmosphere if you choose to eat there. The smells of the grease fill the place, but as long as you aren't wearing your nice clothes (and who goes to a hole in the wall like this in nice clothes), then who cares? And don't come here thinking you can get away eating healthy... for me, this is a rare once in a while treat. But it is satisfying.

You have to think about the decision to eat there, and deal with (or enjoy) the small cramped greasy feeling tables inside, but get the plus of unlimited (!) fried chips with 3 different kinds of salsas, or take out and not have limitless delicious crunchy warm chips. 

On to the food, which is pretty good.The torta is a Mexican sandwich on bolillo bread and is something I would try if you've never had it. It's delicious and filling.

I usually end up getting the quesadilla, as for me it is the right balance of substance and price (note: not the kind of quesadilla you'd pick up and eat, it's covered with stuff which requires you to fork and knife it).

I've had the burrito for takeout, ans sometimes it's preferable to Chipotle's for me. Not easy to eat though.

They have all different kinds of meat for the more adventurous... There are veggie options too.

So basically, Taqueria is good for an affordable, but flavorful, binge on things you should probably not eat very often.
Hit or miss on quality, especially with delivery. It's some of the best Mexican food in the area, but that isn't saying a lot

I live in the neighborhood and have frequented this place for years.  It's a great little hole in the wall - not a place to go to for a fine dining experience, but the food is tasty, cheap and for the most part, authentic. They do have a few Tex-Mex and other Mexican-American menu items to satisfy all the gringos, but I stay away from those items and have little sympathy for those who order burritos or quesadillas and then complain about the lack of authenticity. Oh, and in response to one of the earlier comments - that was Oaxaca string cheese in your burrito, not mozzarella.  The staff are all really nice, though they can be a bit disorganized when things get busy (which happens frequently).

The tacos are really good and are cheap, but my favorite dish by far is the green chilaquiles (not on the menu, but the restaurant does make it upon request).  Order it with a fried egg or two on top - mouth-watering and big enough for two people to share.

Full disclosure - I don't eat meat, but meat-eating friends who I've taken to have all enjoyed their orders.

All you Californians reviewing this place who loveeee this place HAVE to be from NorCal, because this is not authentic Mexican. Try eating in a REAL hole in the wall in the sketch parts of LA, not your gentrified streets around Mission, before you loudly proclaim you know what real tacos and burritos taste like.

So no, Taqueria is not authentic. Everything is made too coarsely, there's no love in the preparation. Plus side -- the tacos and burritos are huge. Minus side -- the tacos and burritos are not authentically supposed to be huge. And my search for good Mexican in NYC continues. :'(

If you are not looking for anything fancy but for really good Mexican food, this should be your choice. Great quality authentic food, flavorful. Can sometimes be a bit dry so don't forget about the sauce. Very nice nachos with 3 different salsas before every meal.
The place itself is very simple but clean, to me that's the most important.
Nice for take-out and pretty cheap. The staff is always very friendly.

We all know that New York can't do Mexican food. New York likes classy restaurants, focusing more on a faux-upscale sheen than the quality and authenticity of the cuisine. Restaurants like Rosa Mexicana, Shun Lee or Ollie's (while they may be the norm) are caricatures of their respective fares.

Taqueria y Fonda has turned New York's Mexican't into Mexican. (Yes, I went there)

From the standpoint of pure authenticity, Taqueria is the best that New York has to offer in its middle-weight bracket (I would give the heavy-weight bracket to Suenos).

It's not an attractive space, it's in the upper boonies of Manhattan Valley, and it's NOT anywhere near the quality of Mexican that you will find in Tucson or San Diego. But it's the best you'll find in NYC. That may not say a lot, but it's information well worth knowing.

Don't go out of your way to visit Taqueria y Fonda, but if you're in the area, it's a must-try. Call ahead and expect a decent wait for take-out and delivery: they're always busy.

In conclusion: for casual dining and take-out/delivery, go to Taqueria. For a classy, sit-down dinner, I recommend Suenos. If you're a tourist, wait until you visit the west coast to eat Mexican food. I suppose you could just travel to the source, but I don't want to be responsible for someone getting abducted.

This is a hidden gem.  Really well made Mexican food in New York is very hard to find.  I have consistently found the food to be great here.  Fast take out too.  Although I feel like Mexican food doesn't travel well.  
Great tacos.  Great spicy salsas.  G

Ok, forget the fancy mexican restaurants with overpriced dishes, the Mama Mexicana's or Chipolte at the other end the commercialization of Mexican Cuisine.  This place is the real deal, great food, great atmosphere.  The decor leaves a lot to be desired but the restaurant makes up for it in it's neighborhood feel and delectable aromas flowing through the kitchen.  Try the pastor burrito (ask to make sure they use pineapples as it really accents their pastor well)  you won't be disappointed .  Also avoid the guac it's tasteless and yet it's still my favorite Mexican restaurant in the city and if I have any doubts I just look to their absurdly low prices and the high quality of their ingredients.

Like a superhero, Taqueria y Fonda hides its special powers by donning the familiar disguise of a generic Mexican takeout joint.  Even stepping inside to see the modest takeout counter, the handful of tables, and the beer/ soda-filled refrigerator in the back doesn't reveal anything out of the ordinary.

If you start with chips w/ salsa, you do start to suspect something is up.  These are the thick earthy tortilla chips that you don't find at most places - especially hole in the walls.  Even more suspicious, three salsas are provided and none of them are pico de gallo - a spicy red, a green tomatillo, and a creamy but spicy salsa verde.  All three are very good but I found myself going to the green ones over the red.

It was only when my taco ($3) and quesadilla ($4.50) arrived that I realize what this place's true superpower is - the ability to supersize the meat in Mexican dishes.  My carnitas (pork) taco was gi-grande.  The roasted pork was served in nice sized chunks and overflowed from my two soft tortilla shells everytime I picked it up for a bite.  It honestly has more meat than you usually get in 2 tacos...  

Similarly, my chicken quesadilla - usually a dish I find provides too much cheese compared to meat - is the opposite.  This barely resembed a quesadilla - it was more like a rolled taco with lettuce, tomato, and small amounts of avocado and grated cheese over a tortilla shell filled with a lot of grilled chicken and a little bit of melted cheese.

My take on both the taco and quesadilla is the same.  I enjoyed the clean flavors and great value of each but feel like their superpower (huge portions of meat) needed a counterbalance.  Don't get me wrong - I loved the pork and chicken but really could've used some sweetness (maybe pineapple in the pork taco?) or something sharp (more grated cheese?).  Maybe if the meat was spiced more?  Even with adding salsa, I just found the meat in both dishes somewhat out of ratio with the tortilla and other ingredients leading to a bit of taste monotony. 

So I'd give this 5 stars for value but 4 stars on overall taste.  For now, I'll round down to 4 stars - maybe after I try out one of their entrees, I'll mark it up.  Consider it 5 stars if you're a huge meat fan (or on a tight budget)...I'd still recommend the Super Tacos truck on 96th street for a more satisfying, balanced taco....

Just because a place is a hole in the wall doesn't mean that it's good. 

Just because food is authentic doesn't mean that it's good. 

A lot of Yelpers seem to cite these qualities in Taqueria's favor, but it doesn't work for me. I could go to Mexico and find hole-in-the-wall, crappy, authentic food, but that doesn't mean it deserves any more than two stars.

I've eaten here several times and the food is underwhelming. It's not bad, but it tastes like the effort someone who has been in a dead-end job for twenty years and knows it puts into his work - tired and disinterested. 

The giant burrito, Taqueria's big gimmick, is similarly overrated. True to its name, it's a very big burrito, but the flavors don't come together very well and the rice and beans don't cut the avocado. Size matters, but not in this case. Maybe it would work better as a burrito bowl. One of the few things New York's culinary landscape lacks is a good burrito. If any Yelpers know of one in the city, please pass along!

Taqueria's only saving grace is its torta, which is really good and the only reason I keep coming back. You get meat, beans, cheese, lettuce, tomato, jalapeno and avocado all on a bollilo roll. The jalapeno provides the sandwich with the necessary heat and the meat, beans and cheese, when squeezed tightly between the split halves of the roll, come together in a way that escapes the unwieldy burrito. On top of that it's well-priced and almost large enough for two meals.

If you're in the neighborhood and your only criteria for Mexican food is authenticity, then maybe Taqueria will suit you fine. However, if you want good authentic Mexican food, then I'd recommend the taco truck (Super Tacos) on 96th, which, except for the torta, is a lot better.
I could eat here every day for lunch and be happy. The little array of salsas, the chips, the tasty tostadas, tortas and enormous burritos....yum. Actually  I think I will go there right now.

Taqueria Y La Fonda... I'm not so fond of you. 
I was super excited to take my friend here, a native Californian who moved in across the street. I'd never been, but had read all of the fabulous reviews. Huge let down! 
I had a special fish enchilada, and my friend got a couple of beef dishes. Overall the quality, taste, and texture of all of the food was off. The oil used to cook the food was clearly used way too many times. 
The meat also didn't look good. When this was pointed out, lots of talking in Spanish ensued, and then they tried to insist it was fine. O-kay. Great customer service!
After the meal, which we couldn't finish, I felt bloated, not satisfied. My Californian was so offended, he joked about purging the whole meal (yes, weird, I know). 
The size of the burritos, by the way, is ridiculous. It's like they shoved an entire baby cow in there, smothered in beans and cheese and wrapped up in a tortilla for your digestive pleasure. So unnecessary.

As others have said, this is really a hole in the wall, but that's where you generally find the best Mexican.  There was only room for a couple of tables, but there was space to sit mid-afternoon for a late lunch.  If you eat in, they bring you chips and
Their tacos are to die for. I love how cheap it is and how I love the service.  This is what every Mexican hole in the wall wishes it could be like.

I was dog watching up at 96th and I ordered delivery from this place.  I am originally from Texas, so I crave good Mexican in NYC.  And let me tell you, this place is one of the best I have had in NYC.  The flavor of the food is rich, not bland.  It is a little expensive, but of course the entrees are pretty big.  I recommend everyone go here if they want to eat some good stuff, although I've read it's a big hole in the wall with very little space.

When we lived in the neighborhood, for my girlfriend and me this was our favorite restaurant.  We brought others here too.  The food was delicious and incredible.  

The poster below me mentioned their spinach and cheese enchiladas in red sauce- I loved that too!  They make them with shrimp if you ask and they're amazing.  Their giant burritos are truly giant, and they're delicious.  If you get something with chicken, it's good, but watch out for bones.

I've liked almost all of the food I try here.  Their prices are very reasonable, and they deliver.  Delivery may take a while but when it finally gets there it's still hot, so just make sure to order early if you're hungry.

The food here is more authentic-style Mexican than American style Mexican.  If you want American-style, you may be disappointed.  In particular, their nachos and cheese platter, an American-Mexican staple, was just bad- so don't get that!  And if you want American style Mexican, Chipotle is just a block away, and there is also Blockheads close by too.  But if you're okay with having more authentic style food, for quality and quantity for you money, Taqueria is the place to go.

Taqueria y Fonda is the real deal for authentic roll-up-your-sleeves Mexican in the M'side area.  Besides the food, there's nothing pretty about this *tiny* place (...but I'd argue that it does have charm).  Not always lightning fast due to high volume around dinner time.  Although, I must admit, it's entertaining to watch the cooks while waiting for takeout.  These guys are controlled chaos!  I recommend the giant burritos.  They are truly giant and always hit the spot!  Comes with yummy salsa verde and another sauce.  

Dig in!

I must say this is the first time I have had Mexican food, that reminded me of being in Mexico.  

It seems that they do use Oaxaca Cheese.  I had the Chicken Enchiladas Verde and the chicken was not shredded GASP.  It actually had big pieces of chicken.

Next time I will try their guacamole.

Gracias Gracias Gracias

Based on the appearances of this place, I was expecting refried pinto beans and limp iceberg lettuce. But no! 

I ordered vegetarian enchiladas with salsa verde. Green salsa was DELICIOUS. (After reading the other comments I'm realizing it's the less-vibrant green one of their green salsas.) The enchiladas were super fresh and tasty (not like "vegetarian" food you order at most places and it's like limp, soggy broccoli). The side salad was fresh and crisp, with romaine lettuce, red onions, and cherry tomatoes! Black beans were yum.

I agree with some of the other people who said you shouldn't order "faux" Mexican food from this place, like burritos. If you want a good burrito, go to a more Americanized place like Dos Toros. I didn't try a burrito here, but I can make the educated guess that it's not as bomb as their more authentic South Mexican dishes. Next time I'm gonna try the pumpkin seed mole sauce!! (Called Pepian, I think...?)

Definitely coming back, thanks Taqueria y Fonda La Mexicana!

p.s. yes, I'm from California. For what it's worth.

Worst burrito I've ever had.  Huge pieces of romaine lettuce, unflavored white rice and a tiny piece of string cheese (trying to pass for oaxacan cheese) all contributed t an overstuffed behemoth of bad.  

One star for the red salsa which was the only decent thing I ate here.  If this is the best Mexican in NYC I'm gonna have to cook all my own.

I really wanted to like this place because of all the great reviews it received but after experiencing it... it was just ok, at most. I got the steak tacos and it just tasted bland, not much flavor. My friend ordered pork taco but got an order of tongue... I don't know how that happened. The spicy condiments weren't anything special either
Tried some of my friend's burrito and it was mostly filled with rice and beans, not much meat- which also tasted kinda bland- I thought mexican food was supposed to be bursting with flavor!!!

Inconspicuous and unassuming. This is one of those places you think you wouldn't stop to look at as you pass by...but you do. Why? Because its packed and it smells like Mexican Food! Being from Southern California, I must say New York definitely lacks quality Mexican food. Some of the best kind in Mexico and in California come straight from a truck! 

But I digress, I would say this taqueria is definitely bringing NYC closer to real Mexican food. The tacos are my favorite. They're about $3 and pretty large, and make sure you get a lot of onions since they sautee them w/mucho flavor. 

There are two eating rooms, if you think its too crowded in the main room, you can go next door and sit. 

Buen Provecho!

I wanted to love this place--I just moved to the neighborhood, and thought it could be a great alternative to Cascabel (which is fabulous, but definitely a sit-down place) and Chipotle (which is... Chipotle). 

but... no.  I haven't had anything that tasted halfway decent, let alone authentic (maybe I'm just ordering the wrong things?).  and worst of all, the smell of stale frying oil permeates both the shop and the entire block.

This place is legit.  The food is a lot better than what I expected from a hole in the wall.  The restaurant appears family run and everyone is extremely friendly and eager to serve you.

I had the Chicken Enchiladas which were more than decent.  Generous portions of rice and beans were filling and the chicken was extreeemely tasty.  Bonus points for free chips too.

Btw, the doors shuts extremely tight so you might look like an idiot trying to wrench it open with two hands, or while you knock on the glass to which the patrons simply look at you and say "it's open!"

The general Columbia area seems to lack great food but this place is the exception.

Hey, it's really quite ok!

Huge burritos. Economical.

Love watching them grill up the meats. They do know how to pile on the food, so if hunger gets to be a problem, go here.

Their tortilla is not bad, but secretly i would prefer Chipotle's tortilla (I consider C to have thinner, doughier tortillas), to TyF's tortilla (thicker, drier, and perhaps lacking the same texture and flavor I've been searching for). Again, theirs is not bad, but it's not quite there.

I appreciate their appreciation of onions. It's in the hot sauce, salsa, guac, and on the platter in good quantities.

Awesome tacos not to far from Columbia.  I went there 4-5 times, but ordered delivery probably 20+ times.  You wouldn't know from the looks, but the tacos are great.  Among the best in NYC.  And cheap.

So the story is, my two friends from California came to eat at this place before I even heard about it and told me how good it was...Nearly half a year later, I finally dragged my butt up-up-uptown to try it, and all I can say is...WHAT TOOK ME SO LONG?

Being from CA myself, I've whole-heartedly given up on trying to find California-style Mexican food. (It's just not going to happen, people, no matter how hard we dream. California is another country after all...split into North California and South California.) With that said, this place is a genuine New York-style, hole-in-the-wall taqueria--basically, as good as it gets.

I highly recommend the Chicken Pipian! The pumpkin seed sauce might sound funky at first, but it compliments the chicken well. The meal had generous portions and well-cooked, tender meat. My friend also ordered two tamales which were OK. They tasted good, but I think the corners of the tamales were over-heated? Indicating that it wasn't fresh. Would not get them again even though I love tamales. (South California, where are you?)

This is actual Mexican food! It's a pretty exciting discovery, wandering around Columbia-land, and then getting a whiff of something that reminds me of the Mission. 

Absolutely recommend you try this if you're in the area and exceptionally hungry. It's definitely small so not recommended for a large group.

Thank god. I've been desperately searching for a real taqueria in this town. Mexican food in NYC tends to the bland TexMex variety (except some very good and expensive high-end spots), and taqueria's here don't seem to know how to even get a corn tortilla right (rubbery rubbery.) This place does everything very well. The cooking is spot on and there's so much food for the $. Finally a real taqueria.

Taqueria y Fonda is definitely the best Mexican food i've had in NYC. It's heavy but it's massive and flavorful. I got their special spinach and cheese enchilada with tomato sauce and was in heaven. I also appreciated the free chips and three dipping sauces that came to the table. 

I'd say items are on the spicier side of life, but it's possible to get mild stuff if you ask.

Also, there's a pretty awesome beer selection for its size!

The tacos al-pastor here have gone down as some of the best I've had in the states, but at 3.50 per taco they didn't completely win my heart.  The tacos are generously stuffed with meat, but I've had well stuffed tacos before in the $2 range.

Very good if you're in the neighborhood and lookin for a good place to munch on some tacos after a few beers.
When I lived on the UWS, this was my absolute favorite place to order Mexican from.  No frills, but so delicious!!  The mole enchiladas are my fav.

When I lived near Taqueria, all those Californian transplants said that this was the closest place to a Cali burrito.  Having now spent nearly 2 years in California (3 months in the Bay area, 1.5 years in the LA area) I can honestly say that I have not ha

A fantastic hole in the wall, beyond where most Columbia kids dare to venture, to pretend that you're in Mexico for an hour or so.

Charmingly family-friendly and a touch run-down, cheap beer, great food, and fantastic chips; my friends and I used to disappear here in the middle of the day (yes, between classes) and soak up such chips, food and, er, beer.
Gave it another shot. There's no hope for this place!

I'm on a desperate hunt for pozole in the city. I originally am from California, and just moved here, so I'm used to seeing it on every street corner. I settled upon this place because its very close to where I live and last time I was there I remember it being decent.

LIke the other reviewers said I wouldn't necessarily go as far as saying this is the "best authentic taqueria" in all of the city. Just the closest one i've come to so far. But then again I haven't scoured the streets quite yet.

I only wish they had refried and/or whole pinto beans. 
:-(

I've come to this place consistently since 2003 and it was only when I moved away that I started coming here infrequently. I came here last Saturday expecting to have brunch. The website says that they're open at 11AM, but they finally opened around 12PM. Starved, I ran in and ordered quesadillas, while my boyfriend ordered huevos rancheros. We were the first and only customers of the morning. While the food came quickly, I was disappointed by my quesadillas, which on further thought, probably wasn't a quesadilla. Quesadillas are crunchy and stringy on flour tortillas- what I received was folded up meat and cold mozzarella on a corn tortilla. My boyfriend's huevos rancheros looked good, but was a bit on the soggy side. 

All in all, I'm giving this place a 4 stars because I've had such good experiences in the past and I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt that this time was simply a fluke. Maybe it was too early for the chefs to cook or maybe the grill was too clean so our food tasted bland. Whatever the case, for loyalty's sake, I'll be willing to give them one more chance the next time I am near Columbia U. 

Food: in the past, the ridiculously big and hearty burritos have never disappointed me. 
Atmosphere: Very hole-in-the-wall type casual. Spanish music will blare, people will be loud, you will be best friends with strangers sitting close to you if you manage to snag a seat. Busy at night, lines out the door type of deal. On weeknights and weekends, you'll do better to order take-out and have it delivered/pick up.

I was at work, and was craving for some Mexican food. I happened to find this place and I decided to give them a chance. I ordered the mole verde chicken lunch special, which came with salad, rice, and beans.

Pros: The black beans were good, and were a welcome surprise, because I figured that they'd serve pinto beans.

          The salad was nice.

Cons: The salad was in the same container as the food, so the steam pretty much wilted the whole salad.  And I really wish restaurants would stop using Italian dressing as their go-to dressing. It's tangy and overrated.

          The chicken was bland and pink. I felt kinda queasy after eating it.

           The tortillas were actually corn tortillas that were wrapped in foil, so the steam rendered them soggy, gross, and inedible.

I probably won't order from them again. Get some Goya seasoning in your life, man. 

Everything came up to $10.87

This place excels at feeding you til you're stuffed silly for not-exorbitant prices. While the meat portions are generous and free chips/salsa are tasty, the tortillas are too dry and the meats could use more flavor. NYC has a long way to go to match California taquerias, but overall this one will satisfy a craving when desperate.

I ordered from here after  hearing from my boss how much better this place was than blockheads.  Not one to turn down a food recommendation for too long I took the plunge and had myself some chuleta(pork chop) with mole rice and black beans.  Holy wow was it good.  So much flavor, so much spice, so good price.  The only reason I couldn't give them 5 stars was due to the delivery taking forever to get to me.  Otherwise, well worth the minimal price, especially if you like some spice in your life.
Delicious, unpretentious, friendly and thoughtful waitress.

Awesome tacos de lengua and al pastor.
I stop by this place everytime I'm visiting Columbia- I'll gladly come in from New Haven for this place.
True, the seating is pretty limited, but I think it's worth the wait.
The only other places in the city I know with really, authentic Mexican food are up in Jackson Heights.

i have started ordering food here, instead of just eating the chips and living in a state of biased fear.
the cheese quesadilla is so awesome and addictive. quite different from its Blockheads counterpart across the street, it's made with a slightly salty white cheese and covered in a delicious and very tasty salad. dig in.

This place very much soothes my late night taco cravings.  I live a little too far away for the taco cart on 96th street, so I am so glad I found this little hole in the wall place!

I've never actually eaten in the restaurant, only to go orders, so I can't speak too much about service.  However, the food is cheap and quick.  It's not gourmet, but if you're looking for a taco on the go, this is the place! (Chicken tacos are amazing!!)

I would say, it's a small place, just a few tables.  So I don't know if there would be the place I'd take a date or anything.  But if you're looking for a quick bite, then come here.  YAY taqueria!

I love love love this place. I am constantly on the hunt for mexican food of some authenticity and I found this place back in like 2003 and just fell in love. It's an absolute hole in the wall which I must say I enjoy. The grill is right out front and it has a family-affair kinda vibe. My most favorite dish is the camarones a la dilbla. Killer! I could eat that every day; nice and smokey. Usually I throw in a nice hot hot cheese tamale a cold one and the meal is complete.
Only complaint other than the fact that it is nowhere near Brooklyn is that the chips aren't the best I've ever had... but this is no reason to hate.
You can't really beat this place for the price.  Some damn good mexican food.  Its a little less greasy than you might think.  The cactus tacos are fantastic.

I don't understand what the fuss is all about with this place. Is this really the best Mexican food In Morningside? Really? I went about a month ago, craving some tacos and what I ended up with was huge, but the meat was dry and unappetizing. The salsa verde was pretty good, if a little chunky for my taste - but salsa served from a community bowl? blech. The chips were really greasy and a bit on the stale side. It seems that a lot of reviews are from California transplants, so maybe this is what Cali Mexican tastes like, but it certainly isn't anything like the Mexican food in Texas (not even the authentic Mexican food that doesn't come with queso). Maybe it's a regional thing? I'll keep looking for someplace else to satisfy my cravings!
omggggggg...the tacos.

Taqueria y Fonda is my secret Manhattan Valley hole-in-the-wall Mexican Taco Joint.
 
Technically, it's not located in Morningside Heights.  It's LITERALLY a hole in the wall taco joint.  Their cheese is special (kind of stringy like mozzarella).  You can add it on, along with guacamole, to any taco / burrito.  Too much of it will be overkill though, so maybe one order of a taco of burrito with the cheese (queso) is fine in my opinion.
 
Oh yes, to add to the authenticity, Horchata is served here.
The chips are authentic too, dunked straight in oil just like in Mexico.
The varieties of salsa and vinegarized veggies on the side are hot-hot-hot!
 
Be prepared to sweat though, the grill amp up the temperature and the food is greasy!  Also, it's cash only, and the workers barely know Ingles, so it's a good excuse to practice your high school Spanglish when you go.

I had never had Mexican food this good before eating here. Not even in Mexico (and I was actually in real Mexico. Not resort Mexico).

The thing I really, really love about Taqueria is that it is actually two restaurants in one. The first is a hole-in-the-wall taqueria where you can get a $5 taco which comes with three tortillas and, with the free chips, is definitely enough for a meal. Although I always order a tamale with it, because I love their tamales. Still, altogether that's still under $10 for a really filling, really tasty and authentic Mexican meal.

The second Taqueria is the one serving daily specials on a par with the dishes at places like Rosa Mexicana, like chicken mole, fresh fish, and seafood enchiladas in chile verde sauce. These dishes are a bit pricier at $10 -  $15, but, like the tacos, burritos, and tortas, are amazingly tasty and authentic. So no matter what kind of meal you're in the mood for, whether taqueria- or full-on restaurant-style, this place has got you covered.

Now, be aware that Taqueria manages to offer its amazing prices by keeping its overhead low-- they keep the decor and the dining experience basic. We're talking plastic tables and chairs, a tiny TV playing loud South American soccer games in the background, and tables so close to the grill that you walk out with your clothes infused with the smoky smell of the churrasco you just ate. (They'll continue to smell that way until you wash them). They recently expanded into the store next door, so now they have two dining rooms, only one of which contains the grill. But it's still very, very basic. I suspect the owning family handles the service, since we are often served drinks by an adorable eight-year-old. Sometimes the service is great. Other times they're slammed and have trouble keeping up. But they are ALWAYS friendly, which excuses a lot in my book.

I can't comment on the reviews that complain about incorrect orders, since I've never had a problem with mine. Taqueria seems to be getting more popular by the day, so my guess is that they're in the process of working out some kinks related to that, like how many staff members they actually need and such.

Bottom line: EAT HERE. It is likely to be the tastiest, most authentic Mexican food you will ever eat and you will not pay an arm and a leg for it.

Okay. Taquiera is a tough call. Of course you've already heard about the dirt and grime everywhere, the lack of space, the dimness, the squeakiness, push-shoviness, elbow-to-elbow set-up. That's all fine. Just be aware that this hole in the wall serves food appropriate for a hole in the wall. If you're not sure what that means, read on.

What makes this place hard to review for me is that everything they serve is good as long as it's not green. The chips to start the meal arrive a little bit warm; I liked all three of the salsas, not particularly the watery avocado but the really interesting, darker-green one and the spicy red sauce. Still, it's great to get to sample all three.

Looking at the menu (trying not to touch it--it's possibly the most oily piece of laminated paper I've ever got my hands on), you won't find a single green thing on it besides three barely-noticeable salads. I jumped for the house salad and the chicken torta (sandwich).

The place is run by two people: a cashier/server and a cook. Both are friendly; neither speaks much English. As this place was packed soon after I came in at 12:45, I had to wait quite a bit for just the salad, which was thoroughly unimpressive. Big, yes, but just totally boring and relatively tasteless. None of the ingredients seemed fresh.

I finished the chips and waited for the torta, which was well worth it. It came all alone on a plate; I was glad to have ordered a salad, all things considered. The torta was really unique: a huge jumble of chicken, guacamole, cheese, tomato, lettuce, avocado, jalapeño, all on the Mexican equivalent of a Kaiser roll: bolillo bread. I was full halfway into this sandwich; it's enormous. But again, enormous doesn't mean good. In this case, I thought the torta was good, but really grimy and greasy.

In this sense, Taqueria serves authentic Mexican, but the quality of the ingredients and the jumble of ingredients makes for food that tastes like it should come from a street vendor or lunch van. That's not to say it's bad, but it is greasier and grimier than I would have liked.

I won't be going back to Taqueria; the food is good, but good in only a certain way. I can see why there is so much reverence for this place; the type of food served here, however, just isn't my type. In the end, this hole in the wall serves food appropriate for a hole in the wall--honest, yes, but a little much.

The last thing I'll say is that the $ price rating for this place is wrong. If you want a balanced lunch, you'll end up paying $14 with tip. There is no option for a side salad, and each dish is very bare-bones. (My sandwich looked out of place on a plate; it would be at home in a brown bag.)
Great burrito, very very big. Lacked a little veg/freshness that I like in Chipotle burritos, especially w/the corn salsa. Otherwise it was a great burrito, I will probably return.

I've been eating at La Taqueria weekly for the past three years and this place has some of the best tacos I've ever had. You can argue that al pastor (spicy pork with pineapples) is the best, or you can say the bistec (carne asada) tacos are tops, but for me the pollo tacos are numero uno. I just haven't had better anywhere, including Mexico. Two tacos are probably enough to fill but three are perfect. The homemade chips and salsa are also delicious, wash it all down with a tamarindo jarritos. The place is tiny but friendly, or you can order in for delivery.

This place could be good, but my opinion is that it's just far too busy to ever really give them the chance to care about how the food comes out.  I think the turnover rate is more important than the quality. 

I had the chicken chipotle burrito, which was really big.  In comparison to the Chipotle fast food chain, this is a much better alternative for the value.  It was $10.95.  I had 2 Tecate bottles of beer, which were $4 each.  That to me, in this atmosphere, was just far too pricey.  Taqueria Y La Fonda is a hole in the wall.  I wouldn't mind paying $2.50 for a beer here, but $4 is a little too excessive for a hole in the wall.  Anyway, opinionated price points aside, the service lacked attention.   Again, they are just far too busy it seems. 

They give you 3 salsa's and some chips.  The chips are homemade so they're crunchy and fresh, but they lack zing.  The sauces are great.  I used them in my burrito.  I've only been once so I'm not sure which is the hottest, but we suspect that it's the toxic neon green looking one.  Maybe not. 

I also had the chorizo taco, which was also ok.  It had a TON of onions, so if you don't like onions make sure that you tell them, when ordering, to hold off on them, otherwise you will spend half of your time picking the onions out before giving up and just devouring the thing.  Bland tortillas and overkill on the onions aside, the actual chorizo was quite tasty. 

All in all I know I doubt I will come back here, although I may order in once, but I doubt it.

Tried to use a Restaurant.com gift certificate here but was unsuccessful. The restaurant apparently only honors these certificates at dinnertime, though that part was left out of the rules printed on the actual certificate, so I wasn't aware of it going in. Sigh. This sort of surprise has happened to me every single time I've tried to use a Restaurant.com certificate, though, so maybe the blame really lies not so much with the restaurants themselves but with Restaurant.com for not making their policies clear to the restaurants and customers.

Anyway, enough about that. The food here only gets two stars from me. I ordered a veggie burrito with a side of guacamole today and both items were really liquidy. Any fan of real Mexican food knows that guacamole should be thick and creamy, not watery, and it shouldn't have such a high proportion of onions to avocado. More than half of this container is filled with chopped onions! Not cool. And as soon as I unwrapped my burrito, liquid came gushing out of it and it looked like it was going for a swim. Also not cool.

I doubt I will be going back to try and use this certificate again. Let me know if you want it and I'll send it to you, but don't say I didn't warn you about the food!
Great authentic Mexican food!

As with everything in life, my feelings about Taqueria Y La Fonda are best expressed in a series of haikus: 

We live close to you
And come from California
So, with hope, we came.

When we tried to share
A nine dollar burrito
You said we could not.

That was stupid, but
We shrugged and got one taco
For four dollars more.

It is always good
To add flavor to your food. 
This place does not seem

To subscribe to this
Specific philosophy. 
Everything was bland.

Rice and beans were bland.
The chicken was quite bland, too.
And the salsa? Bland.

But then the worst was
When you added one dollar 
To our final bill.

"That's because there was
Guacamole in your food."
You said, to explain.

We did not ask for
That added guacamole.
You just put it there.

We're not paying more
For food we didn't order
(Which was also bland.)

You tried to screw us 
By padding our bill total.
Yeah, we won't be back.

(My fiancé thinks
This review does not express
How "truly awful"

The food at this place
Actually was. He wants 
Me to also say

That Californians
Who endorsed this place should be
"Totally ashamed."

There, I added it.
Are you happier now, babe?
Good. I guess that's that.)

The food is DELICIOUS!  The prices are great for the portions they give (huge), but I wouldn't sit down to eat there, unless you don't mind coming out smelling like food, which is the downside.  It's a tiny place (they expanded to next door, but the smell of food still permeates the air) which can't really accommodate a large group.  Overall great place to get some take-out, you can eat there but you will definitely have the smell of food on your clothes and hair.  Even if you order take-out, wait outside for it.

My home away from home now. It's hard to find good Mexican food on the East Coast. But Taqueria has found a place in this California girl's heart. The place is cramped, but perfect for small group of friends for any meal. It gets really crowded during dinner time, so the best time to go is around 10 p.m. The wait staff is friendly and the meal/experience is worth any wait.

We had a big group of people and came at the height of dinner but they sat us in a pretty reasonable amount of time....

Deep fried chips and salsa are complimentary and excellent....

Giant burritos are the size of guinea pigs... 

Beans and rice are authentic (probably made with lard)-- super tasty

Carne- Cesina (marinated strips of beef) is the way to go!
They have pig ear and tripe tacos!! Enough said.
Good Mexican is hard to find... good mexican in NYC, even harder.... great mexican that isnt overpriced? Would be IMPOSSIBLE if Taqueria didnt exist.

I'd give this place ZERO STARS if I could!!! I went in and asked for 2 tacos al pastor w/out pineapple. The girl said she was going to order me two enchilada meat tacos because it's the same thing minus the pineapple. Im Mexican American I know exactly what the different is between the two tacos.
I let it go and sure enough I get my tacos and it's not what I wanted. On top of that the chicken was so dry and over cooked it was crunchy, so crunchy I cld taste the burnt left over meat or what ever it was!

Not only do I try to still eat it because I had just gotten off a 10hr shift the manager or what ever he was asked me how the food was so I told him the chicken was a little too over cooked. He actually Didn't let me finish and had the nerve to tell me "it's not over cooked it's COOKED what do you what raw chicken??? do you want the health department to shut us down??!!!" and at the same time he has his hands up in the air like he's getting ready to fight with me! I've NEVER EVER in my life had someone in a restaurant business be so disrespectful! I've worked in customer service for years I'm a hairdresser and I've never been thus rude to anyone!

The worst part of all my mother was here visiting from florida and I had been telling her about this place. I had eaten here once before with my boyfriend but there was different cooks and the rude loud guy wearing the glasses wasn't there and the food was good. That was of course almost 2 months ago. I'm giving them 1 star because the horchata is good how ever this particular night that I came with my mother I didn't order it so who even knows if it's still good!

"I'm from California"... But wait! This isn't your standard Californian in NY burrito bitchfest. I think this place is actually pretty good, but it's true their burritos suck /compared to what I'm expecting/.

Let me explain, but first let me list out the good and bad, according to me:
GOOD:
- Carnitas meat - just fatty enough, could have been grilled a little longer but this is typical of true blue Mexican carnitas. (My preferred carnitas are the El Salvadorean crispy style.)
- Chips - They have a good crunch and a nice airy center. If anything they could be a little bit thinner.
- Salsa - take a miss on the red one and the radioactive green one, but don't get your hands off the other green one. Shit is tasty.

BAD:
- The burrito seemed to have been wrapped more competently than I've seen around here, but it was also the size of a land mine so there's no point picking it up anyway.
- Not enough pico de gallo in the burrito.
- Not enough sour cream in the burrito.
- No salsa was spicy enough to even register on my burn-o-meter.
- Salad leaves were way too huge, it felt like I was eating a torta instead of a burrito.
- Mozzarella cheese? Weird.
- Only black beans available. No refried.

Now just because I've mentioned some bad things, I'm not blaming them for those things, expecting them to be fixed next time I show up. 

The first thing to remember about burritos is that they are NOT originally Mexican. They are most famously a California thing. It's easy to assume that when you have a lousy burrito here in NYC, the reason is that they are not actually Mexican, but some imitation latinos making Mexican food, but this is flawed logic. I am pretty sure the peeps here are truly Mexican and it shows in the way they cook their meats.

Plus, not all Mexicans come to the US through California. Far from it. If the Mexicans in California make burritos a certain way, it's because they learned how to make it from their friends in California -- remember, not a native dish. So the California burrito is a geographically limited specialty.

If these guys came here through, say, Texas, and then up to New York, decided to start a restaurant, and realized that everyone wanted these ridiculous burrito things, you would make them based on how they sounded and how similar burritos tasted in the area, then check it off the list of "things people want which should be on the menu even though I have no attachment to them."

"Okay, so apparently you take a huge flour tortilla and smoosh some beans, rice, guacamole, and meat into it. These gringos love the stuff!"
"Anything else I should know?"
"Well, all the ones I tried were big.. so let's make ours BIGGER! USA! USA!"
"I love it! What else?"
"There was cheese inside too. Let's stand out by having a different cheese, like.. mozzarella!"
"Great! That sounds like a real winner!"

... And it probably was, because this fits into the concept of the "NYC" burrito. If you don't compare it to a California burrito, to be honest it's not a bad dish.

Long story short? The way I see it, unless the people are Mexicans who learned how to make [insert pseudo-Mexican dish] in [insert American region], there is no point expecting an [insert American region] [insert pseudo-Mexican dish].

So you're only fooling yourself if you call [insert American region] [insert pseudo-Mexican dish] "authentic Mexican food." Cause it ain't.

Instead, what you should do is focus on the traditional dishes that they grew up with in the old country and really know how to cook because you'll only be disappointed with their version of a [insert pseudo-Mexican dish].

And that's exactly what I shall do next time I return to Taqueria y La Fonda Mexicana, then post another review!

It's always difficult finding decent Mexican or Tex-Mex in NYC and having spent enough time down south, I tend to be much harder on the places that serve that kind of food around here. Taqueria Y La Fonda is one of those few and far between places in NYC that actually serves up really good Mexican/Tex-Mex. 

Walking up Amsterdam you can see that this is as hole-in-the-wall as it gets. Most good authentic Mexican tends to be these little understated places that people would cringe at rather than go in. Yes. This restaurant is much like that, however, it's not one of those authentic places where you are the only one sitting there in a dark corner listening to crickets chirping. Don't expect to be patted on the back for your pioneer spirit of eating here. It's a very well known place around the neighborhood, especially among the Columbia University kids. The reason why it's popular is not because it's a place where you can booze it up over mediocre Tex-Mex. You won't find tipsy, sorority girls cackling over frozen margaritas here. I think the only drink you can get is cerveza. The merit of this place is on the food alone. That's why it's popular. 

The first thing that stands out are the freshly made chips with the three different varieties of homemade salsas, ranging from mild to hot. I love salsa verde so it was nice to see that 2 out of the 3 were variations of that. You can tell they didn't just buy a bulk bag of chips from a bodega and put it in a bowl like some other places. 

The burritos here are so big that they draw attention from the other patrons sitting down. They all had this look on their face that I must have no idea what I was about to undertake. I ordered the pastor burrito, which comes with it's own deed and title. Cutting into the meaty behemoth I felt like I was trying to defuse a bomb. One needs the careful hands of a surgeon. I'm told that most people cannot finish one of the burritos here because of the sheer immensity of it. It was so delicious that I had no other cause but to finish it. 

The next time I come here, and there will be a next time; I will make sure to have the tamales for a lighter fare. Everything is good here. While it might not be Mexico, Texas, or California, you can still get great Mexican on the west side of Manhattan without having to go out west.

Delicious mexican food. eNOURmous burritos that are big enough for two full meals, and very juicy and flavorful meat.  The spicy pork is the best in my opinion.  The chips and salsa are also really good, especially when the chips are hot.  Nice and cheap.  Sometimes it gets a little cramped, and if it gets crowded the service isn't always top notch. Definitely worth checking out.

If you are longing for true Mexican flavors, this is the place to come. The staff is really friendly and the food quality has been certified by at least one Chilango (me). Giant carnitas burritos and the seafood platter are really good. The horchata is great, and they have a good variety of Jarritos. If you have a sweet tooth try the flan . The portions are HUGE. Every Mexican and Mexican-American restaurant in the USA should follow the example set by Taquería y Fonda La Mexicana and offer free chips and salsa. They also have a very good delivery service.

Pros: FAST delivery, fresh ingredients and very generous portion sizes.

Cons: Just ok in the taste department. A little bland and not the Mexican food I am use to back in southern CA.

I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  Have been eating here since I was a student at Columbia and still do.  Totally a hole in the wall spot with some of the most flavorful food I've had in NYC.  Very economical, very tasty.  Friendly staff.  I highly recommend them.

don't come here for salad. come here for mexican food. if you like the taco truck on 96th and bway, this place's tacos blow it out of the water. and are twice the size.

stopped by last night after walking by it tons of times and got the quesadilla with meat. also ordered a taco thinking the quesadilla wouldn't be enough... wrong! the quesadilla is HUGE, two tortillas wide, and very filling. the meat is great quality, better than you would expect, and i inhaled the whole thing, GREAT value for your dollar. will def be giong back!!!

What's not to love about a place that will sell you a beer complete with a paper bag so you can drink it on the street while you wait for a table? The mole enchiladas are delicious, and I love the three different salsas they put on the table with your chips. I don't think the burritos are anything special, but they are huge. And, the margaritas which are not on the menu are also quite tasty. Great neighborhood find.
gimme all them chorizo tacos, oh my god how i love them

A late-night hangout staple, this hole-in-the-wall has decent, cheap food with friendly service and an eclectic music playlist (some of my favorites include Spanish renditions of My Way and Ring of Fire). None of the dishes I've tried really strike me as

The second I saw this place I knew it had to be good. One glimpse through the window and I was instantly reminded of countless similar places in SoCal that, almost always, have delicious and inexpensive Mexican food. It's funky and unpretentious. I've lived near La Fonda for about six years and, in the beginning, I ate here a lot, frequently taking visiting friends from out of town for a convenient and delicious repast. They have a number of really tasty dishes. My favorite is probably the green pepper stuffed with pork, almond, and raisins and served with a cream sauce, rice, beans, and a small salad. They have a delicious black bean soup and their salads are very good too. I especially like the vegetable and avocado salad. 
The burritos are the size of a small fireplace log. Enough for two meals easily.
One of my frequent dining companions always gets the asada burrito and loves it. The aguas frescas are very good, esp the piña and the orange. 
As time went on, however, I found myself frequenting La Fonda less and less. The main reason is that, if you're dining with a companion, they almost never bring both dishes at the same time. Many have been the times when they deliver only one order and, by the time the second platter is served, the first person served is more than halfway through his/her meal. This is very annoying and it's a problem that I've experienced here on too many occasions. Now, when I eat there, I always tell the server, "please bring both plates at the same time". It shouldn't be necessary to give this instruction though and even then, they sometimes don't sync up the service.
My sole other gripe is with their chicken--they use only leg and thigh meat. When I've eaten their chicken tacos, I've frequently had to (how to say it politely?) spit out the gristly bits into a napkin. This isn't so much because the meat is not breast meat, but because of the lack of care taken in chopping up the meat in preparing it. Lastly, their delivery is waaay slow. I live practically right upstairs from the place and it took them more than 45 minutes to deliver a platter. When it arrived, it was lukewarm. If they tightened up their operation, I'd eat here--as I used to--much more often.

I can't believe I ate the whole thing! I picked up the vegetable burrito for dinner last night and just finished the rest of it (yes, I know, it's hardly noon , but I just couldn't resist). My burrito was packed with carrots, mushrooms, peppers, broccoli, guac and cheesy goodness! You can't beat that for $9.00! 

The menu is pretty basic, focusing on mainly burritos, tacos, sopas and general Mexican street food. I think that just means this place really focuses on putting out what they know best. 

The restaurant itself is indeed a hole in the wall, but enchanting none the less. You can see your food being prepared and the cooks sing and chat as they work. The guy who rolled my burrito moved with such speed and grace that he seemed to do a dance as he prepped my dinner. I'll call it the burrito dance!

This will definitely be my go to for a cheap Mexican in my new neighborhood.

Excellent Mexican food...even getting beyond what are frankly pretty low NY standards and expectations.

Spicy fresh salsas, crispy chips, and tasty meat and other ingredients...good steak burritos...and with a fun atmosphere and a pleasantly "hole in the wall" ambiance. I'm a fan.

Mole saucee mmmmmmmm..... Fantastic mexican food. The portions are HUMONGOUS -- you'll definitely get your moneys worth. The place is a hole-in-the-wall on Amsterdam, is ridiculously dirty looking, and is the size of my closet. They do, however, have a separate room a couple of doors down for larger groups. But beware, if they put you there...the waiter will NEVER come. Never. And he'll never come to refill your water. And having no water is close to torture when you're eating most of the stuff on this menu. That said, if you're looking to break from Chipotle type mexican food, this is the place. The food is delicious and there's a dish for the spicy lovers and the spicy haters (like me!) ; meatlovers and vegetarians. The foods not cheap, but it's not expensive either.  Definitely try this place if you're in the area!

cute small neighborhood. best mexican food i've had. i dont really love mexican food but this place is great. i had the veggie/cheese/salmon burrito. it was white cheese, similar to fresh mozzerella.  next time ill leave out the fish, and aske for more beans/less rice.

Even visually, the food is wonderful - you can tell the ingredients are fresh, authentic, and delicious.  

They had unusual specials like Salmon Burrito (somehow it really works!)

Yes the space is very bare bones.  OK, a dump.  But it's worth it.

I love this place. This Taqueria has delicious food with great flavors.

This place may not be for everyone. It is not a high end Mexican restaurant with lots of Tequila and trendy people. It is just a good home style Taqueria that serves good delicious food.

The tacos are all delicious and tasty. They are cooked to perfection with an over abundant amount of meat. Yum. Some people may find them pricey at $3 but I think they are awesome. The tortas sandwich's are all good with my favorite being the chicken Milanese. Tender breaded chicken, avocado, jalapenos, mayo, onions in a round Mexican style bread...outstanding. The explosion of flavors is a wow.

I have been coming here for years and I remembered the good old days when you could just walk in, no waiting. Now this gem of a Taqueria is always busy. Good for them. The owner is always there working hard to make sure everyone enjoys their food.

This is home style cooking in a restaurant. If you want something else this is not your place. If you want to enjoy a nice evening eating tacos, drinking beer and enjoying some tasty food, come on down. This is a great place that won't break the bank while having good food.

Those looking for a California style taqueria, keep looking. HOWEVER, this place is pretty good for NYC and its in my neighborhood, so I'll be likely be back. I'm native New Yorker who spent 8 years in the Bay Area, so I have both high standards and low expectations for taquerias around here.

PROS: 
1. Quality of the ingredients/flavor - both the carnitas and the al pastor were well seasoned, veggies were fresh, queso fresco(!) in the burrito.
2. Nice service
3. Not a total hole in the wall - though modest, they keep it clean

CONS:
1. Proportions/construction - the ratio of meat, rice & beans, guac, cheese were all wrong in my burrito and dude wasn't even able to wrap the tortilla properly because he put way too much of it all in. A proper burrito should be able to be consumed without utensils. Likewise, the taco was overstuffed and the veggies not chopped finely enough.
2. Price - $10 for a burrito? $4 for a taco? I think not.
3. Lettuce in the burrito. granted, it was good quality, but I'm looking for mission-style which never has lettuce IMO.

NEUTRAL:
Chips and salsa - could be better, but both homemade.

I'm still on a quest for a Cali-style truck or taqueria in NY. Message me if know of one.

I freaking love this place!

I love that you can get a delicious burrito almost the length of my forearm (and twice as thick) for not that much money at all.  I've only actually gotten the burrito now that I'm thinking about it, but my wife absolutely loves everything she's had, although it's a little hard to get her there because she says the food is too spicy and gives her heart burn (to which I usually respond "don't order spicy food then", but that's neither here nor there).

The limeade is easily among my favorite beverages of all time, the salsas they give you with their home made chips are really intense but really amazing and as I said, the portion sizes border on ridiculous.

My only real gripe with the place (barring the fact that you're pretty much always going to bring home leftovers and sour cream doesn't microwave well) is the tiny size of the restaurant.  It is literally a hole in the wall.  

If I weren't so selective about giving out 5 star reviews, it would probably get one.

Nothing to brag about unless you're desperate.  Based on prior Yelp reviews I had high hopes for this restaurant, but I should've listened to the large minority of Yelpers who claimed that it wasn't anything special.  Whether or not it's an authentic Mexican restaurant isn't even in the picture (although I think it was close to, but not quite, authentic).  The food was just poorly prepared.  My pollo taco was completely flavorless and the tortilla shells were so soggy that it was almost inedible.  My pollo tamale was slightly better, but there was hardly any chicken in it and they definitely didn't put in enough sauce.  Also, they forgot to give me the salsa that I requested.  Maybe if you dine in your food will be better, but definitely don't get delivery.  The only good thing was the price: $7.40 for a taco and a tamale.  I'd rather spend double on something edible though.

Are you really hungry? Could you eat a burrito the size of a baby? Then this is the place to go. It's affordable, it's fast, it's delicioso. The service is good, too. My waitress always makes me laugh. They seem to be a family-run business and they treat their customers with a warmth that you find when you're welcomed into someone's home for dinner. They have a couple small tables outdoors and I like to sit there and people watch. Their chips and salsa are to die for. I love this place so much and highly recommend them.

This place has the best green chicken tamales I've ever eaten. They're moist and just the right amount of spicy. I would skip the tacos, because every time I've had them the meat was overcooked and they were super dry. The main dishes are pretty good too.

People who are reviewing this place looking for great burritos need to chill out. This is obviously more of an authentic mexican place than a chipotles, and they've only got burritos available for Americans who are afraid to order real mexican food.

Delish! Cheap! WOW!
Sad that I've lived near this place for years and somehow hadn't stopped in!
EVERYTHING I've tried is fantastic! Burritos are huge! GO for the Sopas with Pork or Chicken and BOTH red and green sauces.

It's in the front of my delivery menu book now!

DEFINITELY a hole hole in the wall.  I honestly would have never found this place if I wasn't actively searching for it. 

Ordered Carne Asada taco (~$4 total including tip and tax) just as a snack.  A generous mound of meat was piled atop 2 small soft tortillas.  Meat was on the dry side, but with added salsa, I got my taco working to a consistency of my liking.  

My dish was just the Average Joe of tacos so I'd give this place 2.5 stars, but seeing the entrees that my friends ordered, MAN they looked sooo much better and more appetizing.  I'll have to give their other food a shot the next time I'm back!

Oh, almost forgot, free chips served with 3 different salsas (one was avocado-based not guacamole, and two other salsas.)  Delicious!

Taqueria is absolutely best for Mexican food in the neighborhood. I almost always get a chicken quesadilla - simple I know, but it always hits the spot. The chicken is so well-seasoned and it's filled with fresh vegetables and yummy cheese. It's the perfect amount to fill you up without being greasy. I would choose a burrito from here over Chipotle ten times over. The homemade chips and guacamole are also delicious. It's a small, authentic, family run restaurant with fast and kind service. No frills, cheap, and scrumptious every time!

This hole-in-the-wall of a restaurant probably has the best burrito I've had in all my 21* years of living in NYC.

Their vegetarian options didn't steal any grace or flavor from my burrito. In fact, I think I had the Big Eye syndrome. You know, the case in which your eyes are bigger than your stomach. I'm taller than average, but I'm little. 

It was just so big.

I think my jaw dropped when the disproportionately shorter person brought the burrito to me.

First I attempted to deconstruct part of it, because I was with company and trying to make a good impression that didn't feature refried beans and veggie vestiges all over my face. But even after a few bites, it still was too much. 

So there you have it, a bean burrito from Taqueria y Fonda can feed a microcosm, or in my case, keep you digging into it for two sittings.

*I'm 23. I factored in the years in which I had teeth, which if I'm not mistaken match this figure.

Sorry Taqueria Y la Fonda ... I tried to like you .

I had the chorizo tacos and was not  really impressed.  Not that they were of bad quality , just that I have had better. 

I have gotten chorizo tacos in several other places and these weren't all that great. 

The red flag should've been that when I walked in ...the only Mexican eating there was someone that worked there and was on break... ( Key indicator my friends ! )
..but I decided to give the place a try anyway.

I feel like chorizo tacos should be succulent because chorizo has enough fat that there is very little chance that it comes out dry unless over cooked. 

The tacos had very little flavor . Also at $3.65 each taco , this isn't exactly cheap  for it to be flavorless AND dry !? C'monnnn.

I definitely like Taco Mix in East Harlem better . 

The challenge with ethnic eateries in gentrified areas(hello Columbia ! ) is that they serve more affluent , non- Mexican clientele therefore they is no reason to keep the food up to " Mexican par " ..... these guys wouldn't dare to sell these in a street corner in Los Angeles !

Anyway ... this place is good if your other choice is Chipotle down the street...but as far as  " quality , authentic  taquerias " this place ain't it .  The ones I tried in Union City , NJ and East Harlem are far more authentic and flavorful .

Outside (and actually, from the inside too) it doesn't look like much. Inside was the best vegan meal I've eaten at a restaurant that serves mostly authentic Mexican food. I had the vegetarian burrito made vegan. They included more than your standard vegetables - carrots, broccoli, mushrooms, peppers, as well as a good portion of guacamole. I immediately entered a food coma upon consuming it. My meal delicious, satisfying, inexpensive and will feed me tomorrow for lunch as well. My only complaint was they should have salted it a bit more to begin with, but I may just be spoiled by over-salted Tex-Mex.

If I'm craving Mexican food and don't feel like traveling, it does the trick. It's small so I've never eaten in, take-out only for me. My favorites are cheese tortas and horchata. Everything's pretty damn cheap and I've never had a problem placing an order via phone. I've found meat (especially chicken) to be dry time to time though.

This place looks just like a hole in the wall, but when it comes down to it it's pretty damn classy. Not only do they bring you a big basket of chips up front, but they give you three different salsas--green, red, and hot avacado, that are delicious. When you get around to ordering a giant burrito, you'll only be able to eat half of it.

Not because it isn't delicious, just because it's the size of your arm. In fact it's wonderful. I get the carnitas, spicy pork heaven surrounded by rice, beans, and vegetables made even more perfect when you scoop on any of the aforementioned salsas. The giant burritos cost $8.50, but you're getting more than your money's worth, trust me.
