And if you get tired of burritos (is that possible?) there are lots of authentic Mexican dishes I have not yet experimented with.

The service is quick and smiling, and to add to the classiness you can get wine by the glass ($4) or the bottle (around $15). I couldn't recommend a better place for fine burrito dining.

I checked this place out after I read about it on another website.  It was highly recommended by reviewers on that site... also, it's apparently a perennial favorite among the Columbia University  set for having pretty cheap (under $10), authentic Mexican food.

So one night, I stopped in to order take-out and proceeded to wait for maybe 30-40 minutes during which I grew increasingly desperate and started to consider stabbing myself in the eye.  I thought, "That'll show them.  Everyone will feel so bad for neglecting me and that they're too late to do anything about it.  They'll feel soo guilty for ignoring me and not noticing the warning signals.  Yeah, that'll teach them alright.  That'll teach them all."

In the end, I got my food (the chicken mole rojo), which was ok but nothing to write home about and definitely not worth the wait.  I noticed that the people who were sitting down also looked like they were waiting forever.  Meanwhile, delivery orders kept going out so maybe that's a better choice if you want to try it out.

UPDATE:  delivery's not faster.  they're just slow as molasses here.

Yes, this place is a "hole in the wall", but it wasn't a dirty "hole in the wall". If that makes any sense. It, too me at least, seemed to be a typical small mexican food joint. So small in fact, that you would not expect table service. Especially looking at the decor. It seems like a real casual place from the outside. But to my surprise, there is table service. The food: I would have to say that this was some solid mexican food. Granted, I am NOT a connoisseur of Mexican food. I can tell you however that this food *is* closer to authentic Mexican food than you will find at Taco Bell or Crapotle. I ordered the Carne Asada Tacos and they were quite tasty. They were a little on the expensive per taco. At $3.25 per taco, I wasn't expecting to pay that much. (See above; "hole in the wall") But it was well  worth it because those were the best tacos I've had outside of Mexico. The steak was seasoned very well and the portions were huge. To summarize, I would definitely recommend this place to someone looking for good Mexican food in the Morningside Heights area.

First, let me just say that I have been a fan of this place since 2002. Things were cheaper, better and simpler back then. I understand some of the negatives listed by others, and I completely agree. Honestly, over the past 2 years, it's been really hit or miss in terms of quality. I like it, on one hand, because you're not going to find better value for your $10 than a giant burrito. However, I've had times here when they even managed to make so-so burritos. Other times, they throw in free chips to your delivery orders, other times not. There seems to be no rhyme or reason to if you'll see Taqueria Y La Fonda's Jekyll or Mr. Hyde., but when it's good, it's on par with the more expensive places in the same area.
Good food, EXTREMELY long deliver time, horrible customer service when you call them with an inquiry

Good, old-fashioned, yummy and bad-for-you Mexican food. Chipotle types leave the guilt at the door: from the salted chips saturated in oil to the deep-fried taquitos stuffed with your choice of chicken, fish, or ANY part of the cow or pig, this is as gritty and authentic as you'll find in New York City. While the cooking seems to derive from latitudes farther south than the typical Baja and Sonoran styles found on the West Coast (and they are rather heavy on the garnish), Taqueria y Fonda is a great little UWS secret and perfect for take-out/delivery.

Don't let the look of the place scare you off, it's actually really great. There are very few tables, but we went on a Monday night so it wasn't too crowded. You get chips with 3 kinds of salsa to start which was totally yummy. We both ordered tortas (Mexican sandwiches) and they were really good and really filling. The chicken on mine was marinated and juicy. If only they had margaritas (I think they have beer and some wine?).

used to walk 10 blocks to this place all the time when i lived on UWS.

usually got the burrito, which was the size of Rick Moranis.  it is very authentic (ie. not california style), mexican cheese, liquidy sour cream ladled over the top, heavy with beans and rice.  usually it would last me two meals. 

also i like how small and intimate this place is, probably ony 6 or 7 tables.  they serve beer too, so you can have a super cheap meal and drink too.   

always feels like a real old school new york experience dining there.

I loved this place in college, but maybe it's changed or maybe after eating tacos in Mexico and having had other Mexican food, I realize that this place isn't that good.  

The tacos are fine: the meat is flavorful and they use corn tortillas.  It's the other food that's really lacking. I ordered the bistek a la mexicana; it's was worse than a diner steak, a very thin piece of bland dry beef.  It was terrible; I didn't even keep the leftovers.  Plus we waited for about 25 minutes for the food on a rainy Wednesday; the servers seemed much busier taking care of carry-out orders.

Maybe this place invites criticism. Maybe this hot, hole-in-wall den of a Mexican restaurant is too much for some to bear; it's not hard to imagine how these Upper West Siders might be unaccustomed to its true authenticity. These two-stars and three-stars I see here confound me.

Yes, this place is damn tasty.

Your long awaited meal (there's a line to be seated most nights) always begins with chips and salsa. (Three kinds!) Both are definitely homemade. The service is quick because the food is made two yards away from you. The portions are hefty and nearing bursting with its own ingredients. Try the $8 giant burrito - it feeds two, so be prepared to share!

Always choose your carne's wisely - some are juicier and tastier than others, but it shouldn't be hard to remember a few Spanish words. The drink selection is small but nice; few occasions are too unremarkable for a cold Negra Modelo with your tacos.

Taqueria is incredibly affordable. I've come here on dates (kinda), pregaming dinners and movies, even in a pack of 20+. (On that occasion, we waited outside in the cold just to order takeout, and they even brought chips out to us.) If you're in the area, take advantage. The nearest Mexican place might be Chipotle, and c'mon, why would you want to be their patrons?

Oh, and they have a jukebox?

This place serves huge burritos that have to be eaten on a plate lest you end up wearing your enormous dinner. Also, the best tamales in the neighborhood. 

The cecina (salted pork), however, is pretty bad. But it's the only thing I've ever ordered from t

really really good southern Mexican food. The big burritos are fantastic and only 8.50 and their salsas are delicious and spicy!!

The space it tiny and they can take a while to deliver but the food is SUPERB.

DO NOT ORDER THE ENCHILADAS IN RED MOLE SAUCE. The sauce is dark brown and tastes like burnt toast which is apparently normal. It was inedible, and I'm not a picky eater. When I called and tried to return it they wanted to make me pay for another meal. The woman on the phone was nice at least but recommended I ask to sample the sauce next time. That would have been great except it was a delivery order so it's not like they were going to deliver me a sample of mole sauce before I got my food. In my opinion, enchiladas should not be a risky order. I have eaten mexican food all my life and this was a big letdown

If I were to just eat the chips, drink a few Especials and call it a day, things would be fine.. 

 college kids.. 

Yes the food is cheap,          Dried out       of over cooked marinated                   fllat top grill... The                           a ton of peppers and onions.. 

Had    quesadilla        .. Cubed chunks of             , onions and peppers, served with Queso Oaxaca          cold tortilla.. 

        dont have    usual Taqueria fare.. They have pastor and        and a     .. they all come       tasting like peppers and onions               cooked to a dry indisting   e c     tency. 

5 bucks a beer....

This is great Mexican food with some authentic dishes and others that aren't so authentic.  The tacos are an expensive $3.50, but they put in much more meat than an authentic taco so it's kinda worth it even though I prefer the cheaper $2 tacos that are the authentic size and taste.  This place's strengths aren't in the tacos or the street Mexican food as much as the entrees like mole and enchiladas.  They deliver, but they're delivery range is surprisingly small.

Great mexican food at great prices.  it has the atmosphere of a tiny, hole in the wall greasy spoon, but the food is great.  the burritos are enormous and super flavorful.  the soups are very tasty and the mole is extremely rich.  The pastor tacos are cheap and delicious as well.

Charming and delicious. It's kind of a tiny hole-in-the-wall, a real family vibe. The food is wonderful, and one of the few places in NYC where you can get authentic Mexican food. Prices are reasonable, and the people who run it are really friendly, nice people.

For the money, the taqueria is your best bet. The vegetarian food is amazing--try a vegetable quesadilla for under 5 bucks!  Or a humungous burrito.
I have actually eaten the chicken, which is not always very good.  Maybe it's just that I feel guilty for eating chicken, but I think they overload it with dark meat and you can't request a change.
However, they give you a whole lot of shrimp if you order a shrimp entree, with tons of fresh vegetables and sauces. 

Anyway,  I still think this is a good deal.
Good Mexican food for NYC, but I've had way better Mexican food in California. I like the horchatas. Good delivery service too.

We were wandering up to St. John the Divine and famished. So I whipped out my IPhone, opened my Yelp app and T y F popped up with 90+ reviews averaging four stars.  There are tons of Tacquerias in NYC.  It's comical how similar they all look. Typically family run, Brightly lit with florescent lighting that brings out your coyote ugly, six to ten formica tables, a soda refrigerator next to the cash register and 8.5 x 11 portrait folded menus that have been laminated at the local Kinkos.

Ah, that is when you storm in, sit yourself down and order some of the best Mexican food in Manhattan. Oh and what is it I spy on the wall? Yes, that is a wine and beer list. One Negro Modello, no make that two.  We split a giant and I do mean GIANT burrito filled with rice, beans, lettuce, cheese (the wildest cheese I've ever seen in a burrito), huge chunks of chicken and a flour tortilla that had long since exploded under pressure.

They brought us three different types of salsa to choose from. There was a red one, a green one and en even greener one that had chunks of avocado and onions in it.  The chips are the kind you would expect to get off a truck in South Los Angeles.  They're an acquired taste, but felt like home.

As this was my first visit, I cannot speak for any of their other south of the border offerings, but I will say there were many to choose from.

If you're up near Columbia, swing by and check it out.

business.full_address:
3151 Broadway
Harlem
New York, NY 10027
business.name: El Porton Bar and Restaurant

reviews.text: Didn't really enjoy my experience here. There was a group of very loud, foul-mouthed men around the bar area who appearantly were friends of the staff. They certainly didn't help the atmosphere. I got the chicken mole enchaladas, which were ok, but certainly not worth the price. Also, my glass of horchata was half ice and was gone in three sucks at the straw... certainly not worth three dollars! I only decided to try this place because Toast down the street was packed. I was the only customer in the restaurant other than the obnoxious guys at the bar, which I guess should have been a bad sign.
I agree everyone there is nothing fancy here, just a pleasant neighborhood place. My food was mediocre at best.  I will most likely never find my way back.

A few other graduate students and I ordered from this place to help fuel our end of the semester celebration. We were amazed that they would deliver until 12 on a weeknight, and we had a strong craving for Mexican food. We also heard that they deliver margaritas in hilarious Chinese restaurant soup containers, which was an added plus. 

We ordered delivery, which was a mistake. Ridiculously crappy service and the fact that it was only a mediocre value kill this place for me. The menu has a large variety of options, but in my opinion prices were jacked about a dollar or two higher than what was fair, and this takes a toll on the poor graduate student's budget. Even though we made sure to repeat our order three times and have it repeated back to us to ensure it was understood, they still mixed up two of my friend's orders, and if one were a vegetarian it could have been the difference between dinner and no dinner. Also, they tacked on a mysterious delivery charge that caused my $10 Nachos to spike up to $16 when all was said and done (and the delivery charge was split between 3 people).

There was absolutely nothing special about the food. The best part about my meal was a wedge of avocado my friend had on the side of her burrito that she gave to me, so I probably could have walked to Appletree Market, bought an avocado, and saved myself $12. I will likely never order from this place ever again, and I'd only halfheartedly recommend it if it's late at night, you're desperate for takeout, and nothing else is open.

Seriously the best Chimichanga I've ever had. Had the Chorizo and it was perfect and huge! The salsa was a little disappointing but I'm definitely going back to try their other entrees. Oh, and the margaritas were also perfect! One was enough to keep me flying through dinner and on the walk back home.

the fish tacos rule.

tried the barbacoa 'cause i'd never had goat. it was good, albeit a tiny bit too dry. but i'd try it again just to be sure.

the margaritas are good and made fresh. - though like everywhere else, the price has gone through the roof for lime juice and tequila. maybe salt is expensive these days.

I'll admit, I like their flautas con queso.  

But how the **** do they always forget to give me plasticware and salsa when I order in???

I just ordered delivery (chicken fajitas) and I thought it was delicious!! I don't know why some of the people on here don't like it. The chicken and onions, peppers were so fresh, so were the tortillas. Thumbs up and I will order again.

We just ordered delivery and paid $40 for food that was either inedible (chuletas de puerco - waaaay overdone) or not what we ordered (enchiladas mole instead of verde). Needless to say we will not be ordering from or going to this place again. I don't like mole sauce, but I'm pretty sure that even if you do, you won't be impressed by theirs. The guacamole was bland - I had to add salt; mine is much better. I wish we had bothered walking there so we could have sent our food back to the kitchen.

A good bet for dinner/lunch in the area.  Very resonable prices and good south-of-the-border comfort food.  Nothing fancy here, just a pleasant neighborhood place with free chips and salsa, and great enchiladas and chimichangas.  The fresh corn tortillas are another bonus.  Though they don't have any tap beer, the bottle selection includes a bunch of Mexican beers and the mixed drinks are potent.  Come to enjoy some simple, hearty food, but don't expect to be thrilled by plating or innovation -- just classically good grub.

This place is awful. The food was flavorless -- unless you count "grease" as a flavor.
Taco Bell is better.
Skip it.
Walk down to La Fonda instead.

Really this place is sometimes a three and sometimes a five. The portion sizes vary, making the price more or less worth it, and the quality varies. I've never had bad food from here, but sometimes it is amazing and sometimes it is just kind of decent. It is also much better at the place than delivered. The best part of El Porton is the fact that they will put delicious mole on anything on the menu. I also had some ridiculously good chips and salsa here, when normally I try to avoid eating any to save room for my meal. Warm, fresh chips and amazing salsa, followed by the best cheese enchiladas with mole I've had on the East Coast. It was fantastic.

Most recently I ordered a vegetable chimichanga for delivery. The delivery service is always prompt. In fact, it seems that it may be all too prompt as my chimichanga was undercooked: soggy, disgusting, limp. I finished it despite my best instincts and woke up several hours later at 4am with an effusive maroon stool. This issue sullied my entire week, and I didn't return to normal digestive activity until several days later. I will never order from El Porton again, and I will do my best to warn everyone I know against ordering from them as well.

$9.95 for a brunch dish, chips to start and a choice of drink, which includes a margarita? Where do I sign up. That is a pretty solid deal for a weekend when you don't feel like eating the same old cheerios. 

The chips and salsa were fresh and vibrant. The chorizo and black bean omelette was fresh and came out super hot. The only complaint was that my wife's huevos rancheros came out with eggs that were not still soft and therefore a bit dry. Other than that, getting 2 drinks and 2 brunch dishes for $20 is a superb deal. 

They also offer a 7.95 lunch deal with a choice of a dish and drink. I'll be back soon for that.
They make a mean torta. It was great. Good margaritas. Good guac and salsa and ships. Good water. That's everything I had...

So i went there today for the lunch special because a co-worker thought it was great place and I am going to have to agree with him.  I will preface with this, when we got there the place was empty so the only person working the front didnt have much to do but serve us. He promptly brought out some chips and salsa and it was very good. Some people prefer their salsa to be big and chucky but this was not that. It was on the watery side but still very tasty in my point of view and I am one of those that doesn't really like the big chucky stuff.
I ordered the chicken chimichanga with out beans and it was delicous.  The yellow rice was moist, fluffy and tasty.  It came out pretty quick but once again we were the only ones there at that time (noon).  
I have to say that i would try this place again and plan to.

Yes, you are the lucky one to receive my two star review.

It was nothing special, in fact my Giant Burrito was luke warm.  The tortilla was kind of dry as was the contents inside. hmmmmm

Sorry charlie, I would walk on bye.

Food is good (order the fajitas with rice and beans). Don't get delivery, go to the restaurant. You will be disappointed with delivery

A little overpriced for the neighborhood and ambiance, but in general you will get your fix of Mexican food here.

Service is a little slow, but always extremely kind and accommodating. Annoying regulars who sit at the bar and act like they own the place.

Every time i come I love to get me a chicken quesadilla or chorizo tacos. They are both just delicious. The guac is good too plus it's a decent place to watch the big game as long as you don't mind not hearing it. Relaxed atmosphere makes a nice for conversation. I got to admit it is little bit pricey but it will not empty your wallet. I can't help but give it four stars based on its attentive staff.

HANDS DOWN THE BEST MARGARITA IN TOWN. Not too sweet & very potent. 

Okay okay, I haven't tried every margarita in all of New York City, but seriously, its damn good and keeps me coming back here all the time despite the semi-expensive, so-so quality food. 

Also, they don't care if you take up a table just for drinks and free chips & salsa.  Great atmosphere. No pressure, just a good time.

I know the food here isn't gourmet, but i don't think it's disgusting at all and i've been here probably 8 times since i've lived in the neighborhood.  Not sure why all these other folks hate it so much.

The 7.95 lunch special on weekdays is the way to go!  Otherwise it's overpriced.  But you can't beat this deal - tasty chips and salsa out as soon as you sit down, a decent entree and a drink (and yes, it can be a tiny margarita or glass of sangria, and the margaritas are pretty good).
SO worth it.  The brunch special is ok too, but slightly more expensive.

I went here for a low key dinner with friends and had a great time!  The portions were huge and reasonably priced.  I ordered the vegetarian burrito for $10.95 and it provided me with 3 full meals.  Though not perceivable from the exterior, the design inside was really cute and comfortable.
I live in the neighborhood, so have been here and ordered from here many times simply because of convenience. Food is just OK, and definitely overpriced.

Been there 3 times - and I regretted going both the first and last time. Rather overpriced, food isn't very tasty. Beers ought to be cheaper when they aren't draft. This is place is mostly just a bar with a Mexican twist.

Previously I gave this restaurant 5 stars, but I'm bringing it down to a 4. It's gotten too pricey for us! I think it's about $11-14 for a burrito. I know their burritos are great but not *that* great. Also, their steak burritos sometimes have questionable non-meat parts in them. Mostly steak, but some fat/skin. Not a fan. Go for the chicken burrito.

I've eaten at El Porton Bar & Restaurant twice and recently decided to call up for delivery since I live only a few blocks away. While the chimichanga de pollo has always been super yummy, the chimichanga that was delievered to me was less than perfect. I have to say, unfortunately, if you want a quality meal from El Porton your best guess is to dine at the restaurant!

I give this place four stars for four reasons:

1. Hours of operation. Open till 2AM some nights. Great for students/neighborhood people who want good mexican food after hours.

2. Food. No, it's not world-class mexican food. But since when is world-class Mexican food what you crave at 1AM on a Tuesday? Give me a cheesy, saucy, plate any day and I'm happy. The food is comforting, filling, and all-around good. 

3. Atmosphere. Great place to be noisy or have a conversation. They're very accommodating to large groups, too. Usually there's a game on the flat screen tv at the bar. Even though it's in a seedy neighborhood the restaurant maintains an air of pleasant rattiness. You can be comfortable.

4. Staff. Super friendly, attentive, English speaking waiters, bartenders, etc. They greet you, take your order, and leave you alone. Food arrives fairly quickly and chips are at the ready!

I've had numerous excellent late-night adventures here. Good food, friends, drinks, what have you.

The people giving this rave 4 and 5 star reviews either have no palette or have never tasted real Mexican food so they have no concept of what a poor example of it El Porton sets.

The dishes we ordered were incredibly bland, completely under-seasoned, soggy tortillas and the ingredients weren't even fresh. I wouldn't say it was terrible per say, just extremely disappointing and uninteresting. It was also really expensive for what it was.

I ordered the oaxaca and marinated pork quesadilla...not only did they not put any pork on it but it barely had any cheese on it either! It was like eating a dry tortilla served with browning lettuce and crappy bland guacamole. 

Stay away from this joint, try East Harlem if you want awesome Mexican, there are numerous excellent mom and pop joints there.

I think for what they give you except for the huge burritos they are ridiculously over priced.
I've had cheaper and better mexican food elsewhere.  The service is inattentive and we were the only table in there.  I ordered chilaquiles with green sauce and

Went with the intention of grabbing quick lunch special takeout and heading back to work. Subjected myself to an empty place reeking of ammonia and looking like it hadn't been open in a few days. My food took a while to be prepared (longer than it should have), but 8 bucks with a drink (alcohol permitted) ain't a bad deal. Huarache with veggies was solid and the "house made" (jug+Tropicana, etc) sangria was good--well, what was left after they placed the coffee mug sideways in my plastic bag.

Surprisingly good (relatively costly) Mexican food for this part of Harlem. Okay. That doesn't sounds like a raving review, but I'm from California....

Compared to some of the other "Mexican" food joints on the island, this place had a decent fajita and a relatively calm atmosphere. It's a relatively nice place to get a quick Mexican fix while chatting with some friends. 

The vegetable fajitas came on a sizzling plate and were grilled nicely (how do you screw up grilled veggies?). It came with three tortillas (good, but three, really?), a plate of black beans, guac, rice, and sour cream, and a side of green and red salsa. The salsa was probably my favorite part. Reminded me of home. O *sigh*, Manhattan, where is your "good authentic" Mexican food?

Way over-priced for food that should be simple, cheap, and delicious. Pardon my language, but what they call a "burrito" is a heap of steaming shit. Would not be surprised if they are thrown together by a gang of chimpanzees on PCP.

I ordered delivery from this place for dinner tonight as I am sick. I was expecting a nice rojo pozole to sweat this cold out of me, but received a verde one. Still excited to eat the warm and hearty soup, I took a bite. To my near demise--it was so bland and tasteless. 

And this place charged my credit-card twice. 
The reason I'm giving it 2 stars is because the man I spoke to about it was very, very helpful and I almost felt bad for not enjoying my food!

I am going to give it a second chance, but don't get the pozole!
Went here about a month ago with my BFFs.....LOVED the frozen margaritas, LOVED the shrimp salad, LOVED the bartender, HATED that I had to leave so early, lol....definitely a must-see/eat/drink!

I've ordered from here twice, I love the Machos and Tacos. 
They have a really nice meat selection, with good variety. The Shakes are a little watery but still good. They are fast and my food has always arrived hot.

I give them ZERO stars! I ordered a shrimp chimichanga on Good Friday and they deliver a chicken to me and then say oh we'll give you a $5 coupon for next time! They then hung up on me when it came time to give my information.  I called back to try and get a name so that there isn't an issue next time I order and she said she didn't know and then hung up on me again.  The food wasn't even that great and I'm just mad because they tried to make it seem like I should be liable for their mistake.  Even though I ordered on Seamless! I don't know why they can't just read what was ordered and deliver it.  I wouldn't recommend this place to ANYONE.  If you want good Mexican, order from La Cocinita Latina, they always get the order right and are friendly and courteous on the phone.

this place isn't worth even one star!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

wow.. one of the most disgusting places ever known to man.... can't believe i even ate here... yuck

I would have to agree with the previous reviewer. This place was not tantalizing whatsoever. My fajitas were extremely bland and had a pungent smell to it. I was a bit concerned if I was going to catch Ebola!!! I didn't even come close to finishing my dinner. 

One star is generous.

Just got a delivery from here. It was absolutely awful, I could only manage 2 bites. Never again. What a waste of money. The food tasted nasty and weird.

I got a chimichanga and I can't even describe what it tasted like. YUCKY!

business.full_address:
998 Amsterdam Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Melvin & Pat's Barber Shop

reviews.text: This place is super basic and could honestly use a good cleaning, but Ruben is good, quick, and thorough. The price can't be beat either ($13). I've returned to barbers after many year of paying way too much at salons and am satisfied.
Don't even bother with this place. They have super poor customer service, the lady on the phone when asked about prices couldn't get off her butt and ask. She refused to ask on top of that.
cheap price, good service, and good haircut

Go here for a QUICK hair cut. Don't accept anything fancy. 
A haircut is $13. 

~Only go here for a quick cut, nothing crazy!

I love it here - but I only require a simple buzz cut (#2 on the sides, #3 on top, rounded back). I'm in and out in 15 minutes or less and get change back from a $20, which is exactly how I like it. Love the music and, sure, the place could use a vacuum but it sure beats the 45-90-minute "stylists" and their $50 (or more) tabs with the designer digs and low volume dubstep/new age-chill/smooth jazz in the background. They lose a half-star for the mess but it doesn't really bother me. Mambo!

business.full_address:
3501 University Blvd E
Hyattsville, MD 20783
business.name: The Marriott Inn & Conference Center, University of Maryland

reviews.text:
Stayed here for four days while attending a conference.  I stayed in what I call the "Stephen King Tribute" building.  

The SKT building is across the way (easy walking distance) from the fancy new building pictured in most of the marketing materials.  The rooms in the older, "historic" building are very small. They also had a strong odor of 'hey, this place has been around a looong time', so much so that I had to have a number of my wardrobe pieces (which had been hanging in the closet) dry cleaned when I returned home.  Same price for rooms between the building, by the way.  (At least for the conference).

The worst part was the dim lighting in the hallways once stepping off the elevator.  Combined with the historic feel to the place, it truly felt like some kid was going to come scooting around the corner on a tricycle yelling "red rum!".  No good restaurants within walking distance; had room service every night.

It gets two stars for the front desk gentleman who checked me in.  He was fantastic.

Wow, just wow! I have not had such a bad hotel experience in a loooong time. Two incidents stand out.

First, I arrived early afternoon and asked for eating options. I was told there is a restaurant across the courtyard. I walked over, but it was closed. I went back to the reception to ask for more options for someone without a car. They sent me to a McDonald's a mile away going west on a street that has no sidewalk. Partway there I realized it was a completely ridiculous situation and that there must be a food court on campus. Of course there is and it is closer than the McDonald's (and includes a McDonald's option in addition to a dozen others). Why didn't the receptionist send me there in the first place? Isn't it her job to know about such local options.

Second, I walked down to the receptionist to ask for some hot water to take some medication. I was told it would be brought up to my room. I asked whether I couldn't just get it, but no, that was not an option.  Fifteen minutes later I still had no water and called to ask about it and was told they'd check on it. Five minutes later still nothing and I was simply too tired and wanted to go to bed so I called to cancel the order, which they said they would do. Ten minutes after that, I get a knock on the door from room service. I didn't answer. The knocks kept coming so I said I was sleeping. The knocks continued for several minutes. They messed up the cancellation and then proceeded to knock on my door long enough to make sure they woke me up.

Located on University of Maryland Campus. Nice warm friendly staff. Tastefully decorated rooms and great facilities for business meetings. Extra parking in attached garage. Easy wall to Football Stadium and across street from university golf course. Good value.

Arrived at 3 in the afternoon.  The cheerful desk attendant gave us a room key and a certificate for one free coffee at the Starbucks (just one coffee for the two of us; just plain coffee).  Went up to room and found it had not been cleaned.  Back to the front desk, where an apologetic attendant gave me another key.  That room hadn't been cleaned, either.  Back to the front desk, where the first attendant decided he would accompany me on our third attempt to find a room.  Apparently that was the charm.  Went out of dinner and returned to spend some time in the lounge, which turns out to be the bright spot of this place - both servers were friendly, prompt, and efficient.
Returned to the room to find a note had been kicked under the door.  The note was apparently from the manager (who couldn't be bothered to come out of the back room to straighten out the room mix-up), and read that we could call the desk a get a half bottle of wine, or enjoy a complimentary breakfast in their cafe.  We opted for the breakfast, which was a mistake.  The restaurant service and food quality was slightly below that of Denny's or IHOP.  At least we didn't have to pay the exorbitant price that would normally have accompanied it.  
The room itself was okay, but nothing special.  Comfortable bed and nice shower.  Free internet access.  Relatively quiet for a hotel.  Parking garage next door is $8 per day, which can be charged to the room.

I stayed here for a wedding in College Park.  Our room was dark, musty, and had mold on the curtains.  The rest of the wedding party was in the main building which has been recently updated, and the rooms were nicer and what you'd expect of a Marriott. Do not stay in the old building across the courtyard. 
Prior to my stay, the front desk service was HORRIBLE, and did not try to accommodate the request I made (for a DVD player to be brought to our room for 2 hrs during our stay).  Rude staff members answered my call, and one even hung up on me (not disconnected by mistake, she hung up). 
The service throughout our stay was fine.  Housekeeping/maintenance failed to follow-through on requests, such as helping to change the AC in their VIP suite.  
On the plus side, there is a nice little bar area that's a good gathering place -- we were there for a wedding party and it was a good spot to get together beforehand.

Despite the fact that this Marriott hasn't mastered the art of creating key cards that don't deactivate every 5 minutes, this is a pretty great hotel.

I've stayed here over five times, and have never had a bad experience. Some of the rooms are huge while others are more of a standard size, so it's a mixed bag. Either way I don't think size should be a concern which some other reviews have addressed.

The restaurant/bar across the circle is nice, as is the Starbucks in that building. However they have terrible hours so good luck with timing everything properly. Because it's near a college campus, you can always get delivery here which is a fantastic option. The delivery guys know exactly where to come if you just say "the Marriott" so enjoy a taste of College Park as you relax in your room.

The TVs are decent and they occasionally get great movie options (ones that were just released), but I never seem to have a smooth experience with the movie ordering software. One time, the TV completely glitched and the screen literally displayed the desktop of a computer (we couldn't control it, it just looked like Windows 95 for 20 minutes). Good luck ever pausing your movie or god forbid rewinding it, as the remotes appear to no longer function in that way. This happens every single time.

The beds are tip top and always some of the most comfortable in the business. I wouldn't have too many trepidations about this hotel, it's a classic Marriott and is very clean. The parking price of $8 per day is annoying but hey, THAT'S LIFE.

Staying at this hotel was literally the worst travel experience I have had in recent memory. We stayed here for a wedding that was held on campus, so we sort of had few choices, and were told by the couple that this would be our best option. 

The nightmare started a month before we even stayed there, when we found out that they had mistakenly made our reservation for the correct date in the wrong month. Yep, they still charged us for it anyway, despite the fact that the reservation stated that it was for a particular wedding (can't they tell that the same couple isn't getting married two months in a row? I guess not.).

Upon checking in, the woman at the desk handed us our card key, and told us to take the elevator to the correct floor. We went to that floor, walked around for quite awhile, trying to figure out where the heck they could have hidden our room. Finally, we went back downstairs to ask. She looked at us as though we were really stupid, and then told us that OBVIOUSLY, that room is in the building across the street. (duh?) So we had to trek our stuff across there in the pouring rain. Sweet.

The room was nice enough, but insanely small - we had a king sized bed, and there was barely enough room to get between the bed and the dresser/tv stand to get over to the bathroom. The upside: the bed was indeed comfortable. Which was good, because we had to order room service when all of the supposedly open (per their posted hours) restaurants in the hotel were closed. Sweet.

The morning we were to check out, we got several knocks on the door (despite the privacy please sign and being several hours before the 'official' check out time) from the lovely cleaning people who were just itching to clean our room. Each time, the person would tap on their invisible watch as if to say, uh, hey, we want to clean your room now, can you hurry it up? And when I looked at them, amazed, the person would huff, turn on their heel, and walk away. REALLY? Is this a high schooler angry with their parents for grounding them? 

But to really put the icing on the cake, the hotel had to double charge us, too (this is a double charge not counting the one we had to pay a month in advance, so really, we paid three times to stay in this shitty hotel).  It has taken several phone calls with Kimberle (clearly a mental midget) to try and clear this up, and she might just be the least accommodating person working in any sort of a customer service positon, ever. 

Seriously, don't stay at this hotel unless you have to. Though the rooms are ok, the awful awful awful customer service makes you long for a sketchy roadside Motel 6.
Clean rooms, neat arrangement

I had a very nice stay at this hotel with my family. We flew into DC on a red-eye and worried about early morning check-in but there was no problem at all about checking in at 9AM and they even upgraded our room for free to better fit our family of four.
     Parking is right next to the hotel for $8 a day. There is also 10-min parking right at the entrance. I parked there for hours and nobody worried about it. 
     There is a small fitness room and a Starbucks right across in the conference center. The elevator talks to you in pleasant voice, which I thought was interesting. Rooms have a fridge, a coffee maker, a flat screen TV, and an interesting device that lets you connect virtually any electronic device (computer, DVD player, VCR, camera ...) to the TV or the house network.  WiFi is free and available anywhere.

I have a soft-spot in my heart for this Marriott. I'm a Marriott gal. This Marriott is great, located right on the edge of the University of Maryland. Elite members are treated like kings and queens. 

The rooms are like every other Marriott room. The employees are cheerful and ready to help. There is a Starbucks right across front driveway where the Marriott employees there hold the door open for everyone walking through. The whole place runs like a well-oiled machine. 

One of the best decisions Marriott could have ever made was to make the Bath & Body Works's Orange Ginger line their default. This Marriott is stocked. 

Home sweet Marriott.

Okay, the company paid for my stay for a training course at Univ of Maryland.  Some basics for people to know up front about facilities here.

* Gym on site- cardio equip with some small weights and lifting machine
* Restaurant and bar- nice for business and casual meetings
* Garage- parking charged to your room ($9 per day- best parking rate on campus) with in/out access
* Cafe- Starbucks coffee in the morning
* Business center- check email and print out small documents

Please note that there is no bus service to the campus.  You can either walk down or take your car and park in the visitor lots ($$$).  If it's a nice day then just walk and leave your laptop in your room.  Oh yeah, room size is tiny for either queen or 2 queen room.  Imagine that you have a small corridor for you to shuffle your feet from one end of the bed to another.  The desk in front with TV basically cuts off the room abruptly.

This hotel is conveniently located on campus of UMD. There are two
parts: the main building with the reception/checkin and the building
across the street which has most of the hotel facilities; it used to be a dorm. The latter is the one with closet-sized rooms (that they refer
to as "cozy" in a bit of irony). Lucky for me, both times I stayed there,
the nice German lady at the reception moved my res-n to the main
building that has human-size rooms. The main building is just fine -
a more-or-less standard Marriott experience. The gym is weird... It's in a
deserted basement in the other building. Not bad, just a bit creepy.
Parking is convenient, next door -- $8/day. Room service wasn't bad: 
I ordered a soup and a burger and both arrived quickly and weren't 
at all bad.

business.full_address:
230 W 108th St
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Weddings by Joshua Brown

reviews.text:
Wedding photography is usually a bit stiff in my opinion.  When my (now) wife and I were looking at photographers to shoot our wedding, they all tended to blur together.

Josh's work immediately jumped out at us and there was no question in our mind that we wanted to hire him.  I've never seen so much life and energy in wedding photography before.  He captured the event in a way no one else could.

We were highly pleased with the result, and can't recommend him enough!!!

We couldn't be more pleased with the amazing and high-quality photos that Josh took for our wedding.  They capture the moments in a journalistic style that highlights the beauty of our occasion, without making anything look posed or faked.  He gave us gorgeous photos and even set up a web gallery for our family and friends to visit.  Easy, cutting edge, and very professional.  I highly recommend Josh Brown Photography!

What I am most struck by, when reviewing Josh's portfolio, is his ability to  distill the emotions and personalities of his subjects while capturing them with a vision that is uniquely his own. His photographs are artistic while maintaining a warmth and sense of humor that is rare in this type of photography. I work in the film world, and find that his photographs always tell a story in a beautiful, cinematic way. He has a deep technical understanding of his craft that allows him to capture your special day, just the way that you remember it (or don't, as it can be a bit of a whirlwind).

On the business side of things, he is a pleasure to work with and is the consummate professional. His soft spoken, jovial nature puts everyone at ease, which allows him to capture some very intimate moments without ever being obtrusive. He offers a variety of packages to fit all your photographic needs and always has prints and samples to view as soon as possible.

I look forward to working with him again in the future and recommend him highly to any in need of photographic services.

Superb photographer, highly recommended! We just had our baby girl a couple months ago and wanted to capture some of the cute moments with her as a baby. We were so excited with what Josh was able to photograph. He caught cute vignettes of our little family that will be so memorable for us in the future. From the video and still images down to the music, it truly was beautiful. If you want to check out the video you can see it here: http://bit.ly/eeUyCS. We highly recommend Josh, he has an incredible aesthetic and is very talented. Thanks Josh!

When you are looking for a photographer, you want someone that understands you and can bring out your best in each photo. Josh makes that happen. Take a look at the portfolio and you'll see what I mean, Josh is terrific. Extremely professional and a pleasure to work with.

The moment we arrived at Joshua's website, we knew that we had found our photographer.  Josh's photos had us laughing, smiling and going "awww..."    He captures not only the sights of the day, but more importantly the emotions.  It seems a bit futile to

business.full_address:
4004 Chestnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: New Delhi Indian Restaurant

reviews.text:
Massive amounts of delicious Indian food.  Need I say more?

I was a  regular at this place when my husband and I had a dual income and lived in University City.  I don't remember what all of the dishes were called, but my favorite was the chicken smothered in some kind of spicy red sauce.  Veggie, chicken, and lamb dishes were spiced to Indian perfection.  The fried potato-y vegetable pouch and balls of vegetables in a sweet/spicy sauce were perfect.  Naan was plentiful.  Dessert is included in the price; the mango ice cream hit the spot every time.

The atmosphere was more posh than the usual buffet.  Modern tables and chairs.  Mirrors on the wall.  Servers were attentive.  The owner knows what he/she is doing.

We went for lunch a lot instead of dinner for affordability.  The choices were the same per visit for the most part, and they *could* have had more variety, but as long as we kept the visits to one or two a month, it didn't get old.

I don't do Indian food.  Never have.  And this place was good.  The only problem was that the selection at the buffet was slim.  Very good, but only a few options.

Be ready to eat a lot to get your $11 worth.

Nothing like momma bear's food but this place isn't bad at all. We usually only ever go for the buffet because the selection is pretty good and food never disappoints. The staff is nice and it is clean. Decent place if you're craving Indian food and you're in the area!

I've loved this place for years.  I've been here for dinner, as well as buffet.  New Delhi has been in this city a long time (I think at least 20 years) and the owner is a very friendly man who seems to be very tied to Philly and especially to this neighborhood.  He seems to take special care in making sure that the restaurant looks beautiful, the food is clean and tasty, and that customers are happy.  The restaurant just underwent some major renovations and looks great!  I'm not sure if this has increased their business because it seems as busy as it's always been.  The buffet is great (try the lamb korma), the naan is perfect, and the dessert is yummy.  They also have Indian beers.

I mean really, seriously, this is the best Indian food Penn has to offer!? 

We are from Chicago and were very excited to see so many Indian food restaurants around Philly. Just before an MBA session at Wharton, we looked up Yelp and of course went with the recommendation to have the lunch buffet at New Delhi.

We're vegetarians and maybe the meat dishes is what earned them super-star Yelp reviews. At our buffet they had:

- daal makhni - too watery and impossible to eat with naan
- chana masala - also watered down 
- kofta - tasted nothing like actual malai kofta (I'm a New Delhiite)
- navratan korma - there were no Indian vegetables in it, rather mostly zucchini
- naan - that was fine
- rice
- samosa - decent
- bhajia - okay

Honestly, the food was bland and tasteless for the most part. I was really hoping something better from a restaurant named after my birthplace and hometown! 

The one thing I did really like is that you could order any dessert from their menu and it was included in the buffet - that worked really well for me because kheer was the dessert out as part of the buffet but I was able to get gulabjamun instead!

I'm sitting here eating delivery from New Delhi and felt compelled to add to the collection of great reviews.  I'll probably regret this later seeing that my fingers are a little oily, but it's worth it I'm sure.

The usual dishes - chicken tikka masala, tandoori chicken, etc. - are fine and dandy, as you can read in the rest of the reviews.  But I highly recommend you try the other fare as well.  I love the dal makhni and channa masala.    If you're not going for the buffet, try the makhni chicken - it's my absolute fave and almost compares to my Indian friend's mom's homemade.  On that note, all of my Indian friends love it here as well.  No, it's not the same as homemade, but it's pretty damn close.

If you love mango, go for a mango lassi or the mango ice cream.  The rest of the desserts are great, as well, but I find the mango ice cream to be refreshing at the end of this kind of meal.

I tend to get delivery seeing as that I'm usually holed up in my room studying, and I've never had a problem with their delivery service - fairly prompt given the volume of people they serve, and always hot and fresh.
nice, sweet rice pudding is back again!

I've only ever eaten the buffet at lunch, but I've had it at least 20 times now. Food is always fresh and tasty. They always have a good mix of vegetarian options along with chicken and lamb, so there is something for everyone! I find the level of spice to be perfect, but it's too powerful for my mother. If you like moderately spicy food, you can handle their level of spice. 

Compared to the other Indian buffet around the corner, this place is far better in my book on taste and decor. Since they redecorated the place a couple years ago it's a hip, trendy spot to go for lunch.

I tried the a la carte for the first time the other day.  It was actually quite acceptible -  much better than the buffet.  They made it extremely spicy like I asked, which I was grateful for.  As long as you don't get the buffet, this place offers up semi-acceptable Indian food for decent prices.

Thank you, come again.

This place is great for reliable, cheap Indian. The buffet is dope. That's all that needs to be said.

I figured if people who live in South Philly go to this place in University City for Indian, it MUST be good..... and it was! Love their chicken tikka masala and saag paneer. The naan and vegetable samosa were also good.  The inside seating is nice, too. Really good indian buffet and very cheap for lunch ($8.95 per person for the buffet). Will definitely make this a regular option.

Despite the fact that they messed up our order, the food was delish. We ordered chicken mooghlai and received chicken tikka masala, which was spicy, perfectly salted and creamy.  The naan was huge and quite tasty in the different sauces. 

There were lots

Ayyy this shit is so bomb! I got the buffet and asked if there is a difference from ordering from the menu and just getting food from the buffet. The waiter said that getting dishes from the buffet wouldn't have as much flavor than dishes from the menu. If you're feeling optimistic about trying different dishes and can't decide on what to eat, I would say go with the buffet, I didn't regret doing that. I guess if you know what you want then you should order from the menu, it would probably be better.
this is by far the best restaurant for indian food in philadelphia.  the food is awesome.  it is all you can eat buffet style.  great place to go if you are starving for indian food.

The food is not the best Indian food in Philly, but it's always solid, and never disappoints. It varies very little from visit to visit, I've never gone home disappointed. Their buffets are pretty great deals at $8 and $12 for lunch and dinner respectively, I don't think I've ever ordered a la carte.

As for the buffet, it's refreshed often, everything is always hot and fresh, and as stated, the quality varies little from visit to visit. It's also a nice touch that they include a dessert; I always get the kulfi, which is rich but the tiny portion is just the right amount of sweet for the end of a meal.

The waiters are, I think, mostly used to the buffet crowd, so they're either too present at refilling your water or hovering over your plate to take it away, or they're totally absent and it's nearly impossible to flag one down when you want to pay. Still, since you're mostly left to your own devices, which is nice, and this is always a good standby when in West Philly.

In my opinion, if you don't get the buffet here, you're just being silly. They have stuff in red sauces, green sauces, and other color sauces. I can't tell you what any of it is called, but it's all delicious. Rice aplenty and lots of the bread (nan?) to go with everything. There's also a salad bar and rice pudding, which tastes like it was made with lots of love. Also, dessert is included. I've never had anything but the honey dough balls, because those are so amazing I can't even entertain the idea of another dessert. Seriously, just order them; just say "honey dough balls" and they'll know what you mean.

still can't find anything like this and as cheap!  for student discounts 7 bucks or sumptin... tons of buffet selection of meats too including lamb, chicken, kafta.  best part is the dessert that comes with it!  kulfi pistachio ice cream my fav there!

be sure to eat this in preparation of immediate food coma afterwards!

We were there during a birthday party that took up the whole left side of the restaurant. We didn't mind this...it was very festive and entertaining to watch...we especially enjoyed the Indian music. :)

The martinis are great.  The food...meh.  The entree I got was pretty much entirely fried and a bit soggy.  Service was definitely lacking and it took us a full 15 minutes to get one of the waiters to flag down our waiter to get us the check.  It took him another 20 minutes to get it to us and take the credit card slip.

What is all the fuss about? After hearing an obnoxious amount of people say that New Delhi is, "by far," the best Indian food in Philly, I had to give it a try. What did I find? Meh.

Being a huge advocate for Indian food and a regular diner and buffet patron, I have been to my share of Indian restaurants in the area: Ekta, Tiffin, Himalayan, Delhi, Sitar, and the list goes on. The New Delhi dinner buffet is perhaps one-up from the bottom of my list. 

Options-wise, they simply didn't have that much to offer; two chicken dishes, one of which featured "white meat" which was in fact dark, and tandoori chicken which wasn't horrible, but definitely on the dryer side. Their saag took on a shade that resembled an olive brown, rather than green--was the spinach fresh? Their vegetable pakoras consisted of pieces of puny, slightly burnt cauliflower pieces covered in gobs of batter; the pakora chicken wings were not burnt, but simply had almost no meat to them. The vegetable malai kofta were decent, but also not the best I've ever had. All in all, the buffet was a bit too americanized for my liking, (there was macaroni salad in the salad bar!), and not spicy in the slightest bit. Maybe that's why people like it? 

All-in-all, the food was mediocre, some dishes even being cold (not intentionally), and not too many options to choose from on top of this. New Delhi is very attentive service-wise, however, with servers constantly coming around, asking how you are and attempting conversation. Not always what one wants when eating their meal; yet,  at least dirty plates were taken away speedily. They also serve you your choice of dessert to your table, which is a nice touch. The pistachio ice cream itself was just average, but I liked that aspect of their service nevertheless. 

In the University City district, skip New Delhi and head on over to the tastier, albeit shabbier looking, Sitar a few blocks away. 

I'm giving New Delhi three stars because they also labeled the buffet item's if they were gluten-free or containing potential allergens, which pleased my gluten-sensitive self. I knew what I was getting, even if it didn't take the greatest.

For awhile after the original Minar Palace closed, New Delhi was my main source for Indian food. Don't get me wrong, it's perfectly fine, but I am very glad that Tiffin, Ekta and Minar Palace 2.0 exist now.

If you're a broke Uni student like the most of us are around University City, then New Delhi Indian Restaurant is your haven away from your mum's cooking. 

The buffet is divine, and the things they have will surely have you coming back for seconds, and thirds, and fourths - you know what I mean. It's just good. 

The staff is very friendly and joke around with you which leaves you smiling at the end of the day. 

The food is divine, but I love the desserts the best. Their Gulab Kamun (Homemade milk balls dipped in honey syrup) is definitely something to try out. I would take pictures, but I was too busy stuffing my face.

Not the best Indian food--can be a bit bland and 'typical'--nothing to blow you out of the water--certainly not home-style, which is ok. 

One of my best friends growing up is Indian, her mom used to cook for us ALL of the time, so I'm used to DELICIOUS, home-cooked indian meals--

this place is affordable and quick--Only done takeout but seems like it caters to young trendy/college individuals.

It's a go to for quick, inexpensive indian food in Philly

Their buffet is the best deal on Indian food in University City. It is something around $9.99 for the all you can eat buffet dinner, including dessert. They have a good mix between meats and delicious vegetarian friendly dishes (I highly recommend the vegetarian meatballs!). When school is in session, it gets pretty crowded though, but I don't mind the wait.
Amazing!!!! Try the mango ice cream.

I don't eat Indian food very often so we asked for a recommendation.  However, our waiter could not give any recommendation as to what we should choose.  

The appetizer was good, but neither the chicken or lamb we ordered was memorable.  The chicken was dry.

It looks pretty inside and out, too bad the food was not at the same level.

Went here last night and really enjoyed it.  The food was tasty and the service was very quick and attentive.  It wasn't the most amazing or outstanding Indian restaurant I've been to, but I would definitely recommend it.

If you're looking for nice decor to impress someone, then New Delhi is the only West Philly Indian place you need to consider. Combine that with very tasty food and you can understand its popularity on yelp.

Understand though, that Penn students are equally enamored with this spot, and since it is basically on their campus do not be surprised by lots and lots of noise. Obviously if you are a Penn student this doesn't bother you because you're the ones making the noise, but for the rest of us it takes some getting used to.

We initially considered the buffet, but upon inspection decided it was a bit sparse for anyone but an Indian newbie or hungry college student eating on the cheap, so we decided to go menu.

We ordered the chicken saag (mild) and chicken tikka mughlai (mild plus) - the latter being chicken cubes and fresh mushrooms cooked in a creamy tomato sauce - and it was exceptionally good. They say their cooking is on the spicy side, and mild plus was spicy enough for me. I was also impressed by the fresh, moist taste of the poori bread and paneer naan bread. For appetizers, there was nothing to complain about the meat samosas and bhojia, especially when combined with the traditional Indian dipping sauces provided. Sadly they were out of the barfi for dessert, and I was a bit disappointed when they only delivered two gulab jamun, though I suppose they're cheap enough to get two orders. To drink I has a traditional mango lassi, but if I return I am intrigued to try their strawberry version.

As far as outdoor dining goes, the Chestnut street sidewalk might be nice enough with the sun out, but at night it leaves a bit to be desired, as Chestnut Street at this block is a bit of a drag strip for passing cars, and a bit dirty. Obviously Penn students are used to this, as it is the standard in West Philly. (For tourists, note that UPenn can only exist in West Philly in 2011 with multiple campus police on every corner, and the tension is always there, whether Penn students are oblivious to it or not.)

Finally, I must confess I am a Tandoor India loyalist and have been ordering there for 20 plus years. Your choice is between waiters slickly dressed in all black or more of a family staff and traditional Indian decor and music; between a starting point for a weekend evening on the town or a quiet place to have more intimate conversation. Either way I expect you will be treated to a fine Indian meal.

I go to this place regularly with my friends. I'm a huge fan of Indian food and this is the best Indian buffet I've ever been to especially for the price. The lighting is romantic and it's a clean, cozy place. I really like how the servers are attentive and take your plate when you're done and ready to get more! I have a bad tendency to overeat here but it comes with the territory of good food for a poor college student!

I have to say, their mango ice cream is divine. I crave it all the time.

Ok, I admit that I'm giving 5 stars because I've been going here almost my entire life, and the food has stayed reliably delicious. It's not always perfect, especially if you're really craving spice, but how can you beat the buffet, with tea and dessert included and a 10% student discount? The Tandoori chicken can be hit or miss, but their mutter or saag paneer is just lovely, as well as the lamb saag, tikka masala, and fried chicken (coated in chickpea flour, so you feel 2% better about eating them). The owner told us that they changed the kitschy decor to a sleeker look because that's what they're doing in India...personally, I liked the old look better, but hey, now you get a long, silvery, space-trek to the bathroom.

This review is for the buffet only which was very basic, but (like the rating says) A-OK. I think the price is just right, too. I was on a mandatory assignment to get  some Indian food in my brother and this was totally accomplished.

GREAT FOOD!!!! i love buffets. esp ones that include dessert! but since i have had the glorious indian food from ekta i cant help but compare everything to it...and new dehli was lagging far behind ekta.

I'm giving this place 5 stars, because their buffet is awesome! I think this place might have ruined Indian buffets in okc for me. There are plenty of dishes to choose from, and everything tastes fresh and delicious. I really liked the chicken tikka and lamb here, and the kulfi was also good.

The atmosphere here was also nice and clean, and service was very friendly.

Just went here recently with some friends from my church---first time in a long time and I was pleasantly surprised.  

I always knew New Delhi had pretty kick-ass food for an Indian buffet and at a good price too.  I used to come here all the time during undergrad because it was cheap and satisfying (although some dishes, I think, were better at Sitar on 38th).  Not much has changed in way of food (except this time, I thought the chicken tikka masala was weird---maybe their sauce didn't have as much cream as I'm used to but Karma, over on Chestnut, btw. 2nd and Front, blows New Delhi's out of the water---and yes, I know, chicken tikka masala is not really authentic Indian food.  Whatever.  It's still pretty delicious.)  

Anyway, food was great this time around and wish I had went back one more time to the buffet.  Typical offerings---samosas, naan, vegetable and chicken curries, rice, papri chaat, salad.  I chose kulfi ice cream for my dessert (comes with the buffet price) and I love love love kulfi---this was delicious--I like the whole cardamom taste of it.  A bit icy but nothing I couldn't overlook.  Also had masala chai with it (well, not really chai---masala tea which I then added my own cream to) and it didn't disappoint.  By the way, the masala tea is included in the buffet price, which I didn't know before...wish I did...would've ordered it every time I went in college.  

The pleasant surprise came from the decor.  I haven't been here in a couple of years.  In college, we used to joke that when eating at New Delhi, you always needed to adjust your eyesight because the lights got progressively dimmer throughout the meal---so much so that you practically couldn't see what you were eating by the end.  Maybe some thought it was for the ambiance but we all thought it was because they were trying to hide a dirty carpet.  Well, the "dirty" carpet is no more---the restaurant is much bigger, cleaner and more polished than before.  It's lost that typical, mom and pop-Indian restaurant feel, with a fancy-looking bar and bright lighting.  When I first walked in, I almost turned around because I thought I accidentally walked into one of the adjacent restaurants.  Definitely recommend it.  Come here if you're in the area.
I have been here several times and I love the buffet!! I've never been disappointed with the food though the service leaves a little to be desired. Great food!
I love New Delhi! The food is delicious, and the inexpensive buffet offers a number of different choices.  My friends and I go there all the time.

This is a great place to for casual lunch or dinner. The restaurant is really versatile, I think -- can fit well for a variety of occasions. It's modern and clean, spacious. Small buffet in the middle, but I believe they have a regular menu for those who wishes to opt out of the buffet. I always went here for the buffet so I'm not sure how the other non-buffet fares.

I think the food is decent and the service is always really good. If I were to choose between Sitar and New Dehli just based on food (taste & selection), however, I'd probably go to Sitar. 

Nonetheless, this place never disappoints! I'm a fan.

Though I've only been here once, and the only other Indian restaurant I've been to is Minar Palace, I must say, from the flavor to the selection, New Delhi is thoroughly better. I mean, who doesn't like buffets? 

The buffet was small, but it satiates your craving for Indian food. They have a salad bar, flatbread, rice, curry with pork, chicken, beef, or lamb, and dessert. All the curry was mildly spicy. I had their milkballs dipped in warm honey for dessert and it was extremely sweet. Also very small; only two milkballs, but it hit the spot.

For $15 per person, which includes the dessert, I approve.

New Delhi, Y U NO MASALA?!  

I had the lunch buffet which was fairly standard fare: chicken tikka masala, lamb korma, palak paneer, vegetable kofta, samosa, and an item I've never seen at an Indian buffet, chicken wings.  The kofta was abnormally sweet and the chicken wing, though crispy, had no flavor.  The others were very mediocre; it tasted like they used about half of the amount of usual spices.  I didn't expect any Indian buffet to be hot-spicy, but I expect my Indian food to have a lot of flavor.  These all just tasted like pre-made frozen or canned Indian food.  There was almost no effort put into making these.  I thought I could at least count on chutney to be spicy, but no even the onion coriander chutneys were a watery, sugary mess.  

Even though I was full, I still got dessert because it's hard to go wrong.  My husband ordered mango ice cream, which was nice and thick, but it was probably from a tub of Reena's brand ice cream that you can find at your local Indian store.  The kulfi was the biggest disappointment of all.  Kulfi is a dense, creamy, pistachio ice cream, and it is VERY easy to make, so I'm not sure how a restaurant screwed it up. What they served was a small circle of icy, sweetened milk with no other flavors--no pistachio pieces in the ice cream (just a micro sprinkle on top), no cardamom, just ice crystals.  

Seriously, I've had LOTS of Indian food in my life and I will never understand the need to so aggressively anglicize the food.  Restaurants need to stop "dumbing down" their food into some disgusting, unflavored slop.  Indian food is supposed to be known for it's flavors, and although not everything is spicy, one would expect SOMETHING to be. If you don't like any sort of flavor or spice, don't eat Indian food, it's just not for you.

I went here with some friends for dining days and had a great experience. Next time I definitely want to check out their buffet which is definitely a better deal than the dining days menu.

Our waiter was nice and attentive but he may have not understood our order completely i.e. we all asked for different levels of spicy and all our dishes came out being medium/mild spice. Next time if I get him I'll listen extra well when he repeats the order back to us.

Their lime margarita was satisfying. I was very impressed with their vegetable samosas. 

I'm definitely coming back to this place. I actually tried bringing my mother back a few days later on a Monday and they were closed. Lesson learned!

After a couple of times coming here, decided to give this place two stars.  Would have been three stars, but an incident earlier tonight warranted an automatic star deduction.  I'll explain below:

New Delhi Indian Restaurant is perfect for when you want a ton of Indian Food cheaply and in a hurry.  The restaurant operates almost exclusively as a buffet (I don't even know if there's an a la carte menu).  Going here feels much like going to a dining hall, except smaller.  You sit down, place your drink order, and then eat as much basmati rice, naan, chicken tikka masala, salad, or whatever is on the trays that evening as you care.  The young, noisy clientele really makes you feel like you're back in college.  Then you see the one or two older disheveled guys sitting by themselves in the corner or on the side eating alone to remind you that you're in the real world.

The food is actually not terrible: the basmati rice is flavorful, the naan is solid and able to hold a lot of the other dishes, the chicken tikka masala creamy, savory, and with large pieces of chicken, and the mutter paneer was a delight.  It was the lamb saag that got us.  While my serving had no major problems (just large chunks of dry lamb that had a little flavor), it was the BF's portion that made us both do a double take.  As he put the food in his mouth, he realized that something was hard to chew, and it was when he pulled a 6" piece of plastic wrap out of his mouth, I knew that I could eat no more.  Utterly gross and horrible.

While our waiters pushed us to enjoy one of the complimentary desserts included in the buffet, we honestly just didn't have the appetite to stomach it.  If not for the other time that we came here and had a pretty decent meal, I would have probably given this an automatic one star based on this experience alone.  However my rating reflects the average of our two trips here.  Maybe I'll come back if I can get over the plastic wrap hidden in the food.  But with another Indian buffet located around the corner and other cheap dining options nearby, it's hard to make a case for me to revisit New Delhi.
Cheap, delicious, and endless! It doesn't get any better [for me]. I love their fresh salad bar and don't forget to try the naan with hummus!
The best Indian buffet in the city.  Incredible kulfi and rice pudding for dessert.  The samosas disappear so quickly it is difficult to get them.  The only think I am not crazy about is their raita.

3.5 stars.. it's cheap, and it's filling and tasty.  Since there's so much snow, we decided to stay in for the evening and not risk taking the car out and then not being able to park anywhere while out, and then not being able to park when we got home.  

We ordered delivery from this place since we randomly found that they were A) actually open and C) you could access the menu and order online..and I was really surprised that their delivery fee was less than a dollar (course, you still should tip) and the minimum charge was only $10... and even better, they actually delivery to our area, which is right on the border of UPenn campus.

The food was standard in my opinion.  Oily, spicy curried sauces and containers of basmati rice..  The two of use ordered just 1 dish each and those portions easily became at least 3 meals each.  

I won't make it a standard in this house, just because of how oily it is, but if I need take out, I know where to go for my Indian food.

Bangin.  One word review.  Discount these other words.  Seriously though, this place has never disappointed.  I often eat here for lunch and get the buffet, so there is never a wait.  Don't get discouraged when I say "buffet" because the food is of very high quality.  The servers are attentive and the atmosphere is very conducive to having a relaxing meal.

this is not only my favorite indian restaurant, this is my favorite restaurant in all of phildelphia, hands down. i say that in part because it is the only restaurant that i have frequented on a regular basis over the past 13+ years. it's hard to put into words what i love about this place...but i shall try...

my first new delhi experience was october of 1995, yet it seems like just yesterday. i was a freshman at drexel, and a sophomore friend who was helping me with a film class project suggested we get some take-out while watching movies. he called in an order to new delhi and we trekked from powelton village thru penn's campus in the cold. i was bitter about having to walk so far to get our food, wondering why we couldn't get something closer, or better yet - delivery! after walking all the way back in the cold and then unwrapping the tightly sealed packages with nearly frost-bitten fingers, i pretty much would have been satisfied with anything. i wasn't satisfied. i was blown the eff away!

since that first experience (tho not my first indian endeavor, mind you), i have ordered off the menu a mere handful of times compared to the number of visits where i opted for the buffet. now, i am not one for buffets as i generally am weary of the vats of food sitting for long periods of time, however, just as the clientele at new delhi is constantly turning over, so does the food. in one short visit i have seen the naan replenished 3 times - that's a lot. the staff on the other hand? talk about low turnover rate...i gather this must be a family operation because i have seen the same men working there since '95.

and the food, oh the food! while the buffet items are typically not as spicy as ordering a la carte...i have been quite grateful for the pitcher of water left at the table on many an occasion. as i'm the type of eater who takes a bit of this, and then a bit of that, and often mixes flavors and sauces, i can never be sure which was hot and which was not, but who really cares? all are tasty, and that's what matters.

my favorite dishes are the malai kofta, gobi masala, palak paneer and [sorry, i don't know the exact indian name for it] the vegetable pakora in a lemon chickpea sauce...tho i have yet to have anything i disliked here. at least 2 of the above items are always on the buffet when i go in (typically on weekends) as well as naan, basmati rice, samosas and of course a few meat dishes...ya know, if that's your thing.

since the renovation about a year and a half ago, they have also been offering rice pudding (on the side, next to the salad bar), but you still get your choice of dessert as well as coffee or tea along with the buffet, which is already a steal at $9/lunch, $12/dinner. i'm a sucker for gulab jamun and kulfi, tho lately i have been filling up on my food and haven't had the room for it - sacrilege, i know! speaking of which, who else remembers when the front/waiting room housed a sweets counter? man, that was some good stuff...

what can i say? i have requested to be taken here by my bf on special occasions ... i have driven out of my way to come here when other options were closer/easier ... i have opted to see movies at the bridge over other theaters in order to dine at new delhi ... i have been eating here for nearly 14 years! clearly, i love this restaurant, and if you haven't tried it yet, well, what are you waiting for, a UYE? if so, you're in luck - check the events page! http://www.yelp.com/events/philadelphia-new-delhi-uye

This place is pretty good. I went solo to the lunch buffet, and it was pretty busy at lunch time. The hot buffet was small, and good but not stunning. There is also a really fresh salad bar, which was nice. The service was great!
tasty, tho not the tastiest. not bad value, and it's hard not to love a buffet. samosas and pakoras especially yummy!

Excellent dinner buffet! Fairly authentic and spicy vegetarian dishes. Also naan was hot and with generous amounts of butter. The kulfi in the desserts was average but still not bad.  Excellent decor and ambience.
This place is simply the best.  The buffet is unreal.  The food is delicious, fresh and so well prepared.  The staff is nice.  Simply put, the buffet is a "10" so enjoyable!
Very good buffet-- lots of meat and vegetarian options. Buffet includes dessert.

Great quality buffet at very good price.  2 kids 2 adults $40 for dinner including desert.  Can't beat it. Buffet is so good, I've never ordered off the menu.  Service is also very nice.  Lunch is even cheaper.  Very clean.
indian isnt my fav but its good, i guess.

So me and this place have had an interesting past.  In fact, I decided this place just wasn't good enough a while ago.  Ever since meeting my wife, who as I've mentioned is from India and the person I trust the most on finding a good Indian place, we have

I've NEVER left here unsatisfied.  My first Indian experience in Philly was actually here at New Delhi and boy, no other place compares.

I usually come here during lunch for the buffet.  Having to pay only 9 bucks for an unlimited amount of homemade Indian food is a pretty darn good and tasty deal.  I am IN LOVE with the one particular vegetarian curry dish that has the peas, carrots, cauliflower, and green beans (pardon the lack of name for the dish).  It is the most perfect blend of the curry's floral essences and the sweetness of the veggies.  Omg, and naan??  Goodness, best Indian food.....thing ever invented.  Grabbing some of the lamb curry with the naan is absolute divinity!!

Oh, and must not forget about the samosas!!  That starchy, yet smooth texture of the curried potatoes against the crispy and chewy fried dough of the samosa's exterior is...ugh, just too freakin' good.  Buuut, there is just one teeny weeny complaint, and that would be that the cumin seeds are a bit overpowering.  Perhaps if they didn't keep it whole, it wouldn't be as overwhelming.

And to top it all off?  Mango ice cream for dessert!!! *Drool*
