I've ordered both off the menu and had just the buffet. Both are good, though the buffet is clearly more economical.  The Chicken Tikka Masala is awesome.

One warning: Don't bother with the alcoholic beverages. Oh god, worst mojito I've ever had. Probably my fault for ordering a mojito at an Indian restaurant, but whatever. Others I know have had the Indian beer (forget the name) and thought it was so-so.

Some of the best Indian food I have ever had.

Incredible flavor, reasonable prices, and very friendly people.  Their samosa chat is a meal for two for $6.95, and so delicious.  And they deliver to West Philly (at least to University City).  Highly, highly recommend.  Big up yourself, New Delhi Indian Restaurant.

My boyfriend and I went on a recent Sunday evening for dinner with a couple of friends and the place was packed and the buffet was full of hot options.

New Delhi is looks great since the renovations despite keeping some of the cheesy artwork which now hangs higher on the walls.  The service was good with water being refilled regularly, plates were cleared and dessert offered in a timely manner.  What more can you ask from a buffet?

Everyone left happy and full. No complaints.  Always great food.

I went here for my birthday last week (where was my gift, Yelp?) because I haven't had Indian food since I moved back to Philly.

I have to say, if you are a patron who demands good to excellent service, you may not like this place. My friends I were greeted at the door after standing around for a minute by our server who just motioned to our table (we assumed) and walked away. After 3 minutes he came back with water and was like, "Alright, you can eat," and walked away. We motioned him back a minute later, still confused. Was the buffet our only option? Where were the plates? How much did it cost? Can we see menus before makng a decision?

Annoyed, he bought us menus and left again. He came back a few minutes later and begrudgingly answered questions about the menu, then took our order. He was sick of us by then and didn't check on us the rest of the night. When the meal was over, someone started to put my food in a carry out container for me, but another worker there told him to stop. He was like, "No, she can do it." We really did not make a good first impression on New Dheli.

But you know, I can ignore oddball staff if there's good food. Plus, there's always take out and writing scathing reviews on Yelp. We had Chicken tiikka masala, chicken saag, saag paneer, samosas, and garlic naan. Everyone was really happy with their dishes.  I ordered the Saag mild, my friends ordered their dishes medium spicy but said there wasn't enough heat. I tasted and agreed. The samosas were huge and crispy and so delicious. 

I would definetely go back for the food, but may not eat in there again.

Why do I love New Delhi?  I love it because it's a very clean establishment, the food is very consistent, a desert is included with the buffet, the restaurant accommodates large parties, the service is excellent, and most importantly the food is really good!  Both the lunch and dinner buffets are good.  I recommend the vegetable dumplings, samosas, and mango ice cream :)

I saw a couple of Yelpers give New Delhi low ratings because the food doesn't compare with their home, erm, Indian food!  Well, duh.  Of course nothing in America is going to taste like it does in another country.  Food is still local and it has to appeal to local tastes (i.e. Philadelphians).  I think that the spice is still pretty up there for an Indian restaurant in America, though.

Have been here three times, twice for take-out buffet ($9.95) and once for sit-down buffet ($11.95).  Overall, the prices are very reasonable but I wish the buffet had a larger selection- for example, offer some appetizer-type dishes.

I especially like that they offer the buffet for take-out, which is very convenient when I have work to do at home and want good-tasting food that will fill me up. The chicken tikka masala is a personal favorite, and the alu mutter is also very good.  And of course, I like that I can take a lot of naan! 

This hits the spot when I'm craving Indian food!

I thought I hated Indian food until a friend convinced me to go to Sitar, and I ended up liking it and so was pretty willing to try a different Indian place when my friends suggested going to New Delhi. 

Unfortunately, it was a little spicy for me, and so I had to eat really slowly. I took dishes that weren't supposed to be spicy, like the saag paneer, but it was still spicy and I had to drink a lot of water and I just didn't end up eating enough to justify paying the dinner buffet price. They do offer dessert at the end of your meal (although I'm not sure if they only do this for dinner buffet), and that was pretty good. It was probably my favorite part of the whole meal.

I'm guessing that people who like spicier Indian food would enjoy New Delhi over Sitar, so if you like spicy food then you will probably enjoy it a lot. Another nice thing is that you can go to their website and sign up for their mailing list, and once in a while they will give out coupons (my friends go here pretty often and someone always has a 15% off coupon that can be used for the whole table).

Caveat: I am carnivore so my review of the buffet here is purely meat-biased. 

So if you are like most Indian-food newbies, your brain thinks Chicken Tikka Masala w/ Basmati Rice and Naan on the side when someone mentions Indian food. Pretty standard fare for American-friendly Indian dishes. If you are like most people, you don't want to spend $12-14 for Tikka Masala/Rice/Naan when you can pay $8-9 at New Delhi for all-you-can-eat of the above plus more!

Chicken Tikka Masala -- very good here, with the inclusion of red peppers throughout. Love the flavor. Not too oily or creamy but just enough of both, with very savory and lean chicken taste. 

Naangasm -- Fold the naan, scoop rice and tikka masala sauce inside, and enjoy!

Lamb Kofka (spelling?) -- deliciously cooked lamb in a very interestingly spiced sauce. 

Wings -- I hate wings, but leave it to Indians to make the best wings. These things are amazing!

Also, you get a scoop of ice cream at the end of your meal -- get mango or chocolate :). 

Try finding a cheaper buffet, specifically on the weekends. I dare you.

Great indian good, great price with dessert all for around 12 bucks, give or take a dollar lol.  Lamb korma meatballs are really yummy and the chicken tikka masala.  Not a big fan of the rice though, im used to jasmine rice so its just a preference.  

Nan bread + the foods mentioned above= Good Eats!!!  and cheap!

For dessert go for the pistacio ice cream!!!

Happy Eatings!!

New Delhi is perfect for a quick, reasonably priced, and tasty meal. What is it? It's a "China Buffet" of Indian Food, but more of the classier side (no pun intended).

I really liked the decorations and the ambiance, for a buffet this was awesome. The chairs are a tad small though.

The wait was about 10 minutes which wasn't bad for a Fri night.

The food doesn't offer a huge selection but it's big enough. I love Indian food but there was still one thing I haven't had before so it was fun to try. They also have a salad bar, with American and Indian toppings. Heads up the Buffet does change everyday so look on their website.

The Tikka Masala was freaking awesome, the rice was great, and the vegetable samasoa was amazing. I also enjoyed the green sauce but last but not least the RICE PUDDING WAS TANTALIZING  I kept wanting more but was sick of getting up to get it (but hey thats excercise). It was warm and tasty. Just right for an Indian Rice Pudding.

In addition New Delhi offers a separate menu if you don't want to do the buffet. 

New Del also seems very clean.

The best deal and best tasting Indian buffet I've ever had. I've only been here a few times for lunch but the options for the buffet are always great and fulfilling. There's not much service to speak of since it's mostly self-serve but they pick up your dishes right away and the desserts I order come out promptly

I used to come here a lot before I discovered Sitar. Definitely get the buffet. I rarely see anyone order from the regular menu. The food here is your generic Indian fare--chicken tikka masala, naan, rice, tandoori chicken, samosas, saag paneer, etc. It's pretty average and I would say the selection is rather limited, not to mention they rarely change up the variety of the dishes they serve in the buffet. They also don't really have any of the fabulous chutneys and condiments that typically accompany an Indian buffet meal. Sitar totally wins on this count. Anyway, most of the protein in general is really dry despite the sauces and most of the dishes are a bit too spicy for me. I feel like they purposely make everything a tad bit spicier, so you'll drink more water and eat less food haha. The highlight of the meal is definitely dessert--get the pistachio ice cream!

My advice: you can try New Delhi once, but then, you really should go to Sitar.

i like that the vegan items in the buffet are clearly labeled as being vegan (as are the gluten free items, for those that care.) the dal and chana masala were pretty good, if a little soupy. as new delhi is right across the street from work i would surely come back here for lunch again.

business.full_address:
283 W 118th Street
Harlem
New York, NY 10026
business.name: Lee Lee's Baked Goods

reviews.text: great chocolate rugelagh

The rugelach here is really good! There are multiple flavors: cinnamon and chocolate. One of them has nuts (I think the cinnamon does).

I look forward to trying their other culinary delights!

At certain times of the day, they run out of stuff, but they are always baking.

Lee Lee's is one of the older institutions in Harlem that can be overlooked by newer, flashier establishments in the neighborhood. As said in many posts, the rugelach here is amazing. The pound cake reminds me of my Grandmother's pound cake; the cake it's dense and the top is crispy. One can go in expecting to buy rugelach, and come out with scones, a characteristic I feel is unique, and unlike the mass-producing chain bakeries that have their goods delivered from an off-site factory. I just picked up a cupcake this afternoon!
The only rugelach they had the day I went was apricot, but it definitely left me wanting more. Delicious and fresh, in a cute, cozy shop to boot. Definitely worth a visit.

In honor of Small Business Saturday, I'm writing a review of one of my favorite little New York gems!  Although I live in Chicago, my husband and I both try our best to make the trek out to Harlem for Mr. Lee Lee's wonderful rugelach when we are in town for the holidays.  We've turned more than a few friends (both New Yorkers and out of town folks!) onto this buttery sweet goodness.  Make sure to call in advance to see if there are any still around... They're so good that they go fast!

They were remodeling this summer, so the place had been closed for a while. But now that they're open, it's totally worth a visit. 

Hands down the best Rugelach I've ever tasted (no disrespect to my Bubbeh or other Jewish Grandmas out there). Buttery and tasty: probably not the healthiest dessert around, but it will surely bring a smile to your face!

Haven't tried any of their other desserts, as I'm always tempted to just get the Rugelach ... but someday I will test and report.
Obviously, you need to get some soon.
A true jewel in harlem , the reviews don't lie on this one this is a must go to if you're in the area treat yourself don't cheat yourself.

We can't speak to the rest of the baked goods--the bread pudding looked tempting--but the rugelach is hands down the best these Ashkenazi Jews have ever had. We include as comperanda Zabar's, the late and lamented Gertel's, and some very tasty 'rugalitos' from an excellent (Dominican?) bakery under the elevated subway at 225th Street. Perfect texture--flaky, slightly crunchy outside--caramelized raisins--some kind of sublime cinnamony goo nestled within. Worth a trip.

When the African American woman at the store around the corner told me I should go to Lee Lee's for "arugalah," I was seriously suspicious, but my shopping companion insisted we try.   Truly terrific rugelach.  My great grandmother would have been impressed.

Okay, I'm a convert. While initially skeptical that I would find delicious rugelach in Harlem, my taste buds have convinced me otherwise. The dough is light and flaky. There's a slight crunch of caramelized sugars on the edges. The insides are moist, studded with raisins.

I've never been a huge rugelach fan; but then again my memories of them are of a small, hard, chewy puck. This is anything but. Definitely recommended.
Agree with other reviewers! Great place! Very nice people! Awesome Rugelach!

On a sidestreet in Harlem is NYC is a still undiscovered spot for the BEST rugleach. Mr. Lee Lee's bakery is a throwback to the days of yore, when small, quaint places run by independent shop-owners who poured their soul into their product abounded. And make no mistake, this gentleman bakes his rugelach with love, from the crispy, flaky melt in your mouth crust to the nuts and chewy raisins stuffed inside each roll that have your tastebuds screaming --this is one terrific cookie. This is rugelach for those who scoff at calories, diets, who have scoured the earth for good rugelach and have been disappointed. I have read every review on rugelach in NYC and after eating Mr. Lee Lee's cookie, knew I had finally been granted entry to rugelach heaven. Walk two short blocks from the train- station to this charming nook and you will be transported to another decade where time stands still and the only hum you hear will be the purr from your stomach. I was there one afternoon and three older ladies were just whiling away the time, sipping tea and eating their cake. Mr. Lee Lee makes rugelach in both chocolate and raisin; get both, savor the first, be addicted to the raisin. He also bakes Southern style cakes and has a Southern breakfast, with grits. Sadly, Mr. Lee had closed down recently due to a lack of pedestrian traffic. He re-opened after local furor--and many tears from those stomachs that were bereft of his amazing cookie. Put this rugelach artist on the map finally. Your belly will growl with pleasure and you will understand what soul food really means.

A word of advice-the master takes his time. Call before you go to make sure he has rugelach. He does not mass produce. He coddles each piece to perfection. So call ahead and ask him to put aside some rugelach if you don't live in the nabe.

One of my favorite bakeries in all of New York City!!  Don't be influenced by its appearance - I promise its a diamond in the rough!

Its known for it cinnamin and appricot rugelach, which is the best rugelach I've ever had (and I live in Queens!)  It's different than any I've eaten before, and when you get it right out of the oven its light, warm, fluffy, and just a makes you happy. 

I also recently stopped by and got 3 chocolate chip cookies for $1!!!  They were buttery and crispy!  Very good, but if you like a big chewy cookie its probably not your thing. 

The only thing I warn against is the bread pudding.  It was good, but very unique.  It had coconut on the top and was nothing like the bread pudding I've had in Virginia. I was a lil disappointed - but still ate the whole thing.

The rugelach is heavenly! I stumbled upon this little shop while walking in the neighborhood. I was about to walk past when the smell lured me in. I bought two rugelach and tried one on my way home. I was oh so tempted to turn around and walk 6 blocks back to get more! They are so good! Warm, moist, buttery. Everything that a typical rugelach should have but lacks.
I love that place, the lady is very friendly and welcoming. Love that cute store.
Every time I swing by to pick something up they are closed.   Perhaps they need to expand their business hours.  It's hard to support a business you can get into.

If you are looking for great customer service then you are looking in the wrong place. If you are looking for homemade, quality baked products then this is the right place for you!  Don't get me wrong, it's not that the owner is unfriendly, just busy and focused on his craft most of the time. Mr. Lee is a one man operation run by a dedicated gentleman with a passion for baking. You might have to wait a while for him to get to you but when he does it is well worth the wait. The rugelach are about 40 cents a piece and if Mr. Lee is in a generous mood (and you've shown him your best side) he might just slip a few extra pieces into your bag! There is also lemon cake, carrot, cake, and more.  Pop in next time you are in the area.

Perhaps the best example of my favorite kind of business:  Choose one thing and do it right.  

I got the last of the chocolate rugelach this afternoon and Lee had to close the door behind me until more batches come out of the oven.  

Sneaked one before my friends come over for dinner - Dee Freaking Licious.

Agreed! The homemade ginger beer and sorrel are fantastic as well. They are the nicest people - I called to see if they were still open the other night, just before 8pm. Apparently  they were about to close but  they offered to stay for 15 min so that I could stop by and pick up a few things.

Not a fan of rugelah so don't care but love this shop and support it.  It's a grab bag for walk ins but the upside down pineapple cake is the closest to the caribe version I've had in the States.  Yum

There are a few places that I've had bookmarked for a long time but haven't reviewed. They're usually hole-in-the-wall, five star places. Call me selfish, but sometimes I just want to keep these place to myself so I don't have to wait an hour every time I want to eat there. This is one of them. 

Hidden in Harlem is the best Rugleach I've ever had. The shop has no frills and they don't kid around with their food. On some days, a very friendly woman sells all vegan food that includes ribs. She loves her food and her customers. While I didn't have any, it smelled amazing. But back to the star--Rugleach. Sweet, buttery, crunchy in all the right places. Get the one with walnuts.

I'm betting that all of you are too lazy to make the hike up into Harlem. I hope that I'm right.

This is probably Harlem's best rugelach.  Of course, I'm not sure how much street cred that gives the place.  Living in [and eating my way through] Harlem, this is the first time I've stumbled across the pastry of Jewish Ashkenazic origin.  So, as far as I know, it's the ONLY place in Harlem to buy rugelach.  Feel free to e-mail me if I'm wrong.  Actually, please do.

Although this does not necessitate expertise - like the cookie itself - I am too of Jewish Ashkenazic origin. So, let me preface my review with the following statements: I've eaten my way in rugelach across Williamsburg [go to greens for the "babka" (mind you, it's not actually babke - it's kokosh), NOT the rugelach!] and Boro Park.  I've tried it in the shukkim [markets] all over Israel.  I've sat down and snacked on them with the winter birds of the temperate Boca Raton [bridge, anyone?].  My grandparents pushed rugelach on me like martinis on WASPs.  I know my rugelach.

So, I was excited to try the "Rugelach by a brother."  Very excited, actually.

It was decent.  The outside was buttery and soft without being overly flaky or extremely chewy [a crisp finish, if you will].  Solid texture.   But the flavor?  It wasn't quite sweet enough for me - maybe they needed some vanilla.  I tried both the standard and the chocolate, and found the fruitiness overpowered the flavors of the cinnamon, sugar, nuts, and chocolate [clearly in the chocolate variety].  These little babies need nurturing and balance.

In addition, chocolate rugelach and cinnamon rugelach were not born equally.  They should taste different.  They have different notes to stress! The chocolate rugelach was too reminiscent of the cinnamon - with a chocolate coating.  Oddly though, the chocolate rugelach was noticeably chewier than the cinnamon.

Would I go here again if I was craving rugelach?  Maybe.  It's a convenient location.  

But, if I do get the craving, I'll probably just trek down to Zabar's.  [Or follow Sam P's advice and go to Epicure in the m-i-a.]

i had the chocolate mousse cake which was good.  chocolate cake + chocolate mousse is pretty hard to mess up so it wouldnt be fair to give anymore than 3 stars.  

something about the place is just not inviting but i didnt care, i had to give it a try at least once.  

reading the other reviews i guess i'd probably give it more stars if i actually ate rugelach.  not sure what its "supposed" to taste like but everytime ive tried it ive hated it.   im not going to try it again---nope--not even from a black bakery in harlem.  sorry, cant do it.

Love, Love Love!!!! We live only a few blocks down this small bakery. I always pass by by but never have cash (they dont accept cards)....until this past wednesday!!! The Rugelach is the best we've ever had. We also got some chocolate chip cookies (YUM), and a yellow cake with chocolate glaze (heaven). The rugelach is a little pricey ($1a piece) but so worth it. Cant wait to try their other goodies.

The store certainly has that neighborhood-y feel to the place. The operations are low key and the selection is nice and simple. Sadly, the quality of the goods are very mediocre.

Everything here is suppose to be made with butter, but I could not taste it. Yes, butter is suppose to have a taste. I tried the rugelach, apple pie, the cookies, and the both types of rugelach. The only thing I enjoyed was the carrot muffin, not for the taste, but for its texture; crunchy on top, soft on bottom. The rugelach had the worst performance, which was ironic since this was the most well known item from this bakery.

Perhaps it's famous because of its tag line 'Rugelach from a brother'. I'd say people just love the 'idea' of this place rather than the goods sold here.

Overall, highly disappointed... I like supporting small businesses, but golly, I would like to know that it's made with quality. This place has been open for 9 years, and the owner has been a baker in Harlem for a good 30 years. I mean... that's impressive and all, but.... again. I am being wowed by the shop's history, not from the rugelach.

The store closed business sometime in 2010 but reopened with the help of community support. Yea, the people in the neighborhood are nice and very supportive, hence with all the very positive reviews over here. But for a fellow like me who travels an hour to taste a special treat, it certainly wasn't worth my trip.

You guys are nice people, and Mr. Smalls himself is a laid back guy, too. But... Yeah. That's all I can say...

business.full_address:
5717 Greenbelt Metro Dr
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Greenbelt Metro Station

reviews.text: Wait? What? I FTRd both Greenbelt stations? This must be a duplicate, right?

The Green Line in general is loud, dirty and I find has the rudest riders on it. This station in particular has a few metro cops but they never seem to be around when rowdy kids get off, pushing and shoving and at times jump the turn stalls leaving without paying. If this is the only means of transportation that you have to get around the DC metro area just be prepared to be annoyed with all the rude riders who have no respect for the posted rules regarding music being played without headphones, eating and drinking on the metro system. Also, don't be surprised by amount of times the F word is said out loud by the students that ride this system daily.

You have been warned.

business.full_address:
14 Spring St
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: Chelsea Crimpers

reviews.text:
I have been coming to this salon for over 6 years. I have never had a bad cut and have always had great coloring services - to the point where people have asked me where I get my hair done!
Chelsea Crimpers has a great group of people with fantastic customer service. Since moving away from Princeton, I still happily drive over an hour to Princeton to have my hair done. I don't think I could go anywhere else and feel as fantastic as I do after coming to this salon.

Do not waste your time or money - or subject your hair to such treatment.  Nice people but complete amateur hour.  I scheduled a blow dry and styling in preparation for a professional photo session.  They did such a terrible job that I had to cancel the p

business.full_address:
3300 Market St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: La Dominique

reviews.text:
I have been passing this truck almost everyday this year and every time I thought, "I need to try this place one of these days." Yesterday I got my chance!
I stopped by after lunch to get a dessert crepe and it was DELICIOUS!
Zbigniew is a genius! It takes him a couple of minutes to prepare each crepe, but it is most definitely worth the wait.
I had the banana strawberry crepe for only $6. Not bad for a crepe this good. Very very very good!

Try it!

I didn't even know I liked crepe's..........but I love them!  I love them and I really love this crepe idea, truck, guy and location.  Zbigniew Chojnacki (crepe guy) is an artist who decided to open up the crepe truck when the recession screwed us all.  Really interesting guy who now puts artistic talent to use in the form of delicious and stasfying crepes. The menu isn't too large.  It's a seasonal menu and offers savory and sweet options.  I went for savory (I'm just that kind of lady).  I had the veggie crepe.  You know it had an assortment of  greens, including creamed spinach, roast peppers, parm cheese and a pineapple habanero sauce (oh yea!) It was made to order.  I could not stop staring at Zbigniew's hands.  He was so graceful and put a lot of love into my crepe.  I wanted to get back there with him. Sorry, my review just got a little intense.
In closing I recommend this place for a great crepe!  The truck is located on Drexel's campus, 32 and Market, so the wait can be a little long, but worth it!

Artisanal is not a word that often precedes "food truck". But make no mistake: Zbigniew is a craftsman. A master, an ARTIST. 

The crepe's are individually made to order, so savor the wait.    Maybe take minute to enjoy the Drexel Dragon sculpture,  or read through all of the reviews proudly displayed on the side of this tiny cart; including a write up from the sorely missed Gourmet Magazine.   Or just watch a master craftsman in his "studio."

I've tried the sweet, and the apple cinnamon sings with fall flavor; but my all time favorite is the vegetable.   FRESH veggies, deftly zested lemon, and cream sauce unite inside a tender crepe.     Delectable.   It's big enough to share, but I never do. 

You'll drop a few more bills than at  other food trucks, but this isn't your ordinary  scrapple and egg lunch cart.    Bring a $10, not a $5. 

The menu changes regularly,  so be a bit flexible.   Go early (before 11:30 am)  or a bit later  (after 1) to beat the crowds.

Ziggy is well-known for two things.
1. He makes excellent, artistic crepes.
2. He makes them extremely slowly.

If you're willing (and able) to wait out the line, you'll get a wonderful crepe made from fresh ingredients, artistically arranged, and for abo

I am a crepe addict. I always get Honey Mustard crepes wherever I can find  them. At this truck, I got an Italian Chicken, which was different from my norm. This crepe had chicken, tomato sauce, rice, and vegetables and it was sooo good. I actually struggled to finish it because it was sooo much food. The owner of the truck was very friendly. I mentioned to him that it was my first time at his truck and he said he hopes I will enjoy the crepe and come back. I will be back ... the crepe was absolutely superb!!!!

These crepes are phenomenal! You will be shocked at the culinary perfection that can come out of such an unassuming food truck on Drexel campus. The crepes range from $5-$8 which may be a lot for a food truck, but the quality of crepe you get makes it a huge steal. Seriously, the skin of the crepe is cooked just the right amount and has the perfect thinness. 

Spring crab is delicious. I was worried the cream cheese would be too heavy/salty like you usually get but I was blown away by how perfectly seasoned the cream was and how nicely it complemented the crab meat. Btw, there was tons of crab meat - gotta love a food truck that's not stingy with its meat! Also, he sliced a couple pieces of tomato on the top - it baffles me how much care and presentation goes into these crepes!

Vegetable crepe is great as well - the spinach is creamed perfectly. Love the added seasonings and the magic sauce he drizzles on. The sweet crepe with coffee cream is a winner as well (have stolen a taste from a friend's) - I will be going back to get my own soon!

I have not eaten here often, because the lines usually scare me away, but I really should do it more often. La Dominique, a crepe lunch truck run by Zbigniew Chojnacki, is frankly delicious. And its proprietor, who is also an artist, makes the crepes into little works of art themselves. The first time I had ever ordered anything here, I was having a bad day, and the apple cinnamon crepe on the menu (which changes seasonally--I didn't notice this one today) seemed to fit the bill to cheer anyone up.

Watching him make the crepes is almost as fun as eating them. Every step has its due: he slices apples to order, arranges them in an attractive fan shape on the warm, buttery crepe, which is then laced with swirls of caramel sauce, pralines, whipped crime, more pralines... suffice to say this was a rather divine experience.

There are also savory crepes on the menu, with a daily-changing special. For example, today's was a veal stew. There is a smoked salmon breakfast crepe that I am dying to try one day, as well as a coconut chicken veggie crepe, served with steamed rice. Today, I ordered the pepperoni pizza veggie crepe (which may be slightly blasphemous to both pizza and crepes, but was reassuringly tasty, with pepperoni, melted mozzarella, and copious amounts of thinly sliced onions). There are a number of different combinations to choose from, all of them wrapped in that light, airy, signature crepe. I also noticed the girl in line ahead of me order some pierogies which looked incredibly tasty, served with onions and dollops of sour cream--I might have to make another trip back for that.

The only downside that I can think of is that it's very slow on school days at lunch time, and the lines can be intimidatingly long, but it's always worth the wait.
I always forget La Dominique is close to my work, but after the Mexican crepe I had today it'll be hard to forget what a delicious and inexpensive lunch I had.  Ziggy is truly an artist!!

After passing this truck a few times, I of course got curious and yelped it. It got really good reviews and the cart itself looked neat, so I gave it a try. I wanted the salmon crepe, but he ran out, so I got the spring crab crepe. Like most Yelpers say, Zbigniew takes his time to make the crepes. You can tell he is truly an artist, and also truly French, from his accent to the way he handles himself and his crepes! It was refreshing just like the name of the crepe, and surprisingly, these crepes get you full! Trust me, I can eat! I've been back a few times and finally tried the salmon crepe and also the Mexican crepe. Very good place to stop for lunch since it's on my campus! I need to try some of the dessert crepes.

I've been thinking about trying this place out for like ages and finally this early afternoon my friend needed to visit a place at 35th & market and he was starving and crying that he needed something quick and big. so La Dominique came to the rescue! 

It was not really lunch time (around 2pm) but there was still a line. The crepes of the day were Mexican, Italian, and Tiramisu. We got Mexican and Italian. The owner/chef seemed really nice and very, very polite. But I do think he should get a helper, which could definitely decrease the time for waiting. But the food (OMFG!) is way more than worthy the wait and the money! I feel I just paid him peanuts for something that sends me right into heaven. 

The Mexican crepe is spicier than the Italian one. It has corn, rice, and something I couldn't tell, with tomato, green salsa and onions on top. The italian one has chicken topped with cheese. 

For crepe lover, stop going to Beau Monde the fancy and expensive and snobbish French place on South street! La Dominique is your next and for-the-rest-of-your-life stop! 

PS, it's so unfair that Drexel's got so many way more incredible trucks than Penn! :(

I just finished eating a crepe from here and was compelled to write this review. 

I ordered the Mexican crepe which was stuffed with rice, ground beef and cheese then topped with salsa and fresh vegetables. It was freaking delicious.  It was a decent size as well and was very filling. Plus it only cost $6, 

There were also many other crepes on the menu, many of them were more dessert orientated but there was an Italian chicken, pepperoni and vegetables and also a breakfast crepe with eggs, sausage and peppers.

Only reason this truck is not getting a 5 star review from me is because it took a looooonnnggg time to get my food. I went with two co-workers and it took a good 20 minutes to complete all three of our crepes.

But if you have the time and the craving for a interesting meal from an upscale cart, def check it out.

Conveniently located in front of W.W. Hagerty Library, this is one of the best food trucks around. The thing is, as other reviewers have mentioned, it does take awhile to get your food, so you need to have some time to spare. These crepes are a work of art and absolutely delicious. I have tried most of the savory types and they are all wonderful, but I keep kicking myself for never making time to try a sweet crepe, as they sound divine. One of these days. All the ingredients are fresh and of good quality, and the crepes always come out perfect. The man who runs the cart, Zbigniew Chojnacki, is a kind and gentle person. I love the way he doesn't get rattled and patiently makes each crepe as if it were the most special thing in the world. I don't eat here nearly often enough, usually due to the time factor, but I certainly enjoy it when I do.

Tip - this is NOT your normal food truck!

Ambiance:  So no shock here, this is a food truck and thus there is little to no ambiance.  It is a quaint little spot with no other trucks around it.  The owner has proudly posted an article about him and his truck on the front window.  Surprisingly quiet block.

Service:  So you queue up in line and wait for him to finish making the prior order and take your order (one at a time!)  So stand around or lean on the railing and be prepared to let newcomers know you haven't ordered and they have to fall in line.  Waiting around isn't a problem as long as you have the time and weather conditions permit.  It is accurate to say that the owner is precise, almost methodical, with his technique.  DO NOT COME HERE IF YOU ARE IN A RUSH.  Because 1 - he will not rush for you and 2 - you want him to take the time on your meal because it will be all the better for it!  A quiet mannered man who runs the cart with a strong sense of rules.

Food:  We tried the breakfast crepe and the tiramisu crepe.  After taking my first bite I thought to myself, "seriously?"  I could not believe that a $6 crepe would have such quality ingredients and well execution.  I almost felt bad that he spent so much time and care making the perfect crepe for little old me.  The quality of ingredients is great, the care put into construction is great, the composition of flavors is great.  This isn't some slap dash crepe, this has been carefully thought out to maximize your eating pleasure.  That being said, it is still a crepe, so it is accessible to a wide spectrum of eaters.

Overall:  I would happily come again because I know it will be delicious.

There's a line and a solid wait to get your crepe but that's because this place is delicious.  It's worth the wait.  The dude making the crepes is so intense and artsy fartsy about the final product.  You are handed something that looks like it should be from some high end restaurant (minus the styrofoam container).

I ordered the veggie which had creamed spinach, broc, peppers, and some other veggies in it with a pineapple habanero sauce.  It was SO GOOD.  I want to put the pineapple sauce on everything I eat for the rest of my life.  My lunch partner got an italian and loved it as well.  See: 2 members of the clean plate club. 

I was kind of upset that they were out of the smoked salmon and spring crab crepe when we arrived (~12:45) but hey, it's motivation to go back soon.

I'd like to think I know a thing or two about crepes. I've tried them in the crepe motherland (France) and am always interested in trying new crepe places because let's face it, they're one of the most delicious things you can eat on this planet, if done right. 

Houston Hall has passable crepes, but given the choice in University City, food trucks are where it's at for crepes. Who would have guessed? A few of my coworkers are obsessed with the Crepewalk crepe truck on spruce st near 36th (http://www.yelp.com/biz/crepes-and-wraps-food-truck-philadelphia) and I dig their blackened chicken crepe as well as the grilled chicken crepe there. But one day a third coworker of mine claimed that there was yet another, better crepe truck. Enter the contender, La Dominique. 

With two crepe carts vying for "best crepe around", we all knew there was only one way to settle this, and that was a crepe off. One wednesday lunch, 6 crepes were purchased... 3 Mexican crepes from La Dominique and 3 blackened chicken crepes from Crepewalk. Since my coworkers were all somewhat biased to favor their favorite crepe cart, I came in to serve as the most impartial of the crepe testers (best job ever). 

Although I hesitated to really choose one crepe definitively over another (they both really are very good!), clearly my stomach and my actions spoke louder, since I only took bites of the blackened chicken, saving most of my appetite for the edible work of art that is the Mexican crepe. Somewhat sweet but savory, like a taco in a crepe with fresh veggies and herbs on top. It was pretty divine. Maybe it was just the novelty of this Mexican crepe compared to the blackened chicken that I had had before that made it so delicious... but I don't think that was the only reason why I liked it so much. It's just a damn good crepe! It's only too bad that it's almost double the distance from my workplace compared to the other carts, and lines can get pretty insane unless you bypass prime lunch times and go early or late. All I can say is, if you want an awesome crepe... check out this cart, get the Mexican crepe and watch the artist chef in action. You won't be disappointed!

business.full_address:
1225 Rt 206 N
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Bagel Barn

reviews.text: Best bagels. Ever. So effing fresh and delicious, it makes me sad there is no place that compares to this fine establishment in Boston. Cream cheese is whipped (I think) so it's light and tasty. I also got lox from there once too, and once again- amazing. I should have taken advantage of this place more while I was in high school, seriously nothing around me now compares. Weird thing about this place is that I ALWAYS see someone I know in there from high school. ALWAYS.

Bagels are good, yes. But I get the feeling that a lot of the reviewers here have either been eating really bad bagels their whole lives and stumbled upon some decent ones finally and are thereby glorifying them, or I must have been eating somewhere else. Many places in Mercer County offer bagels JUST like these, and in some cases, do it WAY better. You guys need to spread your bagel wings and fly some. Onion and herb cream cheese IS way killer, I will give them that much!

Fact:  The best bagel sandwiches are born and raised in Princeton, New Jersey.

Super Fact:  That is 173 miles from where I live (currently.)

Optimum Fact:  This distance does not deter me from gormandizing Bagel Barn whenever (and as frequently as) poss

I can't believe Bagel Barn does not have any reviews... it has a cult following throughout the greater Princeton area. 

A great selection of fresh bagels, deli sandwiches, salads, cold cuts, and snack. Every time I go home I head over for an egg and chee

Went here for breakfast while waiting for car maintenance down the road. What a nice discovery! We almost went to Wawa for coffee which would have been a sad mistake. We got breakfast platters here. Very good non-factory/non-chain bagels in lots of varities, which we can't find in Princeton downtown. We had the rye and the cinnamon-sugar. Very big any chewy, gave our jaws a workout. 

Non-bagels: the eggs and potatoes were good, coffee and sausage ok, bacon not good.

I have to agree with nearly everything that the reviewers before me said... The Bagel Barn has simply the best bagels and sandwiches around! It's our families' "go-to" place for breakfast sandwiches and lunches... hands down!  The service at the counter is not the "warmest" but they more than make up for it with their food, service and price!

Bagel Barn has the best bagels in the Princeton area.  Period.  However, I docked it 1 star for two reasons:  First, Bagel Barn is in a crap location (sorry Montgomery).  Second, if you order your bagel "for here," you get charged an additional $.15.  That is whack!  I am not penny pincher, but I disapprove of the philosophy.

I have lived all over, even had a brief stint in Brooklyn, and these are by far the best bagels I have ever had. A toasted everything with cream cheese tomato and bacon!!! Heaven.  I have never had a bad experience with the staff either, so friendly and chatty. Who cares about a line? It's worth the wait!!!!!!!!

HUGE, ultra fresh bagels with generous amounts of cream cheese and other add-ons make these the best around.  It's been our go to spot for Sunday mornings for a long time.  They get dinged one star for their appearance.  Place could really use a top to bottom sweepin & scrubbin, but who cares when the bagels are so good.

I use to love this place until I placed a catering order with sarah for a platter of 15 sandwiches which I wasn't told the price over the phone. I love to support local business so I figured I would spent 60-70 bucks but when they told me $138, i fell on the floor. i left a message for Sarah to call me and she never did, then I left another message, still not return call and then another.....at this point I will just stack it up to poor customer service and make my own breakfast sandwich going forward. It's a shame but you can't run a business like this guys- Sarah and Orlando....shame shame shame on you!
Their bagels are out of sight!

Hats off to Bagel Barn for its great sandwiches, bagel choices and really nice staff. I don't get there much because Udo's at the Manors Shopping Center in Lawrenceville makes the perfect bagel. I do try to stop in to BB when driving up 206 headed for New England.

Best bagels around, NO question!
Speedy service, but come early on weekends as everyone wants some and the good stuff goes fast!

Ditto great bagels.  Big as a softball.  Chewy outside, soft on the inside.  Cinnamon-raisin tastes like cinnamon & raisin.  Same thing with blueberry.  Gets crazy on Saturday morning.

Location kind of sorry (strip mall), but lines attest to the quality.
Great find for someone new to the area. Went with my 5 year old for our Saturday morning breakfast and we both loved it.  Lox was fresh, and bagels were fresh as they can be.
Stopped in after a workout for snack.  Great selection and service. Yum!
Great bagels. My favorite is the bacon, egg and cheese. This place can get busy, but the wait is never long as the staff are efficient. Guaranteed to see lots of locals every time you go in.

Is this the only bagel shop in Princeton? There really doesnt need to be another one. Whenever im driving on Route 206 on my way to catch a flight at Princeton Airport, I always stop at the Bagel Barn- and although its hidden within a plaza that mysteriously hidden behind houses and very hard to actually find the entrance- its worth the hunt.

I do not know if they are hand rolled or not, but the connotation that hand rolled brings to my mind is hard and dense and actually being rolled by a machine that is maybe operated by a human- finger rolled is probably a better way to say it, but, who cares how these bagels are made, they are great- and the owners are very friendly

The only strange thing about this place, or maybe all bagel shops in Central Jersey do this, is the way ordering takes place. There seems to be an extra step that promotes jumbling of bagel eaters during rush hours.

I remember on the way home from soccer practice when we stopped to go to Taco Bell...and saw this place being built. Never went to that Taco Bell again. Bagel barn is really great. I know it's hard to tell the difference between bagels, but I love the freshness in their selections and of the dairy products. The service are always really friendly and fast. One of the best bagel places in NJ!

The bagels are pretty good actually. The density, crunch, pull, chewy factor and flavor are very good. I have had better but not that often. 

But the cream cheese ratio is always off. This ruins the experience. The flavored spreads are lackluster. 

Other bad news...a bagel with Lox and cream cheese is $8. I have had great smoked fish that I will pay roughly any price for. But this is not what is served here. Add in a cup of coffee and the bill is  now over $10. 

Dont bother with the breakfast platters. The potatoes are plain old bad, i dont know where they buy their eggs and the bacon is precooked (overly so) and then reheated to order. Not the correct way to treat bacon. 

The burgers are indicative of everything that is wrong with mankind. They are emasculated little beasts. Devoid of flavor, texture and joie de vivre. The bun basically gave up any hope of future glory while the dough was still wet. I think they get their tomatoes from someone who hates tomatoes. This foolishness is overcompensated with a massive amount of very nice french fries, like a small-membered paunchy balding man ensconced in a porche. 

Credit for the chicken salad. I do eat this frequently and the dill is a nice touch.

I'm really baffled by the high rating here...maybe there just aren't any other options in Montgomery? Drive to West Windsor or Plainsboro - there are two much tastier establishments (Bagel Hole and Bagel Street, respectively).

What's wrong with these bagels you ask? After all, they're enormous and should therefore be delicious, right? Wrong. When it comes to NJ specialties (i.e. pizza and bagels), there is no correlation between size and deliciousness (this is a fact). 

The bagels here are way too bready...there is a certain "chew" that one looks for in boiled bagels. I'm not tasting it here...

In better news, good cream cheese/variety in bagel offerings. That said, suck up the gas costs and drive east for bagels.

business.full_address:
PO Box 3607
Harlem
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Tussy Air Conditioning and Refrigeration

reviews.text:
My 15 year old fridge was behaving in a decidedly odd way and I really couldn't bear the idea of replacing it right now. A local appliance dealer recommended Tussy who arrived this morning and fixed the fridge within 30 minutes.

He says he also handles air-conditioners, stoves, washer-driers, ceiling fans. Anything but microwaves.

I'm delighted to have found him.

Probably would have been a great repair guy, if he showed up and was communicative.  His secretary called me around 9:30am saying he was trying to find parking.  10:30am came and he didn't show up, so I called call back to find out that he went off to another client and might be back later.  I placed follow-up calls around 12pm and 3pm to try to get an update, and the secretary says he didn't return her calls yet.   Finally I call around 5:15 and secretary tells me he won't be coming today and I would need to re-schedule.   

While I understand that they have busy schedules and would have been willing to reschedule, I am mostly upset that they didn't have the courtesy to update me on his showing up later or that he wasn't going to come at all.  I took a day off work and spent the entire day at home waiting for him.  Insane.  

I ended up finding another great repair guy that showed up the very next day at the time promised and got the job done.  he even came after work hours, so I didn't have to take another day off.
It's not 2 months later and the relatively minor repair that I drastically overpaid for has now rebroken. I will need to find someone new because I won't do business with them again.

I really like the guys who came to repair my two air conditioners, but both units are still broken and, even worse, it's impossible to get in contact with Tussy to finish the job. I called seven times last week just trying to get an appointment for them to follow up. Regardless of whether it's negligence on their part or intentional, I've paid them $500 for two unsuccessful repairs so far and I'm not even getting the courtesy of a return call. I absolutely cannot recommend this business...it's no way to do business at all.

I am so impressed. Our air conditioner decided to break down just as the humidity is raging of course. So I called this place and the repair guy said he could be over in 30 minutes. Excellent! He arrived and was courteous and quick, and diagnosed that the computer is broken on my GE air conditioner and there's nothing he could do -- i need to order a new control panel. And then when I asked him how much I owe him, he said nothing. WOW! Who does anything for free anymore? I gave him a $10 tip and thanked him. I'm just so impressed at how quick, efficient, and not greedy this guy was. Definitely call him if your air conditioner is busted! And he recommends to not ever buy one that's digital. Figures.

business.full_address:
544 W 113th St
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Symposium Greek Restaurant

reviews.text:
I have been meaning to try this restaurant since I first passed by it on the street months ago. I'm so glad I did!

My usual rating of a restaurant has four criteria: quantity, quality, atmosphere, and the price you pay for all of that.

Quantity:
The quantity of food served here is good. I was a bit worried when our $13 appetizer came out; it was only the size of a small plate. But it turned out to be so rich that my boyfriend and I together could not finish it if we were going to have any room for the entrees. We left a bit of dip, some cucumbers and tomatoes. We didn't finish the entrees either, I've got some mousaka in my fridge for tomorrow.

Quality:
Honestly, I felt the appetizer was more exotic and flavorful than the entree. But maybe that's just because I love garlic and the appetizer sampler included an extremely garlicky dip. Either way, everything we had was delicious and fun to eat. Everything was very authentic, which counts for a lot of points in my book. Where else are you going to get real Greek food in Morningside Heights? Also, they had vegetarian versions of a lot of Greek classics, which was exciting for me because as a vegetarian, I usually have to pass up many Greek specialties. Also, I was impressed that they had a specialty Greek wine called Retsina. This wine sits in pine barrels instead of oak barrels, giving it a distinctive taste; retsina is traditional in Greece and unique to the country. I tried it for the first time, just the house wine here in a carafe, and it was great. 

Atmosphere:
Great art, very friendly service. Not too crowded. Essentially, the atmosphere added to the value of the meal rather than detracted from it.

Price:
Fair.

I'm obsessed with Greek food, so when my friend suggested Greek food, I was definitely in. Plus, our host was an adorable little Greek man - absolutely loved it. I had the Moussaka - so good. It was also delivered super quickly, which was great since I was in a hurry. The menu is a bit hard to read since it's so full, but the host will tell you everything you need to know.

The Symposium is also absolutely delicious - enough for a meal for one or an appetizer for four. There's also unlimited pita bread with the dips - which makes my tummy so happy.

I'd come make the trek back up here whenever - and next time I'm so ordering the flaming cheese. I WANT TASOS TO SCREAM OPAAAA!

-1 star simply because the vegetables on the side of the Moussaka seemed like canned vegetables. But it was totally okay because everything else was so fun and delicious. Plus, Tasos managed to move a booth when two of us couldn't. It was hilarious - two girls who work out constantly couldn't move a booth but an old frail-looking Greek man could. Ridiculous and brilliant.

I went to Symposium fairly often when I lived in the area back in the mid 1980s.  Went back recently just to see if it still exists.  It does and its as steady as ever.  The taramasolata, baba, hummus all rock.  The entrees are large and authentic.

My girl Stacy showed me this place and it's got Greek down better than Zorba.  Fo realz.  The lamb kebob is fantastic and deyz even got a cheese they set on fire!  The pita is warm and tasty and you can't beat their mediterranes apps like the hummous, babs ganoush and the like.  Tuesday nights you get a discount if y'all rolling with the elite of Columbia.  Otherwise, yo ass pays full price.  Either way, it's worth it.  Oppa!
Good food. An old fave from the 60's.
Good greek food.  I usually get the gyro.  I love the sauce and the pita is nice and fluffy.  The gyro comes with a small greek salad, and that's pretty good too.

Let's get the positives out of the way first: the service was quite friendly and efficient, the pita bread was good, and we didn't get sick from our meal.

Unfortunately, everything else was disappointing. The food was such a let down- vegetarian moussaka was reheated (and overcooked), with the vegetables lacking flavor and the sauce under seasoned. Lamb souvlaki was quite salty and chewy, without any of the juiciness nicely cooked lamb should have straight off the grill.  Both dishes came with sides, which included reheated rice, boiled potato, and canned beans in a watery tomato sauce. Basically the antithesis of Greek cooking- no fresh, bold flavours, no garlic, and no olive oil! While the waiter was friendly, this alone won't get us back to Symposium.

So there was a fair amount to complain about after my visit here:
- My meal tasted like it was microwaved and covered in cheap cheese, and the rest in my group had lamb shiskabob which was so salty it was practically inedible. 
- Shrimp was overcooked as well. 
- Octopus was the chewiest I have ever eaten. 
- Red wine tasted watered down. 

The service was OK, but the food was trash.  
Go to Elias Corner in Astoria...

Having recently graduated law school, I'm on a Morningside Heights spree, and consequently, have been writing some really bitchy reviews. 

Symposium is no exception. 

Terrible! Can't even ONE restaurant step up its game? 

An uninspiring (and entirely illegible) menu, bland food, and tough meat. The crew is always friendly enough, but I could never talk myself into going more than once every 6 months. 

Next please.

The only dish I like here is the Symposium salad, which is AWESOME. Makes for a meal by itself. 
Now, I don't know a lot about Greek food, but everything else I've gotten here is just...meh.
It can get really crowded here for dinner, so my recommendation is to get the Symposium Salad to go for lunch and eat it outside. Perfect picnic meal with the bread and all those different dips!

My department went here for our holiday party/dinner and it was a very fun time. The owner/manager type guy was super cute and friendly, and makes the experience feel like you are in  a restaurant out of a classic NYC movie. It is definitely one of those neighborhood places where if you go there a few times, he will remember your name.

The food was decent. It wasn't the best greek food I had ever had, but the atmosphere really added an extra layer of fun to the whole equation. Some dishes were noteable: Their eggplant dip was super delicious, and the bread (good bread really matters!) was soft, hot, and delicious. They have a spinach rice dish that my boss ordered and it was super yummy. The tzaziki was really really good, nice and tangy.

All up, I will definitely be back.

The pitas were warm and crusty, the baba ganoush was rich and creamy, and the flaming cheese was served with an,"OPA"! by the kind, yet slightly gruff, Greek uncle I never had. I ordered the symposium salad, which included an assortment of creamy dips like tzatziki and baba ganoush along with a block of feta and stuffed grape leaves. All delicious, but vegetarians beware, it usually comes with a fish dip so be sure to ask that they omit that one when you order. Tucked away along a line of apartment buildings, Symposium is probably one of the easiest to miss must-not-misses in the area.

In a neighborhood of bland, boring restaurants, Symposium is a breath of fresh air. Okay, the food isn't spectacular, and it looks very home style (which I find charming, anyway), but it is certainly tasty enough. The service is SPECTACULAR, it's great for groups and the decor (and menu layout) is very 70s and hilarious to me. I especially enjoyed the baklava which was the perfect texture and soaked in lots of yummy honey.

I love this place.  Authentic Greek cuisine at a decent price.  Chefs prepare all dishes just like they do in Athens, Mykonos, and Santorini.  Mythos, Greek beer, complements all the entrees.  Good for groups.  Crazy to read menu.  Tasso was such a great waiter - very welcoming. He's such a nice guy and will make anyone feel right at home with his conversation.  Go here and Go Greek!

It's a pleasant enough inside and the people are friendly. But the food... oh god. I've been twice now: the first time I got one of the spinach pie type things and it was bland and boring, overcooked and mushy. So last time I went I thought I'd try something a little simpler: the Symposium omelette. Pretty hard to fuck up an omelette. What I got one one of the most dispiriting things I've ever been served: a blob of burnt fried eggs mixed with some dill and spinach slop, garnished with a boiled potato that was brown from oxidization. Boiled potato garnish? It's hard to imagine a worse plate of eggs. Why anyone with any pride would serve such a thing is beyond me. 

However, the appetizer plate of hummus, tiramosalata etc. is quite good.

Symposium is a homey Greek restaurant with a pleasant staff and generally good food. The pita bread is out of this world GOOD and plentiful. Greek salad is a good starter, although it doesn't deviate at all from the ubiquitous Greek salad it's good nonetheless. Spanakopita (spinach and feta pie) was also a very good starter. As far as entrees you can't go wrong with the gyro or souvlaki; again these aren't the best gyros I've ever had but they are more than serviceable. 

The one issue I have is the question of sanitation; on one occasion I saw a mouse there (in fairness that was a couple years back and I haven't seen one since). The ambiance does leave a bit to be desired but it's still a cool place to share a meal with some friends (like I said it's homey and the incredibly kind staff makes you feel like a part of the family). I recommend Symposium to anyone near Columbia U. looking for some affordable and good Greek food!

It always really surprises me that Symposium doesn't get better reviews. Sure, the design on the menu is busy but anyone who "can't read it" probably just can't read. Maybe you've had better spanakopita, but their dish is still very good, and generous...

The food itself is great, but it's standard Greek food, with no frills or flourishes. If you're a vegetarian, like me, you have a range of options, from massive salads to heavy baked dishes (spanakopita, moussaka). 

Tucked away in a basement on an otherwise entirely residential block in an out-of-the-way neighborhood, it's obviously not trying to be "downtown" trendy; instead, the vibe is warm, genuine, homey -- to the furthest extent imaginable, in fact: my waiter (the owner?) put his hand on my back and brushed my shoulders no fewer than five times during the course of my meal.* Ordinarily, that probably would have made me uncomfortable, but this is a place where, as a rule, the service is beyond friendly: it's intimate. On at least one particular occasion when I was there the staff seemed to know every customer on a first-name basis. A number of them were even invited to step into the kitchen (not sure why, but again, it's a very friendly place). You get the sense that the owners really want you to enjoy your food and the whole experience. I, for one, appreciate that.

*I know what you're thinking. No, there was no quid-pro-quo here. I genuinely like this place, regardless of any backrubs that I may have received with my meal.

I liked the flaming cheese appetizer. My chicken a la Greco was decent, though a little dry. I couldn't figure out what was exactly "Greco" about it, but what do I know? Actually, Greek food is huge where I'm from (Toronto), so I guess I've had my fair share of it growing up--so maybe I was a little disappointed about my choice of rather-dry chicken.

I thought the restaurant had a nice vibe going on though: a quaint little place hidden among a row of apartment buildings; a unique menu, even for an already non-mainstream cuisine. By that, I mean it wasn't your standard souvlaki/gyros/Greek salad joint; they had meat pies, eggplant dips, lots of lamb dishes, and other less common items. Props for that.

In the end, Symposium is a decent place I would probably go back to once in a while.

A cute restaurant tucked away on a residential street ... you feel a bit weird walking off Broadway and the sea of restaurants in the area, but then, there it is. The food was pretty good ... I liked the mousaka better than the souvlaki, but they were both good. The galaktoboureko dessert was fantastic.  The service really stood out here, and really added a lot to the dinner.

Just remember when putting out the flaming cheese, the lemon wedges can be slippery ... one shot out of my hand and nearly bopped the woman at the next table. Very dangerous. Or, more likely, I'm just clumsy ...

A large group of us went here for dinner one night.  Instead of being seated in the front dining room we were lead (through the kitchen, if memory serves) to a second dining room in back.  I like to think of this as the VIP treatment.  Anyway, the staff was very accommodating and we practically had that rear dining area to ourselves except for another small party.

I had a tough time deciding what to order (par for the course) b/c everything on the menu sounded so yummy.  I ended up going with the moussaka (no, not moose kaka) b/c I like it and I kind of think it's a good reference point for judging Greek food.  Well, the moussaka rocked.  If I had a Greek grandmother, this is how her food would taste, i.e., not trying to dazzle, just letting you know she cares A LOT.  

Overall, we were extremely happy with the meal and service and had a great night because of it.  Definitely will be back.  As far as I'm concerned, Symposium is a real M'side gem.  Opah!

I think it is a little hit or miss. Maybe you have to know which dishes to get. The cheese on fire was tasty (and cool! haha). I remember one time the side veggies looked like they were out of a can. I like the gyro.
The restaurant owner is usually there chatting with people. It has character.

Homey and delicious, feels like a neighborhood(/Columbia) favorite, and  a great respite from pretentious restaurants. 

I recommend going on a Sunday night and ordering the peasant's salad (I think that's what it was called).

definitely had better greek in this city. things started off promising - giant basket of warm pita, which we all started pounding like there was no tomorrow. we started with their yogurty-cucumber something or other dip, which was decent and the the popular salad (i'm so lukewarm about this place that i can't even be bothered to pull up their menu and reference the exact item), which was anticlimatic. the service though was pretty impressive, i must say, even if we were 1 of 2 tables being served at 9:30 at night... the waitstaff actually brought one of my girlfriends (the bombshell by far - coincidence? i think not) a sampler of all their dips, and then when she later just MENTIONED that she enjoyed the eggplant one, they brought us a whole plate on the house! 

so it was in good spirits that we sailed into entrees, which unfortunately disappointed. the chicken kebabs were dry, and the vegetable moussaka (sp?) seemed like someone stopped trying halfway through making it. 

i'd prefer not to go again, but if i did i'd probably stick to the appetizers.

Casual dining in a restaurant with bright lighting where you could perform surgery on those tables. 
Score for ambience: 0

They were preparing for a large party from the Renaissance performance, so getting a waiter to actually "wait" on us was an issue. We actually  had to get up and ask to be waited on twice.
Score for service: 0 

They had a very interesting menu in terms of how it was presented. Even with the bright lighting it was not easy to read. We had the traditional spinach pie (spanakopita), tzatziki, Lamb shank with rice and green beans that looked and tasted like they came out of a can.
The lamb shank was tender and tasty with interesting spices. 
Score for Food: 3 

I won't put Symposium on my list of favorite Greek restaurants.

We were so excited when we stumbled upon this charming little Greek place last Sunday! Low-key, fair prices and good food - at least at consumption. Within a few hours, both of us had severe tummy aches. We both had lamb gyros so not sure if the bad reaction was limited to our choice of plate but we were saddened to have to remove if from our Sunday dinner list.

Eh, after re-visiting this place, I'm sad to report that I'm no longer satisfied by the food here. The ambiance leaves much to be desired, and while reasonable, there's now an upper west alternative that is much nicer and more convenient, with better food (Kefi in the west 80's). I don't think I'll be returning...

PROS: Great set-up for this place. Underground, totally crazy and almost illegible hand-drawn menu (see photo), humming with activity, and a hospitable wait staff. 

CONS: The food. Nothing outstanding. 

Go for a good social place with a neat sense of character, but don't expect to be floored by the food.

This place made me feel like I'd stepped into either a time machine, a teleporter, or both.  You've still got it, New York.

The gregarious host, Tasos, is an integral part of the experience.  The poor guy had heart surgery shortly before my visit, so you'd better get in while he's still in tip top shape.  Let him tell you stories.  Ask about his cat.  He's a great guy, and you couldn't ask for a more authentic Greek server.

First, when you get in, do yourself a favor and order the flaming cheese.  Do it.  OPAAAA!

We went for lunch, so they'd just opened.  When the bread came out, the fresh-out-of-the-oven smell drove me crazy waiting for something to dip it in.

As I only had the one visit while I was in town, I ordered the potpourri sampler to try as many different foods as possible.  (Warning: this is quite sufficient for sharing between two meek eaters.)  Least favorite part was the meatballs, which were still good.  The spinach pie was pleasantly sweet and flaky.  I think my favorite was the mousaka.  It was like Greek beef lasagna with some kind of crack spices in the meat.

It was a little more expensive than we'd expected, but the food was good and our server was very attentive. We got the tzatziki (small plate of it for 6.95) and grape leaves (4 or 6 for 6.95) as apps, and honestly with the bread basket I could have made that a meal all on its own! Carafe of wine for $24. Also got the chicken pita platter, which came with a side salad, rice, more tzatziki, and strips of chicken on a pita (9.95 or 10.95 I think?) and my boyfriend got the moussa...laka? (sort of like lasagna. Also 9.95)

I didn't love the chicken meat, but all other aspects of the meal were good.

one of my favorites from my days in morningside heights. my order is always the same: flaming goat cheese (putting out the fire with the lemon wedges they give you is almost as fun as eating it), symposium salad and sangria

Definitely a good value for what you get.

I too found the menu quite illegible... I had to ask which dishes had orzo as that's what I was craving, but aparently it only comes with a heavy-sounding lamb stew. I got a gyro instead -- and was a bit disappoi

I find that my Greek food experience has been rather limited due to my inability to read long, complicated Greek words. The menu really didn't help with this predicament...completely illegible and I'm pretty sure I missed half of the stuff on the menu because of sheer confusion. I ordered a chicken gyro and my friend ordered some other dish with chicken and lemon. The gyro was okay. Very bland, and I'm not even sure if it was worth the $9 that i dished out for it. The service was pretty slow considering how many other tables were in the restaurant..but they were friendly and the ambiance is very cutesy and underground. A very refreshing environment compared to piss loud restaurants on B'way.

My friend and I meet here for lunch about once a month. Love the friendly service, and the lunch prices are reasonable ($10 per person, including tip). From the lunch menu, I prefer the platter of yummy dips and pita bread (the eggplant dip is really delicious), the moussaka (heavy, but I take half home and eat it for dinner), and the chicken dish.

Symposium has a homey quality that we really like. Comfortable, no pretensions. Nice change from a lot of NYC restaurants that try to be something they're not.

The food's not special, but the experience is good. Friendly, relaxed. Get a beer, order lots of little things and enjoy the people you're with. The roast chicken was tasty, and... don't miss the flaming cheese.

Nestled amongst residences & CU buildings, Symposium boasts a cool below-the-street space. Great Symposium Salad, which was plenty of food for $8.50 for lunch; not cheap but certainly nowhere near a bad value. Service did what it needed to, and I was in and out in 7 minutes, tops.

The hubster and I came here after a long day. 
A heavy set man with bushy eyebrows screams 'OOmpa!' while flourishing a dish with orange flames to a table near the kitchen. Loving the presentation and hearing great things about the flaming cheese, we ordered the saganaki (broiled Greecian sheep's milk cheese).
Then I nervously began edging myself towards the wall, in anticipation of hot fat from the cheese and flames shooting out of the dish. The dish comes out with a shout and the flaming saganaki.  In my eagerness to extinguish the flames with the lemon wedge, I squeezed too hard and the juice spurts all over my husband's coat, the leather seat next to him and half of his face, with only a few drops falling on the dish. 
He manages to extinguish the flames and we dig in. The outer layers were browned and had a crunch to it and the innards looked tasted like melted mozzarella with slightly salty nutty flavor.
We also feasted on Potpourri of Greek Foods sampler and Gyro platter. For the gyro platter, the best part was the tzatziki with the beef gyro: the cool cucumber dip contrasted well with the salted broiled beef. The potpourri was a medley of Greek food: roasted beef, Pastichio, spinach pie, a potato casserole, a side of rice, greens (okra, green beans, peas) roasted potatoes, and two meatballs. I enjoyed the Pastichio the best: the ground beef was flavorful, well salted with hints of thyme which complimented the eggplant and the tomatoes. It was rich, moist, sweet and savory. 
The food here is good if you order the Greek specialties and you enjoy traditional Greek food. Come hungry. Expect a hearty meal and bring loose pants. (I made the mistake of wearing newly washed jeans and man- they made eating a little uncomfy).

A pleasant find while exploring the Columbia undergrad campus with a friend.

Good atmosphere. The menu was also very interestingly designed. I had a Chicken Saganaki, which was pretty good. Chicken pieces were boneless and tender, and the cheese complemented it pretty well. It also came with rice and stewed green beans. I also tried their gyro, which was solid. their Eggplant Dip, which was one of the better ones I've had, and I love baba ghanoush.

The good: Good Mediterranean food. All the meat was flavorful and tender. Friendly atmosphere, too. the portion sizes were good as well.

The bad: none to report.

The meh: Pricing was a little more than I'd have expected to pay.

A really great authentic Greek restaurant.  My mother in law is from Greece and an excellent cook and this is the first restaurant I have been to that compares.  I noticed that many people have gotten the gyros, but if you are interested in real Greek homestyle cooking check out the dandelions, taramosalata (fish roe salad), moussaka... they have an EXCELLENT vegetarian version of this dish and a few others.  I found that the owner and his son who waits tables there to be really friendly and surely they will help you with the menu if you don't know Greek.  The place itself is sort of divey but charming and clean.

The ambiance in this restaurant is distinct: a lot of older locals who seem to have been patronizing this restaurant for years, mixed with Columbia students.  A nice vibe, which is complemented by the trippy, doodling-filled menu.  The Symposium salad (a mix of different Greek appetizers) was wonderful, but stop there.  I didn't (I should have listened to the other reviewers).  The entrees will disappoint, though a glass of ouzo will make you feel better.

Went to symposium with my boyfriend, our old friend and my bf's sister - our first time 'hangin out' so to speak.  The Saganaki was pretty amazing, and the souvlaki looked great. I ordered a grilled chicken - was it lemon chicken? that had no lemony flavo

I'm appalled I didn't find this place sooner.  I've been living 4 blocks away for a year now, and never really noticed it.  Who expects a restaurant to be between avenue blocks, though?  Really.

This place is located between Broadway and Amsterdam on 113th, and it's straight out of the 1960s. The decor is very hippie-ish, and the menus are a sort of psychedelic-style drawing that require examining, rather than reading.  But after you get past that initial hurdle, the food is superb.

I had the Symposium salad, which is described as a "conglomeration of appetizers", and I wasn't disappointed.  Basically consisting of various spreads, some vegetables, and a basket of slightly toasted pita bread, it caters to what makes me tick: bread and sauce.

After that, I had the gyro platter, which was equally delish.

To top the whole experience off, since my girlfriend and I looked youngish, they assumed we were Columbia students and gave us a 20% discount. 

Coincidentally, we're both Columbia students.

Dare I not love this place.  Yes, the waiter service was great, the decor was awesome, BUT the food left a little something to be desired.  Now some people may love the following fact, but when I go out to eat I want the food to look like it came from a r
Symposium has a comfortable, neighborhood-y feel and the food is delicious. Highly recommended! I love the crazy menu!
best sangria and cheese (on fire) ever!

I actually found this place using that handy urbanspoon iphone application (yes, i also have the yelp app, but come on, if you can't decide where to eat, IT DECIDES IT FOR YOU!). I would have never found this place otherwise, and it looks really cute, got food to go, and I have to say I was disappointed. Compared to previous greek food I've had, this was super heavy, ate the same old, but Symposium's food sat in my stomach like a lead weight. I'm definitely willing to go back, perhaps eat inside the cute restaurant, to give it another try, but i'm a little wary. Had the moussaka, maybe that was a bad choice, will try something lighter next.

Never really thought of going here until a friend and I decided to pop in for a glass of sangria early this year. Ever since, we've had a weekly Symposium sangria tradition. The amounts keep increasing too, we've gone from 2 people and a glass each to maybe 7 or 8 and three to four pitchers every time.

The place is wonderfully decorated. I wouldn't call it traditional Greek but it's different, for sure. The menu is also weirdly nice, absolutely no other way to describe it. The staff are friendly but my favourite aspect of this restaurant is the owner, who walks around personally refilling your water, asking if everything's good, recommending dishes while dissing others (he once helped me choose between two dishes because he made a face and said 'frozen' when I suggested it). Also quite touchy, his hands linger on your shoulders. Not in a creepy way though.

We've also obviously had a chance to sample some of the food. The flaming cheese appetizer is very tasty, and the way it's presented is cool. The owner comes out of the kitchen with the flames two to three feet high and says "OPAAAA" in a very loud voice, so the entire restaurant pays attention. It doesn't get old.

The souvlaki is decent, nothing special but also can't fault it. The sangria is (obviously) delicious, I could subsist on nothing but sangria if I had to. The appetizer pita bread is free, bottomless and delicious and finally the gyro platter is filling, perhaps a bit too filling. I could hardly move afterwards.

All in all, a great place to go for lunch, sangria and casual conversation. Nothing fancy but a nice place for a chill date too.

Very cute, old-style , mom&pop Greek place!

The menu is a little difficult to read.. but it definitely has character, and if anything.. makes your experience at Symposium more of an adventure!

Our waiter was very helpful and joked/flattered us, making us feel very at home at his place.

We ordered the Mousaka (pretty good), and Chicken Gyro Platter (not THAT impressive, but good!). 

Perhaps we should've ordered different thngs that were recommended on Yelp, but I thought this place was aiite. Because of how friendly they were, though, I want to give them another try, so I'll be back!

First, honest disclosure, I'm Greek, but that should make my review tougher, being used to Greek home cooking.  This is the best place, in my opinion, to have lunch in the Morningside/Columbia University area or dinner for that matter.  Right by Columbia but off the hustle and bustle of Broadway, a place that treats regulars like family. Solid, good Greek food that feels like mom is making it back in the kitchen.
