You can get a burrito or fast food for $10, but here you can sit down, get a pitcher of water, soup, a delicious entree, and be treated well for around the same.  Chicken a la grecque, the lamb souvlaki (which I always get), are always good.

Came here about five months ago. I went with a couple Columbia students who tell me this is one of the places to go, and I could see that the food was pretty authentic. But either I'm not a fan of authentic Greek food, or everything was just pretty bland. I had the sampler dish, which was an assortment of perhaps four (or more) dishes, so I think I got a pretty good sense of the food here. By the end of the meal, I don't know if I was getting full or just bored. The servers were friendly and the interior was interesting, to say the least, but the food simply lacked any sort of excitement. Highly unlikely I will return, unless if in good company.

Tasso is a wonderful host. Every time I come here I feel like I'm back home with friends. he know how to welcome and treat you with care and professionalism.

But the food is not as good as it used to be. The kebabs I had were dry and the rice and vegetables plain. The quality was still good, but the dishes weren't as interesting... something I feel I could easily cook at home as well.

Nevertheless, prices are unbeatable, and the place is still a warm cozy corner in the Columbia area.
Best Greek food in NYC

Yelp totally captured my sentiments on this with, "meh."  

I've been twice, and each time I've left wishing I'd gone somewhere else. In the restaurant's defense, my friends seem to love it, but I'm just not feeling it. There's a freshness that draws me to Greek food that's lacking here, in the mousaka in particular, which was just kind of mushy and bland.  Very monochrome. Although, from reading other reviews, it seems like the salads are the way to go, and I still want to see this garden.  Maybe next time.

They have a seriously cute menu.

I mean, it's seriously cute.

The food, though... well, it's okay. There's a good selection of salads, and they even offer a traditional greek salad (called the "Peasant Salad"). I wasn't impressed with the freshness or texture of the produce, however, I got the "Greek Salad", and the iceberg lettuce in it was actually bitter. Bitter! Also, strangely, the feta cheese was in two huge logs on the salad rather than in the more traditional crumbles or pieces. However, the challenge just added to the appeal. 

The servers are very friendly and responsive.

The owner was there throughout the meal to make sure my friends and I were comfortable and enjoying the food. This is a small place, but it was almost full, so I was surprised and happy with the attention. The souvlaki was great and the thick pita with tzatziki, in which it was wrapped,was excellent. Cheap and a little divey, this was a fun and speedy meal.

This place rocks!!! I repeat, that this is the BEST Greek restaurant I've EVER been to. The Moussaka is sublime and the Spanakopita melts in your mouth. Novices should order the Potpourri of Greek Foods as an awesome introduction as well as the large Symposium salad which isn't a salad at all but a sampling of all their most delicious spreads and dips. Treat yourself to a generous pitcher of sangria while you're at it and enjoy the bohemian art and atmosphere.

This hole in the wall Greek restaurant is the real deal.  Family owned in the Columbia neighborhood, everything here is sublime.  Don't expect anything fancy, it's paper napkins and laminated menus, but the food is to die for.  

The saganaki is delicious, although granted is difficult to go wrong with flaming cheese.  Souvlaki is their specialty, although the pastitsio is my favorite.  Also worth getting is the Greek sangria.  I've still yet to figure out what makes it Greek, but it's delicious and strong.  Also the Symposium Salad which has been mentioned is quite good.  As already discussed, it is an array of Greek spreads served with pita, and is very tasty.

The owner may flirt with you if you're a woman under the age of 40, but it's all in good fun, and he and everyone that work there are the nicest people.  They are very accomodating to groups and any special needs and requests you may have!

I fell in love with this place, even though I've only been there once. First of all, yes, it's underground and it's slightly dinky, but it has charm. When you walk in, instantly you're greeted with friendly, warm faces. The decor is soothing and rustic -- just my kind of place. The entire restaurant oozes familial sentiments. It seemed as if the owner knew most of the people who ate there. He genuinely inquired about their lives, hugged them, gave them extra pita bread. 

Second, for around 8 bucks, I got a delicious, flavorful chicken dish. The chicken was broiled and obviously marinated with spices and herbs. I took my books with me. No one ever rushed me. The owner and his son came over, chatted with me, and joked with me. Basically, if you're looking for scrumptious, fairly healthy food and good vibes, this is the place to go.

I'm just so sad seeing all these mean, terrible reviews. This place is a staple for Columbia students and professors and has been for decades. It is an institution run by a bunch of old-school Greeks - not  an establishment out to garner attention from the New York Times and I think this must be taken into consideration when reviewing it. The atmosphere is genial, kooky and literary  - the menus and decor are inspired by the Greek play, Symposium, all about the different types of love. The wooden tables and booths are worn smooth by generations of diners. The sangria is cheap and good and comes with a big honking wooden spoon. The owner is a doll and remembers regulars (like I was). The little jar of mints on the glass counter up front is a delightful yet unhygenic relic. And of course, the flaming cheese is always a spectacle that warrants a loud OPA from the owner as he carries it out.
Look, most of the dishes are mediocre, but you gotta know what to order! The Symposium Salad is divine and I dream about all its salty dips. The pita is excellent and freshly made. Baklava, sweet and delicious. The meat? Eh. The fish? Probably wouldn't order it. This is one of those places that Time forgot, so go and appreciate it for what it is (and ordering the right thing helps). I am the last person to say something like this, but it's not really about the food at Symposium - it's about everything else. It's long been a Columbia haunt and it has stubbornly resisted the yuppification and severe makeovers that almost every other NYC restaurant has undergone. People pack into this place year after year because they appreciate the unique charm that this restaurant has - and it rubs off. You lurch up the steps out onto the street warm and happy from sangria and cheer. It is a time capsule and honestly, it has the best darn pikilia that I have tried in NYC.

The food is not stupendous, but the sampler salad with a glass of wine is pretty tasty! Nice atmosphere, too. Ducking in here on a rainy night and relaxing with some good food is a nice way to spend the night. Not a fan of the entrees I've tried, I stick with the salads and appetizers.

my favorite tsatsiki ever with delicious warm pita. big fan of the chicken a la greco and the gyros as well.  The flaming cheese is a popular one - always brought into the room with a big "oppa!" (the splendor is well justified once you bite into that delicious gooey cheese).  The owner is incredibly warm and friendly - setting the tone for a great family establishment that keeps you coming back for more!

More Subterranean than Mediterranean...

Sure they take reservations but, like the Seinfeld joke, they don't know how to keep them.  If that wasn't bad enough, they shuffled our part of 6 from table to table to table, until we landed right in front of the door (in the middle of the winter), getting frozen and dealing with everyone's coats. 

As for the food; Greek is a general way to describe it.  I was appalled by the saltiness of the lamb, not to mention that dry, over-cooked, almost stringy quality.  It came with lima beans and carrots, you know - the generic mixed vegetables you thought you would never have to deal with after college.  The rice tasted like it had been in a steam tray for a few hours.  Any hint that it was once a grain had long passed.  

The staff was fairly apathetic.

The menu, arguably the pinnacle of this dining experience, is very creatively drawn.

I will give a restaurant a pass for one or two foibles.  Symposium will get neither a pass nor a return visit.

This little gem is literally tucked in a street between Broadway and Amsterdam ave and has been one of my favorite restaurants in the vicinity when I was a student at Columbia University (2010-12). The service is extraordinary and the host goes out of his way to make everyone feel welcome. Everyone, i kid you not. I got the chicken gyro and grape leaves on most lunch dates with my BFF. In a larger gathering though, we tried their sample symposium starter platter which was another favorite. Their sangria's delcious as are is the mousaka. But the one thing that makes me dream of Symposium now that I have moved to the other coast is their PITA BREAD. Oh. My. God. The softest, warmest, freshest, best pita bread I have ever tasted in my life, that too, complimentary! It hits the right spot every single time.

I've had so much bad restaurant / diner gyro experiences that when I found this place I was in gyro heaven. The platter doesn't give you a lot of meat, especially if you order the food to go around lunch time, but sitting in and having dinner is worth it - the amount of food is abundant and it's a nice atmosphere if it's semi-packed.

Out of 5 different dishes my party ordered, 3(!) had a musty taste. Needless to say we left them almost untouched. The server came by and removed the plates without inquiring why barely any food was eaten. Nor did he offer coffee/dessert because he understood we didn't care for the food.

According to other reviews some people got food poisoning here. Yet they proudly display the A-grade for sanitation and 20 from Zagat.

So, unless you're suffering from a virus but find taking antibiotics pills too boring, eat at this place. Everybody else: please stay away and don't encourage them to poison your fellow diners.

We've been meaning to eat here for the past year and finally made it in a few weeks ago for an excellent meal. At first, the prices on the menu seemed a tad higher than we were expecting but when the food came, we realized it was because the portions are HUGE. My companions and I ordered: 

Grilled Octopus -- I ate it as my entree and it was plenty of food. Not the best octopus I've ever had, but quite good.

Chicken Ala Greco -- half a large chicken, reportedly tasty

A combination plate of dips/appetizer salads -- sufficient for an entree

Combination Plate of Greek Foods including moussaka, spanikopita, roast lamb, kefte meatballs, and a baked pasta and meat dish. Everything was delicious but this plate is very large. 

Overall, a very satisfying meal. I recommend sharing entrees unless you are a really big eater.

Always a fun place!  Great service and delicious food.  The owner and manager remember the patrons and always greet them with a hug or a kiss on the cheek.  20% off on Tuesdays if paid with cash (and also a student?).

business.full_address:
238 Nassau St
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: Ivy Garden NJ

reviews.text: Boring run down typical cheep chineese food  service was slow at best . We had to ask for more tea since after the food was delivered they never came back to the table. Go elsewhere.

another east-coast chinese restaurant. you know... shiny food with same old taste. 
i went there with a friend who's visiting her cousin in princeton. we got general tso's chicken and chicken in garlic sauce. both dishes were nice. general tso's chicken was crispy and tasty, and the chicken in garlic sauce was tender. they didn't blow my mind though. 
the portion was much larger than tiger noodles, AND more importantly, they didn't use as much MSG as tiger noodles! so on your way to tiger noodles, you should stop a block early and eat here instead. the food is cheaper and better, and contains less msg. and the eating area is more spacious.

Good dishes:

Crab Rangoon - crab cheese mix is pretty tasty
Double Sauteed Pork - spicy. pork very tender. Also has mushroom, green pepper, cabbage.
Beef with Snow Peas and Mushroom - beef is tender. flavor is nice with the snow peas and mushroom
Shredded Pork with Bean Curd - my favorite dish and very cheap for lunch special. It's dry bean curd (dofu gan in chinese) with pork. Also has green peppers, onions, and scallions. Amazing flavor.
Beef Stew Noodle Soup - spicy. Beef nice and tender. Soup broth is delicious.
General Tso/Sesame Chicken - both comes with 3 pieces of brocolli. Great for pairing up with another dish that has veggies.

I'd stay away from Mapo Tofu (way too much MSG), Hunan Beef (weird flavor), and Chinese Curry Chicken (nothing like Japanese or Indian curry. Just weird in general). 

I wouldn't say Ivy Garden or Tiger Noodles is strictly better than the other. Both have their specialities and you need to figure out what's good for each.

Semi-decent Chinese food in Princeton. If you have no car to drive to Chuan Mei Zi, this is the only choice you have. 

Getting stir fries is usually a safe choice. String beans is decent, so is the pork/tofu/pepper stir fry (no idea what the actual name is). 

I tend to avoid any fish related dishes (fish with chili oil is quite fisy and nonauthentic).

went last night. beautiful night. not crowded at all :-)

excellent service, excellent entres. we enjoyed the usual suspects like the chinese style saute string beans, which we want to be buried with, and the pork with dried tofu. jesus of nazareth! that was good. we also like that the serving platters are like circa 1974 corning ware plates and NEVER match. a fancy restaurant is nice sometimes, but we are uber casual and prefer a place where we can get comfy as we slurp up our cheap, but omg tasty $11 champagne (see the review of this stuff!). ivy garden rules! it's like having dinner on the patio at home but with way better people watching. AND you don't have to do the dishes. PLUS you get to feel like a big shot and tip generously because the prices are just so reasonable. forget reasonable, for the quality and tatstiness factor, it's downright cheap. it's official. we LOVE this place!

i used to study in Princeton. My office is very close to nassau st. Ivy Garden was one of the places I went very often for lunch and dinner.
The food was so so. Not very tasty, but still reasonable enough to stuff my stomach.
However, the noodle there was good. I ordered the noodle during my birthday, and my friends (who are American) liked it too.
Good!

We avoided this place for awhile. The reason?  Overpopulated most of the time. There's a great open garden during better weather.

We stopped in tonight, and were immediately seated.

They have whole fried flounder--not parts, as most places do, but the entire fish, lightly battered and fried.

And duck--whole duck roasted perfectly and chopped so we could each have parts.  Some crunchier (legs), others tender.  Skin cooked so that it could be eaten.

Then the sauces--as perfectly done as would a French chef.  Including the one served with the egg roll.  Spicy, and made with real chiles.  Then the chopped chiles in oil, more chile than oil.  And the sauce for the flounder, which we had served on the side and dipped everything into.  Then tossed some onto the rice.  Then took the rest home.  Balanced, layered, and no MSG headache.

Service?  They left us alone.  Opened our bottle.  Refilled our waterglasses. Served food when it was ready, asked whether we were enjoying things.  Then left alone--the way I like it.

Such a happy meal.  The best Chinese food we've had in town or recently.

So good!

we picked up a to go menu on the way out, and lunch is $6.50-7.  Cheaper than Karen's, but so much better.

We're definitely returning, even if only for the duck.

Update 4/12/09:We now come here nearly every week for the whole fried flounder, sauce on the side (the unfinished sauce taken home each time because it really is that good with vegetables, plain rice, as a scallop marinade--anything really).

Mongolian lamb was good, but not superlative.  A little too sticky-sweet for my taste, with a hint of molasses.  

The place has not been crowded in awhile, which is fine for us.  Once the weather finally improves, the patio will again be packed.

The interiour is a bit ugly, but who really cares when the food is so good that we return again and again?

Edit 4/14:
I won't downgrade this place because we love their fried flounder and will return repeatedly for it, weekly if possible, but there are some things we have to remember.

1.  specials might be wierd.  On Easter, we ordered the bunny special.  It was primarily rib meat and bones.  A good flavour, but way too much work.  Kind of like kimchee basted rabbit connective tissue.  There was no bite which didn't have something to spit out.
2. appetizers: they're good, but not great. we had the meat skewers and spring rolls (fried--I thought they would be the cold version), but seriously, they're merely ok

The service is prompt and great, and we will continue to eat here for their incredible flounder and duck.  Weekly is what it has become, but now that we're looking for a house, it may be bi-weekly.  Still, what they do great we'll be fans of and come back for--gladly--but the other stuff?  Leave it.

Update 6/6/09:
I've vowed to get their curry ever since we first started dining here a few months ago (each time the plate came by for another table I started drooling), and wasn't disappointed.  The chicken is tender, there's excellent flavour with a medium heat level (by my standards), and the vegetables sauteed but with a bite (more cooked than a stir-fry, but that is how it ought to be).

Now I know where to get my Chinese curry fix which is almost as good as my mother's.

Thank you Ivy Garden!

Update 10/18/09: I hope this was an off day, but I'm not feeling generous today and will ding them a star.  The flounder was perfect but the duck a bit greasy.  Then that amazing sauce for the flounder--it was BLAND.  Zero flavour.  Cornstarch with brown colouring.  We didn't even bother finishing or taking anything home--a first for us.  

So we're 2/2 in terms of places going bad on Nassau since we moved--first Old World Pizza, now this place.

I came here looking for decent Chinese food... and yet again I've been disappointed with Princeton's selection.  I ordered their beef noodles (my favorite dish) and found the soup to be lacking in flavor.  The beef was aight but I felt very underwhelmed with my bowl.  If that weren't bad enough the noodles cost like $8.  I felt seriously fleeced.  I've sampled some of the other food here but like Janelle said, this place seems pretty standard.  They have nice outdoor seating though so I guess thats a plus.

Pros: Outdoor seating can be pleasant
Cons: Beef noodles were overpriced AND underwhelming
Verdict: Another pan for one of Princeton's so-called restaurants

This is the kind of Chinese food that was naturally selected out of the american restaurant pallet when PF Chang's came around. But it survives in Princeton because it is a BYOB place popular with underage college students who happy bring their own. The food is not very tasty and no one in my party of 15 people finished their plate the other night. Some claim the best item are the Scallion Pancakes, but really, they're just fried dough with a bit of green onion in there. 

The decor on the inside is stark and worn, so dine on the terrace if you go. Either not good enough or not cheap enough, but I can't decide which.
Standard Chinese food in Princeton with lots of outside seating.  I'm more of a Tiger Noodles kinda gal.
Nothing special. Just like any other Chinese Restaurant. I wouldn't go back.

The place inside smelled funny. If we didn't have the option of sitting outside I don't know if we would go back or make it thru a meal. The food was cheap (6-7) for lunch. My friend got perrier water and was only charged $1 more then a soda...okay that amazed me. I don't know why. They take Credit cards only past $10. The food was good for the most part..the rice could have been a lot better but the veggies were great and the food came out super fast. I like food a little less oily so I didn't finish it all. The hot and sour soup was pretty good. The fried rice looked more like a side dish compared to the other lunch options and pretty standard not as good as joy yees or other places I've seen for the speed.

Another place for students and not foodies like us. Since the change of management 2 or 3 years ago, their future doesn't look so bright. Actually, we just went there today for lunch and all three of us were disappointed. First of all, there was a greasy, musty smell and it was very stuffy, so we had to ask the waitress to turn up the AC. After that, we ordered. I got my wonton soup first and saw that there was a good amount of extra oil in there. I didn't have the broth after seeing that. Dad got General Tso's, his absolute fave Chinese dish, and was very distressed to see that the batter part of the chicken was very thick and there wasn't enough meat inside. Mom got shrimp fried rice and was also pretty crestfallen to see that there was a layer of oil sitting on top of the rice. Me? I got chicken and black bean sauce, which so far every Chinese restaurant has been able to make the right way. Almost every Chinese restaurant that is. I don't know what the chef was thinking, but the whole sauce seemed to come from a bottle of soy sauce, except for the black beans. No wonder there was a whole crowd at Tiger Noodles and we were the only people at Ivy Garden. Don't waste your money people. Go to Tiger Noodles where you can get some value for your money, and come home with a full, satisfied stomach.

                                                                        -Isha Biswas, age 11

Came here for a meal because I had a buy one entree get one free coupon.  We got the kung pao chicken and shanghai bok choy with shitake mushrooms.  The dishes were well-seasoned, and the bok choy sauce was flavorful without being greasy.  The kung pao chicken was okay but not as good as the vegetable.  Service wasn't very attentive even though there were only four people in the restaurant.  It came to about $15 total for the entrees, including tax and 20% tip.  Not bad for lunch.

Food is literally "just OK". If it's any worse, I would not visit. 

Sliced fish in hot chili oil is a house special dish, and it tastes decent (very Americanized Chinese food). Fish was obviously frozen, and they put a bit too much starch in the dish. 

Sauteed string beans is what I usually get, cannot go wrong with it. 

Today we also had eggplant in sizzling hotpot, and that was the highlight of the meal: flavorful and soft in texture, but still, there is too much starch. 

Come here if you actually cannot find any better alternatives.
Much better before they changed ownership

Chinese is very hit or miss. The Ivy Garden is consistently good. Its service is quick and the portions are just right for lunch. The wait staff is always friendly and very quick. The food is prepared with fresh ingredients and I have not had a meal here that I have not enjoyed. It is way better than Tiger Noodles and its 3 blocks closer to campus. If you are in the mood for Chinese and want to stay close to campus, it is definitely worth the walk to the Ivy Garden,

business.full_address:
423 Wall St
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Creative Computing

reviews.text:
They called me when they ordered the part and when the  repair was complete.   My ipod sounds great  and the repair was reasonably priced.

Some of the staff are still learning the billing system, so I had to wait a while to get a receipt.  However, the managers were sensitive to my needs as well as those of their staff, so I was fine with waiting.

Glad to have an apple retailer and service center in the neighborhood!

Beware the fine print on their prices!  I recently took my old MacBook Pro (a 6-year old model) here after a bit of spilled water seemed to have killed it.  They quoted me a price of $75 to diagnose the problem, which seemed a little steep, but extending the life of this computer for an extra two months was important to me, so I agreed.  Three days later they confirmed that the logic board was fried, and wasn't worth fixing on a model that old.  However, when I came in to pick it up, they doubled the price for diagnostics to $150!  Apparently, the original quote involved a discount that only applied if I used their repair services.  Since no repair was possible, I had no choice but to pay the the full $150... for nothing.  I will certainly not be returning here in the future.

business.full_address:
2857 Broadway
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Wrapp Factory

reviews.text: the wraps here are sub-par but this is THE place for the best rice krispy treats in the city. they are gigantic and actually contain whole mini marshmallows.

Wrapp Factory would have gotten a higher rating from me before it changed its menu.  It used to have a delicious vegan wrap with brown rice, lentils, corn, and your choice of sauces -- the peanut sauce being the best.  It was a perfect wrapp, especially when dealing with a hangover, ha.  They still have an extensive selection of wraps, but they're all hit or miss.  Check out the rest of the menu -- they have great fresh salsa, although the nachos are usually ruined by the black beans they don't drain for some reason.  The spinach artichoke dip is a good bet, with tasty tortilla chips and salsa included.  They have smoothies (including vegan options), but for some reason if you order delivery they aren't very good.  The new menu has a veggie burger panini which is decent.  Great, if expensive, magic bars.  In any case, Wrapp Factory is a pretty good bet for a quick meal, and it's a comfortable, friendly place to eat in by yourself, and the walls give you plenty of wacky things to look at.
This is a nice place to pick up a quick meal.  Their healthy wraps sometimes even conquer my cravings for Koronet across the street.

This place gets pretty good reviews from the office I work in. Everyone has very different tastes and people are very satisfied with their orders. I''ve never actually been in their restaurant, I''ve only ordered in, but been satisfied each time.

business.full_address:
1325 US Highway 206 Ste 28
Skillman, NJ 08558
business.name: Friendly's

reviews.text: Excellent!  Our waitress, Jen was fantastic. Really cute too

First off, they aren't very FRIENDLY at Friendly's. The servers are very rude, and they never come by the table to ask how you are. I got this one sandwich, and the "fresh" mozzarella wasn't very fresh... The chicken was dry and bland, and the whole sandwich was very bland. I got one of those Gold Peak Ice Tea's... And it was completely watered down. Then I was looking forward to our ice cream... The waitress forgets our order after walking around for 10 minutes doing nothing. (The place was empty) Then 10 minutes later, she comes out and asks us our order again. So the ice cream comes out... The best part of Friendly's.... And the ice cream is melted... It's a huge soup with toppings on top... For $9.99... You get bad service and bad food. The place is horrible... Poor quality and poor service. Then when we wanted to talk to a manager... So we called over our waitress and she gives us a huge "humfff".  Our waitress interrupts our talk with the manager and says something stupid. The manger didnt do anything for us and he gave us attitude. Our whole experience was horrible, and I would never suggest this place to anyone. Simple enough. Don't come here.

business.full_address:
2217-23 Frederick Douglas Blvd
Harlem
New York, NY 10026
business.name: Chocolat Restaurant Lounge

reviews.text: Great food and atmosphere. Perfect place for a first date.

I'm all for the local business in the neighborhood. So I popped in to have a bite to eat I ordered a glass of Pinot Noir and my friend ordered Chavignon Blanc.  We patiently waited to be served our drinks. 20 minutes the drinks arrived. Instead of Pinot Noir, I swear it was Asti-Spumante. That was some straight bull crap in the glass. I didn't drink it. I asked to speak with the manager, of course with out any luck.  Just a bunch of excuses. So I'm already over the entire place.  So I ordered dinner Salmon & Bok Choy, it was ok. I'm sorry CHOCOLATE you can't get anymore of my money. RATCHET, with the old dudes by the door ushering people out for a private party. Nice space, need NEW MANAGER one who actually not  ducking from his patrons, become better verse with your wine selection. WE ALL DON'T DRINK HENNEY,
(1)Star for DECOR

Chocolat is in soft launch, which means full menu but no alcohol.  They won't even let you bring a bottle of wine (like Frizzante did when they opened) but say that their license is only a few weeks away.  That being said, the food was pretty good.  I particularly enjoyed the sesame calamari, which was actually large enough to be an entree.  The house salad was good (and large), but nothing you couldn't do at home with a bag of mixed greens.  The flat iron steak special was well-prepared and accompanied by potato puree and asparagus.  The the snapper, however, while incredibly tasty was overcooked.  

I will go back when I can pair a drink with my meal, but probably not often as the prices are steep compared to the other excellent restaurants in the area.

I really tried to look past the negative reviews and try this place out anyway. The service was very spotty. My group and I ordered drinks and the drinks sat at the bar for a good 15 minutes before the waiter decided to bring the drinks over. The waiters were more concerned with make convo among themselves than attending to the patrons. I ordered the crab and lobster dish and disliked greatly :-(  I had the waiter take it back and went with the burger and fries instead and that was OK (i could have made abbter one at home, smh). The fries were actually good. I really liked the ambiance there (very mellow and nice decor). I would go back but only for drinks, no dinner. Sorry Chocolat, you dont get my vote!

Beautiful atmosphere when I walked in. Friendly staff, great service and the brunch was excellent. Will definitely become my new regular brunch spot. 
If you are thinking about going here, don't think just do it. You won't regret.

I love chocolate. What girl doesn't!? But, this was the first time chocolate deceived me! Talk about judging a book by its cover.

I stumbled upon this place after coming out of a nearby museum exhibition opening. Originally my friend and I attempted to dine at the restaurant across the street, but were turned away since they were about to close. They pointed us across the street. I saw the sign Chocolat and my eyes got big, and I danced a happy little jig. I was so hungry that I didn't check Yelp for reviews- mistake #1. As other reviewers have noted, I sooo wanted to love this place.

It was a Wednesday night, around 9:30ish, so there was no wait (that was a plus). Ambience was nice, Marvin Gaye's Sexual Healing was playing - sweet! (another plus). But my giddiness soon came to a screeching halt. It started with the wine. The waiter (super nice guy) wasn't well versed with the wine list. I ordered a bottle of Riesling, and he insisted it was from Africa. Hmmm... I'm not a wine snob, but c'mon man, Rieslings are mainly German - good ones that is. France turns out a decent Riesling, even Australia, but Africa? Pftt. After he realized he was wrong, he comes back to deliver the news that they were out of Riesling and brings me a Moscoto. My friend isn't a heavy drinker, so I went with it. But it wasn't till I saw the bill later that I realized the waiter failed to mention that the Moscoto was $17 more than the original bottle I ordered. That's a negative in my book buddy! Not to mention the Moscoto sucked! Almost $50 for a sucky Moscoto is not cool.

On to the food. I ordered from the appetizer menu, Baby Back Ribs ($14- kinda steep for an app in my opinion) with a side of Garlic Mashed Potatoes . The ribs were just OK; a bit on the fatty side. The mashed potatoes were cold and chunky, and did not have the slightest hint of garlic to them. The waiter noticed my dismay and took my dish back to the chef for an added dose of garlic, and a quick nuke in the microwave (I presume). It tasted a tad bit better, but needless to say I didn't eat much more. All-in-all a very disappointing meal. 

My friend ordered the Shrimp & Grits, the most expensive dish on the menu at $26. I saw that he was struggling to swallow even a few bites. I'm not a grits kind of gal, so I can't judge fairly, but from what I tasted, it was just not good. And the shrimp - do not get me started - was the most overcooked shrimp I have ever tasted. Wait, I can't even say that I tasted it, because I could not even cut through it with my knife! That's how hard and overcooked they were! When the waiter came over, I demonstrated my attempt to slice and he quickly realized we were not exaggerating. He was super apologetic- I felt so bad because he looked like he was taking it as a direct reflection of his service. They offered to make us another meal, but we had enough already and passed on the idea. 

The one good thing is that the manager removed the charge for the Shrimp & Grits without hesitation. But, even though they removed the meal from the bill, we still spent more than we should have based on the fact that we paid for the overpriced wine, and tipped the waiter extremely well, since he really did try his best to fix things. Worst part - all that money spent and we left hungry!

Sorry Chocolat, but you will never earn my business again. The only reason I granted you 2 stars was because of your waiter, and the fact that you rectified the bill. But this experience really deserved 1 star, because the food was simply awful! And it's all about the food for me!

I REALLY wanted to like Chocolat but I was pretty unimpressed with this place. It was SO expensive for what you got. I went there for brunch and was very underwhelmed and the menu was super limited. Also, a place like this should offer bottomless Mimosas, especially since the mark up on the dishes is already so high.

The only thing this place has going for it right now is the location and decor.

Well done steak does not mean one wants a burnt offering which is what I got for an order!

Salmon BLT was just okay.

Food had no element of presentation to it at all. just dished up and that was that.

The service was quite slow and the wait staff seemed distracted though that could be because there were only 2 people serving everyone.

We overheard the folks at the next table commenting that their dessert was the best part of the meal and that perhaps they should have ordered just that.. not having ordered dessert but going by my experience, they were probably right.

Had Saturday brunch with three adults and two kids.  Love the ambiance and decor.  Friendly service.  Food was very good - caesar salad with grilled shrimp, french toast, scrambled eggs, grilled peach chicken arugula salad, and fish croquettes over grits.  All very tasty.  Only part of the menu was available for brunch, but we felt like we had plenty of choices. On the pricey side, but we felt it was worth it and would definitely go back.

Great food and atmosphere! Clean, comfortable and airy space. Love the location! (Near my apartment. Holla!) Delicious meals at great prices! I recommend the calamari salad and the Shrimp & cheese grits with lobster sauce for dinner. Yum!

went here on a friday and all the bar seats were taken. outside of that the place was empty but it was still early (7:30/8ish). seemed nice though inside and i would have liked to stay longer if there was room at the bar. noone seemed to try and get any chairs for us, but hey it is what it is.

Otherwise known as just "Chocolat," this new upscale Harlem restaurant is physically appealing with a nice modern, yet warm design.  Although I did not take advantage of the full menu, I did have an appetizer and glass of wine.  The appetizer was impressive and the wine good enough, but the appetizers list is over-priced, especially for a new eatery with an unknown chef.  They are charging entree prices for appetizers, with the least expensive coming in at $12.  Most appetizers are from $14-$20. Appetizers should be $5-$9 for the most part.  That said, my appetizer of fried calimari was very tasty, with good presentation.

Overall, I'm sure Chocolat will prove to be a nice addition to the neighborhood, but even better when they reign in their prices and improve their wine list.

Yes I returned but not by choice. My husband's cousin wanted to toast a special occassion and asked us to please meet her and her family there for dinner. We couldn't decline as it was a sentimental affair. 
I tried the penne & salmon tonight and it was good, tasty and a decent portion. I tasted the mac & cheese which was bland and a fail. My husband had the NY strip it was average nothing special. The fave seemed to be the calamari asian salad which has always been flavorful because of the necessary spices to pull of calling it asian. 
My mine gripe from the previous reviews remains. The servers are too lackadasical and not very well learned in the way of wines. Our server didn't know what Veuve Cliquot was. Really? They should be trained properly. Otherwise it was one star better and it probably had to do with the great company I had.

Food is good, Prices are not. 

Support the local Community and check it out. This place is a few years too early for this hood. 

~Hope it can hod through.

Hmm, surprised to see this place rated so low! I suppose I understand the price point being high for the neighborhood, but the food quality and portions justified the prices IMO. We had a great experience here,  I thought the food was delicious and had no gripes with the service. We were quite a large party of over 10 ppl with no reservations on a Sunday night. We did apps and drinks at the bar and then had dinner in their private room as it was a slow night. My gf and I shared the calamari app which was huge and really delicious, and then the miso salmon entree which was also really excellent. No one at the table had complaints about their meals or drinks and the bite I had of a friend's dessert was also delicious (: Two thumbs up from me!

Nice atmosphere, good service, tasty food.

I went here last week for my friend's birthday.  It was a large party (about 15) of friends and family.  When you enter the establishment there is a full bar on your left and several tables on your right.  I didn't see much of the place because apparently my friend had reservations or something and we were promptly escorted to a secluded room off to the side.

The decor in this room was very classy.  The perimeter of the room was lined with couches.  There were tables and upholstered stools to match the couches.  The service was a little slow but not terrible for such a large party and it being a Friday evening. 

I shared a pitcher of Sangria.  It was very good but you might want to ask for "lite fruit" (similar to requesting "lite ice").  The pitcher was supposed to supply four glasses.  Due to the fruit is was more like three 3/4 full glasses.  The waiter noticed our disappointment and brought out another pitcher free of charge.  Others in my party had alcoholic drinks and said that they were nice...and strong.

As you see from the photos, the food presentation was appealing.  All of the portions from appetizers to entrées were a good size.  I had the spare ribs and sweet potato fries.  The ribs were tender and well done.  I heard no complaints from the others at my table besides being too full to finish their meal! No one did dessert.  The birthday girl's mom brought a cake. 

The food and drinks are not cheap.  That pitcher of sangria was around $20 and the entrées averaged about 20-25 bucks.  Of course there's also tax and gratuity applied. Not cheap but it is what it is.  Not the worse I've seen.  Harlem real estate IS getting pricey these days.  

I read some of the comments on here before and after I went to Chocolat. Maybe I just got lucky because everyone said they enjoyed their time there.  I would certainly go back....I'll just have to save up my pennies first.

Now that I have had a chance to check this out - I hate to be brutually honest but for the price point and the menu descriptions - I would expect the food to taste better than what I had.  The Cheeseburger was an incredible let down and I have had better at Corner Bistro ($6.50).

I know everyone wants to treat Harlem like it's a West Village and it's already annoying enough that people who live around Chocolat call the area SOHA (really folks?!), but seriously if you are going to offer certain price points you have to stand up to it.

I wouldn't come here again unless someone else was paying and if I wanted a real upscale experience in Harlem, I would head over to Red Rooster on Lenox.

Now that's worth your money.

This spot is like a local beauty queen. Very pretty but lacking in substance, and way too expensive. 

First the good - it is a pretty room. Our server was very nice. The rib appetizer was delicious and the meat fell off the bone. That's the end of the good. Plenty of bad: 
We sat down in a nearly empty room at @ 2:30 on a Sunday. But the lunch menu was not available. We could get brunch or DINNER. They serve bread during dinner. But if you order dinner on the weekend, you can't have bread. Who's on first? At least everything came out quickly.

I ordered a cocktail. I love a good cocktail. Too bad I didn't get one. At $14 a pop they should have revealed that they were not capable of making what I ordered because they did not have the ingredients. Let ME decide if I want a modified version. The main missing ingredient was something they could have bought in a grocery store. They even admitted they knew in advance that they were out but did not try to obtain it.

Then I went to one of the 3 separate bathrooms. I won't tell you what was on display in the toilet of the 1st one. I went to the last bathroom, but the lock was broken. Having already activated the launch sequence, I had to take my chances & I used that facility anyway. But then I tried to wash my hands. There was no soap coming out of the dispenser. It made me wonder about where the staff washed their hands.

As we were putting on our coats to leave, I spoke to the person who turned out to be the manager. He had been standing there watching when I brought my cocktail back to the bar to complain, but he had made no effort to address or even acknowledge the issue. So imagine my surprise to find out he was a mgr. He said he was "immensely sorry" about everything. He offered to buy a drink or dessert, but I was driving and full so I declined. Raincheck.

When you are in an off-brand neighborhood and charge entree prices for appetizers and $14 for cocktails your game needs to be much tighter than that. (BTW - Brunch was very expensive - about $22 for my seafood omlet - with just OK ingredients and no extras. No mimosas, no bread, no nothing) I know they are relatively new, but this death by a thousand papercuts. At least the food wasn't bad. Nothing special. Entree portions are moderate but the rib appetizer was generous. Sweet potato fries were well made.

Had brunch here today and really enjoyed the service and food (sweet fried shrimp and steak salad). The only problem was that a few of the other things we were interested in on the menu weren't available.

 I think they would do well to expand the brunch choices and maybe include a cocktail with a brunch entree for a set price. While we were there two parties came in and promptly left because they wanted more choice and unlimited drinks. It's a shame because the decor is lovely and spacious.

I went here on a Tuesday night and the restaurant was fairly empty.  Service was friendly, food was better than I expected.  I had the Shrimp and Grits which had a lot of flavor, a nice smokiness to the properly cooked shrimp, and the grits were creamy.  The dish definitely lacked salt, which seemed to be a common problem.  Several of us needed a healthy sprinkling and once that happened, my dish started to pop. (It's pretty amazing how bland a dish can be without salt!)  I live in Soho so it was quite a haul to get there and I don't feel compelled to go back or necessarily recommend it to anyone at this point, unless they happen to already be in the neighborhood, especially because it was just as pricey as anything I'd get in my own neighborhood, despite the humble ingredients in my dish.

Sunday brunch--nothing special or noteworthy. Limited menu choices, which unfortunately, didn't limit Chocolat's uber steep prices.  Better choices abound nearby, and I'm sorry, adding an 18% gratuity to one's bill just doesn't feel right.

Hubby and I had a date night here before they got the liquor license. Staff was exceptionally friendly--which was unexpected given the moderately pretentious outward appearance.  A GF and I went back for drinks after dinner on a weeknight (after the liquor license was obtained, of course).  The bartender was very friendly, made great recommendations and the cocktails were fantastic.  

Prices could be adjusted downward a little, but don't seem too out of line with the rest of good dining in Harlem.  I find the down home places in Harlem to be the ones that tend to be overpriced.  I digress.  Nice vibe, good food, great drinks, worth a look.

Before I start-- this restaurant had a GRADE PENDING in the window. :( 

UGH.. This place is a disaster.  Before going to Chocolat, I asked friends in the area for their opinion & they all said 'Ehh'. I went in with average expectations, that declined as the night went on. The waiter was amazing - very attentive and helpful, but the food was a major let-down, fail. . We decided to go with the best selling appetizer - the Sesame Calamari & it was a huge disappointment. The calamari itself wasn't breaded - I should have taken a picture. For a main course, I went with the lobster & crab ravioli --- a greater disappointment. I truly believe the restaurant purchases it from Trader Joe's. It is the same thing if not worse. Definitely not worth the $24. My boyfriend went with a turkey burger that he ended up sending back. It was horrible & he is not anywhere close to a picky eater. My friend ordered the peach arugula salad & ended up getting pears instead of peaches (because they ran out). This place needs to close and re-open with new management & cooking staff. 

I strongly advise you to go to another restaurant. A pitcher of Sangria is $30 and the fruit isn't fresh. The whole entire restaurant is a joke! I felt majority of the food was frozen and not fresh. Shame on YOU, Chocolat. The quality of food doesn't warrant the menu price point. Period.

Love this place...My sister and I took my mother here for her 57 birthday celebration and every single thing was great!!!!! We started off with the Sesame Calamari ( can you say heaven on a plate...yummy!!!)  For dinner I had the Lobster and Crab Ravioli (absolutely wonderful). Love this place and I can't wait to return!

I like this place. Its very cute and they have a nice private room you can use.

The Food however was hit or miss for me.

Hit - the Shrimp and Grits were sooo good.

Miss - I ordered salmon once and it was so darn dry and tough i could barely chew it. I never knew salmon could get so hard! I know it wasn't a fluke because the woman next to me ordered it and sent her's back.

Happy Hour - Was decent. Nothing really stood out about the happy hour. The drinks were not super cheap.. but not expensive. Not bad but not over the top good. It was strong though. They did have some good food options that were not too pricey

I WANTED to like this place A LOT. Unfortunately, I dont. Today was my first day here. We came in at 3:30pm with 30 minutes left under the brunch menu. We considered waiting for the more appetizing dinner menu but who has time to waste, right? Wrong. 

We were seated right away but:
1. Apparently the wait staff wanted to wait out the 30 minutes too so we had to talk the bartender into placing our order. 
2. There were only 2 other patrons but service was still slooooooow. 
3. Food was ok. Nothing to rave about or to stand out despite the French name.

Of course, this may have been a one time thing but it didnt inspire me to return. I had the salmon penne at $18 and my mom had the chicken sandwich with sweet potato fries--which tasted very greasy. With one glass of sangria (red), one harlem bellini and a slice of their red velvet cake total bill came out to $74 including a very generous tip (thank my mom for that mr barkeep).

Saving grace was the delicious and huge red velvet cake dessert!!! try that if nothing more.

Would probably come again to check out the lounge but I'm not going back for the food unless it's dessert to go.

We came here for lunch after my daughter graduated from college . We hadn't booked, just walked by it and picked it because it looked fine, had a good-sized crowd and a menu we felt would satisfy all of us. That turned out to be a mistake.There was one waiter for the whole restaurant who was so pressured he couldn't focus on us properly. He apologized at the end several times, but it was too late by then. We didn't receive water for a long time and our drink orders came nearly a half hour after our meals were served. The meals were served about an hour after we arrived. Why didn't we leave? We're too damn polite and nice.  The food was okay - the fried chicken salad was pretty good, the turkey burger was okay and the beef burger was as ordered - medium well, but dry. The shrimp po'boy was tasty and the fries were deilicious. Would we come back? No.

Chocolat wins on atmosphere, though sometimes it can be completely empty the ambience is hit or miss.  I gave Chocolat two stars not because I've had a terrible experience.  Each time my waiter or waitress has been delightful.  But given where it is and what it is the price for a meal just isn't one that I can justify.  There's no way I should be paying more for an ok burger than I'm paying at Five Napkin Burger, Shake Shake, P.J Clarke's and around the same price as one at Minetta Tavern.  Can't justify it. 

I had the shrimp and grits on another trip.  The ingredients just don't justify a $26 price tag, and while I didn't bother to try my friends crabcakes they weren't Maryland style--I spotted breading, and we don't do that in MD!  But to be fair, they don't claim to be Maryland style.  

I just think for the money there are much better options in Harlem.  There are only two dinner items under $20 and for the quality of food I don't think it's worth the money.

I have only been here for drinks....my friend lives and harlem and thats the only time i really go here. I usually go during happy hour, where the drinks are 7 dollars and the appetizers are 9 to 11 dollars. If you sit at the bar make sure you chat wih Roberto!! Great guy and puts that extra emph into your drink!! The food is okay. I have only tasted the crap spring rolls and the calamari. The spring rolls are good but i wish they could have put alot more crab into it, and i really wouldnt recommed the calamari. It is quite chewy. The resturant is nice, it has a blue glow about it and a really cool vibe. I will continue to go here just for drinks but I dont think I would actually ever sit down and get a meal.

Food was mediocre at best, service was friendly but slow and ill-timed, and generally over-priced for the combo. Went for an early dinner - we were seated in the side room, away from the main area/bar when there were only maybe 3 other tables!! it felt like they were hiding my group from the rest of the restaurant...

Cocktails: martinis were eh; my friends' cocktails seemed just OK too; no prices on the menu but seemed to range from $10 - 14 when we got the bill... (shady)

Apps: mac & cheese (again, good, but nothing to rave about); short ribs, on the other hand - highlight of the meal! the meat fell off the bone.

Main: we ordered various salads, cheese grits (yum!), and mashed sweet potatoes (Note: ended up getting sweet potato fries because 10 min after our salads came and I inquired about the sides, we were told they didn't have any -- after telling us it was a special before we ordered!!)

Bill: over-charged for adding chicken to the salads, but at that point, the service had been so slow we just didn't bother arguing and left less of a tip.

Would ONLY go again for drinks, and probably only if I was dragged there. I would say I agree with most of the other reviews: food is just OK, overpriced, and the service is hit-or-miss.

I really like Chocolat and have been her three times since it's in my neighborhood.  However, I have NOT been here with a large group.  I've been either by myself for a weekday lunch or dinner with just one other person.  Based on the reviews below, seems they have some issue with groups.

Each time, I've walked in without a reservation and have not had to wait.  I'm a fan of the Turkey Burger w/sweet potato fries (the burger is HUGE!) Mussels - SOO good and filling.  The pasta / seafood dishes are around $20-25 and the burger is like $15.  I recommend the sangria as well ($8 a glass)  

Overall, I think this is a great date place or dinner spot with friends!  Good to have a great place in my neighborhood.

I went on a Saturday for Brunch and it was very nice greeted with smiles, the space is nice open and bright. Not to loud, menu is simply you can find something to eat that you like and it's nicely priced. Service was okay as well nothing stellar but we waited long for our food to come. I'll go back due the the ambiance.

I've had my mixed feelings with the mixology at Chocolat in the past but I always like to give them chance after chance because its in the neighborhood. My grandmother wanted to have dinner here to celebrate her and my grandfather's 30 year wedding anniversary. 

I called sometime last week to make a reservation for a table of 8 and when we arrived the host said he didn't have my name or party scheduled for 7pm!!! Just before I freaked out and cried, the manager came over and brought us to our table! Thank you Shareffa! They were very accommodating in adding chairs to our growing party and taking our orders. 

I had a Rum shizzle from the bar (not on happy hour) and it was surprisingly delicious! For appetizers we all shared the fried calamari and ribs which only brought on the desire for dinner. I ordered a ranch burger with onion rings and everything else on it. The burger was huge and my bun was burnt so it didn't taste it's best but the presentation was there.

My number one complaint still and will always be until they change it is: HAPPY HOUR AT THE BAR ONLY, why? That does not make me happy!

The food is quite tasty here, and the service has been pretty good. We've been for both dinner and bruch, and the menu has some interesting dishes, including fish croquettes with grits and a nice steak with sweet potato puree. BUT, the prices are high for the area, so unless that changes this will have to be an occasional treat.

This maybe one of the worse service experiences I and a group of friends had from a restaurant in this area. A group of 18 of us went to Chocolat for a birthday dinner on a Saturday night and waited 1 hour and 45 minutes in order to get our entrees out. The wait was so long that the manager and the waiters apologized and brought out bread with olive oil to tie us over since our entrees were taking so long. The olive oil dip was quite unpleasant. The couple eating next to where I was sitting came after us, ordered and ate 3 courses, and left all before I received the garden salad that I ordered. The manager, in an attempt to make us stay after an hour, offered to take care of all the drinks we ordered while waiting for our food. We were surprised that in a conversation with the owner, he said such an adjustment could not be made. Further, he continued to opine that he thought waiting 1 hour and 45 minutes for entrees for a table of 18 people was quite "quick and reasonable." I am not sure if he was also saying this of the salads that took a similar amount of time to get out. 
We were quite content paying our full bill, but we stayed because of the managers offer. The owner, in saying that such an adjustment couldn't be made by him, could have waived the mandatory 18% gratuity from our bill and that would have been sufficient. Instead, the owner is allowing the portion of the drinks that the manager offered to have waived from our bill, over $200, is come out of his (the managers) paycheck - even though this was a complete breakdown by the entire restaurant, and just an admission/acknowledgment of our poor service and waiving of gratuity would have been sufficient. The owner did not even want to admit that a 1 hour 45 minute wait was outrageous.  
On to the food, which I can only describe as overpriced and underwhelming. Most of my party described the food as lacking flavor (esp. the Madeira Chicken), the chicken for the Caesar salad tasted rubbery and after three bites, another member of the party stopped eating the shrimp and grits. 
Overall, this was a disappointing experience service wise and food-wise.

Not a fan at all for what you get here.  Mediocre food, and even less so quality service.  They almost seem intent on getting your order correct, that is if they ever get around to taking it.  Not to mention the ambiance here feels like an upscale funeral with blue lights.  They're also over priced.  Try it, once, and only once.  But you're not missing anything if you don't try it.

Great ambiance, right in the heart of Harlem.  Good for walk-in meals or a couple drinks.

I had the beef short ribs with saffron risotto.  Let's just say I might have skeeted in my pants - just a little bit.

This is my first review, which I chose to write after my second visit. Last night, it was dinner and previously, it was Sunday brunch. If I were to rate Chocolat solely based on my brunch experience, I would have given 2 stars. There wasn't anything that was "signature" about the restaurant, aside from the cheddar-bacon grits, which I would say- I'm a true fan. However, having glanced over a few of the other reviews, I would agree that they're having growing pains. It may be the "soft launch," but the eggs benedict were too well done. EB are a NYC brunch institution, and if you're going to serve them (and at a significant premium v. Settepani, Les Ambassades and other choices nearby), poach them correctly. I think where they need to improve is the basic blocking and tackling. Upsell liquors and desserts! Dinner is what notched them up to a 3. I had the seared scallops and they were quite delectable. As an appetizer, had the beet salad w/ breaded goat cheese turnover. The salad was too soggy and too heavy on the beets. Scallops could have been a bit more tender, which leads me to wonder the quality of their supplier (or frozen?). What's good is the DJ effect playing great music! Not too loud or hip-hoppy, just right. We'll hesitate for brunch but will be back for dinner.
I come frequently when I can splurge. Prices are higher than I can afford but the shorts ribs are just amazing.

Chocolat is a good blend of upscale and comfortable.  It looks really trendy inside, with blue lighting and dark wood, and it isn't too loud, but it still has TVs in case you want to watch the game (in my case, it was watching the Yankees absolutely destroy Baltimore).  

The menu looks delicious, though I did not get to try it.  It is heavy on seafood, though there are many other meat dishes and a few vegetarian dishes (not too many-- I studied the menu pretty carefully).  They have a good selection of drinks, with wine starting at $9 a glass.  The one thing I did try was the chocolate lava cake, which was excellent.  I love bittersweet chocolate, and this was literally erupting with it.

If I try the food, I may update my review, but for the price and service that I personally experienced, Chocolat deserves a solid 3 stars.

My friend & I went here tonight before going to a comedy show.  The food was pretty good and the ambiance is even better.  My friend had the shrimp & grits which were covered in flavor.  Definitely want to go back for that.  I had the crabcake with sweet potatoes which was also tasty.  Our waiter was very accommodating with bringing us our food in a timely fashion.  I would absolutely try them for brunch!

We went to Chocolat on a Friday night and had a really great time. The inside is very swanky, upscale, and quintessential Harlem.  That night it was full of locals enjoying large gatherings and Christmas parties. The food was well presented and very tasty
Chocolat my favorite place hang out on Sat night, it has an upscale sexy vibe. Always filled with attractive people!

Want to support this restaurant as the choices in the area are little to none. Food was acceptable but unfocused.  I agree constantly seeing an empty restaurant makes one hesitant.  
1)The Menu needs to be separated into lunch, brunch and dinner.  Anyone who has been there knows that the menu is a jumbled mess and on poor quality paper
2)The menu needs to be more focused on farm raised ingredients and good culinary techniques (not something that can be made in a from a box. 
3) Not having their liquor license is a big turn-off.   A glass of wine goes a long way.  
4) The prices are fine. $16 for a Cheesburger is not unusual  (this is Manhattan). 
5) Service was very good and quite accommodating.   

Who are you trying to attract?25-45 disposable income should be your focus. Not everyone wants to go downtown all the time.I get the sense that its target clientele is not very sophisticated to know the difference between La Bernadine and their local chinese, but with a little more effort, this place could be an excellent neighborhood joint.  I will be back to give its brunch a try.  
***Also, change the music.    Make it a bit more differse. I thought I was listening to my parents 45s.

This was my second time here--the drinks seem to be consistent & very good, but today I had a damn near raw turkey burger and this is why I won't be visiting this place again (for food) and will opt out of the $12 turkey burger and will instead stick to Jimbos:(
After taking a few bites and chatting w my friend I looked at the meat of my burger and noticed that the meat was nearly raw and likely cooked to a medium rare heat--the waiter did not ask me for temperature, but COME ONE! Like I want raw turkey meat! I showed my waiter and then he mumbled something about a comp tea and walked away. After about 20 minutes the manager or owner comes over asks about the burger and actually tells me that she eats her burgers all the time like that. WHAT!!!! Not what can I do to make you feel better?! Shocking....I do hope this was the manager and not the owner. I guess she thinks a gross raw burger is normal cause she eats them from Chocolat all the time!

I agree with what most have said about this place. 

The drinks are amazing, the food is a bit overpriced. I've only come for the drinks & we've gotten a few appetizers while here, but the prices on appetizers seem more in the "entree" range for pricing. 

Come for the drinks! They're amazing!

Apparently, we came here minutes before happy hour ended. I didn't realize it at the time until we waited 10+ minutes at the bar to order drinks. It was pretty hectic, but the manager was nice enough to honor happy hour for us.

After ordering drinks, we decided to take a seat to order dinner. We both got the small order of baby back ribs. The waiter looked at us as if we were a tad bit on the crazy side, but I knew that I had a hunger at the time to devour both plates if it came to it.

Needless to say, their ribs are amazing and a great size. The gentlemen next to us ended up ordering the same thing after enquiring on what we ordered. Simply amazing.

Cheers

i can't say my experience here was as bad as some of the other reviews, but it certainly wasn't amazing. we had a reservation and were seated promptly, and the service was perfectly friendly if a little slow.

the food, though, really didn't blow me away. we each had burgers - the meat was somehow dry and flavorless even though it was cooked medium rare, and the brioche buns were both stale and burnt. not good. the fries were ok.

the prices are pretty extravagant given the basic ingredients in the dishes and the location. the atmosphere is pleasant and clean but lacks charm. 

overall, seems like a decent place to go for a drink in the area, but the food is nothing special. i probably wouldn't be eager t ogo back.

This is a nice space...but the food/prices/area is contradicting. I had the Caesar salad & the red snapper...both were just "ok". I wouldn't return for dinner. I've considered it for brunch tho, but it's always empty around 1:30...that's not a good sign, so I always skip it. Maybe they need to lower those prices and amp up the seasoning. IJS.

I know a lot of people have issues with Chocolat and I can see why, but my experiences there have been lackluster. I do love their signature drink - the chocotini. Yum! Haven't actually been in for a meal, but have attended events where some of their food was served and it was decent. With so many other choices along the boulevard now, it is hard to go somewhere where you might not have a good experience. Their prices are also out of alignment with the neighborhood and the offerings. If I know I can go to Melba's and she will knock it out the park every.single.time consistently then I'd rather spend my money there.

As a born and raised Harlemite, Chocolat does the new Harlem Renaissance proud.  The food, the service and the drinks were nothing short of stellar.  I have NOOOO idea what the mediocre ratings are for.  My girls and I had the best time last Friday night enjoying Happy Hour, nibbles and gorgeous ambiance.  Chocolat is the epitome of the new Harlem, a perfect blend of the past and the future, and I absolutely cannot wait to go back.

I like the vibe. I like the space but the food sucks.  I can't give a restaurant a good review if the food is bad. We ordered the short ribs that were supposed to come out with spinach. Instead it came out with carrots.  We actually had to show our server the menu and let him know the kitchen screwed up.  The potatoes we were served came out cold. The short rib was cooked well but it had no taste. The potates had no taste either. Maybe tthey don't use salt or spices.The lamb was undercooked and tough.  I came with about 7 ppl and no body was pleased with their food. The place has good potential but unless they start seasoning their food and adhering to the menu this place won't last. I will not return.

I live in the neighborhood and was looking forward to dining at Chocolat ever since I saw the construction start.  I was not disappointed.  The first visit I had a drink with friends during their second week.  The ambiance is very cool and trendy, its a first for us, and the menu selections were very tempting.   I had red snapper and my friend had shrimp & grits.  Both of us were VERY pleased.  My friend had never dined in Harlem before and was very impressed.  I love the blue lights, and the service was very good. Our waiter was extrememely professional and the wait time was not long. The owner stopped by our table and introduced himself and see how we enjoyed our meal which was a nice touch. 

Both times I went was during the week.  I wish them the best.  Harlem needs more places  like this and I think it has great potential.  Wait staff is excellent!



Try their Chocolate Martini! Excellent and not too sweet!

Cool layout. Music a little too loud and a clueless Sunday afternoon/evening bartender. Pomegranate (special) drink tasted a little off and we watched him from our table pour the same drink in another glass, add more pomegranate juice and hand it back to the server. WTF?! Yeah, not good, so I ordered an easier drink. For dinner, I had the roasted chicken, mashed potatoes and carrots. Chicken was dry and tasteless, but the mashed and carrots were good, so I filled up on that. All in all, not too impressive for my first visit, but because everyone was so nice, I'd give them a second chance to really prove me wrong, so stay tuned.

This was my first visit to Chocolat and, after reading all the not so great reviews, I wasn't looking forward to going but I must say I was pleased. $5 martini's (the mango is a MUST try) until 8 pm! Our table ordered shrimp & cheesy grits with bacon (loved it!), crab stuffed red snapper (loved it!) and lobster & crab ravioli (liked it, but have had better). Our waiter was awesome! Too bad I'm having a moment & can't remember his name.. I will definitely head back to Chocolat and hope I have another great experience.

My first time here.Friendly staff. The Food & drinks was delicious. My waitress was kind. However, the service was slow. The food service was on point, but I would've liked if she kill her customers with service. Service & personality 20 % tip but in this

Theme of the dining experience: #iCant

I'm a foodie, a Yelp Elite member, and a restaurant frequenter. It's my thing. You all also know that I rarely issue 1-star ratings in the many years I've been reviewing restaurants (in fact, this is just the 2nd time I've been prompted to even give a restaurant a 1-star rating).

Before I go IN, what did go right: our waitress was generally friendly and attentive (up until she gave us attitude at the end) smh.

With this said, my experience at Chocolat went from "ok" to "wow, I feel like I'm in the Twilight Zone", followed by "what did I do to deserve this?!"

This past Sunday was my dear friend's bday (an editor in the publishing/fashion industry) who is friends with Leon, the owner. We had just wrapped up celebrating on her rooftop and were ready to unwind over dinner & call it a day.

How the beautiful struggles unfold: 
1) We walk in, my friend asks to be seated @ the back table. We're rebuffed with a no...but as we take a look around, there are only 2, yes TWO parties dining in the restaurant! 
2) There was no silverware on the table
3) Our waitress asks us: "Would you like bread?"...umm, I know that this may be a cost-saving measure on your part but why even ask?! That's a first. 
4) Spoke to the manager (on the nite of August 5, 2012) whether birthday cake was complimentary on a guests' birthday. He said yes...Sure enough, a $10 charge for the cake appeared on our check! $10! Cake costs less at finer establishments (a la Chez/Red Rooster!!)
5) Said $10 cake came with a swirl of whipped cream (not scoop of icecream). Fine. When friend asked for scoop of icecream to go along w/ it, our waitress told us that the restaurant doesn't offer it. Not that night, not ever. 

INTERESTING coming from a restaurant called CHOCOLAT! One would think the dessert options would be exhaustive

6) Added 18% gratuity on a party of 3 ppl. THREE ppl! When we questioned good ol' waitress lady, she said it's a policy they implemented 'months ago' and it's done based on the amount of the bill. OUR BILL WAS $65. WHAT KIND OF SCHEME DISGUISED AS A FINE DINING ESTABLISHMENT IS THIS?! And of course, she couldn't quote the amount that bills have to be in order for the server to instate the 'required' 18% gratuity charge. Just the most ridiculous *ish I've ever heard in my life. EVER. 

7) Waitress had the nerve to get an attitude with us for her and the restaurants' actions. No need to take it personal, IF you're being forthcoming and doing your job. She actually was making comments (along with the bartender) as we were walking out the restaurant!, including "Have a great night and we hope to see you back!" but said very sarcastically. Was just totally unneeded and unnecessary. But I guess when you're running a biz that has no ambitions but to be an around-the-way place, that's how your employees will conduct themselves........

Throughout the entire experience, not ONCE did the manager (male manager working during dinner service on Aug. 5th) bother to come to our table to try to attend to our concerns, smooth things over, or make amends. But with all the foolishness that took place, I wouldn't dare show my face either! 

For this mistake, I will keep my dollars at 5 & Diamond, Chez Lucienne, Settepani, Lido's and Jacobs (for my down home meal fix)! That is all.

I was with a party of four that was seated in less than 5 minutes but unfortunately the food took over an hour to come out.  After calling the manager over she apologized and offered to comp dessert.  When the time came to order the dessert, the waitress told us that the manager pulled her aside and said to only comp 2 of the four desserts.  We called the manager over to ask about the change and was surprised when she said she could actually only comp one.  She offered another apology about the food taking so long to come out and blamed it on a faulty reservation system.  We failed see the connection between reservation and food prep time, but decided not to argue any longer and requested the bill.  

Our great experience (sarcasm) was topped off with a forced 18% gratuity on the bill.

I've been to Chocolat several times.  The waitstaff is pleasant and accommodating.  I've enjoyed their madeira glazed chicken with sides of mashed potatoes and broccoli.  I've also enjoyed their St. Louis spare ribs with mashed potatoes and a vegetable medley.  The atmosphere is lovely.  A nice place to meet for drinks, have dinner with friends or a dinner date.

Food is good, not superb or memorable.  Good ambience, jazzy music and chic decor.  Waiter (and others working) never cracked a smile, the food took 45 minutes, Mimosas were mostly orange juice and the place seemed under staffed for a Saturday afternoon.  Had a minor bill discrepancy that was easily adjusted.  Will possibly come back for the live Jazz on Sundays because I live nearby and really want to like this place, but they don't have the customer service piece down just yet.

business.full_address:
10 Hulfish St
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: Zoe

reviews.text:
I have shopped here for many years, since the merchandise is really lovely.  However, the customer service definitely is NOT.  After putting up with the haughty attitudes of the owner and employees for who knows how many years, I have decided that I will not be returning anymore.  
The straw that broke the camel's back was a recent experience I had when I was shopping for jeans.  I found that for every single style that I was interested in, they were out of stock of size 27 (my usual size).  When I inquired about this, the employee explained that she was also a size 27, and she bought most of them, and no, they would not order that size for me.  She proceeded to pressure me into buying a pair in size 26, telling me how tiny and skinny I was.  When I got home, I realized that these jeans REALLY were not my size and she had just been trying to cover her own ass.  I tried to return them a few days later, but surprise surprise, Zoe does not take returns.
Overall, the merchandise is gorgeous but they do not have a lot of stock, and the employees are obnoxious.

I really like Zoe. While I have definitely been ignored while shopping there, I have never felt it to be done in a hostile way. Honestly I prefer just being left alone to browse by myself. I have never felt like the staff there has been hawkishly watching my every move, like at other luxury boutiques. Zoe has an incredible selection - everything from Jil Sander and Chloe to casual basics like Cheap Monday and James Perse. I love driving up from Philadelphia to check out Zoe, Blue Mercury, and Kitchen Kapers, which are all next to each other. Keep it up, Zoe!

P.S. The brick and mortar store is way more stocked than the website and has a cooler selection.

I recently moved to Princeton and stumbled upon this store on Thursday night. No other store in this area are open this late. So I came in with my husband just to check the store out. As i walked in, i was immediately greeted with a smile by this guy. It's a friendly atmosphere in there, a little quiet, but very friendly. I love how the sales people are not aggressive, but they are still very helpful and friendly. There's no rush was intended when I was just looking around, but as soon as I needed help, they are very quickly came to help. I tried on a few dresses, and the guy who was helping me was amazing! He's very honest yet polite. Not only that, he showed me how the dress can be styled differently. He took his time to look for options for me and showed some dresses that I would never thought of trying. He has good eyes and personality. 

I ended up getting 2 dresses and a pair of shoes. The girl in with red hair was also very friendly. I just thought these people are so good to work with. 

As I walked out of the store, they thanked me and smiled. My husband who was with me the whole time was so impressed with the service we got. It's too bad that they don't carry menswear, my husband would love to shop here.

GASP. I cant believe I waited so long to venture in here. I should have known when on the first visiting weekend, my friend Justene was wearing gold Jimmy Choo flats she got on sale here. . . 

Yes it is expensive, but get over it, if you were in New York you wouldn't complain, and much more convenient that jumping on the train everytime you need a fashion fix.

I've shopped here for 3 years and I think the selection is getting better and better.  The premiere designers here include the row, proenza schouler, ysl, stella mccartney, miu miu, celine and givenchy which i love. theyskens, isabel marant and herff christiansen are my absolute contemporary favorites. i heard they're getting in mcqueen and haider ackermann (!!!!!!).

The "Zoe experience" in a nutshell: On any given day, the women who "work" at Zoe can be found circled around the register, exchanging OMG she SAID that to you's??! while you walk around the store totally ignored.

woahhh princeton stores get THIS NICE? it reminded me of scoop but not as trendy. The prices were pretty insane in here with their herve leger dresses (nice but all the more expensive ones 1.5k ones). The sales are decent since they are 70% off. The women here were super nice in general and helpful. It amazes me they have enough busines to stay open since its a pretty big place and they have lots of not to dressy but not college yuppie girl clothes. hrm...

I don't know how many coffees I've had taken away from me here.

Me and my J.A.P's (no i'm not talking about the japanese) like to come here to annoy the snotty tall girls with weird accents who work at this place.

What ev. 
I don't care if you've got sevens and true religions and marc jacobs! 

your people still suck.  i'll buy them online, k thanks.
