I don't spend that much time in Princeton anymore but I remember when Zoe had just opened in the early 90's and I was in middle school.  The store has only grown and expanded and was a major influence in turning Palmer Square into a downtown with high-end designer shopping.  Many other boutiques have followed suit but none of them have had the staying power Zoe has had.  I've found the salespeople there to be refreshingly friendly and professional, and the people who do the buying there really do a great job.  

Stores like Zoe would be a dime a dozen in NYC (Scoop, Big Drop, Intermix, etc.) but for Princeton, it's quite impressive.

They have APC. Not much, but some. There is nothing more to say. 

The other brands are a mixed bag, some great (Philip Lim), some sucking (Juicy "Couture" coming soon!!!!). Expensive, but there are sales. 

The shopgirls are nice. Just wear your clothes from Zoe when you go to Zoe. If you don't have clothes from Zoe, well, wear black. They'll help you. 

Oh, and APC.

Designer boutique in town, Zoe. My friend Brandon is a shopaholic. He convinced me that the prices were reasonable for nice sophisticated brands. I thought I would trust his opinion. We walk in, and none of the sales people even acknowledged us. We walked around the store, and I thought everything was over priced. The sale stuff looked like it was a few seasons old, and around 20% off their retail does not really satisfy me. I get a bigger discount at Bloomingdales for the same inventory. I did not even really see anything I liked. I guess it was worth a try for them. If I lived in Princeton, and that was the only place to shop, I'd probably buy a ton of things from there. Since I have a car, I don't have to worry about it.

My friend is a fan of Zoe.   After she mentioned that they were having a sale on shoes, I visited the store for the first time today.  My friend bought a pair of Proenza Schouler wedges (and put a pink Miu Miu bow bag on layaway, I think), while I bought a pair of black studded patent Miu Miu sandals.  It took a lot of self-control not to buy a Miu Miu belt, Margiela-esque black avant garde structured toggle coat on sale (Calvin Klein, surprisingly), and Rick Owens puffy jacket.  I may go back...  if they had further substantial cuts on their sale prices, I would have purchased all of those pieces.  I hope they have more Rick Owens in stock soon--I can't believe a store in Princeton has Rick Owens in stock.

During my first visit, the staff members were extremely friendly--all four of the women went out of their way to be friendly and helpful to me, even though I'd never been there before.  My friend then invited me to a VIP event, where the experience was less immediately positive--I didn't think the dress that one of the customers was trying on looked good at all, but two of the staff girls gushed about how great she looked.  I felt instantly suspicious and distrusting, since I've had experiences before where staff would try to sell to me even if the item wasn't a knock-out "must-have" in terms of how it flattered my body.  The fashion show itself was nice, and we sat near a staff girl who was very friendly and kind throughout lunch.

I'd walked past Zoe before but felt no desire to go in because the window displays aren't very attractive or edgy to me.  However, it turns out that the store merchandise had a pretty good selection for young, edgy fashion enthusiasts who would prefer buying in-store than online.  If you live in Princeton, give it a try!  I usually shop pretty intensely in New York City and online, but I think I will visit Zoe again after my first experience there!

business.full_address:
250 W 108th St
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Riverside Animal Hospital

reviews.text:
Please do not take your beloved pets here!!!  They are scam artists.  I seriously think, after spending way, way, way too much time and money there, that the vets are trained to scam you out as much of money as possible.  I don't trust that ANY of the vets there, and I've see them ALL, ever have your pet's best interest at heart.  Just awful, awful experiences there repeatedly.  Yes, I am to blame for going back, but please learn from my mistakes- don't do it!!  

For example- I went to take my almost 12 year old do there (I also have a one and a half year old pup) and they quoted me at $1100 worth of 'tests' for a sore knee.  I left and took her to my beloved vet back in Philly and she was given some pain meds for degenerative arthritis and is doing wonderfully!  That's one of MANY horrific experiences. 

I would never, ever recommend this place- ever!

Gosh, sometimes I really don't get the Yelp filter. I suggest you check out the filtered reviews, as I'm sure they would increase the average rating for Riverside Animal Hospital -- as it should be.

(Hmm, Yelp Filter, will you get this review, too?)

Anyway, I've come to Riverside Animal Hospital with my two cats twice, once for a check-up and another time for a time when I thought my cat had eaten a foreign object...

Dr. East is really nice, knowledgeable, and soothing. The assistants who work there are also really quirky and nice. 

I'd say the prices are high, but, I mean, you live in New York, and you have a pet. What d you expect?

They do have a deal on feline teeth cleaning, though, which I appreciate!

I have no reason to complain! But do give yourself an hour and a half cushion time for the appointment.

First, the good things: I have found the staff to be unfailingly friendly and helpful. They always made time to fit in our dog when he needed to be seen right away. You can tell they are real animal lovers.

The bad: In my opinion, they perform a lot of unnecessary tests/interventions. I'm not sure whether it's driven by a desire for $, is just a difference in approach to the minimalist one that makes sense to me, or is maybe a combination of both. Whichever, I found myself feeling ripped-off and wondering if I had exposed my dog to unnecessary ordeals when I left. We switched to another vet who shares our philosophy and have been very pleased.

took my dog here last year after existing vet couldnt figure out what was wrong with my dog. after a month of tests and acupuncture my baby was diagnosed with cancer. my dr was great. sat with me for hours while i cried and cradled my dog. my dog was a weekly patient here for two months. my dr knew he had a few months to live. my dr knew i was seeing another dr and the cancer center. you think he ever called to followed up or see  how ***I*** doing? no. in fact, i got a "check up" notification in the mail months after i had to put the love of my life in the grave. big thumbs down to this place! i spent thousands of dollars there and didnt get one follow up call. if you are expecting a hug, dont come here!!!!!

I used to be a customer here because it was close and my first visit here was fantastic, but boy has my opinion of this place changed. I have had two emergencies with my dog since about a year ago. I called both times begging to be seen or just speak to a doctor on the phone for some advice on what to do before I could get him to the hospital. In the first emergency they suggested I go to the location in the 70's because the doctor couldn't see more than one patient in an hour THEN that place wouldn't take me. In the second,  they called me back two days later when they said they would get the doctor call me back momentarily. When the doctor finally called me back and i mentioned I was told he would call back within the hour, he said i called after hours, which was absolutely not the case. 

Totally unacceptable. Please try to at least pretend to care about our animals. I am taking my business elsewhere and suggest that you really think hard before you bring your loved one here.

I like Riverside Animal Hospital a lot - they have great doctors and helpful, friendly front office staff.  Both vets who've cared for my cats were great - patient, thorough, explained things clearly to me.  They have a small number of rescue cats there - I got my tabby cat from Riverside.  They also send e-mailed reminders when it's time for checkups, etc., which is convenient.  Very happy with this vet and have recommended them to friends on the upper west side.

I do not like this animal hospital.  They had been giving my puppy vaccinations and she had a reaction to one.  I called the office and they said to come back to examine her.  I told them that I would make it right when the office was closing.  I was then told that they would not wait an extra 5 minutes past closing time.  Also, if I arrived at closing no one would be there.  This is an animal hospital right?  How could no one be there to examine her?

Never going back.  Went to a new vet near Columbus Circle and love her.  She reviewed the scheduled shots that RAH had printed out and determined that she did not need any of them.  Just a rabies vax in one year.

Since when did taking a pet to the vet become worse than going to a used car lot?  We've been going here for a couple years, and this most recent visit will be the last.  The techs are really friendly, as is the desk staff, but the heavy--very very heavy--emphasis on getting you to get extra tests, come back for extra visits, etc is just... slimy.  The vets here, every one I've seen, are very casual about saying things like, "Oh, Fluffy's getting up there in years, let's go ahead and do a senior blood panel."  You discover it's going to cost you an additional $230 only when you get the bill--at which point it's too late.  It's supposedly a "holistic" vet, which, as far as I've seen just means the opportunity to sell another line of products.

I understand they have high overheads and have to pay rent and all that--but the combination of being on the expensive side anyway and pushing all these other test makes for an overpriced vet visit.

I want to make this short and to the point!

We just had to put our cat down in December. It was the most hardest thing I have ever had to go through. I miss him! I had Marley for 16 years. I got him when I was 15 and he has been by my side the whole time. 

My experience at this hospital was terrible. I know they did the best they could but here is what really truly bothered me:

1. Our Dr. was like a robot. No emotion, no expression, very cold. Made me uncomfortable and worried.

2. Even though we would do whatever it took for our cat. I still felt like we were taken advantage of. They explain that they are ethical. In some ways they were and in some ways I felt like they were trying to make a pretty penny. 

3. I was SHOCKED when 2 weeks after THEY put Marley down we received a postcard that I thought was going to be a condolences card but to my surprise was a "Marley is due for a check-up" post card! 

and

4. Today 2 months later my boyfriend and I are ready for another cat. I am from CA and don't know any Persian breeders in this area. So I called them and explained my situation and asked them if they could guide me in the right direction. I automatically felt like I was an inconvenience. The woman I spoke with sounded so annoyed like she couldn't be bothered with such nonsense. 

Here is what I think-
I spent $2000 there. This may be nothing to some people. However, I am a student and so is my boyfriend. Marley meant the world to me and I did what I could do. I just wish they could have been a bit more helpful. I feel like all they care about is the money. They say they are ethical but their actions did not prove that. 

I will never take another animal there ever again. I want a place where they are warm and loving and caring. Of course people have to make money too, but vets do!!! It's a given. They all make $$$! Put the compassion before the $$$ is all I am saying!

Get a WRITTEN estimate before consenting to anything, and make sure you look it over carefully.  If you make any change be sure the new estimate reflects the change.  Every time we've come here our bill has ended up hundreds of dollars more than we were quoted because we took people at their word.  I guess we were the suckers for trusting other humans.  Time to find a new vet for this guy.

My last interaction with Riverside Animal Hospital was almost a year ago, but the experience was so miserable that upon signing up for Yelp, this is one of the first reviews I felt compelled to write. 

Initially, I was very impressed with the clinic. I loved the fact that the vet techs and office staff seemed to really love animals. I think my dog, when I first took him in, must have consumed at least a half bag of treats and there was a real effort to make him comfortable. I also loved that they worked with a shelter to adopt out homeless cats. Such a great thing. On my second visit, I adopted one of these kittens. She was small- about five months, and I paid an adoption fee that I was informed included her spay, but "We'll do that later, because she's so tiny. We'd like to wait till she grows."

So far so good. But about here is where things went downhill. I noticed that Riverside often charged excessive fees. Little things, like I'd be asked if I wanted to cut my dog's nails. I'd say fine, and notice there was a minimal charge for it on the bill that hadn't been mentioned. No big deal. I'd make an appointment for a Wellness checkup for my kitten, where she'd receive several vaccinations, and be advised not to give her a particular shot today, since she'd had so many to avoid overwhelming her system. Fine. But when I came back for that final shot two weeks later, I was charged $80 for *Another* Wellness checkup and informed that every time you go in for shots that is charged. We spent less than five minutes with a vet! Finally I was told that spaying was only included in the adoption fee if you happen to adopt the cat when it had already been spayed. That would have been fine had that been what I was initially told, but I most certainly had been told something else. 

The final time I came in with my cat, she seemed stressed, which I attributed to all the unfamiliar animals. The vet did not agree- worse- said she seemed to be in physical pain and so recommended giving her a muscle relaxant and pain killer.  Who would refuse relieving a cat that was in pain?! So of course I got very anxious and said yes. Had I missed my cat being hurt all this time? I felt awful. However, after giving the muscle relaxant, then they proceeded to take over three hours to administer her vaccination, despite noticing that she was very stressed/in pain. They simply left her in the back of the building, in her carrier. At first I tried to be understanding. It was a weekend and I had errands to do, so I asked if I could come back after making a grocery run. Fine. An hour later? Cat not ready. Ok. I live a couple blocks away. 45 minutes after that? Still not ready. I waited another half hour in the lobby until they gave my cat her vaccinations, and I paid my larger-than-expected bill and took her home. Nothing more was said/done about her seeming to be in pain. It seemed to me so egregious- if she was in pain, figure out why- painkiller is undertreatment. If not in pain, just give her her vaccination quickly so we can go home and remove the stress of the situation asap. Don't keep her several hours and give her unnecessary drugs.

I hated feeling this way. This was my vet- I wanted to trust them unquestioningly, because of course they know better than I do. But if you start feeling like unnecessary treatments are being foisted on you just to make an extra buck, you start questioning every thing. Every last suggestion, every tiny, unexpected charge. Only you don't even have the basis or knowledge to question. You're no medical professional. You just have this vague sense of distrust and feeling of being taken advantage of. This was how I felt at Riverside- like I was buying a used car and had to be wary.

My last interaction upset me so much that I emailed them and explained why I could no longer be a client. In response, a woman called and apologized for my wait, indicated that all charges on my bill were merited, but that she could provide me a discount this one time, and then said something I will never forget. We got a bit off topic in the call and she told me that it was Riverside's policy, when faced with a puppy who had parvo, to only offer in-hospital treatment as an option. This costs several thousand dollars and is the safest but also most expensive form of treatment. But if a customer could not afford this, they may recommend euthanasia but they would not offer or even inform a customer about less expensive treatment options, such as purchasing the saline drip, anti-emetics and antibiotics to administer on their own, because pet owners were not trained medical professionals. 

I really just could not believe this had even been said. Think about it. Because the best treatment isn't feasible, you don't offer any others that have a good chance of working? It's basically condemning a puppy to death.

I was sickened by the call. I declined her offer of a partial refund to my last bill and switched vet practices.

I'm glad to see I'm not the only one who feels that Riverside Animal has been focusing a lot on tests recently. 

I've been going there for about 11 years. The techs and the vets are all very very good, but I do feel like there has been a stronger emphasis on more and more tests in the last few years.  And I miss their old location--it felt less high-tech and more friendly.

But they were excellent when my previous cat had diabetes and hypertension, and you don't wait long for appointments, either scheduling them or once you arrive. And they were fabulous when I recently had to put my 18-year-old cat to sleep.

I had a terrible experience at Riverside Animal Hospital.  I brought a stray cat in to be neutered after purchasing the $75 Friends of Animals neutering certificate.  When I came in for the preliminary exam, there was an additional $140 of tests that were "required".  When the vet took the cat to the back for bloodwork, she said "I'll clip her claws for you and throw in some flea stuff", implying she was doing me this favor.  When I got the bill, there was an additional $15 for the claws and $65 for 3 months of flea stuff!  I was lucky to get out of there for $200, after declining the numerous X-rays, tests, and vaccinations that the vet, the vet technician, and the office manager all tried to guilt me into getting.  When I called back to schedule the actual spaying surgery, they told me it would be an additional $200 for the required overnight stay, additional bloodwork, special cat litter, rabies vaccination, and extra special e-collar!  I wanted to cry.  We're now taking her to the East Side Animal Hospital who will do the Friends of Animals spaying for no additional costs.  I'm so upset about being ripped off by Riverside.  I'll tell everyone I meet not to go there.

Sadly our persian cat Bookaboom became ill last week and by Sunday he was not eating or drinking. Thankfully Riverside opens over the weekends, this alone saved him a huge amount of potential pain and suffering. Dr East and a very helpful team of nurses and staff welcomed us and saw him immediately - a huge relief. Bookaboom was 12 yrs old, he had been ill many times over the years and had an enlarged heart and liver. The current infection had caused sepsis in his blood, he had a very low body temperature and was severely dehydrated. Due to his age and the critical state of his health we decided to let him go, a deeply upsetting moment, one that still makes me cry as I type this. Dr East comforted us and brought Bookaboom to a private room so we could be alone for as long as we wished. After a while we agreed we were ready and my wife held him as they first put him gently to sleep and then with another injection stopped his heart. There was no easy way to do this and we miss him terribly still but this vet helped and cared for us in this very sad time, for which we will be eternally grateful. We have another cat called Garfield whom they also care for, we will continue using them and can thoroughly recommend them to you.

One final note, yesterday we checked our home voicemail (which we rarely do) and there was a personal message from Dr. East regarding how they felt for us in this time of pain and wished us well. - Thank you. I have posted a picture of Bookaboom and Garfield, Boom is the seal point persian (grey) with blue eyes.

business.full_address:
36th and Spruce St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19195
business.name: The Real Lee Ahn

reviews.text: I always get chicken pho here.  I wouldn't exactly classify it as pho, but its a really good bowl of chicken soup.  Not greasy, and you can tell the chicken came from a whole chicken (REAL chicken).  Great place for a quick and extremely cheap lunch!

Excellent Chinese food truck, but be prepared to wait for a while. The story behind the name is that there's another food truck across the street also run by a woman named Lee Ahn, but I don't remember which one came first-- which is sort of sad, considering the number of times I've heard the story.

Actually, if I remember correctly, there are three of these... the "Real", the "Original" and the "Lee Ahn's".

All the history is probably lost by now... but this cart has an interesting method of making food, both steam the noodles/rice and then pour a thick white/brown sauce over the noodles or dish to complete it. Rarely do you get a full sauteed/stir-fried dish, although sometimes it was possible, depending on the dish. I prefer this one just due to the fact I know the owner after speaking with her (and she pops an extra treat into my lunch each time).

Service is a bit slower than other places (there's only so much room to maneuver, and somehow she managed to cram a bit of everything from bamboo-steamed snacks to dumplings in here...), but the wait usually isn't bad except at lunch time.

Every time I see this food stand I am reminded of hip hop's Roxanne wars.

Le Ahn vs. The Real Le Ahn?

As far as Chinese food on wheels goes this one's not so great. 

When I asked if they had brown rice, the reply was "I can put soy sauce on it, that'll make it brown." Clever, but, no, thanks.

Anyway, I prefer Roxanne Shanté to The Real Roxanne. So, you may be able to gather my feelings for The Real Le Ahn.

FYI a few years ago Lee Ahn sold her truck to the nice people across the street. Then she decided to come out of retirement but they would not relinquish her name. So she decided to go the Kramer route with the name.

I much prefer the "Fake" Lee Ahn across the street. The Real Lee Ahn is more expensive, menu is confusing, and the food is not as good.

I was looking for Singapore Rice Noodle. Got a pound of rice noodle with some yellow curry powder mixed in with a handful of random veggies. This review will serve as a reminder to myself not to do this again. She didn't even include a packet of soy sauce to flavor this up with. Me -0/The Real Lee Ahn - 1.

I'm on a mission to try as many Penn food carts as possible.  I ordered a small vegetarian stir-fry singapore noodle.  It was a curry noodle dish (lightly curried) with some vegetables, lots of scrambled egg...and halfway through the dish....LOTS OF HAIR.  No.  I do not do hair cooked into my eggs anymore.  That is a food trend that went out of style with tomato aspic.  

I was already not loving the noodles pre-hair discovery, they were mushy (both noodles and veggies) and too salty.

Plus I ordered a small and she charged me for a large...I tried to explain but it wasn't worth the trouble for $0.75.  Maybe I paid extra for all the hair (seriously, like three long black hairs cooked into the egg).

I gave it two stars because that is how I would have rated the dish without the unfortunate incident....otherwise, it was a no star experience.

I wish yelp allowed us to give half stars because the Real Le Ahn really only deserves 2.5 stars.  It's not 2 stars because it's generally better than the Le Ahn across the street due to greater selection and larger portions, but it doesn't deserve 3 stars because the quality of the food is not that great.

There are a few dishes that I would stick to while ordering from here.  The Pad Thai is generally good, but be warned that it's not really Pad Thai.  The eggplant with chicken in black bean sauce is probably the best dish that they serve.  And the roasted pork with rice is something quick that you can get when you're running between classes.  Otherwise, most of the other dishes tend to be overwhelmed with tons of mystery sauce (probably loaded with MSG).  

Despite everything, the lady who runs the Real Le Ahn is a gem.  She's awesome and makes great conversation when you're waiting for food.  I guess that could bump its rating up to 3 stars.
Ok, this really should be a 3.5 because I have just discovered something wonderful about this place: Curry Rice Noodle Soup. It's a gigantic bowl of aromatic soup for $5.  I mean, this DE-LICIOUS.

The Real Lee Ahn: Serving up MYSTERY MEAT everyday. 

No, but seriously, my experience with this hell on earth cart left me wanting to save their listeria monocytogenes laced food in my fridge so I could chuck it right back at the owner the next day. Let me set up the story for you:

It was late, and I just got out of my 20th class as a Penn student. It was raining, but hungry as I was, I knew it was time to try my first food cart in Philly.  My excitement built as I found myself ordering General Tso's chicken from the very friendly lady at The Real Lee Ahn. I proceeded home on the bus, fumes permeating through the bag ...along with perhaps just a little bit of grease that may or may not have rubbed on my neighbor. Finally, I arrived home to devour this long awaited treat. 

Bite #1- Although the dish didn't look bad esthetically, my first bite into the chicken made me wonder just how long that soggy, pathetic piece of meat was sitting in a steamed container until I was dumb enough to order it.
Bite #2- As I lifted the fork up to my mouth, I caught a whiff of the most ghastly smell that took me a good four hours to actually forget. Upon cutting said piece open, I noted shiny, translucent scales- apparently, there were pieces of fried, rotting fish thrown into this smorgasbord of bad food.
Bite #3- After ridding the dish of all pieces of squishy, fried fish (which was about half!) I went in again, but this time not without cutting it open to double check. To my surprise, the meat was dark and looked like crap. Now I know General's is normally made with dark meat, but this stuff didn't even qualify for meat. If it wasn't squirrel and actually was chicken, I'm convinced it was the rectum (no, not the ascending, descending, or sigmoid colon, but the legit rectum still packed with...you get the point). Following this, my appetite was ruined/destroyed/ravaged. I felt like I needed to shower. I promptly threw everything in the trash and convinced myself to never be daring enough to try a food cart again...or for a month or so. 

Lastly, doesn't the name say it all? Selling the rights to the Lee Ahn name and then changing their minds and setting up shop as the Real Lee Ahn right next to their competitor over some trivial dispute...what the hell is wrong with these people? Perhaps they should be more worried that their food tastes like cancer. 

Hate you long time, Real Lee Ahn!

business.full_address:
6228 A Greenbelt Rd
Greenbelt, MD 20770
business.name: Boston Market

reviews.text: I went to Boston Market in different a few times, especially in Boston where I am from. I love the smell of roasted chicken as soon as you open their door, their hot food, mashed potato with gravy, green bean, corn bread, turkey in November. But at this particular Boston Market in Greenbelt, I  was very disappointed, the food was cold, the cashiers were not friendly, dining room was dirty, nobody cleaned the tables even though we were there almost an hour, on top of those, the restroom was filthy. No wonder among restaurants in this Plaza, Boston Market has the least customers. I would not be surprised if they will close down soon, if they don't improve.

I got home, dumped out my luggage, gathered the things for the cleaners finished my errands (cleaners, CVS, post office, grocery store, etc.) and I was hungry. I needed comfort food. I was determined not to eat the whole bag of potato chips that was in the back seat. But I was hungry NOW. Botston Market will do. Didn't it used to be Boston Chicken? Anyway, I stuck with the chicken. The 3 piece was on special. It came with 2 sides and cornbread. I added a third side and up-sized the drink. (See. This is why we're fat.)

When she brought it to my table (when did they start doing THAT?!?!), my first thought was "Is that a chicken drumette? Are you kidding me?" But I was calm, cool about it. I hadn't touched anything. And when she passed my way again, I just calmly said "Is there a way to exchange this for a quarter dark with a better drumstick? I have been looking forward to having the drumstick all to myself." Even her jaw dropped when she actually looked at the drumstick that was on my plate. She said let me take a look and see what I can do.

Boom. A few minutes later, she returned with a nice, full-sized drumstick. Juicy and ready for me to bite. Mmmm. Mmmmm. Mmmm. Add in the mashed potatoes, the macaroni 'n' cheese, and the lemon garlic spinach (when did they start making THAT?!?!) and wash it all down with some high fructose corn syrup sweetened iced tea and I'm good. I'm a fan.

Pulled BBQ was SUPER!!!  It really hit the spot!  I will definitely be going back again to get more of this BBQ chicken!!!  I mean it was REEEEAAAALLLLLY good!  I really enjoyed my meal here!

On the flip side, the ladies restroom really stunk!  It needed a good cleaning!

business.full_address:
3929 Sansom St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Fatboy and Slim's

reviews.text:
Not the healthy of options, but sometimes that's what the doctor ordered. Yeah, okay, maybe no doctor in hell would order that, but my mind is rarely in the doctor's office asking what it should eat.

What really drew us here was the Sweet Potato Nachos. These are fries with cheese and salsa on them. It was a waste. The fries were okay, so I am really talking about the nacho version. The topping part seemed to mold into one big chunk like thing that was just in the way of trying to pull fries out.

The sliders we got were pretty decent. The mozzarella sticks, chicken fingers, and onion rings were okay too. It's hard to mess up fried goodness, so not really giving them that much credit.

I just ordered from here using Campus Food.  That means that the order is typed out for them, no miscommunication can occur.  Despite this, I got an order that was missing pieces and  when they did not have the sauce requested, they put HOT on instead of calling to ask what we would like in its place.  The person eating the wings does not eat spicy food, who puts hot on in the place of SWEET sauce?  When I called to ask what happened to the pieces that were missing, they seemed unconcerned and when I asked about the sauce they told me that Hot meant Mild... I have never been so angry or disappointed in a delivery.  The only thing I can say was that the delivery person was nice.

I've ordered from here 4-5 times, and have never had a bad experience. Delivery has always been fast and painless. Occasionally on Fridays I will order their special (Any burger, fries and 10 wings for $9.99). The deal just can't be beat. They used to serve crinkle cut fries, which were pretty lame, but I was willing to accept that based on the price. But now they've really stepped up their game with the fries, as they're now quite enjoyable. The burgers are big, juicy, and come with a lot of good toppings. As far as the wings, they won't blow your mind, but they pretty solid. People rave about Ed's wings, but Fatboy's wings are just as good and probably a little bigger. All of their nightly deals look awesome, and I hope to try out a few more of them in the future. Give this place a try. You won't be sorry.

Ordered delivery from here. The wings were okay, not great. Likewise, the chicken fingers were average. The sliders though, were pretty tasty. 

However, the chicken Caesar wrap contained no lettuce. What kind of chicken Caesar wrap doesn't contain lettuc

I love this place! fast delivery and they deliver soup thats not wonton! Acturally that why I started ordering from here, because of there soup delivery. Everything i've tried has been fantastic, and the prices are good, I can't believe that it run out of the blanery stone.

This lovely food joint operates out of Blarney Stone bar (see other review). This restaurant has pretty decent food. Fatboy & Slim's is a typical cheese steak, burger and salad joint. Their grilled chicken Caesar salads are delicious and their fries are perfectly crispy. Their meatball subs are sub par though. Besides the meatball sub, I have never had a bad experience with Fatboy's. Their prices are very reasonable as well!

business.full_address:
3131 Walnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Trophy Bikes

reviews.text:
Nice high-end goods, and good service, but don't you dare bring a department store bike in or you'll be laughed out of the store.

I brought Pacific brand bike there because the tire was rubbing against the frame, and instead of fixing it they gave a polite but condescending spiel on how cheap bikes were terrible and bad for biking culture and you should instead pay hundreds of dollars for a bike that you use once a week.  He complained about how bikes like that had bad frames and so he refused to fix them.  He then tried to demonstrate how loose the steering column was by giving it a good jerk, but to his surprise it didn't budge.  That didn't phase him, and he would have continued but I left and took the bike home.  I found that the last time I had taken the back wheel off I'd forgotten to tighten one of the bolts all the way, and it was fixed in an instant.

I don't have hundreds of extra dollars to pay for a bike that I barely use, especially since it's very likely to be stolen in my neighborhood.  Moreover, the one bike I paid more than $100 for honestly wasn't all that much better than my current bike.  I find their attitude unhelpful and just plain snobbish.

If I had more money than I knew what to do with I'd go here, but right now the only thing this bike shop is good for is the free bicycle pump they have on the front step.

For some reason I really like this place.  Every time I have always gone in I have been wowed by the neat bicycle accessories, gloves, tools, etc they stock.  It seems like they have all top quality products.  As a result, their prices seemed a little high but you can't argue when your buying top notch.  They let me test ride a neat 2-speed bicycle too.  They made me wear a helmet but meh, that was whatever.  The only thing this place is lacking is a good place to test ride the bikes.  The stretch of walnut st where this place is located is very busy and university city has lots of pot holes.  

Otherwise, all-in-all they know what their talking about and have the best products.  I'm a fan.

I visited Trophy Bikes earlier today looking for a new lock and was warmly greeted by the owner. He showed me several lock options and clearly reviewed the pros and cons of each, showed me how to lock my bike securely, and gave me a bunch of great tips for things I could do once I got my back home to ensure my bike would be as safe as reasonably could be. I'm not sure I could have asked for much more.

Unrelated, but also worth considering-- this place opens at 8am, two hours earlier before the other shops in town. If you need to grab something early, it's hugely convenient.

I think this place is a good bike shop even though it's not populated by bike nerds. The staff have proven to be friendly. I plunked down over a grand on this joint a year ago and unfortunately, had some issues with my bike. The staff helped me fix them without question. That was really nice. Only down side was price [a bit high] and selection. I wasn't as familiar with the brands they had. All in all, a good place to go.

Overall, Trophy Bikes has been good to me.  A long time ago I lost a screw for my cargo holder on the back of my bike.  I went into Trophy and a kind bike mechanic immediately found a screw for me that he installed at no charge.  It was a rainy day and I would have been in big trouble without that screw to hold my rack on the back of my bike for a 10 mile commute.  My rack would have flew off with the right pothole for sure.   I never forgot that experience and I went to Trophy a number of times afterwards. Recently, I purchased a Jamis Coda bicycle from Trophy, but I was frustrated it took quite awhile to receive it.  I had to call them a few times to find out when my bike (I put a deposit 50% down) would actually have my bike in stock. I was told the economic downturn caused the shop to take a long time to get the bike, but I love it.  I do not know how typical this is but Trophy had to order my Marathon tires and black Brooks saddle - they were not in stock.  Nevertheless, the guys called me a few days later when they arrived and they installed them at no additional charge.  Also, they helped me install my rear bicycle light (from my old bike) that I could not manage to do on my own.  In fact, they donated to me a special piece of material that helps hold my light in place.  I respect Trophy Bikes.  I feel they are generous with advice and little tweaks light my bike light and long ago with the screw for my rear rack.  I will use Trophy for years to come.

This morning on my way to work, my handlebars came loose.  whoops!  I walked my bike to Trophy because I lost my set of tools it was the closest bike shop and the guy tightened everything and really patiently explained to me what I needed to watch out for in the future.  I don't have any clue how they are with bike repairs/sales/whatever, but based on my experience today I was pretty impressed with how nice they are there.

I was looking for a new commuter road bike recently.  It was my first time buying a bike and was a little nervous.  I must admit I was actually skeptical for Trophy at first too, my impression was that it was expensive and snooty (down the street from Penn after all).  I quite misjudged Trophy Bikes. After checking out 3 different bike shops in Philly, I settled on Trophy.  The selection wasn't huge but was exactly what I was looking for, the staff were all friendly, helpful and not at all snooty, and the price was the best (the same bike at a nearby shop went for $25 more-- nothing to laugh at!).

I'm glad I did buy at Trophy.  Since then I've gone back for my first free tune up (nice perk not available other places) and for two other small additions to the bike. I've been especially impressed at how willing they are to do small maintenance (less than 3 minutes) without charge.  I recommend it!

These guys recently opened a new shop down on Liberty Walk. Great place to get your bike serviced for a reasonable price. The guys working there will check out your ride for free (as I remember it), diagnose its problems, and get 'er goin as good as new.

I'm not a bike connoisseur, so I can't really comment on the quality or prices of the bikes they stock, but the collection -- mostly mountain bikes -- seems geared toward serious bikers, not someone looking for a junker to ride to work/class on sunny days.

Had my bike shipped here from Texas. Trophy Bikes did a good job putting it back together and tuning it up....but that's where competency stops.

I bought a front basket for my bike - simple enough. Went home to attach the basket myself and save myself the $20ish dollars to have them do the work. After scratching my head for HOURS, I eventually went back to Trophy Bikes only to have them tell me they had given me the wrong screws and attachments! They then refused to help me out unless I paid them again and I had to go back home and do the work myself again.

After more frustrations I eventually went to Bicycle Therapy. The guys there were amazed Trophy Bikes had even sold me such a basket as they had clearly seen the sort of bike I ride.....I have not been back to Trophy Bikes since and am quite happy with my decision - go to Bicycle Therapy!

Update/response to the owner comment: I appreciate the comment and the additional information, especially about the flat fixes.  But -- if I may nitpick for a second since you took the liberty of being snarky (I'm very sympathetic to your points and totally get what you're saying) -- not all Yelpers are complainers and many of us joined in order to show our love to local businesses! So for every complaining, entitled jerk that comes on Yelp to vent, I hope you realize that many more came on to your page to give you a better than average review. Don't look at it as letting the Yelpers get you down -- let the Yelpers lift  you up. Entitled jerks are jerks no matter if they use Yelp or not; they only difference is that you actually hear about the jerkiness when they post about it on the Internet.

When I was first buying a bike I tried this store among many others, and the staff here were helpful advising and letting me try out various bikes etc.  Didn't end up buying here, for other reasons; not a negative reflection on them. My mediocre review is based on an incident where I wanted to buy a new fixed cog.  They were plenty nice and helpful in choosing the cog size.  I then asked them to attach it.  This is a job that takes literally 2 minutes and which I would do myself; I just haven't bothered to buy a chainwhip yet. Perhaps I'm spoiled, because at my preferred shop, Firehouse Bikes in West Philly, they will do a trivial little job like this right then and there with no hassle.  At Trophy, the guy said I would have to leave my bike overnight or come back the next day, either making an appointment or expecting to leave the bike there for a little while.  And attaching the cog would cost $10--$15. 

I had the forthrightness to tell the owner that I would be going with the competition and the courtesy to inform him of the reason why.  Where I lost patience was when he then launched into a lecture on his business model, profit margins, mechanics' salaries and schedules, etc. etc.  I can't remember anyone ever having the gall to try to argue me into wasting more time and paying more money for what he even admitted was exactly the same service.  Great, you have a different business model from Firehouse, and yours seems to work for you, since you're still in business.  I however am not a retailer or an MBA student and do not give a fuck about the details. 

Based on other yelp reviews and hearsay, it's clear that this guy has a robust sense of self-righteousness about his pricing.  I'm sure it's frustrating to do all kinds of complex reasoning to determine the optimal pricing for an item or service given your operating constraints only to then have customers complain that they can get it cheaper elsewhere.  But making them listen to the details of that reasoning process is just arrogant and will NEVER succeed in reclaiming a single lost customer.  (Really, I'd have though that was obvious.)

UPDATE:  My straightforward inquiry about cog attachment: ~15 sec.  The self-righteous lecture the owner replied with: ~3 min.  My yelp review based on said lecture: 382 words.  The self-righteous lecture (see below) he replied to my review with: 632 words.  

See?

I recently bought a used bike on Craigslist. I haven't owned a bike since I was 12 years old, so I needed a bike lock and a helmet and all that stuff. The woman I bought the bike from suggested going to Trophy. I stopped in there about 15 minutes before they closed and they were super helpful. They told me which lock to get (Kryptonite, my bike friends agree), showed me how to use a cable to lock my wheels and even fixed the kickstand on the bike for free (it was too long).

They only had really expensive helmets when I was there, and I wanted a cheaper one, so they suggested Eastern Mountain Sports, where I did find one that fit my needs.

I expected them to be snobby bike people, but they were really helpful. I plan to come here again if I need to get my bike fixed or tuned.

Super helpful & friendly staff (grey haired guy Mike was especially helpful - took a lot of time to explain pros and cons of a bunch of different products). Pretty good selection, not the cheapest but great quality.

Megan is great! She was super helpful in finding the right bike for me. She also took the time to explain how gears work since this was my first bike with actual gears (I know. I'm super green when it comes to these things). Though they only sell new bikes, which means expensive prices, they try to make sure that customers only buy bikes that they are totally in love with. As a result, they encourage you to ride as many bikes until you find the right fit. If only all bike shops could be staffed with friendlier people...

I planned to come here originally just for a flat fix and assessment of a few things, but decided instead to just go for the entire tune-up deal, because my bike needed it.  Months after I got it from the Bike Church, I still hadn't invested much time or money into it, so I figured in preparation for spring was as good of a time as any.

The guy helping me was overall very detailed and thorough, and he answered all of my questions, so I can't complain there...but I still didn't feel COMPLETELY satisfied after I left.  It could have been because when I got to the end of the block my chain fell off, so i took it back to have that actually tightened ( I was waiting for it for a good 15 minutes), but the entire way home I feared that something terrible was going to happen, just in general by how my bike felt.  Nothing did, but...I still didn't like the feeling, and it made me doubt if they actually test rode it as they claim.

A few other small things irked me, that I noticed afterward, for example, they did not replace the valve caps on my tire valves and also attached an extra part on my luggage rack that I specifically said I had at home and could do when I got back.  I'm not sure if they actually charged me for that but, who knows.

Eh. I don't know. They felt mediocre to me.  I have no real motivation to go back if I need more bike services.  I'm not sure what the average costs for the sort of things I had done are, but  for the  $100 ($40 was a new rim...so its usually $60 ish) I paid to get that tune-up, I feel as if really a lot of little things got fixed instead of the big important things. And that's not good.

Talk about bad service! the last time i went here was to fix a flat. Now i usually goto my mexican shop in south philly or the firehouse on balitmore but alas i got a flat at 34th and walnut so I shimmy on down to trophy. I walk in No one greats me but about 4 hipsters look at me like a rhino walking in.  I walk up to the counter and the clerk walks away. so i walk up to one of the "workers" and say i have a flat and he says "ok" and i reply by saying "can i get it fixed"  he then tells me it will cost me $17 to get a new inner tube installed. WHAT!?   seriously i usually pay about 4-5 for that service. But I was running late for a appointment and i hand it over.......not 20 minutes down the road my tire pops and i look the tire was properlly put back on...i call and ask if they will re do it for me the right way......"there response was simply "no"    i will never go there again and i tell as many people as possible in that area to bike to 50th and balitmore where you will get freindly fast and CHEAP service.

I've never purchased anything major from this store, so DISCLAIMER: my review is based solely on the one tube I bought from there, and the one time I needed a tube replaced after an unfortunate flat tire on my way home from work....

...So here goes:  It was around 5:45pm, and the store closes at 6pm.  I walked in with my sad bike and its sad flat tire... and asked if they could change the tube for me.  The guy who was helping me seemed quite perturbed with the fact that I was waltzing in 15 min prior to closing asking for a tube change, and I believe he actually used the words "We're about to close"... to which I replied 'well is it something I can get fixed quickly?"... he all but rolled his eyes at me and took my bike back.  I get it: you want to go home.  Trust me, I do too... hence why a flat tire on my evening commute home after working since 8am would cause me to show up at your establishment needing a tube change.

Anywho--he changed it in a jiffy which allowed me to get home in one piece but only after he sarcastically wished me "good luck" as I was checking out.

I'm no expert biker and yes--I was the dummy caught with a flat rear tire sans spare tubing... but cut me some slack--I didn't ask you to fetch my kitten from a tree.  I'm a paying customer and I was certainly not the last person in the store.

I don't know what it is about Philly bike culture, but I constantly feel like a know-nothing dumbass.  I love my bike, and ride it several miles a day for my work commute and general errands when it's not the dead of winter.  But I've yet to have the time to devote to taking a DIY approach to my bike, and because of that, I constantly feel out of place.

At Trophy, however, I don't feel like I'm being sized up when I walk in with my baby.  The clientele isn't made up entirely of pretentious West Philly fixed gear punks, and the staff takes a simple approach to finding and explaining any problems with your bike.  I don't feel stupid asking technical questions here where I might get laughed at elsewhere.

Sure, it's on the pricey side - and why wouldn't they be, with their location next door to Penn.  But they do a great job, and that's all that matters to me.  Until I can head to the Bike Church for bike class, Trophy for a quick repair will suffice.

I've email them a few times about parts for a Brompton bike about 4 years ago and never got a respond from them. Not sure if they read their email. So I decided to visit the place. While I was waiting, I decided to see how heavy a Titanium version of the Brompton was. I believe it was the owner who said don't try to fold the bike if you don't know how to fold it.  I guess I wasn't suppose to touch the bike. He went back to his customer he was helping so I just left the place. That was my experience dealing with the place. Nice and quick. I doubt he would remember the encounter.

I have visited the Trophy a few times, nice selection, i like the fact
that you can buy some English and US made bikes/frames here. 
Surlys are cool and all but me personally I would never spent a grand
on a bike made in Taiwan or China. Italian or American made steel
 is the way to go.
  I see the owner has had some runs ins with customers, who knows 
who to believe, he seemed nice enough to me, very helpful. 

  I have found out in my 40 years that  pretentious and annoying 
people seem to flock to the bicycle mechanic position. I have 
dealt with many nice ones too. BUt far too many want to force their 
 annoying opinions in your earholes. The single speed hipster thing
has brought the pretentiousness to a whole new level of horrible. 
  
   Your best bet is to pick up a park book or take some Park tool classes like
the one Trophy offers and fix your bike yourself, its pretty easy for
the most part, will save you some money , and most importantly save
you from mingling with  the dreaded skinny pants wearing
 Bearded bicycle snob.

Go to Bike Therapy if you are buying a bike, and Performance Bike if you just need parts.

This is bar none, the worst bike store in Philadelphia. I don't say that because the selection is bad, because in a pinch, it is fine. Need tire levers or a tube or something else quite simple? This is a fine shop for it. Need to buy a bike or anything large? Avoid this place like the plague. 

I called the owner asking about his stock in Surly Steamrollers and asked if he had a particular size. His response? Screaming at me that he is sick of people just trying out bikes at his store and buying them online. Never once did he consider that I would (and this was my intention) buy a $1000 bike from him. Get rid of the owner and much of his overly pretentious staff and this store might be fine. Me? I will just ride anywhere farther out of my was to miss this place.

================Update===============================
Just an update to my previous review. Mike (the owner) has now messaged me twice with rather insulting messages that I have copied in full below. I would like to point out very specifically that I had not even begun to talk about prices on bikes by the time that he "growled" at me.

After reading the below e-mails it will be painfully clear how little this owner knows about common decency towards would be customers. Avoid this ass and his business at all costs.

E-mail 1:
"Greets... sorry you caught me on a bad day, and/or called me while having a bad day yourself! That said, you might put a correction in your review -- the Steamroller sells for a little over $700 and we'd hate people to think we were overcharging for it.

Since you've never run a business, you have no idea of one of the best aspects of it -- the ability to simply do without some customers who are not pleasant to deal with, or who view every transaction as an audition.

Of course, there are days when I'd love to fire myself, but   that's simply not possible -- as who would sign the checks and take out the trash?

On the bright side, at least you will be riding farther to miss us and cycling is good cardio!

cheers
  mcget/trophy bikes

Fun Fact: last year our Yelp reviews got about 250 page views/month, that's down to about 60 page views/month for the same period this year. I guess people are tired of the kind of personalities that Yelp attracts. Yelp itself may not last into 2011, according to the Wall Street Journal.

Our business, however, is up well over last year, despite the bad weather -- what can I say?"

E-mail 2 - 
"Fun Fact: Trophy Bikes is among the Top 20 Surly Dealers on the planet--we didn't get there by price matching or babying spoiled price shoppers. Thanks for your comments and stop in any time!
 --the owner"

I would not go here. I went in today because I needed a bag for my dahon since I live on the 4th floor walk up. The two guys were working were extremely unfriendly and wanted to sell me a bag that my dahon wouldn't even fit into. If you want to go to a bike store with good service who will give you the time of day go to Jays pedal power on East Girard!

The pricing here is outrageous.

Repeat: Outrageous.

I went in here to buy 2 spare 700 tubes (or 27x1) and a patch kit. They charged me 16 dollars and change. I could have spent less at REI, but I try to support local bike shops whenever I can. In this case, I have to heartily recommend against going to Trophy. Yeah, I understand that you're a rich Penn student and mom and dad gave you a credit card to buy whatever you want, but it would be nothing if not uneducated to pay double what the items cost for the sake of it. If you disagree, I have a stick of gum to sell you for $5. 

The tubes it turns out are beyond nothing special. They are reboxed run of the mill Chinese Kenda tubes which you find in any generic sporting goods store. The patch kit didn't even have a case. I will never spend money at Trophy again. 

On the other hand, Firehouse at 50th and Baltimore is owned by its employees and very reasonable. They even took a few bucks off of my purchase of a replacement seat and took the old one to recycle onto another bike.

I've bought a bike (mid level) here and have both my other bikes (bought elsewhere) serviced here.  I've had no problem with them, the repair guys are excellent ! They are a small shop and busy @ times unable to get to you right away.  I've had some craiglist project bikes which they fixed modified and gave me good advice.  They will make suggestions and get most any accessary through  a large database.  Lot's of stuff I've read about bikes strongly suggests get fitted properly and maintain a relationship @ a local bike store.

This place is simply ok. That's about it. One problem I have is that they are ALWAYS trying to sell you something. ALWAYS. No advice comes without a sales pitch. 
NOTE: I previously wrote about a particular tall employee who I found to be less than helpfu

This is the worst bike store I've been to in Philly.  I live in Center City so I've been to a few across the river, but since I work in West Philly I occasionally have to stop in here on my way back home for small stuff.  Their prices are  high, their selection is low, and their customer service is OK at best.  

They seem to sell a lot of overpriced bikes to the college kids in U City but if you need a tire or some other assorted part/accessory, in my experience the cheaper models are out of stock and they are quick to upsell you.  If you actually know how to change a tire yourself and don't want to pay the additional $8 for them to do it for you (the ungodly wait is what usually causes me to give up and do it myself) they'll let you use their tools, but you can't do it in their cavernous showroom floor and they move you out onto the sidewalk.

Just last week I came in for a new tire since mine was getting bald--turns out the tire they sold me is not the right type (despite me bringing my bike into the store to make sure I got the right one) and caused two blowouts as I tried to inflate it/ride later.

Bottom line is that there are better places with better prices and better service.

Update: I came back with the tire that they sold me, showing it obviously didn't fit my bike and blew out my tube.  They refunded me after a few minutes of discussion with no real problems.  Upgraded to 3 stars, but I'm still not super impressed with this place.

A couple of weeks ago, I finally joined the smug, unshaven masses that rides a bike. Then I shaved my face. Now I just ride a bike.

I have been telling myself I needed a bike since 2006. I was either broke, or I would put it off, or whatever, I had a million excuses. This year, my tax return was fairly substantial because I got an education tax credit, and so I finally decided to get a bike. 

I went around to a couple shops, and decided to go with this one for two reasons: 1) it's closest to my work and 2) they didn't treat me like the know-nothing that I am when it came to picking out a bike. I was treated with a fair amount of respect and their emphasis was on picking a bike that was right for me. They had a nice selection of bikes and they told me to try them out. 

I ended up going a Jamis Coda Sport. I also bought a rack which has turned my bike into, as one of my friends quipped, the "station wagons of hybrids," and since I purchased it on the same day I got the 5-ride tune-up the install was free!

Thanks guys!

I've been using Trophy for all my cycling needs for well over a year now and purchased a second bike from them.  The mechanics are always accommodating and helpful, and they don't look down their noses at me whether I'm getting a flat fixed or resort to calling a bike part a "doohickie" or thingamajig."  Even when I've shown up 5 minutes from closing time in need of a repair, they've helped me out.   I also frequent the Trophy Bike Garage in NoLibs, which is closer to my place of work, and received equally good service there.  All around, thumbs up.

I recently had the pleasure of renting a bicycle from this store to FINALLY take ride the Schuylkill River trail from the Walnut Street Bridge all the way up to East Falls. The trip was great and I was very pleased with the customer service and the quality of the bicycle.

At first, I went with my friend to rent two bikes; however, at 2pm on a Sunday afternoon with the weather at 78 degrees with a light breeze I should've known better than to think there would be available bikes. The problem is, you can't reserve bikes; you can only call ahead to see if they have them. My friend ended up going home because of something that came up and I decided, "Hey, I'll take the one bike left and ride the trail myself."

For $25 for 24 hours, I rented a city-bike (wider tires, but slick like a road bike), a helmet, and a U-lock. The bike was in great condition. However, it is clear that I haven't ridden a bike in a while because it hurts to sit down right now.

You also have the option of renting the bike for 4 hours for $20... you can see that the 24 hour option is a better deal.

I've never used a bike in Philadelphia because I was always too afraid to be in the streets with the cars and buses. But, I will tell you after a few hours you're out there cutting across Market Street with a messenger bag slung across your back like everyone else. Granted, there are some very confusing streets where it was hard to figure out which direction the traffic was going. When you're on a bike, it's like walking as you don't really think about going against traffic.

When I returned the bicycle and walked home, I felt like I was in knee-high snow drifts as I was able to get so many places so quickly with the bike. Walking just felt slow.

I was working with Natalie (just moved here from Florida). She was very pleasant and helped me get up and running in no time.

I've heard many great things about Trophy, but I'm ONLY basing this review on my TWO flat tire experiences, each at approximately 8:30am on a weekday.

Not only was I attended to immediately and given an option of staying or leaving the bike (with time estimates for each), not only are the employees sweet and friendly and gracious... I could keep going here, but I'll stop.  The point is that my bike was fixed in less time than it takes to use the little girls' room and at a very reasonable cost!

Bike shops, ski shops, and auto mechanics often have customer-facing staff that aren't quite cut out for retail. I think that must be because they're optimized for being really good at working on bikes, skis, or cars. I can't say the guys here are any smilier or more coddling or more apologetic than the folks at Via, or Performance, or Bike Revolutions. I CAN say that McGet is a great member of the bike community. And that everyone I've talked to there has been friendly and decent. And that it's clean, and there's enough room to stand around comfortably and shop. And that even though I haven't bought more from them than a cheap bike light, they've let me test ride about five grand worth of bikes over the last year or so, and always with a smile and a few words of worthy advice. 

Local Bike Shop is Local Bike Shop, if you want sycophantic customer service then you gotta go to a chain.

I went in there expecting to get a particular folding bike, and not interested in listening to a sales pitch. But the owner was so helpful and informative that I ended up quickly realizing that the bike I needed was the Brompton. That was four years ago and I haven't regretted the decision.

This is one of those businesses that is run the way a business should be run - for the benefit of the customer.

Good prices for bikes & accessories.  A very good variety of accessories (lights, bells, etc).  One of the few/only??? places in/around Philly to sell Brompton folding bikes.  I do love the bromptons, though they are _NOT_ cheap, they are very high quality bikes from England.  They show you the basics when you buy it.  

A *minor* ding is that whomever is selling the bike should be mandatory to show the customer how to exactly take off & put back on that rear wheel!  But I did buy my Brompton several years ago, and have had many excellent rides with it.  

Very good & quick service (at least in the off-seasons).  I'm always (happily) surprised at how quick their turn-around is.

I recently sold my car and decided to join the single speed bike movement ( or is it a lifestyle choice?)  after seeking a lot of advice and asking around.

I talked with Brian and he was a  huge help and a very nice guy to boot. Talked with me about my options and did not push the sale too hard on me. After 3 weeks of deliberating on what to get I decided to take Brian's recommendation. A Jamis Beatnik for $600. It was more then I wanted to spend, but from everyone I asked it is a solid bike and decent price.

The shop is a little on the expensive shop but my overall experience to this point has been great.

Can't help but notice the repetitious complaints about prices here... Doesn't anyone believe in "pay for what you get"?

I can't say anything but nice things about Mike and the shop he runs. On multiple visits, he and the staff were very friendly and honest about the pros and cons of each bike I showed interest in. They didn't even mind answering the same amateur questions over and over to help me rest assured I was making a purchase that best fit me.

Today I asked my girlfriend to drop me off because I was certain I'd leave with a bike. And I did. After taking a spin around UCity, I started heading home when the air pump attached to my bike (I honestly didn't know it was there, how embarrassing!) fell off and into my back wheel while at about 7th and Market. Wtf? Grabbed a cab back to the shop expecting some hassle and potentially needing to leave it a day to have the breaks fixed up and the wheel realigned. Instead, Mike was thoroughly apologetic explained to me what happened and why. I told him I didn't even realize that there was a pump on there and that I'd probably never use it. He offered to pay me the difference of what the pump is worth. He also brought my bike over to his techs to have them readjust the breaks and true the wheel immediately. Five minutes later, I left with a perfectly good bike and $22 in my pocket.

The situation kind of sucked just for the sake of having to deal with it. Nevertheless, the service was spot on and I definitely recommend Trophy.

business.full_address:
2084 Frederick Douglass Blvd
Harlem
New York, NY 10026
business.name: Zoma

reviews.text: Zoma is the best Ethiopian place in NYC.  I would have given it 4-1/2 stars if half-stars were possible.  Do NOT mess around with Meskerem, Awash, or the oh-so-creatively named Ethiopian Restaurant. Go for the good stuff. Go to Zoma. The injera is so good, you would probably "injera" anyone who tried to take it from you. The tej (honey wine, for all you ill-informed philistines) is so good, you'll think you were in "Bill and Tej Excellent Adventure." The overall experience is so good, you'll feel like you're actually in Ethiopia, except unlike the real Ethiopia, people actually have food to eat! Ok, ok, calm down, I'm just kidding. We should be working together to end world hunger, not joking about it. In conclusion, Zoma gets a rating of "very legit," and anyone who disagrees with that assessment should be legally banned from writing restaurant reviews.  So the next time your friends suggest some other inferior Ethiopian place, the only thing to say to them is, "Not now chief - I'm in the f**king ZOMA!!!"

Two words quickly come to mind when I think of this place.  Cute and slow.  I came to Harlem to visit a dear friend from college and she loves this place so she took me to try it out for dinner the first night I was in town.

We walked in and there were two other parties.  We got seated and given menus/water quickly but that was the end of the road for the service route.  It took forever to order and I think our server switched like three times during the course of our meal.  It's not like we had anywhere we were running to in particular but  I thought New Yorkers were faced paced, I mean come on.  Anyways, after waiting an eternity to order, we shared the vegetarian combo; I'm not even going to pretend like I remember all the names of the dishes but I know that chickpeas, lentils, and potatoes were heavily involved. Honestly, I'm not sure if it was my expectations or the actual food but it was just okay.

Since I don't live in NY, I'll say I probably won't go again but it was a nice dinner.

A Michelin-rated restaurant in Harlem? No way? Way. This place was great, and the wine selection was awesome. I couldn't believe they had Ravenswood Zinfadel on the list, but a bottle of the good stuff was a great complement to our combo dinner. I don't think the check even broke $60, and Central Park isn't too far away for a post-dinner walk!

I love it because it's so quaint. The interior is small, but in a very comfortable/homey way. The lighting is on the romantic side. And the food... the food IS AWESOME. So lovely and smooth. And so rich in flavor.

Lucky lucky me to live so close to this gem of an eatery. Fantastic place to share a meal with friends or family.  I had not had Ethiopian cuisine before this place but have since in other establishments.  No one has yet compared to Zoma's flavors - bright, spiced perfectly, subtle richness. Great healthy sized portions too. Their service is always  friendly and the waitstaff is happy to recommend dishes suited to your cravings.  Upscale decor with reasonably priced meals and cocktails. Go to ZOMA!!!

The lamb is delicious here.  The portions might seem small but then you just keep eating and eating the injera fills you up quickly.  Try a glass of honey wine.  The honey tastes very subtle but it's perfect.  Also, the kategna appetizer was delicious.  Basically it's toasted/fried injera with spices.  A bit greasy  but it will wake up your taste buds.  This places gets super crowded so try to call ahead for reservations.

My only complaint is that I wish their spicy dishes would be even spicier!

I like Ethiopian food, largely because it's spicy enough to penetrate my dead smoker's tastebuds. But I have a shameful secret about eating at Zoma: The whole time, I just wanted a damn fork. 

Homo habilis started using tools like 50,000 years ago specifically to avoid getting woolly mammoth juice on his nice velociraptor pelt or whatever (I'm not a trained paleontologist). So why do this homo gotta use bread to pick up unwieldy chunks of meat sauce? Zoma is a yummy mess. Probably not good for a first date unless you're into some kinky shit.

P.S. You have to order the honey wine. It's a perfectly sweet balance to the spicy food.
If you have ever wanted to try Ethiopian cuisine, then this is the place to do it. Get ready to share, as all the dishes are served family style.

I never realized how great Ethiopian food was.

It seems the ingredients in Ethiopian food are very similar to the stuff used in South Asian cooking.  Either way, its all very good.  The wait staff and bartender are all very cool and nice people.  If you're in the mood for "something different" this is the perfect place to go.  Good food, good atmosphere and a unique dining experience.

Zoma presents a somber escape from the street, although the ebony hued bar, back-lit liquor shelves, stone tiles and vast candle-lit white walls strike one initially as somewhat incongruous, more like a bar in a posh boutique hotel than a local family res
Had a delicous meal here. The B combition is very filling as well as the appetizers.    The only drag was the spicy crepe/pancake, it was very greasy. Overall this is a great restuarant.

For the honey tej wine, this places gets 5 stars. The food is good, but I felt that their tibs wett was average. And why was the injera cold? I expected more for the hype that Zoma received.

That said, I'll probably come back with friends, as I do feel that the place is a great intro into Ethiopian food. Will update more later when I go back.

Is it wrong that the cuisine of a country where so many people are starving tastes so delicious?

Had a great experience here with a couple of girl friends. I think it would also be great for a date - and a good test to see if they're down enough to eat with their hands.

The honey wine was excellent - a real wake up on the taste buds. The various dishes on the vegetarian platter are all flavorful and have distinct tastes.

Note - the atmosphere is upscale, but the prices are very reasonable.
Sooooooooo good. I dream about their veggie plate. Cash only though. Who has cash on them ever in NYC?

Psycho-zoma-tic Ethiopian Cuisine in Harlem's Arsenal of New Restaurants...

The Locale:
It's funny how I ended up dining here. I was actually meeting the venerable Maria M. at Melba's. My brother and I got there about 15 mins early and it turned out Melba's was closed for a private party. Taking advantage that we were early I began to scout other places I knew about around the block. There's Billie's Black about 5 blocks up but there was also Zoma a block down. I headed to Zoma to do some reconnaissance. It looked fitting for "El Mayimbe" and his guests. When Maria arrived at the meeting spot we all walked over to Zoma. First thing you'll notice is the simplicity of the dcor; the walls in soft pastels with very minimal decorations. This is indeed the soma-like quality of the place. It just eases you into the experience. The bar area was beautifully illuminated. Place really began to fill after 9pm.

The Food:
My first foray into ethiopian eats. We ordered a couple signature drinks. My brother ordered a Harlem Raging Bull ((Red Bull, tequila, vodka and lime) and I had the Blue Nile (Henessy and pure goodness). I personally felt mine was better. Plus, given the spicy-ness of what was to come, the sweetness of the drink made for a perfect marriage in gustatory heaven! Started off with toasted injera to give our taste buds a warm-up. We tried to cover all the basic meat groups. I had the lamb-based Yebeg Alitcha, my bro the beef-based Tibs Wett, and miss Maria the chicken-based Doro Wett. It was all served on a giant white platter on top of a big piece of injera. On the side, elegantly rolled pieces of injera to scoop the food with. Ah, the freedom of eating with just your hands. No dilution of pleasure with utensils! I cannot tell you how generous the portions were. And just when I thought I was out of injera, in came our waitress (almost psychic-like) with a fresh round of the good stuff. The chicken, lamb, and beef were all cooked to perfection. BAM-esque flavor! The only thing is that since the beef and chicken use the same seasonings (berbere) it can seem a bit redundant in terms of flavor. The lamb took care of that! We couldn't finish the entire meal.

The Service:
Top notch. Our waitresses had infectious smiles. They were quite personable never shying away from innocent, flirtatious banter but instead offering smart comebacks. I appreciate humor. Prices were quite comfortable.
Good food & thoughtful wait staff.

Came here when I met my new roommates and it was awesome!

It was a bit of a hike so we decided to drive.  We found out that it was worth it even if had taken the subway.

We ordered their both their combo platters which comes on a big circular sour bread plate.  You eat with your hands and the food definitely has a lot of spices and kind of similar to Bengal and Tamil Indian food.

The sour bread gets a little bit of getting used to but trust me its not that difficult!

I love the food and the vibe here.  It's always the busiest restaurant in the neighborhood.  The food is amazing and totally reasonably priced.  The vegetarian platter for two is like 18 bucks.  Get the Shiro Wett.  Their meat stuff is good too.

The service is kind of weird.  They are really attentive in some ways (warm washcloths at the beginning, and they usually bring more injera before you even have to ask for it), but grossly inattentive in others (they rarely refill water and you always have to flag them down if you need anything, including the check).  Also, they don't take credit cards anymore, which is weird because I swear they used to.

That being said, it's probably the best Ethiopian food I've had in New York and I'm lucky enough to live two blocks away!

I haven't had Ethiopian food in a couple of years, and after Zoma reminded me how good it can be, I've resolved to seek it out on the regular. This candelit spot on the corner is simple but inviting, and the food is delicious. Three of us split the vegetarian platter, the steak tibs, and one of the chicken dishes, and between those three plates I think we were served every vegetable known to man (the meat dishes also come with 2 vegetable sides). This was more than enough food, but we'd order the same again, because the different meats and sauces are all worth sampling. The injera was perfect, and each dish had a unique flavor. Plus, they have a decent wine selection, and Franziskaner on tap.

Note: they take Amex (that or cash)

Friends from Michigan, needed a late-ish spot, and i was between Zoma, Native and one other I can't recall. None of us had tried Zoma, so there we had it. Lovely atmosphere, excellent Ethiopian food (nothing like Indian food, as one reviewer stated, except that food in many Brown countries tends to be based around stew-like dishes - ). I would highly recommend Zoma, were it not for two things: First, our adorable, sweet server was suddenly replaced with another server at the completion of the meal; and, second, we had ordered a bottle of wine, which she poured from, and with at least a quartino left in the bottle, TOOK IT AWAY! Worse than that, she claimed it was empty, but none of us were either drunk, nor first timers on the wine, nor restaurant etiquette front. VERY UNACCEPTABLE, and we felt it was a way of pushing us out the door, as we were among the last parties there. I seriously can't grade them any higher because of that. I'm not fighting over the wine, but you shouldn't STEAL it, either! We still way over tipped - more than 30%, but had it simply been me and some local friends - that may not have gone over so rewardingly for them. Too bad, the management really shouldn't encourage or allow that!

i used to live in d.c. i've been to 8 ethiopian restaurants. all of them blow...and zoma was the one that blew my mind. temporarily. i've read reviews that say zoma isn't authentic--why? because the fare is actually palatable? well-balanced? well-spiced? 

at every other ethiopian restaurant i've been to the food has been bland, of inferior quality. after a meal at zoma my ass is happily whistling away spice, not expired beef. 

TIP: if you order the kitfo for dine-in, FINISH IT. they will not allow you to take it home. if you carry out, the leftovers fry up nicely.

i'm positive zoma opened in february of 2007; i moved two blocks away then and, boy, was this comfort food in knee-deep slush.

for obvious reasons: i had a barking-mad roommate with--get this--i shit you not: an equally manipulative dog. that dog needs an ole yeller done.

and previously obvious reasons: the FOOD! any dream about food is about zoma. now it's worth two stars and the service is still amazing, but there is no excuse for any restaurant to lower its standards so i'm not sure i have that many visits left in me. i don't wanna cry.

here's what happened: groupon. (read that article?) or the economy. they cheat. i was such a loyal customer i'd come both alone and with friends, have brought in quite a few new customers and even converted my mother into an ethiopian-lover. there was tiramisu on birthdays and much love between me and the waitstaff.
