i got into FIT so now i'm scrimping, saving, pinching and penniless. i bought three groupons to up this year's visits to five. i just brought my friend and her husband here for her birthday. they were thrilled; they may be back. i was appalled. the portions are tiny and the quality like a ponderosa steakhouse. if i'd been alone i'd have excused myself the second the food was brought out. without paying.

the kategna (fried injera imbued with mitmita) now comes with the flavorless but awesomely cool cheese they serve with the kitfo; it must cool shocked palates. it sure makes love to mine. it's still a 5.

the lamb has always been disgusting. it's invariably 75% bone, 20% fat and 5% meat and sauce.

the whole fish was amazing and tender. my family still drools. it's been replaced by equally flavorful but wholly unexciting fried tilapia fillets. they've appeased patrons by bringing out two fillets because it's $22 and they didn't wanna reprint the menu but i'm actually embarrassed for them. if you're replacing a whole fried fish with fillets you're in the hole.

the beef for the kitfo used to be buttery. the last two times i've ordered kitfo i could only eat 2/3 of the meat; the other 1/3 was gristle, fat and just plain chewed to death but unswallowable. their kitfo was actually preferable to sushi, and sushi is my #1. again. 

the beef for the cooked dishes was similarly tender. again, the quality suffers. it's tough, portions are much smaller (as are the sides--they make up for it by adding a tomato-onion salad that does nothing but PISS ME THE FUCK OFF. cutting corners EVERY WHICH WAY is not what made m.c. escher famous; it was how elaborate they were!) and the meat is cut so badly that there's a lot of fat and gristle.

the chicken dish--if i'm with friends i always order the meat combo that doesn't include the lamb, so i don't remember the name of that dish--oh, my god! i hated bone-in chicken before i tried this fucking tiny drumstick i hated sharing with friends because i wanted it all for myself. it was tender, juicy, flavorful and powerfully meaty for something so tiny.

now...oh, wait, is that a chorus i hear? fatty, flavorless, stringy. much bigger but in no way better, just badder. i never did like the accompanying hard-boiled egg and shrink in horror as my comrades wave the green-grey yolk at me.  this amuses them to no end and they even look forward to this part of the meal, just waiting to sneak it up on me. urrrrgh-blech!

the vegetable sides--they didn't let me choose last time. zoma gets a big fat fuck-you for that. used to be we'd get three huge piles of whatever i chose. 

back to apps: there's a delicious lentil-filled endive-cup appetizer! love! but undercooked lentils are actually hard on your system and induce more gas...so...not on a date. you don't wanna fake a charlie's horse during midnight sex. if it happens to you, my gay friend's tip: go into the bathroom, no matter whose it is. take the towel off the rack,  no matter whose it is. naked to the shins or toes, get on all fours, wad the towel between your knees and ass, then lower yourself to your shoulders. let 'er rip, muffled.

now, i can understand making some portions smaller if money is an issue. this is just undermining yourself, zoma.

i have one more groupon but am hesitant to use it on my birthday as planned. to cut corners is unforgivable. the quality was top-notch. i hope you at zoma are reading this; i want my true love back.

srsly. then i can update this with 5 stars and delirium.

Michellin rated? Eh...like just barely maybe.

I'm a really big Ethiopian food snob and I think that Ghenet in Brooklyn has really thrown down not only the taste, but also the value gauntlet in terms of Ethiopian in the city.

The service is always a bit iffy here, the food, about half of it is really not great and the other half is workable. I wish I could say I liked it more, but at the end of the day I really just don't.

The green lamb dish looked like puke and the lamb was fused to bones that I was unable to enjoy. All of the stews they serve that don't have chunks of meat in them (but have it ground into the stew itself) are good, and the chicken dish that comes with the leg and the egg was decent.

The injera was bland and unimpressive. I've been twice, and both times I left remembering why I love Ethiopian food, but why I probably shouldn't come back here.

They get two stars from me, but I'm throwing an extra star in for at least being an option for Ethiopian food, as there are only about 6 in the city and 4 of them are terrible (SPOILER ALERT: Bati and Ghenet in brooklyn are better than any of the ones in Manhattan).

Seemed a little hipsterish, but was still tasty as far as I can tell. I'm not an exceptional connoisseur of Ethiopian food, however, so I have no clue, if you're looking for authentic. But the honey wine and vegetarian entrees we picked were tasty and satisfying. By hipsterish I mean the atmosphere was very hip and cool, not terribly traditional at all. Service was very amenable and professional.

Despite the fact that I'm a white girl from Arizona, Ethiopian food is total comfort food for me. 

This is because the sometimes-vegan hippie who raised me took me to this one Ethiopian restaurant in Phoenix basically two times a week from the time I was born. Misir wat is to me what "Mom's macaroni/meatloaf/whatever" is to some people. 

So, two years ago when my boyfriend and I decided to go back to Africa for a post-grad school trip, I was all like, "Uhhh, we're going to Ethiopia, obvi!" So off we went. It was amazing. It also required us to eat nothing but shiro wat for a month, at which point we learned a lot about 1) shiro wat, and 2) whether shiro wat is something you want to eat twice a day for a month (it isn't). 

I'm telling you all this to earn credibility for what I'm going to say next: Zoma has some damn good food.

We've tried the misir wat, doro wat, shiro wat, gomen, assa tibs, and atakilt wat. All of the vegetables dishes were impressively good, but I especially loved the misir wat which was nice and spicy and reminded me of the stuff I grew up on back in Phoenix. The low points of the meal were the injera, which wasn't quite as soft and sour-tasting as I like, and the assa tibs, which was kind of boring.

I'm still recovering from the ridiculous shiro overload of 2009, so I probably won't order that dish again anytime soon, but other than that I'll definitely head back to Zoma when I'm in the mood for Ethiopian food. (To be honest, I'll probably just end up getting ten freaking orders of misir wat. I really love that stuff.)

We keep coming back to Zoma.  It is truly terrific. The dishes are flavorful and generous if you order them individually.  Combination platters are not as generous as the individual orders. So the few times we had the combination platter (veg) I had a feeling we did not have enough food.  Ordering them individually you get more than plenty. 

We'll be back. It's the best in NYC, and I would venture also on the East Coast.

Bring cash, unless you have AmEx.

Zoma is a sexy, romantic restaurant. From the sleek, modern decor focusing on details (even the bathrooms contain well-thought out designed) to the sensual experience of eating with your hands (lol I sound like I'm writing smut..) Zoma keeps it sexy.

The food was damn tasty too. We ordered a vegetarian and a meat sampler for 3 people and had more than enough food. My favorite dish was the aromatic tibs wett (best I've had in the city). 

I was so jealous that the table next to us was friends with the owner and she kept bringing out dish after dish. I need to somehow become her friend for the same treatment...

One place comes to mind when I am in the mood for Ethiopian food, Zoma. Located right off of Frederick Douglass Blvd in Harlem, Zoma brings the essence of authentic Ethiopian food in an updated, yet inviting atmosphere. I frequent this place so often that I have become friends with the owner, Henock. He is always so gracious and very accommodating. Not only is Zoma a great addition to the neighborhood, but Henock is also a supporter of the local restaurants and bars in the area as well. He wants the local businesses to do well, which in turn keeps the neighborhood thriving.

With so much to choose from on the menu, I always stick with the combination platters which serves two people. The platters consist of the vegetarian combination and the Zoma combination. But if you ask the waitress she will customize the platter to your liking. For example, if you are not a fan of spicy food then you can substitute another dish.  One of my favorite dishes is the Gomen Be Siga, fresh collard greens simmered with sauteed beef, onions, green peppers and spices in a mild sauce. A spicy favorite is the Tibs Wett strips of sirloin simmered in a spiced stew with berbere, kibe, garlic, cardamom, coriander, and other herbs and spices. The vegetarian dishes are absolutely flavorful as well. The Atakilt Wett consist of fresh carrots, potatoes, cabbage and onions, sauteed with garlic, ginger and tomatoes in a mild sauce. The Shiro Wett is Ethiopian comfort food and is made up of chickpeas, lentils and peas roasted, powdered and cooked in a berbere sauce with a multitude of spices. These are just a few of many amazing options to choose from at Zoma. But the main staple that ties all these dishes together is the injera. Injera is a flat bread with a unique, slightly spongy texture. The injera acts as the eating utensil, the food, and the plate soaking up the flavors of the food.

The atmosphere is serene and the decor is subtle, but the main draw of Zoma is the food. The ingredients are fresh and the spices are sharp in flavor. Zoma is a real treat for anyone looking for an all around amazing dining experience. Don't expect anything less than authenticity at this Ethiopian mecca.

I *heart* Zoma.  One of my favorite places to go and show off to out of townees.  The best thing about this place is the clean decor and the intimacy effect while dining.  You should be prepared to pay a bit of a higher price while dining here but it's worth it if you have the extra to spend (that fancy decor costs money ya know).  Service is always on point and honestly considering the options in the neighborhood it is a welcome addition.  Harlem needs diversity when it comes to the cuisine category and this restaurant delivers.

NOTE: This is Ethiopian food.  You will eat with your hands.  That is all.

Ok, I 'm going to keep this short and to the point.  This place is no joke. If you're in Harlem for dinner or not you should get your you know what to Zoma.  The food is delicious, thinking about it makes my mouth water. I've been here a few time already

Went for lunch on Sunday afternoon, and the server and food were a bit cold. Nicely if minimally styled decor, which I'm sure benefits from a full room of sexy people at night. Shared the vegetarian plate for two, for the low price of $17, and liked it, but it wasn't making my taste-buds sing. And it wasn't piping hot. I kinda wondered if there was a steam table in the back. (ouch.) No honey for my hot tea either :( The server was on her phone for easily half an hour while we ate and then had to get up to ask for our check. 

I'll go again at night and see if they benefit from a busier scene, as I do love this style of food, but for my next lunch I'm heading to Society a few blocks away. As I walked to Zoma I passed Society and wondered why it was so packed compared to it's neighbor, and now I know. 

Full disclosure: The visit yelped in this review happened under the influence of a relatively awkward first date. It wasn't bad really, but still I feel the need to throw it out there that the vibes of somewhat uninspired conversation might have spilled over into the overall experience.

Zoma was my first Ethiopian food experience and it didn't disappoint. We took sambusa (pastry filled with ground sirloin or lentils) as an appetizer, which was good, but nothing special. As entrees, the four of us ordered the two Zoma's meat combinations,

I really wanted to like this place more but...with all due respect to the positive reviews this is decent Ethiopian food at best. Extra points for the really cool staff and their own beer which was fantastic. 

Had chicken, beef and lots of veggies and they were all just, frankly, ok. I'm bummed because I wanted to get a good Ethiopian place in the city but it appears that my search will continue.

Respectively new to the NYC area, I decided it was finally time for me to try out some local Ethiopian food - since I am both Ethiopian and from DC (the highest populated Ethiopian city outside of Addis Abeba).

Walking in, I noticed that  the usual overwhelming smell of spices that hits you like walking into an Indian lunch buffet was not present - a big plus for me as I hate leaving restaurants smelling like food.  Once seated I noticed the decor was a very contemporary style with hints of Ethiopia's art and culture - another plus as it was refreshing to see an Ethiopian restaurant breakout of the typical, I like to call, "Ethiopian Wedding Decor".

Now comes the food.

God awful and worst Ethiopian food I have ever had.  Now I'm not being picky just because I am Ethiopian, there are plenty of restaurants I have tried in the DC area and none even come close to being this bad.  Even my dad who has just recently attempted to cook Ethiopian food made way better food than this place.  The sambusa was the only some what pleasing part of the night.  The shiro, kik, and kay wet were all off in taste; completely unfamiliar to me.  Worst of all was the Tibs.  It was as though someone threw together chucks of meat and just cooked it along side tomatoes, peppers, and onions.  It was a glorified steak fajita you could get off Chili's menu.  Where were the spices?  Where was that distinctive Ethiopian taste.  My guess in the matter is that they don't cook any of their food using Ethiopian butter, but substitute it for plain oil.  Ethiopian butter is a specially fermented butter and contains that purely Ethiopian food smell/taste.

I would never go back, and I hope those of you out there reading this consider finding another Ethiopian restaurant to frequent.

Maybe I'm just not a big Ethiopian food fan; this is my first time. For one thing, I'm a big fan of the fork. And I know they do have them at this restaurant because they brought it out for the baklava, which was, coincidentally or not, the highlight of the meal.

I didn't really eat the veggie plate, just the meat one. And while it was good, it was nothing special, and I found myself craving solidity, something to sink my teeth into. Don't get me wrong - it was pretty good. It just didn't really do it for me.

Service is good! Restaurant is a bit overpriced... and they claim to accept American Express, which is clearly a lie as everytime I've been there the machine is broken... They used AMex to get a free commercial and now don't accept the cards... Food is okay- typical Ethiopian cuisine.
Food is mediocre and doesn't make up for the HORRIBLE service. Go to Awash, you'll have a much better experience there.

i went here once before because of the recommendation from marcus samuelsson and, while the service wasn't particularly good, the food was reasonably good, so when my girl's mom wanted ethiopian tonight, i decided to give it another go (my first mistake).

when i called to make a reservation,  i was told by the woman on the line that i didn't need one and could simply walk in despite the fact that it was a weekend night. i believed her (my second mistake).

later, when we arrived at the restaurant, i realized that the woman i had spoken with was a liar, engaging in utter malfeasance. they apparently do not take reservations on weekends.  why she couldn't simply have told me the truth, i don't know. other parties seemed equally miffed by the poor management of the door.

finally, we sat down excited about ordering some tasty food (a third mistake). we ordered one veggie combo and one meat combo B (fourth mistake). the waitress didn't write down our order, so i guess that i'm not surprised that the veggie combo didn't contain what my girlfriend asked for. but, the  meat combo platter was the worst. it was inedible because 1. the lamb was, as others have noted, simply little jagged pieces of bone  that were dangerous to pick up with your hand to put in your mouth, 2. the chicken was rancid and 3. the beef dish was lacking beef.

receiving food of such poor quality really was astonishing to us, especially considering that this place was recommended by a celebrity chef.  so, we decided to comment as such to the waitress, when we finally were able to flag her down (fifth mistake).

what we were subjected to at that point was totally inconceivable.  now, i might put forth that i've been eating chicken for 30 some odd years and so you might be inclined to believe that i do in fact know the difference between chicken that is good and that which tastes spoiled. the waitress, on the other hand, berated me, my taste buds, and defended this spoiled chicken.  she disregarded any criticism of the quantity of shards of bones in the lamb dish. and, she simply didn't bother to acknowledge my concerns about the amount of beef in the beef dish. not even a simple apology!

a second waitress came by a bit later and, when my mild mannered girl's very proper and polite mother described the food to her as terrible, we were once again denigrated without as much as a simple "i'm sorry".

i honestly don't think i've ever had such a terrible dining experience.

Really enjoyed the food but the service was really bad. I would suggest the manager to employ more waitresses at least for dinner hours. The girls were just overwhelmed with work and with such good food, I would have loved the place more if the service was better.
We went with an Ethiopian friend and ordered 2 combos, one vegetarian and one non. For the veg platter we got shiro wett, misir wett, gomen and atakilt wett. The shiro and misir were really delicious, just perfectly seasoned. The texture was also excellent. Sometimes restaurants make them too chunky. For the non-veg options, we got doro wett, yebeg alitcha, lentils and one more dish. The doro wett and yebeg alitcha were delicious too. My favorite were shiro and misir though....so good!
The service was another story, they took forever to take the order, no one was interested to check if we had water or wanted anything. Really they left us to our own devices. The girls were not rude but just soooo inattentive.
I would definitely try again but if the service is as disappointing the next time, I would continue my search for my go-to Ethiopian restaurant in New York.

I am hesitant to review this place because it is not that crowded and I want to keep others far far away.  However, it is amazing.  The best value around.  Incredible food that has been carefully prepared.  The staff is laid back and friendly.  I have probably been to Zoma 15 times.  Every time we have a date my husband wants to go there.  Anything with berebere sauce is the best, especially Tibbs Wett.  Honey wine is a nice tough.  Go there with someone you love or like to eat spicy food with, get a combo and a bottle of wine and have one of the best dinners of your life for about 35 dollars each including tip.  BTW, not all food is spicy, so read the menu carefully if you are a wimp.
Yummy. Felt like i was back in Ethiopia... Actually have never been but i imagine the food is very good based off this place.
Love the honey wine and the food is amazing! Go all the time.

The food is acceptable and the wait staff helpful (even if the owner is always trying to upsell) but the prices are absurd.  A 25% reduction would be in line with the quality and make the experience significantly better.  The bland, unimaginative appetizers need not just repricing but a complete rethink.  

The room is pretty sterile, but that's not a bad contrast to the usual Ethiopian restaurant and the spicy, colorful food.  Accepts only AMEX, which seems very 1980s and underlines pretensions to being upscale.  

The many empty tables and frequent unavailability of menu items makes me wonder if Zoma's days are numbered.  I'd rather see them make some adjustments and become the interesting option for this cuisine that they could be.

This is one of my favorite neighborhood restaurants -  The food always gets 4.5-5 stars, but the service brings it down probably to about 3 stars.

I've been here several times,and the food does not disappoint - I love the combo platters - they are perfect for sharing in groups!  There are 4 different choices of platters, depending if you want vegetarian or meat, and then spicy or hot.  Each platter contains 4 portions of food - 2 vegetables and 2 meats.  One platter can easily feed 2-3 people.

The service here is not the greatest.  I can't ever say I've had a "great" experience.  It usually ranges from "just ok" to horrible.  I've spoken to the manager (he's also usually the bartender) about it during one particularly bad visit, and he didn't seem too concerned or apologize, but did take our drinks off the ticket.

Zoma = VERY tasty morsels!

And by morsels I mean any yummy veggie or meat you want mixed in with delectably spiced sauces all on a huge platter with that damn injera bread you can't stop eating. All our dishes - meat and veggie - were excellent as was the refreshingly not-too-sweet honey wine! Okay, granted it was my first bonafide adventure into Ethopian cuisine, but the fresh meat and veggies did not go unnoticed! Service was very slow at first, and at times we thought they forgout about our table, but it picked up in the end... maybe cause we ended up closing the place down that night. Prices were also very reasonable. 

Zoma may signal gentrification, but the fresh flavors are most definitely worth trekking the city for.  I'll be coming back on my next jaunt to Harlem.

I preface this with the fact that I am by no means an expert on Ethiopian cuisine.  I found this restaurant to be clean and the decor to be inviting.  The Zoma tibs were quite good - I would recommend that dish.  The only thing I would say is the service was not that good.  There were several times where the waitress disappeared or was inattentive.  Overall, I thought it was a good experience and would go back.

The neighborhood restaurant you wish you had.  I could eat the Misir Wett (red split lentils) daily, and get it every time.  Excellent platters for two.  All-white late modern, yet soft, decor.  Priced right.

Slightly fancier than the usual Ethopian joints I have been to in the past. Dim lighting and modern furniture makes this a swanky place to visit. The combo platter I ordered with my dining companion offered a variety of choices and plenty of injera to mop it all up with. There was a nice mixture of different spices and textures highlighted throughout the different dishes, and everything tasted yummy. Watch out for small bones in the meat components; test before chomping down!

Zoma is a new Ethiopian restaurant that was reviewed in the Times in early January. When I lived in Chicago, I used to love going to a place called Mama Desta's with friends. I haven't eaten Ethiopian in ages, so when I read the review, I knew I needed to go with a bunch of friends.

Saturday night, C. and I went out for dinner with Rick, Shannon, and another friend. We arrived at 6 p.m., and even though we didn't have a reservation, they seated us, placing several tables together. Rick and Shannon thought the honey wine was too sweet, but the food -- all served on the traditional injera -- was awesome.

For the five of us, we ordered three combination platters -- two vegetarian platters, so we could sample all the options, and a meat platter featuring chicken and lamb. The platters are supposed to serve two, but three were enough for five. Amazingly delicious food.

When we were finished, I wanted a coffee, but the place had gotten crowded, and because we didn't have a reservation, they hustled us out. I felt a little put out, but in the end, decided that it was fair -- they'd done great seating us in the first place.

Recommended. But with a reservation if you want coffee.

Great service, great ethiopian honey wine, great atmosphere, and fantastic food.

Great for groups - get the combinations, they bring plenty of extra injera bread for you, just ask!.

I really think Zoma has the best Ethiopian food in New York City. I've been to Meskerem, Awash, and a couple other places that I can't even remember the name, and Zoma is infinitely better in terms of food. We come here whenever Ethiopian food craving hits us. Order a vegetarian combination and a meat entree or two and that'll be enough food for 3-4 people. My favorite meat entrees are doro wat (spicy chicken) and yebeg alitcha (lamb.) My only gripe is that they don't take credit cards. I hope that changes soon.

My second experience eating Ethiopian food was at Zoma.  Located in a quiet area of Harlem, the interior was very sleek and looked like it might be a lounge or chic restaurant in more southern parts of Manhattan.  

Service was okay.  There weren't that m

I absolutely LOVE ZOMA. If YOU want authentic Ethiopian food THIS is the place!!! The food is always prepared fresh, excellent service and for a GREAT price!!! Whether you are a vegetarian or meat lover you can find something to satisfy your palate here...it is a true Harlem staple!!

Awesome Ethiopian experience!  My fiancee and I went here for a late dinner expecting a hole in the wall. What we got was a romantic candle-lit dinner in a classy yet authentic atmosphere. We shared the  Dorra Weet combination dinner- which you eat with your hands- very intimate and a good date idea. I washed it down with a Zoma beer, which I highly recommend to people who enjoy a full body beer. We also tried the Ethiopian Honey Wine- i recommend it only if you enjoy very sweet wines, as this was as sweet as it gets.

I just got back from Ethiopia, where I completely FELL IN LOVE with the food, so of course the first thing I did when I got home was try and find the best Ethiopian restaurant in the tri-state area.  So I journeyed on up to Harlem to give Zoma a try.

The

Had the less spicy chicken stew dish with collards and red lentils. Collards and red lentils were DELICIOUS. not enough actual pieces of chicken (we had 2 small pieces) in the actual dish, but it was still good. Will def be coming back. Love all the white in the restaurant, and the subtle what I presume are Ethiopian touches. Don't go on a first date though--you eat everything with your hands and their special bread so it can get a little messy. It'd be awkward if you weren't close w/ your date.

Finally checked out Zoma last night, thanks to GroupOn inspiration, and had a really nice meal! The menu may look pricey at first, but one platter (especially one of the Zoma platters which combine meat and veggie options), is enough to feed two people and comes to less than $30 total. I just love the idea of eating with my hands in an upscale establishment; there's something hysterically and coolly ironic about it, while stlil feeling like you're getting a real taste (heh) of another culture. Especially since they serve you moist towelettes in a little bowl to make you feel especially pristine. 

I recommend making sure that no matter what you order, you order some steak and some lamb. Both are phenomenally tender at Zoma, and served up with some truly delicious mushy goodness to soak up with your spongy Injera (Ethiopian bread). Their vegetarian options are also delicious and healthy to boot. But if you think you get stuffed on bread at Italian restaurants, you've got another thing coming at Zoma, where bread is both your side-dish and your eating utensil, and this leads you to get full a lot faster than you would think. 

As the other Yelpers have indicated, the Honey Wine is an absolute must-get; it's crisp without being too heavy (unlike mead), and delectably sweet. 

I'll definitely be coming back, even without a GroupOn!

Gomen (collard greens), Misir Wett (red split lentils), Buticha (pureed chickpeas) were all delicious. 

I can't wait to go back the next time I'm in the city. After reading all the reviews with less than four stars for ethiopian food in manhattan, I chose Zoma. The environment and mood was comfortable and artful, and so I had to give this a 5 star rating.

Not bad.  A bit messy if you aren't used to eating in the Ethiopian way.  An example of what an ethnic restaurant in this section of Harlem should be.  Clean nice vibe, mixed crowd, nice bar, and tasty food!

I'll admit, I'm fairly new to Ethiopian cuisine.  In fact, I really didn't know what to expect when we decided to brave the rainy night and try nearby Zoma for dinner yesterday (a Wednesday).  Apparently we weren't the only ones, because when we arrived (around 7:45), Zoma was already buzzing and, by the time we left (around 10:30), it was packed.  Despite the crowd, we never felt as if we were being rushed or hurried out to make room for more business (we lingered nearly 3 hours!).  The decor is simple and modern, though the small space is dominated by a full-sized bar which extends across one wall.  

I was grateful, though, that Zoma's modern style did not extend into the cuisine (the lack of utensils on the table was an early clue).  The food arrives in traditional Ethiopian fashion, laid out on injera--a large, thin sourdough flatbread used to pick up bites of the Ethiopian stews.  My misir wett, a thick red lentil stew, was poured on one corner of the injera, while my friend's entree (the potato-and-carrot-based atakilt wett) was on the opposite corner.  The remaining corners held our vegetable sides.  While none of the dishes were initially striking, they were surprisingly addicting.  The misir wett was smoky and complex, flavored with garlic, ginger and berbere (a peppery Ethiopian spice mix).  And just as we'd run out of injera, our server appeared with a heaping tray of seconds.  

In all, we really enjoyed Zoma: it was ethnic without the kitsch, the service was friendly, the food was good (and not too heavy), and the atmosphere was perfect for catching up with friends.  I also found myself craving leftovers late into the evening.

*Note: Cash or American Express only.

The best Ethiopian food I've had in the city! 

They start you off with a warm towel to clean your hands ahead of your appetizer. I was a little disappointed that I did not get the wet towel treatment afterwards when my hands were couted with the spongey item.  

Their drinks are nice and strong. I was getting a little too used to watered down drinks.

The food was good although the service was lacking. The place was basically empty but I had to gester to get attention.

Very nice, though not extraordinary Ethiopian. The flavors were good, but didn't sing to me or make me smile the way I have in other places and times. The place is nice, friendly, with a cool aesthetic and relaxed attractive vibe. Prices were okay, not cheap (but what is now?)

They don't accept credit cards -- cash only.

Absolutely the BEST Ethiopian with actual flavor unlike the rest.  Reservations are good for Fridays and Saturdays, but walk-ins are welcome.  The place has a good environment, great service, all for a reasonable price.  It is a GEM in Harlem, literally.  There you find two waitresses  and the owner/manager.  Sometimes it has taken a while, but you can wait a little bit for some good food.  I recommend it wholeheartedly!
Food is very good and atmosphere is great, but the service is horrible. Even when packed, every other table was served besides ours
This is a good neighborhood spot, the owner is a very nice man and the food is AMAZING!  The Gomen (vegetarian collard greens) is my absolute favorite, you must try it.

I have been eating plenty of Ethiopian food in the past month, and I am surely not complaining. I could eat it every day. 

There is nothing like some tej and breaking injera with good friends. Good food, good conversation, beautiful and smart people. I couldn't have asked for better friends, or...better food. 

Zoma has a nice sleek interior with a beautiful mirror at the bar. The walls are white-washed and the decor was not like most of the other Ethiopian places in the city. It was trendy, romantic and lacked the "Addis Ababa" stamp. It was kind of nice to see the difference.

We, of course, started off the meal with a bottle of tej. Tej is Ethiopian honey wine. If you don't like sweet wines, you probably won't understand tej. And normally, I like dry whites, but when you have spicy and pungent Ethiopian dishes, the sweet tej washes it down nicely. 

My friend and I shared the veggie combo which came with 4 veggies of your choice. We opted for the lentils, cabbage, carrots and collard greens. I am not a big legume fan, but man the lentil berbere style blew me away. I couldn't stop eating it. In fact, we had to get more injera since we killed our initial batch. Unlike most places, they were not stingy with their injera. In fact, they gave us too much. That has never happened. 

The food was excellent here and the portion-sizes were large. I was pretty full after leaving this place. My first trip to Harlem was a successful one. I am sure to come back and explore the neighborhood. 

Thanks Zoma for making our evening out so memorable!

This is my favorite place to eat when I am starving for comfort food. Yum!!! Their vegetarian platter is a really good deal to share for 2 and it is so delish omg, the green beans are to die for- as is the timatim fitfit tomato and injeera salad. The only problem is I often find myself too full after a meal, because I just can't stop eating! I'm so glad I found this place.

We went here after trying to find a good Senegalese place (which we didn't) and Yelp's iPhone app suggested this place.

We liked the ambience the moment we entered, and the staff was nice too. The bartender offered me a taste of the cherry whisky I was curious about, which is always appreciated. 

The food was good, but nothing to write home about. The wife and I had the veggie combo, as we always do, and it was just good enough. We really like our Ethiopian food, and this place was good, but not great. 

Considering the ambience and the staff, we really wanted to like this place better, and it's really not bad at all, but Awash's food is just so much better that their lack of ambience doesn't matter...

It says something that I first ate here two years ago and have thought about it since - it was the taste of the red lentils, the ability to distinguish layers of spices, that I most remember. We did the veggie combo - and I had order regret, wishing I did a plate of the red lentils -spicy and intricately spiced and delicious. We closed with Ethiopian tea and headed out into the rest of our night fully satisfied!

I absolutely love the food.  The service is so so at times.  I recently had the Zoma Tibs, atikilt wett (sp?) and Fasolia.  The Zoma Tibs wasn't my favorite but the Fasolia was incredible.  I recommend bringing a friend with a healthy appetite getting one of the combination plates.  I've never left less than incredibly full after getting the combination plate.

I've been to this place twice in around a month. I love it.
It's decorated very nicely, clean and spare. They've hired another waitress which is good, because the first time I dined there it took a while to get my food. If you drink, try the honey wine (I like it with ice). The food is very tasty. The service is good. The ambiance is sweet.
Check it out.

This place was wonderful. I am a vegetarian and they have that type of food well covered. I like their injera, and you get as much as you want, which is standard, but its still good to eat all that you can. The food was not too spicy, and the veggies were all tasty. The Ethiopian beer they had was nice, it went well with the food and was pretty surprising, I did not know beer was big in East Africa. The price was great for this, I could see them charging a lot more for this if they had another location, so I was quite happy.

My momma came to the city to visit me for the afternoon and I decided to walk around the wayyyyy northern part of Central Park to the Conservatory Garden, (where coincidentally my mom decided she wants to have my wedding....good.lord.mom.find.me.a.husband.before.venue.please.thanks)

Anyways, I wanted to pick a place for dinner in close proximity that offered healthful vegetarian fare.  She loves Ethiopian food... so Zoma it was! We arrived on the early side of dinner time (6PM) and had no problems being seated.  (There were only two other tables occupied at that time.) Excellent touch that they bring hot towels for us to cleanse and refresh before indulging in the delectables with your hands!   (Extra points from the hereditary hygeine freaks.)  The servers were friendly and very helpful with recommendations for our vegetarian combo platter...it was flavorful and filling.  Though, I wish they served up some salad and dressed the plate a bit more...I guess preparation and flavor should always outweigh presentation anyways.  

Though the list looked good, I didn't try any of the beer or wine, because my mom loves to remind me how many calories are in each drink...and well... that would just delay the husband wrangling for my big upcoming marriage in central park...ya know.haaa.  

All said and done - I will definitely come back here if I am in the area again and highly recommend it in conjunction with a trip to the north end of the park! :)

The food was delicious and a little different from what I've had at Ethiopian  restaurants in the past.

Unfortunately, it was pricey for the amount of food I received and combo plates were available only if sharing, which sucked for me because I wanted to try lots of options and usually enjoy a good vegetarian combo plate.

Lovely minimal decor, full bar, clean.

Giving this place two stars mainly because the service and drinks were really good... There Ethiopian beer and wine was really good.. But when it comes to the food...eehh dont know.. Order something that look like baby food place on a bed of bread.. It was like pureed meat and a hard boiled egg thrown right on top of it... Really did not enjoy the meal... The ambience is great.. But I am not an expert in Ethiopian food... I took couple of bites out of mine and my dates food.... We were both disappointed...  Don't think I will return here.... My curiosity on Ethiopian food out the window!
A bit over priced.  Very underwhelming.

Rarely do I venture above 100th street but for Zoma I could see myself changing my tune. Candlelit with clean, simple decor and a beautiful long bar, they set the atmosphere right for a seriously gratifying meal. The menu is simple, authentic and supports a relatively wide variety of wines to get you and a date drunk. 

We ordered up the vegetarian platter, okra and steak tibs. While the veggie platter was tasty and typical, the steak tibs were a real highlight ... perfectly cooked and not too spicy for my weakling tastebuds. The serving sizes are slightly less than I'm used to for Ethiopion--between three people we quite literally cleaned the plate with not even a spongy survivor in site. 

Note: they only take cash so hit the ATM before you get caught in a lurch on that romantic date you planned out...

I think Zoma officially qualifies as the last remaining Ethiopian restaurant in the city we still had to try. I love Ethiopian food and have sampled it in almost every city I've been to.

So, I don't say it lightly that Zoma has the best Ethiopian food in New York. I've been several times now and the quality is extremely consistent. 

The ingredients taste very fresh and the lamb & chicken are both moist & succulent. 

So why not a 5 star?

1 - I agree with some of the others that the service is neither fast nor particularly friendly. (Meskerem is much "friendlier")

2 - I find their injera to be slightly dry and tart for my taste. I prefer a fluffier, moister base, but now I'm nit picking...

Oddly, the one place that really has Zoma beat is not even in the city. Mesob in Montclair, NJ is still my very favorite Ethipian restaurant and almost justifies the extra 20 min drive out of the city. 

But if you're looking for great Ethiopian IN the city, then you'll do no better than Zoma.

The restaurant is just a few steps from my apartment, yet walking in I feel transported to a different place. The white on white decor is serene and calming to the senses; ditto the multitude of lit candles and tea lights.
Now to the nitty gritty - we had a very helpful and patient waitress who smiled answered all of questions with ease, and was just darn nice.
The food is reasonably priced, the portions big and this is a must -GO HUNGRY- otherwise you will leave food on your plate. The bread is addictive.

Serious yum! And this was the first time I have had Ethiopian food.

I have to be honest,I  am not really an expert on Ethiopian cuisine. Zoma was my second experience, ( with the big stretch of time from the first one) and the food was OK-relatively good. Decent simple comfort  food, as expected.  I loved the Ethiopian white wine here( listed last among whites on the modest whine list, too bad I cant remember the name) . Its honey based, sweet but delicious, I would definitely like to have it again.
When I walked in to the rest. it wasn't that many people there ( only 2 tables) and I have to admit I didn't feel that great about the ambiance. The wall is painted white, with the few African sculptures from the local stores, still looked very plane and like someone unfinished dining room, or some catered room- cafeteria . It just didn't feel much as a restaurant. The bar area has a large mirror , again on that white painted wall around, looked like some private bar. Ventilation was also poor.
I asked to be moved by the window at that felt better. ( except for the part that the heat was blowing right to my legs).
Later when  more people arrived atmosphere felt  better.
Me and my friend shared the vegetarian plate for 2. Waitress was helpful in suggesting the options, and we didn't regret listening to her.
Highlight is the Ethiopian wine. It would be helpful if they were excepted major CCs.
We paid cash , but I believe they take Amex too.

Really, really wonderful Ethioian food.  We were 6 people, so we had 3 orders of Sambusas (that way everybody gets 1 piece) and the spicy toasted injera bread with extremely rich goat cheese.  The sambusa reminded everybody of an indian samosa, but filled with meat. These were wonderful starters! 

Then we shared all 3 starter plates, one of which is vegetarian and the other two have meat, plus we added a plate of the zoma tibs.  At the beginning everybody was quite civilized, but after a while of eating with our hands there was just meat chunks and torn injera everywhere! Definitely great food and a fun dining experience.
Excellent Ethiopian in a generically nice interior. The veggie combo is tasty and substantial. Seems to be easy to walk in without a reservation.

- recommend: honey wine, yebeg alitcha (lamb)
- loved the yebeg however as a huge disclaimer to the dish, there are tiny shards of sharp bone throughout the dish. BE CAREFUL!
- mentionable atmosphere

A friend of mine had a Groupon for Zoma and treated me to dinner here tonight.  Ethiopian food is easily my favorite type of cuisine, and I rarely have it; I was so excited for an evening out with good company and delicious food.  Even better that we found this restaurant, just a stone's throw from my apartment.

When we walked in, I was floored.  The space is just gorgeous, with really contemporary decor, perfect lighting, great ambiance, and warm, friendly staff.  I was really excited to have dinner here.

Unfortunately, the meal failed to deliver on the what the restaurant's physical space seemed to promise.  My friend and I split a vegetarian combination platter consisting of collard greens, string beans, chickpeas, and lentils.  One of the reasons I am so keen on Ethiopian cuisine is that it is remarkably veg-friendly; a platter of vegetables and beans can be completely satisfying and delicious.  At Zoma, however, I was left rather unsatisfied.  The portion size was really small: our platter was supposed to feed two, but I think that I could have easily finished the whole plate myself.  Our injera -- the soft Ethiopian bread that also serves as the vessel for getting the stewed vegetables into diners' mouths -- was nearly ice-cold and very stiff.  It was unlike any injera I have ever eaten before, and not in a good way.  

The four courses themselves were very classic and tasty -- though I will mention that the gomen tasted a little more bitter than I would have liked -- but I feel like I didn't get nearly enough of them.  I'm used to leaving an Ethiopian restaurant and feeling too full to walk; while that isn't a great feeling either, paying $30 for a few bites of beans and carrots is not something I want to do or can afford to do with any regularity.  I guess I'm extra-crushed because the place was so lovely when we walked in.  I'll probably try again, but only because it's so close to home; otherwise, I'd go with Meskerem, which is a sure thing.

Delicious and very fresh Ethiopian food, reasonably priced, and a beautiful atmosphere.  Four of us had a beer or two, along with appetizers and two enormous combination platters.  Total $84.  The food was tasty and we loved most of it.  The lamb had huge bones in it, however, and the chick peas were really dry.  Aside from that, we enjoyed some great flavors, some with a bit of kick.   The dining room is very nice - candles, dim lighting, nice window and very clean.  

My only complaint was aloof service.  The waitress had a plesant demeanor and smile, but took our order and never came back to ask if we wanted any more food or drink or if we even liked our food.  It was a one shot deal - order from her and that was the end, even though the restaurant was dead.  We had to snap a couple times to get more water and to get our check, and I'm no snapper.  

Warning - they don't accept visa or mastercard.
Great Ethiopian food and ambiance in Harlem. Be sure to get a glass of Honey Wine!

Zoma was my first experience of Ethiopian food. The restaurant had a very nice but bustling atmosphere, beautiful decor, an attentive staff and the food was very good. 

I ordered the Zoma Combination (B), which included Doro Wett, Yebeg Alitcha, and Bozena Shiro for $28.59. The meal was for two and we could not even finish it because it was so much food. 

The only thing that I disliked is that they only accept cash & Amex (I am a Visa user, so it was the first time I could not use my card somewhere) and my friend had to leave the restaurant to go to the ATM to withdraw cash.

What a great experience! Came in at 6:30pm on a Tuesday and were the only customers. The restaurant is clean with simple, nice design. The server was super friendly and great about answering questions. The honey wine was not as sweet as other Ethiopian places that I have had. I prefer it sweeter, but my roommate that came with me doesn't like it as sweet, so it worked out just fine. It was still crisp and delicious. The food came out very fast and was perfectly spiced and flavorful. The Kik Aletcha (lentils) were my favorite and we ate every drop. The chicken was moist, lamb tender and cabbage/potato/carrot absolutely divine. I will return here quite often!
Over-rated.  Flavors are nowhere where they need to be and portions are skimpy.  Drinks yummy.

I had never had Ethiopian food before, but this was delicious. It has flavors very similar to Indian food, but you scoop it up with this spongy, fleshy bread. 

I loved it and was very satisfied. I probably couldn't eat it every week, but I'll definitely be back when I feel like eating with my hands.

Best Ethiopian in the city. Owner is a wonderful guy. Shiro Wett is one of my favorite vegetarian dishes-and I'm a happy meat eater!

It's the best restaurant in our whole neighborhood, to date.

When I think of Ethiopian food in NYC, I'll always think of this place first. When I lived in the area, I was delighted to find this place. It's some of the best Ethiopian food I've ever had. I was also very happy with the couple of carryout experiences I had... Even in the take out cartons, the food was beautifully "plated".

My favorite appetizer would have to be the stuffed pastries... They're stuffed with lentils and are accompanied by super-hot crushed green chillies. All of the chicken dishes have been perfect, and you can't go wrong with the vegetarian combo.

You can guarantee that your meal here will be full of wonderful, exotic flavors. The atmosphere is pleasant as well.

This is the cutest Ethiopian restaurant I've ever seen -- the decorations are really classy, its a chic spot!  On top of that, the food is also great. It's a bit pricey as compared to other Eth. restaurants but I think its well worth it. The service was decent and they have a nice bar too.  I would totally recommend it in fact I think I want to go tonite the more I talk about it. :)  

Oh- but bring cash! They don't take cards. That is the only not so good thing.

DELISH! This ethiopian food is fresh and super tasty.  The place has a lovely chill vibe. Whether it's a romantic dinner, a lunch with friends, or just time with a larger group: this is a great place. They've been CONSISTENTLY good - - for dining in and take out.

Note that service can be slow - - and I don't love that they only give you hot wet towels BEFORE you eat (yeah, yeah, I know it's expensive to wash the towels) - - it's still SO worth going here because it's so yummy!

This was the perfect spot to take a vegetarian friend.  The food was delicious and the ambiance is sexy.  We liked the wine list, too, and the bar area is a good spot for waiting (although a bit drafty...)

I keep returning!

Zoma is the best Ethiopian resto I've been to - on both coasts. While I've never been to Ethiopia, I imagine that their upbeat takes on the classic dishes are what upwardly-mobile people in Addis Ababa are eating (when it's not pizza). Nice ambiance, though a bit echo-y, and generally good service make it excellent.

My only minor gripes are the lack of towels for cleaning up before and after the meal (consider warm ones in the Japanese style) an ethiopian beers! Why no homeland brews, friends?

Don't miss the tilapia dish, btw. It was awesome.

OMG...This is place is heaven! The restaurant its beautiful...and the FOOD is truly the best Ethiopian I have had in the City! It cash only..so prepare for that ahead of time. David and I got the combo plate, it was reasonably priced @ $24 and came with a lot! The best part is unlike some Ethopian places..they were generous with the injirea...the bread that comes with Ethiopian Food. So good, the waitress was super nice!
Oh and I love the hot towels they provide before the meal!! Very chic and old school! I am definitely going back for more!!!!! By the way if you don't know much about Ethiopian food just order anything Tibbs (meat sauteed with onions, tomatoes in a flavorful spice)!!!

Great food, atmosphere, and service. I've been here on a date and with a group of friends and I've always had a great time. The honey wine= yum and the prices are great. You really get a ton of food! Servers are attentive without hovering and offer suggestions when asked. No this isn't the BEST, but it's pretty darn close.

This is the best Ethiopian restaurant in town. For sure. The service is amazing and the food is outstanding. The dim lights for dinner generate a wonderful atmosphere with a gorgeous bar in the backdrop. Seriously, this is a hidden gem in Harlem.

Zoma has typical Ethiopian fare, including a relatively spicy doro wat chicken dish.  My friend and I shared the meat and vegetable combination plate and two orders of the samosa like appetizers.  The appetizers were great and served pretty quickly, and the combination plate was ample with large amounts of that wonderful spongy bread.

The only downer was the service.  I agree with the couple of reviews that the service was standoffish and that's unfortunate.  This place would be packed to the gills if their service was the same as their food.  However, it was pretty empty that night, and it was a Saturday.

great food, nice vibe, friendly servers, and good alcohol selection. their baklava is probably one of the best i have had!

the yegeb alitcha was a little underwhelming, but if you stick with the spicy dishes you are set.

Tried Zoma last night. We went early to avoid the crowds so at 7 pm we were seated right away. The place is cozy and The home beer very hoppy and flavorful. We started with a lentil appetizer served in endives, delicious and light. We then ordered a combination platter and also the ginger lamb. The food was full of flavour with enough spice but not overpowering. It is great neighborhood place

This is the best Ethiopian in the city because it brings flavor equal or better to its competitors but uses significantly higher quality ingredients.  

The sambusas are delicately fried, with tasty ground meat inside, and a well-paired spicy sauce (it's thick, like a paste).  The Doro Wett was incredible - bursting with flavor.  You will want to lick up all the sauce.  The gomen was so fresh, and the flavor was brought out through seasoning (and not the overcooking that happens at many restaurants).  

The only thing that may be better elsewhere is shirro - Massawa's shirro has a richer taste whereas Zoma's is a subtler taste, and it is less pureed.  I don't know which is the "authentic" way but they are both really really good.

I'm lucky enough to live across the street from this place. This restaurant is one of my favorite restaurants in Manhattan. Appropriately priced, awesome service, great little space and very nice crowd of people. 

I recommend getting the $25 plates that you can share with another person... usually we'll get two big plates for a party of 4 and a bottle of wine and share with the bill coming out to no more than $70 or $80 for 4 people. Awesome!

Tasty, comfortable and in the neighborhood. My wife and I enjoy Zoma and our staple is the Veggie Combo Platter with an order of Tilapia. Certainly worth the walk from Spanish Harlem and one of the highlights of Frederick Douglass Blvd various eateries.

To get the best service, get there before 5pm on the weekends. It gets crowded after that and the two waitresses seemed to be overwhelmed when the place is full.

Dinner at Zoma was nice, great atmosphere, friendly  good service  - the food was good but not amazing, but it was reasonably priced I had the Zoma combination with my jump off and didn't want to spend too much money because who knows where this thing is gonna go...besides my girl is rarely in Harlem so I felt safe.  My "date" wasn't used to eating with her hands we loosened her up with a warm towel and a bottle of wine. In the end a wonderful dining experience.
moral of the story: Great jump off meal - eating with your hands is sensual and sharing a platter cuts the cost...side note:  acrylic nails are hard to clean after Ethiopian cuisine

Zoma is beautiful.  As you can see (I guess), I don't tend to give a lot of 5-stars, even to places that I love.

Zoma greatly exceeded my expectations.   I had unconsciously avoided Zoma for a while because I had cynically presumed that it would coast by on the novelty of being such an exotic commodity.  I guess I needed to learn my lesson in true open-mindedness. The chefs' ability in spicing and flavoring is SO refined - a very subtle talent.  This is not merely the best Ethiopian I have ever had; it is one of the best restaurants period!  Every dish is a totally independent creation.

The atmosphere is wonderful too - clean and unique, refined yet unpretentious.  I second Maria F's "OMG This place is heaven."  I couldn't say it any better.

Wow, dinner last night was fantastic.  Not just good for Ethiopian or whatever.. It was one of the better restaurants I have been to in awhile.. 

Will be back sooner than the last time

I was supposed to meet Hugo at Melba's at 8 on Saturday.  My stupid self gets completely disoriented if you put me anywhere between 100th and 168th streets.  Every street/avenue becomes the name of a liberator, third-world style, and then I forget my traffic pattern system and am rendered quite useless.  Let me also mention here that I've been to Society, and Melba's is just across the street, so I knew where I was supposed to go....So I made it waaay late, and Hugo's brother gave me trouble for it, but in the end, I endeared myself to everyone, of course, with my delightful and witty banter.

The place was really nice and sleek.  The decor was simple with uncluttered, clean lines, the whole nine, and there were some cool pictures on the wall I checked out by the ladies room.  The lighting concept was also fabulous and conducive to many things, so the restaurant is a great choice for most occasions.  This place is great for aesthetics-hounds.

For drink, I had some tasty, alcoholically green concoction that was reminiscent of a Midori Sour.  For the appetizer, we had some toasted Injera with some spices that was really excellent, and I could have done with that for the entree as well, as Injera is meant as a sort of bread to scoop up the food.  Untoasted, it's really more of a spongy crepe.  The entrees were excellent too, with spicealicious sauces and succulent meatiness, but by the end, I was not so happy with the regular Injera we were given.  However, I was loving that it was OK, even EXPECTED, for me to eat with my hands.  After all, that is the way God intended.  This is one of things I love about NYC: I can do away with much of the table manners I was taught.  In China/Koreatown, I can slurp my soup all day long.  Here, I can eat with my hands.  Again, for more details and names, mozy on over to Hugo's review.

The wait ladies were very attentive and had that mysterious ESP thing going, so they knew exactly when we would be ready for any next steps.  They were pretty gorgeous and smart-ass, but in a good way, as Ethiopian ladies are known to be.  Plus, one of them referred to me a few times as "The Master" for whatever reason, and anyone who knows me knows that i am a sucker for flattery.  When it is repeated, that's even better. 

The company, the drinks and the wait ladies get it a whole extra star, but I might not come here if in that part of town again.  But if there is a next time, I will tape a map to the back of my hand.

Came here to have dinner with some friends of our. This has to be the best Ethiopian place I've been to.

Service was attentive and quick. No idea why someone would say that the got poor service here. Our waitress came to check on us very frequently.

The atmosphere and decor of the place was simple and chic. This would be a perfect place to take a date. 

Cocktails and bar. They have tej, which is woefully absent in many of the Ethiopian places in my area. I have to say that the cocktails they served here were great. I wouldn't normally think of cocktails at an Ethiopian place, but don't miss them if you come here.

The food was very good. We had the vegetarian combo and the tilapia. Everything was spiced perfectly. They also brought out more berbere when we requested it. The injera wasn't quite as fermented tasting as I'm used to, but it wasn't bland. Portions were very generous. They said that the combo would feed two and it easily did.

Once I relocate back to NYC, this will become a regular spot for me.

Service was slow and unfriendly, the food was not that good (it was definitely hot but did not have the delicacy of spices that Ethiopian food usually has--as my husband said, "How can a dish be bland AND hot?"). The injera did not have the slight sourness that we expect or have gotten at other places. And....it was crazy overpriced. 20 dollars for a chicken dish? Really? For a dish that wasn't that great and for portions that were small? And in Harlem? We wanted to love this place because it is easy to get to from our apt and would have saved us a trip downtown for good Ethiopian. But I don't think we'll be back.

Also, what kind of place accepts AMEX but not visa or mastercard? Yet another bummer. And don't expect this place to be open right at 5 pm. They were nearly half an hour late in opening. Pretty sure Zoma suffers from thinking it is a better restaurant than it is. With the influx of Ethiopian food into Manhattan, I think they better start rethinking how they do business and improve their cuisine.

I've eaten here twice now and had great experiences both times. On both occasions we ordered sambusas (both the beef and lentil are good) and the vegetable combination (4 veggie dishes). Nearly everything was good (the collard greens were too sour for my taste). I especially recommend the cabbage/potato/carrot dish, the yellow split pea dish, and the red lentil dish. Their sponge bread (forgot the name of it) was fresh and light. All of the flavors were a nice combination of spicy, savory, and fresh. 

The prices are very reasonable (veggie combo and sambusas were $30). 

The decor is modern with "light desert" coloring. Comfy hairs and decorative Ethiopian art. 

The only thing not great is the service, which isn't bad, but it's not great. The customer shouldn't feel that they are any sort of burden to the wait staff. Again, they weren't so bad, but I'd give them 4 1/2 or 5 stars if the service was stellar.

A very chic setting for flavorful Ethiopian.  Our waitress made excellent recommendations for the selections for our vegetarian combo plate (perfect for two), each distinct from the next.  Cocktails were strong, crowd was cool.  I'll be going back armed with cash since they didn't take plastic.

This place was really good.  I'm a fan of Ethiopian food because I like eating stuff that tastes good.  Also, you get to use your hands because utensils suck.

Here's how this went down:  I went to see a screening of a rough cut of this awesome film about what goes on in Emergency Rooms called, "The Waiting Room".  (I invite you to check it out once it's officially released).

Anyhow, after the film, I was shepherded to this awesome Ethiopian restaurant in Harlem by three seriously beautiful people one of whom I had met previously and two of whom were new to me.

The restaurant had white walls with wood beams and made me feel like I was "in Ethiopia".  I put that in quotes because I've never been to Ethiopia, but I imagine that really nice people who serve you tons of good food is what Ethiopia is like (along with white walls and wood and stuff).  I've asked around and, in fact, Ethiopia is exactly how I've described it here.  

I guess they also drink Honey Wine in Ethiopia because we started out by splitting a bottle of Tej (yes, it's honey wine, a shocking development I know).  It was really good.  It's substantially different from Mead, which is the thick, syrup-y Viking Übermensch version of Honey Wine.  

I split a vegetarian combination platter thingy with the beautiful person who was previously beknownst to me.  It was really good.  It comes in a square plate with four rolls of Injera (ie Ethiopian carbs) placed at the corners.  We "chose" to go with the lentils, carrots, cabbage, and collard greens.  Two points become important here:

1.  I am again using quotes because I secretly coerced my dining accomplice into choosing specifically those four options because one of the other options involved a thick tomato sauce.  Sadly, I am allergic to tomatoes (oh no Ragu ninjas) [I am a quarter Italian so the tomato allergy earns me the triple word score in this case].

2.  These were not merely lentils, carrots, cabbage, and collard greens arranged in piles also by the corners of the square plate.  They were seasoned, sauteed, and flavorful.  There were definitely moments when our eyes met across the table to see who would eat from which pile.  Seriously, we ran out of Injera and I almost had to throw down Mad Max / Waterworld style for a carb source.  Luckily, the carbonuclear standoff was averted when we were brought more Injera.

Listen, the food was really tasty and it was reasonably priced and the portions were fairly large; not all you can eat sushi large, but I left satisfied (read: I ate a lot).  Come here and enjoy yourself, seriously.

i've only been to a handful of ethiopian places, some in boston, and even dukem in washington dc.  so i am certainly not qualitfied to say this was authentic ethiopian but i can sure say it was the best ethiopian i've ever had.  forget about the ethiopian, it was easily one of the best meals i've had.

the sambusa was really flavorful and light and it went really well with the green chili condiment. i think i like sambusa even better than indian samosa.

order the vegetarian combo.  its the bargain of the century.  you get all this amazingly tasty food and you are completely stuffed and satisfied.  for you meat lovers out there, you really don't even need to order meat dishes here.  the vegetables are so tasty.  split pea, chickpea, collards, pureed split pea, and string beans all excellent.

i did have to try the lamb though which was so well spiced.  i would tell them to make it spicier next time.  surprising how tender the lamb leg meat was considering that they sauteed it.  i would have tried the raw meat dish out of curiosity but it is prepared with a heavy butter sauce.  tried a drop of the butter sauce for taste and it was really damn good but i just knew it would've made me puke if i ate even a few bites of that heaviness.

injera is very good but fills you up like crazy.  if they gave you a fork to eat then you could definitely eat all you want but since you have to pick up the food with injera, you are so full of carbs half way through your plate.   the tej is very nice, tastes like a sweet beer.

the last time i remember being this stuffed was when i hobbled out of sasabune.  its a good stuffed, so stuffed you want to vomit but not because you are disgustingly buffet stuffed but just so overly full stuffed.

zoma is a place i would drive out of my way to dine at.  parking is pretty easy to get around here.  the staff is really nice, they have good recommendations.  the service is slow and they can forget about you but thats ok, you are having such a good time here that you forget about them too.

The food is delicious, and the portions are generous. As another reviewer stated, the ambiance is simple but inviting. Come with friends! 

I have one HUGE gripe with this place, which earned it a one-star demerit. It only accepts cash and Amex...



....o_O


...for why?! This isn't Brooklyn, you know. Catch up!


Ok, but really, the resto is yummy. It's not the best Ethiopian fare around in general, but it's definitely the best I've had in this city, and dining here with friends makes for a great Thursday/Friday evening experience...especially when honey wine is involved!
This is one of the better Ethiopian restaurants I've eaten at in NYC.  Worth the trip to Harlem, no doubt.  Just about anything on the menu here will satisfy.

Avoid this place. 

We waited over 20 minutes till the waitress came to check on us. They served very little quantities 
Also, they only take cash or AmEx.

Zoma was everything I heard about and more! The food was definitely on point and the ambiance was mellow. The layout is simplistic with hues of cream and brown. Although I called to make a reservation, I was told by the hostess it wouldn't be necessary si

Was here with a group of girls from my flag football team for a defense dinner. It's the first time I'd ever tried Ethiopian food so I was excited. We tried all of the combo dishes. The food came out very quickly and with extra bread-like stuff to eat it with. No utensils here ladies and gents, it's all hand to mouth stuff. It's hard to tell when the food comes out which dish is which but just eat it all. I especially enjoyed the spicier dishes with lamb and beef. It ended up only being about $20 per head, very filling and fascinating! Redolent of Indian food but slightly different spices and runnier with a spongier kind of flatbread. 

Great for eating in big groups, family style! Just be sure nobody has a cold....

Been here many times, love it more each time. Nice atmosphere, truly diverse crowd. I am a vegetarian so I usually split a combo platter with someone, but my meat-eating friends have been equally satisfied. Get a bottle of the honey wine with something spicy. Come hungry.

(Please don't bring your kids. I know it's fun to eat with your hands, but they are annoying).

A friend of mine called one night and asked if I wanted to try a new Ethiopian place she had a Groupon for.  We had rehearsal in the neighborhood one night, so we agreed to have a late dinner at Zoma and try it out.

Yum.

We split one of the Zoma combinations (the one with the lamb), and although we generally can pack food away, we couldn't finish this platter.  Spicy and tasty, this was well worth the time and money, and it's quite reasonably priced, even without the Groupon.  The honey wine was delicious as well.

Our waitress was attentive without being annoying, the restaurant is elegant and spare and quite romantic, with low lights and candles everywhere.  

Having tried Awash recently (and found it lacking .... review to come), but having had my first experience out in NJ at an absolutely drop-dead Ethiopian restaurant, I found Zoma a great NYC alternative to hauling ass out to NJ!

I have eaten Ethiopian since I was a kid -- and I love it.

Now in my opinion the food at Zoma was good, not the best - but solidly okay.  I took my boyfriend to Zoma for his first taste of Ethiopian and he really like it.  Yipee.  This spot will make the new comer very comfortable as it is definitely the most trendy Ethiopian restaurant I have ever eaten at.  One big con -- is that the injera bread under the food was harder then the ones served on the side (I've never experienced this before)-- using the bottom bread to get all the taste of the food is one of my most favorite parts.  But to add Ethiopian food to our regular cuisines, I would go back here without too much trouble.

Food and service are very good.  I wish the portions were slightly bigger.  You have to get some honey wine to enjoy with your meal, it's the perfect compliment.  The space is great for dates or small groups.

whether enjoying time with a significant other, good times with good friends, catching up with old friends and/or beating the cold.. Zoma can comfortably cover any reason to have, enjoying your stay @ this restaurant. Their combination platters give you a lovely idea about what flavorful Ethiopian food is about. And the ext time I go, I'm trying their Honey Wine!

This is the best Ethiopian food I've had outside of DC. The atmosphere was a little upscale but still casual dress and the service was excellent. Ordering was a little confusing: they give you two vegetable sides per platter (not per dish) but will put everyone's order on that same platter unless you ask for two. If you are more than two people or very hungry be sure to ask for two platters.

You need to visit this place immediately and order the shiro. I think we had other food, but I was really busy stuffing fistfuls of shiro into my face as rapidly as possible so I didn't care.

Oh my god, the shiro is so good.

Probably my favorite restaurant within walking distance from my home. Perfect for a date (though perhaps not a first date, unless, like me, you like to throw your newest conquest into a situation where he's forced to eat with his hands!), or a casual/leisurely dinner with friends or family. The bartender seemed pretty competent, but the real gems are the 2-person combo platters, I've found. If you're not a vegetarian, Combo B is pretty stellar, and will serve two people for $25. Zoma's dishes have the perfect amount of spice and base, sweet and savory, for my palette. The one disappointment I've ever experienced was the buticha, a chickpea mash: the chef must have thrown in too much flour, because the chickpea was... well, less detectable than I would have liked. I like to think that it was just an off-day for the buticha, but I'll probably try something else next time.

Also, I think they've got the injera (spongy bread) just right. I tend to dislike the bitter tang that many types of injera (such as Eritrean, at least in my limited experience) tend to take on. Zoma, however, has fashioned a more buttery, yet reserved tableau for their dishes. The injera takes a back seat to the entrée without being trite or forgettable.

Service is decent. Waitresses are lovely characters, if not a bit slow. I really like what the skinny one has done with her hair. Ambiance is soft, sultry--but a close look at the walls leaves something to be desired. An interior designer could do a lot for the space.

If you're in the area, make it a point to try Zoma. But a small warning: Zoma only accepts cash/AmEx.

Without a doubt, Zoma is a solid choice some good Ethiopian food. From what I hear, they are very consistent with the quality of the food served. Their food is very enjoyable, and to be honest the service is just OK if not poor due to under staffing and lack of confidence with English. That said, they do offer a wide variety of dishes to suit anyone at very reasonable prices. For first-timers, Zoma has an adequate choices to experience the Ethiopian cuisine. 

I have to comment that did decline to accept my American Express because no one in the restaurant knows how to change the paper tape roll in the credit card machine, and they wouldn't allowed me to help! (how lame!) I smell a mouse in the cash register!! I think the owner is taking off the top, not paying taxes, and making it inconvenient for their customers!

My experience of Zoma was fantastic.

The food was top notch and completely authentic. The service was competent, and I I loved the decor - it is modern and clean, but by no means cold or uninviting. Reasonable prices too, especially compared to some of the more expensive new restaurants nearby that are a bit too cool for school. 

Yes it is cash or American Express only, so plan ahead. They take reservations for parties of six or more only. 

Absolutely love this restaurant being a part of my neighborhood and will no doubt be back many times.

The food is amazing, and the cocktails are damn good too. It's a little fancier & pricier than I expected, but worth it. I'll be going back.

Cash & Amex only.

I really wanted to like this place.  What kept it from one star is probably the same reason that caused Jay Rayner to give the top chef masters season 2 winner 5 stars.  When we arrived, the first thing I noticed was the lack of air conditioning.  In fact, the restaurant was warmer than the outside.  I felt like I was walking into an oven.  The decor was nice and it was filled with trendy customers.  I liked the atmosphere but had difficulty overlooking the warm temperature.  Then when the appetizers came, mine was noticeably absent.  Nonetheless, the busboy/runner still cleared my friends' appetizer plates even though mine hadn't come yet.  I had to bring this to my waitresses attention.  I told her to just bring out my appetizer with the entrees.  When the runner brought out the entrees, we asked what the items were, and he acknowledged that he didn't know.  I told the waitress to just nix the appetizer since it hadn't come before my entree.  The entrees were served on a beautiful platter.  The food taste was entirely another issue.  The problem I had was that I've never eaten ethiopian food before.  Still I didn't enjoy the dorro wett (stewed chicken) or spices.  The bread/wrap used to pick up the food was soft, but overall all the food had a sour finish to it which i found very offputting.  I just didn't like the taste of the food.  As I see alot of great reviews for this restaurant, I've determined that this place does serve great ethiopian food, and that I'm just not a fan of it.

Where to start? Overall just a bad experience...like folks who "know" Mexican b/c they are from Cali, I "know" ethi food b/c I am from D.C. Anywho....Zoma food was a big disappointment. Where's the nittir kibbe (flavored butter), how about the spiciness? Just bland, watered down food possibly being made for gentrifying Harlem????? Seriously in the past the grub has been outstanding...now...I will not be back...when I went to the restroom I noticed the cooks were Latino....could that be it..no Ethiopian grandma in the kitchen hooking things up? Dunno but I am sad. Stale injera lining the plate...I mean the best part of eating ethi food is the injera that has soaked up all the juices..... at Zoma dry, hard bread and the juices aren't even worth eating...d*mn. And the service....also unsatisfactory. Slow and inattentive at best. Ahhh, I'll try Genet and if that fails me guess I'll just have t wait for my trips to the District (or NJ....for those who are interested there's a FABULOUS and authentic spot called Lalibela near Seton Hall). Boo, Zoma. 
**For the curious my party had kitfo, tibs, and yebeg alicha. Sides included gomen, mesir wat, kik alicia, and carrots, cabbage and potatoes. All bland...the kitfo and mesir wat were the best but I would not order any of the dishes again.

I really love the food here.  The atmosphere too.  I get the awaze tibs, which I sometimes dream about later.  Cash only is sad, especially because it's a little more expensive than some other Ethiopian restaurants.  But all in all, I keep coming back, and I'm never disappointed.
Shiro was very tasty. I think the lamb was really goat, but I would go again

Having lived in Ethiopia for 4 years and having visited Ghenet in Brooklyn, I thought Zoma was pretty good. My friend and I shared the vegetarian platter, which is my favorite way of eating Ethiopian food. I love my meat but when it comes to Ethiopian food, I love their vegetarian meals. To my disappointment, the portions were rather small. Maybe I'm just a fatty. Nevertheless, the food was tasty! Just wish we had more of it.

The location is convenient, not too far from the train station. The space and decor is very modern. Most Ethiopian restaurants I've been too (whether in the US, Switzerland or Russia) have been tacky with plenty of stereotypical Ethiopian goods. Zoma was a nice change to that.

Decor / ambiance - 5 stars
Absolutely beautiful inside

Food - 2 stars
Large portions of food that is not that good. The best in this city is definitely Meskerem (any location).
an elegant restaurant with terrific food.

Zoma's okay. Unlike others, I found the service fine, but the restaurant was mostly empty. We got one of the combo dishes with meat, which was plenty big and quite cheap. Each dish on its own was pretty decent. I wasn't a fan of all the bones in the lamb dish, but maybe that's just the way it is. Nothing really jumped out at me, however, and I think the flavors could have used a little variation. The four dishes together just didn't do it for me, at least one should have had a bit more zing. Anyway, minus one star for not having toilet paper in the bathroom.

3.5
