I'm trying not to let the onset of my Montrin PM affect this review.  Bare with me.  So...I lived in DC for years, and I've had some outstanding ethiopian food.  Zoma was good.  I really don't understand why it's Michelin rated though. It's not incredible.  Got the Combo Plate A...and it was fine.  Not memorable or amazing.  The peas were delicious though.

Oh...and only excepting Amex?  Neiman Marcus this is not...

Zoma offers not only fine meat and vegetable dishes but an injera bread that has the perfect delicate taste & sponginess. Perfect for soaking up every last bit of those sauces and even eating on its own. (If you have never eaten Ethiopian food before, note that it is your utensil.) Only the overly salted lentil spread appetizer caused me to  withold a 5th star. The service was polite and helpful.

Nice modern decor. Wine list. Bar. Cash only (I am not sure if they take AMEX, they didnt say). 

Ordered Combo A $30. 5-10min later out comes our combo platter. It had stew with chunks of beer, one piece of chicken, an egg, collard greens and lentils for

Love Zoma for an Ethopian fix. The space is nice, the staff friendly and the food is yummy. Love the combination plates that let you try different stuff. The cocktails are a-ok, but who goes to Zoma for Cocktails anyway, right? There can be a wait on weekends, but its definitely worth waiting for.

zoma was my first foray into the world of ethiopian food. i told my friends, "order what you want cuz i have no idea at all what this is all about." i believe they ordered 2 combos, one vegetarian and one with meat combo. and it was freakin delicious. i ate ALL the collard greens and i do mean ALL of them. and who doesn't like eating with their hands? well, i didn't like the weird floury feeling my fingers had afterwards but it's nothing a quick wash in the bathroom couldn't fix. 

get the honey wine. i don't like wine much but i do like anything with the word "honey" in it. and that was pretty tasty. it has a simple setting with candles at the table. and between us 3 girls, we couldn't even finish all our food. 

although zoma is a trek coming from brooklyn, i'd probably eat here again.

Just got home from an amazing dinner at Zoma. I've brought well over a dozen friends to this restaurant, and each and every one of them loved the food, the atmosphere, and of course the Tej (honey wine). I look forward to dining at this restaurant whenever I get a chance, and my friends are always excited to go back. 
It is an elegant atmosphere, with beautiful art work and gentle candle light. There's a nice bar but more importantly - the food is delicious. My all time favorite is the Kitfo (tar tar beef), and the Katenga (spicy appetizer that's to die for), add on some Tej, and you're all set for the night.
It's also an awesome date place (you get to eat with your hands and share your meal together).
A+
Enjoy!

Pros: 
Delicious food
Modern but simple decor
Great Staff
Honey wine!
Good for kids (had a 14 month old with us and they not only supplied a high chair but  the staff also interacted and played with her).

Cons:
Cash and American Express only

Favorites:
Misir Wett
Atakilt Wett
Tibs Wett
Honey Wine

I had a delicious dinner, moderately priced, at this wonderful place at 113th and Frederick Douglass.  Granted, I went on a cold, dismal night, but it was quiet and relaxed, and candle-lit.  No loud music.  Food was delicious (we shared a platter with several different dishes).  The wine selection is pretty bad, unfortunately.  They did have an Ethiopian wine, however, but I suspect it would be too sweet to accompany a meal.

Food was wonderful, service was friendly, atmosphere was chill.

The food is very very good! Great atmosphere and it's really close to my apartment so that's a very good thing.

The place gets super crowded in the evenings with good reason. That's how good the food is!

Delicious, messy and cheap what else could you ask for in your Friday night?

The veggie sampler was by far the best Ethiopian I've had in the city.  The yelpers below are correct though, the injera under the food is a bit stale- we solved this by simply asking for more injera on the side (I'm pretty sure they didn't even charge us).

Service is slow but once the food arrived I didn't care - who needs a waitress when you have a platter full of goodness!

Ethiopian food is great. Fun, messy finger food. If you're ready for the spices (not necessarily spicy, but flavorful).

Very modern restaurant in the lower Harlem/East Morningside area. A little sketchy outside if you're walking at night, so fair warning.

Kategna - spicy. Their soft finger bread, watch out, add the cheese to help moderate it, but it really made me sweat. Fortunately plenty of water served. This was good with the merlot.

Fillo pastry - I liked this, flaky and filled with lentils and beef. More sauce would've been good..

The vegetarian platter is four of your choice - we had the carrots (awesome!), what looked like sweet potato mush (nothing exciting), the collard greens (great), and mashed chickpeas.

Zoma meat platter of four meats was great, too.  Doro wat was crowned by the egg (the chicken was only so-so). Lamb was awesome, soft and flavorful. The beef, not so exciting. Plenty of extra spongey bread to sop it all up, and packed away much of it as leftovers.

They need to give the table more napkins or the same hot towel that they start with as well at the end to help clean off one's hands at the end. Bathroom is nice and clean, though.

The honey wine - tastes like cough syrup, I suppose it's an acquired taste?

Service was okay, but like Chi N. mentioned, it was pretty much a language issue. At least they'd eaten the food there before. Overall, good spices, but if you've been numbed by eating too much in the way of spicy food, you might want to choose the spiciest dishes rather than the non-spicy ones.

Not the absolute best Ethiopian food in the city, but it's up there.  Had my best experience this past weekend, as my homegirl decided she wanted be a veggie for the day and we had a fantastic combo of vegetarian plates.  Man, I love stuff with bebere sauce.  

The only bad thing was the same as my last time, the terrible service.  They weren't understaffed that night, Zoma is only SO big, but these ladies never looked back over at our table, which got annoying very quickly.  Good service would make me go back to a place before great food, so unless someone else wants to go, I don't know the next time I'll be back at Zoma, unfortunately.

I've come to this place quite a few times and its always delicious!!! They also have a decent selection wine which is a plus!

I usually get the combos which are great- the vegetarian one is wonderful and so is the meat. Cool vibe too. I agree w/the previous reviewer about the Tibb Weitt - It is the best in the city! 

ONE THING YELP GOT WRONG IS THEY DO NOT ACCEPT CREDIT CARDS SO YOU MUST BRING CASH!!!!!!! That would have to be the only drawback about this place. Otherwise, its great and I would definitely check it out!

i think compared to queen of sheba for some reason queen of sheba stood out way more for me.  and compared to philly well philly is still the best!  down and dirty is how i like it... 

  I have no idea what it was, maybe the dishes or the intensity of the flavors and spices... this place was pretty mild... maybe cuz we didn't ask for spicy!  regardless interesting "modern" restaurant tucked away in a shady area of harlem... word to the wise... take the train and get off at 116 and walk down... don't do wat i did and get off at 110 and walk up... it was the scariest 3 blocks i've walked ever... and then u enter into this place and breath a sigh of relief... odd huh.. .

anyway onto the food
- kategna - spicy yum, loved the cheese that cancels out the spice, i think this was my fav of the nite
- fillo pastry was also nice - lentils and filling nicely spiced and season... like the green spices to add as sauce
- we ordered for the 4 of us (WAY TOO MUCH FYI ) 1 vegetarian platter (4 choices) and a zoma meat platter (also 4 choices)

each of these dishes had a very distinctive taste that made it taste like u were eating diff things... other places tend to taste all the same with the same smooshy texture... this place was def diff
- doro wat - yeah i remember queen of shebas was way bigger and more flavorful in sauce however this was pretty moist and tender... gotta love the hard boiled egg!  how the heck did 4 of us manage to not finish one chicken leg i have no idea
- yebeg alitcha - i think i liked this more cuz of the many chunks of tender sweet lamb
- some beef thing - also pretty good, more tomatey based
- chickpea smashed - yum, good balance with the meats
- collard greens - no sauce yet held its flavor, good to balance out with all the other sauce intensive choices
- atakilt wett - very sweetened carrots and super soft, goes well with the green beans
- some other orangey runny thing

the bread was nice and moist and tons of it brought out it was impossible for us to finish...

i would suggest maybe next time ordering maybe 3 dishes less than wat we got haha

the honey wine was not a good complement to all the spicy foods, it made the wine taste bitter sweet... i liked my merlot tho... that cancelled out the spice and brought out the taste of the wine after awhile!

service
friendly but language barrier definitely apparent... they filled our water constantly which was greatly needed however otherwise don't expect to strike up a long convo with these peeps.

business.full_address:
42 Leigh Ave
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: Tortuga's Mexican Village

reviews.text: Never had a bad meal and the service is always nice. Been going there for almost 2 years. Try the carne asada!!!! Bigger than the plate!!
Excellent service and food!  The area isn't Nassau street, but you can walk there from there and it's BYOB.

Can get alittle crowded on the weekends, but overall great, authentic Mexican! The people really make you feel at home and are very kind. I'd reccomend the flavorful chicken rice soup and any of the burritos! Also the pepper steak is very tasty.

I would go to Tortuga if all I could get was chips with salsa and refried beans.  The salsa is not a red goopy mess, but rather chucks of tomato and onion with a spicy, vinegar-y liquid. The beans...well, lets just say they are tasty.  The actual menu items are delicious as well. I'm a big fan of the Enchiladas de Mar.

The service is quick, which I happen to like because it means I spend less time wondering where my server and food are and more time happily eating while I chat with my companions. Toss on a few more points for being off the main road and therefore less mobbed and you have yourself an excellent place for a quality dinner.

Arguably one the best Mexican restaurants in Princeton, but still not fantastic by any means.  Their dishes are overly cheesy and sauced, just like they do at the chain restaurants... not authentic at all.  The food is pretty good, just NOT authentic.  If
food here is very good.  4 stars because there's not much for kids to eat, cash only, and byob.  parking is always a problem.

Honestly, I went here a second time because someone LOVED and RAVED about this place and it was horrendous. The food was incredibly cheesy (hello, the flavor does not come from cheese alone). The prices were HIGH given the type of food given here. And no credit card accepted. Wtf. 

Bottomline: this place parades as a hip, cantina-style restaurant and because it's in princeton, they charge exorbitant prices. Drive the extra distance to Jose Tejas in Woodbridge NJ.

Went to tortugas w/ a friend for dinner. Thank god for the company, otherwise my 40$ + tip spent would feel worthless. A few things about this joint before i head into my review:

- It seemed like it was BYOB. 
-Also, NO CARD!!!... SO MAKE SURE U BRING CASH!  My friend and i had no cash, so i had to walk over to the deli about 5 min away towards to hospital to grab money from the ATM.. not cool!
- Chips and salsa , acc to their website are NOT BOTTOMLESS. The first batch is complimentary. So, savor the free stuff.
- Their new location is across the street from the old location.
- Street parking.
- Pricey. Around  over 10$ for an appetizer. 
- Clean bathroom
- 2 floors

Location: Off the beaten path . It looks like a real estate building in a residential area. Its weird and took a minute for us to realize that this was the location. They need a brighter sign.. actually, they need a sign period. The restaurant name is written on the door. But i guess its good for patrons who want to keep this place a secret-- not too much the owners :)

Food: Not bad.. but definitely not the best ive ever had. Im not a connoisseur of mexican food by any means, but NOTHING compares to Jose Tejas. Even on its worst day, jose tejas ( i think in woodbridge) knocks this place out of the ballpark. That being vented appropriately, the food was mediocre. I got the chicken fajitas. They give you three tiny flour tortillas with rice, guac, sour cream and chicken. The chicken are the size of chicken fingers, they are not cut up to be served in a fajita, so i had to cut it up. However, it was spiced pretty well, i just needed to add salt. The rice and beans were good, but i didnt like the guac. I thought the guac was over processed and dint have enough garlic ( my brother's guac was better than this). It tasted like it came off a shelf (i hope not). The grilled peppers and onions were really good as well.

Service: just okay. I was seated in a heartbeat on a table for 2. While i waited about 10 minutes for my friend to arrive, i wasnt rushed at all. There were 2 menus, chips and salsa waiting for me. I tried not to eat the salsa because i read on their website that the firest batch was complementary and the 2nd was about 3$ ( which is the LAMEST THING EVER BTW!!) Oh yea, the pico de gallo ( salsa) was too salty for my taste. But it tasted fresh. Service- nothing special.


BOTTOM LINE- You lost me at no bottomless salsa & chips oh dear tortugas. Get ur act together. Also, stop being so pricey. Just because u are located in Princeton, doesn't mean its cool to charge 12$ for guac dip that's about 6$ at on the border!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Cost us 41$ for 2 entrees + 2 sodas. OVERPRICED AND OVERRATED.

My suggestion: go to on the border ( if ur in a rush). If you are planning a mexican dinner, please please head over to jose tejas!!.. they seriously are the best!
Best vegetarian selection.  One of the finest places to socialize and just love the atmosphere and friendly, A must and highly recommended Mexican Restuarant.
Best steaks in the continent ( carne asada).

Best Mexican in Princeton. I wouldn't say it exactly satisfies the craving, but it quiets it a bit. Pretty good mole sauce, rice, and beans, generally large portions.

Solid, but not authentic enough. I do like the casual atmosphere, and it's actually a relaxing walk from downtown on a nice night.
Best Mexican in Princeton. The guacamole dip was fresh and creamy. All the entrées were excellent. Highly recommend it.

Tortuga's is a local Mexican institution. It is highly rated on Zagat's so I had to try it for myself. Regulars to my blog know taht I think ratings on Zagat are inflated and I'm happy to report that Tortuga's continues to confirm my hypothesis. Tortuga's has 2 other locations, 1 in Lambertville which serves alcohol and another in PA. The Princeton location is BYO.

The restaurant is located in a sketchy part of town. I was a little apprehensive about parking my car on the street but was assured it would be fine. And it was. The resturant itself is a dive. Basic wooden tables, I won't even comment on the decor because there isn't any! I love dives because they are usually the places you can find great, tasty food at low low prices. I love finding places like that. 

The menu was somewhat surprising. I was expecting something more authentic and the menu has some of those but it's a strange mixture of american, tex-mex and mexican. The spicy chicken wings made with habenero are a case in point. They were good, but strange and really spicy - made my lips burn. For the main course I ordered the Chipotle Shrimp which came with brown rice. It was a creamy jalapeno sauce, taste was good but the food was so unbelievably hot (in terms of temperature). It seemed like tehy had nuked the food for ages. It hadn't cooled down for 20 minutes. The shrimp were massive and cooked just right. But why was the food so damn hot? Kedar tried the tacos with Chorizo and wasn't too impressed. He really doesn't seem to like much. BTW, portions are huge.

Overall I would say the food is decent. I've had better Mexican, but if the craving for Mexican with a twist grabs you, this place is worth the occassional visit.

Without a friend's recommendation, we probably wouldn't have tried this place. It was located on a seemingly residential street, a very short drive from Princeton's busy downtown area. We were there on a Sunday early evening. It was pretty busy, with most of the tables filled and kids running around. Seemed very family friendly.

They brought out chips and salsa while we looked over the menu. I think we went through half the chips before we even started looking at the menu. We ordered the guacamole to start just because the menu claimed their guac to be the best north of the border. It was good, but they were a bit heavy handed on the salt. For the main, I got the Chiles Rellenos Poblanos. Again, a bit too salty. Everything else was good though. Flavors were there, pork was tender, sides were good.

Can't vouch for the authenticity, but the food was good. The salsa and guac were good, but it's pretty hard to mess those up with fresh ingredients. It's too bad they didn't know how to hold back on the salt. The food/ambiance/service and price they charged didn't quite match up. But it's still worth it to give this place a try.

Best hole-in-the-wall mexican place ever. I've been eating here for 25yrs.  Authentic food made fresh in very casual, cozy atmosphere. Carne asada is incredible and the table salsa is killer! !  Cash only. No reservations but worth the wait. BYOB
no cards, no limes,  $3 more pico,  this is 2012, perhaps go to Tijuana for the real thing not here

It is a funky place in a funky part of Princeton. Love their crispy chips and the salsa sauce - with crispy cucumber and tomato slices in a sweet and vinegary sauce. Their guacamole is also very fresh. Their steak burritos were ok but the chorizo ones were funky too... this time in a bad way.

so as you can see from my review of red sombrero, i love mexican food.

someone took me here saying that i'd be in love, i was in bleh. i got the vegetarian burrito platter and um....it was gross. the cheese was that orange cheese that forms a hard plastic sheet on top of the food...and the red sauce tasted more like marinara than anything remotely mexican. the guacamole was ok and the beans we fine but the rice had no flavor to speak of and the meal left a weird grease pile on the plate. nevertheless, we ordered dessert...the flan. in about 10 seconds she came back with it and it was cold and hard and drippy and tasted kind of old. 

the waitress was nice and the place was pretty cute...but the food...i won't go back anytime soon.

I found Tortuga's on yelp when my husband and I went to the Princeton Market Fair Movie Theatre.  
The Good:  This place was packed!  (a good sign)  The food was amazing!  Authentic Mexican Food at it's finest!  If you are sick of the horrid chain restaurants this is the place to go!  They had great outdoor seating but unfortunately it was raining when we went.  It is BYOB!  So don't forget your bottle. 
The Bad: If you care about ambiance this isn't the restaurant for you.  A few old Sombreros and bad mexican art on the walls, old tables and standard Sam's Club chairs straight Divey place.  Not a flashy date night place!  They charge extra for additional chips and salsa. ($3.00)  PLEASE MAKE SURE YOU HAVE CASH!  this place takes NO CREDIT CARDS.  Cash and Check only!  How crazy is that these days?
All in all the food is amazing... who cares about ambiance sometimes!

Now, I LOVE MEXICAN FOOD and this place does not disappoint!  Watch out though, it gets packed quickly (even on weeknights), and there is not much street parking.  Also, it's BYOB and they don't take credit cards.  HOWEVER, the very high quality of the food and friendly wait staff more than make up for the inconveniences.  

The atmosphere is very simple, yet authentic.  The restaurant itself is located in a heavily Latino neighborhood, which makes it a good opportunity to brush up on your high school Spanish!

You absolutely have to order the guacamole here.  At $13, the friends who I was with on my last visit pointed out that it is a bit steep, but you can easily share this with 6 people (save some of the chips they initially give you, the guac itself doesn't come with enough).  I usually order for an entree Chicken Fajitas or a burrito.  Their burritos are extra cheesy and come with beans and rice, both of which are super delicious.

By far the best Mexican food I've found in Mercer County. And BYOB makes it even better.

Try the steak fajita.
Moved here from so cal three years ago and this is the best Mexican restaurant I've found. Carne asada was good. Mole was very good. Would recommend.

Am I missing something here???

Given the fact that they are a cash only restaurant, I expect that I be wowed by their food...and that it has some degree of authenticity...Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed by the service and the food.

SERVICE:

The server (who seemed to be the manager of the place) was in a real hurry...the restaurant wasn't even that crowded...she must have assumed that I had taken the Evelyn Wood speed reading course because our dialog went as follows (with very accurate timekeeping in h:mm:ss)

8:20:10 We sit down
8:20:20: We get our menus
8:20:20.3: Manager: "Are you ready to order"?
8:20:20.4: me...thinking of something witty to say to her
8:20:25: me: "um....not really...give me another minute"
8:20:30: Manager: "So what would you like to have tonight?"....

Don't think of going there if you're looking for even 1/2 a decent romantic meal because unless you're Speedy Gonzales, it ain't gonna happen....

FOOD:
Since it was a BYOB, we had taken Coronas with us (Mexican Restaurant)...so we ask the waitress if she has any limes...her response?..."no..but we have lemons"...WHAT KIND OF A MEXICAN RESTAURANT DOESN'T HAVE LIMES????????  I eventually found out that Corona's don't taste good with Lemons....

The food wasn't that great either....I ordered the Enchiladas Oaxaca, which was horrible...the pork was very tender and juicy, but the dish had no flavor...the onions were so bland...it was embarrassing...

All in all, I think I realized what was happening...I had ended up in an alternate universe where Mexican Restaurants
a. have bland food
b. THEY DON"T HAVE LIMES.....

Don't think I'm making another trip there anytime soon.

Tortugas is the best Mexican restaurant I've found in/near Princeton so far.  BYOB isn't ideal, having to get cash before coming can be inconvenient (there's not a handy ATM), and there is sometimes a wait.  But the food is so good that it absolutely makes up for it.

The dining area is cozy, but not cramped.  The waitstaff are incredibly friendly and efficient, and the food, again, is fantastic.  When was the last time you got free, perfect pico with your chips?  Yum!

I often share fajitas with my date and we both end up paying less than $10 for a delicious dinner in an adorable, comfortable place.  Awesome value.  It costs more not to share, obviously, but then you have lunch the next day!  Nice.

Meh, is right. Perhaps a dozen Modelo Especials would have helped. This place went from a real winner to a real bore.
   I truly doubt that the food is made to order, given that your order is delivered inside of 6 minutes. And by the looks of our plates and those around us, frozen veggies and chewy rellenos, are the specialty. The chicken was over cooked to fire-starter grade tinder and the refrieds should be recanned. Nothing at all "especial" about this on-the-border bus depot trough.

Went back again a couple of weeks ago - Sunday night, no wait. 
Seafood nachos, Enchiladas de Mar, bunuelo for desert. It's always fantastic, and well worth the drive from the Shore.

5 stars for the food, 3 stars for service/generally disinterested staff. 

haven't been there in a while but was surprised to see that they had moved literally across the street. the new digs are a little more upscale.

incredible salsa, seemingly freshly prepared dished slathered with cheese, sauce, and deliciousness that is generally delivered within a few minutes of ordering. burritos and chile relleno are amazing.  i think i consumed about 2000 calories last night.

This place epitomizes Mexican food gone bad!  I tried no less than 10 dishes as we were with a very large party and I only ate the chips and salsa.  Everything else was greasy, brown, mushy, yucky.. and I'm a huge Mexican food fanatic and have been to the country several times, speak the language, know authentic Mexican fare. Basically, it bombed and  I went away hungry.  Had such high hopes :(

Been coming here for years...service is extremely fast, solid quality food... authentic.  A Mexican restaurant run by Mexicans, who'd a thunk? The place is packed even in the middle of the week.  This is one of my favorite restaurants.

Tortugas is the best Mexican food in the area. It's authentic, inexpensive, and really tasty. I've been to both the Princeton and Lambertville locations many times and have never been disappointed. The staff is friendly and efficient. Sometimes you have to wait a bit for service because it's a small, family run business, but the food is more than worth it. 

Since nobody else has done so, I will forewarn you about the neighborhood around the Princeton location; t can get a bit sketchy sometimes. Nothing to be overly concerned about, but it should be mentioned. 

One last thing, if the reviewer below who recommended you go to Blue Taco is actually referring to The Blue Tortilla, they are completely insane. Blue Tortilla in New Hope is, by far, the worst restaurant in the entire area. I would rather eat donuts out the dumpster of a Dunkin Donuts than ever go near Blue Tortilla. I wish I could say I was kidding, but I'm not.

Solid, dependable, yummy Tex-Mex.  This was our favorite in the Tex-Mex genre when we lived in Princeton.  (Just went back when we were in town last month and still just as good.)  There is a lot of cheese, but I don't think that that is a bad thing.  :)

We especially like the free (for the first bowl) salsa though it is hot to me.  We like the setting, too.

It is BYO and Cash only.  But, unlike a previous poster, we had a dinner for two with tax and tip (20%) for $28.

Do not confuse this place with the Tortuga's in Trenton, this place is the real thing!  All of the food is homemade, and is so very amazing!  The ambiance is lively; the staff is very friendly.
Be careful, though, make sure you have cash - they do not take credit cards.

After hearing about this place from multiple friends we decided to check it out - it was amazing from the get-go.  Immediately water glasses were poured, extra glasses were provided for our beer and chips and salsa were placed on our table.  The salsa , by the way, is amazing.  I had the chimichangas, they give you two - which were delicious.  My husband had chicken fajitas and he loved them.  Our friends had the carne asada - delicious and the quesadillas - super cheesy and tasty.  Each meal also came with a small, but perfectly sized portion of rice and beans.  The price was very affordable.  We were all totally satisfied.  The service was great and the staff was friendly.  We will be back again and again!  YUM!

Excellent food! This was our first visit and we were thoroughly impressed. After living in Texas for 11 years and moving to NJ, I haven't found any restaurant that compares to the Mexican and/or tex-mex in Texas, but this restaurant does. I was expecting it to be a little dive restaurant, but was pleasantly surprised that it has a nice casual dining atmosphere. We visited the new restaurant, across the street from the old location.  I highly recommend.

When I moved to NJ from CA in the mid-90s, I moaned to all my friends about the lack of good Mexican food here.  All I saw was one crappy chain after another on Rt 1.  But then I discovered Tortuga's Mexican Village in Princeton.  Away from the crowds of Nassau St, this cozy little cucina is a welcome treat.  Nothing flashy or pretentious about it -- just great food, great prices, ample portions, and nice mellow atmosphere.  I haven't had a bad meal in a decade, so I can't recommend it highly enough.  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.

Tortuga's is locally owned.  There was previously a sister restaurant in Trenton, which moved to Lambertville a few years ago.  I'm pretty sure I've seen some of the same staff there for ten years now in Princeton.

It is BYO, which I personally find a good thing.  And cash-only, which can be an issue since I can't think of a nearby ATM.

We went to Tortugas Mexican Village in Princeton on 1/28/2012--We arrived at 8:15 and were told the wait would be about 20 minutes for 2 people.  During what turned out to be a 45 minute wait, other parties (who came in after us) were sat before us.  From the hostess to the waitresses, everyone was absolutely rude.  Guacamole and salsa were very good.  Everything else was way too SPICY and gross.  We were not there long, but the place emptied out while we ate.  While looking at a dessert menu, the waitress started putting the chairs up on the tables (this was at 10:00pm!).  It gave me the feeling that we were most unwelcome, and to hurry up and leave.  A table next to us with 6 people were still eating at this point, asked for hot sauce and were told "Sorry.  Kitchen is closed."  Are you kidding me??  
Hostess and waitresses were out in the dining room eating... while their tables were eating.  At least we know why there was little to no service.  And, what service we did get was rushed and awful.
I will never see the inside of this dive again.  NO THANKS.

This is a can't miss authentic (non-chain) family-owned Mexican food restaurant.  It's casual, BYO, and they only accept cash.  Parking can also get dicey, but it's worth it.  If you're hot-natured, wear comfortable clothes as it's not air-conditioned.  Try the fresh guacomole, and anything else, as it's all wonderful.  They also offer vegetarian selections.
Great little find while passing through. Everything treated fresh and spicy. Feeling Mexican? no risk here.

This place is OK--their food is average but quite overpriced. It really turned me off that it's in the Hispanic part of town but the locals can't even afford it. Better bet would be Taste of Mexico in the Shopping Center.

They have a lot of vegetarian options. I had the Enchiladas Oaxaca. It was more like a wet burrito. There was no enchilada sauce. It had a lot of bell peppers and onions on top. It was very dry for an enchilada. It was soggy and flavorless. 

My wife gives Tortuga's 3.5 stars. She had a vegetarian burrito combination. One of the burritos had a lot of yummy guacamole in it.

It cost us $37 for two dishes + tax and tip.
Not great, not terrible. Had the fish tacos - blue corn soft shell. Cash only & BYOB.

My parents RAVE about this place so I was excited when we went there for my birthday dinner. I ordered some sort of steak burrito. It was pretty bland I have to say. Although I did try some of my mom's carne asada and it was delicious. So maybe I just ordered the wrong thing ... I am definitely willing to go back and find out. I did think the salsa was incredible though. Homemade and spicy.

I was expecting better.

Funky, friendly joint tucked away on a side street of the Princeton campus.  Cash only and BYOB.  Place was packed on a Friday night, with a line of folks waiting for tables.  Despite this, service was prompt, attentive and friendly, with groups being seated, served and turned loose quickly.

I chose (from their numerous vegetarian options) a Santa Fe Burrito for $13.  It was a huge, overstuffed affair, filled with rice, beans, cheese, and an unusual selection of veggies such as cauliflower, carrot coins, and broccoli.  A nice change of pace from standard burrito-fillin' fare.  The whole thing was served covered in melted cheese and sauce, meaning your only option was to go at it fork-and-knife style.  Also came with free tasty chips and very fresh pico-style salsa (the good kind---almost all chunks with very little juice).

We were in and out so quick I didn't get to linger as long as I'd have liked but the meal was a definite thumbs-up.  Recommended.

I don't see the appeal of this place. Here are the reasons why:

1) Decor- Cute wall mural. Open...could use a little more light or use some candles on the table.  Trying to be a dive spot but didn't hit the spot.

2) Food- Here's where I don't get the raving reviews. 

- We spent $12 on guacamole nachos and I was really expecting some kick ass guac. We had a plate of chips with semi melted cheese and guac on it. Not worth the $12. 

- Most of the menu items are about $16..from chicken to pork to beef. It's a bit pricey for the quality of the food. I can get better in South Philly from authentic mexican tacquerias. I think they can charge $16 a plate because they are in the Princeton area and know that people will pay this price??

-My friend and I had "fish tacos" and my other friend got some sort of beef burritos. I have had plenty of fish tacos before...this was basically fish stew with blue toritllas underneath and some green sauce before. My "grilled" fish was nothing but cooked fish with lettuce and tomatoes on top. I don't recall the last time I had fish tacos that I couldn't pick up with my hand. The tortillas were soaked with the sauce so I couldn't pick it up. My friend and I had to cut it with a knife and fork.

- Didn't bother with desserts so we didn't try any.

3) Service- I saw the girl who filled up my water more than the waitress. She was unfriendly and didn't seem like she wants to be there. It took about 25 minutes for our entrees to come out after the nacho appetizer. 

I guess the appeal of this place is that it seems authentic because it is in a neighborhood off the beaten path but really wasn't worth our trip. 

We had 3 entrees and 1 appetizer..no drinks and no dessert. Came out to about $70 total for 3 people. 

We won't go back...

This place offends me.

 Its not the poor service or the high prices. I can live with both. It not the claim to authenticity (which it isnt). Or the uncomfotable seating for those (ie. me) with bad backs. 

It's that it the food is thoughtless. 

A quick appeal to authority. I spend a good amount of time in Mexico. Lived in southern california for most of my adult life and married a hispanic woman whose grandmother stayed with us extensively. A good friend went on to be a central american chef and authority on cuisine from that region. I base my opinion off of these experiences. 

Tortuga fails in that it does not employ the base approach to food treatment that is found in the region it hails from. Strongly flavored food with a few core ingredients mixed correctly. Citrus, chilis, tomatoes some spices. Maybe cactus or avocado. Sauces/Salsas that are made with rough technique but have deep flavors, especially oaxacan styles. Trotillas, beans, rice...these are all pretty rudimentary tasks and even these are butchered. Even worse, they are ignored and the joke is on us. Cause I swear the business strategy is to prey on the ignorant gringos by jacking up prices (perceived value) and plying everything with cheese and sour cream to hide the really deep flaws. Like an old hooker with caked on makeup. 

But even this can be overlooked...fine..its not authentic. I've been to americanized ethnic restaurants (Indian, Malaysian, Portugese) and have had "good food", if not authentic. That I can live with. But that sinking disappointment bite after petulent bite is something I will not forgive.

Great food!! Tortuga's is tucked away, but definitely worth finding! Food is fresh and tasty!! Bring cash (no credit cards) and a bottle of wine/beer/ sangria and you are set! Will definitely keep coming back to this Tortugas!!

You go here if you're ready to say goodbye to Mexican chain restaurants and are ready to have a fiesta in your mouth!

It's a hard place to find, and parking is even harder to find. But once you get here, you can leave your daily worries at the door and enter an environment where the music is refreshing and the staff is like family.

I usually order from the vegetarian menu - especially the Santa Fe burrito...YUM! However, if you're ready for some tongue-blasting wings, try the Mexican chicken wings...muy delicioso!

Mexican cuisine is nice because it's always a hearty meal with fresh veggies and well seasoned food, but when you come across a Mexican restaurant that does all of that with flair while holding onto customer service as a key competency, you've found a winner!

I definitely recommend! I gave Tortuga's four stars because they don't accept cards and their parking is very inconvenient.

Wow, how bad can the service get? Once we were in there, without a server in sight, to the point that one customer stood up, took one of the pitchers of water, and started filling up everyone's glasses... I have been there about five times. Always very bad, slow service. The food is, well, mediochre. If you want really good and much cheaper Mexican food in NJ, drive 20 minutes to New Brunswick and eat with the Mexican locals! Much better food for 1/5th the price!!! Or if you want a nice and more expensive dining experience, go to Blue Tortilla in New Hope, PA, about 40 minutes form Princeton. Just don't bother with Tortugas's! I would rather go to Taste of Mexico at the Princeton Shopping Center (5 minute drive from downtown Princeton) which has some menu items that are great (chicken tacos) and some that are not so great (mole is inconsistent) but at least you pay a lot less! and they serve you when you sit down!

This is prob the best mexican you'll find in the Princeton area. It's not saying much, but the food is totally passable. It lacks a little in salt/pepper and the portions are grossly gigantic, but if you are craving mexican, then this is where you need to be as the pickings are slim in the area.

This is my go-to favorite restaurant in the world.  Whatever you get will be super delicious.  I've been going here literally since I was born - my parents used to take me in a high chair, and now I take my boyfriend on dates :-)

Recommendations: Burritos, Carne Asada, Pollo Mole - and basically everything vegetarian, for which there are tons of options.

It's a little pricey, but worth every penny.  Their mole sauce is INCREDIBLE.  I can never get enough.

Get here early - it fills up, and there's almost always a long line on weekends.  It might be out of the way, but has a seriously devoted following.

This is a good non-pretentious Mexican restaurant catering the pretentious Princetonians. Gotta love the Carne asada. and the flautas. Well priced and the staff is accomodating; but make sure to bring cash as they do not accept CC and there is no ATMs nearby.

Went here with a friend based on all the yelp reviews. Have to say that Princetonians have very low standards when it comes it Mexican food. The service is good which is a plus but honestly the food is bland and monotonous. Guacamole was average and the salsa was quite terrible. Dont think I'll be going here again.

REAL MEXICAN FOOD!!!! For real!!!

By far the best real thing you are going to get in the area. This place does NOT accept credit cards - it is cash only (or atleast it used to be - I haven't been here since 2003). It is also BYOB. But so what!!!!

I cannot even begin to describe how truly amazing their food is. Amazing. Excellent. Staff is great as well. Generous portions. It has a "hole in the wall" type of feeling when you first arrive, but boy will you be surprised! I wish a place like this existed where I live now...in Mass...
I really like this place.  The food is great and I love the fact that I can BYOB.  Parking is sometimes hard to find but it is worth the ride around the block a few times

Ok, so BF convinced me to come back and try something else, and I'm glad I did. Went for a combo of enchiladas - two sauteed veggie, one cheese. The cheese was perfect, the veggie unconventional (filled with broccoli, cauliflower and carrots, previously frozen but well prepared), and the refried beans are really some of the best I've had.

So, I'm bumping up a star because the enchiladas were seriously decent, but I still can't get fully behind a restaurant where I have to avoid whole sections of the menu.

How can you people possibly keep going back to this place and pay an exorbitant amount of money for crappy food!?

Visit La Costenita (450 Amwell Road in Hillsborough) for a taste of AUTHENTIC Mexican food.

just got back from this place... here we go...

food= better than mediocre. not by any stretch excellent, but definitely passable.

service= prompt.  we thought they were friendly enough. 


ambiance=we liked it. dim pendant lighting, colorful murals and small but cozy table not TOO close together. casual and low key, not pretentious but not a dive at all.


pricing = WAY TO F'ING EXPENSIVE for what you're getting. like a $14
burrito. are they freaking kidding? a $12 taco salad???!!!! WTF?! 3 fish tacos for $14 is muy loco!!!

and what is with the businesses like this one that don't accept plastic? it's 2008 and a new millennium. the berlin wall came down, we have an international space station and a black man is about to become president of the united states, andt these jackasses won't take credit cards. i'm not buying into the whole "things are more expensive in princeton, so we have to charge more to make our profit target" bullshit on this one AT ALL ( i never do ). for what they charge for a meal, they can absolutely afford to extend that convenience to their clientele. they do take checks, which is cool when you don't have cash, but who the hell carries a check book anymore?

byo is cool but it's getting so that you can byo when you grab a sandwich at the wawa, so no big deal. 

bottom line is- the prices are double what they should beat tortugas mexican village.

at harry's burritos in nyc (71st at columbus) the atmosphere is comparable, the service excellent, they have a bar, and it's friggin manhattan!!! and an enormous burrito will set you back a scant $8 and they take plastic.

hey tortugas-- wake up and smell the cafe con leche!!!

I have gotten takeout for lunch once and went once for a sit down dinner... both times it was extremely disappointing. The food was way overpriced for what it was ($14 for a plate of nachos with too much guac on top & shredded cheese). Both of my entrees were soggy, bland, and tasteless. The only good part was the homemade tortilla chips & salsa. An "upscale" Taco Bell at best.

Oh & the service was awful. There were probably only 10 tables of people when we came in for dinner & waited for nearly 20 minutes to be given chips & even longer to have our order taken. We had to go to the waitress ourselves to ask for the check.

I've been a longtime customer. Food is consistently good and the service cheerful and effective. They can get really busy and if you are the impatient type, just crack open another beer, enjoy the salsa, and talk to your table mates. Before you know it you will be eating good food.  Otherwise, go for the take-out option and order in advance.

Favorite Princeton restaurant, hands down.  LOVE Mexican Village so much!  I eat my weight in food every time.  
BYOB
Cash only

When I lived in New Brunswick, there was a place on Easton called Tijuana Burrito, and it was run by this teeny tiny old Mexican grandma.  Well, I don't know if she was a grandma, but if she was, and if I was Mexican, I would want her to be mine.  That place closed, but it's heart beats on in Tortuga's Mexican Village.  

It's an adorable little BYOB ;) open for lunch and dinner, and they have different portion sizes for different times, so watch out with the expectations.  Every time I go there I say I'm going to get something beSIDES the flautas, but then I go ahead and get them because they are SCRUMPTIOUS and delicious, and because I can't bring myself to leave there without having gotten that flavor of fried crisp to perfection tortilla and melty queso blanco.  I only get the chicken and the cheese ones though because the beef and pork ones just don't taste right with the crispy flour tortilla outside.  I guess you need drier consistency of meat.  

They give you chips and salsa for free, but guacamole is extra, although it's not one of those places with insane guac so I wouldn't bother.  If you want sour cream on your entree you have to ask, but if they forget something they're always quick to bring it out, so just tell them!  I've never had bad service there, and I've also never had to wait for a table, but maybe Saturday night or Friday night can get backed up and I wouldn't know, because I've also never gone on a busy sounding night of the week.    

Also they have this dessert with vanilla ice cream, cinnamon, honey, and some kind of friend waffle or other.  I don't know if they still have it but they used to and it was amazing.

Even Ivy Leaguers need their guacamole and chips, and this appears to be an insider's choice for Mexican since it feels off the beaten path in Princeton. Now, "off the beaten path" in Princeton means the residential area since I would have never sought it out had it not been for colleagues who live around here. Is it the undiscovered culinary gem of the Northwest Corridor? Not quite. But it's certainly decent enough to be a viable go-to, cash-only Tex-Mex joint for locals.

The Mexican village part of the equation is actually the mural on one of the walls augmented by the standard ponchos-and-sombreros decor you would likely find at a Chevy's fire sale. No liquor license. Buy your beer near campus beforehand unless you're fine with a Diet Coke. You're gonna need something to wash down the chips - which were frankly on the burnt side during my visit. The guacamole tasted fresh though, and there was plenty of it in a pile on a small plate (see photo).

There are lots of choices on the menu, and while I was contemplating the chile rellenos, I decided on the $16 Steak Fajitas. It was quite a full platter with the so-so refried beans, more fresh guacamole, rice, three lukewarm tortillas, and a pile of grilled strip steak (see photo). Usually I don't complain about getting too much beef, but for some reason, it wasn't marinaded enough to really peak my interest. Oh but I finished it 'cause I was hungry after taking the commuter train from NY Penn Station. My colleagues appeared quite sated by the experience

FOOD - 3 stars...decent enough Tex-Mex food...nothing to call Rick Bayless about
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...standard Mexican decor in an unexpected location
SERVICE - 3 stars...on the quiet side...BTW, they close at 9PM
TOTAL - 3 stars...not many Mexican options in this part of the state, I say go for it

This is the best Mexican in the area, but probably not the best Mexican ever (duh, right?). Good menu with lots of options, but this place isn't cheap - an entree is probably on average $15-17.  It's rather small inside, but they pack 'em in, so the wait usually isn't too long as they turn the tables over super fast.  Dim lighting, very casual, and pretty loud.  The complimentary chips and salsa (it's more like a pico de gallo) are outstanding.  I'm also a big fan of their refried beans.  The California Burrito is the size of my glove compartment.  I would really recommend anything on the menu.  Service is good, but less than friendly.  It gets very crowded on weekend nights.  Come with cash, as credit cards are not accepted and there is no ATM in walking distance.

While parking may be difficult, deciding what to order here isn't. I adore their mole sauce, and I would slather that stuff on anything. It's all a little greasy, but sooooo yummy on cheese enchiladas!

Service is spotty and I don't particularly care for their salsa, but the mole sauce is worth it.

No credit cards accepted, and there isn't a nearby ATM because this restaurant is in a very residential area (aka barrio). It's just down the street from Princeton Hospital so there is nearby street parking, but remember to feed the meter.

I have been going to Tortuga's Mexican Village for many years. I really enjoy their pico de gallo and chips, it's spicy and tangy! Hits the spot every time.  The only downside is that you have to pay $3 every time you ask for it again (the first one is complimentary). 

Although it is a small place, it is very nice to dine. Beware - they DO NOT take credit cards!!! Strangest thing EVER! They take cash or check...really?!?!? who takes checks anymore?! Anyway, if you can get over that, then you should check this place out.

It is a little pricey for being in Princeton, but it is definitely a casual place to eat. I enjoy their burrito each time I visit. It is consistently good food.

I have never had a good meal here. Mexican food is usually pretty reliable for people who don't like to eat meat, but apparently Tortuga's is the exception. First time I ordered the Vegetarian platter. Everything is filled with frozen vegetables, the corn, carrot broccoli combo kind you get at the grocery store. Bland and waaaaaaaay not worth the price tag. The second time I ordered the fish enchilada, which, I kid you not, felt like I swallowed a hot brick. This actually tasted like something, but messed with my indigestion lie crazy.

Only gave it two stars because the department I went with (which includes actual Mexican people) swear by this place and don't see any problems with bland over priced cr*p. So maybe I'm just not ordering right.

Best Mexican food I have ever had hands down. BYOB with a great atmosphere, especially in their new restaurant with much more seating. Staff are always friendly and helpful. There really is not a bad thing on the menu and every thing is made fresh. Prices

Good Mexican food but a little on the high end when it comes to price. They don't serve alcohol so definitely stop before you get there. They do load you up with water because the salsa is spicey (just the way I like it). The area it's located in is in a less desirable area of Princeton and a 1/2 mile from center of town. The service was ok but the food came out within 10 minutes which tells me either 1. the food was already ready to go or 2. the guys in the back really are quick. I will believe #2. The place does get busy and there aren't a ton of tables to fit everyone. I had the Cali burrito and my lovely gf had the chicken something. Like she mentioned, we were sooo hungry that we were in and out of the place i

Princeton New Jersey is just not a big Mexican food mecca. There's a lot of great ethnic food in and around Princeton, but I think in general there are better examples of Indian and Thai than Mexican. That said, Tortugas is probably the closest you'll come to actual Mexican food in Princeton, but that's not saying much. It's only serious competition in Chevy's, and Chevy's at least has a liquor license (Tortuga's is BYOB). 

You won't have a *bad* meal, and the service is always great in my experience, but it's not a stellar example of real Mexican food. As long as you set your expectations accordingly, you'll have a nice time there. It's funky and intimate, and the food is ok.
The food is amazingly delicious.  It makes the parking hassle and the cash-only policy completely worth it.  I've never been disappointed eating here!

My Tex-Mex rating abilities are like my abilities with wine: I can tell if it's really bad, but everything else kind of lies on the same level for me.  So to me, Tortuga's is solid but unexceptional.  I do like their tortilla chips, though.  And they have very, very generous portions.  I'm no wimp when it comes to eating my fair share, but man, the thought of scarfing down the whole entree, beans, cheese, and all, makes my stomach reel a little bit.  Now I usually just do the "pick 2" option.

Most of the times I've been here, it's been packed, which is a big minus, since it's isolated location makes it difficult to scope out other options, so really you're just waiting for an hour.  I'll be happy enough when Qdoba opens this summer.

Update: 4/10/10
As we decided to never actually eat here again, we were craving Mexican food which I thought to make at home, but were lacking totillas.  Needless to say, they won't sell you tortillas either, but the Mexican store near Chapin up on Witherspoon WILL.  And they're much nicer.  I hate this place and feel sorry for anyone who thinks that the food here is good.

Update - 5/24/2009   

We were craving Mexican food and decided to give this place another try.

It's overpriced, loud, and decent enough, but nothing spectacular.  Chapin remains better for tacos and I have to remind myself that the fish tacos here were absolutely disgusting. 

Service remains mediocre--the hostess was rather rude although the server was pleasant when she was finally able to get to us (we were done with the chips well before placing our order). The chips and home made hot sauce (not the vinagrey pico de gallo) are good, but I'd much rather spend $50+ on a meal for 2 elsewhere; go to Calico instead for Baja/Mexican--the atmosphere, food, service, and cleanliness are so much better and you feel great after a meal instead of thinking that you wasted your time, tastebuds, and cash.

I won't be back. 

3/27/09
We stopped by last night for an easy dinner.

I was craving crispy fish tacos, but they don't have them here.  :(  

Service: Friendly and prompt

Salsa: chunky, not many tomatoes, lots of vinagre
Chips: Enormous restaurant-styled chips
Guacamole: Excellent, but overpriced at $10
Fish tacos: these were made with a broiled catfish, and a bit too herbaceous (think grass/dirt)-flavoured for my taste; Jim liked them.  Served in crisp blue tortilla shells (I find blue tortillas a gimmick) with a cilantro-tomatillo sauce which was excellent.  Lots of lettuce in the tacos.  
Beans: some of the best we've ever had--creamy, sweet, yum.
Rice: bright orange and both dry and mushy
Chicken Enchilada: the chicken is a bit overcooked, but the flavour was decent.  I wish I had had more of the tomatillo sauce, which had a nice bit of heat creeping up during the meal
Shredded beef crispy taco: this was more of a stewed beef--and some of the best I've ever eaten.
Chorizo crispy taco--wait, this isn't chorizo!  It's chicken!  I was promptly provided with a crispy chorizo taco with red sauce. Um, something is different here--it's not chorizo, but linguisa and heavily smoked.  :(

Service was friendly, but Chapin's has better tacos.  I'll probably come back to try something else, as it's nice having a sit-down place even if the food was a roller-coaster.   Likely I'd go for lunch, as the prices are slightly more reasonable then.

CASH ONLY.  BYO

Dinner for 2: $53 including tax and tip

New location across the street from the original. Now has parking. Loud but very cheerful. Food was fresh and nicely prepared. Service was fast and friendly. All in all a really nice evening.
.

The place is in the middle of no where. Where you drive down Leigh Ave it's a bunch of homes and then all of the sudden, bam! There's this restaurant (there's other store there but never paid attention to them). It's like where did this come from? I've order the Seafood chimichanga and thought it was very good. I've tried another dish with squid in it. Didn't like it. The chip and salsa they give you is different. I'm not sure what Authentic Mexican food is suppose to be but I know it taste a lot different than On The Border.

It's true, you only get one free serving of chips, but really, they did us a favor, since it meant we still had room for the generous portions, and didn't leave so full that we couldn't grab a cookie downtown afterwards.

I love any restaurant where they put a carafe of water on the table. 

I had the flautas plate, because i am a spice wimp. they were fried but not too oil-laden, the with a good proportion of meat (or cheese) to tortilla. I don't think I'd order the cheese one again, mostly because it got a little too greasy and cheesy for me, but if you want a Mexican version of a cheese stick, you might love it. The mild dipping sauce was indeed mild, which is just what I wanted. The refried beans taste like pure butter, and I'm okay with that.

The boy ordered a veggie sampler. There was a lack of textural variation - beans burrito, guac enchilada. The flauta did have veggies in it. He thinks he'll order more vegetable oriented vegetarian food next time (vs the beans/guac route), but was still quite pleased to have many choices.

Total was $38 including tip, which seems perfectly reasonable to me for the amount and quality of food.

I have no problem with small businesses that try to avoid exorbitant credit card transaction fees. I'm sure we'll be back.

I have been going to this hidden gem in Princeton since I was 10 years old (so 16 years now and counting!). A friend from my soccer team's family told mine about it since it was down the street from where they lived. Well my family and I have been going there ever since! Very authentic Mexican food but you'll likely have to wait for a table as the restaurant isn't too big and is always crowded! Also, they don't take credit cards so bring cash with you. Oh, and it's BYOB! 

Great homemade chips with pico de gallo. The guac, fajitas and combo platters and everything else on the menu are so fresh and flavorful. Check their hours before you head over there since I think they close in the later part of the afternoon.

YUM!!
Anytime I come to Tortuga's, it's a good time.  I like it here.  Food's good, the food's plentiful, it's fast, and did I mention it is good?

They don't take cash.

I had the lunch combo of chicken buritto, beef tamale, and chorizo tostada.

Not a fan of either of them. The beef is ground beef and chicken is shredded chicken breast. Chorizo didn't really taste flavorful. If I had to pick a meat again, I would go with the beef and stay away from the other two (I personally hate chicken breasts).

Tamale seemed mushy, I don't know if it's supposed to be like that but I didn't like the texture. Tostada is basically a deep fried tortilla w/ stuff on top. The shell is quite crunchy, and I don't like eating crunchy things with my meat.

All 3 of these came w/ some kind of tomato sauce on top, but I didn't like the sauce. The taste felt kind of weird to me.

The rice and beans that came w/ the combo were all right. I felt the rice could have had a little more flavor. 

Their guacamole is smooth, not chunky. I liked it a lot.

They start off by giving you chips and salsa. The salsa was fresh and delicious. 

Would not mind coming back again, but not a restaurant I would rave about.

NOT what you'd expect when you go to a Mexican restaurant. And that's not a good thing. Being from out West, maybe I'm biased, but this is NOT really Mexican food. 

Maybe I'm missing something judging the other reviews, but when I order a Mexican meal, I expect the to find my dish full of peppers, corn, and beans ... not carrots, broccoli and cauliflower that looked like it was fresh from a freezer pack. 

The food was mediocre and I wouldn't go out of my way to return. Save the Mexican food experiences for the West.

business.full_address:
4 Hulfish St
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Underground Cafe and Restaurant

reviews.text: We went to this place as this waitress standing outside was offering free croquettes to us and my hubby was in this mood to try a different cusine. We saw the menu outside and it looked good and every item was around 10-15 $. But what we missed was that i

Dropped by this place intrigued by the "Eastern European Food" ad. Most foods seem Bulgarian or Greek.  I had the Tsatsiki salad, which was very yummy and served very nicely. Then I had the Chicken and Spinach Crepe, which was extremely good. The atmosphere was very nice, the service friendly and quick, the food yummy. I definitely recommend this place.

Went in for lunch.  The food was a bit expensive, but tasted good.  We had a crepe and a gyro.  The mushroom crepe was drowned in a heavy cream sauce that ended up making my girlfriend sick.  The gyro pita was chewy.  It was good though and held up well when being eaten.  The side salad for the crepe was boring consisting of just shredded romain lettuce and balsamic vinegar.  Portions were small, but it was enough to mostly fill me up.  My girlfriend actually left hungry (120 lbs).  We went and got dessert elsewhere to finish us off.  Not used to needing dessert after eating out for lunch.

I've eaten here maybe 2 x's, and each time I've left, regretting paying so much (well, it's not expensive, but dishing out any sort of money) for such 'meh' kind of food. The decor is nice, I guess- the tables are made of expensive glass from Europe, but the food is...again...meh. During one visit, the waitstaff was somewhat attentive, while the other time we were checked up on maybe once? Which maybe I would have excused if the restaurant was packed, but there was one other family in the restaurant, other than me and my SO. Also, I don't know if this has changed, but they played really loud music the other time I've been there.

They have great restaurant.com certificates and the food here is actually pretty decent, if different and a little on the pricey side.  The Bulgarian hot rocks dishes are a specialty, as are the kebabs.  I have had the chicken version of both and been satisfied with the portions and flavor.  The meat itself was also tender and well-marinated.  You will definitely leave stuffed, especially if you order/share an appetizer.  I highly recommend the stuffed mushrooms.  The desserts are okay, but nothing to rave about.  The bread pudding is probably your best bet if you do decide that you want to finish with a sweet dish.  Personally, I would just trek over to Little Chef.  Service is friendly if a bit on the slow side.  Definitely stop by if you're in town.  It's just one of those landmark places whose reputation is at least semi-justified.

FYI: website moved to www.princetonrestaurantunderground.com

TIP: Purchase a $25 restaurant.com gift certificate before going. Usually it has huge discounts. My friend got a $25 coupon for only $2! But just make sure to call ahead to confirm you can use it on that day.

Waitress was ultra friendly and food came out fast. I especially liked the mushroom appetizer. The portions are quite large so I ordered an appetizer and my friend got an entree for use both to share. The hot rocks combo was pretty yummy and made me stuffed.

OMG, I do NOT know how this place is still in business!!  I had a friend visiting from out of town & we decided to give the place a try.  My love for exotic food enticed me in.
The food really wasn't too bad.  This is where things got horrible-an enormous amount of FLIES circled around the dining room.  Not one, not two but packs!!  Sounds comical but it wasn't.  Years ago my father owned a diner & everyone knows that where there are flies there is spoiled food!  It was the summer & people could say 'some got in', but it wasn't 'some'.  The server came over and I quote "I, so sorry, for flies...we have someone coming in to spray for them"!!!  ARGHHHHHHH....needlessly to say we left as did another group of people.  This place was not clean.  I would be afraid to see the kitchen.  
Keep in mind this was the summer of 2009 so perhaps someone came out to 'spray' by then!  My advice...STAY AWAY!

Considering that my flower shop provides the flowers for Underground, Kevin and I have never eaten here. We had heard the food was very good and was highly rated and we were not disappointed. The atmosphere was very nice and comfortable. Our server was attentive and amazed us with her ability to tell us about all the night specials (four, very involved meals). 

I had the stuffed pepper which were not only tasty but quite filling. Kevin had the lamb special that was also wonderful. In honor of their 4 year anniversary, they treated all of us to a wonderful starter that consisted of 4 different appetizers. That was especially wonderful, especially the stuffed mushroom and the spinach crouquets. 

Because we wanted to try a dessert that was unique we tried their Bulgarian bread pudding. That was very nice and the perfect ending to a very pleasant meal.  I see the reviews are rather mixed but we really enjoyed our meal.

I've eaten here a few times and the food is delicious!  I always order the sausage shish kabobs, and I've not been disappointed.  Even the white rice is delicious, lol, there's something deliciously different about it - I can't put my finger on what it is

Wow, this place is great.  I actually bought an online coupon for 25 off a 50 dollar meal but since we went for lunch and it was just the two of us, we didn't use it...Anyway, I got the 1/2 grilled vegetable pita with "special sauce" (tzatziki sauce?) with a salad.  I actually got the sauce on the side and just put a small amount on top of the veggies.  It was out of this world good.  Hands down best grilled veggie pita and best sauce ever.  I actually don't even like veggies all that much but am trying to be "healthy."  It was comprised of zucchini and some other veggies.  It also came with freshly made hot potato chips which I enjoyed as well (only ate a few.) The salad was fresh and delicious too.  My mom got the shopska salad which she enjoyed as well.  I saw another group eating some kind of shish kabob that was hanging in front of them and it looked awesome too.  I am definitely going for the shrimp one with my restaurant.com "coupon."  If you search for coupons, you can get the coupon for 2-3 dollars vs. 15.  I paid 2 a while ago with some promotion.

Definitely give this place a try.

Update: We went here tonight for my mom's birthday to to use the gift certificate.  Everything was amazing.  My mom and I shared two dishes: the zucchini boat with fresh tomatoes, feta, and walnuts and the salmon ala greque (and it's wild!:)) with tomatoes, some kind of lemon dill sauce, bulgarian rice, small pile of veggies, and potatoes with a garlic oil sauce.  Since I loved the taztziki sauce so much last time I got a side to dip the salmon in which worked together perfectly.  We really had a lovely time and were very impressed with the food-and it was nice to taste something different vs. the small old dish at a restaurant.  The only small criticism was the salt level which no one else even noticed.  I use very minimal sea salt in my cooking and so that might be the reason.  Oh and I also didn't like the oil for the bread although the bread was good.

This restaurant is indeed underground, as the name implies.  They have both light meals (appetizers) and main dishes, with an emphasis on Bulgarian specialties such as shish Kebabs on vertical skewers, Bulgarian Hot Rocks (read their on-line menu to find out what this is), and plenty of other, mostly eastern European dishes.  If you go to their web site, turn down the volume on your computer's speaker (music is pretty loud).  They also have a children's menu (but with a rather limited set of foods to choose from), and, as you'd expect with any very new restaurant in town, no liquor license.  

The furnishings have a feel much like a cafe, rather than a more formal restaurant.  Nevertheless, the decor is very modern and imaginative (glass tables with crazed glass sandwiched inside, rock wall partitions, mirrors with aligator skin frames, modern plastic sculpture, etc.).  The service was very quick.  This is a nice place to go if you want a meal that is somewhat different from the usual fare, but you don't want to go to a fancy place, eat fancy foods, and pay a fancy price.

We love the Underground Cafe and go there whenever we feel like a good meal. 

We eat all the bread we can because of the addictive oil with spices they serve it with. Wow.

The hot rocks are a bit on the pricey side but are deliciously complex. (If you get the vegetarian option, ask they do it in the regular style and not with the tomato sauce, which isn't nearly as good as the regular spice mix they use.) The kebabs are spectacular in every sense of the world. The milk pie is a really fantastic dessert despite the unappealing name.

Pretty plain food.

Service was quite horrible. Food took forever to come and the waiter seemed to have no idea what was going on.
Bouillabraise and kebab are mediocre.. Bread is good. Escargot is super, served in a glass w/o shell. Service was good.

We went to Underground late at night after a day long event, and were welcomed warmly. The decor is nice and neutral, but inviting. The chairs and tables are comfortable and clean. The service was prompt, dedicated, and smiling. The food is an eclectic mix of Eastern European, but Bulgaria is mentioned a few times. I got Lamb kebobs at a friend's suggestion, and was very happy with them. They were  served on a sculptural hanging spike with a short eating demonstration. The food was delicious, culturally distinct, and interesting. Dessert was delicious, a chocolate crepe with nutella and ice cream. We had a very good time, and I'd highly recommend a visit.

Against my better judgement I decided to go try out Underground Cafe a few days ago. Swati G. was buying so I wanted to go somewhere a little more upscale, but she taunted me to try something new and since I'm always game to try most things once, I relented. I hadn't been there before, didn't know anyone who had been there or even read any reviews. My initial hesitancy stemmed from the cheesy web site and uninspiring menu. I really should learn to trust my instincts.

Underground Cafe opened about a year ago in downtown Princeton, right across from Ichiban and near my favorite Witherspoon Grill. It's owned by a former Bulgarian professional soccer player, Assen Tchongov. He grew up in the restaurant business with his father owning a number of restaurants in Bulgaria. The food is described as european with Bulgarian influences. You can pretty much smell the smokiness of the paprika in the air as soon as you walk in.

The restaurant was pretty empty that night, surprising for a Thursday night (well then again, probably not). We were sat down at a booth I think, not quite sure what to call it. The table was made of green glass. The web site proudly states that it was imported from Bulgaria to create the feel of a Bulgarian restaurant. Somehow I didn't feel like I was in Bulgaria. It seemed like someone's idea of quality decor resembles a cheap eastern european nightclub. A word of advice, if you get to sit at these corner "booths" sit in the middle, if you sit at the ends then the table is too far from you because the angles are all wrong. I ended up getting a chair to sit closer to the table. 

The restaurant is BYO, but there is a wine shop around the corner with a decent, moderately priced selection. 

Overall the food is decent, though not memorable. The appetizers are definately better then the mains. We tried the following:

- Spinach & Feta Croquettes - excellent
- Zucchini Croquettes - more like deep fried, greasy zucchini slices. Not good
- Chicken Paprikas Soup - Was returned after a couple of spoonfuls
- Mushrooms stuffed with sausage - good
- Penne Ala Vodka - Ok
- Hot Rocks - basically your choice of seafood, vegetables and meat (sausage, steak, chicken) searved on a sizzling stone plate. Huge portion. Kind of a fun thing to eat.
- Moussaka - a dud

We didn't try desserts because the waiter said "you guys have eaten too much, you don't need dessert". What the heck was that? This waiter either thought he was funny or pretty much uninterested in serving. I choose the latter based on his performance throughout dinner.

So, I've tried it and can now say that I won't be back.

WWW.foodielifestyle.com

This place is kind of wierd.

We passed it a few times, and made Sproket jokes.

Went there for lunch with small group of 5.

The kebabs were supposed to be good, so all but one at the table ordered them (the other had the tuna sandwich). 2 chicken, one chicken and sausage.

Bread was brought down and served with a walnut oil which I first thought was harissa.  It might have been walnut oil with paprika?  We requested plates for the bread.  The bread rolls were crusty and hot, the paprika walnut oil odd.  
  
Drinks came eventually, followed by salads for everyone except the sandwich eater.  Mesculn salad with a mild balsamic vinagrette.  Pretty good.

While everyone still had salad and  6" bread plates still on the table, 3 large chem lab looking items showed up with our kebabs:
--2 hooks up top, one with the skewer and the other with plastic tongs
--2 bunson burner rings, one with a bowl of rice, the other with yellow creme fraiche
--on the bottom was the plate, directly under the skewer. 
The rice was flavoured with coconut milk.  The cream fraiche may have been tinted with tumeric.  The skewer had to be moved from it's hook and onto the table, as it's a bit precarious eating under a skewer (if you eat here, you really should get this just for the "whoa" factor).

The chicken was tender.  We thought sausage meant ground lamb, but  was kielbasa/polish sausage.  A lot of onion, some bell pepper.

The tuna sandwich came with chips and a salad, and was done correctly.

Getting refills on the beverages was hard.  The server was nice, but overwhelmed.  Getting her attention was a bit difficult.

$16 per person including tax and tip

The meal was rather odd.

business.full_address:
1985 Corporal Frank Scott Dr
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: College Park Aviation Museum

reviews.text: This is a fantastic place to take young children.  I love going with my son.  He has lots of room to run around, and he's fascinated by the planes.  He also looks really cute when he dresses up in their old fashioned pilot clothes.  My favorite time to go is when it's raining or snowy outside so we get out of the house and have lots of fun!  The gift shop is also loaded with fun toys (great Lego sets!).

An under-appreciated gem of a museum! Perfect for kids in both scope, size, and activity levels--and great for adults with shorter attention spans as well.

For $4, it's a steal. There are plenty of activity stations to keep little ones (and, honestly, big people) happy--trying on pilot gear, playing with flight simulators, coloring postcards. There's a nice selection of planes from about 1904 to the late 1940s, with lots of interesting memorabilia too. Also, the text stays nicely in between the worlds of engineers and liberal arts majors. 

The main gallery is entirely glass-fronted, allowing you to watch planes take off and land, and there is an adorable play yard out front with tiny rocking-horses shaped like planes (rocking planes?) and bikes shaped like planes. 

When I went there, the crowd was pretty sparse--but there was a group of 4-5 year olds starting a birthday party as we left. (What a good idea!)  

There's a frisbee golf course right down the road too--but I just wish they had a little  more indoor space for eating and sitting down, particularly if they are trying to appeal to young families.

My 3 year-old and I went on a particularly hot August day to avoid the heat. The staff was very friendly and helpful.  There was a large camp group going through, but they didn't get in the way of our fun and we were even told to join them for a fun craft upstairs. My daughter loved dressing up like a pilot, riding on the planes outside and all the hands-on craft activities.  We brought lunch and ate on the patio, which was cool because we got to watch a helicopter take-off.  All in all a great place to take kids!

And here I was thinking that the Air & Space Museum downtown and the Udvar-Hazy Center out in Chantilly were it as far as museums related to planes. When we were in this hood shopping at a nearby Toy's R Us that was closing, we saw signs for the museum so we made a pit stop.

The museum is located on the grounds of the College Park Airport. The airport itself is the world's oldest continually operating airport. Pretty cool, huh? Inside the museum we saw items and collections from College Park Airport as well as some stuff that was World War I-era.

The best part was a open area that is a story and a half tall with most of the College Park Airport stuff. There is a 1910 Wright Model B Reproduction plane here, too.

Big fan of this place both because of its historical significance and lets face it - its just cool. 

you can sit back and watch MFRI (Maryland fire rescue institute) light their building off and planes land at the same time. you can walk around the grounds to eat at teh 94th aero squad, walk ove rto the tennis courts. 

this is an underused facility.

business.full_address:
3724 Spruce St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Bonded Cleaners

reviews.text: Sure, they can get your shirts clean. But don't expect them to do it with a smile. The first dress shirt I sent there, they managed to break a button (I've been getting shirts dry cleaned for years now, and this was a first in my book). The second dress shirt I sent, they managed to iron the "collar stays" into the collar. Quality. Needless to say, I'm looking for another neighborhood dry cleaner to fulfill my fabric needs.

I thought I'd try out this cleaner when I discovered it a few months ago because it was so convenient for me.  I'm glad I did!  I've never had any problems with the quality of their work and service is always excellent.  I'm really glad to have found a place I can trust that is also easily accessible!

This cleaner did a great job with my dress shirts and slacks.  The shirts came out very clean (especially around the collars) and crisp (starched it perfectly to my request.)  The ladies were very friendly and service was excellent.  I highly recommend th

Two months after loosing an item and promising to find it, I was given a pathetic excuse...So finally, I went in, told them that I will give them one more week and then I am going to send them a bill for the item, they found my polo that same day.

This place is just a terrible cleaner, with no experience in handling clothing and lack any professionalism.

Multiple times I have had poor results from this business: shirts coming back with new stains that hadn't been there before, the inability to remove simple discolorations, and so on. The employees are basically nice enough, but after giving them so many chances (due to its very convenient location for me), I will be trying out something more distant in the hopes that I won't have to make return trips.
They're reliable and they do a really good job on spotting and cleaning.  Extremely convenient for my work schedule because it's right on campus and open a bit later than other dry cleaners.

business.full_address:
185 St Nicholas Ave
Harlem
