Manhattan, NY 10026
business.name: Cedric French Bistro and Bar

reviews.text:
I went here last month with some friends, we had a great time. It's a nice atmosphere for a bottle of wine and nice conversation. I ordered the duck, which was cooked perfectly. Unfortunately, they put way too much sauce over it , overwhelming the meat. 
Cedric's is a fantastic addition to the neighborhood. Although the prices are a bit high for the quality of food.

Had a casual dinner here with a girlfriend on a Sunday evening. Nice spot.  I'd been when it was Mojo and it pretty much looks the same- except for the patronage - but i'll leave that alone.  The servers were nice and very attentive.  I ordered the hangar steak and was pretty tasty considering i ordered them to cook the life out of it (i should've gotten med-well instead of well done, but i take full responsibility for that).  I ate it all anyway because it was good.  And i ordered one glass of champagne.  My friend enjoyed her mussels and escargot, as well.  Overall, it was a pleasant experience- albeit a pricey one.  It's just nuts how a simple dinner for two can soar to $100 nowadays in Harlem.  I'm a Harlem native and I've witnessed and grown accustomed to the bleaching of the neighborhood, but it's still a little jarring when i see places like this where most of the people who live in the area probably can't afford to eat there.  Oh well, that's not Cedric''s problem, is it? Anyway, i'd still return on someone else's dime or if they ever have a special prix fixe situation.
I liked it, I can't find one thing to complain about.  Food, service and price were all on the money.

The food is delicious and it comes quickly. The staff is nice and always asking how things are (OK, got a tad annoying). The space is a bit tight, but I guess it makes it more french and less welcoming to large clientele. The wait staff is a group of good looking guys, some with sexy French accents. Go for the food, stay for a waiter's phone number (and if you can get one, share the wealth)!

This place is adorable. It is located on the corner, so the floor to ceiling glass windows give a great view or the brownstones on St. Nicholas. The menu had many appealing options. We opted for the grilled chicken salad and Nicoise salad, which were delicious. Staff was very accommodating. Will definitely return and recommend to others.

Came here with one of my girlfriends for brunch and this place did not disappoint at all! I absolutely love the atmosphere, the service and the especially the food. I will be taking my hubby here!

We had the soup of the day a pea split soup (I am not a soup person) but I almost forgot where I was and wanted to clean my plate up with my baguette. 

The French toast was crispy on the outside and fluffy in the inside (am I making sense cause this was just ummm?... moving on), the mimosa was strong and great. now I did try some other strawberry drink and it was a bit bland so i went right back to the mimosa. Will I be coming back here? In a heartbeat!

the food was tasty, but they don't allow substitutions.  they charge you for an extra side even if you don't have the side that comes with the entree.  in addition, they don't have a list of cocktails. DON'T GO FOR DRINKS! my husband and i ordered cocktails anyway.  they were expensive.  my martini was $16.  the service was good, attentive, but we found it interesting that TWO members of the wait staff thought we were finished with our dinner when we had yet to receive our entrees.  One attempted to clear the table and the other asked us if we wanted dessert.  i'm not saying they're slow, but we were clearly sitting there way too long when the wait staff thought we were finished or ready for dessert.  my husband felt robbed when the bill came.  if we go back, we will not order drinks.  the entrees are a good price.

Very Solid. 

I ordered the beet salad and a side of Ratatouille. It was all very very yummy. The Sangria was perfect not too sweet and ice cold for a hot summer day.

I came with GF to Cedric for dinner at 10pm on a Monday.  For dinner, Cedric definitely has the potential to earn four or even five stars, but the execution didn't match the potential.  

The Tuna Tar Tar with Avocado starter was excellent (five stars).  The combination of textures and flavors complemented one another.  One main problem with our dining experience is that they were running out of food!  Almost half of the apps/entrees they were out of.  When I ordered from this now limited menu, I was even told that the leg of lamb was out.  I got the duck dish and the GF got a hanger steak (we both had wanted to the steak tar tar).

The Hanger steak was pretty dam good (4 stars).  The potatoes that came as a side were good on the whole, but they were too satly in both of our opinions. It was juicy, prepared exactly as she asked (Medium, not medium rare or medium well).  My waiter recommended the Duck (said it was his favorite thing on the menu).  I can understand why- it is a good dish with nice flavors and tasty sides.  One thing I didn't like about it, however, was that it was covered with too much sauce and the sauce was a little too thick for my taste.

Our waiter was very nice and every one at Cedric's is friendly and helpful.  I don't blame him because it was the end of the night and the place was busy, but I did have to ask for bread after seeing other tables get some and not being given any for a long while.  Unfortunately, this bread was a bit too tough and (though this will sound picky) I like having olive oil and balsamic vinegar to dip the bread in rather than just butter.

The wine he suggested was fine (a Bordeaux), relatively inexpensive, but nothing to write home about.

Did the small things that went wrong with our meal make it not enjoyable? No.  If I have the choice, however, my suggestion is to come here for brunch rather than dinner.

I have mixed feelings from my brunch experience there.
The service was pretty bad: they forgot to give us menus and water, we had to ask for it after a 10-15min wait. Then, it was a long wait for the plates, but that's ok, it's "French style".  And finally, they made a mistake on the check.
But they really tried to make it up to us by offering us drinks and even the desserts after the mistake on the check . This is very nice and we really appreciated it, but we just would have preferred everything went smoothly on the first place.
Additionally, the food was ok but nothing special. Because of the good rating of this place I was expecting better. 
The restaurant by itself is beautiful and it's very nice to have a place like that in the neighborhood. I will probably go back, I want to try some real French food, because, let's face it, brunch isn't something we do in France!

The evening at Cedric was great. Food was delicious, we checked in on yelp and got a complimentary glass of champagne. Service was great too, and the best part was the Funk Band -- totally unexpected and made for a very festive evening.
Tuna tartare was d

Sometimes, you have to let a restaurant know that it did something right. 

Harlem restaurants are not know for their terrific service, and Cedric is no exception. Don't get me wrong, I'm a patron and I like the place, but it's not the sort of place where you come away saying, 'Wow, the service was really great there!'. It's more like, 'That was pretty good for Harlem.'. So here's where the kudos come in:

GF and I were out for dinner  there on a Thursday night--prime time, so it's pretty busy (always nice to see). We're eating fairly light and decide to split an app and entree. The first surprise was that the kitchen took the time and effort to split the dishes for us onto separate plates. Unasked for, but very much appreciated. Shows that the waitress was paying attention. 

The second part comes later. Since we've only ordered a couple of things, we decide to splurge on dessert and place the creme brulee. It takes forever for the kitchen to deliver it to us. Not really a big deal because we're not in a rush, but still, it's obvious the kitchen is backed up and needs time to recover. It finally comes and we finish our meal. When the check arrives, the manager leans over and tells us that he's comped us the dessert because it took so long. 

Now, I've been in many, many downtown restaurants, and although that same scene has played out more times than I can count, I don't think I've ever been comped unless I've complained about it. And in most cases, not comped at all. So imagine my surprise when a mid-level restaurant--in an area of town not known for great service--takes a financial hit because it's the right thing to do! I think that attention of detail should be rewarded.

First let me give big props to the previous post by linda c. I absolutely despise obnoxious asshole parents who drag their brats to nice restaurants and then expect that they should be magically accommodated...it happens FAR too often in this city, and its terrible. Why would you subject the rest of the dining room to your undisciplined brat? Try having a little more humility and consideration for everyone else and leave your little shit of a kid home with a babysitter...or go to Applebees, stop being an asshole. And btw, Bad Horse is great but please don't bring your brat there, no one wants that...but by all means continue to take him to Bier or Lido cause those places suck

As to Cedrics however, it is a wonderful place; small, quaint...cozy even...the staff are friendly and overall it has a very good vibe. While we were there for dinner there was a birthday in the dining room, so it got loud and silly for about 60 secs and then everyone went back to business, sort of a nice mix between campy and fine dining...its kind of hard to explain, suffice it to say it just had a nice, positive vibe to it that most will enjoy.

The food was very good, especially if you like French food... very rich, well executed, nice flavors and combinations and they have an interesting menu of dishes that are both traditional staples and a few things that are kinda way out there. The staff were attentive and friendly and a pleasure to dine with, its a small and intimate dining room but I never felt crowded or pressured the whole evening and they were quite busy.

As others have noted, the prices are a tad high ($20-30 mains) for Harlem but the reality is that there aren't really any options for classic French food in the area. Also the wine list is pretty good and affordable and there are several good options that compliment the menu nicely.

Just had a great dinner at Cedric.

As half-frogs, my sister and I really enjoyed the friendly, French atmosphere.  The food was excellent - we started with the snails, then had the lamb and duck - and the drinks were great too. It was clear that everyone was having a fabulous time in there.  

Also, just for a record, there's not a bad table in the place. I'll be back with more Francophone friends soon.

Pleasantly surprised by how good this place was. The food was flavorful and fresh and the service was really pleasant. They certainly go out of their way to make you feel right at home too. We got the beef carpaccio, risotto, and smoked salmon and everything was spectacular. Brunch for 2 came to about $60. Nice addition to the area, definitely worth checking out.

This restaurant is adorable! Had dinner here on a Saturday night, stayed for three hours, and had a fabulous time. I love the glass paneling that opens out onto the street. Makes for a romantic atmosphere as sunset turns into night. 

So about the food. I had the hanger steak, medium, which comes with some meltingly buttery mashed potatoes and a small green salad. The beef was perfect. Tender, juicy, just perfect. And the accompanying red wine sauce was rich, smooth, and velvety. This is how hanger steak should be done.  My companion and I shared the chocolate mousse, which was heavenly! Rich, chocolatey perfection. 

Service was excellent, as our waitress was very attentive and very warm and friendly. I did have some black bits in my water glass, but the waitress swapped it out immediately. If you're looking to have a nice, sweet dinner in Harlem, Cedric is where it's at!

This is the restaurant to eat in, if you relish having to converse at screaming level. It is a small space and the manager keeps turning up the cheesy 70s/80s music to deafening levels. If eating moules and steak tartare to the blaring accompaniment of the Hughes' Corporation's 'Rock the Boat' floats your boat, then come here. If your idea of a great night out is being compelled to leave half way through the meal because you have a raw throat and pounding headache - look no further than Cedric's. Pity, because the food was great and the service excellent. It's a nice space - although they have crammed slightly  too many tables in. The deal breaker though, is the music. Had we not been there as guests of a visting friend, I would have walked out early on. My husband actually left mid-meal and went and sat in our car outside. To be fair the manager was solicitous, when my husband explained why he was leaving and even offered to run out to the drugstore and buy him some aspirin. This just painfully underscores that he completely failed to get the point though. And if a restaurant manager is not listening to the needs of the paying customer - well it's not ideal is is? Still other patrons seemed to like the place. One lady even got up and danced with the manager at one point, which was buttock-clenchingly embarrassing. Whatever, we won't be back.

I had dinner at Cedric on a Friday night with my boyfriend and another couple.  I had wanted to try this place for a while now since it opened  several months ago.  I have to say that the Cedric  didn't disappoint.  To start we each got a free glass of champagne for checking in on Yelp.  Thanks Yelp!  

I had the tuna tartar for appetizer and it was delicious!  My boyfriend who is not too fond of raw fish tried it and he loved it.  For my entree I got the sauteed seabass.  I thought it was just ok.  The fish was cooked nicely but I thought the dish overall was a little plain.  However, one of our friends got the duck and her dish was very yummy so was my BF's steak.  I would definitely recommend those two dishes.  

The atmosphere at Cedric's was lively and friendly.  The staff was very accommodating and was always making sure that we have everything that we need .  I would definitely go back and try other things on the menu. Cedric is a great addition to the neighborhood.

Last weekend, a group of us visited Cedric for brunch. It was a gorgeous day out and if you're looking for an open air dining experience in the neighborhood, Cedric is the place to be. The restaurant is cozy, with about 15 tables, and is surrounded by floor to ceiling windows on two sides of the restaurant facing the street. On a nice day, these windows are swung open giving you a nice breeze and great atmosphere as you eat.

The service at Cedric is a little slow. After being seated it took a good 15 minutes before a waitress came over asking for our drink orders and another 15 minutes before those drinks arrived. However, the place gives off that vibe and encourages you to relax, enjoy the atmosphere and company, and take your time. They don't rush you out.

For brunch, I ordered:

    Omelet with Spinach and Goat Cheese

Our food arrived fairly quickly (compared to our drinks) and there was an unanimous decision that is was all very good. I'm a sucker for goat cheese so I wasn't complaining about my meal. I did notice that the spinach appeared to be a little bit watery as there was some liquid (I assume it was water) under my omelet but it didn't detract from the taste, just from the visual appeal. My omelet came with both a side salad and fries which were nothing to brag about - I mean it's just fries and a salad. I will say that the fries were a little soggy and I would have liked them a little crispier.

This review is way over due and we went to Cedric three times since I first wanted to write one.  

In short this is a small place with a fabulous menu so make a reservation. Servers are knowledgeable and attractive and the experience is warm and fun so b

I've dined here a few times and in the past the service has been a bit spotty. Last time, however, service was excellent, as was the food. All the mussels are delicious. Beet salad tasty, and duck very nice. Chocolate Mousse desert yummy. Wine a bit overpriced, but good selection.

Loved the decor and it was sparkling clean in there.  Pleasantly surprised at how amazing the food was too.  Every part of our meal was great and the service was attentive and friendly.  I think this is my new favorite place in the neighborhood!

The food in this new place is in general fine.  But given the prices of the entrees, it is lacking in service compared to downtown restaurants of similar pricepoints.  Perhaps I'm a bit particular, but it is a no-no in my book for servers to reach over guest's heads while they are serving.  It is also unacceptable for them to hand the plates to the diners in a way that diners have to receive the potentially hot plates with their own hands.  No, you are supposed to set the food ON the table in front of the guests, and do it in a way that your arms are not flying over people's heads..  NOT over people's heads and NOT requiring people to hold the plates and set them down themselves.  Also, it is custom for servers to know which guest ordered what dish. A few times though, the server would just plunk down a plate randomly without confirming who had ordered what. 

My friend ordered a dessert that was supposed to come with ice cream and whip cream. The waiter came and said that they were out of whip cream and asked whether that was okay; he would compensate that with an espresso on the house. When the dessert was served, however, there was whip cream, but NO ice cream.  My friend was very disappointed.  She asked the waiter for clarification and he only answered, in a dismissive tone, "oh, they told me it was one of the creams that was out."  I was not impressed by that response.

Not everything about the service was bad though. The same waiter was at times quite patient with our party, since we were bigger (7 people) and some of us were fussier than others.  I asked for a substitute for a side and they very graciously accommodated.  The food was also quite good; people were in general happy with the quality and taste.  I ordered the organic chicken with ratatouille and it also came with a little bit of green salad.  The chicken was very tender and the portion very generous.  I couldn't finish it all.  

Another thing I commend Cedric for is that there were no children screaming or running around the restaurant.  This is quite rare since parents in "new" Harlem can't seem to leave their children behind for dinners.  Bier Int'l is a baby central, as is Lido.  We very much enjoy the grown-up environment that Cedric offers.

I am very torn writing this post. Cedric is a gem and it suits Harlem perfectly. The atmosphere is quaint, but lively at the same time, packing in tables anywhere they can in the well lit, open dining room. I came here on a Saturday with a few buddies for a birthday (without a reservation) and were sat right away. I was impressed at first glace. It was, without question a French inspired restaurant with the way it was decorated. 

The five of us were sat next in the corner near one of the open windows/walls and next to the live music. While I can certainly appreciate being serenaded with live R&B the technical difficulties the musician had definitely took away from the experience. First she sang one song and then left the "stage" only to return about 5 minutes later reintroducing herself, then once she finished her song she left the stage again for the same amount of time. When she returned she introduced herself...again. After singing her song we were sure she would leave for a few, but sure enough she decided to stay, but while attempting to move on to another song her mic went berzerk and gave crazy feedback for about 15 seconds, leaving the whole place in agony. I don't know if it was her manager, or part owner of the bar, but whoever it was with her was sitting near us watching and freaking the hell out about her performance, swearing under his breathe. I thought his head was going to blow up. It was hilarious.

Anyway, on to the service and meal. Our waitress was an extremely attractive woman... that's about it. She would bring our drinks over one at a time, I assume trying to not to strain a muscle.. who knows. However even though she would take her sweet time the sangria was really tasty and def did the trick. For apps we got ano order of the mussels, which I have to say were the best I've ever eaten. The sauce was beyond delicious if I were at home I probably would have but the bowl up to my mouth and drank it. For an entre I got the flat iron steak, medium rare and it was cooked perfectly. I would highly recommend. So, as I said above I am very torn about this post because the foor deserved 4-5 stars, but the service was just so subpar it makes me wonder if I would go back. I mean nothing terrible happened besides what was said above and the fact that my friend ordered the burger and the waitress didn't bring ketchup so he had to get up and get it himself. Oh and she also didn't bring bread before anything came out, or even with the mussels. Honestly what kind of french restaurant forgets bread?!

So yeah if you're in the area it's def worth a try. As I said the food is wonderful you just can't guarantee you'll get good service.

I dined at Cedric last night with three other people, and our experience was nothing short of outstanding.  As a local Harlemite, I am a huge fan of Cedric, and I believe it's just what the area needed.  I was lucky enough to meet the owner, and he was both very pleasant and attentive.  He wants to know that everyone is having a good time.  It's rare that you meet an owner as passionate and concerned about his patrons.

Where to begin?  I've read some other reviews that complain that the service is slow at Cedric.  That's a poor interpretation of the service I think.  First, understand that everything about Cedric is 100% French.  As one who has traveled to France before and knows many French people, it's my understanding that the French have always been known for taking their time with most things, so as to enjoy them, never rushing.  And that's what you get a Cedric.  You're supposed to become a part of the culture and relax.  No rushing.  Live life.  That being said, the service is outstanding.  The staff were all very friendly and attentive, regardless of the fact that it was a super busy Friday night.

For starters, I shared the tuna tartar that my girlfriend ordered.  I'm not even a big fan of tuna tartar, but the way in which Cedric seasoned the tuna and placed it on top of delicious guacamole made the dish utterly irresistible.  So try it, for sure.

For my main course, I had the steak au poivre.  It was absolutely divine, and I highly recommend it.  One of my friends had the lamb (cooked medium rare) which was also superb.  I highly recommend pairing the lamb or the steak with the Bourgogne Pinot Noir.  You cannot go wrong.  We also tried one of the Bordeauxs, although I cannot recall which.  Long night :-)  It was a very good wine.

I cannot wait to return here soon to try so many other things on the menu.  I love this restaurant and it's vibe.  5 stars and 2 thumbs up for Cedric!  Harlem is still coming up!!!!

I love a french bistro...and a french bistro in Harlem is just too perfect for words...Was there a night with live music.  The staff was attentive and friendly, drinks were well made, and the other diners were friendly as well.

This is more in reference to "Hiam A."'s review as it's nothing to do with the establishment and i don't like seeing businesses suffer for certain patron's specific demands versus rights: 

1. Are you the same couple in Boston that dined at this amazing cute quaint french restaurant with about 5 tables, candelit, that I had a romantic dinner with my partner in? You know, you had the crying baby at 11:30 pm who threw a fork? 

2. Who brings a 13 month old to places like Red Rooster? Batalis?? A BEER GARDEN?? Is your baby colicky and you're just trying to get him drunk? (which I might be okay with because then we wouldn't have to hear him) 

3. "Its hard to find a babysitter", really? What a shocker! Then stay the f**k home, order in from all those fancy restaurants because they will bring you the food or just put your baby in its Bjorn (which I know you have or, ugh worse, its pouch because that's just sooo authentic) and walk on over, pick the food up, but eat at home because trust that all those people at these fancy restaurants you've independently labeled as "family-friendly" are all hating you! 

4.  Yeah the French do family dining and yea we have French restaurants across the pond here but guess what? Yall ain't in f****n France and if you did bring your American version of family dining over there I'm sure they'd request you to leave. So I guess what I'm saying is -- your baby's not an accessory item, you chose to have it so choose takeout and leave us who prefer dining atmospheres with post-verbally developed people who can control their metabolic functions alone.  Applebees exists for a reason, I hear they have good wings. 

5. A 13-month old doesn't "love" to do anything but pee, s**t, stare, learn by instinct and suck a tit. Don't put what you gave up on him, YOU love dining out. Too bad, so sad. More room for kid-free me!

Great to have this place in Harlem, really
Cute place, I love to seat at the counter. 
Service is usually good, quite slow but usually when I go there, I m not in a rush.
Sometimes too noisy with the live music but I m sure people enjoy it
However, tjs week I came to have a late lunch and the lady server (first time I saw her) was not very great.
Ok it was not busy but for this kind of restaurant with this menu, at least you have to I've a great dinning experience,
Besides that I m still giving 4 stars because it s an amazing place.

Cedric is a delightfully friendly bistro with excellent food and a welcoming environment that is casual but sophisticated. Service can be improved with greater consistency, and I gather that with the obvious hard work and attention to detail of it's owners it will be. I live in the neighborhood and welcome their presence. Give it a try, relax and enjoy.

I came here on a Sunday evening with my roommate, it was her birthday and she chose this restaurant since we have been living in the area for a month now and had not eaten here yet. We were handed a menu and instead of being told up front that a bunch of items were missing, our waitress waited until my roommate ordered lamb to be told they did not have any. Her second choice? Duck..."Sorry...we don't have that either". After 2 more items were removed from the list...I thought...well, what DO you have? 
The waitress put in our appetizer order of beet and goat cheese salad and our wine (or so we thought) while my poor roommate whose birthday dreams of lamb or duck were crushed.  She finally settled on the salmon with ratatouille and I ordered the jerk chicken, which comes with fries and salad. I added a side of ratatouille. 
The beet and goat cheese salad did not disappoint. Beautifully presented and artfully plated, it was the most delicious representation of beets that I have ever had. Just divine flavors. When our waitress refilled our water glasses, we asked if the bartender had forgotten about our wine, which made her quickly admit that SHE had forgotten to put in our wine order and it would be on the house. Fair enough.
Our meals arrived and they were wonderful. The jerk chicken was evenly spiced and moist. The ratatouille was the best that I had ever had, and my roommate agreed. Her salmon was cooked perfectly and her side of mashed potatoes were creamy and delicate. During our meal, we were told to slide our table to the left so that they could squeeze in a table of four, which was odd, these poor people were awkwardly squeezed in and one person's chair was right up near my ribs. As we finished our meals and sat drinking our wine, one of the waiters came up to our table and made mention that he had people waiting and would need our table. I can understand when people are just sitting there and you have a wait - but there was an EMPTY 4 top table next to us and we had JUST finished our wine! I hate being rushed out when there is no need for it. 
So, 3 stars...the food for me was worth 5 stars, but not having menu items and not being told in advance, forgetting wine, being rushed out....it just all felt weird. Thanks for the comped wine, but that is not going to earn more stars. Just irritation. Not sure if I will return here. I may give them another try, we'll see.

Fantastic menu, although, we came too late to enjoy some key pieces of it. (boo!)

Service was fantastic. Wine by the bottle only, so that's a bit of a drawback. Can't try multiple new things unless you're looking to tie one on for the evening. 

Great atmosphere with smart, handsome folks of various cohorts there. Lots of bustle, but not so much that you can't enjoy a great conversation at your table.

Had dinner at Cedrics mid September. Ordered steak tartare (delicious and ample portion) with salad and frites. Frites needed crisping, but had good flavor. Dinner was reasonable but--WARNING WARNING--don't order the coffee. First of all, it's poor in quality and--and here's the warning--it's $4 a cup and NO REFILLS were offered. Heck, Le Cirque, where I had lunch in August, charges a lot less for delicious coffee.

I went to Cedric for dinner and had a lovely time. The atmosphere was great and the food was amazing. The place is always packed and everyone looks like they having the best time. The staff is so nice, too.

However, I must agree with other Yelpers on a few points -- there was too much sauce on the duck which overwhelmed the meat. Also, the prices are quite, quite high! So that is why I didn't give the place five stars.

However, I will DEFINITELY be back. This is a great spot. I am super excited that amazing places like this are opening in the neighborhood.

I've been to Cedric at least three times and each time, I came away very satisfied.
The ambiance of this little place in Harlem is just what a bistro should be; cozy, friendly, slightly nostalgic, with a rather refined looking clientele. 
The fries are really good here - thin and crispy - and my usual go to dish is the tuna tartare. I remember the apple tarte was also quite nice.

They got it right!  In this bustling version of the evolving Harlem, it is amazing the options we now have for upscale dining; quality of food, service and atmosphere.

Cedric's is fab!  I've been to this restaurant twice and it gets better and better.  The mussel options are delicious and varied and the portions generous!  I love the high energy of this location and don't mind the small size as it adds to the intimacy of the space.  

Definitely give this spot a hot!

We came upon this restaurant by chance and it was terrific. 
It has friendly atmosphere and terrific food. The mushroon soup and the sea bass were sensational.
We will certainly return!

Nice brasserie in Harlem. One of the bartenders is a great mixologist. Food is representative of french brasserie food.  The only itch is one of the manager or owner who I assume named the place after himself. EGO!!!!  Think of Dwight from The Office  with a french accent.  Shall we say awkward.

Was very pleased over all with Cédric.   

 The prices are a tad high...but the food quality was great.  The service was ... spacey... very kind...and also very aloof & 'bizarre' at moments. 

I will be back.

I went with my friend and her 20 months old daughter for an early dinner. ( 5:00 PM) yesterday .We shared 3 appetizers ( smoked salmon, foie gras and tuna tartar) We also ordered the side of a french fries and all this with complimentary b+b was plenty for us.
Tuna tartar was delicious and sufficient. I would order it again. I didn't taste smoked salmon, but friend of mine was satisfied.Foie Gras was just OK. Next time I would try  foie gras ravioli instead.The service was tentative, pleasant and fair.
For those with little kids, they don't have  high chairs, but they were super nice to the little girl. Nevertheless  I would rather choose to  come here without my toddler, and that has nothing to do with the service just with the feeling of the space. And that's quite OK by me , as I believe that some places should be like this, where adults can actually get a brake.
Huge side wall windows  let the natural light in and that opens the space beautifully.
I will be back for a "real dinner" soon. I am glad Cedric's is the neighborhood.

Here's the short story: in mid-April I called to reserve a table for three for Friday, May 11th. I wanted to show off Harlem's newest gem to my pops (in town from the midwest). That Friday at around 4pm I hadn't heard from them and called to confirm the res. I couldn't believe my ears when they explained to me that they booked a private event for that evening.

They said they misplaced my cell number so couldn't call me to break the news...they apologized profusely....but really, that doesn't cut it. 

We ended up punting and hopped in a cab and headed to Gramercy Tavern. The stars must have realigned on the ride downtown... we got a table for 3 at the bar with no wait (at 6:45) and had an (obviously) incredible meal. 

As a new business I can appreciate that they are still learning the ropes and trying to capitalize on any opportunity to maximize sales... but this should not have happened - period - and when it did happen, they should have rectified the situation in a more professional manner. Don't give me "heartfelt apologizes," make it right.

I was so disappointed last night at Cedric's.  I was craving the curry and cream mussels so I went and the sauce was more butter, little curry and ground mustard on the bottom.  The crazy thing is I even asked the waiter about the chef last night and he said it was the head chef.  Very disappointed, definitely not the broth where I had previously ate a whole loaf of bread dipping in the broth and then wishing I could pour it on something to finish it.  I hope they read these posts and develop more consistency with the mussels.  Live music was good but it was too loud and I found myself shouting just to have a conversation.

I have been several times before and had a great experience, maybe it was a bad night.

This is currently my favorite place.  Living 2 blocks from here means it's really hard to stay away.  

My wife is a big fan of duck magret and Cedric really nailed it.  They serve it in a cherry sauce which is simply fabulous.  I've also tried the tuna steak with lentils and it's great too but the duck is hard to pass by.

For starters the mussels in white wine sauce might be the cleanest I've ever had.  I'm constantly commenting to my wife that I don't think I've ever had a grain of sand cross my lips eating them.  The sauce is so unbelievable I have to remind myself I'm in public when dipping bread in it.  The tuna tartar is also great.  It's served with avocado and a drizzled sauce that really warms up the flavor.

They took the chocolate lava cake off the dessert menu and it was wonderful but we were only bummed until we were served the chocolate mousse and creme brûlée.  Both were top notch.

The staff is full of friendly people and they don't miss a beat on making sure you have everything you want.

We must've eaten dinner here 10+ times since they opened and I can never wait to go back!

I had a surprisingly good dinner here.  The service was great, very attentive.  The wine list is small but well selected and reasonably priced per bottle.  The risotto was light and fresh.... sooo goood... and the mussels were delicious. All the salads were unique and I could eat them all again. right now.

We went to Cedric on a busy Friday night with a party of four.

Upon checking in on Yelp, we each received a complementary glass of champagne. We also ordered  a bottle of wine, as well as cocktails. The wine we ordered was a Chateau Margaux, priced at $65.00. It was very good and I would order it again. The cocktail list was as expected for a traditional French restaurant, no comparison tothe New American style trends.

For my appetizer I was debating between traditional foie gras and ravioli foie gras. I chose the traditional, but will get the ravioli in the future. Someone else at the table ordered tuna tartare and said it was awesome, I agree.

For dinner I ordered the duck. It was excellent, and I highly recommend it. I also sampled the bass (clean and fresh), lamb (not recommended), and steak (solid). For the most part, you can't choose a bad entree.

We did not order dessert, but the owner brought our table a few plates, which were all excellent.

Over all the night went very well. Excellent service, drinks, food and dessert. Def worth stopping in.

Great bistro good food - tale down that horrible TV that takes you from Paris to Newark, as well as tells women who aren't interested in watching sports that they really aren't important. Take the TV down and it becomes a magnificent restaurant with very good food.

We stepped into Cedric today just to check it out. Had a delicious grilled sandwich on a light baguette with a good crunchy crust. $14. The sandwich was  fresh and flavorful with a hint of heat. It came with a lightly dressed salad and fries. They've lightened up the room  by installing transom windows above the main windows. It looks great and brings in the street. Friendly attentive service. I'll definitely go back to check out the supper menu. It's a lovely room with a modern french hints without sinking into the disney brasserie decor. Why anyone would be offended by a gorgeous flower display is beyond me. Maybe they hate the ones at the Met too.

Big plus for 10026.

Had a yummy brunch with my hubby here. The atmosphere was nice and chill and culturally diverse. The food was good however the wait between ordering and receiving was a bit much as the place wasn't packed.  Nonetheless I'll be returning to enjoy another meal.

This a great restaurant, love the ambiance and corner layout. 

I had the curry mussels, it was delish. 

But yes I do agree with the other yelpers that it is quite pricey for the neighbourhood.

I was annoyed by Cedric's before having dined there because I had the impression that it, like other "SoHA" establishments that will remain unnamed was purposely trying to market and limit itself exclusively to white patrons. Therefore, my visit was meant to be an act of rebellion--crashing the party, if you will. 

Well, I was pleasantly surprised! I really enjoyed the decor and ambiance. I liked Mojo's vibe, but while Mojo was sultry and cavernous, Cedric's is open, airy (despite the tiny space), clean, fresh and elegant. The restaurant itself reminded me of a great bottle of Prosecco. Unlike Mojo, the food at Cedric's was also wonderful, even if the service was a bit aloof and even creepy at times (the manager/owner guy is ridiculously intimidating--there is no need to survey that tiny space like a hungry vulture, sir!). I had the Moules Marinieres for the precise purpose of comparing them to my beloved Moules Marinieres at Chez Lucienne, and they were delicious (though not necessarily better than Chez Lucienne's, which are also much less expensive on Thursdays). My dining compatriots all ordered the Jerk Chicken, and (we're of Jamaican/other West Indian descent) while it was certainly not jerk chicken, it was yumminess. The prices were a bit high for my liking, but Cedric's was still quite a treat.
I stopped by for some beef carpaccio and mushroom soup..it was so good. People are nice, setting is nice. Had some awesome creme brulee there too :)

I have wanted to eat here since it opened in the neighborhood a while back. Late one afternoon, we did just that.

The place is very nice, but the service is not great. And it was not like it was crowded mind you. Our server seemed more interested in her cell phone than taking care of us. The food however made up for it though. My leg of lamb dish was delicious. Came with a delicious sauce, couscous and a little side salad. My girlfriend had the steak in a peppercorn sauce with fries and the same side salad. Enjoyed the dish, but thought the sauce was a bit too much for her taste.

Wished we could have had dessert because they sounded good. Ok. Next time.

CONS: 
SOME...some of the staff just made the dining experience weird and distracting. They congregated at a corner booth right as you walk in and they could be heard speaking loudly (in French which was a nice touch) throughout the entire restaurant. It was unclear who worked there and didn't because some of the guys were dressed similarly in jeans and black shirts and shoes but then the girl behind the bar looked like she was still in high school, wearing ripped stockings, a jean jacket and gossiping the whole time. She was cursing here and there and when describing wines to customers actually said "The Chardonnay is, ehh." It really broke up conversation at my table and you almost felt like it was just a bunch of kids running the place. EXCEPT for my awesome waiter and host. They rocked.

PROS: 
My host and waiter were amazing; they were attentive, polite and make you want to go back for the servers that are actually professional. The decor is done nicely, it's a very clean and cozy place and massive corner windows make it hard to have anything but a wonderful table. The food was very good and presentation was nice, the menu is just perfect, not too much going on and you still get good variety. 

All in all we had a great time and will be going back... hopefully the immature bartender and corner-booth-social-club will have changed by then.

We really enjoyed our dinner there last night. Very good service with high quality food - a really nice dining experience. Escargot was tender, not rubbery, duck breast perfectly pan-seared. Highly recommended!
The best mussels ever !! Can't wait to go back !!

I really want to love this place but...it's too expensive for the neighborhood, food, and service. So far I've been twice. The first time was for brunch. I got the burger and it was a little gamey but still good. French fries were great. The salad came barely dressed, I could hardly tell if there was any on the salad at all.

The second time I came for dinner. I was a little disappointed that they have a 2 page wine list, but it doesn't specify which are available by the glass. When I asked the waitress, all I got was that they had Merlot, Pinot Noir, Cabernet and one other red. I would have expected a little more information, but that's all I got. I ended up going with the Cabernet, but then was surprised that the glass ended up being $10. That seems pretty expensive for only having the basic wines available with no other choices. would have expected it to be $7-8. 

The dinner I got was great, but it was $26 for the steak. I pay that much when I'm in the west village with great service...not sure why it needs to be that much in Harlem, especially with the service.

As for the service...The waitress took over 5 minutes to come and take my order (seems like a lot of time for such a small restaurant). I never saw her again after that. The bus boy brought my food/water/bread. I finished my glass of wine about half way through the meal and would have liked another, but no one noticed or stopped by to see how the food was. After I finished, my waitress was still MIA so I had to ask the bus boy for the check (never came), then i had to ask the host for my check. He was very nice and went to ring me up right away, but in helping me, he wasn't at the door and I could see that the owner/manager was annoyed because some people came in without getting greeted...but hey, maybe the waitress could have done her job and he would have been at the door to greet the newcomers.

Excellent French food served with a flair and charm. If you love authentic French food-this is the place to get it in Harlem for sure. The service is consistently good and they attract a nice cross section of patrons. I absolutely LOVE the mussels - Prove

This is the ultimate, cute and wonderful neighborhood bistro. I love everything from decor to staff to food (of course, food).

The tuna tartare appetizer is amazing. It's also a large portion which is always wonderful. It's a great share.

I had the duck and my husband had the lamb. Both were fabulous. The sauces for both were so phenomenal. The food really is wonderfully prepared and presented. And for a French bistro, the portions were also great.

The owner or manager (not sure which) was a huge presence in the restaurant, making rounds to all the tables. I love that.

Dessert was also pretty good. The cream puffs (Profiteroles) were just okay. They had the potential to be amazing but it just seemed like the pastry was a little overdone. It was covered in chocolate and whipped cream though. Maybe just an off day. The creme brulee was super and the Île Flottante (meringue) was also good.

A wonderful addition to the neighborhood.

Oh Cedric, went in for brunch two weeks ago with my lady and I found the ambiance to be quite nice, sadly that is where it ended. I liked the drinks on the brunch menu, although I found them to be pricey. The bacon stood out to me as not good with my omelet which was average but ridiculously over priced. If this place were less expensive I might go back to try other things on the menu. Overall the place is clean, the staff is friendly enough but the prices do not be fit the quality and leaves much to be desired for a 80 dollar bill. There are too many other options in the neighborhood to pay these prices.

i wanted and tried to make this my favorite spot  in harlem but the food is a disaster 3x in a row the owner  terrible ! im shocked that people think the food is fantastic  ? canned tuna  and saucy dry chicken  really ? ive been in harlem for 17yrs  i loved it then and i love now but without all the fraudulence . The only thing that kept me coming their was Dard  and his attention to detail and my experience and the service that i expect  maybe the owner should take his lead

I dined here with my girlfriend and another couple a couple of weeks ago, so I don't remember every detail.  We all took advantage of the Yelp Checkin offer, and we each received a glass of champagne, which is an excellent way to start an evening.  We ordered two red wines: A moderate-priced Chateau Margaux and a Bourgogne.  Both wines were excellent.

I did not partake in an appetizer, but everyone else seemed to enjoy their first course.  The tuna tartare, if I remember correctly, was very well-regarded.  I ordered the Roast leg of lamb with couscous with was great.  Initially, they brought me an over-cooked piece of meat.  Upon letting them know, they happily brought me another which was cooked properly and delicious.  My girlfriend ordered the duck, which was divine.  The cherry sauce complemented the meat quite well.  The other couple had a seabass and a steak.  I tried the steak, which was cooked and flavored very well.  The desserts were also great; We had two: a chocolate mousse and another that I can not recall.  The mousse was rich and smooth, and the other dessert was also great.

As mentioned earlier, the service was great.  Those who waited on us were very attentive.  The atmosphere is also quite nice; the restaurant is buzzing and the decor is very nice.
Great food. Great staff. Going back again for sure.

business.full_address:
3701 Chestnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Aroma Cafe

reviews.text: This place was so so. The breakfast wraps were good but the coffee was bad. The iced coffee was just their regular coffee with ice in it, no flavor or anything.

Great place for a quick lunch! I have been going here for a few weeks now and the quality has steadily gotten better. The service can be at times slow, but the food is wonderful. No condensed soups here - all of them are made daily by the owner! So that's a plus! And they make an awesome Peanut Butter Chocolate Smoothie!! It's amazing and filling! And if the owner is there you can convince him to make a Nutella Smoothie - it's divine!

International House's Aroma Cafe is not a restaurant or much of a cafe. It might have an Aroma, but I have such a lousy sense of smell I can't comment.  It's kinda like a food cart inside; there is coffee so I guess it is a cafe.

IHAC has a sandwich press, which is great if you like paninis, tosted sandwiches or wraps hot. I'm usually happy just eating cold sandwiches, but given the choice I'll opt for my sandwich to be George Formaned. The menu board is full of good looking options and I've tried a few of the sandwiches and wraps to go. The people that work there are pretty friendly which is one of the reasons I've gone back a few times. 

Unfortunately I'm always disappointed in my choice by the time I start eating.  I blame the potato chips. I think what happens is when they toss the potatochips into the Styrofoam clamshell with the hot sandwich the chips end up soggy AND the sandwich ends up absorbing the fat and salt from the chips, leaving it tasting like soggy potato chips every time.

The space itself is as comfortable as the back seat of a Volkswagen with an overheated engine; it's definitely an order and leave kind of set up. The bathroom is somewhere hidden in the International House.  The muffin/bagel selection always looks beat by the time lunch rolls around and is fly fodder that should be chucked after 10AM.  Now that summer is here I probably won't be eating any hot sandwiches for a while but may give Aroma another chance in the fall.

My office recently moved to 39th and Chestnut. I had passed this cafe on my way into work numerous times and decided it was finally time to give it a try. The reviews were pretty good and it sounded like they used fresh ingredients. 

I walked over for lunch at around 12:30. The OPEN sign wasn't lit, and the inside looked dark. I peered through the window and saw one person sitting at a table, so I felt safe to go inside. Word to the management: please, turn your OPEN sign on! 

It took me a little while to choose from the menu because there were a number of delicious sounding options like the "aroma verdura" (a wrap with vegetables, mozzarella and pesto) and the "avocado panini" (a grilled panini with guacamole, cheese, tomatoes and chicken). I decided on the "lena bella" a wrap with roasted peppers, roasted eggplant, romaine lettuce, hummus and feta. It came wrapped in a tomato basil tortilla with a side of chips. To my surprise, the wrap was grilled on the panini grill which and it was quite tasty and warm. The only thing I would ask for is more vegetables! I wonder if I could ask them to double the veggies? I would pay extra for more eggplant and peppers! 

I'll be back for sure.

While I found my first experience to merit three stars I do feel that Cafe Aroma can own up to a higher ranking in the not too distant future. It's a fairly new cafe located inside the International House (http://www.yelp.com/biz/international-house-philadelphia) which is one of my favorite West Philly spots. So it definitely has a prime location. I just didn't find it to be that great for coffee and a muffin.

the guy working the counter was extremely friendly and accommodating. But I found the self serve coffee that I picked up to just be average. And the chocolate chip muffin I picked out was good, but tasted exactly like the one's that Wawa offers. So in essence I could have got the exact same thing that I picked out at Wawa for a bit less.

But upon checking out the menu afterwards I found out that I chose wrong (D'oh!). They have a full fledged cappuccino bar that can spruce up you caffeinated treatsTheir menu has offerings like a jerk chicken wrap, double cheese quesadillas, homemade oatmeal, and plenty of veggie sandwiches and salads. They even hook up a variety of smoothies and milkshakes, and a combo deal where you can score a soup and a sandwich for $7-8. Second chance here I come!

business.full_address:
3801 Chestnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Jolly's Dueling Pianos & American Beer Bar

reviews.text: Great service, food, and drinks. Definitely recommend Wednesday happy hour

I did a little happy hour at Jolly's last week with a couple of colleagues.

They have some nice beers on tap. The happy hour prices are good, but typically don't apply to all the beers on tap. The night I went it only applied to the two local beers. However, different nights offer different happy hour specials. I was happy with the two local beers.

They also had 1/2 price apps and 35 cents wings. I had some buffalo wings and Thai wings. Both were very tasty.

I also had some Awesome. That's right, they have an app called Awesome. Why, because it's Awesome. I had no idea what I was getting when I ordered it, but did just because it was called Awesome. The menu had this as the description: Pecan smoked bacon, housemade ranch, shredded cheese. They left out one very key detail. It's French Fries topped with the aforementioned description. Well, maybe if I cocked my head up a little and realized it was the 3rd item listed under a larger header that is titled "Basket of House Cut Fries." But seriously, a few beers later and who wants to look that far up?

But anyway, the Happy Hour was good. The food was good. The Awesome was awesome. And they have some nice beers.

PROS: Live piano, large portions, tasty fish tacos
CONS: Crappy service, long waits

The food was okay --- slightly above average bar fare that took 30 minutes to get to us.  The appetizer and main entrees came together. Our water was never refilled. The waitress almost completely ignored us and forgot to bring the condiments we asked for. The piano was fun but got boring after a while.
Meh. No piano playing. Rather calm. It looked more like a restaurant that didn't serve food than a bar.

I effin love this place! The piano guys are so talented they can cover literally ANYTHING and they're all about getting the crowd involved which if your a total ham like me you will adore. Not to mention the food and service is top notch especially the burgers nomzzzz. Also the bartenders have an amazing drink menu which will have you feeling like you are the x factor.

I went here on a Monday evening, so I wasn't able to see the dueling pianos. But I was able to taste the food. I had the Devil Burger, which was cooked perfectly. The Chesapeake Bay Fries were awesome with lump crab meat. Side salad tasted very fresh. 
The service was great. Asked if I had any questions about the beer list, made specials clear to me, and offered samples of any beer I wanted. 
This place is pretty awesome. I hope to go back for dinner again soon!

business.full_address:
525 W 120th St
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Grace Dodge Cafe

reviews.text: Food is pretty average quality and a bit pricey.  Half the time whoever's preparing my food serves it with a nice side of 'tude.  There are slightly better options nearby.

I love the TC dining hall! It's set up into stations: hot food, grill, salads, cold sandwiches, pizza, and soup. They have really great deals on breakfast- eggs, bacon/sausage, and toast for between $3-$4. The hot food options are actually pretty good and as gourmet as cafeteria food can get- they often do stuff like salmon with chutney, roast turkey with all the trimmings (my fave!), and chicken saltimbocca. What I love the most is that the cooks are SUPER friendly and nice :) 

They also have a sushi station that sets up on Wednesdays only- be careful if you are in a rush, though- the sushi is good but takes FOREVER to make. I'm not a huge fan of the cold sandwiches, though- too dry and not enough flavor. Overall, a great place to grab food near Columbia (I think you'll need a Columbia or TC ID to get in, though...)

First let me say that most importantly, the food offered here is generally of good quality. The pizza is delicious, and they often have specials for the day (cheese sticks, calzones, etc.) to offset the normal menu items. There is also a sandwich station with a variety of options to choose from, and a salad station that offers a wide variety of topping options. I'm not as familiar with the grilling station, but the several times I have ordered from there, the burgers and fries I got were made well. Even better, none of these items cost very much. It's rare that for any meal including a drink that I pay over $10. 

The downside is, they are so often out of ingredients that they often become useless to me. They frequently are out of basic things that they need to operate--lettuce for salads, meat and cheeses for sandwiches, pepperoni or cheese for pizzas, etc. It seems reasonable to think that basic elements required for the food they sell would be in stock, but often it's not the case. 

The moral of the story is that when they have food available, it's great for the price, but don't count on being able to order simple menu items.

Great variety and a very good school cafeteria. I ate bacon cheeseburger deluxes here for a solid semester, gaining a good 10 lbs, but man, it was worth it. They were very good burgers.

On the healthy side, they have giant salads, too. Coffee, tea, you name it. The lines can get long and if there is something special going on at the school it can be hard to find a seat, but why are you reading this? You are either a student, staff or faculty and already know these things, or you are an outsider who doesn't have the presence of mind to yelp such an obscure dining establishment...I guess I could be wrong...

And today I was reminded why I normally dine off-campus. In what I guess was an attempt at promoting healthfulness, they had a promo for a free fountain soda with a wheat personal pizza. My wheat shrimp pizza was transformed, I assume in the oven, to a white shrimp pizza and rendered the only reason I went for this option irrelevant. Luckily, the pizza turned out well regardless and the cashier was very nice about it, or I'd knock my rating down to 2 stars. The fountain raspberry iced tea, however, tasted like cream soda without even a hint of raspberry.

CulinArt is a step ahead of the previous vendor (Sage) in regards to the TC cafe, however with all these new fancy additions they lack on simple things. You can't get a veggie side you must order the whole hot meal. No small side salads anymore. Pricing isn't often available at the cashier if you order something off of main menu.  It's better than Sage for sure but they have a long way to go. The best thing about CulinArt is the sushi chef on Wednesdays.

We all know that school cafeterias bank on the fact that students and faculty will often be too lazy to go anywhere else. The coffee is easily the worst I've ever had (that includes McDonalds' coffee). I've never met one person who didn't hate it. The pizza station has the looks of an old fashioned brick oven pizzeria, but the pizzas are haphazardly thrown together and drowned in sauce. The guy ignores you if you ask for garlic knots, and generally frowns if you even order from him. The cold sandwich station is decent but the servers there tend to ignore you for a while until they finish conversing with their friends. No "can I help you?" or anything like that. I am not sure what to do, so I usually wait until they look at me and then order. Sometimes they continue their conversation, other times they listen and make the sandwich. The hot breakfasts are fine, as are the hot lunches, and if you are willing to wait 10 minutes for some eggs, that's a fine option. The salads are mediocre; go to appletree if you want a better one. The cashiers are always very friendly, which is generally the most pleasurable part of eating here. Finally, the seating area, while old-fashioned and kind of drab, is a good place to eat if all the seats at the pizza place are filled. We all know how these places work. It allows TC to feed it's students as cheaply as possible while giving the illusion of semi-fine dining. In reality, this is crappy food dressed up to look decent. The service staff are often more interested in socializing with one another than they are with serving people. A new food provider and service staff would be a start.

TC cafe always has vegetarian options which I appreciate and the prices are great.  A salad with a Salmon fillet cooked to order will run you about $6.  Amazing for NYC!  The dining hall itself is a beautiful old room which feels like a connection to the past academics who've walked the halls.  Breakfast is good too.  Always lots of options for grilled-to-order items, salads, soup, pizza, etc.

Grace Dodge Cafe makes some pretty okay food. However, they take way too long to serve you and cook your food. This isn't a fancy restaurant, it's a cafeteria. Waiting 45 minutes for a burger and fries is just not acceptable to me.

Plus, many of the guys who work there are moody. Would a smile really kill you? I think not!

Overall, it gets the job done if you are hungry and want a bite, however, notice I didn't say quick bite!

This one of the best dining hall food I have ever eaten. The food is edible woot woot!! thats a first right?  The salads are great and there are so many topping you can put into it. My friends get them all the time and they are a decent size. I have never had their breakfast but I heard it is pretty good as well. 

Everyone is friendly and the dining hall in itself is gorgeous. You can just sit there and do work without anyone bothering you.

School cafeteria?! You typically think frozen dinner style: bland, overcooked food. NOT HERE! The food is good, seriously, and cheap! 

The cafe has a few options: hot food (like pot roast with carrots and grilled veggies), hot sandwiches (grilled chicken with tots), salad, soups, pizzas, sandwiches, ice cream, and the list goes on. 

I wanted to try a few of the different stands before reviewing to get a total idea of the cafe and hey, because it's 5 mins from my office! 

So here's the lowdown: 
pizzas-delish! Especially when trying to make it through the day a wee bit hungover! 
sandwiches-my go-to place for lunch 
hot sandwich bar-avoid, takes too long to prepare and doesn't leave me time to check Yelp and Facebook on my break.
Cafeteria. Pizza is okay and the salads are decent and large in quantity.

business.full_address:
4835 Rhode Island Ave
Hyattsville, MD 20781
business.name: Mountjoy's Autoshop & Auto Parts

reviews.text: Recently bought a 1970 Triumph TR6 (aka, the money pit), and took it here to get looked at for mechanical issues (which I knew it would have). They identified all of the problems and did the work quickly and professionally. When one of the repairs didn't stick (the clutch rebuild on these is tricky), they took it back no questions asked and redid the whole job for no charge. It's clear that they are experts in these kinds of cars. The prices are fair--if you expect that an old British car is going to be cheap you have another thing coming. I will definitely be here again for jobs I can't do myself.

Say you have a 1969 Jaguar XK-E and need hard to find parts for it.... well okay they can get them. Say you need them to install the very hard to find parts since not to many people works on the old classic cat car anymore...... okay no problem they can do that too. If it's British and very old that you have then you have come to the right place. They have a passion for British automobiles.

That's right for the past 25 or so years I have been keeping my old Triumph alive and running thanks in no doubt to the very knowledgeable guys here at Mountjoy's. Whenever I need a part for it these guys come through or they know of a way I can skirt around it with a subsitute part or when ever I throw my hands up in defeat I just take my old British roadster to them and know that they will fix it right where I have failed. So don't pay attention to the "Stupid Question Stick" that's sitting at the front counter. The only stupid question is the one that is not asked and causes more problems in the long run. They will get you in the right direction and keep you there. So go ahead and take your old Lotus, Jaguar, MG, Triumph, Austin Healey, Land Rover or what ever under the British Empire that you may have in your garage, these guys have skill to keep you on the hi-roads.

business.full_address:
3419 Walnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Modern Eye

reviews.text:
i was in need of transferring a prescription from an uncomfortable set of frames into 2 frames i bought from boutiques in ny. thinking "americas best optical" was a cheaper spot to start, they were rude & wouldn't transfer my prescription without the paperwork. the cost wasn't worth the aggravation.

so, i stopped into MODERN EYE & even though i didn't buy my frames from them, they were amazingly helpful & read the prescription from my original glasses. done done done...and i was lucky & got the discount on the 2nd pair!!!

so, if you think you can't afford this place...think again. they're helpful, affordable, & terribly knowledgeable. worth every penny. i almost wished i had just gone here instead of finding frames in ny.

My first eye exam ever. I had no idea I had eye troubles. I had my eyes checked by the optometrist there, Bryan Machamer. He was a total baller. Very relaxed, knew his thing, and explained everything. He even had advice (I'm a computer scientist so my life = screens) that was reasonable. He did give me the party line (rest every 20 minutes of screen time, yeah, like I'd have a career if I did that...) but explained that he knew it was unrealistic and gave me some more advice that was more realistic.

I'm coming back every year for my annual eye exam. (He even said not to bother, that at my age I needn't return more than every couple of years, but I'm the paranoid sort.)

The people with the frames were very helpful too. They've got good taste, and although I didn't end up ordering there (they were backlogged in orders and I wanted my frames much sooner), they have an excellent selection.

I'll never buy my glasses anywhere else. I was skeptical at first and bought a few pairs of crappy glasses from those shops with the 2 for $69 deals - ill never do that again. I picked a pair at Modern Eye, was quoted a price (and given a discount), and decided to go for it. Expecting a wait of a week or more, I paid, and they told me to wait. My glasses would be out in 10 minutes (ok granted, they have no prescription). 10 minutes later, there they were. Fabulous and I love em (I'm wearing them right now)! I can't wait to get more pairs from Modern Eye.

I took in a pair of sunglasses to have nosepads put in or the frames tightened. The fellow who helped me--I believe his name was Tom--assured me right away that tightening the frames was a far better option, both for aesthetics and cost, and he set to work. While he was working on the frames, he pointed out to me that the lenses were bowing out slightly, and promised to get them fully back into the frames.

In the process of getting them back into the frames, unfortunately, one of the lenses cracked. He was immediately very contrite and went straight into the storeroom to look for matching lenses. They had matching lenses in stock, so he promised to replace the lenses that afternoon.

The sunglasses were fixed within half an hour. Tom had me try them on again and made a few additional adjustments to the fit--and then didn't charge me. I hadn't expected him to charge me for the lenses, but he didn't charge me for the significant time and effort he'd expended on the fit, either. 

As ever, the staff at Modern Eye is attentive, helpful, and incredibly thoughtful. I look forward to paying them next time, as this is a business well worth supporting.

absolutely amazing. Consistently outstanding and dependable.  Kind, talented staff, Dr. Chris is the best, and the selection of eyeglasses are spectacular.  One of the finest such places I have ever been to -- anywhere in the world

Modern Eye definitely has a great selection of glasses but the frames can be really expensive. I bought a pair of reading glasses that were $60 but I was pleased with the service and quality of the glasses.

I love Modern Eye and  have been going to this place since forever! Dale and Kate are the absolute best! The other staff members are super helpful and very nice. Drs Chris and Bryan are knowledgeable, downt to earth and approachable. I have a friend, who flies in from London just to get her eye exam and glasses here. You can't go wrong going to Modern Eye.

Coolest eye office ever. Staff is super friendly and helpful. Doctor Bryan was really approachable and down to earth. I got an exam and glasses prescription. They have a great collection and will help you honestly pick out the best pair for you. I had to try on about 15 pairs and they were happy to humor me, but I ultimately chose the first pair they picked out-- of course! I'd unreservedly recommend this place.

I went to Modern Eye because of all of their fabulous reviews on Yelp (thanks Yelpers!) and I wasn't disappointed!  Dr. Chris was great and the staff was knowledgeable and very helpful.  I found super cute frames and the prescription is perfect .  I've never had glasses that were fitted as well as these were, thanks to the great staff.  They really know what they're doing and are really nice and make you feel comfortable while you're there.  I highly recommend this place!

Just got my frames from here. AMAZING selection. Pretty good service, Tom helped me and he's very nice. I tried on a ton of frames. Most will cost you for frame around $300-$400 (they have pricier and maybe some lower, but every one I tried on was in that price range.) This does not include the lenses. Of course, my insurance would never cover these frames! But, the selection was the best, esp if you are looking for cool, dark or vintage-y looking pair. They do a good business, always busy. Maybe a little too busy...they were running around busy, but once I asked if they could take me seriously....I wanted to purchase two pairs, Tom focused more on me.  I guess I wanted a little more after reading reviews, seeing that I was spending so much and need lots of advice when I pick out glasses, but I was overall happy with the experience.

I used to walk by Modern Eye all the time + always assumed it'd be way too expensive since their decor is fabulous -- with Victorian couches and nice art, and a truly lovely store. I was used to going to places like Four Eyes and Pearl Vision.

Then, Iswitched jobs and  was looking for a new eye dr. that accepted my new insurance and saw Modern Eye on the list of Optometrists. I was really excited to give them a try, admittedly, purely on aesthetics of their store.

I was not disappointed! I've had several exams there and everyone who works there is super friendly, informative and seem to genuinely enjoy their work. They stock really stylish, hip frames, but the prices really are very reasonable (being that the frames are designer). 

I wasn't planning on getting new glasses, but was sucked in by the awesomeness of their selection. The guy helping me was super honest about what looked good + bad and had a great eye for what style would work on me. 

I highly recommend anyone with vision needs to give Modern Eye a shot.

Bingo, bango. 

Modern Eye has never let me down. Five years later and my specs still garner oodles of compliments. 

Next time I need glasses, I am taking a vacation to Philly for a fitting. (Did you know that Modern Eye ships? I do, because I've had glasses mailed to me! This is what happens when you move away right after you find your dream glasses.)

I feel compelled to write a glowing review of this eye center. Modern Eye was highly recommended by several people on yelp, google, and a host of other sites, and being that I needed to get my eyes checked, as well as a new prescription of glasses, this seemed to be the safest bet. Their eye exams are very thorough, and their doctors are extremely knowledgable. (I have been going to eye doctors for over 20 years, so I do know quite a bit)

The pair of glasses I got were great, until recently they broke. I contacted them the next day, and within the same day, they ordered a new pair, no cost, and sent me home with a back up pair of glasses, only paying for the frame which was discounted.  

I would highly recommend Modern Eye. Their doctors are terrific, and their service is amazing.

Now THIS is eye candy.  

Beautiful, high quality eyeglasses that last and last, making the somewhat pricey frames quite affordable when you spread it out over time.

Lovely staff that have the the best eye for what fits your face. When I go there, I don't even look around.  I only pick from what they bring me and it is always exquisite and perfect for me and my face.

The only downside to this place is that you want to take them all!!!!!!!!!!!  There are so many pairs of beautiful glasses!

These guys are great.  Staff really took the time to help me find a perfect pair of glasses.  Of course, I ended up going with the first pair that they showed me.  But first I had to try on at least 30 others.  Great service; excellent frames.

had eye exam for contacts. excellent service. i had trouble wearing contacts, and they were very patient with me and made sure i felt comfortable wearing them before they handed me some samples. then i had some problems with dry eye. i went back for 3 follow ups and they offered me to try 5 different types until i settled on one type. there was no extra charges for that. the price for the exam was very reasonable considering i had to go back 5 times and try 5 different samples.

I had to revisit Modern Eye last week to see if one of the embellishments on my frames could be replaced when I noticed it fell out. They not only replaced the frames for free (because it was within my one year warranty) but the fella behind the counter even noticed the lens was scratched and took it upon himself to have those replaced as well, so I didn't need to waste my time making another trip. And that was also covered in my one-year warranty! This kind of stellar customer service is hard to come by these days, but it's not lost on me! Hip hip, hooray!!

Super nice glasses. Really good, eager service. 

But the prices are astronomical. I don't want to sound cheap but when did glasses become so so so expensive. I guess when celebraties where them... Damn you Sarah Palin! 

I won't blame this shop, however. I think these folks do a fine business.

This place is great.
I went in to today with a pair of glasses I'd bought online. They were the only place I found in the city that would tighten them up for me. No fee, they just told me I could make a donation to their SPCA charity piggy bank (which of course I did). 
My husband bought glasses and sunglasses here a few months ago. We likes so many of the frames we had a hard time choosing. He loves both pairs, and they look great on him.
The staff was warm and friendly on both occasions. They are experts with a great product! Four thumbs up from our family!

Beware of the people at Modern Eye.  I've been going there for eight years, and I am not sure how they do this -- whether it is through all those weird high-tech machines they say are for testing your eyesight, or the absurdly fun, friendly people who work there at least at the University City location) or maybe the mad genius Dr. Chris putting stuff in the eye drops--but I know that they have changed me.  I used to hate wearing glasses.  Now I can't wait for my eyes to get worse so that I can justify going in and getting new frames.  I hardly ever wear my contact lenses any more,  but they do a great job with contact prescriptions as well:  I just like wearing glasses, something I never thought I'd find myself saying.  It's entirely their fault.  

They have the best frames in the city, hands down.  I always ask them to help me pick out frames, because it goes so much faster:  they have great taste.  They'll tell you if something looks wrong.  In fact, part of my addiction to Modern Eye is because I have never had so many compliments in my life as I now get on my glasses.  No matter where I travel, people are always saying, "I love your glasses, where did you get them?"  I don' t know where that other reviewer went, but I can assure you that there are no tasteless people at the University City location ( will refrain from cannibalism joke).

I totally agree with the previous posters. I've stopped here several times to get help fixing some frames. The optometrist here has always been helpful, generous with his time, and even when he's needed screws and such, never charged me.

I always vowed to bring my business here. If you're a Lenscrafters/Wal Mart some of person, the price tags will scare you away. But if you want to rest assured that you've got quality, style, and a place that won't forget about you after the register closes, Modern Eye is 20/20 like Barbara Wawa.

A hipster optometrist- what next?? Major props to this little oasis of eye care. Helpful, professional and thorough. Got myself some super hipster glasses, was fitted for contacts and walked out partly blind (thanks to being dilated on the sunniest Winter day I've encountered), but thoroughly pleased. I can't recommend this optometry store enough...Oh they have a great collection of sunglasses as well, if you're fortunate enough to not need contacts or glasses...

I like this place a lot. They've been supportive when I try to little avail to finally get contacts in my eyes (sometimes for over an hour in a sitting). I've been seeing their doctors for years and they take nice care of me. The array of glasses is phenomenal, hundreds. I currently have a pair of Ollie's by salt that I've been using since March of this year; check them out at http://www.contactsandspecs.com/salt-optics/Salt-Optics-Ollie-11892.aspx
I came in the other day for a routine adjustment of my glasses that were askew, no cost of course. They remember me and ask how I'm doing, give a couple smiles and send me on my way in no time with a sharp brow and aligned not so bi-focals. They ask me how I'm doing and whether my last repair turned out satisfactory. People friendly, user friendly, check out their selection and they'll give you ample time to peruse kindly and give honest opinions. Not only that, they'll give you multiple opinions from different glasses wearers. If you're bashful you can try on more pairs than you think, if you're not don't hesitate. If you're in to transitions or prescription sunglasses they carry many of those as well. They have provided me with a case and cleaning cloth every time I purchased a new pair. Not to mention that their exhibits of quirky eye wear models doing poses with some kind of alteration that makes them have an eye for a head or something optical of that manner. They have little toys that kids can play with on one counter, which I did as a kindergartener on with glasses.
