The hip layout of Modern eye is intensified by a spotless counter sharp over a smooth tile floor, sometimes they have this trance like music playing with a pleasant up beat and mild bass. Once you're in you're completely flanked by translucent lenses and an esher painting of frames. 

I definitely recommend them. They're pricey, but it's worth it.

My husband could not find glasses anywhere. We drove down to this store from Allentown, PA based on other recommendations here. The sales person was very helpful and made the process fun. Hubby got glasses and is happy. He gets compliments on the frames everywhere he goes. If you want an excellent selection, this is the place!

I can't rave about Kate highly enough at this location!  She went out of her way to help me with both sunglasses and new lenses for my glasses.  She's made me a loyal customer.  Not to mention they have a great selection.  Check them out!

My experience was great at Modern Eye until I realized that the glasses I had picked were not a good fit for me so I went to change them and it happened that the ones I like were $300 cheaper than the initial ones but they do not refund you ... But I had paid cash so he ended up refunding me cash, thank you guys you rock and I will come back in 2 years for my new frame!!!!!
Great selection of frames.  Great service -- both choosing frames and during the eye exam.  Plus, they take my insurance.

This place is just the best.  Incredible selection of frames including Paul Frank, which has some great stuff at very reasonable prices ($200 frames!!).  The staff here is out of this world.  I must have tried on 30 pairs of frames and the person helping me out was the best.  He gave me honest opinions and did not try and push expensive frames off on me.  Extremely cool atmosphere.  They have my business for years to come.
Super nice.  They tightened my sunglasses at no charge.  How often does that happen in West Philadelphia?  Yeah, that's what I thought.

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place. They have a great selection of frames. The prices aren't my favorite thing in the world, but this place makes me happy. And honestly, they have cheap frames and expensive frames...though I have expensive taste.
The whole staff is SO down to earth. Dr. Bryan checked my eyes and he was so nice and talkative. The staff helped me pick out a wide array of frames with different price points...all according to my vague explanation of what I was looking for. It wasn't hard to come to a decision, as everyone there is super helpful...and honest. ;)

I LOVE Modern Eye.

I went in looking for some new frames and wasn't quite sure what I wanted. The staff was amazing-- they didn't mind pulling probably upwards of 30 frames for me to try. Though the frames were kind of pricey, they never pushed to get the most expensive ones, and even helped me save money by telling me about a coupon for half off lenses on their website. When I went back in to pick up my frames about a week later, the guy remembered my name.

About a week after that, I went to the Barbary and one of the guys who works at Modern Eye was working the door. I said "I know you!" He said "Modern Eye?" I said "Yeah!" and he let me in for $5 instead of $8.

My boyfriend recently got an eye exam and frames there. Again, they pulled tons of frames (with the same guy that helped me), told him about the coupon, and when he went for his eye exam, the doctor knocked off another $100. His frames were originally $312, plus about $70 for the lenses and another $70 or so for an anti-glare treatment. He ended up paying under $300.

If I could marry the place, I would.

I never knew an optometrist could be so hip/cool/down-wid-it.  All the workers look like they possibly have side jobs at M.A.C. makeup since they have that funky-fresh alternative look to them.  Dr Anastasiou is really down-to-earth and down-to-business.  This place claims to be "the hippest most modern eyewear in the land" and to have "an over-dedicated, very-involved, non-comission staff that won't let you leave with a pair of eyeglasses that looks bad."  Check out their web-page at http://www.modern-eye.com/ it's kinda creepy kinda cool.

I have lived away from "home" for 15 years now, but always waited for return trips to visit my beloved family eye doctor. He is amazing. And Modern Eye was amazing enough to make me make the switch! I have now been a customer here for about 5 years, and I couldn't be happier. The docs are great, the customer service is phenomenal, and while my glasses were a little pricey 3 years later I still love them. The staff really has an eye for what looks good on you, and helps you find a frame that looks good and meets your budget. I recently had trouble with my contact lenses, and Dr. Bryan was excellent - he kept working with me to try drops, different solutions, and different lenses until I found something that worked. I couldn't recommend them more highly, and I imagine that once I leave Philly I'll once again be saving my eye appts. for return trips.

I stand outside this store and admire the sheer creepiness of their window displays--the rotating scenes of voluptuous women admiring the man with the eyeball for a head, or posed barbie bodies (heads also replaced with giant, plastic eyeballs), or the nativity scene with the eyeball as the Christ child. They're really quite glorious. I first entered to try and convince the store owners to give me one of the eyeball shirts on the mannequins in the window. No luck there (not that I won't try again), but they fixed my bent glasses for free. That was nice. 

I bought my next pair of glasses at Modern Eye because they have such a great selection of brightly colored, but unobtrusive metal frames... a rare find when the current fashion leans toward thick, plastic-framed hipster-wear or old-man, accountant chic (comb-over not included). A bit expensive, true, but you can find frames that aren't exorbitantly so. 

*If you want a huge selection of frames, from Harry Potter to hipster to please-take-me-seriously academic to old-school uncool, GO HERE.

*The staff is wonderful. If you're not sure what will look best on your face and want someone to throw the best options at you, GO HERE. 

*If you have a habit of bending your glasses beyond recognition and needing them bent back into place, GO HERE. 

*The staff (is wonderful and) will work with you and your insurance. If you want someone who's willing to go the extra mile to make sure you get your glasses covered, GO HERE.

*And if you really like creepy eyeball displays, GO HERE... but please bring me that eyeball t-shirt I so covet.

Super super super experience all around. You will not find a better place for eye care. Beyond the very thorough and well-explained eye exam, the staff was awesome. I am usually a wreck when having to pick out eyeglass frames, but they were patient and helpful, and even gave their opinions in helping me select frames that I love.

Never go out of business or I'll be wandering the streets blind.

I've been a customer for years. All the staff and doctors know me by name, and I even get a little friendly harassment when I stop in. They even fill out my stupid insurance forms. I love these guys. Really, I actually have fun at the eye doctor and look forward to my visits!

Doctor Chris gives the best exams I've ever had. If you have never had an exam by an actual doctor and have only went to mall cheapo eye places, you will be shocked on the thoroughness of his exam.  He's even seen me without notice when I had an injury. He explains things to me and answers questions. 

They have the best frames around. I used to wear contacts most of the time, but over the years they have convinced me glasses are cool. With a little feedback, I sit back and let the staff choose for me most of the time. They even debate about the best pair. I only wish I could take them all clothes shopping so they can dress me too. 

It's not the cheapest place around, but I'm willing to spend more on cool frames that everyone sees on my face every single day. I'll never go anyplace else.

Great selection. Great, patient, friendly service. Ah, and I can see now.

(Not expressly a budget frame place, though they do have some good deals, so don't count it out if you're on a budget!)

business.full_address:
3815 US Rt 1
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Courtyard by Marriott Princeton Hotel

reviews.text:
Very nice, posh hotel. Really modern & nice lounge area downstairs. Always fast service, and they have an automated wake up call system so you can be assured they won't forget due to human error. The 24 hour gym was nice.

We had a huge block order for a work conference - probably over 30 rooms. There was some mix up (not sure what all the details are) where one of my co-workers asked for extra rooms which, it turns out, had already been added to our order. This somehow resulted in them resetting the keys to all our rooms so even those of us who had checked in a day early had to come back down to get new keys. It was some big mix up that took a lot of time, and I'm still not sure whether it was our fault or theirs.

This review is from this april. Woops lol.

But Wow! This place was beautiful and awesome and just pretty much mind blowing.  There was Free dinner every night which was delicious every time! And there was beer and wine with dinner too. Freaking awesome. There was a full kitchen and they even provided Popcorn in the room! I loved this place and can NOT wait to go back

Great staff at this hotel that make the stay so much better. The front desk really goes out of their way to be nice, 

The rooms are clean. There are 150 rooms often fully occupied due to location, about 6 suites and there are 25 rooms with additional ammenities that aren't suites. The lobby also has a few frozen foods, pints of ice cream, snacks, and beverages.

The breakfast staff is also very nice (anna and another lady). They remember all your habits so its easy to go to the lounge, grab a WSJ or whatever newspaper you want and walk across and get your breakfast. Fruit, waffle machine, yogurts, oatmeal, eggs, muffins, they make omelets, etc. Its a great breakfast there!

The only downfall is the internet (golden tree) is a bit off depending on how far frmo the center of the hotel you are. This can be fixed if you call IT help or change your wireless band to only recieving B instead of A and B alternating.

The fitness room is a bit small but the upside is there are the chanels you have in your room on the teradmill. It is 24/hour key access,

Comfortable beds, reasonable rates, good amenities (especially flatscreens with HD channels in every room).  The only thing wrong with this hotel was the scratchy towels and toilet paper.

I'd stay here again.

I came here for a demonstration meeting.  As a result, I did not stay here but was promptly greeted at the front desk upon my arrival.  The gentleman directed me to the conference room where the even was held.  My colleague was with me and not feeling well.  The guy at the counter sold him medication and provided a free bottle of water.  Very great service I must say.....!
High price, dingy rooms with loud wall mount ac, paint pealing from bathroom ceiling, stains on walls, wall paper pealing off, breakfast order to go was incomplete........

Stayed (currently staying) here for work. Reserved via Marriott website.

Checking in went fine.

Room was clean.

Nothing I can complain about.

Rooms are nice and roomie... plenty of non-furniture-occupied walking space.

Indoor pool/spa is a bonus.

"Fitness room" is small: 2 treadmills, 1 elliptical, 1 work out bench, and weights from 5-50lbs (1 set each at 5 lb increments). Not quite enough for a trained professional like myself... but enough to get a decent work-out in.

Located on a confusing stretch of Route 1 (confusing for a West Coaster like me) which required a U-turn if you're coming here from the south on Route 1.

Only "walkable" place to eat is Ruby Tuesday.

Had breakfast buffet one morning (10.95) -- typical hotel buffet.

This three star is NOT a "bad" review... I was neither disappointed nor "wowed". Sorry Marriott!

business.full_address:
2766 Broadway
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Carlton Tower Cleaners

reviews.text:
I brought my LBD here to be taken in a bit around the waist.  $58.
1 week later when I picked it up, it didnt fit! They made the dress too small and instead of feeling bad, they told me i gained weight!  Really? I gained weight in one week?    

No remorse. No money back. No more Carlton.  

p.s. Im calling the Better Business Borough.
Great dry cleaners!  Prices are normal for NY and the service is fast and reliable!  Great owner, great working staff!

Uhmmm... If you like spending $9 per garment... this is the place for you.  I moved recently and this cleaners is closest to me.  I'm not sure if the prices are higher because they claim to be "organic," but the prices are way too high!  I might have to walk the two blocks to my old cleaners who charge approx $6 an item.

Don't go there. I've been insulted like never before just because I wanted an explanation about the destruction of some buttons on my shirts... Among other things, the guy told me that he "doesn't give a shit about the customers" and that the customers are "little bitches"... It's not a joke : the guy almost hit me and I was about to call the police. I finally decided to go and move on... DO NOT GO THERE !!!

business.full_address:
3041 Broadway
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Union Theological Seminary Landmark Guest Rooms

reviews.text:
Union Theological Seminary rents rooms. The rates are $135.00 (single occupancy: $156.93w/tax) and $165.00 (double occupancy: $191.35w/tax) per night per room. I don't know if you've tried to rent a hotel in New York in this price range that doesn't involve staying in a cardboard box under a bridge overpass. I once rented a room in this neighborhood for about $100 a night and the bed was one foot smaller than the room itself. 

OK. Union is at W 121 and might not be downtown, but it is at Columbia University and the 1 train is about three blocks away. There are plenty of restaurants and sights right there. I arrived on a Friday afternoon and there was plenty of safe street parking. 

The room is not frilly, but it's very comfortable compared to other hotels at this prince range. The air conditioner could be stronger (I just opened the windows and was fine), and the cable television hardly worked (you are in New York, why are you watching TV anyway? About 20% of the people in New York with Time Warner Cable are having the same issue with cable not working on any given night). 

I was checked in by a joyless security guard. My room looked into a very quiet courtyard (more like a cloister) with trees and gardens (perhaps ask to be placed on that side). There is wireless Internet that works without any issues. The rooms are very quiet. There was a small kitchen area in my room with a refrigerator. The shower works great. There is lots of hot water and all the soap that you feel like stealing. For New York, this location, and the price it's a pretty good deal. It was very easy to rent the room. I found that calling them was more effective than sending e-mail.

This is from their description of the room:

Each room is NON-SMOKING and comes with:
~private Bath
~iron and hair dryer
~miniature refrigerator
~basic cable television
~free local telephone service (all incoming calls are free also. We 
    do not have long distance service)
~housekeeping services
~24 hour access front desk security
~ free wireless internet access

135 bucks a night for a single bed room. If you are a Columbia Alum you can get a discount. 

Its clean and close to campus.

business.full_address:
65 Witherspoon St
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: Princeton Public Library Cafe

reviews.text:
I'm sitting in the Library Cafe as they prep for their "Grand Reopening"  I think the new interior of the cafe looks nicer than it did.  It's not a dramatic change, but a subtle face-lift.  The new softer lighting is nice.

It's fun watching the team of seven people discussing how best to display and serve all the new foods right now.  I appreciate all the attention to detail(!)  But I already miss the old salads display - the front counter used to be a refrigerator case filled with fruit, veggie, and pasta salads.  I particularly liked the fruit salad they used to have - lots of pineapple.

Hopefully they'll be reintroducing those somehow, at some point.   Right now, they have a few sandwiches, yogurt and granola, but mostly pastries (from Witherspoon Bakery) and beverages.

The croissant I just had wasn't as good as they were a few months ago (now smaller, tougher, slightly dried out).  But the coffee is *dramatically* improved.   Seriously, so much better.  Their cappuccino machine apparently isn't working at the moment, but I'm looking forward to next winter if they get that fired up and running.

On balance, I'm happy.  I like the new look, and I love the new coffee.  The coffee is the most important thing to me as I sit with a book or my laptop.  The pastries are beautiful; I hope today was a fluke and in the future they'll taste as good as they look.
This cafe is a great value. The yogurt comes with free granola. The pasta and sandwich I've tried were both good. I also recommend the ice coffee. Very good and very cheap.

business.full_address:
990 Amsterdam Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: West 109 Gourmet Deli

reviews.text:
I have a deep appreciation for the spicy special, especially on nights when I visit neighborhood bars like 1020. 

Columbia students call 109 deli an affectionate name: "Crack Del".

This is just because often times there are sketch characters standing outside possibly dealing drugs or loitering in a way that makes everyday people feel uncomfortable. 

However, the place is totally safe. Young clientele, often well heeled, visit this place to grab cigarettes and Spicy Specials.

I personally usually grab a Spicy Special with hot peppers, but will entertain if they have something like buffalo chicken with melty goodness of mozzarella on top. 

Many people don't understand the Spicy Special (including food critics who have checked out what we're raving about), but maybe that's because the flavors go especially well with a cool Yuengling. That, or, when you are inclined to get a SS, you are halfway out of reality. 

I've done the SS mid-day, and I'll say maybe it's the cook, or maybe it's just like having chicken wings without blue cheese, dipping veggies, a cold brewsky, and a game on...

Serious Eats New York has said: "The sandwich consists of Cajun turkey, pepper jack cheese, lettuce, tomato, and "spicy sauce" (i.e. mayo and spicy mustard)." The statement is true to some extent--the spicy sauce is not mayo and spicy mustard, because it's got an orange tinge in it too, so I suspect more cajun type seasoning (perhaps akin to Tony's?) and perhaps some small quantity of russian or catalonia dressing. Also, it's a SERIOUS mistake to get the sandwich cold. Minus two points for forgetting to ask for hot peppers.

Yes it is true.  The "spicy special" is awesome.  I've ordered it 4 times now and it is consistently good.  It comes toasted and warm, though it maintains integrity after cooling down.

If you call ahead and order 10 minutes before pickup, they'll have it ready for you.  So you cut down on the time spent hanging around the store.  Then, walk across the street to the sculpture garden next to St. John's Cathedral.  Unwrap your sandwich and enjoy the moment~!!!!

This is a great sandwich to pick up on your way to the park, the airport., or wherever. Transports easily for a meal on the go.

I like this place - this is where I stock up on beer. They have Modelo in a can and Presidente in bottles.  Sometimes you gotta fight your way to the register, but this place is usually pretty quick. 

Plus it's cheap. A big-ass coffee will run you a $1. Toss in a couple of quarters and you got yourself some Swedish fish. 

Go early in the morning, and you'll probably run into a few owls. If you've got a kid with you, this may be a time for earmuffs. There's a lot of shit-talking that goes on in here. But it's mostly just show. 

I've never tried any of the sandwiches, but some of the locals seem addicted to them, so they must be tasty.

Mention of Spicy Specials and sketchy characters abound, I experienced only the latter (don't eat meat). Nothing but white bread, but they have no need for it; got a few cheeses on a roll for $3.50. Their Boar's Head sandwiches are very well-priced, and the service is a bit distant, especially if they don't know you. On that note, make sure you speak up and assert yourself, or you'll get stepped over. Toss-up between this & AGD across the street IMO.

The Spicy Special, extra spicy, will run you $4 and it's actually really good.  

This place is referred to as "Crack Del"... not sure whether or not it's because the Spicy Special is so addicting or because people might actually be dealing right outside the door.

Either way, $4 for a good sandwich is worth it in my book.

Yea, it's gross looking. It's filled with all sorts of questionable characters at all hours of the night. Suck it up and go in and ask for the "spicy special". All you need to know is that it's a hot pressed sandwich and leave it at that. Pretend like Ryan T. didn't ruin the surprise for you and don't ask what's in it because that's what makes the "spicy special" so special. Enjoy!
i didn't think a sandwich could be charming. i was wrong.

This place is good for a sandwich after a night out.  They deliver, too, which is awesome and they deliver late at night.   The food is decent.

My only compliant is that the place is just ghetto.  The service itself is nice, but the clientele in this place is just, beyond words.  

So, my advice:  get delivery!!!

I'm bummed to see this place only has 3.5 stars.

109 Deli is affectionately known as "crack del" to Columbia students because of the sketchy dealings nearby.  Scary clientele or not, the "Spicy Special" is one of my favorite sandwiches...ever. 

No one quite knows what's inside but no one ever questions it either.  It has pepper jack cheese, turkey, lettuce, and some mystery chipotle sauce.  It's amazing. And to top it off, it's only $4.  This place is the best at 4am after a rough night. 

Cheap beer is also a plus! (They deliver it too!)

The spicy special is amaaazing.  The perfect late night food when koronets' pizza gets boring.  They've got a good selection of vitamin water and other beverages (cheap beer!) to wash the sandwich down and pepperidge farm cookies for dessert.

Sure it's incredibly sketchy, but that's part of the unique experience!

I once saw someone order the spicy special with 2 eggs and bacon..try it sometime for a change.

my fav deli and not just because it's a block away from where I live.
They use Boar's head for their sandwiches, which is extremely important. A sandwich is not the same without quality cold cuts.
2nd, its made to order, cheap (3.50) for a sub and (3.00) if you want it on a roll.
Aside from the cheap delicious sandwiches, I get my coldcuts by the lbs here... 6.99/lbs for boars head, yes please@

This review is only for the gourmet deli "spicy special" sandwich.

It is the best sandwich for 4 dollars in the Columbia area.  The deli itself is a tiny, sketchy convenience store frequented by lottery addicts, smokers, drunkards and Columbia students - or drunk Columbia students.  In any case, the cajun turkey, pepper jack, lettuce tomato and spicy sauce make for a delicious sandwich.  When inebriated, the sandwich only tastes better.  The sandwich also goes well with Campells chicken soup.

I wish that I could give this place 4, or even 5 stars. The food is actually quite cheap, and they do a good job with it. It is one of those locations which is half supermarket, and half deli shop. Everything from both sections is run up via the cashier, and it is relatively quick and easier. The problem that I had with this place, which is only a valuable review if you obtain the same Deli guy, is that he was super damn rude. I walked in, was looking at the various sandwiches which were available, and asked what their BEST possible sandwich was. The cashier gave me his recommendation, so I ordered it. I then proceeded to kill some time by walking around the store, and picking up some groceries. After a few minutes, I walk up the deli guy, and ask him if the singular sandwich which was wrapped up, and ready for pickup happened to be mine. He stopped what he was doing, and gave me the absolute most vile look you can possible imagine. It was as if I asked him if I could have start having sexual relationships with his wifes unborn baby fetus. It was infuriating just how upset he was by my simple question. Without answering, he went back to what he was doing, and 30 seconds later handed me my sandwich. So over all, the price was good, the sandwich tasted alright in comparison to other shops in the area, but the help was terrible.

Cheap food and made very quick. 

The spicy Special is worth the 4 dollars. 

~Egg and chesse sandwiches are great, but they don't always have eggs!

I love this place. Its really cheap (Marlboro lights are $9 as opposed to $10 everywhere else) and fast. 

Deli wise I always get the 109 Spicy Special. They make it to order and a hero is only 3.50!! I also get chicken breast here for my salads and it usually costs me about 1.75 for two lemon glazed chicken breasts. YUM!!

I never thought I'd be yelping about a corner deli, but damn! I ordered the spicy special and wooooah mama was it good! Good and cheap! I don't know how this place stays in business, but hot diggity dog, I like it!

The fact that this bodega gets this exposure is a testament to the power of a site like yelp.

In short this is my local bodega and as such I buy mostly beer and sandwiches from here. The sandwiches are the best value in the neighbourhood and some are so well known they've now been named after the street : "109 spicy special". I would like to think that buying this particular sandwich for the last 3 years has helped....
Ordering at lunchtime can be fun when a crowd of school kids surround the counter and you have to shout your order over the top of them but your sandwich always seems to appear a couple of minutes later. The service is generally fast and they have a big enough turnaround that none of their deli meats hang around for too long. A cold sub costs $3.50 and hot $4.
The breakfast bacon,egg and cheese for $2 is also a great deal. The coffee is 50c but really only tastes like "bodega" coffee.

The staff are friendly enough but not over-flowing with pleasantries. I've seen them take some real abuse in my time so I think they've built up immunity to normal civil conversation. Some reviewers mention the sketchy characters but there really aren't too many. These blocks used to be much worse than they are today and thankfully they still retain some of the local characteristics but without the dangerous element.

Could I be one of the sketchy characters..?

This is the closest store to my house, and while the '109 Spicy Special' is indeed awesome, I think the assessment can be broadened for all of their sandwiches.  I had the 'London Bridge' and was very happy that it fell down my throat.

The overall score is lowered because of the overwhelming feeling that you are about to be punched in the face by some of the frequent visitors to this small convenience store.  However, the sandwiches are priced to make it worth the risk.

SPICY SPECIAL. Amazing. Hot pressed sandwich on a hero for only $4. Perfect drunk/late night food.  Bacon egg and cheese sandwiches for only 2.50, cheap beer, and 25 cent bags of chips (I didn't know they existed anymore). Staff is a little rude and place

business.full_address:
3900 Chestnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19195
business.name: Hamilton Court Apartments

reviews.text: Let me make this absolutely clear: Unless you are a college student between the ages of 18 and 21, you don't want to even think about moving to HamCo. All of the buildings have a not quite party, but social, atmosphere, so HamCo made for a swell place to hang out junior and senior year in college. But I've seen people there who aren't college students; they look miserable.

business.full_address:
10100 Baltimore Ave
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Any Assembly

reviews.text: This company was absolutely awesome.  I had four pieces of exercise equipment that needed to be put together--I would have never gotten around to it.  They gave me a quote online.  They showed up on time.  They did a fantastic job.  Aziz, the owner showed me how to use the equipment.  I would recommend them any day.  Loved them!!

These guys are great. Very prompt with communications and price estimates, even over the weekend. They moved a beast of a children's play set for us up several steps (~30) and into our hard-to-access back yard. 
They were punctual, communicative, efficient, and strong!
Reasonable price as well. You'll do well to hire them.

I love AnyAssembly! They arrived on time and got straight to work. The gentleman was concerned about protecting my floor so he used a piece of carpet to make sure there was no scratches. Wonderfully considerate of him! They put together my
heavy duty treadmill within an hour and that includes hauling it up 3 flights of stairs! I am so happy with the service that I will use them and recommend them to my friends. Great rates, great service, great people!!!!!!!!!! THANK YOU SO MUCH ANY ASSEMBLY!!

This company was a very good choice. I had an entertainment center that was put up incorrectly and they came and took it apart and put it back together correctly for a fairly reasonable price, all in little to no time :-) Thanks guys!!!

business.full_address:
5908 40th Ave
Hyattsville, MD 20782
business.name: Golden China Restaurant

reviews.text:
If you are looking for convenient, not-so-expensive Americanized Chinese food, this is the place.  

If you are looking for really good Chinese food, look elsewhere.  Even still, I'll come back to this place.  It's far far better than the place next to CV

I just moved here and live within walking distance of this place.  Tried it on one of those nights where I couldn't be bothered to cook, and just wanted to eat on the couch and watch Netflix.  I'm the type that always orders the same thing from every Chinese take-out place (general tso's chicken or bean curd and hot and sour soup).  Boring, I realize, but it is a good basis for comparing different places.  The food was what you would expect for inexpensive Americanized Chinese take-out, although maybe even better than average in comparison to some of the other places in the area, which was a pleasant surprise since its in kind of a random location and would probably only be known to locals.  You can order online (and pay when you pick up so you don't have to input a credit card) if you don't want to be bothered to pick up the phone or to speak to an actual person.  The first time I ordered from there, I was surprised to get a free drink.  Then I saw on their website that you can choose between a free drink or a free egg roll.

They do deliver, but I live so absurdly close that I've never had them deliver.  Usually I order and my boyfriend will pick up on his way home from work.  The one time that I did pick up, the lady at the counter chatted with me while I waited for my order to be bagged up, and she was very friendly.  Another customer walked in to pick up his order, and was obviously a regular.  He asked how her kids were, whether she will visit China anytime soon, etc.  It just seemed like a nice, local place, so consequently I'm on my way to being a regular there as well.

Does anyone know if this restaurant has changed hands in the past few years?  They used to be really good and I LOVED their General Tso chicken wings.  Anymore they're just an average carryout/delivery place.

Not the worst Chinese food around. A bit better than the other Chinese takeouts around here, but nothing to write home about. It's passable, and will feed you in a pinch. It's pretty much what you would expect for cheap Chinese takeout. They have been in the neighborhood for a long time though. In the time that I've been going there the little kids that used to run around the storefront have grown into teenagers and actually work there now. There is something to be said for a long standing institution in the community that serves a needed niche. I'm happy to support this local business.

One of many, many Chinese restaurants in the area. I'm lucky I remember the name of this one, since they're all some variation on Hearty's Golden China Asian Panda Delight, or something like that.

Nice because it's a very short walk from my girlfriend's house.

Not-so-nice because their "Chef Specialties" are basically the absolute basic stuff you get when you think Americanized Chinese food: orange chicken, kung pao chicken, etc. And they close at an absurdly early time every single night.

Also, after 18 some odd times of going there, I expect (perhaps mistakenly) that you maybe might know me by now. It gets a little frustrating saying no mustard, no plastic bag, YES fortune cookie.

Otherwise, I love you, and all the greasiness you provide.

I eat here a lot, but only because it's a 30 second walk from my house. The food isn't bad, but it's basically just like any other Chinese restaurant. They have pretty decent egg rolls and spring rolls (compared to places around here) and the garlic sauce they use is really good even though it tastes nothing like garlic sauce.

business.full_address:
30 Palmer Sq E
Princeton, NJ 08542
business.name: The Original Soup Man

reviews.text: I'll admit it, I was drawn in my the fact that this was the soup made famous by the soup Nazi on Seinfeld. I thought, I've heard so much about this place, it's got to to be good. Man, was I wrong. I ordered the Italian wedding soup, which was horrible. It didn't taste like any Italian wedding soup I had ever had. It was spicy and there were no meatballs. Plus, it was almost seven dollars for a little cup of soup. I have had way better soup for $1.75 at my local diner. This place is way over priced and over hyped.
Food tastes alright but portions are small and uber expensive. Would not recommend, no soup for you!

Once a regular, my first visit in almost three years was a disappointment. Soup Man used to have some of the best lobster bisque one could purchase -- even when compared to nicer sit-down restaurants. 

Before I could count on each bowl having several generous chunks of lobster meat. Generous servings of expensive ingredients and the once free Lindor truffle, piece of fruit, and fresh bread used to justify the premium price for soup (~$10). Nowadays skimp a lot on ingredients, making the soup just above average. The apple and truffle now cost an extra dollar -- certainly reasonable, but I miss the old days!

Like a lot of people, this place attracted me because it inspired a classic episode of "Seinfeld". I'll give it two stars because the soup was pretty good, and I like the way they throw in a piece of fresh fruit along with the bread.
What I didn't like were the obscene prices. I bought two quarts of soup to go, and I think I spent over $40. Getting a take-out order from here is a great motivator to learn to cook.

business.full_address:
1233 US Hwy 206 N
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Rocky Hill Automotive

reviews.text: Rocky Hill Automotive is now closed. Hopefully they can open up again in a more visible location.

The most trustworthy auto service I have ever encountered. We used them for years for our 2002 VW Jetta and 94 Geo Prism and they never let us down. No pressure to do unnecessary costly repairs, just good honest advice and high quality, professional service. Don't be scared away by the small size of the place or the run-down look of the building. You will not regret taking your car here. Hope Joe stays in business for many years to come!

business.full_address:
830 State Rd Rt 206
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Daniel Smits Salon

reviews.text: Daniel Smits Salon is my favorite! I don't go anywhere else. The decor is simple, clean, and hip. The staff is friendly and helpful. And most importantly, Dan is the best. I don't trust anyone else with my difficult hair. I highly recommend it!

I've been going to Dan to get my hair done for the last 8 years so naturally I decided to move with him when he opened his own salon last year.  The salon itself is chic and modern, yet still comfortable.  The staff is young, hip, and very accommodating -- you can't walk in there without someone offering you a cup of coffee or a glass of cucumber water. A haircut and blowout can run you almost $100 but it is worth every damn penny. My hair never looks as shiny or falls as nicely as it does after I leave Dan's chair.

business.full_address:
1219 Amsterdam Ave
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Hartley Chemists

reviews.text: This place could not be more convenient for the Columbia community. The pharmacist is personable and friendly, to boot.

After multiple eye-stabbing experiences and extreme lines at the crap Duane Reade pharmacy on 111th, Hartley is like heaven.  They always get your prescription right and call if they have any questions.  In addition, there has never been much of a line, and if you need to drop and wait for a prescription there are chairs -- what a concept!

I'm sure the previous reviews regarding the actual pharmacists are right on, but as I've never had a prescription filled, I'll only speak to the quality/price of the retail items.  They are WAY, way overpriced.  If you're in a pinch and need shampoo or cold medicine, just walk the extra few blocks to Duane Reade because this place is just shy of exorbitant.

Outstanding...this is what a pharmacy should be! Thao, R.Ph. is the best always friendly and builds a relationship with her customers. We highly recommend Hartley Pharmacy to all in the Columbia University community.

The pharmacist here is so incredibly helpful - she has talked on the phone to my insurance and my doctors on my behalf dozens of times, without getting annoyed and without even needing a reminder. She knows your name when you walk in, and gives completely useful advice. Even after I move out of Morningside Heights, I think it will be worth the trip.

Wonderful pharmacists!  They know me by name and are extremely helpful.  When they didn't have my medication in stock the pharmacist called three pharmacies for me to locate it.  I ended up at Duane Reed, which was hell compared to Harley.  

The shopping area seems overpriced and disorganized though.

Important note: I have never used the pharmacy at Hartley; I've only shopped in the drugstore portion. This review is based only on the drugstore.

And holy moly, what a drugstore it is. First of all, it is the most poorly-organized store I have ever been to. I have walked around for fifteen minutes looking for three things before, because there is no logical order within the aisles. If you can find them, they have a few decent products, but the store itself feels really cheap. 

The biggest problem, though, is the staff in the drugstore (again, the pharmacist sounds great). During one trip, I was trying to grab some toothpaste, and someone was restocking the shelves. No "sorry," no move out of the way, no "can I help you." I literally had to squeeze my arm in front of her to grab blindly for an item. So weird. Another time (the last time I will be going to Hartley), I had something like $9 worth of stuff and only a credit card. Ignoring the fact that it's illegal to set a credit card minimum, I WAS SPENDING $9 AND THEIR MINIMUM WAS $10. The guy said I hadn't spent enough. I told him I'd just put my stuff back and go somewhere else because I didn't have any cash, and he replied in a very condescending tone, "Just this once." Yep, just this once indeed because there is no way I'll be going back.

Finally, a regular pharmacy! I like to patronize Hartley's because it's not a chain pharmacy. I don't have to meander through aisles of seasonal food and displays, groceries, a photo booth or any other non-health related items.  The same woman is the pharmacist every time I go, whether it be to fill a prescription or ask some advice.  Unlike chain stores, where the pharmacist never seems to be the same person, Hartley allows that level of comfort you'd want when getting medicine from someone.  Of course, there are non-prescription items too - your typical over-the-counter items are available in abundant supply.  

In the age of an influx of chain stores throughout NYC, it's nice to have a neighborhood place to go to.

I agree with Megan below, Hartley is really disorganized. You need help finding anything in the store because really there is no rhyme or reason as to how they are stacking the shelves there.

The store is also a bit expensive but I suppose that comes from being in New York.

One plus is that they sell stamps though and so I had to bump them up a star for that reason alone.

Hartley Pharmacy is a god-send.  The pharmacist, Tao (sp?), is absolutely amazing.  After too many bad experiences with the Rite Aid on 110th and Broadway, I decided to move all my prescriptions to pharmacy, and it was definitely a good choice. 

Even though it's only open 9 AM - 7 PM and closed on Sundays, Tao is the most helpful pharmacist I've ever met.  She has called my doctors and insurance companies many times if I need a refill or the prescription won't go through.  I have heard her literally arguing with the insurance company to give me my medication.  And then she calls me back to tell me what happened. (A Rite Aid employee would do that for you... when hell freezes over.)  She is friendly to every single person who walks through the door.  And her adorable daughter is usually there during non-school hours.

Now I live 11 blocks away and still go there, despite the many other pharmacies closer to me.  Thank you Tao & Hartley for making my life easier.

I could not agree more with the previous reviewers, Hartley is the best pharmacy I've ever been to.  The two women who work at the pharmacy are so nice and personable, they'll know you by name after you've been there two or three times.  Another man consistently works the register.

It is no refreshing to have a local pharmacy with people who know your name and needs.  The only downfall is they close somewhat on the early side; however, they are so accommodating that it is of no matter.

Well-stocked, clean, nice selection, and the pharmacist was very friendly and accommodating. She did, however, give me an estimate of 30 minutes, which 30 minutes later miraculously remained at 30 minutes. Not a fan of the drug store scene, if you could call it that, but a nice resource nearby...

I agree with everyone's comments! While at Columbia, I tried the surrounding Rite Aids and Duane Reades and was consistently annoyed and angered by slow and incompetent employees.  I finally found Hartley on a friend's recommendation and have always had n
I come here for the pharmacy. The pharmacist is really nice :)

I live in New Jersey now and STILL go to this pharmacy!  When I first moved to New York I went to several different pharmacies and experienced various degrees of rudeness, slowness, and general incompetence.  Then I found this one, and it's top notch by any standards.  Tao is great -- she will even offer to call your insurance company on your behalf if they are refusing to fill a prescription or if you're going away on a trip or whatever.  Everyone in the store is very friendly and they're FAST.  No line and 20 minutes to fill a prescription -- in New York?  Maybe I shouldn't be telling people about this place!

Hartley is absolutely the greatest. Dealing with the pharmacist here is like living in a small town- she knows my name, my meds, my insurance company, reminds me that I might need a refill before a long holiday weekend. That sort of thing. It is very comforting. I get the feeling that the pharmacist is also the owner. She is always there and is 100 percent on the ball. Please support Hartley!

I LOVE this pharmacy! Tao (not sure about spelling either) is FANTASTIC, attentive, knows me by name and does everything ASAP and/or on time. It is a much better experience (and way less of a hike) than the chain stores around here. As for merchandise, once you know where stuff is, it's easier to navigate but I don't hesitate to buy from here to support local stores. :)

This review is basically only for the pharmacy. The rest of the store is so-so.

Yaaaaayy for Hartley Pharmacists! They've accomplished something that Duane Reade, Rite Aid, CVS, Walgreens, Walmart, Longs (oh wait, that's only in CA) and other drug stores will never accomplish. They are friendly, informative, and they very quickly remember your name. There's one woman in particular who is almost always working, and she is so wonderful. Such a pleasant experience, and never any mix-up of medications.

business.full_address:
5550 Greenbelt Rd
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Beltway Plaza Shell Servicenter

reviews.text:
Worst service station EVER.

I went here to get my tire patched and I'm sure they made the whole bigger.  After 45 mins, they told me it was all done while I CAN HEAR THE AIR COMING OUT of my tire and they attempted to charge me 30 bucks for 2 patches (only 1 patch worked!!).

Needless to say, I ended up getting a new tire the next day.

I went here because it was the closest gas station when I got my flat tire and will NEVER GO BACK.

I confess: the main purpose of this review is to get me to 90. I am a numbers guy and 90 feels better than 89. I do have something useful to say about this gas station though--it has consistently been the cheapest in town. Last week it was @$2.19. With these rock bottom prices it almost feels like it's 2001.

business.full_address:
120 Rockingham Row
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Tre Piani

reviews.text: Trepiani was terrific.  The food was very good but more importantly the service and the general attitude of all was warm and welcoming.  We were running late for our dinner res and called and they were extremely accomodating.  I would definitely recommend this place.

Got an email stating that on 3/23/12 the oysters would be 1/2 price at TrePiani. When we asked about the 1/2 priced oysters, the waitress said, "People keep asking about that, but we know nothing about it." We called the mgr over to show him the email on my Blackberry. He reluctantly agreed to give us the 1/2 priced oysters but said that we could not have the Friday 1/2 priced wine by glass special. Guess we were being punished. Won't be back.

First time to Tre Piani on a Monday night in October, party of two. 

It was a little too cool to dine outside, otherwise we would have been all over it--lots of outdoor seating, probably wonderful during the summer. 

We arrived around 6:00 and were the only ones in the restaurant.  Generally that would worry me a bit, as I tend to think that places that have lines usually have them for a reason.  But we had our choice of tables, and then the full attention of our server.  

Everything we ordered was *excellent*. 
Bread comes to the table after drink orders, and every table has its own bottle of good quality extra-virgin olive oil right there so you can have as little or as much as you like for your bread.  Mmm. 
We started with the Antipasti appetizer special, which was probably the best antipasti I've ever had.  Marinated mushrooms, roasted yellow peppers, crostini, caprese, endive, prosciutto, and fantastic fried calamari--all served to us from a serving plate onto our plates individually and identified for us by our server, which I thought was a very nice touch to the service.  Highly recommended. 
Then had the specialty seafood salad--cucumber, fennel, and tomato with scallops and squid in bread.  A very different approach to salad, but very good.  
My entree was a special for that evening--spaghetti squash ravioli with brown butter, pancetta and walnuts in a very light cream/butter sauce.  It was incredibly satisfying.  My date had the pork tenderloin and cauliflour gratin that was on special--also very well prepared and delicious. 
We weren't going to order dessert until we saw the menu and saw that there was a Nutella semi fredo.  We debated...and finally ordered it and it was AMAZING.  I would definitely order all of these things again, but the dessert floored me. 

Our server was very good throughout the night; got us everything we needed without being in the way.  

The restaurant itself is airy and spacious, warmly lit and decorated in a comfortable, modern style.  Dress code is casual, we were dressed nicely, but there were other patrons there in jeans. 

Happy Hour M/T/Th is 1/2 price glass wines, not a bad deal!  (W/F $5 mixed drinks).  

If I could afford it, I'd go all the time.  Delicious, comfortable, beautiful dining experience.

A-Ok about sums up Trepiani. It's neither bad nor great. We went there yesterday in advance of a show in Princeton. First the place was hard to find due to the directions on their website and parking near it was a challenge. The service was fairly slow and we became rushed for time to get to our performance. My dinner partner had short ribs with sweet potatoes which she really enjoyed. I had chicken milanese which arrived at room temperature and was kind of on the tough side. Our waitress was pleasant and tried to please. I'd say Trepiani is okay if you're in the neighborhood and have plenty of time but I would not go out of my way to go there.

My wife and I went here for a last-minute birthday dinner. I thought we were going to Salt Creek until we arrived :) After four laps around the plaza and deciphering the fact that their directions for parking were not near the restaurant, we found it. Odd that they refuse to give more detailed directions about where they are in the village on their automated phone system. We arrived at 8pm on a Monday night. Well after the evening rush, and we liked it that way. Definitely upscale casual. We liked that, too.

Wonderful indoor/outdoor seating - we chose al fresco. Ordered a bottle of Castello Banfi "San Angelo" Pinot Grigio. I had about the best Caprese Salad ever. The fettuccine with shrimp did not disappoint. The pasta was so fresh it was amazing. My wife had the daily special tomato soup and linguine and clams. We did not have room for dessert or after dinner drink.

Ran $100 even, so its definitely not an everyday place. It is nice for special occasions, however, and it sounds like a better place after the evening rush has passed. Would definitely go again, but not necessarily on a whim. Only gave it 3 stars because of the price. We can eat on Palmer Square and get Thomas Sweets for half the price and still have a great time.

If there was a half star option i'd give that.  

This place is terrible!  How it has as many stars as it does is beyond me!  I don't even know where to begin.  I guess I'll start off how our evening started off. 

We sat ourselves because no one directed us to our table. While the waiter was taking our orders he said 'wait wait' and walked away from the table in the middle of taking our orders and us giving them.  We waited about ten minutes for water. Uh really? 
So the menu looks good and so many things are appealing but don't be fooled because it all sucks. I was really looking forward to the baked artichokes and was greatly disappointed when all I tasted was rosemary and the artichokes were smaller than my spoon. The pizzas were salty, the calamari was cold, and the salads were small and did not live up to their price tag. If you say it comes with bacon there should be bacon. Oh and that 'as seen on food network' seafood crap? You failed to mention it was on the 'worst dishes of all time' show!  

The entrees were worse than the appetizers. Each dish just got worse around the table. The pasta with mushroom stuff tasted like wall paper paste it was so bland. The lamb chop came with no bone and was not good. The rigattoni with eggplant was salt with a side of pasta. The tuna was over cooked and that rissoto cake was garbage. I ordered the veal and I kept thinking this tastes familiar and then my boyfriend said 'tastes like cheese-its'  and he was spot on!!!  I was eating cheese-its from the big red box and they were charging me $32!  Before our food was cleared we asked for the check. 

Bottom line is this place was horrendous and waaaaaaaaaaaaay way over priced for the food you got what a ripoff!!  

I'd never go back!

Positive:  Excellent fine dining experience with delicious food and superb service.  Especially for those who eat only Halal food. 

Negative:  Not enough virgin cocktails, and the desserts are mediocre.

Overall: Great restaurant to visit when in the mood for a fine dining experience or for a special occasions.

Revisit:  Yes, especially for the steaks and burgers along with the ambiance.

We have eaten here before and found the food pleasant enough although never stellar.  Last night, however, was a disaster beyond  belief!  Eight of us with reservatiions to celebrate a birthday had calamity after calamity!  Our server was personable and kind but completely inept.  Missing salads, wrong entrees, special requests never communicated BUT the worst and most  unconscienable act was the lamb special!  Four of us ordered the rack of lamb ($33 for 3 tiny lamb  chops).  I ordered mine medium rare and my dish was served medium rare but ice and I mean ice cold...not room temperature but refrigerator cold.  My fellow lamb diners all had the same experience...no problem...tell the waitress; she tells manager and they whisk away our dishes...5 minutes later, they are returned...microwaved or heated in a skillet...not  sure but the plate I received was well done now and here is the unconscienable part...a piece of lamb was missing from one of my chops!  Lo and behold!  They had mixed up the dishes and returned them randomly..i received my fellow diner's dish!  Yuck!  I refused to eat and spoke  to the manager who sent over his manager and they did remove the lamb from our check!  Big deal! Very disgusting practices...not to be trusted!  We will never eat here again!  Who knows whose leftover food you may  be getting!  Our lamb should have been discarded and new ones cooked for us....that is what any reputable restaurant would have done!  Very suspect food hygiene practices to say the least..I went home hungry!  Better safe than sorry!

Addendum:  just found out that two members of our group became ill last night!

How fitting that my last meal in Princeton was at Tre Piani.  We've been coming to this place since it opened last year.  It's a bit on the pricey side, but the food, service, and ambience can't be beat.  The bread basket comes with a nice assortment (tho not warmed) and u can dip it in the olive oil that is on the table... so good!  I've had practically everything on their menu and everything's really solid.  

Get the tiramisu for dessert.  It's really quite wonderful!!  We think it's the best in Princeton :)

And don't forget to pick up a handful of their mints on your way out... again, the junior mint kinds :d

I went here for mothers day and I thought the restaurant was decent for the area. You really cant compare any restaurants in the area to NYC. Well maybe you can, but i have yet to find a superb restaurant in the area. There are plenty of expensive ones but u dont get the same as you would in NYC for the same price.  The service was nice.. maybe it was because we had a baby at the table? but the waitress was very nice and caring. The food i thought was fine. I think they fared better than one53 in rocky hill. I would think of returning here if it were a lil cheaper but its definitely  not crossed off my list for the area. Tiramisu was good.. portion size was fine for me.. but i dont each much i guess :p

Jim Weaver, the chef owner of Trepiani, brought the slow food revolution from Italy to New Jersey.  He alone scores three stars, just by being affiliated with this restaurant.  Go Jim Weaver, even though I hear he's kind of a big ole' jerk.  Whatever it takes, I guess. 

The one thing I can't stand about this place is that I work so close by and I can never come there because they close down in the middle of the day from lunch, and then reopen for dinner and close early!  I would have to intentionally go there one night for dinner, and if that's the case I would go someplace that I've been meaning to go to more than Trepiani.  

I did visit Trebar one day after a lunch shift let out late, and I ordered one of the few craft beers on the menu and the tuna tartare.  I freaking love tuna tartare, I will order it everywhere I go until I get mercury poisoning, I don't care.  Also, I don't know if that's true or not.  And when it came out, it looked presentable, but the tuna itself had been macerated and chopped up like it was put through a meat grinder.  I was disappointed with the overall texture of the protein, because what I enjoy so much about tuna tartare...what is essentially the beauty of it in the first place...is that the tuna itself has such a delicate, tender texture to it that biting into raw fish wouldn't gross you out.  To eliminate that delicacy is a shame.  I didn't order anything else, and I haven't been back, but perhaps I will head in to try something else on their rather extensive bar menu and then I will update.
I'm a bit spoiled being this restaurant is right next door to my flower shop. Chef/Owner Jim Weaver does a great job with the menu. The flavors are wonderful!

I ate here once a week for approximately 5 months in mid to late 2011. I usually ate at Tre Bar, but if it was nice out, I would eat outside at the main restaurant.

The menu is wildly inconsistent, but once you find their best main dishes, you can have an outstanding meal.

Apps: 
- Fresh mozz and tomatoes is usually very good. It can be a little salty sometimes, but not many restaurants offer house-pulled mozz, so it's worth trying. The tuna tartare is great, but the fish hasn't always been fresh. I would argue it's worth the gamble, and if it's too fishy when it comes, send it back. If it's fresh, you'll be thrilled - tuna, soy, pickled onions, wasabi, micro greens and toast. When it's good, it's really good. 
- The Panzanella is, in my opinion, absolutely terrible. I don't know what show it was featured on, but it was obviously one that lacks any sort of credibility.
- The beet salad is ok, but the thought of using feta instead of goat or blue cheese is a little ill-conceived. It isn't robust enough to stand up to the rest of the ingredients.
- Crabmeat and avacado is very nice. It's not really a salad, but it's a good app option.


Pizzettes: 
- They have $5 pizzettes in the bar one night a week. I don't think any of them are very good - they tend to be quite bland regardless of the ingredients.

Pasta: 
- The fettuccine with sausage sauce is transcendentally good - like absolutely amazing level of good. It's far and away the best dish I've had here. If you eat here once, this is what you should get.
- They sometime have a pappardelle with rosemary chicken and lemon that is really really good - nice and light. It's not on the menu right now, but it may be a seasonal item.
- I've found the gnocchi to be too gummy and it just sits in your stomach like cement. 


They have a very good wine selection and bartender is knowledgeable about what they offer by the glass. They also offer reasonably priced wine flights.

The three stars are because of the tuna on good days, the fettuccine with sausage sauce, and the consistently good wine recommendations.

Tre Piani is an italian restaurant in Princeton, though it isn't quite in Princeton. It's in Forrestal Village off route 1 near Ruth's Chris and Salt Creek Grill. I've been avoiding going to Tre Piani for a few years since a work holiday party. The food was pretty mediocre and I'm not crazy about the location so it usually doesn't enter my consideration set when I'm thinking about italian food.

My brother was in town visiting from england and we decided to go out for dinner. I wanted something that even my kids would enjoy (10 and 12), though they are pretty adventurous when it comes to food and have decent palettes. Having not planned ahead, we had trouble getting reservations at my first choices of Eno Terra, Medittera and having been to One 53 quite often lately I wanted to go somewhere different. I went onto Open Table and Tre Piani was one of the few places with a 7.30pm reservation available on saturday night, so we ended up there.

Tre Piani is a pretty large restaurant scattered over 3 floors with an outdoor seating area. The restaurant is across from the Cando gym and some office space making the outdoor seating seem somewhat out of place. We sat by the empty bar on the main floor. The tables are spaced nicely apart making for a easy dinner conversation. When you enter the restaurant you are greeted by a pretty cheerful older guy, maybe the owner who makes you feel pretty welcome. He walked over and chatted with quite a few diners who seemed like regulars.

The food itself was better than I had remembered though overall it was pretty mixed. Some items like the calamari were very good - crispy and tossed with a sweet and sour sauce. The tuna tartar was under-seasoned and just ok. For the main courses the tortellini alla bolognese and fettucini with roman style sausage sauce were very good while the osso buco was a little too heavy on tomato sauce, though it was perfectly tender. The risotto side with the osso buco too was decent though not great. For dessert, my son was the only one to order something and he went for creme brulee which was perfectly made.

The wine list at Tre Piani isn't great. They also have a wine bar next door (Tre Bar) which I've been to a few times. Unfortunately I'm not a huge fan of their wine lists. Quite disappointing actually.

Service is on the slow side, the time between courses is exceptionally long. While the resturant was busy it wasn't so busy that it should have slowed down service so much. If you go make sure you plan on spending quite some time there.

Overall the food is decent. I would give it a 3 out of 5. If I'm looking for italian food I would choose Eno Terra but Tre Piani isn't too bad an alternative if you can't get a reservation there.

www.foodielifestyle.com

The food is the only thing that saved this place. The service was simply awful. And its to bad because the menu is promising and the decor/ambiance is defiantly working in their favor. 

I was very apparent that our server was not experienced or knowledgeable. I by no means felt comfortable asking him for a wine recommendation, so I chose that on my own. 

I stared myself off with a Homemade Mozzarella appetizer. I'm not entirely sure they can safely call that "homemade", but the dish was good overall. DINNER = WINNER. The pasta dish I chose as my main course absolutely  stole my heart. Rigatoni with Filet Mignon Tips and Gorgonzola Cheese. The dish was so creamy and rich and full of flavor. Paired with a full bodied red wine, this dish could take you to the moon. Sadly, the filet mignon tips were cooked poorly. They were chewy and dry, even after sitting in the sauce. Bleehh. Next time, if there is a next time, I will order it without the meat. 

Instead of dessert, I opted for a cheese plater .. which was not on the menu. I (hesitantly) asked the waiter if a cheese plate could be put together. He returned back to tell me that it could and that he would bring it out with my guest's dessert. He brought over the cheese plate .. and just walked away. No introduction to what was sitting in front of me, what-so-ever. I later called him back to ask him what types of cheese he served me, and what exactly the sweet jelly-like thing was in the middle. He had no idea (surprise, surprise) and returned to the kitchen to find answers. He came back to the table and attempted to tell me the name of the jelly-like item (I could not understand what he was saying) and said nothing about the cheese. 

I rest my case .. enter at your own risk.

My family and I went to Tre Piani for dinner on a Saturday night. Very disappointed. The building is pretty as well as the outside, but honestly for our $180 meal we were expecting good service and good food. 

Our waiter was unfriendly.   On the menu it states "all of our food has a story with it... just ask us"   so we asked our waiter and he said no it doesn't.  He was rude throughout the entire experience. 

Honestly all of our food was absolutely terrible.   I had checked out the menu before going to the restaurant and couldn't wait to try the hanger steak salad.  First of all, it came out on spinach instead of arugula!  Thank goodness I like spinach.   The steak had no flavor. And there were disgusting fried onions on top that were greasy.  Are you kidding me???   On a salad?

My husband got the steak tip and rigatoni.  Very small meal.  Sauce was good. 

My dad got a chicken dish and my nanny got the vegetarian soufle type dish.  Both mediocre. 

Our drinks were soft drinks.   The cost was $3.50 per drink.  They didnt refill them!

They don't have a kids menu...


I will not return to this restaurant.   Usually I give second chances, but this was such a horrible experience.  If you choose to go, I hope you have a better experience:)

Went with a large group.  We were seated separate from the main dining room, which I thought was considerate of the other diners there (of which there weren't that many).  The food was pretty good, but maybe a little pricey.

We had a very nice date the other night at Trepiani (or is it Tre Piani?) in "Princeton's" Forrestal Village.  The food was great and the service very competent (we must have had a half dozen staff attend to us at various times!)  It was a luxurious way to celebrate our 44 years together.

We enjoyed an eggplant rolantini appetizer (with our Prosecco) that was just perfect (we measure our this dish against that of our restaurateur friend Tino P. and this was almost as good as his!  Sorry Tino!)  My spouse enjoyed Tortellini Bolognese and I had a Fettucini with some type of creamy sauce with delicious chunks of slightly spicy sausage in it.  For dessert she had some kind of froo-froo after-dinner drink/decaf coffee that was really loaded with hootch!  Whew!  I settled for one of the best examples of creme brulee I've ever had.  Amelie would be proud of the chef's interpretation.

Like General MacArthur famously said:  "I shall return!"

Great space.  Food is good, but can be somewhat inconsistent.  On a business trip in recent months I ate dinner here with a few colleagues and one of them said the seafood risotto was awful.  Maybe it was just an anomoly, but I haven't ordered it based on that experience.  I had some ravioli here that was great and most of the pasta dishes seem to be very well prepared.  

Service is excellent as is the live Jazz music.  Still a good bet for a business dinner but overall seems a little pricey for the quality.

We went for Valentine's day at 9pm and the ambiance was the first thing I noticed. The lighting was nice and the noise level was good(not very loud). Those two things can make a date night not so romantic. 

We started with the carpaccio(excellent) with their bread. I ordered the scallops and my partner ordered the osso bucco. Both were very good - I kept stealing bites from the osso bucco. We had drinks(3) that were a bit expensive ~10 dollars apiece. Also, we ordered two desserts which were good. I think the final check was about 120 with tip which is what I was expecting for a nice night. 

I would go back again for a special night - after we sample other places. We don't go out for $$$ dining that often so it will probably be a while.  I would post my rating as 4.5 if it was possible - my experience was very good, but it wasn't "As good as it gets" which is the description for 5 stars.

I've been to Tre Piani several times: a few times for business lunches, a few times for happy hour at Tre Bar, and last night I had dinner there for the first time. I think it's one of the better restaurants in Princeton, and I really like their emphasis on local ingredients. I was surprised at the number of negative reviews here, as I have never been disappointed by the food or the service.

I gave 3 stars just to keep the average score of this place but i would like to write something about Trebar.

I just moved to the area, had some friends from overseas over and I realized I dont know nothing about Princeton's nightlife. So, i google to find out: "princeton nightlife" and came this website:

http://www.shopprinceton.com/nightlife-in-princeton

There I found Tre Piani and Tre Bar and says: "Although this restaurant it is located at the Princeton Forrestal Village, a few minutes from town, the bar scene is really cool and can result in some rather rambunctious behavior (which is good). They have live music and the dance floor is rolled out on Friday nights."

Ok, to make the story short, I was there yesterday (friday), at 10PM. The nice host gentleman from Tre Piani invited us to go check the bar but he warned us that the restaurant and bar were about to close... 

There was 2 girls at the bar and 1 or 2 people from staff kinda setting up to close at any minute. We decided to leave.

So, what happened? Is this place over? 

We ended up having drinks at PF Changs... how excited :(

i only came here bc i was unable to score a last minute reservation at salt creek grill... i was obviously desperate since i heard only less than positive reviews about this place.

to my surprise, i was pleasantly greeted by the host when arriving.  i liked the quaint, open space.  then it went all down when we got our food.  HA.  3 out of 3 dishes sucked.  my tortellini was hard, lukewarm, and uber salty.  friend's angel hair pasta tasted diluted and bland.  the bolognese pizza was also salty and unsatisfying.  couldn't complain about the service but who cares about anything else if the food just sucks.  never again!

Cute local GOTO restaurant.

Have eaten here 10 or so times in the last 5 years, and have only had one bad meal (an uber salty pasta tapenade). Cute interior, nice wine list, good service (surprised by some of the complaints on Yelp.)

Connected to the local Slow Food Movement - some nice choices on the menu -try the Crabmeat and Avocado Salad - or the Rigatoni with Filet Mignon Tips and Gorgonzola Cheese - or the Osso Buco. Great specials too.

The boyfriend and I have come to Tre Piani many times, one of which was the obligatory  "meeting of the parents" meal right before graduation, which luckily went off without a hitch. The service here is always great and everyone is friendly. The food is good. Not amazing, but good. I haven't been since Valentine's Day, as I no longer live in Jersey, but it's safe to say that I'm a fan.

Stay away if you're on a low carb diet though.

We made reservations for 8 pm and weren't seated until at least 8:30 pm because they had no tables for our party of 4.  When we finally did get seated, we were greeted by a less than friendly waiter who hardly provided any service for the remainder of our meal.  When we ordered coffee to start, he didn't bother bringing any cream with it, so we asked again, twice, until finally another server brought us some.  The "Brooklyn Bread" was a big disappointment, cold italian bread...nothing special.  After placing our orders, we didn't get our meals until 40 minutes later, and boy were they disappointing.
We ordered the rib eye steak - completely bland, dry, and a waste of $32.  It came with gorgonzola fries which were just Ore Ida fries with gorgonzola melted into a greasy mess.
We also ordered the Tre burger - bun was cold and too hard, meat was bland, and you couldn't even tell there was cheese on it.  It came with a side of fries that again, Ore Ida must have supplied, because they were definitely not house made and were overly greasy.   
Lastly we had Papardelle with exotic mushrooms and chicken - the chicken was completely bland, no taste whatsoever.  The rest of the dish was too greasy and not very flavorful.  
The only thing good at this restaurant was the coffee :/
If the service had been good, we might have overlooked the overall bland flavors of our food, but when you're paying $100+ burgers, etc. good service is the least you can ask for.  The elderly man who seated us was very apologetic and kind, but unfortunately it did not make up for our rude waiter.  We could not get out of there fast enough, but even getting the check and paying it took at least 20 minutes.  Would I go here again?  Never.  Big waste of time, money and calories.

My girlfriends and I went here for happy hour.   The server was very friendly and doted on us.  Nice, but also annoying since we were trying to catch up and I guess he was lonely since the place was fairly empty.   Apps were decent but nothing to write home about and the wine was full price. 

I prefer Salt Creek Grille for happy hour.

Everything went wrong. Very expensive for less than mediocre food. Service was horrendous.  If your going to charge me a lot of money for a less than spectacular wine, please fill the glass. Don't fill it 1/3. Sorry, service was bad, food was worse than the service and was shocked at the bill. But then again, it's Princeton. Never again.

This review is solely about TreBar -- Tre Piani's wine bar next door.  We ate a take-out lunch one day & stopped by the next night for a wine flight & some tapas.  The lunch was INCREDIBLE.  We agreed it was the best turkey sandwich we'd ever tasted.  The bread was delicious.  We also shared a perfectly prepared pumpkin sage soup & their original hummus salad.  And you can't beat their lunch prices.  The next evening we ordered two Italian wine flights -- one white & one red.  There was only one red wine that we weren't crazy about -- all the other wines were wonderful.  But the tapas?  Mmmm... not so much.  We went on a Friday night -- it was very busy & the food suffered as a result.  The lamb was overcooked & the infamous "french kiss" sat on the counter for so long it was cold & hard.  We spent $93 for the two flights & 4 or 5 tapas & we were bummed that we didn't spend it at Ferry House.  Although the lamb wasn't prepared correctly & we didn't get our food on time, Rich & the bartenders were super friendly.  Next time we're in town we're definitely going back for lunch.

Ate here for Christmas Eve last year with the family and it was an overall good experience.  I would not classify my father and brothers as "foodies" so as long as their dishes are hot and come out quickly, the restaurant did it's job.  It's clear you're paying for the ambiance and live music as the food is on par with the much more casual Romeo's down the street.

I'm surprised I haven't yelped this establishment sooner, as I've held multiple functions here, along with spent time at their downstairs Tre Bar happy hour on many an occasion.

Tuesdays, head down to Tre Bar for happy hour to get their infamous Tre Burger for just $5 (and it comes with an order of fries)!  By far the best 3/4 pound burger you can get for the price...juicy and covered with caramelized onions, and farm fresh lettuce and tomatoes (and they support local businesses for this).  You can also get it halal just FYI.  Appetizer wise during happy hour, I've had their meatballs which are overly oily and their margherita pizzas which are nothing special...good thing they were about half off.  Note that they have other happy hour specials like 1/2 off glasses of wine, pastas, pizzas, etc on other nights.

Came here for dinner last night and started with a half dozen of their Cape May salt oysters ($10).   They actually gave us 7 oysters, which was a nice surprise (for the informed, a half dozen equates to six).  Wasn't a fan of the cilantro sauce accompanying the dish, but lemon was more than enough flavor for it.  Then shared a humus salad (~$9), which I wish their was more pita bread for...while I thought it was tossed with too much dressing, it very well could have been the fact that my friend had put olive oil in the humus, which I was not used to. I'd get it again.

Tried out their seafood mixed grill ($24 - see picture).  The salmon was a bit overcooked and burnt, as was the shrimp, but the calimari (which I though was an onion initially) was perfectly seasoned (although some may say it was salty), and the tuna was seared raw just the way I like it.  The 4 pieces of seafood sit over a bed of greens, which (once again) was overly dressed with their vinaigrette.

Overall, Tre Piani is quite pricey for the food and service; however, I highly recommend their happy hour specials at Tre Bar for those with a more constrained budget.

I absolutely enjoyed my evening at Trepiani. I went on Sunday, the day before Valentine's Day to celebrate a nice romantic evening- and that it definitely was. The decor is soft and not over-the-top. It's an italian-american restaurant with people who looked like they were enjoying their food (as we did). I have tried a few other Italian places in Princeton, the cost less with similar taste to what Trepiani offers, but there is a little bit more that tripiani offers (not a crazy rush, very friendly staff, definitely a classier option). 

The music in the background was eclectic (arabic beats, spanish drams, italian sonatas). 

We ordered the fried calamari, and enjoyed it. It was tasty with a not-so-overbearing sauce and a great tasting coating. 

My husband orderd the Tre Burger (off their Halal menu which they offer for those who eat halal) and itw as delicious. He loved the grill-feel that the restaurant kept without compromising their higher-class cuisine. 

I ordered eggplant rigatoni with tomatoes, garlic, capers and blackened chicken.. it was really tasty and definitely enjoyed the taste. It was not over-bearing, it was proportional with the other things on the plate and I didn't  need to bury it in lemons or pepper (as I typically have to do in Italian). 

And finally, the evening ended with my husband FULL, so that I could eat my desert ALONE-- definitely recommend their mint chocolate mousse was deliciiiiiiiious- it was $10'ish but prepare to spend in trepiani.. a dinner for two was around $70 (bear in mind my husband only ordered a burger)... so it is definitely on the $$$ area.

But, we do recommend it for those in a budget, to at least try the place. 
For those with money... I'd probably go more often!

We ended up in Tre Piani on a Saturday night for the amateur Comedy Improv show  (a bunch of Princeton folks, providing 90 min of entertainment for $15 a ticket.). Since the show was sold out, we went with low expectations of service - and unfortunately, it was exactly so. Very slow service, not too many wait staff upstairs, where we were seated.
