Food, when it finally arrived was OK - not great - calamari was a tad soggy (microwaved perhaps?) & came served with raw kale!, the fish special - grilled trout stuffed w crab meat - looked great, but got over before we could order it, our $20 pastas were good &  filling, bland though, and nothing I could'nt make at home for a lot less. And the glass of Malbec I ordered must have had sulfites or something in it, because I felt awful - so dehydrated - the next day. The creme brulee was a saving grace, it was perfectly carmelized & creamy inside, not too sweet, and the comedy was good. Still, no reason to go back.

business.full_address:
4511 Knox Rd
Suite 103
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Bananas Hair Design

reviews.text:
I have been going to Bananas off and on since I attended the University of Maryland in the '90s.  In college I would just do a walk-in and always had a different stylist.  As that my hair was long, layered and color-free, I never could gauge the quality of the cut - I was happy, the place was nice and friendly.

After college I tried many salons in the DC/MD area and no one seemed to know how to cut my fine (yet plentiful) slightly wavy, slightly curly hair.  I went back to Bananas just because I was in town and for the first time in years got a quality cut.  I continued to visit that stylist, and even when I got married I had my entire bridal party have their hair done at Bananas (and I also got my bridal manicure there).  All the updos were lovely, and my nails looked pretty yet subtle.

When my regular stylist moved away, the manager suggested I start seeing Kathleen.  Best decision I had made in a long time.  Kathleen totally got not only my hair type, but my personality and style.  I can go in and say, "I trust you" and come out with amazing color, a fabulous cut, and a great experience.

The other stylists are also quite talented - I have had my hair cut by John and Michael in the past and they are both artists.  I like to see loyalty and see stylists who have been there since I used to go in college.  Casey is the owner and she is regularly there, cutting hair, chatting with clients, fully aware of her business.  

Bananas moved in the past couple of years to a larger location off Knox Road.  The place is modern, cheery and always clean.  They have brand new tanning beds, waxing rooms, several chairs for cuts and washing, a color bar, and chairs for manis and pedis.  The place always seems busy, but I usually can make an appointment same week.  And a bonus - free parking (almost nonexistent in Downtown College Park)!

I find the prices are reasonable, competitive.  They often do promotions where you can get a discount on services if you refer a friend, etc.  They also have competitive prices on salon products by brands like Pureology and Redken.

I was recommended to this place by my friend's daughter who gets her hair cut there. I really just needed a trim, my hair was growing out, looking unruly and I had an event to attend the following day.

Michael cut my hair and styled it. He did a good job. I was happy when I left and I didn't have to go home and re-do my hair afterwards because the style looked good.

There's plenty of parking, its a block off of Baltimore Avenue, but not terribly close to the College Park metro if you are walking.

I'd go back, it was clean and the people were friendly. They didn't try to up-sell me on hair product and I appreciated that.

The cut itself, while an inch longer than I would have liked, was acceptable. By no means was it great or good, but my hair isn't falling out. This review is purely about the service.

At first everything seemed fine. The stylist was nice enough enough, I got a good shampoo, everyone seemed friendly. However, it soon turned sour. The stylist would not stop talking about how difficult my well maintained, medium length curly hair was. First of all, it is thick, but it is not tangled, and not THAT thick. Second I really don't like being like being essentially ridiculed by someone I am paying to do a job. I don't ridicule others when they come to my place of work and I expect likewise. 

Initially I had asked for 2 inches off. She took off maybe an inch. I then said I would wait until after it was styled to decide if I wanted more off. I did and after her accosting me for 30 minutes I decided I wanted it just a little bit shorter, to shoulder length. She tried to dissuade me solely because she didn't want to do more work, which she blatently said in order to get it shorter she would have to cut all of my hair (duh I wanted it even, not the mullet look). She then cut all the way up to my chin, not my shoulder. Ok fine. It's not what I wanted but it is hair. 

After the haircut (and miserable blow drying job, which left it frizzy and still half curly), she bolted to the desk. When I got there she was whispering to the woman at the desk. I was given the traditional first customer discount which brought my price down to... the price it was supposed to be. The website says $42-47 and after my $5 discount I was quoted at $47. Um what? Yes the woman had charged me $5 for my hair, my medium-length, well-maintained, albeit curly hair, was too difficult. After she moaned the whole time I was already fed up, then her cutting the wrong length and telling me I was wrong, she charged me extra.

The manager was nice enough, and I'm very unconfrontational (in fact this is my first ever review), but I will NEVER go back and plan to tell everyone else I know. There is no excuse for rude behavior, especially since it is your job and at nearly $50 it's not exactly the cheapest cut ever.

I've been going to Bananas exclusively for my haircuts for several years. I have had long hair cuts and now rocking a cute choppy bob. I constantly get compliments on my cuts and have referred several people (all with excellent results). The staff is quite friendly, the salon is clean, and appointments always run on time. And if you're looking for an awsome wax job, there is no place better (no place more economical either). So if you're looking for maintenance or a funky cut, Bananas is your place. BONUS: Free parking - which is nonexistent in College Park.

Cheers!

I used to get crazy overpriced haircuts and color done at a fancy salon in Chevy Chase. One day, when I couldn't get an appointment there, I tried Bananas, hoping for the best. Well, after that day I've been back many times, always with my awesome stylist, Katie. She is an amazing colorist, cuts my hair exactly how I like it, and always on time. I love talking to her; she has a great personality and is just so talented. The salon is laid-back and relaxing, with professionals who know what they're doing. What more could you ask for?

I have been going to Bananas for the past ten years. Kathleen does excellent color, cuts, and blow drys and she's an awesome person!  Whenever I come in with a particular look I want to try, she does exactly what I want. Cathy does a great job shampooing, it's like getting a massage:) Everyone is super friendly and I just love going there. I moved to Texas last August and still get my hair cut and colored there when I'm in town. Why mess with a good thing? 

If you are looking for an all-around awesome experience getting your hair done, look no further! The stylists are great and they listen to their clients.
Great!

I am only unhappy I did not discover this place like 2 years ago..! All those PAINFUL afternoons spent at Oho Nails for waxing..sigh! Well, I believe this is one of the best salons in College Park! They are spacious, clean, helpful and not too pricey either!

I am also super surprised that I am the first person reviewing this place! Whatever happened to all other UMD chicks?! :p

Anyways, I've been here for a haircut and wax. My underarm and arm wax was so good! The lady who did it was a wee bit talkative, but it worked well for me, cuz I needed something to distract me from the fear of pain anyways! :p  Well, she was polite, smiling, deft and very professional! She made my arm/underarm seem so much less painless and quick! 

For the haircut, well, I believe it might have been a bit pricey, but she did a good job, asking me what I specifically wanted, and then doing the same.

So on the whole, I love the place! 

p.s: The lady who owns the place, is nice to her customers, but at the same time really strict with the girls who work for her! :( I am not sure if I like that!

Never again. Low-end work with a high price tag.

Casey (the owner) and Kathleen seemed to be the only competent ones there. And the reviews here echo that.

I went in asking for dark red hair, specified that I wanted it more violet than orange, and brought three photos. I was extremely disappointed with the color it turned out to be, and politely expressed this to my stylist, Jannett. She said she would try to fix it, and proceeded to complain that it was a lot of work the entire time. After Jannett's second attempt at coloring my hair, I still looked like a nightmare. You could have taken my picture and put it next to the definition for "hot roots." I've added a photo to demonstrate, along with one of the three photos I brought in. I left in tears. I couldn't justify giving them a third chance at coloring my hair. I was genuinely afraid there was a chance i would walk out without any hair left.

I expected to walk out looking like a goddess. Instead I'm stuck coloring over it with ammonia-free dye until I can condition it enough to be willing to try coloring it again--elsewhere.

I noticed a curious sign stating that tips could only be in cash, because taxes have to be reported for all credit card transactions.

Check the filtered reviews, they all seem valid.

Rania N., why do you give five stars when your cut was just okay, and you wound up having to modify it yourself shortly after? Surely that is not "as good as it gets" for you.

What the heck? I am surprised there aren't more reviews for this place! This place rocks! I have been getting so many compliments on my new hair!

The last designer to touch my hair is located out of state leaving me to find a replacement back home in CP, MD. After lots of searching and back and forth I decided to give Bananas a shot.

At Bananas, I had my highlights redone but asked for bolder ones near the nape of my neck, toner to blend my roots and the rest of my hair + a haircut. The owner did my highlights and my oh my. She surpassed my expectations. Then Jillian arrived... she designed a pretty ok cut . She gives the best hair advice which is a plus.

To sum it up... my highlights came out UHMAYZINGGG. I was VERY surprised. My cut was OK.. I was hoping for a precision cut and to thin the weight out along with a frame for my face for the days I throw my hair up but instead I got layers for volume which I didn't ask for. I had to guide her for the frames and to define it more.. A few days later, I took some scissors in my bathroom and gave myself the frames I wanted.

Next time I will just have the owner do both...my highlights and cut. She owner is a genius.

I was afraid before going in because honestly, it is located in college park, md. I was afraid they wouldn't give me style and trend with some funk. I did not want to look like an old soccer mom. A High end salon in college park. I... love....it!

On second thought, I don't see too much good looking hair in CP so this probably is indeed a hidden gem. I am glad I do not have to drive far for a high end salon.

Kathleen is a color maestro and gives a darn good haircut too.  I really trust her to work magic on my hair.

The salon is unpretentious and comfortable and the prices are decent.

I just started going to Bananas this summer.  I was so desperate for a hair cut that I walked in and made a blind appointment.  I have been going to a salon in Columbia for about ten years.  I love it, but Bananas is closer to me.  And, like I said, I was desperate.  I came back for  my appointment with Kathleeen.  She was amazing!  She has a great spunky personality, and my hair cut was wonderful.  I usually don't get my hair blown dry because I am lazy and never do it myself.  She asked if she could dry it, so I agreed.  I felt like a movie star!  My hair was so beautiful that I left the salon calling everybody I could think of to go out that night!  I wish my hair would grow faster just so that I can go get it cut and blown out!!
A  note to people who complain about salon prices:
My step mother owned a salon.  Growing up, I got free hair cuts for many years.  Some good, and many not so good.  (a lot of experimenting on me)  When you find the right artist to do your hair, you shouldn't mind if the bill is $15 or $50 as long as you love your hair.  "you cut it to grow it, you grow it to cut it"

Went in today for the first time. I brought in a picture of the haircut I wanted. Jillian, the stylist, looked at the picture for 3 seconds and started cutting. Thirty minutes later my hair looked even better than in the picture. I have very thin hair and can never get it to do anything. Jillian actually gave me volume and shape to my hair. Very clean and professional place. Will definitely be going back.

business.full_address:
1217 State Rd
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Red Oak Diner

reviews.text: Another pedestrian Central NJ Diner. The decor is decidely bland. A measure of a diners food is the breakfast potatoes. These were flavorless, colorless and cold. At least they didn't burn the toast.
Don't know how this place survives. Ordinary food. Dismal service. Uncomfortable interior. I live less than two miles from this place, yet I drive five miles each way to another diner.
Went for lunch. Would not let me change the rye to wheat bread on the tuna special. Seriously? !  Not busy at lumchtime. No guesses here as to why.

business.full_address:
256 W 116th St
Harlem
New York, NY 10026
business.name: Africa Kine Restaurant

reviews.text: My boyfriend went this afternoon for the first time. I am Caribbean American and he is African American. From the moment we stepped into the dining room, we felt unwelcomed. No one greeted us, and the waitress was SLOW to arrive (because she was too busy talking and rolling silverware).  When she did arrive, she says "order- what do you want to order." No smile or anything. We knew to expect slow service, but she was rude and cold as well.  Although there were only 12 people there, service was absolutely terrible. We came in before the Hispanic family, (european) French family, and interracial family. We ordered before 2 of the three families, but were served last. Served 15 minutes after the last family to arrive, which was almost an hour after we sat down. While my boyfriend and I were wondering where our food was,our waitress sat down with her back facing up and proceeded to eat her own meal.  After watching her eat for about 10 minutes, we got up to leave and another waitress assured us our food was on its way.  We did NOT order complicated meals: shrimp and chicken skewers. So why were we ignored until the food arrived and served last? There were only 2 of us, compared to the non-black families of three and four that were served with kindness before us.

A+ for actual Africans eating there...

Service, Slow as molasses 

Portions, huge

Food, nothing to rave about.

DISGUSTING!!!

I ate here once and that was enough.  First it is in a semi abandoned building.  But a friend of mine insisted that we try it.  First the place can do for a remodel, but as an ethnic restaurant I tried not to let my western thinking effect things...but clean would have been nice.  I should have left when I WENT TO  THE BATHROOM AND THE WATER WAS NOT WORKING...  Plus it was nasty in there.  As someone mentioned the menu is sugesstive as many items aren't available so you need to talk to a waiter for a true idea of what you can order.  It took too long to get the food, and I noticed that they were microwaving the plates on the side.  I really hope I didn't eat yesterdays food in that rat trap!  DON'T GO!

I have to change my review. After squirming around last minute to find a place that would accommodate 20 people for my graduation dinner, Africa Kine was the only one who would do it for an affordable price. 

it was great, not to mention that they let us order from the dinner menu at 1pm when it generally isnt served until 5pm. The trick was I called Alhasan, the catering manager...who organized everything for me. Everyone loved the food and the service was pretty swift. It was nice cause we were virtually the only one's in here. I hope Africa Kine can have all its service be on this same par.
The dishes are great, very traditional food from Africa. Service needs to improve! The wait time is like forever, and the professionalism is just not there. The 3 stars are for the food only.

This place is in the middle of the Little Senegal neighborhood, and when my friend and I walked in we felt like we were transported right out of cold, concrete NYC into West Africa.  I would say one would have to be comfortable with going to Harlem and being in a very foreign-seeming setting to enjoy this place.  There were tables of Senegalese hanging out, socializing over food and drinks, really a fun experience to sit in the midst of this.  A casual atmosphere.  The waitress was very quick, attentive, and nice (and we were two women - I see some reviewers recommend going with men to get good service), and the food was great.  I had lamb with rice, with stewed onions on the side (and an extremely hot little green pepper on top, be very careful!), and my friend had the grilled whole talapia fish.  The food was very tasty and fresh.  I love the mix of spices used in West African food - very flavorful without being spicy.  The check came quickly.  Everything is very affordable, for New York City as well as for the size of the portions: $11 for my dish and $13 for my friend's fish, if I remember correctly.  I will definitely go back and recommend it to friends.

Came here on a Thursday at around 12:30 for lunch for my first and certainly not last dance with African food. Upon trying to enter the establishment I soon  found out the door was locked, I knocked a few times and some guy opened it (I think he is the manager/host/owner/waiter/chef/busboy). The genteleman's english wasn't the best but I was able to communicate with him thanks to HS french. I order some tap water and of course he brought out a bottle of Poland Spring, I was a little ticked off about this but let it slide. 

My friend and I both order the Lamb Mafe, it's a peanut based lamb stew over rice. Unlike many of the other people who reviewed this place our food came out very promptly (we were the only 2 patrons in the establishment which might have something to do with it). Anyway the Mafe was quite delish, unlike anything I've every tasted before. It reminded me of a mix between an Indian Curry dish and those cold Peanut Noodles that chinese restaurants serve. The lamb was tender and well cooked. 

On a 97 degree day eating this food and walking around the city for 5 hours may not have been the best combination, but I enjoyed my experience at Kine.

I love the food at this place.  The service here is a joke.  I honestly thought I was being punk'd.  The guy waiter is always nice and effecient, but the female waitresses are HORRIBLE.  They're slow and have really bad attitudes.  Last time we walked in the place was almost empty and the two of them just sat there watching TV looking at is like they didn't work there.  Then when we went to seat ourselves they still didn't get up, but instead said that the table we picked was dirty so we should sit somewhere else.  We've had bad service here a few times and each time we've sworn to NEVER return, but we really like the food.  Next time we'll just order and pick it up. 

The chicken brocette with couscous and plantains is great.  The piosson grill is also great.

A walk down the mountain of stairs in Morningside Park in Harlem is perhaps one of the most distinct changes in atmosphere possible in Manhattan. At the top of the stairs, the Ivy League university of Columbia, with its proud old buildings and campus courtyards. Young people scurrying this way and that or tanning in the lawn. Three minutes later, at the bottom of the stairs, one is thrust into the very different atmosphere of 116th Street, a distinctly West African part of New York City.

The noises are different, louder. The accents are French, and Wolof, and Bambara. The colors are brighter, the clothes flashier, and the people more sensual. The smells are sweet and spicy, and very alluring.

As the sun was setting to the west over Morningside Park and Columbia University, we decided to settle into a popular, yet cozy restaurant. My apologies for the photos, the interiors had almost no light. It was not the eyes that were necessary for this wonderful eating experience though. And how can you go wrong with an eatery that boasts such amenities like a coat check, a carryout window!, and even a "grand" ballroom downstairs!

At Africa Kine Restaurant the focus is on the cuisine of Senegal and is not so aspiring as the name might allude to, but that always equates to better food, as pan-anything restaurants are thoroughly mediocre in everything. And let's be honest, a menu with all the food of Earth's most diverse continent would be nothing short of insane.

The women serving us are beautiful, and beautifully wardrobed, in very bright dresses native to Dakar. We have many questions about the food, and all are answered with depth and friendliness. We are disappointed that the national dish of Thiebu Djen ($10) is only available at lunchtime, but are more than satisfied with our eventual selections, starting with the Poisson grillé ($11), which was served with an excellent onion relish/sauce, part mustard and part pepper spices. The fish was obviously cared for, as every morsel inside was tender and marinated to perfection.

Our other dish was Dibi ($11), grilled lamb also served with the same sauce. Unfortunately it turned out too tough and required a lot of jaw work. I will look forward to going across the street another day to the Dibiterie Cheikh, which sounds more promising in the world of Dibi.

The dessert menu was less than exciting, so we decided to take our search for sweets to the nearby candy stores catering to West African sweet toothes.
The food was good, A LOT OF FOOD! But the service is slow and inattentive.. but I think i kind of expected that..

The food is filling, tasty, and spiced well.
Waitress attention is hard sometimes especially at night.  It's a good place to take a date as well as a nice place to order out from.

More on the waiters.  They do not try and kiss your ass for a tip 10 times a meal like in some downtown restaurants and I appreciate that.  If you do not this not the place for you.  When I go out to dine I primarily care about the quality of the food.  The close at around midnight or 1 AM.

There isn't any real need for a menu after going here a few time, because they normally carry 5 basic dishes.  Grilled Fish, Chicken Kebab, Lamb, and 2 variations of the previous.  

Drinks: I recommend the Sorrel or the Ginger Drink (spicy)

Being that my hubby is from Senegal, I trust his judgement.  I read other's comments and was confused because we have eaten here on several occassions and the meat has never been tough.  Overall, I find the food to full of flavor and extremely filling, since the portions are large. My favorites are the Thu Okra and Thiebou Djeun.  The take out service does take some time, so be sure to call and order before arriving.

Food didn't seem pre-cooked or reheated to me. I got the Lamb Mafe and it was tasty, tomato-y, stew-y heaven with fall-off-the-bone tender lamb. Simple, hearty, good for what ails ya.

Service was crappy: There was only one guy and we were the only customers, and he was definitely more glued to his iPhone than us. Performed the most basic perfunctory services with nary a smile. Hence my docked star. Also, the place could be more cheerful and cleaner-looking. Hence, the other docked star.

But one taste of that hot, greasy stew and I could probably forgive anything.

Closer to 3.5 stars. The food is very tasty, portions are generous, and prices are fair. The decor and service is straight-forward and no frills. Last time I was there it was cash only. Only downside was that several items on the menu were unavailable and the waitress failed to mention so at beginning, instead waiting until we've perused the menu and decided what we wanted, only to find our 1st choice wasn't available :-/. Nonetheless, I'll be going back.

Okay, I'm sad by a lot of the reviews.  I've been to Africa Kine several times and never had a bad experience.  I always order the fish and it always tastes fresh and comes deliciously spiced.  Once the staff threw in peanut sauce on the side, for free, just because I asked for it.  I mean, you're not eating in a fancy, five-star restaurant --  the decor is somewhat cafeteria style.  And, sure, the service is slow, but the food is good and just accept you're not going to be waited on hand and foot.  The second time I went, a friend asked for something on the left side of the menu.  The waitress apologized and said that nothing on that side of the menu was available.  She didn't lie, she didn't try to push another dish, she just honestly explained the situation as it was.  We could have left, but instead found things that were available and ended up with a lovely, delicious meal.  If you want spicy, delicious food, this is a great place to go.  If you want a five-star dining experience, don't bother.

Save yourself the "Russian roulette" based on these reviews and go around the corner to Ambassador on 8th Ave btwn 118/119st.
Food is always high quality!

I've been eating there for 4 years and lately two or three times a week. Also it looks clean outside and inside.
Service can be slow occasionaly but has been getting better.
Just be firm and tell them if you've been waiting too long.
People are too scared to demand good service. Particularly in Harlem.
Same food as below

The food here IS OUTSTANDING!!! Amazing Senegalese food for incredibly affordable prices.  Literally everything on this menu, from the appetizer to the drinks to the entree tasted DIVINE!  There's enough seating for large groups, however this place is by no means the most aesthetically pleasing place you've seen....you get lost in the food that you wont really notice tho :)  The real reason this place gets a 4star from me is because the service take a WHILE.  My recommendation, order to go...they're much faster.  If you like chicken, order the Brochette Chicken (chicken skewers + moroccan couscous) or Dibi Allocco.

Bon APETITE!!

You know its really sad...because this place for African food is great-unfortunately the service TERRIBLE!  Make sure you go with Men! Otherwise its going to take you about an 1/2 an hour just to get water! The food is amazing, for the price and the portions are great! I usually get the full fried fish with salad and fries...The waitresses are really lost and barely want to talk to you (unless you are with MEN!!!)seriously!
I am so torn with my review on this place, because I would love to recommend the food, but the service really makes it a terrible experience!

This is a critic's pick in New York Magazine.

Be forewarned:  This is not the restaurant for those afflicted with TMJ!
I don't know what was harder to swallow:  the tough meat or the god-awful service.

The place serves no alcohol, but allows you to BYOB.  If you choose to do so, arrive bearing the necessary tool to pry open your beverage. We practically used our teeth.

So, why is this a "critic's pick" in New York Magazine?

First off, the restaurant was out of most of its dishes.  Perhaps this was due to the lateness of my party's arrival.  However, judging from the other reviews, I sense that time had little to do with the limited menu.  Ultimately three of us ordered the Dibi, and the fourth ordered the fried fish [as those were the only two dishes available].  Having ordered the rock hard lamb, I preferred the fried fish because at least it was edible.  My tilapia-ordering companion preferred the lamb because at least it had flavor.  Eh, it's a matter of taste [or lack there of] I suppose...

Seriously, why is this a "critic's pick" in New York Magazine?

The meal was proceeded by pleasant conversation amongst a sated bunch waiting for the check.  While I love a rousing chat with my friends, after 15 minutes of watching the waitress sit in a chair, I was relieved when she finally brought the check.

Which was wrong.  The check was wrong.  She had erred by a good amount, and the gratuity was included.  I asked the waitress to fix her tremendous error, which she did - by hand.  [albeit no change to the inflated gratuity]  Also, as another reviewer commented, do bring cash.  If you don't, they unapologetically add a 5% service charge on to your bill.  

I think I will try a different restaurant in Little Senegal in the future...
Probably not one out of NYM...
The food here is amazing! All of it!!

The food is yummy, I normally don't eat lamb but when I go there from now on, I will choose the lamb.  Its seasoned well, cooked well, and the side dishes are also pretty good. 

Its open late ~~

the service,well let me just say that they wont go down in history for the best service awards.... so if you don't care about that and just want to come out with a satisifed stomach you'll be satisified. If you care about the people to overly greet you and cater to you... its not the place for you...

As far as price, they are NOT down town prices and not down town serving sizes so it works out pretty good

Was there with my friends on Saturday and we all surely enjoyed the great tasting food at Africa Kine Restaurant in West Harlem. It is a nice place to hang out, the decor is simple with lots of African paintings, it is also quite spacious. The service is slow but what I heard that is normal ... ha! The service staff are very very friendly. Now over to the food, it was my first time eating African cuisine, definitely a nice change. I had the Thiebu djeun which is fish stewed in tomato sauce with eggplant, carrots, cassava & white cabbage, served over exotic rice, this is their traditional dish and it was simply delicious. My friends had the Grilled chicken with seasoned vegetable rice and Savory lamb with seasoned vegetable rice. The lamb looked really good but since I don't eat lamb/mutton/goat dishes, I will never find out how tasty the dish is .... heh heh. I had the Ginger Beer, a non-alcoholic drink which seems to have a mixture of ginger, water, sugar, water and have a tinge of citrus taste. The pricing is very reasonable and the portions are big. Everyone definitely had a good enjoyable time.

Amazing! I had the lamb in tomato stew, huge portion, with a nice blend of spices in the stew sauce. Friends had a chicken dish, as well as a grilled fish with a very strong flavor, reminiscent of blackened catfish flavor. Nice!

Had food from here several times. Its rather inconsistent in quality. The service is can also be slow and border on unpleasant. Now maybe this has to do with that we live in the neighborhood and have brown skin so we do not get treated with respect like others who venture uptown, but that makes it so that I wouldn't really recommend this place as I am not sure what attitude or food quality you will get.

I was with friends that I haven't seen in a long time so we decided to celebrate and enjoy a good African meal, we made the mistake to go to Africa restaurant...
We were with hungry kids and waited over an hour for our food. Asked for water over and over again which was given to us at the end of our meal in a very nasty pitcher full of sauce.
One of the kids received her order and started eating when a very upset waitress came by to yell at us that they made a mistake and the  meal was for someone else.
The food seemed/tasted old so we barely ate. The restroom are really gross, and at the end we waited another 45 minutes to get our check....
They had included the gratuity which we refused to pay by principle.
I am from West Africa and felt awfully embarrassed to have my friends go through this experience. I walked in proud to share part of our culture, a good, tasty meal as we know so well how to make them. I came knowing that for the Senegale culture the word "Teranga" which means "hospitality" is one of their values. Although run by Senegalese, this place has nothing warm and hospitality has obviously no meaning in their vocabulary.
I walked in proud to share what Africa is all about and walked out a bit ashamed by the whole thing. I will never go back and will never recommend this restaurant.

The food is perfect to me. If you want to try African food or if you're an amateur, you'll love the food there. The only thing is that the service is non existent. Three stars are only for the food. It's low price, tasty, fresh and they serve you large amount of food. They should hire real waitress that knows about customer service...

Africa Kine has authentic, delicious Senegalese food!!!

I've gone there several times and have had the thiebou djeun (national fish and rice dish), thiebou yapp (lamb and rice), chicken and shrimp brochettes, suppa kanja (super yummy okra sauce with fish/lamb and lovely distinctive red palm oil w/ rice); chicken/fish yassa (lemon and onion marinated, with rice), basic, well flavored grilled/fried fish with fries/salad and tasty grilled onions..

I can honestly say I have never been disappointed with their food. The food taste and quality is consistently delicious. Maybe 3 times I have asked for a dish that wasn't ready yet (would have to wait) or that wasn't available, but I was steered to what was ready and have never been disappointed with food. And even this is not an inconvenience as I'm happy to know that the server is honest upfront, that someone is in the kitchen developing the taste of the home-style meal and that any option here is still a good option!!

Service can be perceived as a bit lacking if you have expectations of being asked constantly if things are ok and require constant checking...however, personally i go there strictly for the food...the servers are not overly attentive this is true...when i go alone it does take some time to get attention of a server, maybe around or a bit less than 5 minutes, menus are usually on the table already so I just peruse or watch whatever is on the wall-mounted TV...i have witnessed that a group of men will receive attention right away (receiving attention, drinks and food before I receive my food despite my having arrived earlier) and when I dine with a male companion the servers are more immediately attentive, but I chalk it up to the culture of the beautiful Senegalese people and am not bothered in the least...just letting you know what to expect

Decor: not totally unattractive, but dated. It looks standard for what is considered nice when Ive visited countries in Africa...Things are clean. Bathroom clean but not attractive.

Bottom line:This place lets you relax!!! I love that I do not feel rushed here, that sometimes I can watch an African soap on the TV, read a magazine or newspaper if I like while waiting, that the food is DELICIOUS, the portion sizes generous and the prices are excellent!! They are real people, polite, beautiful with gorgeous smiles creating incredible food at a very fair price!!

Tip: if you are done and want to go and don't see your sever just go to the counter, simple enough and better than just sitting there. Likewise, if you want or need something and don't see you particular server: just ask the nearest server to find your server or just ask for what you need, they are always accommodating and whoever is at hand will usually take care of you. Not standard, I know but, so what...things are what they are!

Africa Kine is the best Senegalese food restaurant i have been to in the US. The food is fresh and delicious , the staff is pleasant and the atmosphere and restaurant is clean and cozy. The food is authentic ( i am from Senegal born and raised). I never Fail to take a taxi to Harlem every time i go to New York to have food from there.
I took several friends there from all different backgrounds and they loved it and go there religiously.

Prices are nice for any budget.  Large savory portions.  Best time to go where there is not a crowd is between 2 pm and 4 pm.

If you like something different and spicy.  Waitresses are very nice, but in that culture they do not rush, so sit drink some Bissup juice, and chat with friends, the food is worth the wait.

I called my order for pick up and they told me it was going to be ready in 15 minutes. I was staying at a friends pad in West Harlem during my visit in NYC so the restaurant was only a block and a half away. It was 11pm, I dragged my friend out in his pjs to pick up the food with me.

We get there.  The vibe of the place is weird.  There's a random guy with a table set up selling what seemed like pirated DVDs.  Weird.  The pick up window reminds me of the 24-hour Jack In The Box on Geary Street in San Francisco.  I told the guy I was there to pick up my order.  He looked puzzled.  I guess they never made it.  We wait for another 10 minutes and finally he calls me to the window and hands me a black plastic bag.  I pay him, then we walk out.  

OK food (the beef was a bit chewy and rice was sticky), not the best service, but big portions (had enough leftover for breakfast the next morning).

I've frequented this restaurant from its days on W. 53rd Street, when the grilled fish was fresh and tasted of Senegal. Several years ago, 53rd closed, so I shifted uptown to the W. 116th St location. 

Over the years I've experienced a serious decline in service and taste. The fish is bland; request to have it prepared "Senegalese Style" or "well-seasoned" are ignored. One day I wanted a side of joloff rice, for which I was willing to pay. The wait staff refused to bring it, telling me it was finished. I ordered it from take out as I left the restaurant. 

I always request grilled fish and often receive it fried or steamed...only to be told it is grilled. I stopped going ...only returning when my taste for grilled fish and salad was overwhelming. Well. My most recent experience was so insulting and awful that I promised them I'd never return...

I went there with a friend last night.  The service was beyond horrible.  The waitress would not even speak to us.  After about 30 minutes, my friend decided to call her over and ask for soda, the waitress seemed upset and walked away sayings SPICS.  We could not believe what we just heard, We continued to stay and realized that everyone else around us who had just walked in, were being served within minutes.  We got up and walked out.  It was obvious that they are predudice there.  I am still in shock.  When we walked out, 2 ladies by the steps said that they saw how we were treated and that we should notify the owner because they always do that.

Dakar, Senegal, is a place I would like to visit. I had a layover there once, and it seemed like a cool place. 

Africa is a world of wonder. If I could, I'd spend all my days traveling there. But since that's impossible, I have to settle for eating at one of NY's African restaurants, in this case Africa Kine, a Senegalese joint on 116th Street in west Harlem. 

The dining area is located on the second floor. It's nothing fancy but the wood-and-brick interior, with art on the walls and big curtains on the windows, is soothing. African tunes play softly in the background. 

I grabbed a seat in a booth by the window and settled into a good read, one that takes place in Congo. For a starter I could not resist Nem ($7). These Vietnamese spring rolls -- which reflect how other french-colonial cultures emigrated to Senegal -- were served with a spicy fish sauce, along with lettuce and sliced carrots for wrapping. They were excellent! 

Meanwhile, I noticed the TV was turned to the Olympics and when a runner from troubled Zimbabwe won a semifinal heat in Track & Field, a few customers cheered quietly. 

On to the entrees, where I had a tough time choosing. There was the Pintade, grilled guinea fowl served with eggs and seasoned onions....hmmm, perhaps not...I've seen how cute guinea fowl are, running like crazy men along the sides of the dusty African roads, and I could not in good conscience eat one. Too bad it wasn't Friday when Soup -- a cow foot with vegies -- is served.

I settled on dibi, a dish of grilled lamb served with a salad, a side order (fries!!) and seasoned onions. The lamb had a charcoal-taste, smoky, but it was a little tough for my taste. Still it was pretty good, plentiful and quite the deal at $11. I washed it all down with homemade ginger beer. 

Africa Kine was an interesting night out. I wouldn't necessarily take a first date here but it's a worthwhile stop on your culinary tour of Manhattan. The service is a bit slow but, hey, that's the way things work sometimes in Africa. 

Someday I'll definitely make it to Dakar. Meantime I'll get my fill of Africa along 116th Street.

A nice atmosphere is certainly not what Africa Kine is going for. When you arrive at the restaurant you enter a strange run-down vestibule area and then walk upstairs to a restaurant that is in serious need of a renovation (bad economy or not they should really consider doing something). I would definitely recommend avoiding the bathrooms as they are in even more need of a makeover. On the plus side avoiding the bathrooms should be fairly easy as you will not get refills of water, which I actually don't think you'd want because if I had to describe the water in one word it would be 'thick'. I don't know what this means and I don't want to give it too much thought but seriously that water was thick yo. 

I've read reviews that the service at Africa Kine is incredibly slow, but surprisingly it was quite speedy when I went with my friends. We ordered a plate of plantains for the table which were pretty good - not too greasy, but a bit unevenly cooked. I had the chicken kabobs with salad, onions and cream sauce. The chicken kabobs were quite good - nicely flavored and all white meat. I was not a fan of the onion salad nor the cream sauce but I believe that was more of a personal preference. The salad was....a salad....nothing exciting to report at all. It was fine. 

Though we got our food very quickly, we were not so lucky with the check. It took over 10 minutes for us to get our waitress's attention and when we finally received the check, the prices were different than on my friend's menu. 

I suppose I should have tried a more typically Senegalese dish, but based on what I had I do not plan on going back uptown to Africa Kine anytime soon. The atmosphere, or more accurately the total lack of atmosphere (and generally feeling of uncleanliness) will most definitely prevent me from going back.

Once you get pass the lack of service from the waitresses who take forever to serve you, you get your food and are finally happy that you made the trek to Harlem. It's great to enjoy some traditional bites, and the appitizers are very tasty. Be warned however, you will be very exasperated by the lack of service.

business.full_address:
10250 Baltimore Ave
Suite D
College Park, MD 20741
business.name: Essential Day Spa

reviews.text: You know... I don't know why these reviews are so negative. I've been there twice already and I've had great experiences. Both times I got a pedicure and they were very relaxing... nice foot massage, I love the massage chairs, and my feet and toes look great. They also gave me a nice manicure yesterday and a good eye brow wax the first time I went there. It's nice and clean and the prices are very reasonable. I've been to other nail salons in the College Park/Hyattsville area and this one is my favorite.

Best place to get your nails done in the College Park and surrounding area! The only nail salon around College Park to offer a pink-and-white manicure. Kelly is wonderful and so is her husband. 

The second time I walked in they remembered exactly who I was! Wonderful service and happy people!

I was running late and ran in here to get a quick lip wax. Should have just waited. The lady just slopped on some wax getting it on my lips and chin, and could have cared less about how it looked. When I askes her to rewax a section that she had missed she pushed the wax stick hard on my face, almost as if to punish me for asking her to do her job!! Never EVER again. And now, which I've never had before in my life after a wax, i have bumps all over my lips. Charged me 7 bucks for the honor.

I really, really needed the toes done and my friend took me to Essential Day Spa for a pedi...the results was great but the experience was bare bones.  For a few extra bucks I added the paraffine treatment and basically walked out with a good foot scrubbing, toes clipped and new polish.  $32.00. Not bad but, like I said, bare bones treatment....no foot rubs or massage of the lower leg. I probably would not return except that my friend goes there so if we decide to do a pedi day, I will go with her!

I've been to both the College Park and the Hyattsville location. Both are equally bad. Now I'm referring more about the customer service. The employees constantly speak bad about each customer. Every time I have gone, I have brought along a friend who understands each and everything they say. The employees say some customers are fat, some customers have ugly feet, etc. I know I wouldn't accept an employee talking poorly about customers at any other business, why am I purchasing from a business that does this on a regular. I continuously receive gift cards here, thus I go. However, if it were my choice I wouldn't dare be supporting this business. 

During my last visit (to the hyattsv location), I didn't have a clue what the employee was saying. I had to ask my Vietnamese friend to tell me. When I handed her my gift card at the end she looked puzzled and had no clue what to do with it. The last time I went to College Park and gave them my gift card, the employee looked pissed off and apparently in Vietnamese told the other employee that I was cheap because I didn't walk in there with money. The last time I checked, a gift card is used as money -- so what difference does it make!! 

Ughhhh, I wish this place was better. I so wanted it to be nice. However, this is a big strikeout.

I took my Hubby here to get both of us pedicures. The salon is clean, great pedicure stations, the ones with the nice comfy massage chairs and nice jet tubs. That's where the good ends! For $25 they barely spent 15 minutes on our feet, and the place was empty! They only used the cuticle cutter and a pumice like stone to scrub the deadskin. No cutting, triming, filing or shaping of the nails. No time taken to remove the deadskin from the feet. No base coat, 2 coats of polish and a top coat. I came home and still had cracked heels. I had to file off my own deadskin. Ive paid less and gotten better service, Needless to say they won't be seeing me again.

First let me say, I never write reviews but this establishment gave me just the proper motivation. 
The place was clean which is very important to me but that is the ONLY positive thing I have to say about it. 
The other reviews were right; all of the employees talk very loud the whole time. Talking goes on in other salons but I have never seen anything like this. 
Not only is it annoying to hear someone yell less than a foot away from you but I had a hard time getting a word in to ask her to shape my nails differently... and it wasn't a couple comments they talked the whole time. 

The other thing is she just barked orders at me. I don't expect to be pampered but I do expect someone that is pleasant. 

Lastly, I got a french manicure. As the woman did the first two nails I explained that I wanted less of a white tip to which she responded it would not look good. 
Once she finished I told her that indeed I did not like so much white and she yelled at me and almost refused to fix it. 
Now I understand that she may have been frustrated that she had to redo it but if I know what I want then I think it should be done that way. 

The polish they had made me wish that bottles had an expiration date. It was clumpy and had the little fuzzies. 

So all in all if you bring your own nail polish and you don't have a preference on how you want your nail shaped etc. and you don't mind an attitude and you still want to pay full price, then knock yourself out.

UPDATE: My french manicure has 3 chipsonly two days later.

Pop Quiz:  How does a manicurist know when it's time to crack open a fresh bottle of nail polish?

a. The old one is empty.

b.  The bottle's not empty, but when the brush is removed from the bottle, long, gummy strings of clumpy polish emerge, threatening to form an acrylic web that will connect the bottle, brush and client's nails to eachother for all eternity.

c.  Never.  Just spit in that sucker and give it a good stir.

Trick question!  If you are a reasonably astute individual, you know the correct answers are both A and B.  However, if you work at EssDaySpa, the correct answer is apparently C.  (Okay, okay, there was no spitting, but still.....)

Worst. Manicure. EVER.  

I think it was the receptionist who ended up doing my french mani, given the way she seemed to be trying to simultaneously man the front desk, take payments, arrange bookings, bark orders at her co-workers, etc.  She rushed through the process and her work was haphazard and slapped on.  Add to that the fact that she seemed determined not to waste a fresh bottle of clear polish for my mani -- absolutely STUBBORNLY determined to gather the coagulated, stringy goo in the old bottle and somehow transfer it to my nails -- and you can probably imagine the results.  But I'll describe it for you anyway.

French manicures feature painted white tips with a clear or pale pink sheer polish on top.  MY french manicure features topography similar to a small mountain range; little white freckles on the nail beds where the 'manicurist' accidentally slopped the white tip color (she was in a hurry -- no time to wait for things to dry!); and today, the morning after, parts of the paint job are already lifting off the nail bed.  And the piece de resistance?  Some of the nails on my left hand feature delicate little lines, thanks to the fact that the tips of her hair dragged through the wet polish while she was working on me.  

Full disclosure:  Thanks to the generosity of a lovely former work colleague who treated me to my mani, I did not actually pay for the crappy results now displayed on my fingertips. So this review isn't motivated by feelings of being ripped off.  It's motivated by the desire to warn strangers about this joke of a joint, and general irritation that I have to go buy a big bottle of polish remover to get this mess off my hands before I go to work tomorrow.

I cheated on my nail salon just to get my brows done here. The girl who did my eyebrows here was very sweet. She shaped them better than I had been getting them done elsewhere. She waxed them thinner than I had asked but in the end I was happy because she

After reading the reviews on here, I took my chances and went to Essential Day Spa 2, the new location in Hyattsville.  I couldn't find any other reviews for this one, so I will post my experience here.  The spa is in a convenient location not too far from my house and there is plenty of parking.  There's also a few restaurants nearby for lunch with friends before or after.  I was really hoping that some of the negative reviews would be inaccurate or exaggerated and that this would be my new go-to spot for pedicures and such.
I went during lunch hours and the place was empty.  There was a lady at the desk and instead of being friendly, she asked "What do you want?".  Maybe I should have taken that as I sign to leave, but instead I responded with "a pedicure" and picked up a brochure.  She instructed me to pick out a color and another girl began to get a chair and foot tub ready.  
I have to admit, the chair was super comfy and everything was really clean.  Overall, the atmosphere was pretty relaxing.  My complaint would be that there was no where to put my purse and I found it strange there weren't any magazines anywhere.  Not too big of a deal; I don't mind placing my purse on the floor and I can bring my own magazine.
Now onto the pedicure... The girl started by "selling" me all of the extras.  I told her NO several times and she continued to insist.  I shouldn't have to say no five times and then open the brochure and point to the services that I want.  Finally, she understood and began the "basic" pedi + hot stone foot massage.  My feet soaked for maybe two minutes, then a quick scrub, then she clipped two out of ten nails!  Only two!  The big toe on each foot.  She didn't even file any of them or work on my cuticles before adding the clear coat.  What's the point of having the service done if they skip 3 steps?  After the clear coat, she did one coat of red and didn't follow up with a second red coat or another clear coat.  When nails were drying, she told me that they were dry and pointed me to the register.  At the register, I had to explain my charges to the lady and again she was rude.  I asked to leave the tip on my card and she said "you leave cash".  I had cash, but asked if I could leave it on the card instead, again "you leave cash".
I'm giving three stars because I really did enjoy the hot stone foot massage and I didn't think that $7 extra was too expensive for what it was.  If you're looking to try this place out, just don't have high expectations.

Okay I have been going here regularly for almost a year.  I get mani-pedi's and my eyebrows done and have always been extremely pleased. I always go to Tina or Lisa they are both great and so sweet, the other ladies also seem very nice and from what I have seen do an excellent job.  Tina even chases me outside to give me my nail polish that I always seem to forget.
    I see some complaints mentioning high pressure sales. I have NEVER been pressured to select extra things such as spa pedicure, etc.  They always ask before they do anything extra and if i don't want anything extra, I just say no thanks and they leave it at that, no pressure or lack of service after that.
  The price is comparable to any other salon and they include a paraffin wax dip for the manicure.  They do not let you put the tip on your credit card so make sure to hit up the ATM before hand.  There is a bank in the shopping center.
    Another really great thing about this place is how clean and nice everything is.  It is clean, not usually crowded, great massage chairs that all work, and plenty of free parking. 
    If you haven't been in a while I would give them another chance :)

STAY AWAY PEOPLE! 
I had a manicure done once here awhile back, and from the sounds of these reviews, NOTHING has changed! 

I was waiting to meet up a friend at Buffalo Wild Wings, and was trying to kill time, so I came in for a manicure. It all started with the nail technician complaining about how I wanted a manicure and not a pedicure. She then complained that I was taking forever to pick out a polish for "just a manicure". She then sat me down, and continued to talk trash about me and how boring her life was and how she wished some rich guy would come along and whisk her off! BLAH BLAH BLAH.

Of course, she had NO idea that I could understand every last word she was saying, and even looked at me at one point and said, "this girl looks like she knows what I'm saying", but never bothered to actually ask me if I did. What an idiot. 

To top off all her trash-talking, my 12-year old cousin could have given me a better manicure. She missed the sides of my nails, and the layers were so messy. I left completely dissatisfied, and my technician surely heard while I complained through the phone to my cousin in the same language she's been talking about me in. 

After awhile of not being able to get over how ugly they really looked while at Buffalo Wild Wings, I came back and demanded that the polish be removed. I didn't even want her to put a new polish on, because I knew it would be as equally nasty. She then tried to be very sweet, but it was bit late and extremely fake.

GO ELSEWHERE PEOPLE!

I don't usually give reviews, but having read the ones for this spa, I wanted to speak up.  I've been going to this spa for about 3 years, and I absolutely love it. I am floored by these bad reviews.  I know that beauty is always a subjective experience, but these people do a really nice job, they are nice and quick.  It always looks really nice, if something doesn't look good, they fix it....I just can't imagine what people are expecting?!?!  They also give you a hand massage complimentary and a wax dip.  I've been to a lot of places in this area, they tend to be cheaper than most. Unless you expect to be treated like Queen Victoria, this is the place to go for the non-royality folk.

AWFUL! AWFUL! AWFUL!

This place is absolutely horrid!  I took my boyfriend to get a pedicure a couple of weeks ago and it was terrible.  First off, the lady at the reception desk was pretty unfriendly as we came in.  Immediately telling me to pick a polish before she even knew what we were there for.  I told her that we both wanted pedicures, she begins repeating "It's extra for him! It's extra for him!".  I say, fine (as it wasn't a problem).  She rushes us back to the spa chairs.  The young lady who did my pedicure was alright.  She didn't provide her name and when I asked her she acted as if she didn't hear me.  My pedicure was adequate, not good, not great, but adequate.  My boyfriend's on the other hand was terrible. It just so happened that the lady who greeted us was the one who did his pedicure.  She did almost nothing.  I was so ticked because I didn't look at his feet before we left as he was done before me (no polish).  When we got home, I looked at his feet and immediately called the salon and asked to speak to a manager.  They scurried and said he was gone home for the day.  I explained the situation and since they didn't ask my name or tell me theirs they only recognized me by the amount of tip I gave the two ladies.  Oh, had I known his was so bad, I wouldn't have tipped his pedicurist until she'd actually done a proper pedicure.  His feet weren't pumiced, his nails weren't buffed or filed.  She only clipped his toenails and washed his feet!!!  They tell me to come back the next day for ME to get a new pedicure...um, I didn't want one for me, but for him.  So the next day I call back to speak to the manager who said his name was "Ethan".  Ethan tries to get me to come in right away, but the problem was neither of us live in College Park and my boyfriend has a pretty busy, high pressure work schedule so coming in during the week wouldn't work, hence our coming on a weekend (and they were NOT busy).

Needless to say, I will NEVER return to this establishment! Nor would I recommend them.  Why is a man's pedicure more when they don't do a much?  Also, they taught me NOT to tip until AFTER you see the work they've done for the other people with you.

The guy barely spoke english. He had goobs and gobs of this acrylic on my nails and underneath the tips. I looked at him and said it appears you do not know what you are doing, is there someone else that can take over from here? The man appreared to be running the shop  was standing there and totally ignored my request and went to the back of the shop where i could not access him. I looked on the walls and no one had their licenses posted. This guy was young had a short haircut with blonde accent highlights in the front. I should not have to pay that type of money for someone to practice on my nails. I kept my cool, because I knew that the way to fight back would be to send this letter. 
 
I am asking that someone from the state go in the salon and ask everyone working to show their licenses and ask them why they are not in view for the customers. My nails hurt from being handled roughly and the application of the chemical is a bit too thick. I did not want to make a scene, but I am asking that the State contact me after they have visited Essential Day Spa to notify me of the worker's license status. 
 
I feel like once you sit down and these people get started, you are at their mercy, they have the upper hand because they can communicate in their own language, leaving you in the dark as to what is really going on. They had no price listings and their pamphlets were all gone, for all I know the nail tech. could have just made up the $50 price just so he could ensure himself a fat tip.

My manicure and pedicure here were TERRIBLE.  The girl put on basecoat, two coats of color and a topcoat bam-bam-bam with NO drying time in between.  The result is that there was hardly any polish on the tips of my fingernails, and they started chipping immediately.  The manicure looked two weeks old by the next day and the second day after I had to remove it because it looked so shabby.  I was super careful with my nails too.  
She didn't know how to use a file and sawed back and forth, making the edges of my nails ragged.
I also felt rushed through and ignored, she glared at me when i tipped about 18% (WAY more than she deserved but they made me pay and tip before my manicure- makes sense but not if they use that as an excuse to do a crappy job!)

DO NOT GO HERE!  I read all these reviews before I went, and most people had a good experience, but mine sucked.

save your time and money and don't go here. I have been here to get my eyebrows done and even though they looked alright it doesn't excuse the rushed and carelessness of the woman doing them. She put the wax on my skin WAY too hot and when she pull she tore the hair & skin under my eyebrow clean off. talk about painful. not only did she then charge me for this mutilation, she expected a tip. it took weeks for my poor eyebrow to heal. :(

I just want to start by saying I highly recommend that you do NOT go to this salon!!

When they first opened a few years ago, they were very friendly, and very CLEAN!... That has changed BIG TIME!

I live and work in the area, when I attended for their grand opening, I recommended the place to ALL of my friends who live and work in the area as well!!  The staff was very friendly, took their time to ensure you were getting great service, and most importantly the salon was super clean!!  My friends agreed!! It was the local place to go!!

As time went on (in a matter of a couple months actually) the service went way down hill.  One when you walk in the door they no longer really greet you, you kind of just stand their hoping they will finish their personal conversations and notice you!!  I get that its a salon and when you don't have any customers sure feel free to lounge around on the pedicure chairs in your lil group and chat and eat... BUT when you do have a customer ugh I dunno it may be a good idea to make them feel welcomed??? But what do I know?..

Also when someone FINALLY acknowledges you..... they are very short with you ask you what you want!! Most of the time I simply go there to get my eyebrows waxed.... (every 2 weeks)... and I suppose that is NOT good enough for them because they catch an attitude and point to a filthy room for you to go lay down in.....then they proceed to tell you what you NEED.  you need ur mustache waxed!! (excuse me, I am a female and I take offense to that!! one I am a white female and the couple of little hairs that are above my lip are BLONDE and unnoticable....) not to mention I didnt ask for that.  I will tell them no thanks, and then they catch an attitude and take it out on your brows!! Ripping your skin right off (never used to be that way)... sometimes they even pick up my hands when I am getting my brows waxed and will say you need a manicure.... :(

When I do go to get a mani-pedi...... they always try to UPSELL to spa mani-pedi which is significantly more.... and of course their a business so I get that they are trying to upsell.... ONLY problem is.... they dont tell you that its more expensive, or anything... they JUST start doing it.  I go in and ask for a mani pedi, pick out my colors sit in the pedicure chair, and then they will put the parafin, etc on you....and just do it.... then when you get the bill its ridiculous the pricing when you ask about it... they say you didn't say NO! And I say you didnt tell me what you were doing, or that it wasn't included in the regular pricing etc...once I learned i passed that around to my friends... I did continue to go a few more times, hoping that maybe it was just an off day or something...but NO dissapointed everytime I left... and after learning about the spa mani-pedi upsell, i would say to them just a regular mani-pedi...they would catch an attitude and do a TERRIBLE job.... absolutly terrible... I could paint my nails better with my eyes closed using my teeth.  Honestly... I try not to complain.... and I am the type of person that would try to offer suggestions to help fix their service... but they didn't care or want to hear it.  I always tipped.... even when I shouldn't had....thats just the type of person I am ... but now that i think about it I really shouldn't have I was treated rudely, and the job done was terrible.


It really disapoints me that their service declined SOO much.  My friends and I have all discussed this several times, and we all found new salons!!... Just disapointing that it had to go down that way.... From the bottom of my heart, my review is 100% accurate.... I highly do NOT recommend this place what so ever!!

P.S. Not to mention parking in that shopping center isn't easy anyways!! This salon isn't worth the circling of the lot to find a space!!

business.full_address:
Mercer Mall
3371 US Hwy 1
Lawrenceville, NJ 08648
business.name: Great Looks 4 Less Hair Salon

reviews.text:
I just went to GLFL yesterday because my regular hair stylist has moved. I heard about GLFL when they came to Gold's Gym Lawrenceville to cut hair to raise money for victims of Hurricane Katrina.

This was my first time going to the salon.

As soon as I walked in, it felt like a peaceful place. Nice music, warm & stylish decor, and I was given a friendly greeting by Lena who was to be my stylist.

Lena was wonderful, professional and genuine. Having a head massage while getting my hair washed was a pleasant bonus! A cup of hot tea during my haircut was nice, too. I truly felt pampered, comfortable and cared for at this very affordable salon. Denise, the owner, was gracious and friendly.

When I got to work yesterday everyone complimented me and loved the haircut.

Thank you Lena, Denise and Great Looks For Less Salon

Christina

I've been going to Great Looks 4 Less for almost 1 year now and I've had a wonderful experience. Owner Denise is my stylish and she's fantastic. My hair is not the easiest to cut but she really takes her time when working with me. If it's not just right, she encourages you to come back so she can make tiny "tweaks" until it's just perfect. She is a master at color too and I get so many compliments on my hair. I can't recommend them enough!!

I brought my 8 year old daughter here for a very simple, straight across the back hair cut.  She sat in the chair for 1 1/2 hours!  I've never seen people in a salon move so slow.  Both my daughter and I were so frustrated when we left.  The cut is ok.  But the time it took to do it was just ridiculous.

business.full_address:
1005 Columbus Avenue
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Mirror Image Beauty Salon

reviews.text: I'm totally a fan of this place. I first tried this place on the recommendation of a co-worker. I later found out a few other friends I know go there too. They really take care of my hair. They have a variety of great conditioners, but I always bring my own (and save a few $s while a it). I really like that the women won't blow all of your hair out unless you ask for it. Usually, they'll just blow out the roots which is so much healthier for my hair. It's no longer as dry and brittle as it used to be. They also have a loyalty card. After a certain number of wash and sets (8 or 10 I think) you get a free one (not valid on weekends though). Also, it's closer than where I used to go up near 145th so I save on travel time. This place is near 110th.

NATURAL HEADS BEWARE!!! I have 4a shoulder length hair and it was a big hassle finding a stylist who could work on me.  The attitude of the stylists was standoffish and I did not feel welcome.  Because I had natural hair I was not charged $18 I was charged $35 and the turn out was not even that great.  My hair had hardly any swing to it which was disappointing.  I will definitely not be going back.

I love my hairstylist Juana, but honestly the owner Dominga tries to change the price of my relaxer every time I go in for service.  She can get very aggressive and since there's no real price list, there's not much you can do to refute her rudeness and inconsistency.  I've been going here on and off for almost 10 years.  Juana is the only person I want to do my relaxers, so I haven't left there yet, but I wanted to go on record about the rudeness of the owner.  It's a shame, the stylists are nice, but she just ruins the whole experience!

Beware!

I've decided to review Hair Salons, because I'm constantly looking for salon reviews and have a hard time finding them!


Positive:
I occasionally go to this salon; my hair stylist is Toya who does an amazing job. 
I usually come here if I'm in a rush. What takes the typical Dominican hair salon to do in 3 hours, Toya does in 1. She's also great at cutting and styling. I've always had issues with stylist who cut too much; Toya understands what a trim is!

Negative:
What I do not like about the Salon is that the owner Dominga charges a different price every time I go.
I've had one too many arguments with her regarding pricing. 
I stopped going for a while because my wash & set went from 30 dollars to 45.
My local neighborhood hair salon charges me $25.00 and does just as great of a job.  

-I once bought my own hair treatment and she wanted to charge me $3 extra dollars for using the electricity from the hair dryer while the treatment set in.  (Tasteless) 

-I Also took my mother there to perm her hair.
My mother had her own products and Dominga still charged her the same price to perm!
 Most salons will at least charge a few dollars less for having your hair products on hand.

Please don't let them sell you on the Brazilian Keratin it is Horrible for your hair!
Keratin is worst than hair relaxer, stay away!!!! 

Like I said the women here do amazing work, if Dominga wasn't so money hungry I'd go there more often. 

*Please note this hair salon caters to Hispanic & African American hair. I'm not sure how much justice they will do to any other type of hair.

business.full_address:
111 S 40th St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Mizu

reviews.text:
Mizu is just OK.  The first time I ordered here the rice wasn't cooked right.  It was kind of crunchy.  I thought I probably wouldn't order from Mizu again.  But I am lazy.  And I love sushi.  And they deliver to my house.  So I ordered again.  

The second time the rice was cooked well, but the ingredients just didn't seem fresh.  The avacado that was topping my roll had lots of brown spots in it.  I realize that getting quality avacado in Philly is hard (believe me, it is one of the things I miss most about California).  But the avacado Mizu was using was really pretty bad.  And the texture of the rice still wasn't quite right.  

And if their avacado is bad and the rice is off, it makes me question the quality of their ingredients.  And sushi is not one of the things where you want to be questioning the quality/freshness of ingredients.  

I'm probably spoiled by living in San Francisco (where multiple, inexpensive, quality sushi restaurants delivered to my house).  I didn't really expect to find inexpensive, quality sushi that delivers to my house in Philly.  And Mizu is neither inexpensive nor quality.  

The truth is, I'm lazy.  And I love sushi.  So I will probably order from Mizu again.  Because the sushi wasn't horrible and it didn't make sick.  And they deliver to my house.

They have good spicy mayo! Our dinner for 4 with cocktails was super expensive, almost $200! I had their special that night, a couple phoenix rolls that were huge and hard to eat in one bite. Their drinks were very strong and the food took a long time and we were all served at different times. I liked their mochi ice cream a lot though. I would go back but I wasn't super impressed by the sushi, I've had way better for the price.
I love this little sushi place! I've been to the one in West Philly. Service is very friendly and the sushi is VERY affordable. Absolutely worth a visit if you're craving sushi.

So, we're about 26 hours post-Mizu and if I wasn't given glaring evidence to the contrary every 20 minutes or so, I'd have assumed that I had nothing left in my gastrointestinal tract about 10 hours ago. Yeah. It's like that. 
Instead of merely killing a piece of my soul, they've decided to rip my soul out through my intestines. And esophagus. It's unfortunate, to say the least. To say slightly more, I feel like a honey badger found it's way into my intestines and is trying to Lemmiwinks its way out. 
As we all know, the honey badger don't give a shit. I wish I had more in common with the honey badger right now.

Solid, reasonably priced, and I have never had suspicions that they are going to kill me with bad fish or unsanitary practices. Everyone needs a go-to, cheap sushi spot. If you are in UCity, Mizu is a good option.
Not crazy about the sushi here. I normally order hwe dup bap/chirashi to go since the seating inside is very limited. Prices are adjusted to being in University City.

Mizu was my go-to sushi place when I lived nearby.  The rolls were totally decent and the fish-to-rice ratio was always pretty high.  Free, usually speedy delivery with a $15 minimum, which honestly wasn't hard to get to because, while affordable, it's not exactly the cheapest cheap sushi place out there.

(vegetarian / vegan review)

Went here for lunch with a friend, and was glad that I did. The service was friendly, the seaweed salad (which I ordered based on the recommendation of a fellow Yelper) was quite good, and the veggie roll that I ordered was satisfying and tasty, although not sensational. In all, this was a good experience, and I'm sure I'll be coming back.

Mizu is my favorite place to go for a quick sushi lunch on Penn's campus. While it's not the best sushi you'll ever have, it's never very crowded around lunch time and they get the basics right--Philadelphia roll, etc. 

I like that it's not uncommon to h

Dear Mizu, 

Thank you for making brown rice vegetarian maki rolls. I love brown rice, and you make them fast and fairly fresh, and not all that expensive. And you've made me some nice and fairly priced catering trays. You're A-OK.

I was in the mood to be brave and try sushi again, as I have had very mixed experiences. Yamaki (a block away, with good reviews) was closed so I poked my head in here instead. Plus their $9 lunch special piqued my interest. Four 1/2 rolls plus miso soup. It's a cute (read: small), clean little place with friendly staff. I ordered:

California Roll- This was pretty standard, and my second favorite. The only problem- Whatever they used tasted like imitation crabmeat (I.e. Whitefish).

Yellowtail Roll- This was my favorite! I had decided on this due to another Yelper's review. Super fresh, not at all fishy, and a tad sweet. Mmmm, I could've eaten this all day!

Alaskan Roll- Not my favorite. The texture seemed off and it was a bit fishier than I feel salmon is supposed to be.  

Veggie combo roll: Meh. It was lackluster. I've made better veggie sushi at home.

The miso soup was satisfying and tasty. My two-year-old devoured it before I could get much!
Decent sushi, nice staff. Nice if you're eating in. If you're looking for takeout, go across the street to Fresh Grocer. I'm serious! They have an equally awesome sushi bar that's a bit cheaper.
This location does not accept VALID VOUCHERS!!

I decided to try this place for its hole in the wall like appearance. A friend and I went, she got seaweed salad (portions are not that huge for $4) and we both got edamame and I also got miso soup. Everything was delicious, and since we were the only people in the place, we got quality service.

I ordered the spicy salmon roll, and she had the ghost roll. both were delicious and filling.

I would recommend this place, although the smell of fish is quite strong once you walk in the door. it wore off, or we got used to it. 

the place is very small and there are not very many seats, i suggest the window bar.

I had a hankering for a cheap sushi lunch. Let's just say 'cheap' and 'sushi' should never be in the same sentence.  But listen, for $9 you get a choice of 4 types of sushi (none of the very fancy ones, but still many to choose from), which makes a total of 16 small pieces of sushi.  The spicy tuna was fine; maybe next time they can pull back on the siracha. However,  i was not a fan of the rolls that had cream cheese in them.  I usually like some cream cheese in specialty rolls, but I felt like I was ONLY eating cream cheese. Do you know how weird it is to have smear on nori?!   It overwhelmed the fish, rice, and veggies.  Rice was bland, fish didn't have the freshest taste.  Miso soup was really good, but could have benefitted from more tofu.  
I won't be craving Mizu sushi, unless I have another desire for cheap sushi *see above!

I enjoyed their veggie sushi options at pretty decent prices. Their spicy mayo is a little more spicy than I'm used to, and a little more pricey at .50 cents for each extra 2 tablespoon container you ask for but hey, that's sushi life. :p My friend inhaled her creative maki rolls (with fish) she absolutely loved them, and I must admit, they looked mighty tasty. Overall, a good sushi experience, I would go here again.
i have found mizu's sushi to be good, not excellent. however, the prices are excellent. also, considering the other option in west philly, nara, this is a winner.

ughh this place is just terrible. i can't believe they can call the food they serve here sushi. i've never had such horrible sushi in my life. the fish is not fresh at all and the rice is hard. i hear this place is supposed to be better than nara a couple blocks away. which makes me reallyyy scared to ever set foot inside nara for fear of death by food disappointment.

as for the other food here, the appetizers are the normal mediocre kind. nothing special about this place. the decorations are nice, but that's really the only thing this place has going for itself.

I give Mizu four stars based on the fact that it's sushi in Philadelphia. You have to be grateful for what you have. And for all those who would decry: "What about Buddakan and the like", my repost would be: "why needst I spend house and home for satisfying sushi?"
