'Sides, Buddakan ain't worth the money no matter how you shake it.

Mizu also offers the convenience of a ten-minute walk as well as the potential for delivery. But down to brass tacks.

Edamame was decent. Not too salty. Warm. About as flavorful as edamame can be.

The sushi. We had spicy tuna [which was really spicy], Spider Roll and a roll called, "American Dream". What they consisted of is less important than they were good. So for three good-sized rolls, two miso soups, to Aloe vera soft drinks and edamame bringing the bill to $50 even with tax and tip, I have to say it was worth. A bit more than worth it. And at a time when dining out in Philly continues to heavily disappoint, this was a pleasant surprise.

Dirt cheap and surprisingly good.

I normally get take-out from here since it's relatively close and open until 10. Everything is always good. Nothing spectacular, but $10 for a filling meal is nothing to complain about.

The only problem; they won't deliver to my house.

Had lunch here for sushi.  The fish in the display case looked beautiful, but the tuna and salmon rolls I had did not have a rich fish taste.  Bland.  Very good salmon skin roll.  And the miso soup is delicious.

I only had one dish for take-out (and a boring one at that), so admittedly, this might be a tad harsh - take it with a grain of salt unless you specifically plan on getting shrimp tempura rolls (regular - not the special one with avocado and eel). 

Although the rolls succeeded in quelling an insatiable craving for sushi that pervaded my thoughts while sitting through a painful 2-hour lecture on the physiology of the kidney, they didn't really do so in a positive way. Finishing the last piece was more of a "glad that's over with" as opposed to "pretty, pretty, pretty good." That said, they did have a decent crunch...but the whole thing was just so underwhelming and didn't seem fresh. As far as portion, there was a piece of shrimp in each about half the size of a peanut M&M. Realistically, they didn't seem any different than those scary prepared rolls that you see in the prepared foods section of a market or CVS.

Went to the one near the Mutter Museum.

Ordered:
-Seaweed salad, huge portion for only $3.95!
-Chicken tempura roll, great and stayed crunchy the whole time it took us to finish!
-Yellowtail roll, best yellowtail I've had in ages!
-Special eel roll with cream cheese (I forget the name), good, but I got sick of the cream cheese

Large selection of beverages. Not very pretty or spacious inside, but a great little lunch spot and very reasonably priced!

I love living in West Philadelphia, but my main gripe is that there's nowhere to get good sushi. You've got Nara, which is overpriced, mediocre and skanky; and Pod, which is overpriced, mediocre and pretentious. But Mizu? Is perfectly adequate.

If I want a really good sushi meal, I'll head over the river to one of many places I enjoy: Fuji Mountain, Yakitori Boy, Raw, Umai Umai, etc., etc. If I'm sitting at my West Philly home on a Wednesday night and I get in the mood, I'll order takeout or delivery from Mizo to satisfy my cravings. The sushi isn't spectacular, but it's decent -- and decent value for your money at $6-$7 rolls with 12 pieces a piece. I reiterate the takeout or delivery, as I would never eat in because college kids are awful. Seriously, once I stopped in and ordered without calling ahead and I think I legitimately lost IQ points overhearing the U Penn conversations. Better yet, just order delivery and avoid them all together.

Anyway, sushi does the job at a decent price. Thumbs up from me.

I can't believe I've lived a block away from Mizu for over a year and just discovered it!  It's moderately priced for sushi (two rolls, shrimp dumplings and seaweed salad came to $34) and the portion sizes are generous.  We had the American Dream (shrimp tempura, avocado & eel), which was huge and had the perfect amount of crunch and sauce.  There was avocado both inside and on top of the roll - Mizu definitely doesn't skimp on ingredients.   We also had the Rainbow Roll, which was good and as expected.  I really enjoyed the seaweed salad and thought the portion was really generous.  The shrimp dumplings were also yummy and came steamed, an extra plus.  

Though the restaurant is small, it wasn't the tiny hole in the wall I was expecting from reading the other yelp reviews.  It's an actual restaurant, with about 6 tables and window seating.  We went around 8:00 on a Saturday night and it was about half full when we got there.

I'll definitely be frequenting this place often!  Crossing my fingers for lunch specials. =)

For what it's worth, Mizu serves up great sushi at a price that won't leave a hole in your wallet.  This location is just a bit smaller than the one in Rittenhouse Square, but it's in an area with a lot more foot traffic and can get a bit crowded sometime
cheap, mediocre sushi.  good miso soup.

Ugh. This is not good. It's not really a real sushi restaurant - maybe it works as a takeout lunch place. I went for dinner and they don't even have beer or sake. Most importantly, this fish is not good. I am not the biggest sushi snob either - I like cheap sushi, I like expensive sushi, I like it all, as long as it's not BAD. I would happily live on a desert island with a fishing pole and sharp knife. I don't need fire. Cold raw fish, yum!

If this is the best sushi you have ever eaten, you really should try a little harder. I am really scared now to try Nara since this place is supposed to be so much better. Frightening!
The staff is nice, but all the fish tastes like imitation meat. I do not recommend at all.
Wow, lots a food for little price!!!  Tasty too!!!  Dragon roll was delicious and avocado and eel was fresh!!  Definitely coming here again!!

Mizu is a great balance of taste, price, and portions: a good amount of decent food for a reasonable price. They also now have what they call the "smart roll," where for $9 you can mix-and-match up to four different types of their non-specialty rolls, 16 pieces total. For an indecisive person like me, that's pretty convenient.
I go to Mizu if I am not really in the mood for sushi.
Fresh, fresh fish and fast service! I highly recommend the Volcano Roll and Firecracker Roll if you are craving something spicy.
Very good sushi. I like the fact that they offer brown rice. and you get a lot of sushi for your money.
GREAT Sushi!  Had a craving and they hit the spot perfectly.

I ordered the salmon lovers sushi... it was mediocre. I also had some vegetable gyoza, which was also mediocre. Although it's priced right, I'd rather pay a little more and get amazing sushi @ POD.. it's just very mediocre.. the place is tiny, you don't really feel cramped , but you sort of do..the fish was fresh.. enough... hmm next time I'm in the mood for a sushi fix in Ucity I'll skedaddle my way over to POD... yupp

The existence of udon on the menu is a disservice to humanity. I've tried udon from three different continents, including instant ones. The udon here is by far the worst I have ever had. If Mizu wants to keep the dish on the menu, the name of the dish should be changed to "seawater, soy sauce, and noodles" to accurately reflect its abysmal, half-assed quality. If you happen to be in a relationship and want to call it quits, come to Mizu and order udon for your significant other. The silver lining of this mediocre restaurant is the Smart Roll special, which consists of 16 mini sushi rolls that can be surprisingly fulfilling. However, this deal is only useful for broke college students looking for sustenance. If you want real food, please do your palates and stomach a favor and go elsewhere.
DO NOT ORDER FROM HERE!  I have never written a review about anything before.  Over a 2 hour wait, wrong order, terrible customer service... PICK ANOTHER SUSHI PLACE!

Really delish sushi! Mizu has a really yummy volcano roll and dragon roll. The miso soup is really nice as well. The only downside is the price is a bit high. But I would definitely keep paying $14 for that volcano roll!
yeah, im a fan.. great sushi...some of the best around. decent prices and not a long wait. its a small place and the ambiance is non existant... but just get it to go or something.

Ate here a TON when I lived nearby. It's nothing fantastic, but the prices aren't too too high and the sushi is perfectly fine - a step above the pre-made stuff at Fresh Grocer across the street but nowhere near as good as the best places downtown.

If you're looking for affordable sushi in University City it's a good option, and you can BYO which is always a plus.
Wow. Before coming here, I've never had good sushi. At Mizu, the seaweed salad is actually green and not a murky brownish green! The sushi is prepared when you order it. I still cant get over it.

Just okay. The shrimp tumpura roll and soft shell crab were clearly fried the day before, sealed up in some tupperware and dropped back into some old grease before serving. That was disappointing. They really try to bulk each roll up with cucumber so they can avoid actually giving you fish.

meh :-/

I've only had vegetable rolls from Mizu, so can't really comment on the fish (which may make this review not so helpful to many), but if you like veggie rolls this place is great.  What's really nice is that 1 order of a roll contains 12 pieces, so you really are getting two rolls for the price of one.  The edamame, seaweed salad, and green salad (with or without avocado) are all great as well.

Come hither from the cracks on the pages of your books, poor and hungry students. Forget the rich LV-covered girls whose daddies pay for Butcher & Singer birthday parties. Your sushi doesn't come more affordable than at Mizu. 

My friend once had a holiday party with some catered Mizu. We drank and ate and didn't break our wallets, hooray!

Mizu offers everything I could ask from a take-out Sushi restaurant.  The food tastes great, presents well, and is reasonably price.  It is also insanely fast! I live 6 minutes away and my order is ALWAYS ready when I arrive.  I am accustomed to getting 6-8 pieces in a roll and Mizu always gives 12.  EXCELLENT!

I had low expectations going into this place because of the lackluster reviews I see here on yelp and now that I experienced this 3 star restaurant first hand, It is still three stars. 

Knowing it is going to be somewhat expensive I decided to look up the menu on the window. Spicy Tuna roll for 7 bucks? Damn! thats pretty expensive, I can get that for like 5 bucks back home. Then I saw in the small print, 12 pieces, thats like one and a half rolls! So I went in, ordered my food and it came out. I don't know if it was because I was hungry but that roll is probably a normal sized roll stretched into 1.5 rolls. 

The rolls here are just not that great, not terrible, but just A-ok. For the price the rolls are kinda subpar, If you are craving some rice and seaweed then go for it.

business.full_address:
Beltway Plaza Mall
6200 Greenbelt Rd
Greenbelt, MD 20770
business.name: Jo-Ann Fabric and Craft Store

reviews.text: This is pretty much the only fabric store nearby, so it's my go to location. Pre-renovation they only had one working register, which lead to extremely long check out lines. I've had problems with being over charged for fabric here as well, and they didn't really have any idea how to fix it. Renovations are about half way done at this point, and I really do like the new layout. The old store was pretty badly designed, and this one now flows like most other Jo-Anns I've shopped at in the past. Overall, I still prefer the Columbia location. The staff is much nicer and so is the store.

Unfortunately, this is the closest fabric and craft store to where I live... and I need fabric and other supplies on a fairly regular basis.  This may be one of the worst Jo-Ann Fabrics I have ever had to shop at.  (And I used to work at one that was pretty  bad, so I should know.)  It's a small store, so their stock is limited.  
Also, some of their employees are extremely rude, and keep messing up my ticket at the cutting counter.  
I agree, the location is sketchy as well... but what can you do?  Jo-Ann's needs some local competition.
Does anyone ever SMILE here! Hell, do they even talk to the customer? Lordie!

Like Jenni K. and Jen F. mentioned, the location of this place is terrible.  It took a while to find a parking space because it was so crowded with all the other businesses, and it's inside of a really sketchtacular mall.  When I went, the selection of cross stitch supplies was mediocre at best - they were all out of plain black embroidery floss, and the rest of the flosses were completely mixed up and not in the right bins (so for all I know they had a ton of black floss in the bottom of the wrong bins).  The store had the general look of slight disarray throughout, but I headed right for what I needed and then left without doing much browsing.

Since I live in the city, there isn't anything in the way of jack of all trades craft stores like Jo-Ann that carry my cross-stitch supplies, so I might be back here out of necessity - if you have the means though, I would highly recommend their Falls Church location over this one!  Their store seemed to be neater, and they had ample stock of everything I needed.

I just got back home from this place. It was terrible as soon as I put my hands on a shopping cart. The cart twisted and turned; it wouldn't go where I pushed it. Apparently something technical was damaged with the wheels or something. It was very annoyin

The place is decently sized and has a good breadth of different products.

The yarn selection was so-so.  More variety would've been nice.  There was a sale going on on a ton of stuff which is nice- who doesnt love a good deal?

The place is in a kinda sketch mall so don't be surprised if random people start talking or hollering things at you.  Just a warning.

business.full_address:
2888 Broadway
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Pertutti Cafe

reviews.text:
Here's an example of a restaurant that, if it weren't in such a busy area, wouldn't be there anymore. The service was fine, but the food was sad, sad, sad. The pesto on my wife's pasta was all but tasteless, my son's pasta was undercooked, and my linguine was partially stuck together. 

On the other hand, the interior was unfriendly and drafty. They should rename it Perniente.

Avoid it.

This place is not terrible (i.e., I didn't get sick or send my food back), but certainly very forgettable.  In my opinion, just another Italian-themed placeholder on Broadway that caters to the more undiscerning amongst the Columbia crowd/locals, tourist types and sidewalk seating hounds.  Did I ever eat here?  Yes.  Does anything about the experience stand out in my mind?  Yes.  Nothing.

When I used to know the night manager, this was a great place for me to hang out.  It was all about the free drinks, discounted food, and the waitresses hating on me.  

Since my night manager no longer works here, the gauze has been lifted and the food is just obviously mediocre, especially in comparison with some of the amazing Italian food a couple blocks uptown.

Overpriced and not so delicious italian food makes this a no-go in the Columbia area.  With better options all around (Carmines, V&T, Sezz Medi, Max Soha, even FAMIGLIA), this place really shouldn't be having any business.

If you must go, get brunch there or dessert.  Neither is phenomenal, but neither is offensively bad also.

i am so thrilled to see i'm not the only reviewer who hates this place

decor: tacky italian. in the back room, they have cupid and angels tackily painted on the ceiling. 

staff: idiots. i mean seriously incompetent. 

food: if you know what decent, good italian food should taste like, stay away from this hell hole. it's edible, but not good. 

overall: if you haven't gotten my gist, i hate this place.

I've been here several times beause it's close. The food is usually decent and the prices are reasonable, but the service is ATROCIOUS. The wait staff is exceedingly slow and never gets the order right if you make any modification at all. 
On the plus side, brunch on a sunny day can be very nice. You can sit on the sidewalk and you can get a complimentary mimosa!

Tonight, the waitress told me the olive oil and vinegar that I asked for, for my bread, was also for my salad, because they were out. She tried to "scrounge some up" for me and brought me the container used in the kitchen with a small amount of dressing. Constantly trying to get someone's attention. The sauce on my Chicken Caccitore, not fresh. I asked for Puttanesca sauce,after I wasn't satified because I saw that on the menu, initially. Fresh but charged two dollars for it. I also saw a bus boy scrape a table clean into a bread basket. Dirty times ten. Gross and I had bread!!!!

Some negative reviews here, but I always liked the place.

Nevertheless, as of mid Feb 2008, Pertutti's is closed.

Word on the street is that the place has been sold. Whether that means the new owners will renovate a little and re-open using the Pertutt name, or if it will turn into something else with a new name and a new genre of food, no word yet.

Food has been decent but recently has gone WAY down. Friend of mine recently related a typical Pertutti experience:

Tortellini with Brodo soup was like dishwater with uncooked tortellini. Peas in the pasta sauce were still frozen. Bread was decent.

Of course the service is NOTORIOUSLY BAD. I have experienced and witnessed the following scenario multiple times:
"would you like dessert?"
"sure, I'll have the tartuffo"
(five min. later)
"I am sorry we are out of tartuffo"
"okay I'll have spumoni"
(five min. later)
"I'm sorry we're out of spumoni"
Lather....rinse....repeat.....
You are better off hauling your ass to the dessert carousel in the back and checking it out for yourself.

My friend also had to ask THREE times for the bill. Then of course another ten minutes goes by as he waits for change (the restaurant is deserted at this point). Waitress is sitting near the bar, chatting and refilling creamers. Friend gives up and asks for change at the bar. Waitress cuts him a look. Friend's mild manners are spent at this point:

"Don't you cut me a look. I waited longer to pay for my meal that I did to eat it. I'm never coming back." He threw a wad of three dollars at her and left.

UPDATE: Pertutti has closed, and supposedly the owner, a blows-with-the-wind kind of guy, has decided to go into tattoo laser removal. Apparently while the restaurant started out strong, management and cooking staff were beset with various personal crises and the place completely fell apart by the end. Opening soon in its place under new ownership is "Campos", which also seems to midpriced, Italian-themed.

oh pertutti how i wanted to love you! you are close to the train, have a lovely patio, and serve my very most favorite cuisine. alas, your despicable service, stale bread basket, and over-seasoned, gloppy linguine alla vongole makes me weep. back to carmine's and the eat-it-for-a-week portions.

business.full_address:
304 W 117th St
Harlem
New York, NY 10026
business.name: Karrot

reviews.text:
The reviews are right about Carlos: he's awesome. 

Unfortunately, this doesn't make up for the sky-high prices that Karrot charges. I get it of course - it's an organic health food place in Manhattan, of course it has to cover its costs somehow. 

The produce section is also severely lacking. I went in for a bag of carrots and there was one expired bag sitting among the wilted group of questionable greens.

There is a very nice variety of packaged and canned goods and drinks, however. At a price. And the new beer section is packed full of microbrews and unique varieties from all over the country.

All-in-all: cute store, great staff, high prices.
I was just in Karrot and saw that they have ice cream with toppings. Frozen yoghurt is on order. Much needed item in the neighborhood this summer.

I'm only giving four stars because of the vibe in there, it's a small local business, with really friendly, happy people inside, just hanging out.  I get a VERY enthusiastic HELLO! from the patriarch Carlos, which took me aback.  Walking around the store, it's really tiny with very little selection & they really looked like they NEED to hire a stock person/ buyer.  I am OCD, so I was walking thru straightening items on the shelf, which were in major disarray.  And the lemons In the "produce" department were way past fresh...it was sad.  But the fact is, we have to support local small business.
If you want to walk into a store, that sells health and organic food, and be greeted with "Hey, Whasssup" and sky high prices for vegetables, milk, baby food, vitamins, etc, Go to Karrot

Great place!
You can find all organic and natural-made products for personal hygiene and cleaning the house!
In addition, Carlos makes great smoothies and ice creams! 
Support this small but valuable local store!

I live a couple blocks away, and my friend mentioned this place a few days ago so we went it. I can't believe I had never gone in before! I guess it's because I just recently have wanted to go more organic. Anyway, as soon as I walked in and saw all the hair & skin products I was in love! I also met Carlos and he is as cool as all the other reviewers have said. Will be going back soon (maybe even today) to buy some items! :)
Carlo's is a great addition to the hood.  He make's a point of calling is customer's by name.  Everytime I request an item it's there within a week.  And the smoothies aren't bad either.

Apparently this is the only place north of 57th street that sells specialty beer, well, a particular specialty beer that I was on the hunt for.  And yes, this is still a health food store.

Carlos, the owner?, was quite nice enough to hold the beer for me

So, I read  every review about Karrot before I wrote mine, and found that every one had one similar truth: Carlos. What a nice guy! I came in here because I am semi new to Harlem, and wanted to check out my local places. He made me feel so great! That is the key to a successful business! I really feel like it is worth the above average prices just to shop there knowing that 1) this place will remain open 2) I am supporting a business with a fantastic owner. You got me Carlos, you and your store are fantastic. This is the ONLY place in Harlem that sells Sam Smith, and Carols and I spent 10 mins shooting the shit about some of the best beers in the world. There isn't much in terms of produce, but that's cool, because it would be a waste for this store to buy it, when there is already so many options nearby. What Karrot is about is fantastic service and quality product, both of which they do extremely well. The only reason they don't get 5 stars is because I'm broke and can't afford some of the stuff there, which is kinda on me, and not on Karrot....

I love this place. Carlos, the owner is a tremendous guy. It's great to have a good local store so that I don't have to make the trek through the park to get some nice food. Awesome that they now have great microbrews as well!

I feel so lucky to have Karrot two blocks from my apartment.  Carlos the owner is incredibly nice, knows his stuff, and will order things for you if he doesn't have them in stock.  In addition to the great food, fresh smoothies, supplements, and personal items to be found at Karrot, there is also Ciao Bella gelato and Green & Black candy bars (try the caramel)! 

Not much produce yet, but as the hood grows, I'm sure that will change.

Ha, funny that every review has been about Carlos. But, ultimately, that is why we all shop there. He is awesome. Of course he doesn't have a whole lot at his store---he doesn't have enough costumers that he'd be able to sell it all before it went bad (thus the produce section seriously lacking). 

Despite the fact that Carlos doesn't have everything we need, we (my apartment mates and I) will continue to shop there because 1. he is awesome, 2. we like supporting local shops, 3. he's got some seriously great products (like his hazelnut coffee...yum), 4. every time after being in Karrot I leave with a huge smile on my face (and yea, that has to do a lot with Carlos, but come on, he's totally awesome).
Carlos is a great guy, really takes to his role as neighborhood welcoming committee. And he now has great beer. Long-overdue in the 'hood. A bit pricey, but the guys trying to make a living...

I loved the location in Brooklyn so I was excited to discover they had one in Harlem. In all of they years they were open I only went there a couple of times. Both times, I was not acknowledged and given the cold shoulder when I asked questions. Their selection was not up the best and I actually prefer Best Yet and Wild Olive's selection and prices. On top of it, I often forgot they were even there because they were located around the corner. Bottom line is that they quietly went out of business and there is a for rent sign in the window. Someone said the landlord wanted $8K a month.
They had a horrible selection and they just went out of business.

business.full_address:
N 33rd and Arch St
Powelton Village
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: KAMI philadelphia

reviews.text:
This place is awesome! I had the bulgogi kimchee cheesesteak and it was delicious! It was so good that I decided to try another dish, so I got the spicy chicken over rice, which was also excellent. 

The service was also great! Fairly quick service. Great people working there! 

I am definitely going to go back ASAP!

This lunch truck is on 33rd & Arch St, Across from the soccer field on Drexel campus. I had the bulgogi kimchi cheesesteak. And it was very tasty! You can put provolone or cream cheese on the cheesesteak, but I chose both. Also had the udon soup, and it definitely warmed me up on this chilly day.

I often wonder about the design choices of certain buildings, restaurants, and food carts. Kami is a new food cart on the Drexel campus that's bright red in color with a caricature of a duck wearing a chef's hat and holding a cooking spoon. Kami translates to "god" in Japanese. What did Kami's owners mean by that? Enter the bugogi kimchi cheesesteak with your choice of provolone or cream cheese. At the suggestion of a fellow food reviewer, I got both. I opened the foil wrapper. It smelled really good.  I sunk my pearly whites into the most tantalizingly juicy sandwich I've had in a long time. The hoagie roll was pillowy soft like the buns used at The Spot. The marinated meat was perhaps the most tender meat I've ever, ever, ever had from a food cart or sit-down establishment. The mushrooms and onions enhanced the beef's flavor. Only a sparse amount of kimchi was used, but it was just enough to give the steak a little kick. I didn't taste the provolone, but I did taste the cream cheese and it really gave my cheesesteak an interesting texture component as well as curbing the spice of the kimchi. What a great combination. This is hands-down the best cheesesteak I've ever eaten. Now I know what Kami refers to. This is God's sandwich... for just $7.50. The free salad was a nice touch. Kami offers only three menu items - chicken bulgogi, bibimbob, and bulgogi kimchi cheesesteak - ensuring specializaton and high-quality preparation and ingredients. I wish it wasn't Friday because I'd love to go back there again for lunch tomorrow. In my earlier review of The Spot, I mistakenly believed that Kami's owners were somehow related to them. They're not. "They helped get us started," the young woman manning the grill at Kami said. The cordial, older woman taking food orders reminded me of the same setup as The Spot. Having a separate money handler and allowing the cook do what he or she does best is a winning formula. Both Kami and The Spot are setting new cleanliness standards for food carts. For this reason, you can't call them food carts anymore. The more proper term should be mobile kitchens. Kami is a frickin' awesome mobile kitchen.

business.full_address:
2301 Walnut St
Rittenhouse Square
Philadelphia, PA 19103
business.name: Rite Aid

reviews.text:
Man, this rite-aid is just the worst. The staff is slow and bored (a couple people at the pharmacy are nice! they're still slow though). The shelves are often unstocked. The whole place just feels like no one really cares.

 It's a rite-aid, it has the things you need, so it's not the worst place EVER. But as far as Rite-Aids go, it's the just the worst.
Friendly knowledgeable pharmacy staff.  Definitely recommend this pharmacy over many others in the city.,

This Rite Aid has had such a wonderful effect on my quality of life.  Their pharmacy staff is smart and competent and personable. 

Also, they have one of every small electronic appliance you may need in a pinch (or not a pinch.) 

They also have the Sunday NYT usually in stock.  And they are open 24X7 which makes the neighborhood much more well lit and safe.

This is one of the funniest pharmacies I've been to-- but it seems to be in line with many urban Rite Aid stores in quality. I'm giving it two stars because it's open 24 hours (!) and seems to keep a consistent stock on hand, but no more than that because it's bizarrely difficult to navigate! It's hilarious, actually-- I've been coming here for months and I still feel like I'm circumnavigating the entire place before I find what I'm looking for. Yes, granted the staff could be friendlier, but hey, you still find what you need.

Well, it's a Rite Aid. It's pretty standard, and I haven't had any problems with staff members to date. I find the pharmacists and pharmacy technicians to be helpful, if not overly-friendly. 

Three big pluses for this Rite Aid: 

1. Free and ample parking. 
2. Open 24 hours.
3. It's not a CVS.

If only I could give zero stars...

Originally I was going to come and say, "Well, at least you have two options as far as people who work here.  Surly and effective or sweet and incompetent."  Now - after waiting literally a half an hour for a prescription that sat, filled, on the counter in front of the "pharmacist," while he filled other prescriptions, contemplated his navel, wrote the next great American novel, who knows what... - I have to say both are totally useless, so good luck if you get one of the surly ones. 

This place is like a block from my house and I'm totally having my prescription transferred to a CVS that's farther away just because I had such a crappy experience.  Fuck you, Rite Aid.  Fuck you.
The people who work her are abysmally unfriendly. The Rite-Aid is stocked well and will sort you out in a pinch. Plus they're open 24 hrs and has a huge parking lot.

Ok - I'll give it 1 star - maybe 1 and a half.
The staff (what staff?  One disgruntled lady at the front counter?) are inattentive, underpaid and look bored.

The prices are city prices - so I bought my much-needed box of Kleenex and got outta there.  Gla

Parking sucks and they don't sell wooden popsicle sticks/tongue depressors--those are the negatives. The place is clean and the pharmacy has always been smart and fast to fill my prescriptions. Some people get aggravated but they haven't used CVS on 19th and Chestnut, I'm guessing. It's convenient for me to go here. Not too many made for TV things or good nail polish to distract me while waiting for prescriptions is a plus.

business.full_address:
949 Columbus Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Voza

reviews.text:
one word to describe Voza: Spicy! The Chicken diablo did not fail to live up to it's name. The chicken was moist and well cooked with a lot of flavor, but be sure to have a glass full of water next to you. The Red Snapper special was quite tasty as well - yet had a surprising "kick". Not sure why it was so spicy. 

The portions are good, but skimpy to American standards. Although the inside and outside spaces are EXTREMELY small, it does not feel claustrophobic. A touch-up to the grates in front of the door could use a little face-lift, and you definitely need  to reserve 2 hours for dinner. These are the reasons they have lost 1 star for me.

Very small selection of really well made food.  Best value for money is the pasta.  Shawn, the chef, is an incredible wealth of foody information, and makes a mean banana's foster at the table.  He is very friendly and made my whole family wish that we could just be his friend.

His partner always seems to be in some other world, and always forgets orders, or requests for more water.  But Shawn, when he is there, makes up for his partners lack of gumption with his perfect pasta dishes, fresh bread, and delicious desserts. 

There are only about 6-7 tables at the restaurant.  The corner booth in the window is the best spot, so if you make reservations, I recommend requesting it if you have 4 people.

First: NO LONGER BYOB (which i learned after packing a purseful of pino)!!!

Second: The food is delicious and in an unexpected atmosphere.  Chef Shaun is a lovely host and joyfully overseas the preparation of delicious creations, but the place is teeny tiny with no real chairs- stools and a few benches that line the walls.  It is even smaller than my NYC bedroom! But the food make up for the space. And once you go you can say that you have truly had a NY experience. With some small tweaking and more word of mouth there will be lines around the block. 

Third: Go. What are you waiting for.

My friend and I were strongly urged to eat here by an older couple who were sitting at one of the tables out front.  "we LOVE it! You HAVE to try it!"   OK!  who wants to disappoint old people?  Not me.
  
1 star for coziness!  
1 star for BYOB.  
1 star for the tasty food.  First of all, thanks for serving warm bread with butter. I am over this olive oil nonsense.  the bean soup amuse bouche was a nice touch.  The salmon with polenta and the stuffed shrimp were very satisfying.
1 star for easing my resentment about having to spend so much time uptown, learning & shit. 

the only problem is that the service was wicked slow (1 waitress, 1 guy cooking) so don't go if you're in a rush.

Unbelievable. Might be the finest meal I've had in NY so far (first year here).  Tiny, local, and a lot of character. I don't really care about bread, but we were practically fighting over it. Had three appetizers, they brought us spinach and artichoke dip by mistake, it might have been the best one, not something I would normally order, I associate it with Chile's or something. The ceviche was awesome, and the potato gnocci, to die for. Chicken Penne Pasta Diabolo and the Pecan Crusted Salmon were awesome! Great place, but cash only.

Do you have Albanian friends with a TINY apartment, who invite you over for a great meal whenever they happen to have thrown something amazing together?

Now you do...

Voza is a tiny place run by an Albanian couple and an American chef/owner whose food is surprisingly good and amazingly varied for the size of the kitchen (it's so small, the dishes have to be washed next door.)
I had a three course ($40ea) meal which included a generous +APPETIZER mixed plate with 
*Crap cakes (very nice - ton of crab, but the heavy allspice dipping sauce was overwhelming) 
*Crostini (quaintly spelled "Crustiness" all over the menu) with pesto and sun dried tomato
*Hummus which was rough cut and nicely seasoned
+ENTREE
*Marinated Steak - thin, a little over done but tasty
*Sauteed Shrimp - slightly salty but good otherwise
*perfectly cooked/seasoned green beans
*stuffed potato - twice baked, slightly bland but with the shrimp perfect
+CHEESE BOARD
*Morbier, Aged Gouda and Danish Blue (with decent but uninspired pairings)

Very nice overall - with great attention to detail, great personalized care.  Definitely a slower meal, but just remember to bring TWO bottles of wine and enjoy it. Also this is NOT the place for an personal conversation as you will be likely to be sitting AT someone elses table....

Love this restaurant. My server was so nice and attentive, the food was amazing, and the wine list was great. I tried a bottle of syrah, Oriel's Courant, it was a perfect complement. I will definitely take my out of town guests to wine and dine here this weekend (I know variety is the spice of life, but this place is great)
I like to pretend that this is my second apartment where my private chef actually lives.
Now that Voza is closed I want to point out that the word Voza is a dirty dirty word in Swiss German.  I guess I won't be able to giggle every time I walk by anymore

So this may not be the best Italian/Southern European food I've ever had (see Porcini's in Philadelphia for that), but it was damn good. The owner/chef/waiter (unclear his actual position, since he seemed to do everything) brought us a split pea soup that we didn't even order because he "just made some," and it was probably the best thing we ate that night. I originally ordered ravioli stuffed with truffles and cheese; however, owner/chef/waiter man came back and informed me that he would not permit me to order that item because they didn't look very tasty to him. I swear, it happened just like that. So I got ravioli stuffed with mozzarella instead, smothered in artery-clogging goodness (cream sauce). My dad got a slightly spicy tomato-based dish that I thought was fantastic, although I didn't try the chicken, being a vegetarian and all. 

We finished up with a chocolate cake that was, quite simply, divine. We sort of waddled out once we were done. Totally charming, hospitable, and yummyyy. The guy sitting at the table next to us said he was a regular, and that he usually just let them bring out whatever they had - he doesn't bother ordering anymore, since owner/chef/waiter guy always picks the best stuff anyway. That's my plan if I ever return!

I'm just so sad, as I tried to go here tonight and it appears to have gone out of business with a FOR RENT sign in the window.

Such a shame he couldn't make it.  Last time I was there he was talking about expanding.

4 Stars for providing quality Italian in Manhattan Valley for quite some time.
I tried the shrimp stuffed w/ goat cheese, it was very good.

Wonderful wonderful cozy atmosphere. I was so surprised when my boyfriend took me here by the ridiculously quaint interior and ambience that I had a smile glued to me all night. BYOB and reasonable entrees keep it cheap. Portions a little slow.  But LOVED IT!

This place is super.  I went a couple of weeks ago during a weekend in NY, and it was tots impressive.

Like, this place is really small and cute, and their food was four stars.  I bump the total rating up to five because we had a super cute waitress who sat down and chatted with us about dessert even though she'd been working since 8am (we arrive at 10:30ish).  Seriously, she was so cute my entire table developed a crush on her, so that when she forgot to bring out one of our credit cards, we were convinced we had somehow made it disappear after she set it down, and we proceeded to overturn tables and search the ground for like 10 minutes before someone finally realized she had forgot it inside.  I know this might normally be something you'd complain about, but we really had a great time searching for the credit card.  Maybe it was the bottle of wine we consumed, or maybe we're just wonderful people and this was a wonderful place.

P.S. The kitchen is super small, so its amazing they can do what they do.

P.P.S.  If you think I'm just some stupid San Franciscan easily impressed by anyone who can cook something 1/2 decent, read some of my other reviews, I can be irrationally brutal too.

This place is tiny, so you'll probably not get a seat unless you reserve it ahead of time. It can get a little pricey if you're not careful, but the food is well worth it.

The food is spectacular! This place easily rivals those giant, exclusive restaurants!

I had the pork chop, which was the best I've ever tasted. I also had the scallops, crab cake, and veal. All of these plates were amazing, mouth-watering, and cooked to perfection. Okay, so I spent a little bit more than I thought I would.

The wine choice could be better, but other than that, I have nothing bad to say about this place. The staff was friendly and nice and the cook comes right up to your table to explain the specials of the day.

Tiny, rustic, and dark. As soon as I stepped in my mouth was watering because it smelled so good! Even though it's a very small space, it didn't feel too cramped. The background music was perfectly mellow, and not too loud. Delicious warm, crusty bread with a fat slab of butter and complimentary roasted red pepper & tomato soup amuse bouche kept us happy during the lengthy wait for our main courses. I had a special tortellini and my friend had the seafood stew. The food was piping hot, very fresh and flavorful. Generous portions too!

3.5,  I was in the worst mood ever after a long work day, and because I was in such a foul mood, the -surprise- of a band including a trombone, trumpet, and tap dancing guitar player entertaining outdoor diners did not make me happy.  However, after being

This restaurant was great.   Went here with a group and everyone loved their food!  I am very picky about giving a 5, so that's why it gets a 4.  The $24 pinot grigio is a great wine.  Also try the salmon and polenta!  The people at the next table said it was their neighborhood fave - I can see why!

I went to Voza for the first time last night despite having lived in the neighborhood for over 6 years and it made me wonder what took me so long to try the place out. I was debating between the baked red snapper with mango salsa and chicken pasta diabolo. With the recommendation from the chef and my liking for mango, I chose the red snapper. The fish really surprised me with its tender top and crispy bottom. It also came with asparagus and brown rice. The brown rice was alright, but the asparagus was very good. Oh, I loved their bread so much that after I finished my entree, I made sure none of the bread go back to the kitchen.

I really can't believe it has taken me this long to write about Voza.  The food is simply amazing.  Let me say that again so you get it:  The food is simply amazing.

Nothing on the menu is over $30 and I fear the Shawn the chef will get snapped up by some rich benefactor and relocated downtown where everything costs an arm and a leg.

Favorites:
The sautéed spinach with black truffle oil.  Oh. My. God.  
The pork chop is gratuitously huge and I'm sorry but I couldn't help myself, I gnawed on the bone trying the get the last morsels of goodness.

Honestly every single dish I've tried has been wonderful and full of flavor.  I recommend it to anyone in the area and to those willing to brave a trip to the Manhattan Valley

As a side note my brother a foodie from the San Francisco Bay Area has decided that Voza is his favorite restaurant.
Fun, straight forward, relaxed, friendly, GREAT FOOD! I loved the selection and the presentation. Live jazz outside and great cozy atmosphere inside. Wonderful service. Can't wait to go back!

Anyone who can make a perfectly cooked steak in a kitchen the size of an airplane bathroom is 5 stars in my book!

We loved this place from the minute we walked in. We made a reservation, having seen on these reviews that they had very limited seating. Limited was definitely the optimal word; there were 8-9 total tables for 2 in the whole place! We loved that it made the whole experience much more intimate. The restaurant has a very rustic feel: exposed brick and intimate lighting. 

The service was equally excellent. Three men controlled the entire place, simultaneously serving as the waiter/maitre d', cook/waiter, and busboy/spiderman (no joke! he scaled the walls in the back to a pantry hidden in the ceiling!) The waiter/maitre d' came over and described the specials to us, recommended wine pairings, and was generally very helpful and accomadating. He even sent over a free dessert after we paid the check since the dessert we had wanted had been sold out. 

The food was SOOO good. We had the special ravioli appetizer, which was cooked perfectly and had a great sauce. We then each tried one of the special entrees...I had the steak, and my girlfriend tried the chicken. Both were excellently prepared and seasoned. The only complaint we had were my girlfriend's green beans, which had been overly seasoned. That one grievance was easily forgotten in light of the rest of our evening!

The waiter/maitre d' even invited us to come to their expanding party in a few months when they break down the walls. As Shea said, whoever invites me to a party is a-ok in my book!!!

When you can't find me I'll be here with a glass of wine and a filet mignon. :)

I was super-excited to find a cute restaurant near my apartment with a great-looking menu.  While the food was good, I was freezing half the time and crying the other half.  

The inside of the restaurant is tiny, as other reviewers have mentioned, and seats only about 12 people.  It's like being in someone's apartment, as you can watch them making your food in the also tiny open kitchen.  The farmhouse decor is pretty awesome.  The downside of the small space is twofold:  1) on a freezing night, the effects of the door opening and closing are hardly remedied by the curtain in front of the door and 2) the smoke from the food was just killing my eyes.  Granted, I get cold easily and have sensitive eyes (just a minute of chopping an onion will make me tear up), but still.  I couldn't really enjoy the food because I was alternately shivering and weeping.

The food, on the other hand, is very good, as is the service.  The main chef is the waiter, as well, and he will sit down at your table to discuss the specials for the night (there were MANY last night - almost like a whole additional menu).  There is a very affordable wine list, especially by the glass ($6-$9).  The food took a while to come, probably because we were the first ones there for the night, but they did give us a free small dish of bean chili - yum.  No one else really came in until around 8 PM, so we had the place to ourselves for a while.  The pesto shrimp pasta appetizer was very good, as was the crabcake.  I had a special red snapper with beurre blanc sauce, which was excellent.  The cous cous that came on the side was tasty, but the green beans were covered in some kind of pepper that was too spicy for me.  The dessert was okay.  We got the cookie with ice cream on top, and the chef substituted chocolate sauce instead of white chocolate sauce on top because we asked (who likes white chocolate anyway?).  The cookie was not so great, but the ice cream was good, as was the Valhrona chocolate.  

I'd come back to Voza, but probably only when it gets warmer and they can keep the door open or I can sit outside.

Okay, first off, the staff are awesome and invited us to their expansion party when the construction is finished. Anyone who invites me to a party is okay in my book.

Second, they offered to let us taste the two types of wine we were debating over and gave us some bread and water to wash out the taste of the first one in preparation for tasting the second one. Someone who knows their wine tasting...excellent.

Any place where the same dude who cooks and serves the food sits down and explains the specials to you in a very laid-back manner is absolutely fabulous in my book. Add on the free dessert that was not on the menu that he sent our way after we'd paid the bill, and this a 5-star place. Hands down.

This place is *small*. There are less than 10 tables and the ambiance is very rustic and romantic. It looks like there's outdoor seating, and I now know that if I cannot find my girlfriend at home, she'll be around the corner at Voza. The food is DELICIOUS, and I loved the fact that I could watch them making our dinner while enjoying a bottle of wine. They serve you unlimited bread with a delicious sauce to dip it in to start out with, and both the filet mignon that my girlfriend had and the boneless chicken that I had were just amazing. They practically melted in your mouth.

Finally, the price = not bad at all. We had a bottle of wine, an appetizer, and two of the special entrees, and it came out to $100. Obviously not cheap, but definitely not bad considering the kind of service we received.

A gem in the beautiful Manhattan Valley area...i have only been there a few times, but the owner personally greets me upon each arrival. His wine/food recs are spot on as well. I've tried just about everything on the menu, and have only spectacular things to say. Cozy, dark, and intimate, it is an ideal date spot as well. You will not regret!

Voza is just perfect.

I used to live in the apt. building right above it, and I would have many wonderful meals here with roommates and friends. Here is a list of reasons that make it so wonderful.

1. They are THE NICEST RESTAURANT STAFF I have ever encountered. so accommodating and friendly.

2. It's tiny so there are never more than like 12 people in there so you really get an intimate dining experience.

3. The food is freakin delish, portions perfect, and prices are fair. The chef (who you can literally watch make your food due to the open kitchen space) is always smiling as he works to create your dish with care.

4. It used to be BYOB. Apparently from what I read below it's not anymore, but that's totally fine, I'm sure the liquor license will help balance out the tiny space. 

I miss my old apt. I miss this neighborhood, and I miss this wonderful little  restaurant and it's sweet owners/staff.

Anyone reading this, it is worth the C train ride up, so enjoy!

I came here this Saturday for a Bachelorette Party.  I must really really really LOVE this girl for me to take my lazy butt out of my comfort zone - I even came here without knowing anything about this restaurant.

My friend LOVE to eat here since she used to live around here and so she decided to throw our mutual friend's party here.  Since the soon to be bride was running a bit late, we decided to order appetizers first.
(An hour later-when the rest of the party showed up, our appetizers were still not served!)
The reason behind this is because they only have ONE CHEF and ONE waitress.

For Appetizers:
Voza's Jumbo Lump Crab Cake with Cajun tartar sauce
-EVERYONE SEEM TO HAVE LOVED IT EXCEPT ME, I HAD BETTER 
Fried Mozzarella Cheese with marinara sauce
-YOU CAN'T REALLY MESS THIS UP, YOU KNOWS?

They also gave us two free specially prepared appetizers!  One of them had eggplant and the other one had shrimp.

For Entree:

I can't remember what the other girls had but I know I tasted these three dishes below.

Stuffed Shrimp with goat cheese and basil pesto. with yellow rice and vegetable  
OKAY DISH-nothing to rave about

Shellfish Stew crabs, clams, mussels in a tomato base served with yellow rice  
WAY TOO FISHY for me-I had seafood stew before but it never tasted this fishy and the clams tasted a bit sandy too!

Ravioli of The Day (Spinach that day)
This one was my favorite of all three dishes that I tried!

Since my friend is a regular there, they gave us FREE BLACK BEAN SOUP!  I have to say when they first served it to me and told me it was BLACK BEAN-I wasn't too excited.  I am just not a fan of beans in general.
But I never knew how much I would love something that I detested for years.  I seriously would just come back here for this soup.  (It had a bit of a kick to it!)
Unfortunately, it's not a permanent dish on the menu!  (So so sad!)

Then for dessert, they also gave us free FONDUE with fresh sliced fruits!

I would come back here for the great service and the black bean soup alone.  But my friend still LOVE this place and the other girls rave about it too!
I don't know, perhaps I am just a really picky eater!


P.S It's BYOB.
The BYOB might entice a great percentage of readers (liquor store right next door with plexi glass), but what can I say I am not much of a drinker!

I went to Voza last Friday night with a group of 6. We asked to sit outside, and they moved three tiny tables from inside to balance halfway on the sidewalk and grates (that moved) in front of the building next door. It took about an hour to get our food, and after making a trip to the bathroom it was easy to see why. Our waiter was standing behind the very tiny bar cooking on food on a single burner. There is no kitchen. The stuffed shrimp with goat cheese and pesto was basically five warm cocktail shrimp with a pea sized dollop of goat cheese and squirt of pesto on top. And only after we tried to pay with credit cards did they tell us it was cash only. It would be a great quirky place if the food was good, but we weren't impressed and won't be back.

I had a great time here.. Its a super cozy place, probably the smallest place I have taken anyone to in a long time.  I hear they are expanding a little.  Even if they don't- its a good place for a date.

The owner was the one taking care of our table giving it a personal touch.  The food was very good and the wine affordable. 

 A band started playing outside- they were good- so good that cars stopped to listen..  Again it depends what you are looking for and if the place was not wall-to-wall people when I was there and even so- it was summer and outside seating was possible too....
Worst steak I have ever had. Ordered the skirt steak and it tasted like a microwaved tv dinner. Never again!!

3.5 stars.

Cute dark little place (and i mean little as in room capacity no more than a dozen or so!). Nice romantic ambiance with nice food presentation.

Complimenary bread but it was a pretty burnt on the bottom. Super slow service which was sad since we were first ones there :/ 

((Crab Cake)) w/ cajun tartar sauce $11 for just one, no bigger than a credit card ! we savored the delicious fresh flavor of every bite!

((Voza's O-La-La Pork Chop)) w/ roasted potatoes $25. Pork chop was really tasty albeit a bit dry. Potatoes were very flavorful

((Broiled Salmon with Creamy Italian Polenta)) $19 Polenta had a nice creamy texture, but salmon wasnt anything spectacular. ok. 


Tasty food for the most part, but overpriced for not being exceedingly delicious. I wouldnt mind returning, but wouldnt say Id go out of my way to find this lil place again.

Voza is incredible and I wish I could give it 8 stars.  Yes, it is Tiny (Sharn swears it fits 22 close friends) but really warm and inviting and all the staff are really amazing.  

I think they threw some bread in the oven when we walked in because it was piping hot when it got to our table a few minutes later.  We ordered some montepulciano by the glass and had so many Sharn charged us the bottle instead, which is the epitome of hospitable.  Our glasses were never empty! 

The food that comes out of that impossibly tiny kitchen is heavenly.  Our complimentary amuse bouche was a very good spicy black bean soup. I tried the special vegetarian entree of the evening (buttery carrots, string beans, cream of spinach, mushrooms and garlic mash) and each item was cooked perfectly.  So many vegetables has never been so satisfying! My friend's tortellini in a vodka sauce was amazing as well.  I could eat that sauce with a baguette all day, any day.

They are planning on expanding in May so they will have a back dining room and garden/patio and jazz on Saturdays once the weather warms up.  I certainly hope they also expand the kitchen since I'm sure there will be line out the door for this place!  What an oasis in a culinary wasteland. 

Also huge props for keeping such a nice and clean bathroom.  Dirty bathrooms are common in tiny restaurants, and though Voza's isn't covered in fancy tile with a single potted orchid, it is very very clean, which is what really counts.
Nice little romantic place. The chef is a real nice guy and let's you know the deal at your table. Food is great. Solid fine dining experience. Not too expensive either as far as NYC goes.

Food - Good
Sevice - Good
Atmosphere - Good

Went on a Tuesday night and we were the only ones there cuz of the cold,  so they were not very pumped I would guess.

Had pasta with Diabolo sauce, nice and spicy.
My date had the crab cake and spinach artichoke and they were good too.
I was not in awe for the food to make me go gaga, but I would go back to try one of the steaks, they looked good.
It is a very ,very tiny place but very nice too,

I really wanted to like this restaurant.  Cute, friendly staff, the chef sits down to talk with you about the menu....

But my steak special was not a fillet mignon.  There is absolutely no way the steak they served me, which was supposed to be a fillet, was a fillet.  It was so tough I struggled to cut it with my steak knife.  I didn't pay $37 for a 5.99 supermarket steak.  I know my meats (the butcher at Citarella and I know each other), I grill a lot, and that was not a quality steak.

Also, most seats look comfortable despite the small space, but the small metal stools are not.  Try to avoid sitting on one, by the end of dinner you will regret it.

Aside from those two problems, everything else was good.  But while I think great food can make up for bad service, good service can not make up for unacceptable food.

Fellow wannabe food critics -- I am back. I felt compelled to return after a brief hiatus to continue being awesome.

Here goes...

Hole in the wall, seriously don't know how the owner saw potential in this block and neighborhood but seems to attract via word of mouth.

The decor is subdued, romantic, dim lighting, cozy, rustic. The space itself is tiny. My bedroom that fits a twin bed and a small closet is bigger. It's open kitchen, meaning it's not behind the scenes. It's about the size of a closet and truly a prime example of making the most out of nothing.

We arrived at around 6:30 pm on a thursday night (tonight) -- it was empty. By empty I mean the other 5 tables were not occupied so a table for two is enough to make the place feel packed (see my tiny restaurant note above)

The overall experience was both good and bad. Let me explain..

= GOOD =
- Good food
- Nice waitress
- Cute baby
- Free lentil soup

= BAD = 
- It was only 6:30 pm, how could you be out of a mixed greens salad and two soups on a cold night?
- The free lentil soup was given because the place was cold. Was pretty good, smoky flavor, too much black pepper.
- The snapper filet was tiny, like the restaurant. They should state if it's a whole fish or the size of my palm. Snapper was over peppered. They are pepper happy here.
- The red wine was extremely chilled (because the place was cold)
- The waitress, whom I presume was the owner's wife, did not turn on the heat because she didn't know how. It was until we left that she put two and two together and said "Let me ask one of the workers"
- We were not offered dessert
- We were given the check without requesting it
- Portions were small. We got 7 asparagus each (not even full size)
- Some items were overpriced. $14 for two ravioli's? I understand it's a special, but does it make it more special when it's a limited serving? With the high price and small portion, you'd expect this in a high end restaurant -- not a hole in the wall mom & pop shop.
- Waitress' crying baby. He's cute but distracted too much from our intense love making conversation. If I don't get any tonight, it won't be of surprise.
- Cash only. Cash only restaurants should make a large notice on the menu or be told prior to seating so we can have the opportunity to go to the atm BEFORE eating. If it's cash only, should be BYOB.

I understand there are off nights. Tonight was an off night. Probably the owner left his wife to run the place and babysit at the same time. Good food (most important factor for me), but wasn't enough of a great experience to think about coming back.

This tiny new neighborhood restaurant features a cozy atmosphere with heavy doses of wood and exposed brick, and a small decorative loft. Nearly everything about the place is perfect - wonderful service, extremely reasonable prices - except the food itself, which tends to be a bit on the bland side. I'm hoping that the cuisine gets better with time; until then, I still consider it worth stopping by now and then for the full experience of dining here.

After my second visit I decided Voza is a rare treat.  With seating for roughly 15-20 people, and the chef himself visiting your table, you feel like you're in the kitchen of a close friend.  They score extra points for their BYOB policy.

The cuisine is mostly comfort food--chicken, pork, seafood, et al--but is delicious and full of flavor.  Fresh bread and an unexpected sampling of a soup de jour kick off the meal.  I recommend the pecan-crusted salmon and the roasted pork (a special).  The bananas foster dessert is also terrific--and prepared at the table by the chef.

I feel compelled to make people aware of this place after having eaten dinner there earlier today.

The service is very personal - the chef himself comes up and tells you the specials of the day, and because it's so small, your water glass gets refilled nearly instantaneously.

Now, because of its size, be warned: the wait time is a tad long, but let me assure you, it's worth it. Especially because the prices are so reasonable compared to restaurants of comparable quality.

Highly recommended: the free bread. I think they made it fresh every ten minutes. It was awesome. I told them to not bring us any more bread until the entrees showed up because we would emphatically devour the bread right as it'd be set down.

I had a special appetizer - foie gras pate, which was so good that I was speechless for thirty seconds after trying it.

And the rack of lamb (I had it medium-rare) was very good. I had it with the garlic mashed potatoes and corn and couldn't be happier.

I bet that the reason the wait time to get the food is so long is they wait for you to order it before even starting make it, unlike lots of places where it's just sitting in a pot ready to be thrown on a plate. i think freshly cooked food is worth it, you know?

I think I'll leave it at this: when it came time to give in the plates, all but one were nearly clean already from the concerted effort my table-mates and I put into finishing every last morsel. I'm starting to think you can't go wrong in this place.

And the cozy atmosphere was so memorable. I can speak no ill of this place.

no bigger than this
review, though charm and flavor
are abundant. call ahead.

Was kinda turned off by how tiny the place is at first, they only have like 4 tables in there, however I had an excellent dinner and overall experience.  The food was really tasty and I'll probably go back to try out some of the stuff on the menu I couldn't decide between. The host/owner was very friendly and helpful.  Its a BYOB  and cash only just FYI- didn't realize this until we got there.

Voza continues to impress.  After reading reviews we decided to give Voza a try.  The service was amazing and very personal.  The seating was comfortable and the ambiance cozy.  (They even have outdoor tables with heaters for the brave who want to dine alfresco in the colder months.)  The menu was inventive and well executed.  Will definitely go back again.

Wanted to like this place, especially after reading all the glowing reviews. A VERY small space, cramped and dark, had the cozy rustic ambiance thing going (they provide flashlight if you can't read the menu). Sitting on the conga drums DOES get old after a while.

Very charming, friendly service, especially considering the three guys waiting/busing are also cooking. After a good long wait, pregnant with anticipation... we were very disappointed.

The only thing French about the cuisine was the tiny portion size. I thought one of the principles of French cuisine was to enhance the flavor of what you're eating, not disguise it. My puny snapper filet and my friend's half dozen scallops were all salted and seasoned to DEATH. Accompaniments included a dozen green beans each (again, coated in red pepper flakes), accompanied by rice and couscous that we are convinced came out of a 'Far East' brand box (my friend swore he had made that particular mix before). The microwave whirring the entire evening was ultimately the big giveaway. It all felt like a really nice meal a friend might cook for you. But at this quality, two main courses for $44 is not really acceptable. This place may appeal to sodium addicts, but I'll pass...

Voza is one of my favorite restaurants in NYC.  True, it's tiny, and you might end up on a small stool with no back, but even with that it's worth it.  The food is amazing!  The chef is friendly and always stops by to say hello.  Get the bananas flambe for dessert, you won't be disappointed!

You'll find this little gem tucked away between storefronts and bodegas. As we entered we were floored that there were only 5 tables inside, and 4 outside. The ambience inside was charming and the host (possibly owner?) greeted us with a huge smile. The open kitchen is maned by one busy chef who dishes out all the cuisine. Let me start by urging you to go with the specials. We ate:
App: 
Baked tomato stuffed with feta and bruschetta toast points (special)
Ceviche
Highly rec the tomato
Entree:
Baked snapper (Yummy and healthy)
Pork Chop (delish)
Dessert:
Chocolate Cake (ehh)
Cookies (double ehh) skip it

All in all we skated out of there around the 100 dollar mark and thats including a few drinks. Very nice restaurant for the local. Give it a try!

Yes this place is small as has been stated by others. But you'd never know from the size of their menu and the amazing execution that the kitchen is tinier than a shoe box. Chef Owner Shaun is as vibrant and welcoming as his menu. I had the chicken breast with sun dried tomatoes. Truly delicious! We ordered wine and enjoyed the cozy atmosphere. I'll definitely be back though I am deducting one star for the somewhat steep prices (for the neighborhood) and a slight lack of ventilation

Turn around. Close your eyes. I'm about to show you a great surprise,...

*blindfolds.* Spin around ten times. Bigger circles. Non of that wussy stuff. Alright. That's better. Now I'll lead you somewhere special. But shhhhhh! It's a secret.

Tiny. Small. Cozy. Max capacity at 20 people. This little Mom and Pop restaurant is warm and friendly. We came here for a birthday dinner and everyone in our party of 8 (it was a squeeze for such a small restaurant) was thoroughly impressed. 

Firstly, the service was AMAZING. They were extremely accommodating to our party. It was a rainy day and, since they didn't have a coat rack, or space for one, they stored away our umbrellas, bags, and coats upstairs, allowing us to enjoy the serenity of the meal. When one of the vegetarians asked about the polenta, they brought her a little side of it. Btw, the polenta is fantastic. Cheesy, great texture, good balance.

Great fish dishes. Great vegetarian options. Imaginative and tasty. Fantastic food. Great wine selection - try the pinot. 

Don't forget, cash only.

Let me please tell you about one of the best nights NYC has ever shown this suburban girl.

Bump into my Big Crush from college. Ask him out on a date. Consult Yelp. End up at Voza. The ambiance is as cozy and intimate as my living room bedecked with candles. We relax, drink red wine, and become disproportionately excited when we are served free mini-bowls of split pea soup with bacon (amazing). The owner/head chef takes a seat at our table; we offer him some wine (he declines). We decide on broiled salmon with creamy polenta and the chicken parmigiana.  

I'm not sure I have ever enjoyed waiting for dinner as much as I did at Voza - let alone eating it. The kitchen is part of the dining area, so you feel as if your food is being created especially for you by someone you know. Not en masse, and not in a busy, messy, hidden back room. Delicious smells wafted through the restaurant and I wanted to know what everyone was eating. Thing is, I was so enthralled by the company, and the absolute masterpiece of my own dish, that I totally forgot about everyone else.

There is definitely something to be said for having a long, relaxing dinner - the wine, the waiting, relishing the conversation of your company!! The art of dining has returned. And so has my Big Crush.

Imagine if you could pick your first love after falling in love a few times instead of before. Well that's what writing my first Yelp review is like. I wanted my first review to be about a place that I've experienced that I think is incredible. Forgive me for getting sentimental but your first time should be special. OK here we go:

I'm usually the one researching and suggesting restaurants so you can imagine my surprise when my boyfriend found the place that we would go for our one-year anniversary. Voza met every expectation I had for a celebration so special. It's dim and cozy atmosphere is very romantic. From the moment we came to the time we left (3 hours) I was thrilled. The food was incredible, the staff were like friends and the price was just right. Absolute must try is the chef's Banana's Foster. I've never seen my boyfriend eat anything so fast. My only word of caution is that Voza is extremely small (like 8 tables), but for me that only adds to its charm.

I hope I've said enough to make you try it. We loved it so much that we went back one month later for Valentine's Day and were not disappointed!

insider tip: BYOB (there is a liquor store a few blocks away)

HUNGRY HIPPO PICK: Banana's Foster

business.full_address:
University of Maryland
Golf Course Rd
College Park, MD 20742
business.name: University of Maryland Golf Course

reviews.text:
Pretty spot on review by Paul M the only other reviewer at this point.

NOTE THE COURSE IS CLOSED UNTIL JULY 2009.  They are renovating which will make it even nicer and, ive heard, even tougher.  New bunkers, redoing many of the green complexes, adding tee boxes.  Im anxious to see the new look.

I went to school at UM and used to play here on the regular.  Have always loved this course.  It's sneaky long (tough long Par 3s, plenty of uphill holes and forced carry shots) and sneaky tough..but pretty and a nice layout.  For the money its a steal.  And it never seems to be too crowded during the week.  Weekends are another deal.

Lastly they offer nicely priced memberships for not only the general public but also UM alum.  No extra fees or sign up fees or anything like that, just a yearly rate for as much golf as you can stomach.

The good news is this is another outstanding inside the beltway public course. The bad news is that on July 14th it closed for some huge renovations which will last until April 2009.

I always thought it was just for the students and staff of the Uni. Not so. It's public and it is a beautiful course. None of the convenience of Rock Creek or Sligo Creek, ( at least for me ) none of the history, uniqueness and riverside splendor of Langston, just a beautiful park like course right in the middle of the city. 

Parkland setting, long flowing fairways, challenging and tough. Smallish greens, some water to contend with, probably the best value for your $45 inside the beltway.

I'm a fan of good twilight rates and UofM GC definitely has those.  This is a big, hilly, fun golf course - even from the old tips which are now nowhere near the way back tees added for the buy.com tour (or whatever it's called now).  I want to give it mo

business.full_address:
9203 1/2 Baltimore Ave
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Dominican Hair Studio

reviews.text: Great customer service. I am a licensed cosmetologist and I can tell you they know what they doing. Hair came out great!!!! They blow out my 3year old hair and the ladies were very gentle.

business.full_address:
3153 Broadway
Harlem
Manhattan, NY 10027
business.name: Panda Garden Chinese Restaurant

reviews.text:
Tons of MSG in the food, even more than most Chinese take-out places. If you want to take an instant nap after eating, order Panda. 

I ordered the Garlic Shrimp combo that included shrimp, pork fried rice, and veggies. They throw in those crunchy Chinese snacks and an eggroll. I also got the won ton soup, which was below average. It came out to be 10 bucks. Pretty quick and tasty stuff, except it'll knock you out.

Just ok. Nothing special. Same old americanized chinese takeout place. cheap prices, decent portion. I, like Elsa G. ordered the szechuan chicken and it wasn't spicy at all. I should ask for it spicy next time.

This place will do on occasion, but only be

Not too shabby for delivery take-out chinese food.  I had the Singapore Chow Mei Fun and it has a nice kick to it which I really enjoyed.  My friend ordered the Szechuan Chicken and it too had an appropriate spice to it.  So many Chinese places say the dish is spicy  but it ends up being sweet or bland instead.  Not too bad here.

Honestly, it gets worse every time I'm here.  And I think finally, FINALLY, I've decided to not return here again.

Keep in mind, the first time I ever came here I gave it a four star review afterward.  I think in retrospect, it's because, the food is marginally better (or at least, I thought it was) than the average Americanized-Chinese take out.  
However, I think either I was dreaming and hoping for a "great local take out spot" since I was new to the area back then, or maybe Panda Garden's quality has genuinely been slipping.
Either way...

The steamed vegetable dumplings last night tasted... off, at best.  It almost tasted like the vegetables were perhaps placed on a counter top and mixed with a cleaning fluid of some sort?  I mean this literally.  

Bad food, equally bad service from a miserable looking man who never smiles EVER, and sketchy clientele... don't waste your time.

For what it is - a sketchy Americanized Chinese takeout place - it's great.
It's cheap, it's pretty fast (if you order at the counter - i haven't done delivery) and it's tasty.  Bonus: it's not overly oily like a lot of cheap Chinese food.  I don't know of any better place in this neighborhood because everywhere else either seems super gross or way too pricey.

business.full_address:
3420 Sansom St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: White Dog Cafe

reviews.text:
Had brunch there and was wowed by the creative offering of local, organic foods as well as the pleasant service.  The "bread basket" had a lovely selection of not too sweet (which is GREAT) muffins chocolate and pumpkin, coffecake and a perfect savory biscuit.  We devoured it along with the perfectly cooked omelet with a well balanced filling of goat cheese, spinach, sun dried tomato and bacon.  
The waitress kept our coffee cups filled (the coffee was as good, not great).   
I thought it charming and will return when back in Philadelphia.

I wanted to love this place with its fresh local food, its name reminiscent of Martha's Vineyard's Black Dog, and the cute little attached shop called The Black Cat.
I will never go here again.
The service alone deserves no stars.  Our server would appear every fifteen minutes or so and the rest of the time was MIA.  We had a lovely beet and walnut salad to start, but it went downhill from there. Not a lot of options as far as entrees go - I settled on the soggy kung pao tofu because I didn't want fish or lamb.  It looked and tasted as if it came from one of the cheap dives further down the street.  I had every intention of sending it back - which I have never done anywhere! but by the time our server finally coalesced out of thin air everyone else in our party had long given up on finishing their mediocre meals and we were just cranky for the check.
Average price for entrees is $25. The desserts looked good, but not good enough to pay $10 for.  We had all planned on getting dessert to make up for the terrrible dinner, but we tired out after staring at our half eaten meals for a good 15 minutes.
Other reviews have mentioned the air of pretension....for my part I am just shocked that no one in this establishment seemed to give a lick about the customers' comfort and enjoyment. That is why I think this place needs to close.  If you don't care about your customers you've got no business being in business. There I said it.
It was also way too loud in there.
Are there any good restaurants in this part of Philly?  I am losing faith fast.

Nothing special or remarkable.  This was my first visit under the new ownership.  A friend of mine and I were there for brunch.  The srever was friendly, but unattentive.  The bus boys, however, were terrific and would have made great waitstaff.  

My friend's panini was just plain tasting.  My omlette was overcooked and the bacon inside dry and cold.  The fingerling potatoes on the side were undercooked and bland.

I wouldn't make a point of going there, but if you are in University City on a Saturday at mid-day, they are about the only game in town sadly.

Best place for a business lunch in West Philly. We always bring visiting faculty here. Food is local/sustainable with quite a few vegetarian/vegan offerings, so there's something for everyone. While nothing I've tried here is out-of-this-world, everything I've tried is pretty solid. 

Prices are on the higher side but reasonable, especially for lunch (that's what makes it good for a business lunch). Service is always excellent (servers are super polite and attentive). The place itself is classy in a cute and homey way, like eating at someone's rich great aunt's house. A rich great aunt with good taste in decor (you know, for an old person).

I know that White Dog isn't as cutting-edge as it used to be, but I don't care. They have a very good beer selection, and the bartenders can actually, you know, bartend. This is usually a good sign, and White Dog is no exception.

The food is very good, and while it's not going to "wow" you anymore, just about everything I've ever eaten here has been appealing to both the eyes and mouth.

As most people have noted, it's a great date place, and I particularly like sitting in the bar area. In fact, I won't sit anywhere else.

It doesn't matter who you are... resident, visitor, tourist, student... White Dog can appeal to everyone and has been in business long enough that it deserves its reputation as a Philadelphia "institution".

We went to the White Dog for a late dinner, and the food was good. The meats were especially good. The deconstructed pot roast was excellent, and the flank steak special I had was really good too. I also started with a mushroom soup that was excellent. For desert, I highly recommend the Apple crisp. 

The service was good, and the local beer selection is excellent. The decor could definitely use a refresh, and while its not a ripoff, I would say its pricey. Overall, a good place to go if your near Penn.

So close to being a perfect meal. I do not get out to University City much but this place has been on my must try list for a while. The layout of this place works very well with some outdoor seating, a large bar area and a more quiet back dining room where I was seated. 

I love getting mussels when I go out to eat and these were some of the best I've had in the city. The bacon/beer combo was executed perfectly and the mussels themselves were fresh, huge and plentiful. For an entree I went with the five spice tuna.
