We had a lot of fun eating with our hands and using the injera to make the best combinations of what was in front of us. 
I've never had Ethiopian food before but I believe this is authentic Ethiopian cuisine--my authenticity radar (the same radar I share with Andrew Zimmern) says so.
Okay I've packed up the ton of leftovers and now I'm gonna leave Shagga to pick up my little sister from Cheer practice--but I shall return.

I've said it before and I'll say it again - when looking for good Ethiopian just keep an eye out for taxis parked out front. If you see more than two then run, don't walk, in the doors post haste.

This unassuming little place on Baltimore Ave looks like it used to be a Duncan Donuts. Might be called "Shagga Coffee" but "Shagga Kitfo" would be closer to the mark - this was as close to home style Kitfo as I've had in a restaurant.. I suspect the meat might've been hand cut rather than the blender job you get at most spots - which makes ALL the difference in the texture and consistency. 

The sambusa was also on point - perfectly shaped and seasoned like it came out of some 3rd generation vendor's stall on a side street  in Addis Ababa.


The coffee for which the place is named is also respectable and the owner's an absolute sweetheart.
Let's just say I took a 14 year old there and he liked everything.

This little restaurant is still (inexplicably) a neighborhood secret.  We have yet to visit it and wait for a table or eat in a full restaurant.  I cannot understand this at all.  This is the best Ethiopian food in the area.  I love Dukem's, Etete, Little Ethiopia - but they are 4 stars compared to Shagga's 5.  Fine, it's not as pretty inside as Dukem's, but really, they've done a very decent job with what used to be a donut shop (if I remember correctly).  

The food... the portions are generous, the dishes are uniformly delicious. Start with the lentil sambusas and make sure to request the sauce.  At this point I am in the habit of ordering a vegetarian plate in addition to any of the other combos because I don't want to miss out on what is sure to be at least one interesting veggie dish that doesn't make it onto the regular combination plates.  I have yet to have a mediocre veggie here - the hot and cold dishes are amazingly fresh and flavorful.  Standouts are the kik alicha, tekil gomen, and a couple of amazing dishes I haven't seen on the menu as standalones, a cold lentil sour sort of salad, and some pickled beets.  The injera is warm and soft and perfectly sour and spongy for soaking up the delicious sauces and juices of the food.  Meats... oh the meats.  While you would not in any way suffer as a vegetarian at Shagga, this place is a meat lover's dream.  The doro wat is deliciously spicy.  The lamb of any kind is perfectly tender and perfectly spiced.  The beef tibs are juicy and not dry at all.  The minchet may be my favorite though.  It is comfort food at its best.  And with the portions being large, it reheats beautifully the next day which is a huge plus.  If you're daring, the kitfo raw is also amazing. 

Have I mentioned the coffee?  This is easily my favorite cup of coffee in the area.  Granted it takes them forever and a day to make it, but that's just kind of the speed of this place.  It feels like going to dinner at a friend's house - leisurely, relaxed, welcoming.  Everyone working here is extremely nice and gracious.  Service is slow, but not in a way that feels incompetent, more like they'd like you to stay awhile and really enjoy the food.  I can't say enough good things about Shagga.

My partner and I are a bit Ethiopian food obsessed lately.  We had dined at two of many many Ethiopian restaurants in DC in the last few weeks, but one night when we were home (outside of DC) and wanted an ethic dining experience, we turned to a local Ethiopian joint we had passed many a times on our way to College Park and beyond.  Hyattsville isn't exactly known for its Ethiopian community, so I was skeptical even with all the rave reviews on Yelp.  

I was pleasantly surprised by this lovely hole in the wall restaurant (my favorite kind of eating establishments) with friendly servers and yummy (and I think pretty authentic) Ethiopian food.  We ordered a combo (can't remember which number) with lamb, chicken, beef, and veggies of our choice.  All the dishes were quite flavorful.  The only thing is that I thought the injera was kind of cold.  It tasted fine, but I just noticed how cold they were (not room temperature).

Also, I appreciated that the bathroom was pretty decent with hot water, soap, and paper towel.  I make this note because some smaller restaurants that are more hole in the wall-type often have not so clean bathrooms that concern me.

I can't wait to go back to this place, but we'll probably check out a few other Ethiopian places in DC first.  More about that later!
Tasty, cozy, friendly, and good coffee. Staff seemed overwhelmed with takeout orders so it was a bit slow though

Decided to come here for lunch, but we couldn't decide if we wanted to order the lunch special or off the dinner menu because we didn't know if the lunch portion would be "enough." We finally decided on the lunch specials because they were about $7 each. All I've got to say is they are very generous with their portions, especially with the meat.

Coffee: Their signature Ethiopian coffee (the 1st one on the list) was delicious. I'm not a huge coffee drinker, but it had great flavor, if that means anything, haha

Lunch combo #1: Chicken (mild), beef (spicy), and veggies. I replaced the potato salad with a fresh tomato salad. The spicy beef wasn't too spicy, but it had a nice little kick. Delish!

Lunch combo #4: Cubed Beef mixed with tomatoes, onions, and fresh jalapeno, and veggie sides. The beef was AWESOME! It was the perfectly cooked, very tender, and had amazing flavor. The fresh jalapenos gave it some spice (which i love), so this dish was definitely a winner!

Oh yes! the injera was very fresh and very "new" to me. When I first touched it, I was surprised at how the texture felt...kinda spongy, soft, and jiggly. After the lady taught us how to eat with it, we ripped off a piece, scooped up some meat, and punished the whole plate. Overall, our experience at Shagga was wonderful! The owners were so friendly and helpful, the food was perfect, and my stomach was more than satisfied! =)

Our first time with Ethiopian food, so I can't compare to other restaurants, BUT, we really enjoyed this!  The food was interesting, beautiful, and delicious.  The service was super-friendly.  The servings were quite large, so you won't go away hungry.  Even my picky 4-year-old found something she liked there.  We'll make it a point to go back next time we're in town.

Nice family owned business.  They have done a lot to improve the look since they've been here.  Service is efficient and food is great.  Never had a meal that I did not like.  The chicken sambusa's are superb and I just love the chicken/garlic dish (unable to recall the exact name).  Dont let the outside look fool you.  Nice/homey feeling place and friendly atmosphere.

I love Ethiopian food so I was happy. I got the combination #2 which had lamb alicha and beef wot. Very small place and it wasn't busy. I went to pick up lunch. I'm going to try to make it for a happy hour type session with some friends. I think it'd probably be fun. Finally, an excuse to eat with my hands!!!

Finally, decent Ethiopian food in Prince George's County!  We're used to trekking to Silver Spring or into DC for some injera covered in delicious meat and veggies... now there's a place just a couple of miles away!

Shagga has a traditional Ethiopian men
As good as, if not better than, Etete and Dukem. If you live closer to Shagga than U Street, there's no need to drive into town.

Shagga has answered our prayers for a decent Ethiopian restaurant in the Maryland 'burbs.  Not only is it decent, but it surpasses our old DC favorites in food and service.  It is a real family restaurant, with heartfelt mom and pop ambience that is family-friendly and welcomes kids.  And obviously knowing the stresses that kids pose, Shagga not only offers a full bar, but serves drinks cheaper than our neighborhood Chinese hangout.  Their menu is smaller than many places but still offers 2 or 3 tibs dishes and a couple of wots, with several veggie dishes.  Try the veggie combo to save money.  I even ordered minchet abish, even though it didn't appear on the menu.  Everything--injera, too, of course--was excellent and fresh, not greasy like the big restaurants in DC.  And they take their coffee seriously, as the name suggests.  New place, great discovery, near the Hyattsville courthouse on Route 1...  Good luck, Shagga!

The best Ethiopian meal I've ever had! 

I kinda expected it being that the DC area has the largest population of Ethiopians in the US. 

When my friend first told me we had to travel 45 minutes from her house in Fairfax, VA to the restaurants in Hyattsville, MD (I had no idea where that was, I'm just regurgitating facts) I was slightly doubtful. This place is really small and incredibly sparse and located in a random area. 

We ordered the lamb wot, chicken something, beef tibb combination for 2. Such a great choice! The lamb wot had to be the best of the three, with the beef tibb a close second and the chicken close behind. Everything was so good. I'm salivating thinking about it again. It came with 4 different veggie sides, 2 that were lentil based I think, a tomato salad, and a cabbage salad. The spongy bread was not as sour as most places I've been too which was nice. Really helped let the dishes shine. 

The service was great. Definitely a family owned shop. Kids home from school working in the corner and the adults drinking coffee and such close by. Apparently they do a coffee ceremony in the afternoon sometimes but I think we missed it. It took a bit for our food to come out but they were hit pretty hard right before we came with a couple of take out orders. Incredibly family friendly.

I've only tried their coffee, which is excellent. I've also asked one of the workers to make me a cafe au lait, which she glady did. It was, once again, wonderful. I've yet to try any of their food- I have to get in there one of these days and grab one of

I have to admit, I waited to go to Shagga because it still looked like the doughnut shop that used to be there. But, once I heard a great review from my parents, I had to try it. 

In my experience, the server was very nice. I was there with friends who had never eaten Ethiopian food before and she helped them with their selections and patiently explained injera to them. It took a little while for us to get the check, so I wouldn't go there if I was in a hurry, but it wasn't too long. 

I ordered the veggie combo and it was great! The injera was very fresh, the price was good, and everything in the veggie combo was delicious. I'll definitely be heading back as soon as I can!
Great food, reasonable prices. Best Ethiopian I've had.
Food is excellent. Be advised that the online menu is different from the restaurant menu which may present a problem when you call in an order...

For some reason I was craving Ethiopian food. We were driving through Maryland and found a 4 1/2 star restaurant on yelp, so we decided to go. The reviews were right about the way it looked. Don't be fooled by the outside. Once we went in it was pure silence. No music, no talking, air was warm. 2 other customers were already there-  1 older guy drinking at 11am (he had about 3 before he left) and 1 lady on her nook (free wi-fi). The staff (one lady) was very nice, quiet, and well reserved. The water was warm and the ice melted quickly. We got the mango and banana smoothies - thanks for the heads up from other yelpers. The coffee was dark and strong.  We got the chicken app- my friends described it as an empanadas/egg roll/crab Rangoon app. It was good. We ordered #4 combo- chicken,lamb, beef. Thanks to other yelpers we ordered just one and it was enough for 4. The enjera (bread) was tasty. To me it looked like adipose tissue, spongy look. It was nice and soft. The meats were great too. My fav was the chicken- spicy and tender. Be careful with the chiles in the salad. There was no napkins around, so we used the table cloth. Towards the end the air kicked in and xm radio turned on. 

The reason I gave it 3 stars was because I thought it would be better. I guess I need to get out more. My friends prob would have given it 3 1/2-4 stars.

Oh yes, very yummy.  Had the veggie combo for lunch, and really enjoyed the kik alicha, tekil gomen and gomen.  The misir wat was a bit salty, but a very nice spicy flavor.  I liked the potato dish too, mild but flavorful.  The salad was lacking in flavor
It's inexpensive, offers great food and service, has a full bar, and is a nice place to go with kids. I like the vegetarian plate best, and definitely try the busas.

Ever since that Washington Post piece, this place has been getting much more crowded and the service has slowed down noticeably but the food and coffee is still amazing and worth the wait. We thought of this place as our quiet secret because all of the ethiopian places where we live (DC/SS border) were always crowded. 

The veggie combo is delicious and filling as well as the beef tibs. The food is flavorful and fresh, and most of all they're consistent! If I didn't have to fight for parking on campus I would love to come here for lunch more often! The coffee is also very good and I read they get their own type beans from Ceremony roasters in Annapolis.
I no longer need to go down to DC for Ethiopian food -- this place is as good or better than any of the places I've tried in Adams Morgan.

I'm so glad I live nearby Shagga; the food is good and the service is efficient and friendly.  LOVE the beef tibs and the sambusas.  The sambusas are filled with either beef (slightly spicy), chicken, or lentils.  I usually order a half dozen and get 2 of each.  (they also have lunch specials during the week)

Yebeg (lamb) tibs were fine, but the portion was small compared to other places I visit.

I'd almost say the same about the sambusas: they're smaller than what one would find in an Ethiopian grocery.  On the other hand, they are fresh(er) so it's really apples and oranges.

The best Ethiopian food in the area is  in Prince George's County. Shagga is excellent every time. I go often. I bring my friends and colleagues here every chance I get. The lunch special is an outstanding value, and the owners are delightful, generous, and kind. The food is never too greasy, which is often a problem at other Ethiopian places. The coffee is always a great way to finish a Shagga meal. I only wish the Tiramisu didn't come in one frozen block. Other than that, I have no complaints.

they have raw beef!!! yay!!! been trying to find a place that would let me try some kifto, and they had it!! we got an order of kifto and a combo veg platter. both were just delicious =),definitely liked the kifto, though the portion was quite large! we only finished half of both and took the rest home (cooked the raw beef so that we could save it for later, which was well seasoned and yummy cooked too =)). 

the place was kinda empty but there was only one waitress/host so it worked out great. she was very kind and helpful, and definitely not too attentive nor did she ignore us. 

great food, great service, priced fair.. i'll come back =) don't be deterred by it's looks outside, this place is yum =).

The food here is decent, but not spicy enough, in my opinion. I want to sweat when I eat Ethiopian food! I was a little disappointed after my visit; I was really hoping to have a go-to Ethiopian place up the street from my house.

The coffee they serve is quite delicious, though.
This place is great. Thank god, I was about to give up on this area entirely. Good coffee, great food, and fantastic service. Free wifi makes it a place I can hang out, much needed in this area.

The place may have been a doughnut shop once upon a time, but it doesn't matter. The food is great! There are several vegetarian options, & both omnivores & vegetarians can have meals where the salt count's low. Unfortunately, my condition prevents me from enjoying full-strength coffee, but my friends tell me it's very good. I would say that Ethiopian food would be perfect for the right kind of kid-besides a pizza, what else besides injera is napkin, plate, starch, & serving utensil all at once?

Great sambosas; veggie platters and chicken dishes particularly well done, too - 

Calling ahead is a good idea if you plan to carry out.  It can get crowded, too, but that's just because they can put together a nice meal.

I'd never had Ethiopian food before setting foot into Shagga.  But, always questing for new food experiences, I dragged my father here while we were staying at a nearby hotel in order to get an idea of what the cuisine was all about.

The restaurant is a laid-back sort of place.  Service is prompt and pricing is highly reasonable for the amount of food you get.  We split the yebeg tibbs - lean lamb cubes sautéed in onions, green peppers and herbed butter.  The lamb came in a dish alongside a piece of injera spread with a side-dish amount of kik alicha (a buttery dish of split peas sautéed with onions, garlic and herbs) and some greens with a very light dressing.  We were also given a basket of two or three more injera rolls, which are highly filling in and of themselves.  The lamb was prepared very well, savory and tender in a sauce that had just the right amount of kick to it.  All of this fed the two of us well.

All in all, a great first experience with Ethiopian cuisine.  It was fun to eat with one's hands as well.  Perhaps I'll be adventurous enough to try the kitfo next time I'm in the area!

The only thing that makes me sad about this place is that I did not discover this place sooner. Now I don't have to go into DC if I want amazing Ethiopian food.

Not only is the food here AWESOME cause it is. The service is so warm and friendly that it made me feel like I was eating in their home and not at a restaurant. It's so cozy.

Don't wait. Put on your coat and shoes and go now.

Although I removed one star for ambience, Shagga is still a great place to grab coffee with a friend or a good Ethiopian meal. 

I've been eating Ethiopian food since I was fourteen, so I forget sometimes that people can think the cuisine is weird. The meal is served with a bread called injera, which is made from a grain called teff (in the U.S. the teff is often combined with wheat). The bread looks like a napkin if you don't know better. The injera gets wrapped around whichever morsel you would like to eat and then put into your mouth. No utensils required beyond your hands and injera.

If the above turns you off, then Ethiopian food won't be your thing.

It wasn't until coming to Yelp and reading reviews that I learned they have free wifi. I'd been driving all the way to Silver Spring for that. From now on, I'll be visiting Shagga to give my money to a local business with good food.

The tables don't force you to be elbow to elbow with people, so this is a good place for groups and people with kids.

I love having Shagga "in my backyard."  The service is graceful and the food always fresh and delicious.  The vegetarian combo is very good.  Kids fit in very well here unlike some of the places in Shaw and Adams Morgan.   Spices can be a bit "off" at tim

Shagga Coffee is cheaper, more generous, and tastier than anything in DC. The service is also great--the owner (I think--she's always there, anyways) is very sweet and helpful. In my experience the food comes out very quickly, always with generous and delicious portions. I recommend the veggie combo. It's hard to stop eating it even if you are stuffed beyond imagination. The coffee is good, as is to be expected, and they will happily throw out an old pot to make you fresh coffee. 

This is one of my favorite places ever. And now, writing about it, my mouth started watering and I think I am going to have to go there right now.

Wow, I can't believe I haven't reviewed Shagga!

When I moved back to the DC area a little over three years ago, my goal was to try every Ethiopian restaurant around. I've been to Meskerem, Queen of Sheba, Etete, Addis Ababa...

But now I'm not sure if I can make good on that goal. Because Shagga came to Hyattsville, and now I don't think it's worth it for me to spend extra time and money to go into DC for some fine Ethiopian cuisine.

I grew up around here, and I remember when Shagga's building was a Donut Connection, and before that, a Dunkin' Donuts. Given the less-than-ideal space they had to work with, it looks pretty nice, and there's only a lingering shadow of donut shop around the place. But I don't really care that the atmosphere at Shagga isn't up to Meskerem's standards. The service is far friendlier (I say this with a special place in my heart for Meskerem) and on a much smaller, local scale. As far as I've seen, the only people who work here are the husband and wife who own the restaurant, and one other woman who usually works as the waitress. They are all warm and welcoming, whether you're by yourself or in a large group with children, and they remember their returning customers.

The food is great and includes all my favorites: kik alicha, gomen, tikil gomen, misir wat, yebeg tibbs. I wish they had shuro wat, but it's not a big deal. They also serve a beet dish on the veggie combo that I haven't seen anywhere else. Harar and Meta beer and honey wine are available, plus great fruit smoothies. One thing I actually haven't tried here is the coffee!

Prices are more affordable than the DC places. As long as Shagga is around, you'll only find me in DC for Ethiopian on very special occasions.

Yes!

The vegetarian combo is excellent (really, the best I've had in the DC area).  Sometimes I stop in just to order some sambusas to go.

With so few non-chain restaurants in the area around Shagga, the place should be packed every night.

Plus, it's the kind of small business one likes to support.  The two women (owners?) are there all the time, and so kind.  

Be forewarned, if you're in a big hurry the coffee service is a little slow.  Which is okay--sometimes I need to slowdown.

I'd go back next time I'm in the area.
Ambience: Simple place with a bar and clean, quiet atmosphere.
Service: Friendly waitress.
Food: I got the Yebeg Awaze Tibs (lamb with tomato and paprika seasoning) which was very good. The main came with sides of what was essentially a salsa and a nice corn side. Plenty of fresh injera but for those native Africans who prefer their injera to be on the tart/bitter side you will be disappointed. Another highlight was the mango smoothy which was made to order with fresh mangoes. 
Price: Just about right.

Shagga is one of our favorite Hyattsville restaurants.  Don't be fooled by its humble curb appeal.  The food is great, prices are reasonable, and service is efficient and appreciative.  We are lucky to have such a gem in the neighborhood!

Hot. Damn.

It was a dark and stormy night. It was also uncomfortably cold. My friend from undergrad was in town for the week. Our choices were: work on papers or watch West Wing or try out Ethiopian food for the first time. 

Why does everyone who comes to DC assume I just watch West Wing all the time? I mean, I do watch it all the time, but still? 

Anyway, I'm really glad we went to Shagga. This place throws anything else in Hyattsville or College Park way out of the park. I understand that you don't "throw things out of the park," but I've never been good with baseball idioms.

I got the vegetarian combo and my friend got a few chicken dishes. The injera is wonderful and all of the different samplings of dishes were amazing. I have no idea what was what but I will surely be returning to exact my revenge and learn everything. My favorite thing was the sweet potato dish (I think). It didn't really matter that I knew nothing about what I was eating. All that mattered was that it was the best thing I had eaten in a long, long time. I got one of the Ethiopian beers (Harar) on the recommendation of the waitress and it was delicious - it had an earthy aftertaste that went perfectly with the meal. 

The location is convenient for College Park residents (just go down Route 1) and this place would easily be swamped all the time if it was located in the District. Don't let the exterior fool you - Shagga is as cozy and welcoming as my grandmother's house. I'm sitting right now at my childhood home and can't wait to get back just so I can dine here again. The owners and wait staff are incredibly friendly and were very patient with us for our first experience here. 

Seriously, though. Stop whatever unimportant things you're doing right now and go to Shagga.
Family owned, good food, good service -- a great small restaurant to enjoy authentic Ethiopian food, easy parking. Free wi-fi, too, and excellent coffee!

This is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant ever. In fact, this is my favorite restaurant, period. This is saying a lot, because I live in Austin now. We would always get the vegetarian platter, which is just unbelievably good. The samosas are fantastic, they have a cool selection of Ethiopian wines and beers, and of course, the coffee is to die for. Do not be fooled by the modest exterior, this place is by far the greatest Ethiopian place in the DC area.

You should give this place a try.

Hyattsville has certainly moved up in the number and quality of eateries in the last year or so.  But this place remains the place to go.  The food is Ethopian.  If you haven't tried it, I highly recommend you do because it is very good.  This restaurant is great because it is family owned, not a chain like many of the other nearby options.  The people who work at Shagga are very pleasant and accommodating.  The building itself is the worst part; it looks like an old convenience store or laundromat.  But do not judge a book by it's cover.  Check this place out and you will be glad that you did.

This place seems to be improving, and I'm pulling for it to succeed. The food has been delicious every time I've gone there - I can't remember the name of the dish, but the "potatoes and carrots" was amazing. The "improvement" is in everything else. The first time I went, I wanted to have coffee and work on my laptop, but no outlets. I see they have them now. Its in a converted donut shop, so it still has that feel, but every time I go, they seem to be changing the interior bit by bit. The family that runs it is super nice, and its the kind of place that your two-year old can run around and be a two year old, and everyone seems to be cool about it. Unfortunately, part of that is because every time we have gone we are the only customers there. Sometimes I want to give them advice, a la Jerry Seinfeld, to improve the place, but I've held back since everything I seem to touch loses money. They actually have a selection of beer and wine, but the first few times we went, nothing of the sort was offered. At any rate, for the food and friendliness I give it four stars, but the place itself is still a work in progress so - three stars.

I am a big fan of Shagga even though my spicy-food tolerance isn't. Despite this, I continue to force down bite after bite! My absolute favorite was the kifto, I ordered it medium rare as I wasn't ready to fully commit. I love the semi-raw flavor with the spices. The rawness, for me, actually makes it one of the tamer dishes heat wise. 

The vegetable sides were good, I loved the cabbage. Finally the injeera. Okay this may sound weird, but the only other time I've eaten Ethiopian the injeera left a chalky residue on my hands, at Shagga it didn't or perhaps I didn't notice it? What does this mean? Does that indicate that one place uses entirely teff or a teff-wheat blend? Please let me know if you have any idea - I'm very curious. 

I think this is honestly the best Ethipian I've ever had. Oh, and the good news is if you over-order you can tear up the injeera, put the whole lot of it in the skillet till it's hot and you have another dish - fitt-fitt! Trust me, it's a meal fitt-fitt for a king!

Shagga Coffee has fresh, healthy, delicious Ethiopian food. There are very few good places to eat in this neighborhood, so Shagga is a gem. It's better than most Ethiopian food I've had in DC. If they ever get breakfast back on the menu, you should GO - it's VERY good and unique. In fact, ask them when it's coming back - just to encourage them. :)  The owner is kind, service is good, the restaurant is pleasant and clean inside. It's very easy to drive by Shagga and think that it's not worth stopping, which makes it a rather well-kept secret around here. Ignore the appearance and give it a shot - I can guarantee you won't be sorrry, if you like Ethiopian food. Like Allison W., I recommend the veggie combo, and their doro wat is also very good.

We're so happy to have a great, casual Ethiopian restaurant in the area.  We like Dukem in DC, but we don't always have the time to travel into the city.  Having Shagga right in Hyattsville, where the old donut shop was, is so great.  Hands down, one of the best locally owned restaurants in the area.  

It's a small casual eatery.  We went for the first time on a Sunday afternoon.  There was a mixture of regulars and new timers.  It was quiet and laid back.  

The food took a long time to come out, but this is probably because it was Sunday.  We didn't mind too much because it allowed us time to relax.  The lady who runs the place is super nice and friendly.  

We ordered two sambusas and the meat combination for two.  The sambusas are thin, seemingly wrapped in spring roll wrappers, and super tasty.  We had a beef and chicken.  Delish!  Each is $1.50 or a half dozen for $7.50.  We definitely wanted more!  The meat combo was also delish.  The quantity of food is about 3x that at Dukem for about the same price.  The cheese was rich and cool.  The lentils were very good.  All the meat dishes was spicy and delectable.  The only item we wouldn't order again is the kikfo.  It was too mushy for our tastes.

We are looking forward to going again.

Though it looks like a Dunkin' Donuts, the food and service are good and prices reasonable. There aren't a ton of choices in the area so it's nice to have Shagga. Not really a romatic ambience for a nightime date, but great for lunch.

Most amazingly delicious food prepared by a wonderful family for a devoted community.  As visitors to Hyattville, we stopped by just a few minutes before closing time, and they welcomed us warmly.  We ordered the vegetarian combo, which arrived as a spect

Decided to try this place this past weekend, since I have been craving Ethiopian.   Food was delicious.  Service was great.  Only tried this place because of the reviews.  Thought this place had a bit of an identity crisis when driving by previously.  It just seemed like the Ethiopian cuisine may have been an after thought.  But the place was completely Ethiopian cuisine and good fresh coffee.

Picking the top Ethiopian joint in the DMV is an impossible task.  Some automatically shout out the big names (Dukem, Addis Ababa) .  While all those places have their charm and supporters, I think I have to go with Shagga for the very reason that it is often not mentioned in the greats of DC Ethiopian.

This tiny, unassuming place off Route 1 is definitely a family owned and run joint.  It's rare to see more than 5-10 people at this place; even during meal rush hours.  And I think that is its top selling point.  I know it's horrible to praise a restaurant on its lack of customers, but some of us don't like having to shout over the crowds at places like Dukem or Addis Ababa.  It's lack of overcrowded yupsters and party people give it a secret charm- like this is our place and only we know about it.

First off, the sambusas are top notch.  I get the veggie ones and my better half gets the meat ones- I rave over mine and she raves over her's.  Good deal.  I usually go for the veggie combo because I hate having to choose from so many delicious choices.  The food is spicy with the Berber seasoning being clearly homemade with care to its equitable composition.

I never get the coffee (which, by the way, is actually hard to find at DMV Ethiopian joints!  What gives?  You invented coffee! Start serving it!), but next time I'm definitely getting it.  

So skip the crowds and head up the unholy route 1 into the PG burbs.  It's worth it.  But not too many.  This is our place after all!

business.full_address:
1401 University Blvd E
Hyattsville, MD 20783
business.name: El Puente De Oro Restaurant

reviews.text:
I drove about just a little more than an hour to find this restaurant.  I had heard some good things about it so I had to check it out.

As we walked into the black light lit dining room I could see the Karaoke stage that supposedly starts playing at 9pm on Fridays & Saturdays!  We were promptly seated and asked if we care for a beverage.  We both ordered Jugo de Tamarindo that usually is very tasty but this one looked like flavored water and tasted worse! I took one sip and put to the side, and ordered me a Stella beer instead :-)

I've had Lomo Saltado at La Granja de Oro, El Chalan, & at the Salsa Room so when I saw the menu included a Mariscos Saltados I was excited! When my food arrived, nicely presented it looked a little dull!  The potatoes were way too moist; almost to a point of being called mashed potatoes, the Shrimps, the mussels, and the whatever else was included just tasted bland!  So No, I don't think I'll order Lomo from this place again!  

If I ever do make the trip to Maryland again I'll like to come during Karaoke hours because at 3pm there isn't much to look at! Where were them servers that one of the reviewers was talking about? Our server was pretty descent and she seemed to know what she was doing because she did include a 15% tips on our check :-)  I did add another 5% in addition just because I always tip 20% or more! I do feel kinda discriminated when they add the tip on my check though but perhaps that is because this place is mostly patronized by people who love the Cerveza and don't tip well! 

I will comeback but for the Cerveza and the Karaoke music!   I hear they have contests and although I cannot sing, I've got some friends that do so I look forward to coming back ;-)

OK, similar to my review of Taco Mex, this caters to the local Latin American native. Puente features damn good food, very loud music (Karaoke night will bust your eardrums after 9 on Sat), occasional drunks, and hardly a word of English in the place. Been there a dozen times and can count all the Anglo customers I've ever seen on one hand. Not that it's a bad thing- quite the contrariorerrific thing. The all-waitress service is capable and friendly,  though again they're more focused on flirtation with the guys. Go for the food and the feel of being somewhere far from the USA. If you feel uncomfortable sticking out like a sore thumb based on Anglo ethnicity, this is NOT the place for you. If you like damn good Mexican / Salvadoran food, YUM!

I stopped here after getting lost trying to get to the University.  I ate until my hearts content, for about 12 bucks.  The food was fresh, flavorful, and nicely presented and the beer was cold.  It is pretty far from where I live so I probably would not go out of my way to go back, but if I was in the area, oh yeah!!

business.full_address:
4101-19 Market St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Pep Boys Automotive

reviews.text:
I have had very mixed results from Pep Boys at Market St. I would actually say the mechanics are slightly better than the guys behind the auto parts desk - one of those guys is clearly racist as he will help black folks who clearly arrived at the desk later than me even though I LIVE RIGHT BEHIND THE PEP BOYS.

A big scam they ran on me is this buy 3 tires, get a fourth free. To qualify you need to purchase their alignment service which invariably involves them telling you need new tie rods, suspension, air freshener etc. Just expect to pay for 4 damn tires.

These days I take my car to Carlos' shop at 40th and Powelton and just go to Pep Boys for parts when I need to feel really white.

It's a shame you have to give even one star. 

The guy in the morning was alright, almost friendly though certainly not efficient. But when I came to pick up my car just after 6:00 p.m., after work and after I had four tires replaced, there was a shift change. They loaded up the bill with all kinds of extras without telling me about it. Like a warranty... keep reading.

When I went to have those stricken from my total, the manager on duty gave me and the politely persistent woman before me--who had exactly the same problem--all kinds of attitude as he fumbled with the register he clearly didn't understand. Eventually, after an argument and a mumbled rant about how the shop guy always does this, he just gave us cash. She even got some free stuff because he didn't want to bother ringing her out. I bet corporate loved that. I anticipated a minute or two spent giving them my credit card and taking my keys but the process took nearly an hour. It's unclear what they spent most of that time doing. I do know they were unapologetically rude throughout the process. When I woke up the next morning, I realized the back left tire was totally flat. The employees kept disappearing inexplicably during the process and when I left, there was a razor blade next to my car. Make of that what you will. I plan never to go back there. 

Anyway, I took it to the much better Pep Boys on Columbus and got it replaced under warranty (the same one I tried to remove!) because the Market St. manager took it off the bill incorrectly. 

Hey, sometimes incompetence serves a purpose

FYI: Don't bring your car in for anything here if you're in a hurry. The older adults at Parts and Service (Carl) are great, but the young guys have no sense whatsoever of customer service. Things that should take about 5 minutes, like dropping a car off for inspection, end up taking about 15 minutes because there's lots of activity without much happening. Picking up a car after anything has been done also takes a long time due to paperwork/keys/info not being where it should be. They do have the cheapest prices for some things, but you might lower your expectations if you go here for any parts or service work.

Don't even bother with this place.  When I first called to ask about service (my AC wasn't working properly and my fan wasn't working at all), they seemed alright, but when I arrived to drop my car off, the guy that took my information had no idea what he was doing.  At first he pretty much told me they wouldn't be able to help me, even though the person on the phone had said otherwise.  I should've just thanked him and walked out.  When they finally called the next day to tell me what they had found, they said my fan was working just fine - it wasn't!! - and the AC just needed recharged, which they wanted to charge me $200 for!!  Basically they just wanted to charge me a ridiculous amount without actually doing any work.  I told them no way, and came back to pick up my car.  In all, I wasted about $30 to have them look at it, flat out lie to me, and accomplish nothing.  I will never go back here.

I called Pep Boys' corporate last year to let them know just how suspect this location/staff is.

Those scenes in movies, where it's time to pay the mechanic and says, "How much you got?" That's true of here.

Go to Pep Boys at 8a.m. some morning, and you'll see troubled motorists lined up at the doors like fiends waiting for crack. When staff apathetically turns the key at 8:07a.m., a frenzy begins of customers clawing for "do my car first."

The staff here knows NOTHING about cars, and they prey on poor people, and charge three times what the independent guys do. I refuse to return here, and I'd pay to have my car towed somewhere before I let these morons tighten a lug nut.

Went here with a nail in my tire, and they put in some plug gunk to seal it.  The nice thing was that the service was free with a Pep Boys Rewards card!  That was a pleasant surprise.  Now let's just hope that the plug works...

I went here to get a replacement driver's mirror for my car. I was excited that they had one and a decent price. I was being helped by a very nice gentleman until Frank got involved in our conversation. This idiot  starts taking over the order and evidentely orders the wrong mirror after me and his co-worker repeately tell him I need the Driver's mirror. Of course, I don't realize until I'm at the mechanic and they've removed EVERYTHING!!! 

I go back and specifically ask to speak with him. He does aplogize, but of course it's not helpful when my car is pretty much non-drivable now :( 
Luckily I spoke with Ruth before coming back into the store and she tried to get overnight shipping instead of the normal 3 day shipping like Frank was saying that's all he could offer. I'm still awaiting to find out if it came today, but looks like it didn't. 

Moral of this review: CHECK and VERIFY everything you order at the store!!!

I have been going to Midas across the street for most of my vehicle issues. But since I moved recently closer to Center City, I wanted to find a place where I can wait while my car is being serviced. So when I found that Pep Boys at this location offers 29min oil change and also provides online appointments, I decided to give it a shot. 

I made a 8am appointment the night before for oil change and repair on gas tank heat shield (although I didn't know this was the issue at the time) and got to the place exactly at 8am, which is when they open the door. They also take overnight drops, which get serviced before the first appointment of the day, so I expected somewhat of a delay. They have a waiting area in the store, so I waited there for about an hour. There were a few people before me who also waited in the waiting area. I also walked around the store and bought some air filters. (By the way, the store is quite big and well stocked, it seems) After about tow hours of waiting, I went up to the service desk to ask about the progress of my car service, the guy gave me a nonchalant look and went back to look at some paper work. Then, he tells me that I am the next car to be serviced. By this time, I was getting a little bit impatient but I hold my tongue since I only have to wait a little bit more. Or so I thought. After about another hour with me hovering over the service desk, they pull me into the service area to show me a gas tank heat shield that came off on one bolt as the socket rotted away. They gave me two options - 1) I take it to Midas to get it welded (they don't do welding here apparently) or 2) just take it off completely.  The reason why I brought in my car in the first place was because of a clanking noise coming from the back, which I now found out was due to the heat shield hitting the exhaust pipe. So I considered just taking it off completely since that would stop the noise. But my instinct told me no. So after four hours (!) I come home and go to Midas the next day and they tell me I definitely need the heat shield and I need to take it to Toyota dealership. 

So here's the gist of my experience at Pep Boys at this location: a looooong wait and one bad advice, which I fortunately didn't take.  Their 29min oil change is a joke because what they mean is it'll take 29min to change your oil IF there are no other cars that are being serviced at the moment. And they do have a lot of mechanics working in the back too.

I will not go back to this place for any servicing related issues. This is an adequate place for shopping for parts.

I was very satisfied with the assistance offered at this location.  The manager at this store went out of his way to help me to get a battery put in my car which had broken down just outside the store. I look forward to returning to this store for help with other automotive needs for my car.

Seriously, I should have read Yelp first.  But I was in a hurry and thought that the 29 minute oil change would be easy.  Umm yeah - more like 3.5 hours with no apology.  The place is dirty, poorly managed, and the staff could not be more surly and unhelpful.  They also have an absurd amount of staff just walking around doing nothing.  There was seriously one guy doing any actual work - small wonder it took 3 hours. Could Pep Boys just be one giant front for an organized crime syndicate?  It would explain a lot.  Save your time and money and go to 11th Street Auto instead.  I went there to get my car battery fixed and those guys are seriously nice.
Yawnzer. This place take a poop on the stick!

Unsurprisingly, the West Philly Pep Boys is characterized by words such as "racist", "scam", "crime", and BEST of all, its customers described as "waiting for crack"  by my fellow reviewers.  Unsurprising, because the reviewers are all white.

I come here regularly and I get excellent treatment...and I'm not black.  

Yes, it's the hood...but if you walk in expecting to get mugged, cheated, or treated unfairly, you're probably evincing those pre-disposed notions of yours.  Frankly, if you made me feel like a criminal, I'd want to take your head off.

Yours truly,
-e

Took my car here after a PPA tow truck damaged my car. I can't prove that they conspired with my insurance appraiser to say there was no damage from the towing, but the facts don't lie. Regardless, according to them, my car had no damage from the towing, but there was wear and tear on my struts and they needed to be replaced. And so they were. And then my car still sounded like the shocks were full of gravel and a loud popping sound when I turn my steering wheel. 

So, of course, I took the car back there. They covered the suspension and drive-train inspection, because it was within 90 days and while I was it I figured I'd have them replace my windshield wipers. I got a call the next day to let me know that they found nothing wrong with my car, though "we definitely heard that noise it is making." Well, at least I didn't pay for that service. But then I got to my car and saw that they didn't even replace my wipers! They did charge me for them. Begs the question of whether they even inspected my car, considering they weren't going to make any money from it.

Don't waste your time with these people unless you need to get an oil change. They are not real mechanics.

business.full_address:
3649 Lancaster Ave
Powelton Village
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Green Line Cafe - Powelton Village

reviews.text:
Great coffee shop perfectly poised in Center City.  The coffee is  La Colombe, which is delicious and strong as hell.  I run around the city like a ADD Japanese kid after I leave.

  The owner frequently has cool photography/paintings adorning the walls.  It has high ceilings and good satellite radio music.  You can grab a bagel or a PB and J to munch on and the windows open up the place on a nice day.  

  It is a little small with less than comfortable seats, but it has a similar feel to some of the coffee shops I went to in Lima.  

  It's a great place.  Go there for the happy hour and get fifty cent espresso shots and green tea iced tea.  The service is all from some of the most friendly people around (unlike The Last Drop where you leave soaked in pretention).  Few places make me want to go out of my way to go there, especially when you can get decent coffee all over the place in Philly.  I make special trips to Loftus because it is worth it.

My iced tea was more than $2, but the store is adorable and a great study place on a weekday morning. They have sidewalk seating, but also a great screen porch out back! It's very small, though... Not for groups of more than 3 people.

Yet another reason to love Green Line Powelton: the recent renovations are absolutely gorgeous! It was always cute, but now there are huge open windows unencumbered by black metal grates, a porch, or tables on the porch. It's sunny and the new paint job is really nice and soothing. Also, there's a bar near the window for improved people-watching. Really nice job, and as always, the baristas are nice, the sandwiches tasty, and the coffees and teas delicious.

This is probably my favorite Green Line, mostly because they are usually not crowded when I go there (except for one terrifying Saturday morning when an entire dance school full of small, screaming children and their mothers came flooding in). But anyway, the coffee is really good here and, although they don't have a lot of food options, they do offer some good bagel toppings like hummus and vegan cream cheese. The staff are generally courteous and mellow, and it's a pretty good place to get work done without (usually) a lot of background noise. The only real complaint I have is that they're not open very late at all - they close around 5 or 6 most nights, even earlier on weekends and in the summer.

I'm not much of a coffee drinker (more of a tea guy), but I really enjoy getting both from Green Line. The barista is always friendly and is super knowledgeable about all of their offerings, for example after telling her the type of coffee I usually enjoy she was able to pick the perfect variety for me and was even able to convince me to abstain from adding sugar (this NEVER happens when I drink coffee, but I'm glad I listened). I have never tried any of their food except for the occasional bagel, which is good, but because I'm not a big breakfast eater (well, in the morning anyway) I usually avoid some of their other offerings.

The prices are very reasonable and even after customizing your order with numerous additions you'll be pleasantly surprised with the final cost. My only real gripe is their hours, they open early but close very early as well so it makes it impossible for me to stop by after work, but it's understandable given the area (Powelton Village). While I may not be as passionate about my coffee as most (read: Wawa suffice on most days), I do think they are one of the better shops in all of Powelton Village (read: 400% better than Wawa) and I definitely think you should stop in and give them a try.

This green line is the worst.  They never have anything in stock - no sandwiches, no iced coffee.  You have to just be willing to eat or drink whatever.  On a recent trip to buy a vegan wrap for breakfast the server told me that the breakfast wraps don't come till after 10:30.  Not an ideal time for breakfast.  Of course, she told me that they just stay for a couple days so they should be in stock the next day.  Then, she corrected me several times for saying breakfast burrito when I meant sweet potato burrito.  Why did it matter so much?  Both were out of stock.

And So I have officially been to all 3 (4 if you count the now defunct one that is became Cafe Clave.). After reading some good reviews I decided to hop on the trolley and make my way down to the Green Line that is farthest away from my house. and in a lot of ways it was well worth the trek.

The first thing I noticed was the ample amount of Outdoor seating. Compared to the other two this Green Line definitely offers the most, and they even have a small back courtyard. If there wasn't snow outside I would have been all over it :(

The second thing that I noticed was that out of the three they definitely had the smallest indoor space and smallest counter space. In some ways we're talking drastically small. I'm so used to picking up the tasty sandwiches and wraps that they offer behind the counter at the other two, that when they didn't have any I instantly assumed that they were out and opted for a croissant. That was when I realized that they were inside the drink cooler of all places. lesson learned!

Service wise this Green Line was on par with the others, making it a trifecta of good service. and the croissant and latte that I picked up definitely satisfied my taste buds. This is probably the Green Line I'll be going to the least, just because otherwise would be trivial since I pass two others along the way. But I know where you'll see me once Spring hits!

i think i like this place more than i should because it is so close by, but i do like it a lot.  they're coffee is strong, they're galleria is constantly changing, and one of the counter boys is pretty cute.  sometimes i blog from there, but with the trolly rumbling by, its easy to get distracted.
They lengthened their hours, here's my update as promised.

Thank you for accommodating our semi-large party by letting us rearrange two-tops :) I still love pumpkin shots.

I'm disappointed that your later hours have already been revoked... I arranged an evening tea there, and after 30 minutes I was told it was closing time, cutting my catch up session super short... ie 2 hours early. le sigh.
Not sure what it is, but I've had much better customer service experiences at the Powelton location recently.  Nice!

While Green Line does have good coffee, I've never had a good experience there. They're almost always out of multiple baked goods (despite whatever time of day you visit). Also, they're always understaffed. This morning I waited in line for nearly 15 minutes with only 5 people ahead of me. There was only one employee behind the bar. Highly annoying. I've tried Green Line a few times and it has never redeemed itself. Will not be going back. If the coffee wasn't so good, I'd have given it 1 star.

I've never been particularly fond of Green Line Cafe. The staff has always seemed kind of disaffected and the food is mediocre. Still, when it comes to coffee I'm not picky and I certainly like anything free trade. 

However, just a few minutes ago I went to buy a small iced coffee. It was $2.50 and being visibly filled almost entirely with water. Even still, fair trade is something I'll pay more for. It took me about fifteen minutes to get a simple iced coffee because two girls, who were way hipper and more bubbly than me apparently, were gaining all of the attention of the staff. Even the manager. When I finally got my iced coffee, I went to put a lid on it and it accidentally slipped and fell spilling everywhere. Keeping in mind that I just paid these people $2.50 for a small container of mostly water, it would have made a great impression for them to offer me another. Instead, they chose to avoid eye contact and act extremely put out as they cleaned the spill. I thought about buying a second one, but decided I didn't want to give their business anymore money.

I really enjoy this Green Line and consider it my favorite neighborhood coffee shop.

The coffee is always hot and quite decent, the seating is surprisingly plentiful, and the back patio is a wonderful place to spend a sunny morning or afternoon.  If it's cold and/or rainy outside, two of my favorite places to sit are at the front window bar (great people watching) or in the back by the bathroom.  There's free wi-fi and plenty of outlets.  The staff and clientele can be quirky sometimes, but that's just part of why I like it here so much.  Remember to bring cash, because they don't accept credit cards.

great place to grab a cup of coffee! If you popping in and want something seasonal, go for their pumpkin spiced latte. I'd also like to mention that this place really brings the community together, its a great place to meet new people, and have a conversation. Lastly, Its important to mention that they now accept plastic, which was my only complaint in the past. I full heartedly recommend the Green Line, I will be there weekly as long as I am a Philadelphian.

Not only does this coffee shop have the (dubious) honor of being the closest coffee shop to my home, but it also is a truly wonderful little spot.  I love the fact that there is so much outdoor seating.  I also love the atmosphere; it's peaceful in here, which makes it a great place to get a little work done.  Like the other Green Line cafes, the coffee is great, the food is yummy, and the tea is amazing.  Not to mention, the staff is so downright pleasant that even before you take your first sip of coffee in the morning, you're already smiling!

Dear favorite barista (hey girl).
Thank you for waking me up, laughing at my terrible jokes, and tolerating me.
You are the very best.
Brooke
Green Line is a cool little place tucked away in Powelton.  It's good if you want to work and have coffee on hand.  The barista is really personable and the coffee isn't half bad.

Green Line is one of my favorite places to get coffee. The quality of the coffee is excellent, and they have the most amazing cherry apple walnut bagels. Their other snacks and bottled beverage selection is very good as well, and they also have a great selection of tea. I like that the space is comfortable and pleasant, the staff is friendly, and I have always been able to find a place to sit. I've spent a fair amount of time using the free wifi, which is very much appreciated. The seats by the window are a lovely place to enjoy the scenery and people watch. Highly recommended if you're looking for coffee and wifi near Drexel.

Summary: Decent place, okay food, okay coffee

I'm rather picky about my coffee (aka I can be a coffee snob), and when you're opening a cafe, you should make sure that you have good coffee. Green Line in Powelton Village is a block from my apartment, and they're probably just short of the mark for what my definition of decent coffee is. Not by much, though.

It's convenient and close by, but is in a relatively 'interesting' area. Powelton Village isn't known to be too dangerous, but do note that there have been two armed robberies at this very location in the last 6 weeks (same guy, who's been caught now). Not that this is by any means the fault of the cafe, but just be aware of the area that you are in, and always make sure you don't take any unnecessary risks (general advice for life in Philadelphia, or in any major city, for that matter).

If they lengthen their hours a bit (they close VERY early), they might be able to catch more of us on the way home from work and/or school, and might become a more appealing place for me to sit down and do my work at.

Tip: the baristas are really nice, and can customize your drink to how you want it. Don't be shy, just ask!

Cafe Loftus is one of the only non-Starbucks coffeeshops for what seems like miles around.  It's got a trendy/loftlike feel to it, spacious, airy, all of those adjectives found in ads for loft rentals.  The coffee was decently strong and the chai was very good.  I was addicted to iced-chai in this summer and when I was going to class at Temple Center City, it was the only place I could go and comfortably spend my hard earned dollars and know they weren't going to the corporate coffee ho.

Great little coffee shop and very close to my new home! It seems the crowd here consists of mostly students which makes sense because of the location. The staff is friendly enough and the iced coffee is delicious! If I had to have one complaint or suggestion it would be that they close pretty early, I believe it is 6pm on weekdays. Also I wish they had some kind of customer appreciation card, buy 10 cups of coffee get one free??? pretty please :o)

This place is great!! 

The drinks are awesome. I'm both sad that it's just outside where most Penn students go (because they don't get even more business and money from that demographic), but also glad because it makes Green Line Powelton even easier for me to enjoy! (selfish, I know...) 

Green Line Powelton - there are so many reasons to love you!! 

Drinks = A+
Service = A++
Price = A (you pay a fair price for what you get!)

My only wish - that they would take credit cards! 

p.s. - They also sell yummy Route 11 chips!
Great vegan options. Check it out. Kids love the eats as well (nonvegan)

Cosy enviroment, cool staff, great art.  The drinks aren't great, probably a little overpriced, but the environment is chill, and the music isn't played too loud, so its a good place to read, study, or have a conversation.
Nice place with friendly staff. Warm environment and good food.

business.full_address:
7150 Baltimore Ave
College Park, MD 20740
business.name: Plato's Diner

reviews.text:
If you're trekking to IKEA in College Park for a day's worth of shopping, I highly recommend a pre-game meal at Plato's Diner.

The diner is hard to miss. It's a standalone restaurant nestled next to Quality Inn. You'll see some hungover students stumbling as they walk out the door (not really, but I wouldn't be surprised if that happens every Sunday morning).

Yes, Curtis and I went to Plato's on Sunday morning. While we expected the diner to be absolute chaos, we were seated immediately at a booth (with cute handpainted murals on the walls). The restaurant isn't pseudo-retro like Silver Diner, but not minimally furnished and soulless like IHOP. 

The menu selection is not unlike other diners'. You have breakfast items available all day, as well as lunch and dinner options. Really, who orders Prime Rib at a diner?

Speaking of meat, I was more than pleasantly surprised to find VEGETARIAN SAUSAGES on the menu! I have never been to a restaurant that offers that for breakfast! Sure, it costs like $2.89 extra, but I still ordered them on my breakfast sandwich. Yummy.

A minor plus is that Plato's doesn't offer two different sizes for juice drinks. I normally order a small tomato or orange juice because I'm cheap like that. (Though if I'm at a fast food joint , I am willing to upgrade for a few cents if the cashier asks, but they don't do that anymore. That saves a few calories.)

Plato's Diner is nothing to wildly rave about, it is an establishment in College Park among locals and college students. The prices are reasonable, the servers are friendly enough, and they offer freakin' vegetarian sausages.

Plato's Diner is one of the best diners in the DC metro area.  Having said this, keep in mind DC doesn't have the best diner selection.  Plato's does have a huge selection and a few vegetarian options.

Both of my visits have been positive.  I have tried the Baked Vegetarian Moussaka and the Greek Lentil Soup.  The Moussaka was excellent, a great treat for us vegetarians.  The Lentil Soup was ok, not much better than what you could get out of a can, but hearty nonetheless.  

The coffee at Plato's is standard, nothing special.  The service is good (though the waiters are inexperienced and screw up orders on occasion without making amends - ergo (pun intended) the customer pays for the waiter's mistake).

My companion, on both occasions, enjoyed his meal.

This is a good DC Metro Dinner, a place to get a simple meal when other places are closed.

what can I say about this place. It's my shameful destination after a night of heavy drinking to the point where your taste buds cannot distinguish meatloaf from souvlaki. And that's also the only time you should go. 

Typical diner food, horrible service most of the time, but HUGE servings for the price. Don't get the meatloaf special. Meatloaf used to be one of my favorite foods (i know right), but somehow, they always get it wrong. 

Stick with the burgers, the Hellenic Delight is their only redeeming note.

Definitely one of the places to go when you wanted comfort food that wouldn't kill your budget.  We'd come for milkshakes and breakfast.  For breakfast, I liked getting the spinach and feta omelet.  Mmmm.  Definitely yummy.  The service isn't the best, but it's pretty good considering how it's almost always packed in there.

Plato once said "A hero is born among a hundred, a wise man is found among a thousand, but an accomplished one might not be found even among a hundred thousand men."

THEN HE OPENED UP HIS OWN DINER!

Plato's is has hosted parts of many classic nights in my College Park life. The menu never ends and the food is so standard that you'll forget you're eating. What you're left with is a classic time with friends and a full stomach. 

I love brinner (breakfast for dinner). Plato's ROCKS it with their pancakes. Honestly it could be far better but whose counting that late at night. Bacon strips and bacon strips and bacon strips....GREAT BACON.

You pay on your way out, and they are GREAT about individual people paying for individual things on the check. Some diners can't seem to handle this concept, but Plato's thrives on it.

They have some nice desserts on rotation (or at least they look nice), and any variation of their chocolate cake seems like a good bet.

Occasionally they aren't up to the challenge of seating enormous groups, but when they are we've squeezed about 12 people at a table.

Plato believed that "a good decision is based on knowledge and not on numbers." Well when you come to his diner, you'll find his knowledgeable staff eclipse any price you might be paying - which is never very high.

Still the same nostalgic feeling. Was just here last week, with who? You guessed it...my mommy :) And what did I have? You guessed it. Good o' BLT on wheat. I know...I am so boring, oh well, can't teach an old dog new tricks :)

My favorite, under-the-radar restaurant in PG County.
Not many students know about Plato's, so let me provide some wisdom...
The strawberry shortcake is a sweet eat, as well as their amazing falafel!
Only the co-op in stamp has better falafel in College Park.
They serve very tasty chicken sandwiches and hamburgers.
The quesadillas are tasty, too.
I would avoid some of the pricier menu items (such as the steak + pasta dishes) because the best items here are typically the ones people order more often i.e. the cheaper options for college students.
I give this establishment my highest recommendation.

Plato's is a middle-of-the-road type of diner but it seems that they are trying to go a little bit above and beyond.

I stopped for dinner here (because it was the highest rated thing I could find on Yelp in town that was still open around 11PM).  I was in College Park on business for just a couple of days.

The waiter was a young guy (college student) who was very low-key but dind't make any mistakes and did come to refill my water and got my order right, so no complaints there.

I got the lamb sliders on special; which were made with fresh ingredients (roma tomatoes, red onion) even though it was late at night.  It came with fries but my waiter had no problem when I asked for them to be Hobo fries (brown gravy and cheese on top... generally called 'disco fries' in most diners in the Northeast).  I wasn't enamored with the lamb sliders but the fresh ingredients and good presentation show that Plato's is trying a little harder than your average diner.  Would definitely get those Hobo Fries again!

Have been coming to Platos for several years; it's not fancy but it's good solid diner food.  Most of the time I order the dolmades (stuffed grapevine leaves); they're always fresh and taste great, with a nice side of Tzatsiki sauce and wonderful warm pita bread.  I've also had their omlets which are very good. Service has always been excellent, at least in my experience.  I love going to restaurants that are NOT part of national chains, where you can get something different once and a while, and Platos has something for everyones' taste.

I'd give it 2 & 1/2 stars if I could. I only get in there once or twice a year while attending an event in the area. No real complaints, except the place itself seems a bit dirty. Food has always been good and plentiful. Service is quick and efficient not overly friendly but no problems. They get you in and out with no issues (at least in my experiences). Weekends can get a bit crazy. Many employees and most, if not all, customers at UM students. It is a OK place if you are in the area but not worth a special trip.

I liked this place a lot back in my not so long ago UMD days. For a diner, it had such a vast selection (including a beer and wine menu? what!). I recall getting an omelet that had spinach and feta cheese that was always solid. Their fries were always good. Also, the vegetarian sausage was awesome and welcome in a town with little to no vegetarian options. The milkshakes and malts were notably awesome. The service was generally solid. 3 stars because of their annoying conservatism on separate checks and also I thought it was a little overpriced for a diner. But whatever, came here a lot and dug it. I miss it...a little.

I only stopped by because Marathon's Deli was closed for the day and I was craving a Souvlaki...so I checked Yelp and this was the next best thing. I was sad that they only had a chicken version but when I tasted it...it was pretty darn good for a diner!! I can't review the cheesecake slice that I ordered because I forgot it in my car and well lol..ooops!

I am a fan of the diner concept, but not of most diners. Plato's is a rare exception which I will gladly eat when I am in College Park.

Mix 'n match traditional diner food with the Mediterranean menu.  It might not be the best Greek food ever, but its pretty darn good for a diner!   Mmm, spanakopita with a chocolate milkshake and fries...

After getting of at work at 12-1, there is only a number of places open.  One is Platos.  Coming to CP will entail a number of drunk individuals along with the staff that has to deal with them.  The food overall is ok.  I usually go with the chicken parm sand.

HOLY SHIT AVOID THE DESSERT. I almost forgot that.  They dress it up in all sorts of stupid ways, and somehow it tastes old and stale.

Every now and again you get to see some poor kid throw up.

Greasy, sloppy, wonderfully tasty diner food. The decor is like a Silver Diner that let itself go, but that broken-in feeling is what makes it feel cozy, right?

Service has always been good, food has always been great, and I think menu is well-priced.

It's right down the road from the University of Maryland, and with 24 hour service on Fridays and Saturdays, there's always going to be groups and couples of University students there on the weekends.

Even now if I find myself in the area, I'm apt to swing on into Plato's. Sure as heck beats the Applebee's up the road.

I'm addicted to this place.Everytime my husband asks the magic question,"What do you want to eat?"...the answer is always Platos.Everything here is delicious...especially the shrimp and chicken alfredo and if you're anti-cow like him...I suggest the spinach and basil ziti..which comes with a soup and salad.The foods' reasonable and the service is beyond enthusiastically good.
I have trouble finding good cake anywhere. But this place fed me a great piece of German chocolate. Hooray.

This place is a great choice for us for breakfast because of their vegetarian/low fat options.  The first time we went I got fried egg whites, veggie sausage and toast for around $7.  Today I got a delicious Athenian omelet which had spinach, feta, onion and Greek spices.  It came with wheat toast and was a tad more expensive at $10.  We love coming here with the kids, its a perfect place to relax, enjoy a meal and read the paper.  highly endorse!

Been here 2 or 3 times already. Went this past Saturday, so I thought I would write a review.

I had some friends over for a night on the town and we woke up the next morning needing some nourishment to help our physical condition. Plato's Diner was the closest place to walk to, so what the hay.

I always come to this place expecting good diner/breakfast food, but compared to other diners I've been to, Plato's is certainly lacking. The portions are not very big for the price you pay. My Huevos Mexicano wrap was pretty small and with a side of chips thrown on a plate (not much effort there). What am I supposed to do with tortilla chips with no salsa? I expect more for my +$7. I was definitely still very hungry after finishing. Also, my friend's home fries were orange for some reason and didn't taste good and her sausage links weren't cooked very well.

The only good looking item among my friends' dishes was a california chicken sandwich with guacamole that looked very delicious. Perhaps they do lunch/dinner well but not breakfast. I do not recommend this place for breakfast food. You're better off going to the College Park Diner. It's possible that some of the dishes that I haven't tried yet are worth getting, but I haven't found a good dish yet.

Plato's Diner became a staple in our diet when we were desperate (and broke) undergraduates at the University of Maryland over a decade ago.  When you wanted decent food after midnight (but before sunrise) in College Park... Plato's was among the only options.  And it probably wouldn't kill you.  

The diner has changed hands a few times over the last ten years, and undergone a series of changes that are wholly for the better.  It's cleaned up a lot, and been decorated with murals of Greece, gods, statuary, mythology, etc.  It's still a bit tattered (and sometimes we are seated in the booth with the torn seats and the missing light), but it's good for four things - breakfast, Greek food, burgers, and dessert.  If you're contemplating something on the menu that doesn't fall into those categories, don't do it.  Save yourself the heartache (and heartburn).

Breakfast is standard diner fare.  They have homefries instead of hashbrowns.  Omelettes are huge, and their pancakes have that fluffy texture that I can never duplicate at home.  The Greek menu is excellent, and they offer a number of special Greek dishes every Thursday.  I love their spanakopita and the "vegetarian delight" salad (with falafel).  They do good burgers and fries (seasoned with Old Bay).  And like any respectable diner, they have a wide selection of shakes, pies, cakes, and other desserts.  Oh, and if you want an appetizer - try the hobo fries!  French fries with melted cheese and gravy, sure to clog your arteries as they worm their way into your heart.

Ignore the blue plate specials and never order the pasta.  Don't expect anything fancy on their beer and wine menu.  But if you stick to the staples, you won't be disappointed.

Two years ago this place was one of my favorites but I don't know what happened to it! 

This weekend I had one of the most traumatizing dining experience eating with a group of friends :( so be prepared this review might be a little melodramatic but it  is my own personal therapy to get over this traumatic experience. 

The service was just so HORRIBLE! I am usually very understanding with servers cause let's face it their job usually means dealing with really crappy mean people and I don't want to be one of them. But if you're a horrible waitress then I have no sympathy! 

First off after we were seated and no one came to wait our table. After 10minutes of waiting we had to ask if someone was going to serve us. After we asked the waitress brought us our water and said she would be back to take our order. After another 20 MINUTES, we still had no one come to take our order!  We went to the manager  to tell them no one has come to take our order and its been over a 30minute wait and instead of apologizing they insisted we were wrong and tried to argue with us!  Hello, we knew how long we were waiting we were looking at the big clock you had us seated right near the whole time we were waiting! 

Anyways, we tried to put that past us and just have a good time....but that would not be possible as I look back now. We ordered our food and they said it would take 20 minutes to cook.  Yippy...(Even though usually the food comes out much faster than that! ) 
Exactly twenty minutes later we got our food. By this time people that were seated after us had already eaten, paid and left.. -_- 
 
My friends asked for hot sauce and mayo to eat with his burger and it didn't end up coming out after 5minutes and he was just too hungry to argue or wait so just ate it without. She finally brought the hot sauce and still forgot the mayo. She remembered she forgot though.. (I'll give her points for that?..) but his food was gone so it didn't matter. 

We then wanted some coffee and cake so we ordered some. I wanted a tuxedo cheese cake which I saw in the glass case in the front no more than 5 minutes earlier because I got up to see what they had. When I ordered it, she said that they didn't have it.. (even though I physically saw it) and argued with me about what it was called. I was like whatever the cake is called I want "this cake"... and ended up describing exactly what the cake I wanted looked like and told her to bring that one. She ends up bringing out a cake that looks absolutely nothing like I wanted.... surprise surprise... and I was just too tired to fight it so I ate it, and it was dry and yucky. 

She brought out our cakes but no coffee, and we just thought she forgot. After we finished our cakes she said the grounds got in the coffee and they are making another batch. (How do they mess up coffee making?) My friends said to scratch the decaf coffee cause he ordered it to drink with his cake but she decided to argue with us more saying since she put it on the check we might as well wait, and we had to force her to take it off our check. After a 2 and a half hour meal ( which mostly consisted of waiting) I don't think we wanted to wait anymore lady! 

Anyways we were finally out of our dining hell and I can proudly say  we survived without developing any anger issues and I still have faith in humanity even though she was testing me that night. You know some people have sour attitudes but  you can't let that bring you down in life. 

I now will be avoiding Platos and I want to save you all from what I had to experience so you all can maintain your positive attitudes and personal happiness.
Breakfast anytime of day. Great portions! Fries with cheese and gravy are popular. Greek food is awesome! Omelettes are awesome! Services is great - Desserts are fresh and beautiful!

My parents and I ended up eating breakfast here one morning since it is located so close to my house.  I was pleasantly surprised by how tasty the food was.  Standard diner fare but with great flavor.  

Recently we all went to Plato's Diner for dinner and it was wonderful!  My father got a crabcake that was awesome.  (And that is saying a lot because I am a crab cake snob)  Everything was incredibly tasty.  I had the Chicken Parmesan and it was the best I've had.  Plus, the portion was huge and I had enough for lunch the next day.  

The decor is a bit dated but definitely not the worst I have ever seen.  The staff all seem really friendly and very attentive. 

Now that I have deemed this place a winner, I will make it my mission to become a regular and have everyone yell out my name when I enter, Cheers style.  :-)
Delicious!

On a trip back east recently, I was excited to have the chance to eat at Plato's again -  it's been around since the early/mid-90's (?), and will almost never let you down.  A quintessential diner, they serve standard diner food, with a slight emphasis on Greek dishes.  I've always enjoyed their falafel, and I recently had the Athenian omelet which was incredible!  The place is showing its age a little and the bathrooms could use some help,  but the food and service at Plato's are always terrific.

I've been going to this diner with some people in my orchestra after rehearsals and so far, my experience here has been alright. Service has been pretty good, even with our group of 15-20 people.
