The food came out together warm, but not hot (I suspect our food was set aside so the chefs could make the food for the rest of my group...understandable).

Their food hasn't been something to rave out. They are okay but not fantastic. As some reviewers have said, you won't be amazed by the food, but they are decent and WILL fill you up. They give you a really generous portion, even the salads. I usually gobble down my entire salad dishes, but here, I couldn't finish half because they gave me so much!

All in all, while the service is good, the food isn't something to be impressed about. If you just want something to fill you up (and I really mean FILL you up) then come here. But if you're looking for quality food, then go someplace else. Seriously, this is a diner. You can't expect TOO much from a diner, right?

It's often been said that the only good thing to come out of Maryland is an empty hearse. I was reminded of this bon mot while visiting friends in College Park this Sunday. Being in the mood for gyros, I hit Yelp and saw that a joint called Gyromania was selling them, and with a name like that, how could I lose? I was in Maryland. That's how I could lose. Of course, like most things in Maryland on Sunday, it was closed. This has been a longstanding tradition in Maryland that pre-dates Chik fil A. Apparently, you'd have to be insane to want to eat at a restaurant or buy liquor on Sunday. You should really be attending your church (or "synagogue"), not paying to have someone give you food. No matter. You're in a college town and college kids have no idea how to feed themselves. They'll subsist off Lean Cuisines, cold pizza, and beercan ashtrays for months on end. Surely there's something open peddling gyros.

Back on Route 1, I remembered that Marathon Deli sold some excellent gyros back in the day. They may today, but I'll never know, because it too was closed. So now we're in third-tier gyro territory, which found me at Plato's Diner. Now, you'd figure with a name like that, at least they'd have decent Greek food, but remember: we're in Maryland. When I went to the University of Maryland in the Pleistecene Era, this place used to be a Howard Johnsons serving the typical HoJos meals: meatloaf, burgers, clam strips. A hotel in back ensured the fryers were running on all eight cylinders and the staff could handle a few diner basics. At some point, it became one of those chrome-plated retro diner joints that manage to combine the worst elements of chain dining and kitsch. I put in a carry out order for gyros and fries ($8.50). About ten minutes later, I was given a styrofoam box. At this point, it goes downhill. 

In a nanny state like Maryland, you'd figure they'd have some state-wide requirement that gyros actually resembled gyros instead of grilled bologna strips embedded with bits of burnt ca-ca. Yes, they've gone the route of every other place that doesn't want the financial and training responsibility of actually owning a gyro spit. What passes for gyros here are the Sysco cryovac zero-prep gyro "product" that's infecting the once noble tradition of Greek gyros. This stuff resembles gyros in the same way that Hitler resembles a human being. Truly horrible in that "I can't believe I'm eating greasy burnt bologna embedded with bits of ca-ca, but I'm f**king starving" sort of way. Snappy service, though, and the cashier was nice enough to give us a free refill on our Coke while we were waiting. The fries were also nice and crisp and not those execrable "coated" fries. So if good service and fries are more important that edible gyros, I'm sure you could have a nice time at Plato's Diner having breakfast or staring at the linoleum. But until Maryland enters the 20th Century and starts repealing their blue laws, I'll steer clear of the gyros at this joint.

This is a great place to stop by and get some decent diner food, which is always delicious at odd hours of the night during the weekend. They also have nice breakfast specials in the morning which can save you some $$$. 

The food quality is good, but nothing special - it's still diner food. I think the Hobo Fries are the best thing on the menu (french fries covered in melted cheese and gravy). There's nothing like it when you have the late night munchies! I would also recommend the Plato Omelette.

Service is always pleasant and accommodating.

If you're in College Park, and you have the craving for some diner-style food, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend stopping by Plato's.

Platos is a solid diner with a very extensive menu. Portions are large on most of the entrees and the food is tasty. I am a big fan of the sliders and the hobo fries (which is kinda sorta poutine but with mozzarella instead of cheese curds). This is my go to diner.

If I didn't have a heart condition that only got discovered in the autumn of 2010, I'd give these guys four stars. My wife & I found this place when we were still engaged. We've gone here for breakfast, lunch, dinner, & when we had the late-night munchies. These days, their breakfasts are easier on my diet than the lunch/dinner options, but I haven't found a clunker on their bill of fare as far as taste goes.

Pretty much amazing. I've never been disappointed with the service, but you do sort of have to know of a few things to avoid on the menu. this isn't the sort of diner you should go to for any sort of pasta. That also goes for their beef burgundy (beef and noodles with a burgundy wine sauce and mushrooms).

Instead, come here for the Greek food. Even the Greek burger is delicious. They also have something like a Greek burger but with steak tips that was to die for. The stuffed grape leaves were okay. they left a little to be desired but are still quite delicious. The gyros are also pretty good.

They have this one burger... I forget the name of it but it's essentially a cheeseburger with swiss cheese, barbecue sauce, and i recommend getting a side of onion rings to put on top of the burger. It's to die for. 

this is also really the only true 24 hour establishment in College Park which makes it ideal for a truly late night dinner. You want to celebrate studying hard? A 4AM dinner is in order. did you n your significant other just finish a bit of playtime? forget a smoke and a nap, head to Plato's! it's good for any situation.

Most people I know love going here and enjoying breakfast any time of the day. It is delicious. Enjoy!

The portions are enormous, the service is fast, and the prices are cheap! What's not to like?

Well, the frisbee size pancakes look delicious but are actually kind of dry and tasteless. They definitely don't have the melt in your mouth texture of IHOP buttermilk pancakes. The home fries are bland and hash browns aren't even on the menu.

The French Terp is the reason I love to come here for breakfast. The challah french toast is awesome and you get 4 giant pieces. But wait, there's more! You also get 2 eggs, 2 bacon strips, and 2 sausage links. I usually skip sausage but these aren't those pansy sausage links all other diners serve. No, these sausage links are nearly the size of hot dogs! Did I mention this huge 5 million calorie meal is only $9? In the words of my favorite Italian American philosopher, that's a situation!

This review is long overdue.  I used to really like this place.  I love diners because the great range of food they offer and the overall ambiance of the place that makes me feel like I could plop down a deck of cards while waiting for my food.  Plato's has a very tasty Red Hot and Blue burger that I am absolutely in love with.  However, almost a year ago, my experience there was more than ruined.  I've had some bad experiences here before, but continued to go because I know that if I came back a different day, things would be different.  One fateful (very slow) night, my party of four accidentally turned into a party of five.  Our waiter was fantastic.  He KNEW that our additional person came from a table of people that had already been there.  We just so happened to bump into a dear friend of ours that decided to join us.  Only four people ate...and we actually only needed to split the bill 3 ways.  The waiter did this for us without any problems.  However, the host was a complete jerk.  Like...made a big deal and made us feel like idiots type of complete jerk.  So I wrote a complaint...something I've never done before.  The owner was very apologetic, sent us a $50 gift certificate so that we'd come back.  We eventually went back and I thought all was well.  However, a close friend of mine who works in this sort of business was friends with this host.  The host was very ungrateful and said he hated me and my group.  He got into a lot of trouble for be unpleasant, which I think he deserved.  He all but actually said we'd be sorry if we came back there when we was speaking with my friend.  Sounds like a threat to me.  I will NEVER go back here EVER EVER EVER again.  Which is a shame, because the food is great.  Not so long as people can't act like adults instead of laughing at a group of people that walk in to sit down in your restaurant to help pay YOUR salary.  Even if he decided to man up and be real about the whole thing, I'd still never go back here.

DC is seriously lacking in good diners. I was hoping that humble college park would offer me something better, being somewhat of a college town. I had high hopes for this place. My experience with Greek diners was usually good. I was hoping to find a gyro omelette, unfortunately my search yielded no such results. Our server seemed like he hated his job, so instead of being a jerk and ordering off menu (gyro omelette), I made the mistake of ordering the mile high meatloaf sandwich. 

Where do I even begin, in describing my disappointment? The first thing I noticed about the sandwich was the gravy. The menu described it as being a "BBQ gravy". This should have been a red flag, but no... my curiousity delved me deeper into troublesome territory. The BBQ gravy was odd. It was as if they took BBQ sauce, and added powdered gravy mix to it, only causing it to further coagulate, and make what could only be described as a "glop" of semi-liquid, semi-solid amorphous blob of disappointment. This was of course, only the start of the long list of disappointing features of the dish.

Beneath the façade of gravycue sauce was meatloaf atop toast, topped with mashed potatoes. The portion was huge, and the "mile-high" moniker is rightly so. My disappointment was also mile-high as I don't like leaving food on my plate, so I felt I had to power through this meal just so I could "man-up" in front of my male compatriots. The mashed potatoes were odd. They weren't box, but they DEFINITELY weren't freshly made either. Maybe they just mixed the dry flakes in with laundry detergent powder, or SOMETHING. The mashers were off. But that wasn't even the bad part. 

The meatloaf....good LAWD the meatloaf was just not good. Okay okay, I realize that in signing up to eat meatloaf, I'm not allowed to complain, just as when your mom/grandma makes meatloaf, you don't complain you just eat it. Well, the thing is, I actually like, maybe possibly even love meatloaf. But this meatloaf they gave me was the problem child that you're just trying to find room in your heart to love, but just can't. The meatloaf was lacking in flavor, and the little flavor it did have was not a very good one. I gotta give it to them, it's hard to have fresh meatloaf on hand, when you have such a huge menu. I doubt ANYONE ever orders it, so when I made the mistake of doing so, I'm sure the short-order cook begrudgingly went into the back freezer and pulled out some meatloaf that probably expired in 2000, and tried to put some "life back into it" by dousing it in a hot fudge-like consistency "BBQ gravy" sauce. 

Lessons learned - Just don't order something crazy like this. Sure, it's plato's diner, sure it's late at night and you may have been drinking, and the prospect of sopping up all that alcohol with delicious meatloaf sounds tempting, but in case you just skimmed my review to get to this point, THE MEATLOAF IS JUST PLAIN AWFUL. 

My friends also got the club sandwich (half decent), and the Spanikopita. The Spanikopita was also disappointing. Instead of being put inside of flaky phyllo dough, it was more like if they put it in a phyllo dough burrito, with non-flaky dough, some weird cheese mixture that may have had traces of feta, but more/so some other mysterious cheese that tasted nowhere near as good, and the spinach... The spinach was frozen, not properly thawed, and most importantly not properly seasoned. Spinach needs a good liberal dousing of salt to taste right, especially frozen spinach, and this was nowhere near as good. Add on top of that my friend felt sick later. 

OKAY! I hate writing scathing reviews, and I know it's hard to operate a restaurant, especially one that operates 24-hours a day, and has actually reasonable (possibly even affordable) prices. Two stars to this place, because the service wasn't really that bad, everyone else around our table seemed to enjoy their food, which was then when I realized that they had all gotten breakfast food. It's probably the way to go when eating here, and even though I'll never come back, if you do find yourself at Plato's diner, just order the breakfast already.

I always get Greek food here.  It's surprisingly good for a diner, and who can argue with fresh baked pitas and homemade tzatziki?  And their banana cream pie with confetti sprinkles reminds me of church pot luck.

Plato's is the only establishment I continually return to in College Park. When I first moved here, I had romantic notions of being near a college town, but at 40,000 students, UM cannot even support one lousy independent bookstore. What a disgrace! 

The food at Plato's in bland, reliable comfort food. This atmosphere does not have a hint of irony, and the menu is without pretensions. I have never had bad service here and have always been able to get a booth without a wait. There are newspapers such as the Onion and post available. 

Today, I was waited on by Karen. She was perfect and made me feel like I was in a 5 star restaurant rather than a diner. I am guessing that many of the waitstaff here are students. They tend to be very refined. 

I got the vegetarian moussaka, as usual. The first time I ordered it, I was disappointed because it didn't even come with a side salad, but it turns out that this dish is so rich and heavy that you won't want to eat anything else. But that didn't stop me from ordering a slice of blueberry pie, served hot with a scoop of low fat vanilla ice cream, as if that could make up for all of the bechamel sauce from the moussaka! 

Plato's always has a wide assortment of pies and cakes that are made on the premises. They are for the most part, impressive looking but uninspiring when it comes to taste. However, the blueberry pie was not bad at all.

I like this place not so much for the quality of the food, but because I know I will have a relaxing, hassle-free experience. There is plenty of free parking available, which is not the case for most places in College Park.

It's fine, but not great.  The prices are low but the quality matches the price.   Comfort food, but nothing you'll remember a few days from now.  It's a good place for college kids or families with small children.

Haven't eaten yet, but the manager just bitched out a member of our large, yet polite crowd, for asking if it was possible to charge her phone. Beginning to think this place is the "before" on an episode of Restaurant Impossible. Parties of twelve bring lots of revenue - they, like all guests, should be treated with respect. It is just good business.

Ahh, Plato's. Once upon a time this place was a Howard Johnson's, I think. Since then it's one of the few businesses that's actually stood the test of time in College Park. I think every student at UMCP has a friend who worked at Plato's for 2 days. The "Now Hiring" sign never seems to go down, but they've stayed in business.

Silver Diner ain't got nothin' on Plato's. SD is overpriced and has a limited menu--Plato's has pretty reasonable prices and a pretty diverse menu plus daily specials. I usually stick to the omelets, burgers and gyros, but once I ventured to order a salmon dinner with soup, salad and vegetable. Everything was actually really great, and the spanakorizo (spinach & rice) is the way to go if you're ordering a vegetable. It's also a good place to go just for a cup of coffee and a slice of pie.

Not all the food on the menu is spectacular, but hey, it's a diner and it's the only place around that's open 24 hours on the weekends. The service is usually friendly and quick. In the time I've been going there they've upgraded the decor a couple times--not sure why they put a mural of the Death of Socrates on the wall, but that's part of the enigmatic charm of the place.

I don't understand how I managed to go so long without visiting Plato's Diner (along with most of the establishments along route 1).

We came in on Sunday around 3 PM, so there weren't many people in the restaurant. Our party of 5 was seated very quickly near front.

We did have to wait quite a while for our food, but I think that's because my boyfriend ordered a 16 oz. medium well T-bone steak and all of our food was coming out together, so we all had to wait. In the meantime, we danced to the retro music softly playing overhead. (Nothing says Sunday like grooving to "I Will Survive"!) 

I ordered the Terp - 2 pancakes, 2 eggs, 2 strips of bacon, 2 sausages, and I got them with homefries for a little extra. It was a lot of food. I was not expecting my food to come out on more than 1 plate. (I get overwhelmed when my food is spread out over more than 1 plate XD)
Pancakes....... were dry. Really big and fluffy but kind of dry. I only got 2 little syrup packages and I wanted to DRENCH these flapjacks in syrup to make up for their dryness. But otherwise, totally fine. Very big and came with a little dish of butter that I didn't need but appreciated.
They accidentally messed up my eggs order and gave me over-easy when I was craving scrambled, so they just brought out a plate of scrambled eggs for me. (For those folks keeping track at home, I now had my meal spread out over 3 different plates. Omai.) I really appreciated that, although I feel bad because I definitely could not eat that many eggs.
Homefries were cut pretty large. Other than that, I don't have anything else to really say about them.

My meal was overwhelming with the amount of food I received. I underestimated their portion sizes and overestimated how hungry I was.

My friends seemed to enjoy their meals. They hid butter underneath the toast, so that was a bit strange, plus it led to completely melted butter, but other than that, I heard no real complaints. One of my friends got a chocolate milkshake that looks absolutely divine.

Service kind of confused me... Our server would swing by with the water pitcher kind of anxiously trying to see if any of us needed water. None of us did, but I felt rather nervous for her. Then when I did need water, she didn't seem to pick up on me lifting my near-empty glass. A bit of a gripe for how long our food took, but again, boyfriend's fault for getting a steak medium well. (ALTHOUGH. There was a LOT of red for a steak that was supposed to be medium well...) 

I will definitely be back with either a bigger appetite or for a more reasonably-sized order!

I really like this place.  The trick is to get there when it's not packed with people.  

My usual routine is to stop by mid-morning for breakfast.  I usually order the same thing and it is uniformly good.  The waitresses are friendly, the service is fast and the prices are reasonable.

I've met friends at Plato's for dinner a couple of times and I've always been pleased. If anything, the portions are too generous.

A great diner experience near the University of MD but not for students only!

The food was average, reasonably priced, portion was generous and the service was fast. 

I had the gyro platter and was not impressed. The gyro was good but nothing exceptional and the dolmas had minimal flavor. The Greek salad comes along with the platt

Holy cow the portions are huge.

I had a side of chicken. That sounds like a lot-and it is-but it also included gravy, stuffing, a baked potato, beans, a salad...it was intense. I had an iced tea and water to help me breathe.

It's well worth the money.

Otherwise, yet another Maryland establishment with mediocre service. But their food wins so hard. But their service is so mediocre! I hope it gets better next time. Definitely on the border of 3-4 stars. The iced tea was poor. They offer desserts. Lots of menu items.
Above-average diner food -- certainly better than any of the other diners in the area (and *much* better than the Applebee's half a block away).

Good solid place. Had cup of chili which was very good. Not 80% beans like some places. Red, hot bleu burger was good as well. Fries were fair. This is in good location right next to Quality inn so I can stay next door and have place to eat late night!

I don't think I've ever had a bad meal here, although not all of them have been amazing. My favorites are the breakfast BLT (a BLT with a fried egg on it), the french terp (a french toast dish), the greek salad, and the hot roast beef sandwich. The hobo fries are also great.

The fat free shake deserves its own paragraph. I was skeptical when a friend suggested it on one visit, as I am generally not willing to sacrifice flavor for something healthier. However, you really don't miss the fat at ALL. I think they use fresh bananas and strawberries and it's amazing.

The only real disappointment I can remember was when I got a belgian waffle with strawberry topping. The waffle was pretty good but the strawberry topping was obviously out of a can. It was overly sweet and the strawberries were mushy. I recommend the waffle but not the topping.

The only other problem is that they won't take more than 2 credit cards per check and they don't really do separate checks. For a place in a college town, this is unusual. But as long as you go in prepare for that, you shouldn't have a problem.

Plato's Diner has everything that you would expect in a local diner - and then some.  The food is great and the well-priced menu has something for whatever mood you might be in.  You have your choice of the typical diner favorites - burgers, BLTs, chicken, pancakes, etc, or you could try some of the the Greek items on the menu to change things up a bit.  If you haven't been there before, I recommend the Roadside Sliders  (3 mini burgers that are always delicious) and a chocolate shake.
The atmosphere is great as well.  The servers are always friendly and the decor in the place will make you feel cozy and comfortable.  The last time I was in they were painting some new murals on the wall and updating some of the retro-style interior.
It's right down the street from the University of Maryland, so on game days the place is packed with students and Terp fans into the late hours of the night.  Friday and Saturday Plato's is open 24 hours and makes for a great place to extend a date after a late night movie.
Overall, it is my favorite diner and is well worth a visit if you're in the area.

Go someplace else.

The food is less than mediocre.  Still I would find myself there very infrequently.

Ah, then I met a couple of people who used to work there.  They shared what a terrible place it is to work--workers are treated  by management like they are disposable.  The stories were terrible.

Bad, overpriced food AND treats works like dirt?  Nah, I'll eat some place else.

I've never touched their dinner entrees, but their sandwiches and wraps are quite excellent. I've never been disappointed with a sandwich of theirs and its always pretty fresh even at 1am. can't go wrong with their gyros and falafels. haven't eaten one of their burgers though, however their chicken sandwiches are pretty good as well. their fries are fantastic- maybe i've been in a crappy cafeteria fry stint but they are a breath of fresh air in a sea of bad fries.
I don't typically write one-word reviews, but here it is: "Meh."

The food is gross and tasteless. I ordered some sausage links with my pancakes. The portions were huge and my first thought when I received the sausage links was: The Jungle by Upton Sinclair. The meat was suspicious. *makes shifty eyes*

The souvlaki is decent, but their pitas are pretty tough, and the gyro meat is not fresh, and that is a travesty. I'd suggest avoiding the greek plates here. The Hellenic burger is one of the best burgers I've ever eaten, flat-out, and that's pretty much what I order every time I go to a new restaurant. The fries are sort-of bland, typical diner fries, but if you get them Hobo style (with beef gravy and melted mozzarella cheese), they're vastly improved. I always order this when I go, and it's enough food that I always have to take half my burger home with me. The chocolate shakes are excellent too, but with all that food, my stomach can't always take that much stuff. The service can be just a little slow on busier nights, but it's always to an understandable degree.

The pros are that the portions are huge and they are really good about splitting checks. The round booths are cute and going on a Friday morning meant we were surrounded by old people, so it was pretty quiet and nice.

On the other hand, the omelet my friend got was sad and rubbery and apparently just wrong in many ways. 

I got the French Terp, which is french toast (small, four slices) with two slices of bacon (meh), sausage (pretty good), two eggs (sunny-side up, good), and I added homefries. The potatoes were orange but completely lacking in flavor! And I pretty much love potatoes in all forms, so I was surprised that I didn't like these. It took a good amount of salt and pepper to make them decent.

I've been to more diners than I can count and Platos is medicore- not great, not bad.  I go here quite often because it is the only diner nearby (I live within walking distance) and it is nice to get hungover [or still drunk] breakfast/lunch after heavy drinking the night before.

First off, the food is mediocre.  The breakfast options are average, and so are the lunch options.  Maybe a little overpriced, but the food is fine.  You will probably not think at any point "Holy crap this is so good," but you will leave full and content.

For a diner, the service is not very good.  It is faster than a restaurant, but slower than typical diners.  But then again, their kitchen is pretty small.  The servers vary, some are friendly... some do not smile at all, but they are all pretty attentive to your needs.  

One thing I love about Platos is that you can get orders to go.  It usually takes about 10 minutes or so depending on what you order, and you can order ahead.

Platos is not open 24/7- I dont remember the hours, but check ahead.  They close at 1 or 2am most nights, I believe.

My heart aches for Plato's.  It was my home away from crappy apartment when I was at U o' Maryland.  All diners should be Greek.  Why does that only happen in Maryland?  Now that I have moved south and "food" here means "Tex Mex", I have been unable to find a diner that serves mozzarella sticks.  They are a diner STAPLE!  Why does the state of Texas NOT understand that?  However, we do get our starch and cheese at every diner in the form of queso, but I digress.

Back to Plato's.  I have done homework here, collapsed after finals here, argued with my bf here, laughed hysterically with my best friends here (so so so many times), I had lunch here with a soaking wet friend who had just fallen in the fountain on the mall (totally didn't push him), I found out I had strep throat while having lunch here (sorry about that one guys), waited here while my truck was worked on across the street,  and I have actually eaten here for multiple meals in one day.  I love this place.  It really is home to me.  When I think about living in Maryland, I always think of Plato's.  

Also, the deserts are insane.  The giant case of bizarre butt plug looking things always makes me laugh.  I have no idea what they are, but I'm glad that they're there, and I'm sure they are delicious.

Ive been here a couple of times, with and without a large group. Service is pretty good, with the waiters being available and generally quick to satisfy. For the large groups the food came out together and hot, which is always important. 

Overall I would say the food is decent. Better than other diners in the area and in general. But still nothing to really write home about. The crab cakes are an exception, large, succulent, and full of lump crab meat with hardly any fillers. Make sure you get the broiled crab cakes, as they taste much better than the breadcrumb fried version, and are probably healthier for you.

I've been several additional times since my initial review and I would say may initial review is more of an aberration from the norm.  Service is typically efficient, not necessarily friendly, but gets the job done.

It's best to keep it simple.  My go-to is the Chicken Souvlaki Salad, a great meal with warm pita and tender chicken.  Club sandwiches are good, meatloaf is good...

Good comfort stop. Plus free parking.

My friend and I stumbled across Plato's on our way to the College Park Rita's.  I was so excited to see a Greek diner (I knew b/c of the sign outside that said a new baby Athanasios was born), and we were both hungry, so we just had to go in.  My favorite part about diners is I never know what to order.  There are always 400 things on the menu that sound delish.  This was that type of diner and I loved that!  I finally settled on the chicken souvlaki salad (and the waitress even let me get spinach salad instead of dreaded iceberg).  It was piled to the ceiling w/freshly-grilled chicken that was seasoned perfectly.  It also came with warm pita, homemade tzaziki, feta, tomatoes, kalamata olives, and cucumbers (I had them hold onions and peppers, but those come with it, too).  It was humungous.  My friend ordered the Greek chicken plate, which was HUGE.  He got the Maryland crab soup, a salad, and a vegetable with it.  The chicken already came with oven-roasted potatoes, so he got the french fries for me (I begged--it was SO worth it! They were a-MAZing).  When his plate came out, we both kind of sunk down b/c it looked a little bland, to be honest.  His soup was a bit salty, but otherwise good.  The chicken had nice flavor but was a little bit dry.  I would not recommend you order that dish, but there are certainly a million others to choose from.  If you want Greek-style chicken, stick to the souvlaki.  I want to come back to try some other stuff.  A lady across the dining room ordered the belgian waffles and they looked fantastic.  It's too bad this place is all the way in College Park, but I'll find a way to make it back there.

YUM. I came here at 4 AM after a night at the club with a group of my friends, and the service is REALLY fast. It gets crowded/very busy around this time during weekends too. Imagine this as a Silver Diner + Ihop hybrid...delicious comfort food and nicely-sized portions. Not overpriced at all... I'd say around $6 for gyros and $8 for breakfast dishes. 

Minus one star because our waiter ignored a lot of our requests, but all-in-all, this is a reliable late-night eat after a fun night out.

I love Plato's. It's fairly standard diner fare, but without the trying-to-be-retro annoyances. They have AMAZING soups. My roommate loves the hellenic burger. I'm a huge fan of their breakfast food (French Terp all the way!). When I've had their mains I've been a little underwhelmed (the pastas aren't amazing, and the moussaka had marinara sauce on it. What's up with that?). But, really, who goes to a diner for main dinner food? You go to a diner for breakfast or a burger. The fact that they also make amazing soups is just bonus. 

Oh, and their hot chocolate is not too shabby. Even though I know deep down it was probably instant, they do something to it to make it still taste better than the burnt awfulness that Starbucks tries to pass off as hot chocolate.

Average food but really great service. I don't know why I always get Greek food at these Greek diners. Maybe I think it's going to be authentic? Meh. My Souvlaki was just okay. Chicken was a little bland,tasteless so I added LOTS of tzatziki and paid $2.00 (!!!) for a side of feta. Didn't make much of a difference, unfortunately. The kids loved their burgers, though. They did look tasty and juicy. 

I'll go back, but this time for breakfast. It was amazing how attentive our young waiter was. I wish I could remember his name for a proper shot out!

The best of all the restaurants, my fav. loved it. HUGE PORTIONS, tasty. lovely, the waiters were great, the food was tasty, cheap. I paid around $ 21 plus $5 for the waitress we had, who was nice. This was the second time we went there. I had a Greek dish the first time. The second time I had a Greek omelete breakfast plus french toast. I loved the food would definitely go there again.Yummy!

One of my favorite spots. A great traditional diner that's fun and family- friendly. The menu is quite large but my favorites are the breakfast and the Greek food. Also be sure to check the daily specials page for unexpected hidden gems. Keep in mind that the portion sizes are very generous. My only disappointment has been the desserts. They look so beautiful in the case but have yet to taste as good as they look.

My husband and I ate here for the first and last time.  The food was mediocre, and soon after leaving the diner we were both sick with stomach illness.  If you're looking for diner food, the Silver Dinner in Greenbelt is a better option.  If you're looking for Greek food you have two options: the New Deal Cafe in Old Greenbelt (which recently became mostly Greek) and Marathon Deli (4429 Lehigh Rd, College Park).

Stopped in on a Saturday afternoon. The place was crowded and there was a wait (not always a bad thing, sometimes the sign of a good place) . I got the stuffed eggplant special , quite tasty. This is a solid Greek diner and would definitely go back the next time I am eating in the area.

I just like this place.
 Yes, it is kinda funky.
But so is James Brown.

They could have either opened the door for fresh cool air or turned on the A/C.   So, word to wise.... don't let thm seat you on the west side of the restaurant during warm days.... sit by the glass bricks.

If you're into big potatoes, over cooked veggies, plain food with large side salads.... then this is your place.  Two stars.... cause I'm not coming back for seconds.

I went here for a quick breakfast one morning when I was craving french toast. The french Terp was a good portion size, and the staff was super friendly. My only complaint was the abnormally large sausages that tasted weird.. Next time I go i will skip the sausage and get double bacon.

So i went here on a Saturday and just wasn't impressed. I get it, Saturday morning at a diner are busy. But that is where a diner should shine, be able to turn out a quality product to a large number of people. We are all here because we don't feel like cooking breakfast ourselves. At any rate, I had pretty good service. I ordered the platter with 2 eggs, grits, bacon, and sausage. My food took a little too long to get there, and coffee refills were hard to come by. The food was just ok, with breakfast I feel the quality of the ingredients are the benchmark. In my waiter's defense he had a section on the main floor and had to cover me and a couple who were sitting at the counter. The worst part was getting out, I actually gave up my seat at the counter so a couple could sit down while I waited to pay my check. Coming from upstate NY, i love a good Greek diner. Unfortunately, Plato's wasn't it. There are too many breakfast options in the area to warrant going back.

I like Plato's. It's not just average diner food, but also some decent Greek stuff as well as a variety of things I wouldn't normally expect on a basic diner menu. My repeat favorite is the chicken souvlaki salad, which is huge and comes with warm pita and the best tzatziki sauce I've found anywhere. Another hit for me is their disco/hobo fries. Avoid the falafel, it's dry.

It's a bit expensive for diner food, but can be worth it, depending on what you get. The hours are pretty good, 24-hours on Friday and Saturday and open until 1:00am the rest of the week. Service is fine.

business.full_address:
503 N 33rd St
Mantua
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Black Star Hardware

reviews.text: Black Star Hardware is in a convenient location with a good amount of parking available on the street. I usually stop there on my home from work driving on Spring Garden Street. I can find what I am looking for at Black Star Hardware and the service is excellent. Jantra

Relatively small selection--this is no Home Depot--but convenient, close, and friendly.

Since their recent expansion they have carried a lot more stuff, and the place looks much nicer.  They are a great place to go for simple household stuff like brooms, plungers, mousetraps, or having keys copied.  They even have a few things you wouldn't expect like bathroom fans and some tools.

That said, it's still a tiny store, and the convenience factor is often negated by the fact that they just don't have what I'm looking for.  Need some sort of rubber hosing to control your A/C's dripping?  Probably best you try elsewhere.  Looking for boards or even a few small bits of lumber?  It's hit or miss--mostly miss.  Not that there's much that they can do about it; it's a small inner-city hardware shop, they only have so much space for so much stuff.  And they are very nice about helping you find what you need.

So minus two stars for a small selection, plus one for friendliness and convenience.  I'm pretty happy with them.

business.full_address:
Reading Terminal Market
12th & Arch
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19176
business.name: Hershel's East Side Deli

reviews.text:
Hershel's has done something that only a few other places (places like Sweat Fitness for example) have managed to do to me. Hershel's has made me feel like less of a man. 

"But how can that be, Jeff? You're all man!" is what you would be saying. At least, that's what I imagine you would be saying for the sake of my fragile ego. And in response to you, kind reader, I give the following explanation:

I feel like less of a man because one sandwich from Hershel's put me in a food coma for the remainder of the day. I ate half of the sandwich, and then spent ten minutes looking at the other half while trying to figure out how I was going to tackle that corned beef behemoth. I think my brain was trying to process how I could enjoy the deliciousness that was the Corned Beef Special, while also not upchucking right after because I already felt like my diaphragm was up to my neck. So yeah, I did feel somewhat emasculated that as a man, I was letting this damn sandwich triumph over me. But after those ten minutes, and also due to the verbal abuse of my friends (various derogatory terms that are synonyms for the word "cat") I dove into the second half, and then proceeded to pass out. I remember thinking that if I was going to die, I couldn't really think of a better way of dying. "Did you hear that he died because he was overwhelmed by the awesomeness of a corned beef sandwich? Apparently there was crack in there, because he couldn't stop eating it." 

Anyway, I've wasted enough of your time, dear reader. The corned beef special was my first experience with corned beef, and I loved it. I hate coleslaw; like, genuinely, abhor with a fiery passion, that most disgusting of side dishes, and that sandwich even managed to make me rethink coleslaw. It was the messiest sandwich I've eaten, and I'm pretty sure that my intestines still haven't finished processing the meaty goodness, and I had it yesterday at 11:00 am. It was worth it.
Their Reuben is a must. Go get one asap!

I am from San Diego and travel to Philadelphia frequently. I love the Reading Market and recently discovered Hershels.  All that I can say I'd "WOW"!! I have never had a sandwich as great as this one.  Do yourself a favor and make Hershels a must when you hit Reading Market
It's a bit pricier than one dollar sign. but hands down the best pastrami sandwich i've had in philly or possibly ever. thick peppery slices. try the pastrami reuben, you wont regret it.

I worked at a deli for a year or so and was used to Pastrami from a prepackaged meat vendor. The first time I has a pastrami from here I understood what a real pastrami on rye should taste like. The sandwich is a little more then a average deli but well worth it.

Corned Beef Heaven. That's the only way to describe it. I absolutely LOVE their hot corned beef sandwiches. The owner of Hershel's has never heard the term "less is more". The sandwiches are piled HIGH with meat. So much so that I usually take half the me

follow the long line!  tons of ppl are willing to wait cuz they serve up huge portions for not so much cash.  i had the brisket w/ american cheese, the meat was tender and not overly seasoned.  good place to stop by if you're in the mood for something simple and food coma-inducing...

The Hersel's "Special" sandwich wasn't and neither was the service. The kid who took my order was too cool to be pleasant, the Mac salad tasted spoiled anid the only saving grace was the corned beef.  Simply stated the meat was sublime.  Too bad the rest of the experience was not!
The best pastrami around. Don't let the line scare you,they are very fast moving.

It's the end of the day.....a large amount of brisket is still lurking around under the heat lamps....a sweet young fellow asks what we would like to eat....we murmur... whatever's the best, and throw everything on it....I sit down to rest my weary legs....my boyfriend brings the sandwich over....i take a bite and SUDDENLY.... my brain and tongue explode with delight!  I didn't stop to notice what was on the sandwich, i was too focused upon cramming every last piece of delicious meat in my mouth.  foggy recollection begs the mention of coleslaw, russian dressing and some sort of cheese.  I was lost in a fog of food pleasure.  and really, its BS that i live so far away.  Is the reading terminal market a big enough reason to move to philly?  it's looking that way....

This place makes one of the best corned beef sandwiches I've had. Hand sliced , lean. juicy beef piled on a slice of rye or pumpernickle and slathered with mustard. Simple an superb. No ambiance and a struggle to find seating but well worth it.

So this vegertarian Yelper was really bad the other day. I was in reading terminal market with my lil sis, browsing and getting lunch. I saw the "Famous Rueben" on their menu and had a weak moment. I ordered it.

It was truly delicous, great quality pastrami, the marble rye was super choice and the saurkraute, russian dressing and and metly cheese was mouth watering.

I ordered an Ice tea too and the guy let me come back for refills.

Although it was super yummy I do have to say that it was too much meat.
Rueban-man below me liked that, but I personally didnt. I want equal flavors of the dressing, kraut, cheese and meat, and this was overwhelming with the amount of meat. Also its not cut thin like I am used to, its slabs of thick meat and massive ammounts. I took my sandwich a part and rebuilt it with the right amount of pastrami on it, and then it was perfect. After I was done (meat falling out of the sandwich with every bite) there was a pile of pastrami on my plate large enough to feed a family of 5.

lol.

but if you are a "Rueban-man" this is the place for you

Try a pastrami sandwich.

As soon as you're done with that, feel free to send me a Thank You card.

Unlike the pastrami, their bagel lox is just so-so. Theirs is one of the biggest I've had - they pile on the salmon and trimmings - but not exactly bursting with flavor. On the other hand, it's good enough to save you a trip to NYC.

Very skillful meat carving. Very wasteful food disposal. I get it. The Jewish deli that Louis XIV would have loved. The way to experience the feeling of owning a Hummer I without shelling out tens of thousands.

The sandwich was pretty good. We can probably find a better rye bread vendor. And we can probably exercise a little judicious restraint with the Russian dressing. But the meat is lean and tasty.

And they have Brown's Cel-Ray, which is just what you want when you don't want to have to share your drink with anyone.

Dear Hershel,

Let me start out by saying Thank you, in fact, a thousand thank you's.  Thank you for the quality of food you serve, thank you for the consistency, and thank you for taking pride in serving some of the best deli-style sandwiches in Philly.  

Was your pastrami cut and cured from heavenly cows?  I just can't wrap my head around it.  It's so perfect... the seasonings, the marbling/fat content, the tenderness of the meat, and the cook temperature on every hot sandwich.  I started writing this review this past Saturday and took a quick break to run over to your spot and grab another hot pastrami special (w/ Russian and Coleslaw on Marble Rye) just to gvie my taste buds a refresher.  Wow once again!  Not only was my sandwich better than last time, but every employee there is so accomodating and really works hard to keep the line moving. 

I'm so happy that you don't stop at the amazing pastrami, corned beef, and brisket you serve.  You also disperse some of the best-tasting potato salad and coleslaw from ANY deli.  I could keep going on, but instead I'll just make sure to visit again soon so I can become reacquainted with the finer things in life.


Sincerely,
-One of your most loyal customers
Brisket on Jewish Rye with mustard....Absolutely Perfect. Bliss.
Corned beef sandwich was the best I've had. Get the 1/2 sandwich it is huge.
Best pastrami sandwich i've ever had, I dont' even feel the need to try another one, I mean don't get me wrong I will, but this one totally reigns supreme, hands down!
I had the reuben, and the tons and tons of corned beef was super tender and falling apart and tasted terrific with the saurkraut.

This little stand defines what a Reuben should be. 

The corned beef is simply delicious and cooked to perfection.

I make it a point to stop by when in the area, and have turned on quite a few people to this gem of a spot. 

Service is timely, and the portions generous. 

Keep up the good work!

AMAZING!! This place made my eating experience from a fair to a great of Philly! We came to the Reading market on our last day in Philly. The only place we had time to go to was here. When had our first cheesesteak in Philly for lunch in the reading market...It was terrible. I was upset that with all the food in the place I picked such a lemon! After lunch we need to pick up food for the plane. We saw alot of people eating grilled reuben's. I asked one couple where they got and they said HERSHEL'S. So my wife and I went over and Got a pastrami reuben loaded to go.WOW! absolutely amazing! Great size for the price. The pastrami was so juicy and the bread was so fresh! I wish I ate here instead of that cheesesteak I had earlier.
What more can be said. Excellent pastrami reuben. Perfect.

The amount of meat they put on these sandwiches its amazing. I got the turkey reuben, and it was good. The turkey was moist and plentiful, and the bread was toasted to perfection. My only issue was that with that much meat, the sauerkraut and dressing got lost in the flavor shuffle. Overall it was very good.

Had a delicious Hershel's special pastrami sandwich on a break from the convention I was attending across the street. Great choice. The service was quick. The pastrami, on fresh rye bread with Russian dressing and Cole slaw were all in good proportion. The hand cut pastrami was juicy and delicious. I topped it of wit a dr. Browns cel-ray soda. All in all it was great lunch I would highly recommend.

Herschel's is a Jewish style deli inside the Reading Terminal Market.  I must say that as a David's Brisket House and Katz's Deli devotee I find their corned beef and matzo ball soup to be pretty good. The corned beef has a nice fat content and isn't overloaded on with saltpeter. And the matzo balls  are golf ball sized and have a heavy matzo taste.  Good stuff.

Is it sacrilegious to say I ate at Hershel's and just got matzo ball soup? And if that's okay to admit, how about the fact that the soup was really only so/so?

Unlike other places in the market where people are very friendly and personable... 

Here's a reenactment of my experience just yesterday at the Flying Monkey Bakery stand:

My boyfriend and I: "We'll take a butter cake, please."
Cashier (to me): "Hey weren't you here earlier?"
Me: "Well I wasn't at this stand exactly, but yes I was here in the market."
Cashier (smiles): "I thought so."

...they were more like "What'll it be? (pause) Just soup?" 

The broth of the soup was tasty but the carrots were pretty bland and the matzo balls (actually one mammoth ball) was nothing to write home about. I could see how on a really cold day sidling up to a hot bowl would hit the spot, and I would give it more stars. After all it really was my fault for not trying the pastrami sandwich, and at $5.00 for a small bowl of soup and a can of Dr. Brown's Black Cherry soda it was a cheap treat. But until next time, folks, with mediocre soup and a complete lack of the embarrassing back-and-forth about my habit of frequenting the market that I expect from cashiers everywhere... it gets a three.

ROCK ON HERSHEL'S!!! 

As a native Irish American New Yorker who grew up on Grandma's corned beef on select Sunday's...I thought...that was it.  That it couldn't get any better. I was WRONG WRONG WRONG.  

Hershel's Corned Beef Ruben was piled high with meat, perfectly touched with an appropriate amount of fixing's and an AMAZING experience. I had to stretch my mouth to put it all in, in one bite (insert joke here).  The potato salad was just enough to complement the sandwich and at $.93 - well worth it.  A friend and I split the sandwich which was a perfect later afternoon tie over before a late dinner. 

On a side note: I decided that Hershel's had nothing to do with the obnoxious Coney Island loud phone talker at the table next to us. After getting off the phone he leaned over and proceeded to dictate the meaning of life to us for the next 15 minutes.  The involvement in my yummy sandwich was a good distraction from his ignorant question "Are you guys from the Midwest?" Apparently he failed to notice my own NY accent and that of my friend  - who has an obvious non-American accent.

The Reading Terminal Market is also great for people watching!

Going to the terminal can be overwhelming with choices, especially for a first timer there.  Hershel's corned beef special is super delicious and is huge to boot.  With many options in the market, brisket or corned beef here has never disappointed.

Their reubens are phenomenal.. by far my favorite (along with Koch's Deli).  There's enough meat on the sandwich that you can make it into 3 meals.  The price is a little expensive for a sandwich, but it's worth it with the amount of food you get.

If you're in there before 11, their challah bread french toast is also really really good.  Great staff too

ended up getting a Reuben with pastrami as suggested by a bunch of other reviewers. the sandwich was really good, but ended up being a little pricey for me (10.75 after tax). overall, very good sandwich as I've never been a fan of sauerkraut or really ever tried French dressing. top notch, but you're paying for it.
the broth in their soup is tasty, but their matzoh balls are crazy dense. like can be used as a weapon dense. that said i guess it's a good value because you fill up after eating 1/4 of one...

Whoever gives this a high review really does not know deli.  They keep their meats under a heat lamp -- which helps dry them out.  If you want real deli, go to Famous or somewhere else.  A disappointment.

Hey everyone, I had the great pleasure today to have the BEST corn beef special ever at Hershel's East Side in the Reading Terminal Market! The corn beef was extremely tender and warm topped with just enough Russian dressing and tangy cole slaw! The rye bread (which you can purchase by the loaf) was absolutely perfect with that soft yet slight chewy texture. So the next time your visiting the Reading Terminal treat yourself to Hershel's! Trust me you won't regret it!! YUMMY!

I am so very torn with this review.  I had a hot pastrami sandwich there last week and I dare say it was better than Famous 4th.  It was tender, juicy and delicious.  A bit greasy but delicious.  So good that I was craving it and had to go back again.
So, I went  today and got the very same thing.  The slices of pastrami were way too thick that I couldn't even bite through it.  Terribly disappointed this time.  I ended up chucking my sandwich after the first bite.  I'll go back again but not for pastrami.  I'll stick to Famous 4th for that one.

A common complaint I hear about Philadelphia is our lack of delis. Although I love Wawa as much as the next Philadelphian, sometimes you just need a little more out of your sandwich. Cue Hershels East Side Deli.  Their sandwiches are just awesome. They are known for their  pastrami so if you're a fan, get it. But have no fear, pastrami haters, their other sandwiches are really fantastic.  I had a chicken salad here that just might have been my favorite in Philly. 

This place is a perfect location for a lunch in Reading Terminal when you just want a solid meal.  It even has seating, win!

This was a cool looking joint.  You get to see the carvers and the meats doing it up.  The meats, corned beef, pastrami, and brisket looked and tasted so tender.  Not piled as high as New York Delis, but easier enough to eat on the puny rye bread.  New York delis tend to believe that their sandwich can be eaten without the request of more bread.

Anyway, I'm not really a corned beef guy but I had the Reuben and it was so good.  Along with the coleslaw and dressing, just puts it over the top.

Corned beef reuben-man, corned beef reuben-man.
It's the size of the entire universe, man!
Most delicious to my stomach, man.
Corned beef reuben-man.

Hershel's corned beef reuben ROCKED MY WORLD.  The most tender corned beef ever, and better yet, they give you a ton of it.  Perfect amount of Russian dressing + sauerkraut to complement but not overpower the sandwich.

If I lived in Philly, I'd eat this sandwich every day for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.  And I'd be fat.  And REALLY happy.

Every now and then, I come across food combinations that make absolutely no sense until you try them. French fries on salad sounds ridiculous until you give the Pittsburgh specialty a try. And Hershel's?  Hershel's has the knish dog.

If you've ever visited a street cart in New York City, you're likely familiar with the potato knish, a Jewish mainstay jam-packed with a garlicky potato mash and squirted with a liberal dose of mustard. 

Hershel's takes one of these knishes, splits it open with a knife, and presses the two halves onto a hot dog bun. Layered on top is a kosher hot dog and the option to add on sauerkraut and mustard. It sounds insane (especially when you consider that the word knish is, according to the all-knowing force of Wikipedia, Yiddush for "kind of a bun" so you're essentially stacking two buns) but it works.  The whole concoction is so Jewish I practically sprouted a yarmulke on the spot. And like street cart food, you can get it at a steal (at $3.75, if memory serves).

I'm sure their deli is great as well, but how can you pass on your chance at a knish dog?

At Hershel's, you have the choice to "dine in" (or the nearest approximation possible at Reading Terminal Market) on one side of the counter or get your food to go on the other side. It seems a bit heretical to sit down to eat a knish, so I suggest grabbing yours to go.

Delicious and clean but a bit on the dry side for me.  I will take that for corned beef without all the guk you get at most local places.

I wish there were more options on the menu.

This is third time I've been to Philly in the last two years, and I can honestly say I've eaten at some of the "best" deli's anywhere and Hershel's Ruben's, Pastrami, Corned beef specials set them apart from anywhere else I've eaten at. As far as the review about the heat lamps, the meat was never under there for more than a couple of minutes as they were selling it so fast it would only be out in an eye blink. A most stop by, Can't wait until this winter when I go back.

Best corned beef sandwich I've ever had!!!

The corned beef just melts in your mouth. Very little amount of fat. Go for the special, you get coleslaw and russian dressing on slices of rye bread. They give you a huge amount so I asked for just a half sandwich, which was perfect for me. It also came with a pickle!

Hershel's ruined me for pastrami.

This was awesome: Thick, tender pieces of pastrami cut from a larger roast and piled high on thin rye bread with Russian dressing and cole slaw. I knew I was in trouble when I saw the volume of dressing slathered on my bread, and indeed, I needed about forty napkins and a bathroom trip to manage the mess all over my hands and forearms. But my mouth was so excited about the experience that I was able to completely overlook the gloop. This was like essence of pastrami--the best of pastrami flavor and texture distilled into a freaking amazing sandwich.

I might opt for the pastrami on rye with mustard next time rather than the special, just to cut down on the mess and because the pastrami is such a superstar that not much else is needed. Whatever you want on your pastrami, though, you need to order it at Hershel's.

When this place opened a few years ago, I wasn't too excited about a deli. Sandwiches=boring. But now that it has been around for a while, I love that I can get a delicious super-thick bagel with cream cheese and lox for breakfast before I head to work.

I discovered this place over a year ago when I was working in Philly - I got to say this is still the best Beef Brisket that I've had in my entire life!  I always intended on eating half a sanwich at lunch and save the other half for dinner - but somehow I never quite made it until dinner.  Their soup/sandwich combo is very good too - they have the noodles in a separate container so they stay al dente.

I'm in Arizona now and was just disappointed by a sandwich I had out here at one of the top deli's.  Sure it was loaded with meat, but not that flavorful!

Inside the Reading Terminal Market, which is a maze of culinary damn piled up all over the place. But that's another review.

I was there only briefly -- but Hershel's actually challenged my beloved Dallas' Jimmy's for the best sandwich I've ever had.

Jimmy's Cuban vs. Hershel's Reuban.

TOUGH call. The Reuban was -- literally -- piled 3" high with meat that literally fell apart in your mouth like a freakin' Krispy Kreme donut. Oy. amazing.  

Not sure how the place could get anything less than 5 stars....

I had some time to spare while I was in the area by Reading Terminal Market one day, and since i knew I didn't have time to sit down and eat a huge lnch, I settled on a cup of matzah ball soup from Herschel's.  The soup was definitely hot, but the matzah ball was a tad too dense and not nearly as fluffy as I would have liked for it to be.  Not bad, but not as amazing as my grandmom's matzah ball soup that I look forward to every year, especially during Passover.  However, since Herschel's has such a big menu, I'm willing to give some of their other selections a try.

Prepare yourself for a juicy meat holiday.  I'd passed by this place a few times before hand, regrettably with a full stomach, but it always looked and smelled amazing.  I went up to the counter, asked the butcher which was better, the corned beef or the pastrami because they both looked great.  He said he was partial to the pastrami, hands me a scrap, and I knew I was in for a good sandwich.  

So he starts cutting slices of the giant hunk of warm pastrami and puts about a layers worth of meat on the rye.  And i figure, well, thats probably it, and I guess  that will be enough.  Oh how I was wrong.  My sandwich was like a glorious tower of meat.  Warm, juicy, meaty, delicious.  Thats what I want from a deli sandwich.  If you're looking for a meat coma, go to Hershels.

Visiting Phila and a casual stroll in Reading Terminal had me stumble on Hershel's. As I was with my mother, who wanted a pastrami sandwich I thought I'd try the chopped liver & onions.

Woo Hoo!! I was happy about the friendly greeting...happy about the quick service and even happier about the food. My mum changed her order to corned beef after seeing how yummy it looked. She told me it was moist, delicious & seasoned well. My chopped liver didn't disappoint, also moisty with a nice texture - I added brown mustard & delish it was.

We enquired about who 'Hersel' was (original owner) who went on to start Katz Deli in NYC. Not sure if it was true or not but the story was interesting.

The prices are a bit up there but we both enjoyed the food and great customer service.
This place has good pastrami. Good-sized portions as well. Try it, you'll like it.

Unbelievable!!!

Had the Pastrami reuben, and it was definitely the best I have ever had.  I pretty much feel nothing will ever to it.  The meat was...really really succulent.  I have been to Katz, and it doesn't compare.  Haven't been to Carnegie though so I can't comment about that comparison. 

Also had the salad sampler with macaroni, potato, and whitefish salad for the vegetarian in my group.  Pass.  No flavor and mayo ridden.

5 stars for the Corned Beef Reuben.  3 stars for everything else on the menu such as the matzo ball soup and other extras you can buy to go with the sandwich.  I've never had a bad reuben here.  I always ask for extra kraut and pickes, which they accommodate.   HUGE sandwich.

So, an average of 4 stars.  New York better watch out!

The sandwiches here are ABSURD! Delicious, fresh rye bread jam packed with your choice of one (two? three?) of their hot, tasty meats (corned beef, brisket, pastrami or turkey). Pile on whatever condiments tickle your fancy (mustard, sourkraut, coleslaw, russian dressing, onions, etc.) or go with  one of the standard sandwiches (special or rueben). Anyway you take it you're sure to be blown away. Every sandwich comes with a pickle which goes great with every bite of the sandwich. They also offer Dr. Brown's sodas and if you are unfamiliar with them give any variety a try, they all go perfectly with the deli meats. The sandwiches are absolutely out of this world and will fill you to the brim (maybe twice) but try to leave some room for their other menu items. They have great homemade soups everyday and the knishes are phenomonal. I never tried a knish until I had one at Hershel's and I can't believe what I was missing. All in all you can't go wrong with any choice at Hershel's but in my fine opinion I will reccomend a corned beef sandwich on rye with plenty of mustard, onions, some extra pickles with a potatoe knish and a Dr. Brown's black cherry soda. MMM MMM!

I've been eating the corned beef and pastrami sandwiches from this place with every visit to Philly. But today was my last. 

At first, I was really blown away by this place. The quantity of meat that they put in the sandwich and the amazing taste ensured that I'd be back. But when I returned, I didn't get quite the same juicy & tender cuts of meat which I expected. Instead, I got some dry, crappy corned beef. Really regretted it. 

But still I came back, again and again, hoping to get that tender cut which I got the first time. I never really got it. And now I give up on them. 

Today I got a half pastrami / half corned beef sandwich. Absolutely disgusting. Dry piece of garbage. Didn't finish it. And regretted paying $12 for it :(

I've eaten at Hershel's maybe a half dozen times but never was compelled to review it until the corned beef sandwich I had yesterday.  I don't know if it was just everything lining up right, but it may have been the best corned beef I have ever tasted, and definitely the best in the city.

I'm a fan of the $7 half sandwich and small matzo ball soup special that's always available too.  And the guys who work there are really nice.  A lot of times they'll toss in a bagel for my 2 year old son for free if it's past the morning rush.

Perhaps I am a snob for deli's...but I just wasn't satisfied with the pastrami on rye at Hershel's. I think that the Philadelphia Jewish deli experience is not fulfilled here and in fact, it is not fulfilled anywhere, not even at 4th Street Delicatessen.

In all honesty, you have to go to New York or Baltimore. These are the places with the good deli's and the old school panache that make them the world's greatest deli's. Attman's, Katz's, Ben's Best Kosher, Weiss'...you can't deny these places.

Anyways, a solid effort Hershel's on the hot dog...I love the sauerkraut on a Hebrew National frank!
Amazing! The Pastrami is out of this world. I crave this place all the time.  Well worth the trip. The corned beef is very good too but the pastrami knocked my socks off. Go get one NOW!

There's something to say about giant slabs or roasted meat just out or the cooker sitting on a counter in front of you with guys in competition to see who can pile the meat the highest on your sandwich. I say "bring it on!" Hershel's is relatively new to The Reading Terminal, but I feel like I've known them for years. When i need a kosher fix, this the place to be! The Corned Beef, Pastrami and Brisket are all to die for and you will never leave there hungry. Whenever I eat there, I'm taken back to the good ole days at Bain's delicatessen on Broad st. How can something so simple taste so good?

This was my first time in Reading Terminal Market in nearly ten years. After walking the floor, I settled on Hershel's for lunch. I ordered a corned beef reuben. A little fattier than I prefer normally, it, however, made the sandwich truly delicious. The sandwich size surpassed the $9 price. My only minor complaint would be the pickle, not nearly enough.

Went to the Reading Market in search of Hershel's (after going to Chicago where I had Jewish deli multiple times), I was feenin for some pastrami on rye and some matzo ball soup.  I go here, and get my fix.  The pastrami is plentiful and juicy, matzo ball soup tasted exactly how I wanted it to taste (read:  good), and the price was right (lunch special!).  

If you like crowds, come to Hershels.  After finished with a full belly and have excess energy, grab some cheap fruit and meats from the market!

Couldn't resist coming back here on my second visit to Philadelphia.  I tacked on a last star for great consistency in their food.

This time I tried the corned beef special.  A very large amount of meat - but since it's not pastrami, it definitely felt a lot healthier scarfing the whole thing down.  Check out the gf's picture (Annie M.) ...it's the first picture for Hershel's on Yelp that really captures the sandwich in all its glory.

I was really excited to try this place and when i got here I was even more excited since the line was so long. Well it was ok for me, I have the  Ruben with pastrami and it was difficult to eat, the pastrami was pretty tough to chew so you actually get tired of chewing. The  meat was flavorful but  with the texture, I think I should try the corned beef instead next time.  The Matzo Ball soup was really good.

Their Pastrami Sandwich is the best sandwich I have ever had in my life. i cannot say enough good things about it. 

I met my husband at a conference in Philadelphia for the weekend. I had big plans to hit up the two famous cheese steak joints (which shall remain nameless) in town. 

After eating Hershel's Pastrami sandwich, I could hardly think straight. I have a hard time believing that this is not the first sandwich people think of when they hear "Philadelphia". 

Just for the record, I did end up visiting one of Philly's famous cheese steak stands. It could not even hold a candle to the pastrami at Hershel's. (If you want to talk about an epic Steak & Cheese, may I suggest Nadeau' s Subs in NH?) 

I continually check out Southwest's offering for cheap flights to Philadelphia, solely to have just one more sandwich here. 

I dream about these sandwiches at night.

omg, INSANE. really, truly insane. got there just before closing and ordered a large matzo ball soup, corned beef sandwich, and brisket sandwich. everything was ridiculous. I honestly stuffed my face until I was ready to burst and at that, I would have gone back the next day and the next had I not left Philly. The value is incredible as you get triple the bang for your buck, the service is the best as it seems like its all family  -staff, customers, everyone - and the taste is unparalleled. Really, haven't had anything like it before and can't wait to go back. these west coast jewish joints ain't got $#!* on Philly!

This place is overpriced for how their food is prepared and kept.  Living in New York I've grown to love Real Pastrami and Reubens.  They're not the best I've ever had here, but they are better than most places in town.

Jewish Heaven. Just the way my dad use to make my sandwiches. Big and obnoxious! Growing up in an all Gentile neighborhood the kids in my elementary school just didn't get it. I remember one girl used to get a hard boiled egg, a slice of bread and an apple. So I'd always give her the other half. 

Well me and my stacked meat sandwiches were a revelation compared to the PB J's and 1 Slice of cheese sandwiches that I witnessed all around me in the cafeteria during lunchtime!
oh yeah, back to the review. I had the whitefish platter and finally tried out the Cel-Ray soda that my boyfriend had been raving about. The amount of food I received on my platter made 4 sandwiches. So there was plenty of take home. Which I tentatively hid in the back of the fridge so my bo wouldn't find it. (he's such a foodie)
This place is a little heaven and the service was great. Jill was my waitress and a real doll. She said the tips weren't great which i was hard pressed to believe but I still slipped her a 40% tip. I recommend this place highly. Food was fresh, mounds and mounds, even the Q-tips at the Early birds in Florida would be jealous!

* Q-Tips are Seniors with white hair.. get it :)

If you say you don't like the pastrami here, its either because you don't like pastrami in general or you're just being a jerk.  

Don't be a jerk.  This place is awesome(for pastrami sandwiches).

Juicy. Thick. Stacked...
Pastrami Reuben.

As my equally stuffed & satisfied companion put it, "I'm no, reubenisseur, but this is the best I've ever had."

Just go get a pastrami sandwich.

(I can't write any more than that because number 1, I've never had pastrami before, and number 2, I don't ever plan on having pastrami from anywhere else...ever...because the thought of eating marbled, cured meat rubbed with pepper is actually kind of repulsive.)

Corned beef sandwich was good with the slaw. 4/5

Brisket sandwich was disappointingly dry and flavorless. 2/5

Would definitely be willing to try some other sandwiches though.
Enjoyed the Reuben sandwich. Beef is tender and flavourful.  Good bread, dressing, cabbage.  Nicely put together.

No better folks...  had the pastrami sandwich a couple times and there is no better that I have ever, ever had...  they pull what looks like a side of beef out of the oven, cut it in half, chop it up and that is what goes on your Pastrami sandwich...  so not only was it huge, but the most tender, melt in your mouth sandwich you will ever have the pleasure of biting into...   one great sandwich!

OMG their corn beef sandwich is to die for. I visit this place every time I go to Philly. Its like my must have meal. The sandwich is freaking packed so thick with meat I can't even open my mouth big  enough to eat it. The staff is super awesome to!
I stop in every time I'm in town. I always order the pastrami sandwich...the BEST! They do not skim on the meat and the briskets are awesome!
Zomg... the Reuben was so incredible, and the pickle was the perfect compliment. 4 stars and not 5 because as other posters have mentioned, $12 for a sandwich and a drink is a little steep for me.

I was eating the corned beef sandwiches for a while until I tried a pastrami. Not going back! It's all about the pastrami. You can get a half sandwich for $5, which is more than enough for lunch. The matzoh balls soup is good in winter, I always burn my tongue on it.

Hershel's is one of my go-to quick weekend brunch spots in Philadelphia...and a must for anyone who's visiting the Reading Terminal Market.  Whenever I come here I get either the Bagel and Lox sandwich or the Turkey Reuben - both are delicious.  When I visited Hershel's yesterday, I chose the Bagel and Lox sandwich- plain bagel,  light on the cream cheese (if you don't tell them they will overdo it!), with everything (tomato, onion, capers, and lettuce).  When my sandwich along with two deli pickles showed up, it was packed with fresh lox - in fact yesterday the sandwiches seemed even larger then usual- ok with me because I was starving.  My boyfriend ordered the Turkey Reuben sandwich- stacked high with smoked turkey, sauerkraut, liberally drizzled with Russian dressing, the bread crisped to perfection on the panini press- delicious with a can of root beer! 

There are only about 8 or 9 stools here, so you're lucky if you get the chance to sit down.  Service while minimal, has always been friendly and pleasant.  Prices are fair, but definitely worth it for the amount of food you get.  

Recommended!

Now that I have explored lots of deli options in PHilly and South Jersey - I goot say - for corned beef?  Hershel's is absolutely 5 star in my book.  I often will get a 1/4 or 1/2 lb of sliced corned beef to go along with my fruits & veggies from Iovine's or Fair Food Farmstand.  A few decadent slices are all I can handle.

This is GOOD stuff!

So much better than Katz's in NYC. The pastrami and other meats are such great quality and contain far less fat than other delis that I've tried, including Katz's, not to mention that sandwiches here are half the price. Check it out whenever you're at Rea

Great pastrami sandwich!!!

Had Dinic's the other day and must say, this sandwich blows that place out of the water!! Wish Dinic's wasn't such a tourist trap that sucks you in...would have  preferred two Herschel's sandwiches instead...amazing.

I'm surprised by all the four- and five-star reviews. I didn't think Hershel's was all that great. When I asked local Yelpers about delis before coming to Philly, no one had any recommendations for good places, and I was told NYC and LA have much better d

Best reuben I've ever had! Wife and I were visiting Philly over the weekend and we stopped at Reading Terminal Market for lunch. As we wondered around the market, trying to decide what we wanted to eat, we noticed some people eating some amazing looking reubens. We decided that we had to find them. It wasn't hard to miss Hershels, they have several huge cuts of meat out getting sliced up for the enormous sandwiches. We decided on getting a pastrami on rye reuben and a brisket on rye reuben. We both ate a half which was more than enough but they are so good, you can't wait to finish eating it. In both of our opinions, we thought the pastrami was the better sandwich but even the brisket was top notch. 

Hershels will definitely be on my list of places to eat at next time we come back.

Whose bright idea was it to place Hershel's next to Bassett's turkey?!?! My two favorite places in the Reading Terminal... side by side. Not fair! I hate making these type of tough decisions :) ... A HA, THE SOLUTION! Order one of both, eat a half from each, and take the other halves home! Genius!

Hershel's has so much to offer, and is perfect for the Reading Terminal. I personally love the hot brisket sandwich on marble rye. Fresh baked and fresh sliced bread + carved brisket straight from the oven? What else is there to ask for. Ask for some horseradish sauce on top, and you have the best sandwich in the entire place. Pair it with a Dr. Brown's black cherry, and you're set!

Wow!!! The pastrami is amazing here! I saw the price and I wasn't crazy about paying $8 for a sandwich but once I saw him cut the meat and put 2  yes 2 heaping handfuls of meat on the bread I was amazed! The meat is so flavorful and delicious! My only complaint is the meat was a little bit fatty. Thats why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. I have had it before and it was not fatty at all. Also try the Kasha. its a pasta with wheat flour or something. whatever it is its pretty good. I think it is an acquired taste so some people may not like it.

This is the absolute best pastrami in the world.  I'm from New York and have been to pretty much every well known Jewish deli here for the pastrami and nothing comes remotely close to Heshel's.  I've also been up to Montreal and tried the smoke meat at a

This place really is "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"

There's nothing wrong with this place. At. All. Aside from the prices being a little high it's perfect. And it makes sense that perfection would come with a higher price tag.

The pastrami, corned beef, and brisket are out of this world. I've had better brisket, but I don't think I've had better corned beef or pastrami ever, and yeah that's including Katz's or whatever other "famous" deli in NYC or wherever have to offer. It's so moist, tender, flavorful. Mouth is watering right now. I've never tried the turkey or any fish or chicken salad but I imagine them to be fantastic as well. The soup is great too. They put the noodles in right as you order so they don't get mushy while its just sitting in the steam trays.

So yeah, I've been to this place countless times and finally wrote a review because yesterdays experience was almost like Paul of Damascus style or whatever.
This is perhaps the shittiest brisket I've ever eaten in my life. So dry and bland I had to douse it in mustard. If I ate it there I would've returned it.

what do you know...a perfect new york deli in the middle of reading terminal, philadelphia.  for those visiting, it's a great alternative to the lines wrap around the "famous" spots like carmen's or dinic's.

even though i'm a huge fan of pastrami (though i'm rather biased to the pastrami dip found at the hat...oh how i miss thee), i went with the corned beef reuben instead.  and since i stole a few bites from my friend's pastrami sandwich, i was happy to scarf down my reuben with russian dressing in peace.

Wow! I stopped in here for lunch one day while I was in Center City Philadelphia attending a 2-day seminar. My intent was to go to DiNic's, but the lunch line was entirely too long. Now, I'm glad it was cause I found another gem in Reading Terminal. I ordered a pastrami sandwich and after one bite something just felt familiar.
