I've visited Katz's Deli many times during visits to NYC and this sandwich tasted eerily similar, which was a great thing. Turns out the brother of the owner(of Hershel's) ran Katz's Deli for 30 years. So now you no longer have to go to NYC to get a world famous pastrami sandwich or worry about boxing out other customers to make your order...and the pickles are better at Hershel's anyway. Highly recommended! The brisket looks good too.

I sought out Hershel's after a stellar recommendation from my co-worker.  

So one lovely Friday afternoon, I took off from work early and stopped by Reading Terminal to pick up a (very) late lunch for my boyfriend and I.  Hershel's did not disappoint.

By the time we ate lunch (around 3:30pm), both of us were starved.  Sadly, I was able to finish my monster of a pastrami, which was paired with a very delicious pickle.  The good news is after that, I didn't need dinner.  The pastrami is sliced thick and every bite was as delicious as the last.

On top of the fantastic pastrami sandwich, this place has A+ customer service.  Very friendly.  I'll definitely be going back when I've got the appetite for it!

WOW! Best Pastrami I ever had. I was tempted to get the brisket instead since they brought a fresh one out of the oven right in front of me while in line. the pastrami looked drier and not as juicy. But so glad I picked the Pastrami Reuben--it was juicy, lean, plentiful and flavorful. The sauerkraut and Russian dressing didn't overpower the meat and complemented it very well. 

Try to see if you can get a seat at the counter, otherwise you'll have to wait long. But the wait it well worth it!

The first time John Jameson had this sandwich he walked up to the owner and thanked him for changing his life.

I had a similar experience.

I never thought corned beef could be a religious experience but it can be, and Herschel is god.

Go, and go now.

Oh, the glory! Oh, the madness! This. Is. Hershel's! 

After stumbling upon Hershel's Reuben a few years ago, its hard for me to order from anywhere else but Hershel's while in Reading Terminal. The Reuben is absolutely one of the top sandwiches in this fine city. The moistest meat ever, they cut it off the slab right in front of you as if it were butter. So much meat for your buck, the 'wich in all its perfection is worth the price. Great rye, sour kraut, and russian dressing really send this particular Reuben to the top. 

The deliciousness has distracted me from another great aspect of this experience--the service! I can't imagine the customer turnover this place must have being in the center of Reading Terminal, but it doesn't matter. Those guys always serve and ring you up with a smile and thank you--lunch rush or not.

While the standard corned beef Reuben here is great, the Pastrami Reuben is second to none.  Piled high with meat, sauerkraut, swiss cheese, and thousand island dressing, it is grilled to perfection and served with a pickle spear.  Not cheap at just over $11 with a drink, but quality has a price.

The potato knishes are also enormous and outstanding.

Well worth the visit to Reading Terminal Market.

I got dizzy going around Reading Terminal looking for this place but the reward was worth the nausea. The line was shorter than Di Nic's, the attendants, friendlier and the food, 10 times better. 

The corned beef sandwich was huge and I didn't think I could finish it but it was so good I didn't even share (and finished down to the last morsel). My hubby (who was eating a jambalaya) was so envious he ordered a pastrami to go and they gave him some free savory pastries (lucky).

We ate the pastrami later on at the hotel and it was cold and not as good but maybe if it was warm it would have been as stellar as my corned beef. Will definitely eat here again when we're in Philly.

My cousin recommended this place to us and he said that this place has the best corned beef ever. He was right, one bite, i was in heaven. The meat was so tender and juicy. The line was long but worth it.

Come on folks!  $10 for a Pastrami Ruben that is average to slightly above average at best?!? I'll give them that the sandwich was large, but that merely made it difficult to eat and not any better.  Maybe I've been spoiled by some great delis or maybe they had an off-day, either way 3-stars is what they are getting from me on this trip...

This was my 2nd trip to Philly and the highlight for me was Reading Terminal as I ate just about every meal for 4.5 days there and of those meals my pastrami sandwich at Herschel's was one of my favorites if not thee favorite. I had hoped to there for a 2

Both the regular Reuben and the turkey Reuben are delicious, piled 3in high with juicy, thick-cut meat and plenty of sauerkraut.   One sandwich is definitely shareable, which makes the $10 price tag a value for two meals.

I wanted to give an extra commendation to the service.  The last time I visited it was a Sunday afternoon, which in RTM inevitably means busy with a long line.  I walked near the counter with the second half of my sandwich, and I did not even have to ask--despite the line, my server held out his hand and wrapped the half for me to take home.

Overall, an excellent Sunday lunch and my go-to spot for a deli fix.

This place is the REAL deal. This 9 dolla turkey sandwhich was ree-diculously moist. Hands down, the best turkey I've had in Philly. They don't skimp on the turkey meat either. Turkey's craved right in front of you, nice thick pieces of juicy meat. SO GOOD!! 

Oh, and if you're a soup fan definitely try the matzo ball soup. Great hangover food that hits the spot especially on a cold day. Did I also mention that both the soup and sandwhich lasted me for two meals?

Don't let those long lunch lines scare you. The food here is DEFINITELY worth it.  Folks, you don't want to miss out.

I have NEVER EVER in my life tasted a sandwich so good.... Me and my coworker used to always go and get one sandwich and split it because its so huge... Either try the Pastrimi or Cornbeef by itself or if you want to really indulge yourself get it mixed ITs sooooo delicious....

Not expensive so now since my coworker left my job I go to get half sandwiches...

Thick, Hand Cut Peppered Pastrami. Hot Mustard. Side of Pickles. Delicious. 

Great location. I love the hustle and bustle of the market. 

I rate 4.5 stars. I rate half a star down because the portions are too big for me! The sandwich size is too much for one person but too small for two people.

Best NY style sandwiches in Philly, and this is coming from a NY'er.  I find myself in the Terminal market several times a yr and always end up getting a sandwich here.  This time I had the Corned beef reuben style.  Meat was very tender and moist.  Not salty at all, which was a nice surprise considering it is CORNED beef after all.  One slight note, the beef could have been a little less tender if that makes any sense.  I like my beef to still retain some of that resilience when you bite into it.  Makes it a little less like over boiled meat.  And this time they were a little light on the coleslaw,  I'm used to it dripping from my elbows when I'm done.  Otherwise a top notch sammy.
Wow, the matzoh ball soup rocks and so do the pastrami sandwiches. Really, I'm serious. Absolutely amazing. Try the soup, it's worth it!!!
Best Reuben in town hands down!  Pastrami is fantastic as well.  This is not just a tourist spot this is the real deal!  I eat there way too often to be honest!

"I'm visiting for a day from New York. I must get the cheesesteak," I'm thinking while passing Hershel's busy counter. "We've got plenty of those east side delis and corned beef rubens that have got to be the best. I should go for cheesesteak while in Philly."

And so I end up standing in a long line to Tommy DiNic's instead, because supposedly its roast pork sandwich is the best of the best - never mind the cheesesteak. Until he announces that he just RAN OUT OF EVERYTHING. "Everything, folks. Come back tomorrow morning."

But tomorrow morning I'll be back in New York. So I consult Yelp and go back to Hershel's - another non-cheesesteak choice.

Boy did I not regret it!  This was the best, piled mile-high corned beef ruben I've ever had.

I went here for lunch on a weekend and the counter was busy but no line!  I had the matzo ball soup and a hot dog(I couldn't help myself) and my boyfriend had the Reuben and he said it was very filling.  They were really friendly- So glad I stopped by for lunch!

By far the best Turkey Ruben I have ever had!  And the Kugel! Oh man.  One of my girl friends makes amazing homemade sweet, noodle Kugel, and this was right up there.  

There's nothing more to say; I'll keep it short and sweet.

Yummmmm.

I can hardly visit Reading Terminal Market without stopping for a Hershel's sandwich. I've had the corned beef, brisket, and the pastrami. Honestly, I can't decide which I like the best. They will all blow your face off in flavor and the meats are hand carved in front of you. They are then piled high on homemade rye bread and are served with 2 dill pickle spears. Order any of them with mustard and onions. Also, their reubens are probably the best I've ever had! 

The portions are huge, definitely save half to bring home.

If you've never been here, you don't know what you're missing out on. Eat here and I promise you will not be disappointed.

In a land (ok, section) of Reading Terminal Market where the real estate is expensive, the food is overpriced, and everything looks more visually appealing than it tastes, Hershel's is the real deal. Their cornbeef sandwich, stacked a mile high between rye, is totally worth the line you'll probably have to wait in and then some. It's really, really delicious.

CORNED BEEF SANDWICH... absolutely to die for!

The corned beef looked so tender and juicy that I wish I ate that huge slab of corned beef all by myself like a barbarian.   I never was a fan of corned beef until that MOMENT.  At that time, I haven't even tasted it but it screamed yummy.

Next they slathered some special spread on 2 pieces of rye bread and topped one side with some type of slaw and the other side like a gazillion slices of corned beef.

The sandwich looked 5 inches tall, it was stacked so high!!!

In the beginning we wanted to wait 2 hrs to eat the sandwich because we just ate at Genos and Prince b/c we were tourists and wanted to try the hype and we were full but was disappointed.  Neways back to the corned beef sandwich.  After looking at the sandwich being built, it was like we couldn't resist.  The sandwich was so high that we couldn't eat it with our hands.. we had to use a fork.

After the first BITE... we heard... a symphony of ohh, ahh, mmz, OMG...not only from myself but from my bf and sis...   it was that good.  It meet every expectation and then some. try, enjoy it and lick the sandwich paper if you need to. hehehe

5 Freakin' STARS!!!  When I walk past here the JEW in me completely takes over!   If you like corned beef or pastrami you can not go wrong! 

I'm a sucker for a good Rueben...and this place is perfection.  Homemade rye bread, hand carved meats and served w/ two Jewish pickles.  Plus, you have dinner when you get home, portions are huge.  

To those that said it's expensive...remember, you always get what you pay for.

Wow! I have always loved the Philly food scene but I would never have thought that I would find the best Jewish Deli sandwich ever there. This place blew Katz's on the LES out of the water! The corned beef was so succulent and moist but not fatty and the

Came here on an eating trip into Philadelphia and i was impressed.

The food was good, and the line moved along.   The Ruben was outstanding and the Matzo ball soup was also good.

I would recommend it in the area for some nice delish food!  try it here.

Pastrami and corned beef. You won't find a better version of either anywhere else. Yes it is fatty but what's the point of living if you don't allow yourself these little indulgences?  Latkes are good, not great but the meat is delish. Grab a lb or two to make your own reubens during the week. Your coworkers will be jealous.

I should really give Hershel's a 3.5, because in my book it is a solid 3.5 But I'm going to round down because I really don't think it deserves a 4.  I have been here twice for an egg and cheese on a bagel sandwich, and had a near exact experience both times.  Both times, the sandwich was good.  Nearly great, but missing just a little something something. Unsure what, but it was good.  The kugel was great the one time I've had it here, and I think I've had their latkes before and enjoyed them as well.  Overall, a solid deli experience.

Ok. Yes you will be crowded out in line or jostled on your stool. But the pastrami is the greatest thing south of Schwartz's Smoked Meat in Montreal. (The pickle isn't as good as Schwartz's). 

The matzo ball soup is perfect and the potato Knish is also right on the money. Counter service is efficient but still polite and takes the time to chat.

Last Saturday, I wanted to find out what all the fuss was about. I had a pastrami Reubin that set me back $9.35. The slabs of rye were about medium. The meat portion was generous. The sauerkraut and Russian dressing were spread on so thin I couldn't taste either. The oily after taste of the pastrami still lingers even now. Was it worth almost $10.00? I don't think so.

I've been looking forward to returning to Hershel's since first having a Reuben here in 2007.  This time I had a pastrami Reuben, and I was not disappointed.  The food is great, and the staff is very friendly.  This will be a staple each time we're in Philly.

Located in between perhaps two of the most popular sandwich vendors in Reading Terminal Market (Dinic's and Original Turkey), Hershel's East Side Deli doesn't get full recognition as the go-to place for sandwiches. Well, at least for me, it took me a long time to realize that!

Famous for its corned beef and pastrami, Hershel's is operated by a bunch of young-looking, hat-wearing fellows. Although it may not sound so delicious, Hershel's serve one of the best greasy sandwiches! The pastrami is tender, juicy, and with a slight hint of pink in the middle wrapped around with great seasoning outside.

Recommendations: 
1. Pastrami Special (Not grilled, with russian dressing & cole slaw)
2. Pastrami on Reuben (Hot sandwiches, grilled with russian dressing & sauerkraut in it)

Pros:
1. Perfect coordination between the russian dressing and the meat
2. Takes LevelUp and I believe there's $2 credit for Hershel's! Hooray!

Cons:
1. A bit too pricey for a medium-size sandwich despite its hard work on making them (Usually goes over $10 for a sandwich with small fountain drink. But with the LevelUp credit, you can simply ignore this point)
2. A bit too greasy if you're looking for a light, health meal.

Stuck in between all the "must-go-to" places in Reading Terminal, Hershel's East Side Deli blew me away with some serious stuff. Before I can find better pastrami in town, Hershel's is still considered as one of the best place to grab a quick sandwich!

I cannot think of Philadelphia, without professing my love of cured meats, sliced thin, piled high 2 inches, thrown between rye, and pressed in an iron. This despite Philly supposed to be famous for its cheese-what? 

Hershel's is honestly one of the best sandwiches I have ever had. I first experienced Hershel in the Summer of 06, and years later, it is still the same great wich. Wich-craft, and all you "gourmet" sandwich shops, eat your heart out. This is a real sandwich. For about 8.99, get try the Reuben Special with Corned beef, and toasted on Rye with Saurkraut. I honestly could not sleep after this meal, it was either out of joy, or out of gluttony for finishing the whole thing!

Funny Melissa W and I both independently happened upon Hershels and when it came to talking about the Reading Market, it was unanimous for Hershels.

Also try their matzo ball soup if you can stomach it all at once!.
The young guy working there wrapped up my sandwich without a word. So kind. Best quality food too!

There were about 20 guys working that day in this small place in the Reading Market. 
 
Some would even cash out then go and make a sandwich w/out washing their hands.
  
Despite this the meat was very tasty, succulent and tender.  
I pd $5 for a half sandwich of brisket.  Loved it.  Wanted more.
  
The corned beef sandwich they were making for someone else looked really succelent as well.  Someone who tasted it told me that they enjoyed it. 

 I would eat here more often but paying $8 to park just for a $5 to $10 sandwich is not worth it, as I don't do much shopping anywhere else at the Terminal.  I guess I could park across the street, run in there and get a $10 sandwich, get my ticket validated then run back out before 2 hrs is up and pay $4 for parking.  That might work.    Yeah, the meat is really good.   I trumped down a star for the location and parking headache.
noooooot keen at all.

Reading Terminal Market seems like a tourist trap!

I was around and needed to get a bite to eat.  I walked by Hershel's and saw the juicy succulent meat on display.

I decided to get the meat platter and boy was that a mistake!

The brisket was drier than it looked.  The pastrami was dry and had a horrible texture, but it tasted ok.  The corned beef was nothing to write home about.

The price was a bit steep.

There is someone out there in the internet universe that is probably going to give me flack for awarding yet another place 5-stars, but that same person also sent me a message (within moments of gloating that I was chowing down on a Hershels reuben) saying that if there were no health effects of eating that sandwich every day, he would....I'm thinking 5-stars in this situation is absolutely acceptable.

Shortly after that message was received, a friend (who has in recent times gone vegetarian) sent me a text message saying that it's posts like mine about the reuben that make her wish she ate meat again.

Brass tacks? Go. The sandwiches from Hershels are made with love and of monstrous greatness both in size and flavor. Don't bother with anything else but the pastrami or corned beef and for the love of God just do yourself the favor and do it right, get the reuben. Take it to stay at the counter, take it to go on a picnic, take it back to your office to make your co-workers jealous...it doesn't much matter, it's perfection wherever you enjoy it. Yes it's beautifully marbled with fat, yes it is smothered in dressing far from the fat-free variety, yes it has cheese, and possibly it's only health redeeming condiment - the sauerkraut. This is not the type of sandwich you order on the daily...if you try, your arteries will scream at you until you succumb to acute myocardial infarction which in fact is not "cute" at all. 

So let's boil it down: try the sandwich, don't have a heart attack, and PM me to tell me all about how you fell in love.

LOVE THIS PLACE! 

A friend from Philly recommended this place to us.  It's right across Tommy DiNic's.  If I were u, I would skip the line at Tommy DiNis'c and head straight to Hershel's.  I really enjoyed the Corned Beef Special from Hershel's.  What made the sandwich so good was their coleslaw! I've had the same sandwich at Kat'z deli in New York, but I think Hershel's blows Katz out of the water.

This place is awesome!  Come early.  There is a line of 10-20 people, and if it's a major time to get lunch or dinner, it will be longer.  Luckily the line moves fast and you'll get a seat.  Sometimes, in Reading Terminal, seats are not easy to come by.  You have to scout for a seat and hunt one down by observing those people that are almost done with their food.   With your cold cut, either corned beef, pastrami, brisket, you can get cole slaw and cheese on top.  You also have the choice of choosing what bread you would like: seeded rye, marble rye, challah.  I got the brisket with chunks of fat and coleslaw with swiss on top a marble rye sandwich.  Oh man, it was heaven in a sandwich.   The brisket was well flavored without being salty and the bread was delicious!  I should mention that the sandwich is a big one, so make sure you are very hungry.

business.full_address:
4049 Hwy 1
Monmouth Junction, NJ 08852
business.name: Burrito Royale

reviews.text: The food here was some of the worst I have had... "Mexican" or otherwise. I use quotes because the menu items are far from food Mexican. My friend ordered the veggie burrito which was mostly just store-bought guac. They put tomato sauce on the salads. Expensive for what you actually get. They don't take credit cards. The bathrooms are outside. Service is slow. Otherwise it is ok.

i wish i could vote 0 stars.  being from so. cal. i've had my share of good mexican....this place being open for a while makes me think new jersians need to find out what good mexican food is.  it was boring, kind of like going to taco bell without any flavor.  we waited forever on top of bad food.  i usually think that when i see a hole in the wall like this mean great food.....WRONG.  do not, i repeat, DO NOT go to the royale.

My old saying "if a place looks like crap, is out in the middle of nowhere, and has been open for a long ass time, it HAS to be good" has failed me here.

The food here is quite...subpar.  I was full on expecting gut busting burritos, quantity sized quesadillas, something to really write home about.  But it was quite a disaster.  The fajita burrito had 2 thin burritos with lettuce/tomatoes thrown on top.  What's that?  The quesadilla was just so average.  Chicken and cheese.  That's it.  

It's just sad that I was expecting something good.  But it wasn't even decent.  So sad.  At least there is a Qdoba coming on July 11!
My family has been going to this place for years, and we all still love it! Very laid-back, mellow atmosphere, with delicious and affordable food. Fast and friendly service, as well!

Please do not listen to the good reviews and try this place like i did.  It was the most horrible experience in my life.  Honestly I can understand the food being bland but the quality of the food was horrible.  If you are looking for a meaty burrito make the trip to chipotle or any other burrito place.  They call it the Burrito king... It should be NonBurrito.  All it was and I wish i took a picture was two small very small pieces of meat, a little bit of lettuce... (come on MAN ITS LETTUCE!)  and cheese wrapped in a tortilla.  Honestly go make yourself a cheeseroll up it will be more satisfying.  Also people call this place a cheap place to eat but honestly for the food quality youre getting this place is kind of pricey...

My boyfriend is a man of very few words, so when he does have an option about something and expresses it, it means a lot.

Me:  So what did you think of the place?
BF: It's like Taco Bell meets Chef Boyardee... in a microwave.
Me: So we're not going back there again?
BF: No.

We weren't sure about trying this place to begin with (based on all of the reviews) but decided to try it since we drive past it all the time.

The review by C.S. sums it up quite well.  It had so much potential in terms of location and crappy hole-in-the-wall decor.  We ordered some chips and salsa to start with.  In all our lives as Mexican food connoisseurs having grown up in SoCal, we have NEVER had warm "salsa."  I swear it was probably salsa out of a jar that they microwaved... bland, gross, and warm.

I'm glad we shared a burrito.  We've never had a burrito with ground beef as the meat.  To think of it, no authentic Mexican joint ever uses ground beef in burritos - at least of the ones we've been to.  The only "Mexican" place that does use ground beef on a regular basis is Taco Bell.

'Nuff said.

I've been going to this tiny hot spot for close to 20 years now & still love it! If you're looking for a simple, low cost mexican meal, look no further! Better to take out than eat in unless you're my kid who thinks eating on benches is fun. 
I can eat their tacos all day! Love it

One word Microwaved Mexican food (and that is probably an insult to Mexicans everywhere) Keep driving there are plenty of places with in a ten minute drive where you can actually enjoy your food and it has some taste to it.

Terribly bland. There's not much else to say. I'm speaking of course of Burrito King (formerly BR). We got chips and salsa and the salsa was tasteless. I ordered the steak burrito and it had steak (unseasoned), lettuce and tomato. that's not what a burrito is you guys, that's just a wrap... My girlfriend got a chicken quesadilla, also unseasoned chicken. All around super bland, would rather Taco Bell over this place.

This is a great little place that doesn't look like much from the outside. We drove by it for years until finally stopping in about 5 years ago. The food is very good, prices are decent and we didn't experience any slowness that another reviewer mentioned.

Worst food ever!...wont even call it mexican food. this place needs to close down. Dont waste your money...its so gross i almost throw up...nothing was good...i think they only reason you see people there are because they are first time goer's...i believe this is the only way they make money there...also the decor is horrible inside, yet they have this cute sign in the outside that makes you think that it will be a hole in the wall that has good food yet not the case.

Quick tip: If you don't like Mexican but need something quick & cheap, eat here! You can even kiss your date afterwards, no onion, garlic or cayenne!

You'd think that a cinderblock shack on the side of the road that has been around since I was 3 (1975) would be great and authentic (yes, I'm using that dreaded word), kind of like the taco trucks or barbeque places, but sadly, that is so very much not the case here. 

Bland bland bland bland bland bland bland bland bland blandidy bland!  Blandidy bland!

Have I mentioned that it's bland?  It's kind of what you expect of what people with no tastebuds want from Mexican food.  This might be a good place to take 2 year olds and those on a cancer friendly diet, as the lack of spices would then be welcomed.   I think that it might even be good for someone getting over food poisoning when they're tired of boiled chicken and rice.

We have lived in the area since October 2008, and had been curious about this place for awhile, but it was never open (closed Sundays and Mondays).  Needless to say, we won't be back.

The first sign of a meh place: tacos in beef, chicken, and bean.  No al pastor, carbon, lengua, just beef, chicken, and bean.  They also serve pizza.  Huh?  Yep.  And the tacos are hard or soft shell.  No real Mexican place serves crunchy shells.  We also couldn't figure out the difference between a burrito and taco here, as they each have meat, cheese, and lettuce.  Um, okay.

The menu boasts of patents for their sauces; well, they needn't worry, as no one will be stealing their sauce recipes.

Imagine a sauce lacking in the basics--cumin, onion, garlic, cayenne.  Even marinara has all but the cumin or possibly cayenne.  Here?  None of the above.  No cilantro either, and you can choose to have munster cheese added to a burrito.  Yep, that staple of Mexican cuisine, munster cheese.

Also, the tacos have lettuce on them, in addition to the munster cheese, no cilantro in sight.  Why am I going off on munster?  If you're going to Americanize it, at least use Monterey Jack, cheddar or American/square/yellow cheese!  Wendy's chili sauce, Taco Bell, and those tiny MSG laden packets from Olde El Paso have more seasoning than this stuff.

Oh, and if you're on a low sodium/sodium restricted diet, go here.  I rarely if ever salt my food, but here I had to salt even the guacamole, which came from a squeezy packet--perfectly smooth and perfectly bland.  We're also convinced that they refilled the El Tapatio sauce with their special patented sauce, as it too was bland.  I asked Jim whether it was just me craving salt on a hot and humid day while pregnant, but sadly, he had to agree that it needed salt.  

Pros: it's clean, and the service is nice.  But the food?  Ugh.  I think it might even have been microwaved on its styrofoam.

$16+tip for an enchilada, 1 beef taco, 1 chicken taco, a large soda, and chips with guacamole.   Cash only.

I hate to say it, but I'd go to Taco Bell before returning here again, and I don't even remember the last time I last ate at one.

This is  a clean, inexpensive place to stop for a quick bite as you run around central nj.  The service was good, I asked for hot tea and got a nice hot cup of tea and had three of their beef tacos-much better than Taco Bell, etc.    Note it is just south of New Street on the west side of one so be careful or you will breeze past it. 

These were fine and better than some recent food I had in NYC.  As a Texan/Oklahoman I have not found good mexican food in NYC or NJ compared to the Southwest.    So still looking for a 4 star place in this area.

We really wanted to like this place. We were on our way back from the city and saw it and thought  "hey why not?" Figured it would have to be pretty good given that it's still open right? 

Sadly not true. The food was just barely 'eh.' 

Two of us got the "Californian", and two of us split and order of chicken burritos and beef burritos (you get two smaller ones). The ground beef had a very odd consistency and the chicken burritos were very dry. They also just weren't that filling. 

But hey no one got sick, and it was OK .

Two of us are still curious about their nachos though... anyone ever order them?

Great little place! i like the chicken and tomato nachos (w/ jalapenos of course!) and their traditional burrito. They use corn tortillas instead of flour which adds to the flavor...they make their salsa fresh and also use muenster cheese....my husband and i love this place!
It may take a bit to get your food during peak times because there is just one chef in the kitchen, but it's always worth the wait.

Had been recommended this spot by colleagues and have been driving past it for years. Had high hopes, but was a little disappointed. Firstly the menu is overly complex. Ordering two burritos to spec. seemed to be an ordeal. When they arrived the order did

I wish that we (I went with my friend Dave) could have reviewed the food, but sadly, we could not.  We were really psyched about finally stopping at Burrito Royale, the shack we had passed numerous times driving along Route 1.  We entered the restaurant before closing and were not stopped.  Upon entering the restaurant, being decent people, we took a menu, and stepped out of line so we would be ready to order when we reached the counter.  There were already 8 people ahead of us in line, when the gentleman manning the register walked past us, locked the door, and explained that there was only a few minutes left until closing.  Assuming that we were in the clear, of the now locked building, we continued to wait in line . . . we assumed wrong.  Upon approaching the counter, we were informed that the restaurant was closing in two minutes and that "there was no food."  We thought he was joking, seeing as the people in front of us had placed their orders and were waiting for the orders' completion.  We asked if they had any prepared food to give us and he said, "I can give you hot sauce."  Having nothing else say, we promptly left, before anger clouded our judgment.  Interestingly enough, Burrito Royale has designed a new business model, whereupon they trap the customer within the restaurant, hype up the customers expectations, and then deny them food.  For the past twenty years, I've looked forward to unlocking the mysteries of Burrito Royale, and it appears that I shall continue my longing into the future.

This place sucks. Located in a gravel parking lot right off of Route 1, I didn't even realize it was still open at first. Their "traditional" burrito was bland and had no flavor at all, besides the hot sauce I put on it. The serving size was kind of small, too. Prices aren't too bad, but you can get a lot better at chains like Chipotle, South of the Border, and Qdoba, I'm sad to say. Skip it.
Cheap, very authentic Mexican. Great place for a quick lunch. Can be hard to find first time as place is surrounded by overgrown brush!

I'm always on the hunt for a good burrito and I had high hopes when I spotted this little restaurant on route 1. I was sorely disappointed!! While my bean and rice burrito was cheap (4.95), it tasted like cardboard. It was rolled incorrectly and mostly consisted of thickly cut iceberg lettuce. There was also some unseasoned yellow rice and a few beans that seemed to have been cooked in water alone. Allegedly, there was cheese, but I couldn't taste or see it. Despite the nice waiter, I will definitely not go back.

STAY AWAY!  SO GROSS!  My dad and I popped in mid afternoon on a Thursday because we needed a quick place to grab some spicy food on the southbound site of Rt. 1.  Upon entering all I could fixate on was the moldy carpet, the insessant noise of the AC and freezer machines, and the fact that everything was cooked in a microwave.  The bathroom was so filthy that i opted NOT to wash my hands before eating because I was more scared of what i could catch from the sink or door knob.  

Now the food.....seriously.....a microwaved burrito with overcooked rice and cold beans?  The cook in the back couldn't care less about the food since he was on a cell phone the entire time.  Chipoltle is one million times better and they actually give you a warm and filling burrito.  

My dad had the enchillada which were swimming in tomato sauce.  So lackluster and sad.  Lean cuisine makes a better enchillada.  In short....don't ever stop here.  Just keep going and hope the health inpector finally makes a visit to this dump.

I agree with the bad reviews. My last visit was terrible. The food was bland, cold, and boring....I happen to pass BR this weekend. It is now Burrito King.  I did a little research and found out that the old owners retired and sold the restaurant to an employee.  He is looking to regain the status of BR to what it used to be.  Check out the article.  I will wait a couple weeks before returning and see if there are any changes.

http://southbrunswick.patch.com/articles/burrito-king-continues-tradition-and-recipes-of-burrito-royale

This burrito place is on US-1 in a small lot by itself. I thought Burrito Royale might be a special "local" place but the reality isn't so. The food was nothing spectacular. I ordered super nachos and the portion size was large.

I'm not sure why this place was reviewed so poorly.  My food there was delicious, and possibly bordering on exceptional.  The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars was because the salad that came with my meal was a little bland-- tasty, but not 5 star material.  While I thought that muenster cheese was an odd choice for Mexican cuisine, it all blended together nicely.  This will definitely be a place that I'll start frequenting.
Burrito is very simple and fresh tasting. We were in a rush but it seemed to take longer than it should have to prepare the food.

business.full_address:
1734 Elton Rd Ste 104
Silver Spring, MD 20903
business.name: Auditory Services Inc

reviews.text: This is an outstanding audiology practice. I have been a "customer" for 8 years, after initial referral by my ENT medical staff and local reviews. Over the years, they have fitted me with two sets of hearing aid instruments--one set in the ear, and eventually one set behind the ear. They did not try to push me to buy unnecessarily expensive solutions. In addition to a good "fitting" experience initially, Auditory Services has provided ongoing support:  periodic adjustments to the programming of the digital hearing aids, a return to the factory fixing one of the Widex aids, and replacement of the tubing on the Phonak behind the ears set. They charge very modest fees (sometimes nothing!) for ongoing maintenance. They really care and provide top professional services.

Really pleasant staff, no hard sales for random hearing aid accessories, and the cheapest prices I've seen for services and parts. I thought I'd have to replace my aids recently, since my former audiologist told me I'd need to get new ones every five years.  However, Auditory Services told me that with an extremely cheap adjustment, I could probably get another 5 years out of my current pair--a LOT of money saved on my part, and essentially a lost sale for them (for now). I really feel like they are working in my best interests, and not just to make money.

business.full_address:
3432 Sansom St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Doc Magrogan's Oyster House

reviews.text:
TL/DR: Dinner for two consisting of a shared appetizer, a drink each, one entree from the menu and one daily special, tax and generous tip for under $80.  Very good, considering the atmosphere.  Will frequent again.
--

Edamame was as expected (hard to me

I was on my way to another nearby establishment for lunch with co-workers the other day and we decided on Doc's instead. We were seated immediately (we requested outdoor seating) and the service was very good. One of my co-workers ordered the Manhattan chowder and said it was very good. She also had the chicken salad and fried oysters and said it was good...but we were all surprised by how much mayo was in the chicken salad after the waiter explicitly said the chicken salad was "light and not a heavy chicken salad." She also had to add salt and pepper. My other co-worker had a salad with a variety of seafood on top. She said it was OK, nothing to write home about, and was disappointed in the lettuce selection. I had the mahi mahi tacos, which were very tasty but could have used a bit of salt. Other than the lack of salt, I had no complaints. Again, our server was excellent so no complaints about the service. I think this place has great potential, but at this price-point, they need to master the flavors and put out excellent quality food. I would definitely return, but I'll probably wait a bit to see if they work out the kinks in the kitchen.

It takes a lot for me to one star a review and sadly Doc's hits it. I waited nearly a week as my writing tends to be incoherent when I am so disappointed/upset with a restaurant.

I came here with a friend to a basically empty restaurant at dinnertime on

OMG! This place was horrendouse from start to finish. The food was mediocre at best and my server John was terrible. When my friend and I arrived for early dinner the place was dead yet thet sat us right next to the only other diners there. There were empty tables EVERYWHERE! Next, our server John just kept talking incessantly and wasnt a good listener. He continuously made mistakes with our order. The oysters were good but everything else was just so so. We ordered orange sesame shrimp(flavors were ok but poor quality shrimp) , grilled octopus ( literally 4 chopped up pieces of octopus),Lobster spring roll ( poorly wrapped in way too thick rice paper and very soggy). I know this place is new but the food should already be on point.

First impression was promising. The outside of the restaurant has an inviting feel. The interior was large but separated into several rooms so it felt partially cozy. The menu had a large variety of options of oysters and seafood but the end product was disappointing. We tried 3 types of oysters and couldn't distinguish one from another. The miso halibut was bland. The Korean BBQ skirt steak was pretty tasty but a bit too rough and the orange sesame shrimp were small, fried, and straight from a lean cuisine. Also the restaurant is too expensive for the quality.

Today was the first day they were open for lunch.  Have been waiting for this!  They took over the old La Terrasse location.  Great decor, old oyster house feel.   Had the mustard crusted tuna sandwich.  The ahi was THE best ahi I have ever had!  Melted in my mouth!  So fresh!  Great service.  The dishes I saw coming out of the kitchen LOOKED great and the 2 gentlemen that sat at the table next to me also said their seafood (shrimp & salmon) was very fresh.  Of course they have an extensive oyster menu as well, though I don't care for oysters.  What a great addition to University City!  Doc Magrogans should do VERY well.  I HIGHLY recommend it

The food here is pretty good, but it's a bit on the pricey side.

My first visit to Doc Magrogan's was for a work happy hour. We started at 4pm, but Magrogan's  starts at 5pm. It was around 4:30pm and I inquired about some oysters and ordered 3 of them. They are about $3 bucks a pop. However, they offer $1 oysters once their happy hour starts. This was pointed out by a co-worker, to which the waiter debated and argued a bit, and was not forthcoming. Since I had to leave at 5pm anyway, I still ordered the more pricey ones. Well, 5pm rolled around, my oysters didn't come, and the table next to me got 2 dozen oysters they ordered after me. I cancelled my order since my time was out.

My second visit was for a colleagues birthday. The food was pretty good. I ordered fish and chips. This was a different waiter. He was nice, but could have been more attentive. After dropping our food off, he did not do the standard check in with us to make sure everything was okay.

Anytime we needed something, we had to flag our waiter down. it would have been nice if he checked in with us more often. Only because the food tasted good did I give this four stars. For service, it's more like 2 stars.

I was really disappointed about my experience. I had high hopes but pretty much everything was terrible. We were greeted and seated in a friendly manner, and our server came over and seemed helpful and nice. We ordered drinks and appetizers and the drinks were good. We received one of our appetizers, 4 oysters, after a short while and also after we were told pretty much every other kind we wanted they were out of. We ordered a tuna appetizer as well but it never came. During our meal when she came to check on us, after we were halfway done, we asked her to please remove the tuna from the check and she said "oh we are out of that, didn't I tell you?" Um no, you didn't. 

Our meals were subpar. My boyfriend got surf n turf- his steak was chewy, his lobster was only partially cooked and it didn't come with anything it said it would on the menu. I got the seafood pasta dish, which was completely flavorless. The seafood in it was good, but the pasta and broth were completely bland- I don't think even salt and pepper were used. 

We didn't want to bother with dessert, so we asked for the check and handed the waitress our groupon (I always wait until the end in case the fact I got a lot of food for half the price makes the server half ass it). She came back with the new check and took my boyfriend's card for the balance. She came back and dropped it on the table and didn't say thank you at all, just walked away. That was probably the second time we saw her anyway, since she pretty much forgot about us the whole meal. 

Our reservation was 7:00 on a Friday- it wasn't packed, there was no wait, so there was no reason for any of that. We might return for happy hour and an appetizer but never, never again for dinner. Especially not for that price! The prices are insane for the quality.

My new favorite happy hour in the city!

My boyfriend and just got home and we talked the whole way home about how great everything was. I purchased a living social deal for $25 and we could spend $50 on dinner, alcohol included. We loved it so much that while we were eating I bought another :). We got there at the last leg of happy hour which was GREAT. We ordered some drinks ($3 beer and $4 house wine), two $5 dollar appetizers (calamari which was cooked to perfection, and the wings which were awesome) and of course, $1 oysters which were phenomonal! The oysters were shucked perfectly and cleaned very well. I was a happy girl. We then shared the mahi tacos which were tasty. I like how they used corn tortillas, it gave the tacos a more authentic taste. It was served with french fries and a malt vinegar aioli which was a great compliment to the fries. There was also a little side of guacamole which I could tell was made fresh. 
We ended our meal with a key lime pie dessert cup (YUM) and a coffee. The total bill? $6.00!!!!!!!!! We were blown away. 

I hope this place never changes. Everything is high-quality and made fresh to order, and I really want them to stick to the way they are doing things, and not turn into a commercial disaster like many other restaurants in University City (except  White Dog, which I love).  Bravo, Doc!!!

This place has potential.   It is super nice to see so many different raw oysters featured.   A great place to sample different kinds.  Not cheap though.   Other items have gotten better more recently and their lunch items offer pretty good value.  The trend is up and I hope they can make it better.

Awesome restaurant! The place is well decorated and makes you feel as if you are at the shore instead of in the middle of  university city. 

Food is great and really flavorful! The lobster bisque is soooo yummy, but very rich, best to share with a friend. I just so happened to stop in during buck a shuck monday and was very impressed. In addition to the soup and oysters I also had the tuna steak which was perfectly cooked and seasoned. 

Can not say enough good things about this place!

came here for happy hour on a monday evening and found it to be a fun experience. the decor, as mentioned by other reviewers is fantastic. i couldnt help but to compare it to the oyster house downtown. in terms of experience it has it's pros and cons. pros:  it's not crowded, even thought it was buck-a-shuck monday (this is a biggie for me because oyster house in center city seems to be perpetually crowded during HH; cons: you can't see the shuckers, and buck-a-shuck only happens on mondays. oh, and all the other food was super OILY. i would come back again for happy hour (mon-fri 5-7pm they have $5 appetizers, $5 wine, $4 cocktails, $3 draft beers).

Came here on an off-peak hour with a friend. Pretty expensive, and even then, service was kinda slow. Got their Perfect Storm seafood combo platter or something like that. It wasn't bad, some pretty good raw oysters. Also ran with a seafood gumbo / pasta of sorts, which actually in my opinion was better than the raw stuff. Food was decent, but probably not worth the price we paid for. Not coming back anytime soon, but I hear they have a decent oyster happy hour that might be more worth it.

Buck-a-shuck Mondays!  I love how close there is a new oyster house so close to my work building.  It's such a pain getting to center city Oyster House and it's always packed for Happy hour.  Now there is another $1 oyster place in the city.  Doc Magrogan's recently opened and is part of a chain.  Their only weekly special so far is the $1 oysters on Mondays from 4-10pm.  They had four different oysters at this price!  Pretty good deal and the oysters were fresh and nicely shucked.  

We also tried some of their regular menu.  I love me some lobster roll but this was a bit disappointing for me.  Comparing to Oyster House, Doc's lobster roll was lacking.  Their bread to lobster ratio was off and didn't have as much flavor.  The crab cake was just alright.  I appreciate being able to see chunks of crab meat but it wasn't spectacular.  

I have been craving fish and chips for a long time (oh Codmother, I miss you).  Doc's fish and chips was pretty terrible.  The batter had absolutely no flavor.  Can you just imagine eating fried paper?  I had to douse it in tartar sauce.  What a shame.

Definitely come here for Buck-a-Shuck Mondays, everything else needs improvement.

i try new places when Google Offers, LivingSocial, or Groupon gives me a restaurant with a good deal so I bought a LivingSocial deal for $25 for $50 worth of food. Also I don't know how a previous Yelper got away with using the deal during happy hour because we couldn't and we asked before ordering..It's for dinner only.

The place is in a pretty good location, on a fairly quiet not-so-busy street, compared too all the university commotions around that area. It's next to White Dog Cafe (which I've never been to) and New Deck Tavern. It's a pretty small place, fairly upscale, but also very loud. We came during happy hour.

We sat at a table next to the bar so it was pretty loud. They have outdoors seating and it looked pretty nice. Nice raw oyster bar too.

OK, onto the food. We started out with the lobster bisque, and half dozen of oysters on the half shell (not from the happy hr menu). We also got their orange shrimp from their happy hr menu which was okay and shared their famous crab cakes. The lobster bisque was pretty good, had a crostini that was topped with a little but of lobster meat on top of the soup. It was a good amount of soup too. We shared the Blue Point oysters and Carraquets which were fine. The shrimp was just okay. Nothing special about them. I think they could've used more crunch. The waitress knew we were sharing the crab cakes so she asked the kitchen to separate them for us which was very nice of her. The crab cakes were actually very delicious. They had it over a honey mustardy slaw and some thinly fried sweet potato strings.

I may come back for their happy hour, but their dinner menu is a bit too pricey for me unless it's for a special occasion. We had a little problem receiving our dinner. The appetizers came out fairly quickly, but then our crab cakes took over half hour to get them. We were just sitting there waiting for them.. It's new in the location so maybe the GM still needs a little practice because we had a couple more problems but were solved immediately. After the Livingsocial deal, we spent $30 including the tip.

What a great place!  The atmosphere is very welcoming with a well trained staff.  My wife and I couldn't decide on an appetizer...so we got two.  

The calamari and edamame with old bay.  The calamari was cooked perfectly so we weren't eating breaded rubber bands like some places.  You could tell it was fresh.  It is similar to Capital Grille's calamari with the hot peppers, but a little better.  I love edamame with old bay and would definitely order it again. 

My wife stuck to her favorite, the crab cakes.  She really enjoyed them and kept saying how there were "such big lumps of crab."  I tried the Seafood Bouillabaisse and oh man was that awesome!  As I am typing I can still remember how great it tasted and want some now!

I highly recommend this place to my friends and family.  Can't wait to go back for oysters on Monday for a "buck a shuck."

Had a great lunch here the other day. I had the Seafood Cob salad and a half dozen oysters. The seafood was cooked perfectly in the salad (I hate overcooked fish). The oysters are right on, with a nice list to choose from and describing the varieties. The bartender was able to give recommendations and was friendly and attentive without being overly in my face. The beer selection was OK but the taps could expand a bit. Price was still seafood high, but better then the annoying-packed place downtown.

Overall experience: not great.

The restaurant is located in a nice area of University City, and street parking was readily available just a block or two away when we arrived at happy hour on a Friday night.

After being ignored for about ten minutes at the bar, we were finally approached by the bartender.  We ordered two beers, and when they were delivered to us, one was incorrect. Mistake fixed quick enough.

Dinner. I ordered the Grilled Swordfish Caponata with fingerling potatoes. The potatoes were so dried out and COLD that I couldn't eat them. Good thing there were only five of them on my plate, so I didn't even bother to send them back. The Caponata sauce was supposed to include capers and kalamata olives, but there was only one half of one olive on my plate! The Swordfish was cooked OK, but it wasn't spectacular.
When my three friends finished eating, they looked at one another and someone asked, "Are you still hungry?" The resounding answer was "Yes."

Since we were all still hungry, we asked to see the dessert plate. To our disappointment, there were five desserts all contained in large shot glasses: layered cakes + mouse.  Not too appealing if you can't eat gluten. 

I would not recommend this restaurant to my friends or family, even if they have Groupon/LivingSocial coupon.  Spend the money elsewhere!

Not a fan.   I know they just opened so i may give it another try.  For now, its Sansom Street Oyster House for me.  They had a nice selection of Raw Bar but the cooked items were bland.  My oysters were also room temp so i couldn't even finish them.

business.full_address:
6 Market St
Ste 904
Plainsboro, NJ 08536
business.name: A&G Italian Fine Foods

reviews.text:
Had two nearly identical experiences here, each of which involved stopping in for take out food during off-peak experiences - and I agree with the others here; the food is amazing!  Had a flatbread pizza the first time, and a great sandwich (chicken panini, think) the second time.  They were quick and the food was great.  

Though I think there were a few tables, doesn't really seem like a place you would for a sit down meal.  And were I a local, I'd definitely want to explore some of the catering take-out items.  Looks like a great selection, and if it's anything like their lunch entrees, I suspect it's great.

Thumbs up A&G!

This was my go-to place for years. Then two out of the last three visits were not good not even worthy of one star:(
The beef is no longer tender. Out of an entire portion I ate one or two bites. Even with a steak knife it could not be cut. Too much salt on the overdone pasta and too much pepper on the under cooked veggies. Nothing was right. Same last month. The lasagna in the display case looks old and dried out. So does that lunch meat.  I used to love this place but it seems like it will be out of business in no time. You just can't serve inedible unsafe  food. There is still a chance for this place to save it's self. Go back to the way you were, use the best ingredients, only use fresh foods and you won't be losing loyal customers like me...

Waited 20 minutes for 1 sandwich (seriously). Over-priced for what you get. Just OK as far as the food goes. The chicken cutlet was so thin it was like I was eating a fried breading sandwich with cheese.

Awesome Food!
killer sandwiches & pizzas... great atmosphere.
The best A&G I've been to. This place makes a great lunch spot, or for a quick bite.

Would be 5 star if the deli service was a little faster.

A&G was literally the first place I came to when I initially moved to NJ and was in search for decent food.  While I typically take my order to-go from this location, I had the pleasure of dining in earlier this week.  Ordered their Special Foccacia (~$8), which they cooked in their brick oven, along with their Di Casa salad, with olives on the side ($9).  While waiting, they brought out their awesome homemade bread, covered in cheese and garlic awesomeness.  Both dishes were delicious, per usual.  I'm always a fan of their Portobello panini on foccacia bread ($8), which contains a nice piece of portobello (not surprisingly) and grilled chicken, along with roasted peppers and their fresh mozzarella.  While I think I have a big appetite, I can usually eat half for dinner, and save the 2nd half for lunch the next day.
Was slightly peeved that they automatically put in 18% tip (I'm already a pretty nice tipper, but please don't tell me what I should be giving as gratuity unless I have a party of 6 or more), but all in all, a great place to grab a bite.

Try the cannolis here -- they're very good.  The sandwiches and entrees are also pretty good, although you may wait for a bit if you order from the deli.  This is a great place for a lunch stop while you're in Plainsboro, the atmosphere is very casual and relaxed, and they have a few gourmet Italian foods you can pick up to take home as well.

Take out is also available, and they have a lot of options on the menu.

business.full_address:
304 W 115th St
Harlem
Manhattan, NY 10026
business.name: Marcel Cleaners

reviews.text: VERY overpriced, and the worst customer service I've ever experienced. The man at the counter gave me a pickup day and time when I dropped everything off. When I arrived to pick it up, he informed me that only some of my pieces were ready. He made no apology, and was very rude when I said I was disappointed. If that's the owner... wow!  If it's not, the owner should certainly fire him immediately. I would not want someone like that representing my business, that's for sure. For what they charge, they should be ashamed of themselves. From now on I'll go to the place on 117th street that Kevin mentioned in his review.

Was a customer there for years and even went back when things were repeatedly pressed improperly.  It got to a point where I just checked everything before I left.  Then I got there right at 7pm (closing), I realized it was late and asked if I could pick up now or should I try back the next day.  They never even acknowledged I was speaking to them.  I now go to a great little place on 117th St just off FDB (8th) toward Morningside Park.

business.full_address:
993 Amsterdam Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: Mugi Pottery

reviews.text:
The information provided about the "Couples Night" is completely misleading.  What they don't tell you is that you are only allowed to make slab or coil forms -- the same building techniques third graders use in art class.  Even though every picture on the website shows either people throwing on the wheel or completed projects that were thrown on the wheel, as a customer, you don't get to go near one.

I've taken advanced pottery classes in the past, so, as a part of my Christmas gift, my girlfriend signed us up for one of the Couples Nights thinking that I would enjoy working on the wheel as well as teaching her.  We were both incredibly disappointed to learn that we had been misled.  Despite the fact that the site doesn't explain what couples can and cannot make -- and that this was a Christmas presents -- no refund was offered when we tried to cancel.

I really, really wish we could have saved our money and, more importantly, our disappointment.

Mugi Pottery Studio is a really nice place to take pottery classes, or to shop for pottery, and even paintings. They are a gallery in front, and a studio in the back for beginners and experienced potters of all kinds. I took a class on a whim at the beginning of summer, and it was so great. Like Yoga for the hands. They've been in the upper west side for years, and have even, I think, been a location for a movie. The teachers are so nice and patient, letting you do what you like while guiding you at the same time.

And DO check their $5 and $20 bins for a lucky find on your way out!

I took an 8 week course, it was alright. I learned some things about pottery and it's actually a lot harder than I thought. Margo and the others were friendly. I thought it was kind of intimidating because of all the different level of skills. I think I would've done better with private lessons or same level students because my anxiety. Also made some things but when I came back to finish working on them, they were gone so idk I was disappointed about that.

I was a student here for a while before I hurt my foot and had to stop going. As a pottery experience in NYC it might be very high quality but you need to be prepared for the fact (not provided up front) that if you can't go to the "free hours" on the weekends you won't really be able to do any projects because every time you get there to your weekly session you will find out that the bowl you made last week is either still wet or too dry to trim. Also, the studio is always very crowded and you have to kind of weave your way past people to get around the table. My spot on the shelves was very high up and for whatever reason people always piled stuff up on the stepladder so I always had to put other people's stuff away before I could start.

Also, when I injured myself I asked for a refund of unused classes and was denied.

Overall though the teachers and fellow students are friendly and helpful, so... 3 stars. Recommended if you have the spare time to devote on weekends and lack claustrophobia.

I've been going to Mugi for years and this place is friendly and amazing. I strongly recommend signing up for classes or simply buying some of the beautiful and unique hand-made pottery. If you are looking for a non-judgmental, friendly and welcoming/warm atmosphere to make or shop for pottery, go to Mugi!

I took a class at the beginning of summer and loved it! The teachers and fellow class mates were all very friendly. It's a very laid back atmosphere. A great place to get creative and yet learn a new skill. I am definitely going to continue with a class i

business.full_address:
45 Everett Dr
Ste 140
West Windsor, NJ 08550
business.name: Sky High Energy

reviews.text: be careful.

Be very careful.  got a salesrep at home indicating that they were running an ad promo giving away systems for free.  that is not the case.  you are taking out a 30K load from PSE&g which you are liable for paying in case you sell the house.  Please make yourself aware by reading the PSE&G FAQ at http://www.pseg.com/customer/solar/faq_residential.jsp

business.full_address:
3191 Brunswick Pke
Lawrenceville, NJ 08648
business.name: Joe's Crab Shack

reviews.text: All I can say is ... Hell. Yes. I don't need to speak about the food, just try it yourself. If I had to decide between Red Lobster and here, you can believe I'll be rolling over here.

I always had a craving for Joe's Crab ESPECIALLY after watching the countless commercials on their steampots! The one where the people's hair are flying in a tornado. So, I came across this location closest to NY to try their seafood. We had such a great time! It reminded me of my trip a few summers ago to Daytona, FL. 

Our waiter stringed "Let's Get Crackin" bibs around us. The waiters and waitresses perform a few dances to Cotton Eyed Joe, Cha Cha Slide, and other 80's tunes which was pretty entertaining. It's a very laid-back and mellow atmosphere. 

For some reason, it was everyone's birthday. About 8 cakes were brought out and announced to everyone while belting happy birthday tunes. Unlike the typical dining leisure, this place really brings out the relaxed and fun side of us. 

We shared the Great Balls of Fire for an appetizer: jalapeno, shrimp, and crab balls with cheddar & sour cream was really good. It also included a side of fries. 

I had the Ragin Canjun steampot- 1 pound of dungeness/snow crabs, shrimp, potatoes, fresh corn, and sausage all spiced up cajun style. My husband had the Key West Chicken glazed with mango jalapeno sauce with crabmeat and rice. My sisters both shared the Bean TownBake for two- 2 whole lobsters, 1 pound of clams & shrimp, sausage, fresh corn, and sausage. My brother had the Samuel Adam's Steampot- 1 pound of Alaskian King Crab, 1 pound shrimp, potatoes, fresh corn and sausage flavored in Samuel Adams and a bit of Old Baye seasoning. 

In the end, it was messy and good ole fun! We were trading here and there to sample our steampots. I think the overall experience is a lot better than Red Lobster. More seafood and a table full of shells & laughs. For dessert, we shared the Key Lime Pie w/ whipped cream and the Sea Turtle Sundae-Chocolate cake a la mode topped with caramel and candied nuts. Key Lime was definitely not as good or famous as Daytona but it did the job. It's def worth checking out esp for a night out with friends or a casual birthday dinner!

First time I went here was in Virginia, either Chesapeake, Virgina Beach, or Norfolk.  Either way, it was really good.  Tried the one in Jersey, first time I went, the wait was insane and my sister and I had to leave.  The second time I went, we went early, got seated and enjoyed ourselves.  The steam pots are delicious.  Been here a few times since, food is always great, but I only get the steam pots.

What can you say about Joe's Crab Shack?  The place is a restaurant and a party mixed together.  No wonder there's an hour and fifteen minute wait.  This place is nuts.  Super crowded.  Super loud.  Super fun.  Staff is pretty animated both at your table and away from it.  Every twenty minutes or so a song pops on that the whole staff will start dancing to.  Also, good luck if it's your birthday because you'll be getting up out of your seat and acting like some type of animal (usually a horse or bird).  Oh yeah, the food is pretty intense as well.  Loved my Samuel Adams steam pot.  They have great combos of shell fish pots.  You will have to work for your food with all the cracking and peeling you'll be doing with the crab, lobster and shrimp.  I must say its all worth it to me.  Food and atmosphere are great.  Will run you about $25 a person.  Probably not the best first date spot.  I say if you don't mind waiting for a seat or getting a little messy, check out Joe's.  It's a good time!

So my brother and I decided to stop in to Joe's for lunch.  The place looks very cool and spacious and the staff are really personable and nice, but the food leaves a lot to be desired.  This place is a one in a medium sized chain of restaurants hence the bowl of fried oysters appearing deeper than it actually was.  The oysters were also obviously from the freezer so the flavor was lackluster to say the least.  My brother ordered a crab cake sandwich and it arrived resembling nothing like a crab cake.  It looked more like bits of yellowy frozen crab bits that have been re-fried in butter and spread over a little portion of the bun.  My fish and chips were greasy as hell and the fish was again, frozen and yellowy.  Is it so hard to serve non frozen food at a seafood place?  
Overall I think you are better to keep driving and find another place that puts a little more care into the preparation of their food.

Coming from NYC, you're on the road for at least an hour and a half.  But if you're into seafood and road trips, this one is worth the wait.

Let's keep it simple.  If you go at night, you will be waiting at least an hour for a table.  Once you sit down,

Great bang for your buck! I was dying to try this for years after seeing numerous commercials! Unfortunately we didn't have one close to us in NY but it was definitely worth the wait! The lobster nachos to start was good although I could have used more of the lobster mix on the chips. The crab was amazinnnnnnng and dessert was the perfect end ;) we got campfire s'mores and it was just perfect.

I LOVE Crab, and Joes is all about crab. My food was yummy, and the atmosphere friendly! I wasn't a big fan of the side dish (steamed red potatoes, steamed with the crab), but other than that LOVED my meal! I will be back (prob. by myself since my husband is allergic to shellfish- we went for mothers day because I bugged him LOL). 

Oh, and  FYI my meal was only $22- I had the classic (mixture of old bay and scampi seasoning- yum) and switched it up a bit- only snow crab legs (2 bunches), and peel and eat shrimp (not a fan of sausage etc.), steamed potatoes and steamed corn came with it as well. The bar looked good, but I don't drink when I have my toddler with me :(

If heaven were a restaurant, it would be called Joe's Crab Shack. And seafood lover's, you're missing out on one hell of an experience if you've yet to dine here. This was my first time and our menu selections were the crab nachos (delicious), calamari (p

Yummmm!!!! I LOVE Joes Crab Shack!!! This was our second trip there over the past 2 months. I love the fun atmosphere! We had the steampot both times, me the sunset fire grilled and my wife the diablo. Both were phenomenal! The seafood is cooked to perfection,  reasonably priced, and nice sized portions. The andouille sausage that comes with the succulent crabs is amazing!!!! 
Go To This Place!!! You will have a blast (great for a birthday dinner as the do more than just sing, they REALLY embarrass the bday victim!)
Just wish there was one closer!!!
Best crab and seafood in Princeton Area.  The service is great.  Well recommended.

Would I call Joe's a Crab shack? No. The crab is mediocre and  so is the seafood. the interior and outside design is very appealing and inviting. The prices are okay, but the line is always long. I cannot say i would return here for some above average seafood...

Came first time on Sunday and really enjoyed the atmosphere; the waiters and waitresses would dance every now and then and ppl just seem to have a good time all around. 

As for food, we end up ordering the Dungeness Crab (BBQ flavor) and the crab dip for appetizer. The crab dip was a bit too salty, but the BBQ Dungeness Crab was pretty good; had lots of fun cracking the shells with the little tools they provide. The yellow little tools are very handy and have "Stolen from Joe's Crab Shack" printed on them, so you need to make sure that gets done! 

Overall, a good place to hang out with friends and enjoy some crabs, go get them!

This place exceeded my expectation. Three of us went there for lunch and it was not crowded.  

We shared three baskets/pots: 
New Orleans (craw fish, shrimp, sausage) + fire grilled flavor
Big daddy feast (all three kinds of crabs) + famous BBQ flavor
Snow crab basket  +  Spicy boil 

Crabs were obviously frozen, but you really cannot ask for live ones here in Princeton. They still taste very fresh and tender.

The spice it up flavor is actually quite spicy (we all eat a considerable amount of spice), but we still enjoyed it when eating it together with the classic flavors. 

Service is amazing: manager comes to check if everything is OK, gives you a free appetizer for next time, and they also take a picture of your group.

Second time around was even better at this place. I've been to the Joe's Crab Shack in LA but I don't remember enjoying the food there as much as here in this location in Jersey.

Friendly staff and good seafood.

My husband and I spotted Joe's on the highway driving back to NY from PA.  I'm not a fan of chains usually, but my husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our Fire Grilled Steampot of crabs and shrimp!  By no means high-end considering you're wearing a paper bib and throwing shells into a metal bucket, but it hit the spot!  The seafood was fresh and well-seasoned, IMO. 

The 45 minute wait wasn't fun, but the place was busy and patrons tend to stick around longer on a Sunday evening.  When we were seated the service was quick and our waitress was very attentive.

1st and last time to joes...   The hostess told us it would be an hour and 20 minutes for a table when we got there, which seemed odd because there were empty tables not being bussed and the staff appeared to be all hanging out by the server station.   My suspicions were correct and we got our seat in about 30 minutes.  That was the best part of the meal.  

Our seat was way off in the corner of the bar area, and it smelled like old, stickey beer.  It took our server 15 minutes before she even came over and acknowledged us.  I watched her sing happy birthday, take a desert order, give a table their check and get them change before she took our drink and dinner order.  

We ordered king crab legs and sodas.  Our drinks came out fast and so did the melted butter for our crabs.  We then sat there for 40 minutes with zero contact from any staff.   Our server must have had to run home to add the fabric softener, because she was nowhere to be found for the entire time.  After 40 minutes of watching their lackluster and disorganized staff go through the motions, what appeared to be a manager approached our table with the food.  I say "appeared" because this is the same guy who was standing at the server station chatting with his staff while customers were told it would be an hour and a half for a table while there were empty tables sitting for 10 to 15 minutes without being cleaned off and seated.  He walked over like frankenstein and said this and only this: "this is the old bay and this is the garlic".  

The server came over and said that was her manager and she was very sorry for the wait.  She confirmed our ticket had sat there for 40 minutes and finally she had to go "talk to someone in the back".  I can just imagine how that talk went.  "wow it finally slowed down, it's almost empty out there.  Hey, what's that behind those boxes?" 

Well we got the crab legs, they were mediocre.  She forgot the hush puppies, whatever.  Some people sat down next to us, ordered and had their food in 10 minutes while we ate our very fishy smelling crab legs.  The quality of the crab seemed low, probably frozen.  And the way it's prepared makes the shell bend instead of break.  

Anyway,  the two orders of crab legs and two sodas cost me 90 bucks.  I could have done a lot more with that money.

First time at a Joe's Crab Shack - I ordered the Paella, nothing like the real thing however I give it a higher rating because the calamari and shrimp apps were very good and the crab legs were REALLY good!!  LOVE the atmosphere and enjoyed dancing the Time Warp and YMCA with the staff! LOL

My boyfriend and I decided to splurge here. We came around 3pm so it wasn't crowded. It was our first time here and we were super hungry.For drinks, we got  their limited time in mason jars, country sweet tea (very good) and strawberry lemonade (both spiked haha)   

We started out with the crab nachos which hit the spot; generous with the toppings and very tasty. For our entrees, we both got the steampots. He got the sam adam's steampot (included 2 lobster claws, snow crabs, clams, andouille sausage, sweet corn) and I got the Joe's classic steampot (shrimp, cluster of snow crabs, dungeness crab, sweet corn, and andouille sausage).. honestly though, both flavors tasted about the same. 

We were filled in the end and if we ever wanted to splurge again, we'd definitely come back!

My wife saw the commercial and we hit the road. After a nice long drive from NYC we arrive at a small restaurant with high expectations. 

We were delighted by the staff as the gentleman was very informative. He made quality recommendations about drinks and meal choices. After a few minutes we were ready to order, the portions of food was pretty large. 

Everything tasted fresh, the seasoning was spot on. The plates was well worth the drive. The drinks were also delicious and well sized. We went on a Wednesday so we had no wait and pretty much had the place to ourselves. There is a small play area for children which proved useful as my 6 year old needed to burn off some energy and my wife needed finih up her food. I did mention that the portions are large. 

We were very happy we made the trip!

me and my husband went here tonight omg it was great the atmosphere is fun and the food is great i was pleasently suprised ! we def will be returning there again there cheesecake is awesome too.....only thing i would change is the seat the picnic benches are a little hard on your back

After they renovated, this place is better than ever.  Friends and I stop by here on the way home from philly.  Yes, we go to philly just for cheesesteaks.  Greeted by two hostesses.  One seemed friendly, the other looked like she didn't want to be there.

Our waitress was the amazing "Amanda P."  She had a smile on her face, was friendly, got our drinks fast!  Oh yea, order the "Shark Bite" drink.  It's Blue Curacao and some other liquor in it.  Then the waitresses pours some red liquid sugar into the drink.  The liquid is cleverly contained in a toy shark.  So get it?  "Shark bite"

Food wasn't great but it wasn't horrible.  The paella i got there was so-so.  Why 4 stars when food was so-so?  Clean bathrooms, fast service, GREAT service, souvenir toy shark, AND i bought a T-shirt there that says "got crabs?".

Only based on one visit but....

A group of about 20 of us took a roadtrip here from Philadelphia. We called ahead and warned them that we would be there in an hour and they made it seem like they would be ready to receive us when we arrived, however, we ended up having to wait for about 45-60mins to be seated. After that though things were great. Our server was really fun and nice - he even got in on some of the jokes going around the table. The food was as good I remembered it from the last time I was at a Joe's. Prices are what you would expect for seafood and the portion size is always smaller than in the commercials. It was also really loud. All in all I had an awesome time but probably more so because of the roadtrip then the destination.

I LOVE SEAFOOD... 
...But my meal at Joe's was greasy, disgusting, overcooked and just plain blah! I really have nothing good to say about it, besides the fact my friend and I were promptly seated. It was so loud in there and it's one of the annoying chain places that do annoying songs and dances randomly. With most kitschy chain places, I just grin and bear the pain because it's all in good fun... but here it was just annoying as hell! I hate Red Lobster, but I'd sooner go there than back to Joe's Crab Shack, and I went there once in my life on a field trip for Cub Scouts. haha. But I'll stick to paying way too much for seafood at normal non-chain original overpriced restaurants to retain my sanity and stomach. Amen. haha

P.S. hey buddy-beneath-me, this is not quality seafood. May I ask a question... Is this even seafood?

P.S.S. I went here because a friend made me go! He had worked in one in Delaware. I also had a student teacher in high school who worked at this location and she said it was... interesting, to say the least. I was nervous to eat here and rightfully so.

My wife and Mom-in-Law had lived in Eastern Shore MD and miss eating buckets of crabs.  For that, this place is great.  Never a complaint on the whole crabs.  As for the rest of the entres and appetizers, it's hit and miss.  We enloy the entertainment of the waitstaff dancing in the aisles!

Overall it was a pretty bad experience.  First off, I know that Joe's Crab Shack is like the Denny's of seafood and I wasn't expecting too much, but at least three of the people in our group got food that was near inedible.  Next off, the service was horrible.  The place wasn't even half full and we waited over an hour to get our food.  One of my friends' orders was lost entirely and he didn't receive his food until after everyone else had finished.  Though I will say my meal was good, using Old Bay seasoning as a selling point seems pretty ridiculous, especially considering you can get it at almost any grocery store.  Drinks came incredibly slowly, if at all, and I personally never got the drinks I ordered, always the wrong drink.  When we complained to the manager she had the gall to yell at us.  It was a horrible dining experience and I don't plan to ever go to Joe's again.

My fiance and I went there just last night and i have to say, we had a great time! If you're looking for a romantic place where you can whisper to your date across the table Joe's is NOT for you. It has a fun and lively atmosphere which is quite infectious. There was a little bit of a wait when we got there, but it was no more than 30 minutes tops.
