Once we were seated, our waiter was table side in a matter of seconds taking our drink orders. I was quite impressed that he got our order correct without ever writing down a thing or asking twice. We started off with the crab nachos which were just too good to put down! Everything tasted fresh and was well seasoned. The portion size was just enough for the two of us to be satisfied and not waste a thing. 
The food itself wasn't as abundant as I had thought it would have been but it turned out to be the perfect portion leaving me satisfied in the end. My future hubby and I both ordered "Joes Classic Steampot" the crab was DELICIOUS however the shrimp was EXTREMELY over done. Their corn is to die for, its so sweet and delicious, it will leave you wanting another ear. I had an order of coconut shrimp on the side which was very tasty and perfectly cooked. For dessert my hubby ordered the key lime pie, it was the first time I've ever had key lime and I must say it tasted great! 
With all that said I will be returning to Joe's in Lawrenceville again soon! Its a great place to bring your family and friends for some good food and a good time!

i came all the way to new jersey for this so it was GOOD

yes i do agree it's not the freshest seafood but this place is all about the fill-your-belly FUN - the drinks come in big glasses and the seafood comes in a big bucket (i like BIG)

throughout the night, all the waiters dance around to 80's music, i'm sure they hate it and i usually hate it but this place puts me in that mood that genuinely enjoys the silliness

come with a big group of friends, make it someone's birthday even if it's not. in the end there will be a hula hooping contest involved and you will fight to win

bonus - they have t-shirts that says "I GOT CRABS" with a cute picture of a crab. yes i bought one and i love it!

I'm a regular at Joe's, and I must say that it's one of my favorites. In fact, it became one of my favorites the first time I stepped in the door. I usually have my two goddaughters with me when I go (it's on the way between my home and theirs), and it's their "most favoritist" place in the world to eat.

Joe's is a fun, family-friendly place with outstanding food, reasonable prices, and a magnificently gawdy decor. There's a big sign on the side that actually says "EAT AT JOE'S", and the interior is decorated with all sorts of maritime- and fishing-related paraphernalia.

Joe's also has the most relaxed, most family-friendly environment of any high-quality restaurant I've ever patronized. They have hula hoops and other toys, an outdoor playground for the kids, and a guy who makes balloon animals. In addition, all the servers do little dance numbers every 20 minutes or so, and guests are encouraged to join in and dance with them.

The servers -- who dress in jeans and tee-shirts to help set the relaxed mood -- are truly exceptional. My girls routinely go around and hug them  all -- they have come know them by name -- as soon as we walk in, and this doesn't bother the staff in the least. I reprimanded the girls the first time they did it, but I was told not to worry about it -- that they were glad the kids felt at home because that's exactly the mood they want to create.

As for the food, it is exceptionally good. All the food is always fresh and each meal is cooked to order, however, so this is not a place to go if you're in a hurry (or if you're anal). Order some appetizers and drinks and let yourself unwind while you wait for your entree. Get up and dance with the waitstaff. Sing along, too. Or grab a hula hoop if you want: they're hanging on the wall by the restrooms. No one will mind. Really. The food is well worth the wait, so have fun.

The specialty, of course, is crabs, which are served in many different ways. There are also other seafood dishes, of which I've tried maybe half over the course of time. All have been excellent. Like most seafood restaurants, there also are steaks and other non-seafood dishes available for non-fish lovers. The only one I've tried has been the steak, which was excellent. The appetizers also are novel and delicious. (Don't miss the Crazy Good Crab Dip. It's, well, crazy good.)

The prices at Joe's are moderate, but still a very good value considering the quality of the food. They're certainly less expensive than many other seafood restaurants of lesser caliber. The pre-tax, pre-tip tab for appetizers, main course, desert, and soft drinks for myself and the two kids (who order adult portions of crabs -- these kids are no slouches when it comes to eating) is usually around $70.00 - $80.00 at Joe's, which really isn't bad at all for a quality seafood dinner for three.

The portions at Joe's are about right, which is to say that they're generous, but not excessive. Crabs and seafood in general don't lend themselves too well to doggy bags because they don't reheat well. Nonetheless, we usually manage to have some leftovers to take home.

In summary, if you like shellfish and aren't too anal to enjoy a place where the wait staff dances and hip boots hang from the ceiling, be sure to give Joe's a try.

business.full_address:
3943 Chestnut St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Papa John's

reviews.text:
Standard Papa Johns. They honor coupons you call in, and they don't collect it so you can keep on saving :)

Spotty service (aka they move slow).

Typical Papa John's. Not much in the way of seating, but somehow monopolized the Penn campus events circuit for pizza.

I always like the hot peppers, and the butter/oil solution is a great way to swallow their crust (thicker than the average New York style). Totally unhealthy, and light on the toppings at times, but overall not bad.

Regular mistakes in orders, poor service, long wait times.  I would also consider checking with the Philadelphia board of health; in-store conditions at my last visit were reminiscent of a Dunkin' Donuts in the NYC subway.

As of today I order from Domino's.

business.full_address:
Powelton Village
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Price Is Right Plumbing & Drain Cleaning

reviews.text:
I am sorry to say I did not have a good experience with price is right. They were initially responsive and return my phone calls quickly to set up a time. However they were very expensive for a relatively simple job. My leak was bad so I went with it. 

I left my husband home while Troy worked and when it was finished I came home to find the tub spout more than a 1/4 inch away from the tile wall and a deep scratch in the tub underneath it. I could put my pinky finger between the wall and spout and see the pipe. It was about 5:40 when I called and asked them to come fix it, the man said he would have Troy come back tonight and fix the problem. Troy called and asked if he could do it another day, when we said we would rather it be tonight....he finally showed up at 9:40pm after we called him again at 7:30 to see if he was still coming.

He tried to "fix" it by cutting the pipe which made the whole thing not work and leak water out the back. then he informed us the problem was the spout he bought uses a screw at the bottom, it is not the threaded kind like the original. Well... He bought the thing, installed it and then left with our money like it was done correctly. And now he is telling us it is the wrong faucet. Needless to say he had to come back the next day with the right part. And to top it all of he left a mess of plumbing grease dripping down the tub underneath the faucet.

So after my very long story, they did bad work and it was very obvious they didn't care about doing a good job, putting the right parts on or about fixing their work.

I would not use them again.

I called and one of their plumbers came out within the hour and solved the problem.  James educated me on backflow issues with the house.

They really do take 24 hour emergency calls.

I called James Price of the Price is right Co. He and his colleague, Troy came out within under an hour. They were very courteous, nice, helpful and impeccably honest they fixed my drain issue really fast and for a great price, too. They also threw in a free inspection of my home pipes to let me know things that may be an issue down the road... but didn't find anything (which tells me that they are honest they didn't "find" a huge problem they would have to come out for).

My initial experience, late last year, with Price Is Right Plumbing and Drain Cleaning was positive, so I contacted them again last week to replace two toilets in my home. The owner was helpful over the phone. However, Troy, the employee, was unprofessional during the estimate. I was told that he would contact me by a certain day/time to schedule a time to do the job and confirm the price. I did not hear from Troy until well after the agreed upon time. Troy is not dependable and seemed to have an "I don't care" attitude. He was a poor representation of the company. Needless to say, I did not hire Price Is Right Plumbing and Drain Cleaning and will not recommend their services to anyone.

This company is a rare find - honest, courteous, and experts at what they do. They are simply amazing. They're straight shooters, get the job done, and guarantee their work.  Great guys, solid work, and reasonable rates. Everything they've done has lasted. This is the second project I've had them out for, and the only company I would use.

Wow, rip off. So I called about a leak in my 1st floor ceiling. The bathroon ceiling that was leaking is right below the 2nd floor bathroom. I aksed them to come out to fix it. I got a call back from Clarence (maybe Terrence not really clear) and was told it was $119 just for him to come out. I asked if the $119 went towards the cost of the repair and was told "If I didnt charge people to come out and tell them what was wrong I'd be cuttin my own throat". Who says that to someone whose home they want to go into? Extremely unprofessional would not recommend.

Called a few other places that either didn't call back, or got quoted a ton!  Called Price is Right and Troy called back in two minutes.  Then he was at my house in under 30 minutes.  Didn't try to hit me up for a big job, just popped my drain and charged me a totally reasonable fee to clean it out.  Also quoted a very reasonable rate if he needs to come back and snake it later.  Easy, cheap, just what I needed.  Thanks Troy!

I called three plumbers to get estimates for a gas line install.  All three came out and looked at the job, and gave me a price.  Price-is-right was by far the most expensive estimate I got.  They were charging almost exactly twice the cost of the guy we ended up using.  All of the places we looked at were fairly highly rated on Yelp (licensed, and insured and all that stuff).  In all fairness, when they outlined the work they planned on doing, price-is-right planned on using more high-end pipes.  But I couldn't justify spending an extra $800 for that.  The guy who came out to the house was nice, he answered all my questions.  The deciding factor was really cost.  The price was definitely NOT right at price-is-right.

I came home at 6:30 on Sunday to find my basement flooded and water spraying all over the place. I couldn't find the valve for the broken pipe and had to turn off water for the whole house-so no flushing, bathing, etc. I don't have a plumber, so I called several plumbers and Price is Right were the first to get back to me. Troy was at my place w/in an hour.  He found the right valve so we could turn the water back on, then came back Monday morning to replace the pipe and move the valve to a location I could reach. Getting here on a Sunday night really saved me.

business.full_address:
20 S 36th St
University City
Philadelphia, PA 19104
business.name: Axis Cafe/Stratum Cafe

reviews.text: Given the number of so-so food trucks with long lines of scrub-wearing dental hygienist and nursing assistant students, $8 for lunch isn't a bad option for this part of town.  The food's not terrible here and it's pretty clean.  They don't take credit cards, so bring cash.

This full-service apartment complex opens it's ground-floor dining area to anyone who walks in.  It's your basic cafeteria, one step up from university dining.  $7.95 all-you-can-eat lunch, with a decent salad bar and dessert bar, and a few choices for entrees.  Not great, but if you're sick of the limited selection around Penn and want someplace you can sit down and not spend too much money, this isn't a bad choice.
I eat here about three to four times a week. If you're affiliated with Penn, you can get the all you can eat for $6. I love the entrees most of the time.

i live above this "cafe" so for me it is super convenient.  perfect on rainy and cold days  . . .just head on down the escalator.  it is a cafeteria set up but is very clean.  they also have giant tv's with remote controls so you can change the channel. they do now accept credit cards with no minimum purchase.  i like the chicken fingers and fries which cost me $5.13.  I think thats pretty cheap for university city.  most places want at least $9 for chicken fingers.
Don't order from Axis - estimate was 30 mins, took 1.5 hours to go 4 blocks. Food arrived cold. Marinara tastes like tomato soup. Nothing to recommend it.

This cafeteria serves the cheapest lunch in University City. The customer service is pretty good - everyone who worked there was attentive and friendly. My passable chicken cheesesteak cost less than four bucks. 

The downside is that it is a cafeteria. Think of the connotations of the word 'cafeteria.' No one eats in a cafeteria if they can help it, except for those weirdos who love Old Country Buffet. And that type of person, generally speaking, is probably not wandering about the vicinity of the University of Pennsylvania at 12-1pm. The kind of people who do mill around this area are usually chained to meal plans requiring them to eat in this type of setting anyway, which would explain why it was completely empty the day I went. Who passes up cafeteria food for more cafeteria food? It's also located in the the basement of the building, hence no windows. No windows plus lunch on a tray is no one's idea of a good time. I couldn't help but have horrible flashbacks to college while I was eating.

business.full_address:
6500 Capitol Dr
Greenbelt, MD 20770
business.name: Capitol Cadillac Company

reviews.text: THIS BUSINESS IS A TIE WITH COMCAST AS THE WORST COMPANY IN THE DC/MD/VA AREA!!!!!!!!!! Where do I begin? First of all, they keep ur car for weeks lying to you about when it will be done. Then when  you get there, they tell you...oops, we messed up, someone forgot to put the light in... can you come back? Then you come back to get fixed what they messed up b/c you couldn't leave ur car for a lightbulb after they had it for 3 weeks... when you get there the second time, you get ur car and it has a dent in the bumper and scratches on the side that they just fixed and painted. They say oops, come back and we will fix it... You come back weeks later mad as hell.. they have an entire new staff who can't remember crap because the company is so bad they can't keep employees and everyone is miserable. You leave ur car there again... now they mess up the entire insurance pay out and try making u pay extra... I call a manager... Instead of the manage refunding $ to me, he refunds my insurance instead amd I am still stuck with the overpriced bill. Again, the have a third manager and you just give up trying to explain urself because ur so happy it's finally fixed. Besides, the other department on the other side of the building handles this and they are new as well and don't communicate to the service dept for crap... A week goes by... ur car starts having electrical problems and the battery is dead...you give up and go to the greatest repair shop in the world on Kalorama in columbia heights (plug because I am so impressed- ATS-automotive tech services). They find the problem. It's the fact that the battery that Capitol installed shorted out circuits in my lights and killed the battery. I decide to YELP and warn the world to RUN!!!!!!!! I know my stuff and I am telling you BEWARE! I heard other complaints while I was there. This place plain sucks! It's a $ factory. They RIP YOU OFF... My bill was thousands and ATS charged me only $140 for what they charged over 2G!!!!!!! They BLOW!!!!!!! You have to be an idiot to go here... Where are the rest of the reviews... They probably used abused customers' $ to pay off YELP to remove them! Look at the other review.... You've been warned!!!!!!!

Ok, let's get started. I went into this place to get an estimate for rims and tires. First of all the darn lady running the parts dept. has not a clue of how to look up tires. Ok mam why are you working the desk in the "parts" dept? She advised us to get a "vin #" why in the Hott hell would you need a vin for tires, really!  Then she proceeded to tell us to go the service dept. where they said for us to go to the collision center. Ok damn Capitol Cadillac, it is 100 degrees outside damn walking from place to place!! Then we get there to the collision dept. and this MF is asking crazy questions like we were there to get some work done on the truck (accident or something), which we weren't (and we had already informed him of this, and his lazy ass didn't even want to pull the vin up, once again WHY do u need a vin for an estimate of tires that don't originally come on the car anyway? Of course, I did my homework before asking for the darn sizes so (I knew they would fit). WTH?? So once we got on the phone to get the vin, we asked how long was the printout estimate of the tires and rims gonna take. This man said we should have made an "appointment" to retrieve an estimate, that is crazy as hell! Why would you need an appointment for a printout! Really lazy ass people. And then how can you make an appointment when you are always getting put on hold for like 30mins. and never coming back to the darn phone or just plain hanging up on you when they tell you to hold on?  I'm done with Capitol!!!!!!  They are some ish!

I never have a bad experience at this location. The staff are friendly. I will admit, the wait time can be a little extensive, but thanks to the invention of a customer lounge which includes wifi, coffee, TV, and reading material, you can not be bored.

business.full_address:
961 Columbus Ave
Manhattan Valley
New York, NY 10025
business.name: 107 Rainbow Cleaners

reviews.text:
Definitely the worst experience I've ever had at a dry cleaners. They took all the buttons off of my Diane Von Furstenberg blouse (which incidentally said Diane Von Furstenberg on them, well actually her initials DVF). I think these people remove the buttons from nice clothing and then put them on clothing that they make and try to pass them off as genuine garments???

Word to the wise: Don't go here; they will rip you off, and destroy your clothes.

I've never had an experience with a business like the one I had at Rainbow Cleaners. Say what you will about your Duane Reade disasters, your Time Warner debacles, your Con Ed fiascoes; this beats all.

You see, I'm a 20-something bachelor in the great city of New York. I may not have a penthouse apartment nor a Bentley in the garage (nor a garage), but at the very least I can look like I do. I take pride in my wardrobe, however limited it might be, and I take care of my most precious numbers so they might last until I settle down, marry a trophy wife and develop the rock-hard beer gut I've so dreamed of.

Flash forward to Monday the 1st of March. I brought my three favorite shirts to get steamed and pressed at Rainbow Cleaners. Yes, it costs extra, but they are two Armani's and a Zegna -- total retail cost: $600.

I came back to pick up the shirts, saw them nicely hanging in their plastic sheen, paid and left. When I returned home, I noticed something unusual: my gray Zegna button-down now featured two new varieties of buttons. In black and brown. The remaining, factory buttons were a shiny gray color, so black and brown don't exactly match. To add insult to injury, they sewed them on improperly with thread dangling off.

My first impulse was to run down there and tear someone's head off, but I realized I should probably investigate my two Armani shirts. One was pristine. The other: NEW BUTTONS and two tears in the cuff! Not little tears either.

By this point, I was furious. I took the shirts and went back to the store to demand an explanation, a refund, and for them to fix the problem.

Imagine my surprise when they refused on ALL THREE ACCOUNTS. No refund, no explanation, and they refused to fix their own destruction.

I don't need to tell you that when a company DESTROYS something of yours, that they are responsible to fix it on their own dime. But this went beyond that. They wouldn't even take responsibility. According to them, it was not their fault. No apology. No remorse. No attempt to rectify.

Anecdotal rants aside, I realize that it will only cost about $25 and a trip to a sewing store to fix this mess. I have no delusions that this is the end of the world.

However, when a business treats me like this, I take it to the streets. While I may not burn their establishment down, I will certainly make it known that this is how the folks at Rainbow Cleaners operate.

You've been warned.

It seems a bit disheveled inside. Figured out after the fact that they send their dry cleaning out, which isn't appealing to me. Got four items done within four days, but I'll be going someplace else next time.

business.full_address:
5000 Rhode Island Ave
Hyattsville, MD 20781
business.name: Hyattsville Auto Body

reviews.text:
I have been here twice on different occasions... They nice, and took pretty good care of my ride. 

The only thing that would make this place better is more parking...

I took my WRX here after I was sandwiched on Rt 1. They fixed everything up but my trunk was soon smelling damp and musty. I assumed there was a leak but it took an independent auto-whiz to realize that they had not sealed the trunk properly down by the wheel well. Thus, I had to take it back to them and drive a pickup truck around town for four days while they took their time sealing her back up. Not a very professional shop.

I'll edit this after i get my car back, but just wanted to talk about customer service. My mom has an accent when she speaks English, so you can definitely tell that that's not her primary language. I found it offensive that the lady in the front was talking down to her as if she didn't understand what was being said. I don't even think she would listen to the end of my mom's questions and just pipe in whatever answer came to her mind. When I started talking (I guess accent-free), the lady found out I was with my mom, she became immediately nicer to my mom. Just so weird. Whatev. 
In any case, hopefully they fix cars better than they talk to customers... we shall soooon seee...

business.full_address:
Princeton Market Fai
Princeton, NJ 08540
business.name: Victoria's Secret

reviews.text:
I'm starting to realize that Victoria's Secret is kind of a nightmarish place. For some reason it's ALWAYS packed no matter where and when you go, and the brand doesn't seem to understand that writing awkward sexy things on the butt of underwear and pants is just embarrassing now (Juicy, I'm talking to you too).

I've been going to this location since high school (when writing on the butt was kind of cool... to some people) and it's always been a little bit lacking. Despite the relatively large space, there seems to be less inventory and things just seem to move slower.

I stopped in today to take advantage of the semi-annual sale and was pretty successful. Props for selection, usually there is one lone somewhat cute D amongst a sea of A cups that can do nothing for me but make me jealous, but score, this location definitely delivered.

However, it's like time slows down the second you enter this store. I waited quite a while for a fitting room. The area was empty, and I had to wander the store twice before finding an associate to open one for me, and my transaction took almost 15 minutes. The two ladies behind the counter seemed pretty new and inexperienced, but nice.

Overall, if you have some time, this Vicky's is just fine. If you're in anything resembling a hurry though (or just don't have an hour to buy a bra), you may want to hold off.

business.full_address:
1187 Amsterdam Ave
Morningside Heights
New York, NY 10027
business.name: Haakon's Hall

reviews.text:
I have a lot of experience going to Haakon's and I would recommend it for drinks, dinner (I get something different every time, but at the bar I get the wings), desert (cookies or pumpkin pie) catering or private parties (I've use both services) to anyone. Atmosphere sophisticated without the extra fee. 

The Chef is the best cook and will work with you. They stay pretty busy and Chef likes to be on the floor with his customers if he can. He is a fun and warm guy even though at first he seems stressed because he likes everyone to be perfectly happy and to feel welcome. 

I am there 3 times a week and use them for 90% of our parties. I had a Thanksgiving party and Halloween Party for 75 people each. On Halloween the party food was suppose to end at 11:00pm - James the Chef kept the food coming out until brought out new appetizers till 11:15 (unheard of anywhere in the city and without an extra charge).

For Thanksgiving we ended up having less people show up than expected and Chef made sure everyone got seconds which was amazing because the food is AWESOME.

Chef is also helping me with a fundraiser! So it's a great place, food atmosphere and people -

The day after I posted my first review of Haakon's Hall, I received a message from James (the chef/owner) apologizing profusely for the bad service we had and asking for a second chance.  The following week I went back with most of the same group and he made sure the menu item I had asked about was available, the service was friendly and attentive (a different waitress) and he even came out to personally check on us several times.  He also offered us an amuse-bouche that I didn't have but I gave my portion to the Norwegian guest at our table and he, and everyone who tasted it, thought it was delicious.

Since my original review was not based on the food but only one individual, I decided to update the review after they made sincere efforts to address their customer's complaints and provided a very positive experience on our second trip.

Came up on a Sunday evening to have dinner and play trivia.  The food was solid - but considering the price - was a steal.  Had grilled chicken over mashed potatoes and a nice selection of sauteed vegatables.  I believe that was $10.95.  Rolling Rocks were on special for $3.  Our table ended up winning the trivia and took home a half-magnum of wine.  I don't live in the area so it's a hall (sorry) but it's certainly worth checking out if you live in Morningside Heights.

A new bar/restaurant just opening where Radio Perfecto closed.  It adds a much-needed food and drink destination to that stretch of Amsterdam Avenue.  

The decor includes Norwegian flags, and the menu includes some Norwegian fare, including lingonberries.  I haven't seen the regular menu yet, but the prices on the graduation menu looked very reasonable.  

The new waiter was sincere and attentive, sweetly handing me my glass of pinot grigio to drink "before it gets cold."

This was my second visit to Haakon's Hall.  This time I brought 3 friends and we all enjoyed it. The atmosphere is so friendly and comfortable!! I had made a reservation earlier in the week so we could get one of the round booths, and that worked out great. My friends had the salmon and thought it was perfectly prepared.  I had the paella and thought it was fresh and very tasty. For dessert we had the norwegian ice cream sandwich and everyone loved it. The house wine was especially delicious. All in all a wonderful and reasonably priced evening. Cannot wait to return!
Wooooo beer and football. Yep that's what happened tonight. Good house brews. I'll be going back for food. Wooooooo. I know this isn't review of the day material but deal with it yelpverse
A staple among the Columbia grad student community. The ales are delicous as are the burgers, but the best part is the friendly staff and owner and the homely feeling you get as soon as you walk in.

Everything I have tried in Haakon Hall was really good.  From the Fries to the Watermelon and blue cheese salad.  Crab cakes were good too.  From outside, you can't tell how cozy it is inside.  My favorite restaurant in the neighborhood.

Hmmm... what does it say about a restaurant when the owner offers you a free meal after reading your less-than-favorable yelp review, you're too busy to take up the owner on his offer, then he throws wild conspiracy theories about you across the internet

I believe this place hasn't been here that long, but it's been here as long as I've been in Morningside. In fact, I walk by the place every day and always see the chef/owner? outside smoking a cigarette. I haven't exactly identified him, but each time I stop by, he's always there to make you feel welcome. The menu is pretty eclectic, including a "pantry" section serving pb&js and other simple items. Of course this scales up with some higher end entrees. So far each time I've gone, I've found something that suited my tastes and was not let down.

I like Haakon's Hall! I've only had the food there once I believe, it was a good burger and I had some of the salad that my accompaniment ordered and that was really good too. The bar is well stocked, though their drink menu is a little limited and I wish they had a few more beers on tap 
The BEST however, are the fresh baked cookies for dessert. Ooey gooey goodness.
The staff, bartenders, and owner are all very welcoming, warm, and professional. Overall a really great place and highly reccomended.

Solid 3.5
To be honest, I'm not really sure what is considered Scandinavian food besides the very stereotypical lingon berries and Swedish meatballs.  The menu consisted of a lot of comfort type foods - stuff 'in the pot', meats and potatoes smothered in sauce, fish, salads, and  roasted root veggies.  
Eating at HH tonight with the rainy weather outside was like eating in the kitchen of the house you grew up in. Comfortable, plenty of dark wood/puffy cushiony furniture, and the service was super casual.  The foodwas just straight up salty/flavorful hearty food.  The salmon salad had exceptionally crispy fresh greens and the meat patties [hamburgers in sweet/salty brown sauce] were surprisingly tasty for their kind of scary description.  One of the best things to eat was the dessert, a flaky apple turnover with ice cream and a cognac sauce.  I would go back if in the mood for this type of food - niche craving!

I've found the food at this restaurant fairly tasty on multiple occasions, and even my German girlfriend had good things to say about their Bavarian Platter.  But hey, this is New York, and a good restaurant isn't just the food, right?  My overall read on this place is that its run by people who try very hard but come up short (sorry guys, not a personal comment).

The negatives?  Well, the service needs work in a lot of ways.  

*I agree with previous posters - the bartender can come off so strange as to make the drinking experience a negative one.  I was happy to call the previous incarnation of this place my local bar, and I now avoid this one like the plague because of this very reason. 

*The waitstaff is eager but seems inexperienced.  We asked for water, we didn't get it.  Apparently my dinner came with a salad, which perhaps I should have realized, but tell me that before you bring it so I can tell you what dressing (if any) I want :).

*The owner/manager person on the scene was trying to help and failing.  Every previous interaction I've had with management at a restaurant, especially owners, is that they may stop by and very politely ask if you're enjoying your evening.  This person hovered within 10 feet and stared.  He was also dressed in a trenchcoat and I honestly thought at first it was just a crazy person!  Sorry pal!

I've been coming here for drinks for almost a year, and I've always enjoyed the atmosphere, the music, the space, and the outdoor seating. The drinks are pricey, but great beer selection. I keep coming back for their home-brewed beers, Haakon's Ale and Seasonal Ale are the best. I finally ate here the other day, and I've gotta say the burgers are phenomenal. Costly, but it's hard to find a burger like that in the bar, worth every penny.

A nice spot around columbia.
love the rotisserie chicken, very tender and lots of flavor.
tried a type of norwegian sausage with beef and lamp, no special, but like it
also tried the pork( one of the monday special, can't remember the name), love it.

it's a cozy and warm place, perfect for chatting and a drink. and they give cooking class too.

I am surprised by the negative reviews.  I go to the Hall occasionally and have never had anything but a good experience.  The staff is always friendly, the food is solid and fairly priced; the surroundings are cozy.  One Saturday afternoon a friend of mine stopped by about an hour before the kitchen opened (we did not know it started dinner at 5pm) but they opened up and fed us anyway.  I have never had a problem with the tab, either.  The beer selection is good (of course there can never be enough varieties of beer on tap to make me truly happy) and the desserts are yummy.  I went for dinner one weeknight the week before Christmas and there were several groups in there and everyone seemed be having a good time.  I would recommend you go and try it out and decide for yourself.  I however like the place, even though it's a bit out of the way for anyone other than a Columbia student or resident of Morningside Heights.

(I kind of suspect that some of the bad comments may be related to the owner's unwillingness to advertise on Yelp, it would not be the first time I heard about that.)
Good penne pasta. Generally, overpriced. $10 minimum per person in the restaurant.

Haakons has some good happy hour specials and it's a family-run place with a friendly staff.  I'm a fan of some of their home-brewed beers which are on tap for happy hour--in particular the Haakon's Hall Ale.

The restaurant is divided into two halves--a sports bar atmosphere on one side and the more sirene sit-down atmosphere on the other.

I wish I could comment on the food, but I've only ever had the fries (they're great).

Great location for any Columbia student ...outdoor seating in season.  
My menu did not look anything like what is on the website.  In fact I did not even realize it was a Norwegian restaurant...if I had I would have tried something besides a burger.  It was good.
Probably worth a trip back.

Came here last night under the delusion that I could out drink some army rangers.  (I cannot.)

This is one of the "easy access" bars near school where my friends and I often go after being mind-effed by teachers all day.  It's a very chill restaurant/bar that also serves interesting food along with classic pub grub.  One of the owners was working behind the bar last night and he was doing a good job making sure everyone was having a good time.  $4 drafts are available but the drink of choice for last night was the Haakon Special (a black and tan with a shot of whiskey).  

Always a good time.
I had the grilled cheese and tomato soup. she had the Norwegian meat patties. The food was delicious and we had a great time. I will return again.

Took my mom here for dinner and loved it!  Highly recommended

Recommendations:
Food
*I got the Kjoh-Akaker (norwegin style meat patty, simmered in red wine and aromatic veggies) absolutely delicious! for 12.50, TOTALLY WORTH IT! GET THIS!!
*I also tried the French Onion Soup, 4.50, and it was really tasty as well
*My mom tried some sort of fish assortment, and we were pleasantly surprised at the quality and quantity of the seafood.  Although I thought the white fish tasted the best.  

Ambiance and Service
*Festive, homey, and contemporary (if you can imagine those 3 adjectives together)
*Marco, our waiter, was very kind and frequently checked with us for our needs. 
*Great place to take friends visiting the Columbia area

The days are shorter, the nights are longer, the clothes are being piled on for warmth, you're staying home more often because going out is becoming a hassle with the weather a little cooler than  you'd like.

You're a busy student and maybe you're missing home cooking. 

You're a Columbia employee and are tired of having a sandwich for lunch.

Well, look no further than Haakon's Hall! A restaurant/bar that focuses on comfort food with a Norweigan twist. They even sell products for you Scandanavians. 

This restaurant is a full service establishment:  you can come by for a bite or you can stop in to learn to cook, offering such classes as "Dorm Cooking 101," "Gluten Free Cuisine" and my favorite "All-American TV Dinners." Go here. I like them and would like to see them thrive!

The negative reviews on here are rather shocking to me. Out of the three or four times I've been to Haakon's I had only pleasant experiences.

Food: The burger's here are delicious, and they actually cook them how you want them (which of course threw me o

HOT, FRESH baked cookies straight out of the oven are beyond divine.  The chocolate chip, and chocolate cookies with marshmellows hot and gooey out of the oven are hands down one of this town's best desserts.  This is their signature dessert. Served with milk- plain or chocolate these cookies are a uber comforting, delectable treat and well worth the $10 price tag.

Our second visit included one of the few Scandinavian dishes on the menu with was meat patties, cabbage stewed in wine, some veggies.
Delish!

Two nights after moving to town, my lady friend and I were walking past Haakon's Hall in search of the S.F. Giants game on TV. An employee saw us standing on the sidewalk debating whether or not to come in. He saw our Giants hats and came outside, telling us he would put the game on. Seduced by his promises, we entered, and I've been grateful every day since. 

Haakon's Hall has become my happy hour haven and my late-night lighthouse. The owner is a great dude (and a talented chef with an amazing background) who loves to shoot the $#it with his customers. His son, the namesake of the place, is usually around and is equally welcoming and cool. The bartender is the man, crackin' jokes with me every time I saddle-up. And every staff member I've met has been good folk. The food is fantastic, the vibe is legit, and that's why I call Haakon's Hall my spot. 

Great staff, delicious food, comfortable. Good times. Thank you for existing.

I have eaten here a few times (as Julian, Felicia or Andrew,aka waitstaff, might attest ). Have yet to try something i didn't like. 

Luv the baked mozzarella (stop running out!!!!)
LUV the Thanksgiving sandwich (thanks for adding it to the Lighter Fare menu).
Liked very much: the shepard's pie, the rib eye steak, the lamb, the tomato soup, 

Very reasonable prices and always greeted with a smile. 
Will continue to update as i eat more on the menu since it's only 100 feet from my job.

THIS IS PURELY TO SPECIFY FOR GLUTEN FREE ASPECT.  I give it a middle ground rating so it doesn't affect the rating overall too much.

I have not been to this restaurant but I do want to specify for the Celiac's out there that they no longer have gluten free items (except for a beer) on the menu.  I keep wanting to go here but the two times I have called the person who answered very kindly informed me that they no longer have gluten free menu items.  Burger, no bun...sure.  French Fries - no.  Put into the frier with the wings (breaded).  

While I had pleasant experiences when I have called to inquire...if you are gluten sensitive or a Celiac, don't expect to eat food here.  Enjoy a beer perhaps though!

Haakon's Hall offers a nice alternative to Amsterdam and for those of us who spend most of their waking hours within a 5-block radius of Columbia (especially the various libraries on campus) it's a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  

I've gone here a number of times for lunch/dinner or drinks and I've yet to have a very bad experience.  I've read some of the other reviews about their service and I couldn't disagree more.  All I know is that the waitresses and bartenders that I've met have been friendly and helpful - even looking into some odd requests for off-menu items or dishes without some main ingredients and usually coming through.  The last time I ate there the manager even came to ask how everything was, found out which cocktails we were having, and brought over a free round of shot-sized drinks for the whole table so we could try some of the other cocktails they offer.

As for food, the salmon with beet-risotto and french onion soup are yummy, the short-rib special is heavenly, and every dessert I've had is sinfully tasty.

I ate at Haakon's Hall within its first week.

A group of four of us went.  The two that ordered salads were very happy with their meals.  My other friend ordered veggie paella which was mediocre.  I ordered the "macaroni" of the day, which was very good, although not macaroni, rather just a pasta dish.

The decor was very nice inside, and the restaurant certainly seemed to have a lot to offer.  It has hours until 4am and has pb&j and cookies and milk, as well as free wifi, gearing towards the Columbia crowd.  

The restaurant certainly needs some work, although I will definitely give it another chance.

One of my favorite watering holes near Columbia. Great happy hour deals on tap beer, and the bartenders are super-nice. The food is excellent, too- my favorites are the burger and the TV dinner (especially when they do Thanksgiving dinner). 

My one complaint is the $10 minimum for credit/debit cards- when a happy hour beer is under $3, and when you're not in the habit of carrying cash, it can be a little inconvenient. That being said, this place is pretty great- just bring cash or be prepared to drink a lot :)

Food is great and ESPECIALLY the bartender Mel is the BEST!

Try it out.

After a long wait, Haakon's Hall is finally opened.  It had been under renovation for all of last year.  All of us Columbia-SIPA students were waiting intently.  

Had the Thursday TV dinner here (Turkey "and all the trimmings").  The variety was excellent  (mash potatoes, stuffing, berry sauce, salad, etc).  They only had turkey breast though; I prefer dark meat.  Service was good.  I didn't get much gravy with the turkey and the waiter was more than happy to get me extra.  

My friend got the burger, which was a shake shack burger.  This is one of the few places that have exclusives to the shake shack burger.  It was nicely done and the fries were perfect.  

The dessert was awesome.  We got the Norwegian ice cream cake, the peach cobbler and the gluten free chocolate cake.  The Norwegian ice cream cake was amazing.  Waffles beautifully done with chocolate ice cream and Norwegian lingonberries.  Every bite was delicious.  The peach cobbler is simply classic.  Nice and warm with a crunchy top.  

The chocolate cake was AMAZING.  As the owner said, "how can something good for you (gluten free) taste so good?"  Apparently the owner's sister was the mastermind behind it for her kid.  It took her 20 tries to get it, but man did she get it!  The cake was nice and soft and the chocolate is dark... almost like a soufflé.  

Apparently they also do a Norwegian brunch.  So we'll have to go back and try that sometime.  Very happy to have them so close to campus!

Had no idea this was Norwegian food....I had a good solid burger that was the size of my head (that came with delicious fries) and my friend enjoyed his chicken pot pie thoroughly. 

Note: don't walk through the floor/ceiling open windows thinking it's a door. I did.

Just got back from brunch at this place. Right near Columbia (literally across the street from university buildings), I was surprised to see it not as busy as expected. Walked in, got a table and service right away, and felt comfortable immediately.

Drinks for brunch (Sundays 11a-4p) are half-off at the moment.. Bloody Marys for $3, Bellinis for $3.50. No reduction in quality, simply for the half-off price, either!

As far as food goes, I had an "Omelet of the Gods," which had tomatoes, olives, and avocado, topped with a delicious champagne cream sauce. Served with wheat toast, delicious potatoes, and a fruit-skewer garnish. Perfectly filling, delicious to the gills.

My brother, who was visiting from New Hampshire, had the Eggs Benedict, Scandinavian-style (with smoked salmon), and he said it was really excellent. Served with a side of potatoes and topped with very well-done Hollandaise sauce.

All-told, for two people, with two cocktails each and two entrees, the bill was $38. Well done! Will definitely come back for non-brunch food sometime in the future.

I love this place. I haven't tried the food (but I plan on it) but I had an event there last night and the staff, managers and owner were all amazing and gracious. Organizing an event for 100+ people is never easy especially when you are on a budget as tight as mine and the managers and staff really made it possible (every other place in the neighborhood turned me down). They definitely have a loyal customer in me after how accommodating they were!

More specifically, the bartenders were fast and the drinks were strong (especially for an open bar situation!) and the owner was around all night to make sure we were taken care of. All of the guests raved about how happy they were with the space.

I came back to this place the other day. I'm not sure if my review's legit because I was really sick when I revisited. I'm not sure if it was me or if it was the heavy greasy a little bland food, but I felt a little nauseous afterwards =T

It's easy to walk past this new restaurant, but don't.  You're not going anywhere.  

I've only been there once, so here are my first impressions.  No one was there at dinner time (7:15-ish?).  Just me and my date after happy hour at 106.  I had noticed this new Norwegian place on Google Earth the day before.  Their website gives a pretty good idea of their approach to the restaurant, with an almost bizarre care to homey detail that you Just Don't Find in the City.

Service was OK, still getting started, still a little fresh (so the timing isn't perfect yet), but no complaints.  

They do food right.  My date got a dish with two kinds of sausage and a ham steak -- I think it was their In the Pot special of the day, but it keeps changing, so I can't say for sure.  Came with onions and mashed potatoes, if I remember right.  I got the Norwegian dish "Kjoh-Akaker," which is meat patties, lingonberries, and veggies & potatoes.  Perfect, comforting food.

We shared the milk & cookies for dessert.  Took half the cookies home (it's enough for three or four people... or two people if all you're eating is cookies and milk).  These were very hot when they came, and they must have been cooked at a pretty high temp, because the outside was crumbly and the inside was not cooked all the way through -- in other words, the cookies were ******* delicious.

By the time we left, the place was hopping, but almost entirely with drinkers, not eaters.  That's too bad.  I am curious about their ale, though.

Looking forward to going back!

I am really looking forward to dinning here officially in the up-coming weeks. So far I have been chilling at the bar - but they have a great selection of beers, and there service is great. We did sample their fries with blue cheese crumbles and red pepper flakes -- and that was d-lish! 

Looking at the menu - it seems a little random, but I am looking forward to trying a few dishes out. Overall a very promising addition to the neighborhood.

Surrounded by subtlety, they exercise none; their e-letter arrived in all caps, obnoxious size 72 font. Echoing Sarah J., it's pathetic; no, James, Yelp had nothing to do with my honest denouncement. Stop bothering me ("Hi, what did I do to piss you off").

UPDATE: Received 2 virtually identical e-mails (in characteristic obnoxiously enormous font) for their 11:30-6:30 Easter "dinner". One would've been too much. SCRATCH THAT...4 in an hour...2 originals + 2 duplicates, the latter 2 of which were in hot pink & vomit yellow discussing a Spring Fling.

ANOTHER UPDATE: The e-mails keep pouring in, and my name isn't Danny. Respect your customers, and realize that not all press is good press. You deserve everything that's happened to you with the way you handle all these situations.

Following some well-deserved Eater infamy, a delightful PM arrives:

OK BUDDY
You don't even have the guts to come and speak to Haakon or Me personally.

Anddd another:

Danny can we invite you to the restaurant so I can offer you a cup of shut the f*ck up jerkoff

The microbrews are pretty good, as are the burgers(LaFrieda). I was hoping for something a little more Norwegian, given the name, but I think the proximity to Columbia precludes that sort of architecture, and it certainly precludes that sort of mead fueled bloodlust. Back to the boats! We'll have to have our bar fights somewhere else. But if you're looking to lounge somewhere in Morningside without paying through the nose, this isn't a bad place for it.

I got the small platter from the Oktoberfest menu.  I chose knockwurst and it came served with sauteed onions in some kind of dark red sauce (caramelized?), mashed potatoes, boiled carrots, and a tiny plastic cup of apple sauce.
The food was solidly tasty, though I think the knockwurst was overly soft.
I'd probably order it again.

But I'm not so sure I'd come back here for food anyway.  Despite sitting at a table for about a half hour, no one came to ask for my order.  I'm not sure if this is, because there is a "restaurant" side to the place and a "bar" side- nevertheless, this is not clearly marked anywhere.
So yeah- I had to eventually walk over to a man who worked there to place my order and paid while standing up at the register.
I will say that the guy who charged me was a good guy though, as he could have ripped me off, but didn't!  I originally ordered a Boddingtons but changed it to a Bitburger.  The Boddingtons was more money and he accidentally charged me for a Boddingtons.  I didn't even notice that I signed for a more expensive bill.  Luckily the guy had some morals!

I'm not sure about the hours at this place.  It seems to have a lunch menu on its website, but it wasn't open for lunch when I went around January, claiming to be closed for lunch during the "winter season."  

Anyhow, in memory of Radio Perfecto, we decided to attempt dinner.  We were pleasantly surprised by the quality of their food, especially for Morningside Heights.  My salmon was nicely seasoned and cooked, with a delicious roasted beet risotto that perfectly complemented the fish.  My bf's pork tenderloin was also nice and moist, though a bit too sweet for my taste.  Their dinner rolls were also good (bread baskets are key to a good first impression).  

I didn't see any problems with the service here, but maybe I went on a good night.  I thought the place had a nice ambiance, both quarky and old school - which reflects the style of food at this place.  In any case, this place is way better than Amsterdam Cafe next door and I would definitely give it a try if you're in the area.

They don't have as many Norwegian items on the menu.  They have revised the menu to be more bar-like. We met the first owner, who was very nice and interesting. We had the sangria and cucumber martinis, both of which were excellent.

I love this place!  Which is good, since it's my new local.  Haakon's Hall has a pretty nondescript facade and while there is nothing incredibly unique about the decor, it just "clicks" for me.  First time I was there, my girlfriend and I were intrigued by the "milk and cookies" desert--which was beyond amazing.  You might say that $8 is steep for an order of cookies, but these were five cookies (three different varieties) baked to order and they were so rich that we couldn't finish more than two.  We took the remainder home and snacked on them for the next couple of days.

Over the past couple of months I have been back a few times for drinks--it's a great place to grab a beer, or two, or three.  Bartenders are really friendly.

After our experience there in January, the owner/chef contacted us. He'd read the review here on Yelp and wanted a chance to make amends.
It's good to know that James reads these things - something others have noted on here as well.
Anyway, he offered us a free table for two at their Valentine's Day special. Gluten free the whole way.
He gave us very personal service, comped a bottle of wine, and provided some excellent food. The chocolate pasta with pork ragout was outstanding and my glutard wife loved her oversized deconstructed salad platter.
It was a return to the positive experiences we'd had at Haakon's earlier in '09, and we're back to being fans!

After a less than amazing first experience at Haakon's Hall, I gave it another shot at the owners insistence.  If you read through the reviews you will see that he is super active on yelp so I'll give him points for caring.  
I'm happy to say that my second experience was much better than my first.  The food was extremely tasty.  We decided to order exclusively from the Norwegian side of the menu and I think that was a good decision.  Fish and meat were both well cooked, the flavors were well balanced and original, and even though everything had a unique taste to it... it somehow still felt like comfort food, so pretty ideal on a rainy Sunday.  If all you care about is getting some tasty Norwegian food then Haakon's Hall has you covered.
The service, is really mediocre at best.  After we ordered bread plates were brought out... then after our food arrived I heard one waiter say to the other "aren't you going to bring them bread?" and suddenly our bread arrived.  The service throughout the meal had that sort of "we are still getting the hang of this" feel, which is part of why I would rate this 3 instead of 4 stars.  I'll probably go back in the future to see if they have worked all of the kinks out. 
The draught selection is also really unfortunate.  I'm not sure if I should call myself a beer snob... I brew my own, I love going to beer bars and trying new beers, and I spend a lot of time hating on macrobrews... so maybe I am more of a beer asshole.  With its big bar, its super convenient location, and cheap draughts, HH would be a great place to drag coworkers for happy hour... but the draught list is a mine field of average beers (Rolling Rock, Stella, Blue Moon, Becks, Guinness... you get the idea) with only two house beers to cut through the mess.  I would love to see someone who cares about beer step up and help this place out.  
Finally, this doesn't really effect the review, but I wish they would create an offering for the take out lunch crowd.  I don't know anything about running a restaurant but it seems like they are missing out on a major income source by not offering some sort of food option for the usual $7-$9 take out during lunch.  

So, in a city where too often great places go down hill, it looks like HH may actually be getting better.  Good, original, food makes for a great base to build on, but its still 3 stars until I go back and see if all the kinks have been worked out.
Classic Columbia hangout  - we always end up having a great time here.

I would really give Haakon's Hall 3 1/2 stars but that wasn't an option and so I bumped them up a little bit.

I came here with my friend for lunch and we had a good experience. I ordered the burger which came with fries and their coleslaw. The fries and coleslaw were amazing, the burger was just okay.

My friend got their bento box lunch special, which came with vegetarian lasagna, salad, garlic bread and chocolate cake with whipped cream. All for $9.95. What an amazing deal. She said the lasagna and the salad were great. The chocolate cake was just okay.

Other diners complained abt the service, but they seem to have changed it up now. You order at a counter and pay and then they call your name when your food is ready and you go and pick it up. If you are looking for a fine dinning experience this is not the place to come, but if you don't mind serving yourself it is cool.

Overall, Hakkon's Hall was a good experience and everyone who worked there seemed nice enough to me.

Community Food and Juice meets IKEA (in a good way) at this vibrant and charming Morningside Heights spot. Fresh and tasty food, attentive service, and affordable prices make Haakon's Hall a welcome addition to the Columbia neighborhood. Kudos to the kitchen for a great meal! 

(1) Comparison to CFJ: Fresh comfort food (including warm cookies and milk), warm ambiance, a communal dining table, and loud; however, presentation is more homey and less artisanal than CFJ and unlike CFJ, Haakon's ingredients lack the imprimatur of eco-friendliness. 

(2) Similarities to IKEA's cafeteria (no offense intended - I like IKEA's cafeteria; also, my apologies to Scandinavians for this admittedly ignorant comparison): They serve Scandinavian-inspired food (see lingonberries below - sorry, where else can you get lingonberries!?), charge affordable prices for large servings of food, and offer a sufficiently diverse menu.

(3) Food: I ordered the Amish rotisserie half chicken half (~$9.50); the chicken was flavorful and mostly tender (the breast meat was a bit dry, but far superior to Tom's limbless chicken special, see http://www.yelp.com/biz/toms-restaurant-new-york#hrid:mxJQ-oUQ38QPHnMjNxQ-_Q); the side dishes (mashed potatoes and roasted vegetables) were very good. My wife ordered the Norwegian meat patties and sauteed vegetables ($13.50), which came with a fresh green salad with tomatoes in a light dressing, a side of lingonberry sauce, toasted bread, and a piece of cannoli. The patties were flavorful and tender and the sides were also tasty. For dessert, I could not resist the warm plate of cookies and cold milk ($8). They did not disappoint: the five large  homemade cookies were warm, gooey, and delicious (2 chocolate chip + 3 fudge with white chocolate chips). I think I've found my neighborhood alternative to Specialty's warm chocolate chip cookies (http://www.yelp.com/biz/specialtys-cafe-and-bakery-san-francisco-12#hrid:R05FSWWymz5gAL14zRfz8Q).    

(4) Service: Attentive and earnest, but a bit uneven. I had to order dessert twice and ask for the check twice.  

(5) Price: We left satisfied and stuffed, having consumed two entrees and dessert for $40, including tax and tip - a great deal.

Haakon's Hall food is unique and the atmosphere is relaxed and fun.   They have a gluten free menu, including bread, pizzas, pastas, and desserts.  Just speak to the chef so that they are aware of your allergy!

I've had good and bad experiences at this restaurant, but no matter what, the chef is available.  This restaurant is like no other in Manhattan and I will be sure to return many times!
